title: Transfer Deadline: Dempsey Heads to Spurs
description: United States forward Clint Dempsey secured his move away from Fulham in the final hours of the transfer window on Friday, signing a three-year contract with Tottenham Hotspur that will keep him in Englands Premier League.

title: Pakistans Premier Televangelist
description: Aamir Liaquat Hussain is a broadcasting sensation and a contentious figure.

title: Way Cleared for November Vote in Texas
description: A federal three-judge panel in San Antonio ruled on Friday that the November elections in Texas would proceed, ending uncertainty about whether a Washington courts earlier ruling would delay the elections.

title: View at Practice Courts an Intimate but Possibly Endangered Perk
description: When Sandra Unger heard that Roger Federer was headed to the practice courts at the United States Open, she immediately texted her sister Laurie McLeod, who was having lunch at the food court.

title: Debt Collector Misled Borrowers, Court Says
description: For borrowers struggling to pay off their student loans, getting rid of the debt in bankruptcy is difficult because they need to convince a judge that it constitutes an undue hardship.

title: Republicans, in Search of a Foreign Policy
description: Washington

title: Cardinal Carlo Martini, Papal Contender, Dies at 85
description: ROME  Cardinal Carlo Maria Martini, one of the Roman Catholic Churchs most influential progressive thinkers, who once was considered as a possible successor to Pope John Paul II, died in a Jesuit retreat near Milan on Friday. He was 85.

title: Rushing to See Roddick, If Not to Praise Him
description: When Andy Roddick announced his impending retirement Thursday, Ann Morrissey texted Lisa ONeil: Turn on the Roddick press conference.

title: Feline Film Festival
description: Thousands of cat lovers and cineastes gathered at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis to celebrate the Internet sensation that is cat videos.

title: Only the Good Get Rich
description: As the Republican convention fades into oblivion, the one thing everybody is still talking about is, of course, the party platform.

title: The G.O.P. Fact Vacuum
description: Tampa, Fla.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: The Occupy Wall Street protest in Hong Kong ignored a deadline to leave HSBCs headquarters, European leaders worked again to reassure investors on the debt crisis and Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chief, committed to aiding the economy.

title: Aug. 31: TV Ratings May Be Leading Indicator of Convention Bounce
description: It remains too early to tell exactly what effect the Republican National Convention has had on the polls. But television ratings are one measure that come in almost instantaneously. Ratings for the final two nights of the Republican convention were down quite a bit from 2008, declining by about 30 percent overall.

title: Giving to a Newborns College Savings Plan
description: The best gift any of us can give to newborn babies is to point their sleep-deprived parents in the direction of a good 529 or other college savings plan and then seed the account with a little bit of money.

title: A Superstar Televangelist in Pakistan Divides, Then Repents
description: KARACHI, Pakistan

title: Families Bond Is Severed as Blood Spills
description: This is the story of two modest, crowded apartments in two buildings in the Tompkins Houses in Brooklyn: 5C at 65 Tompkins Avenue; and around the corner and 10 stories higher, 15G at 919 Myrtle Avenue. The Hartley family lives in one, the Mann family in the other. They share a timeline that spans 30 years.

title: Trying to Recapture Normal at Penn State
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  This year, more than most, felt like a long overdue reunion: Penn State students converging, the professors awaiting, all savoring their own slice of normalcy.

title: Sex Charges Cast a Pall on a College Town
description: MISSOULA, Mont.  Students are back in their classrooms this week, the heat of summer has cooled and new chalk lines have been placed on the football field as the University of Montana Grizzlies and their devoted fans prepare for the opening kickoff on Saturday.

title: Risky and Getting Riskier
description: Just what grandpa needed. Soon retirees and other investors will be barraged with advertisements for private stock offerings  via mail, cold calling, television, radio, billboards, the Internet and so on.

title: Facebook Plays It Safe
description: I read with some amusement the news that Facebook had brought on the architect Frank Gehry to design an expansion to its Menlo Park, Calif., headquarters. Or more specifically, a new warehouse for engineers at its Menlo Park headquarters. Plans for the Silicon Valley site include a 420,000-square-foot, single-story warehouse topped with a garden that will span the entire roof. A tunnel will connect Facebook East to the companys existing headquarters in the former space of Sun Microsystems, whose more hierarchical floor plan has been demolished to make way for Facebooks open-plan ethos. (As one British blog so delicately put it, Facebook moves into Sun Microsystems carcass.)

title: Cleaner Cars, a Safer Planet
description: The federal automobile efficiency standards announced this week are an important step on Americas path to a lower-carbon and more-secure energy future. They are expected to yield multiple benefits: reduced dependence on foreign oil, fewer greenhouse gas emissions, consumer savings at the pump and a more competitive auto industry. They may also serve as proof that well-tailored government regulation can achieve positive results and that consensus among old enemies  in this case environmentalists and the car companies  is possible even at a time of partisan discord.

title: Campaigns Play Loose With Truth in a Fact-Check Age
description: In his very first television advertisement last year, Mitt Romney highlighted the nations dire unemployment crisis, its record number of home foreclosures and the rising national debt, and showed video of President Obama delivering this arresting remark: If we keep talking about the economy, were going to lose.

title: Why College Money Is the Best Baby Gift
description: This weeks Your Money column about the ins and outs of giving money as a gift to someones 529 college savings account wasnt meant to be an etiquette lesson. But I do think giving money is totally defensible, even if it means pushing the parents to open a 529 or other savings account to use the gift.

title: Rage by Miners Points to Shift in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG  When 360,000 gold and coal miners walked off the job in South Africa in 1987, protesting the poor pay and grim working conditions of apartheid-era mines, a charismatic young man named Cyril Ramaphosa, the firebrand leader of the National Union of Mineworkers, led the charge.

title: Romney Shows Support in Storm-Battered Bayou
description: KENNER, La.  Mitt Romney on Friday used the first day since accepting his partys nomination for president to tour hurricane-ravaged regions of the Louisiana bayou, a visit that seemed intended to convey an unmistakable air of presidential authority.

title: Lottery Numbers
Woods Finds a Groove and Stays There
description: NORTON, Mass.  What the butterfly effect is to science, the Tiger effect is to golf. On Friday, a 6-inch putt rolled in the hole at No. 5 and caused a commotion between the 9th and 10th holes at T.P.C. Boston. The roar that punctuated Tiger Woodss eighth birdie of his morning round of the Deutsche Bank Championship prompted a mass dash to the front nine by fans wanting to catch a glimpse of the new old Woods.

title: A Fight Over Spending in New York State
description: Twice in August, judges declared unconstitutional or otherwise rejected state laws because, they said, the laws ran afoul of a provision in the New York State Constitution known as home rule. Both decisions involved transportation, and both could cost the public a lot of money: New York City in one case; the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in the other.

title: Suits That Accused Sloan-Kettering Chief of Stealing Research Are Settled
description: Two lawsuits that accused the president of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center of absconding with groundbreaking research from the University of Pennsylvania to start a biotechnology company have been settled.

title: Mexico: Drug Gang Suspect Extradited to the U.S.
description: A 20-year investigation into one of Mexicos largest drug trafficking organizations came to a close Friday with the extradition of Eduardo Arellano-Flix, a top operative of the gang, to San Diego. After exhausting his legal appeals in Mexico, he will face a variety of charges, including racketeering and money laundering, in a United States court. The Mexican government sent Mr. Arellano-Flix, a capo in the Arellano-Flix organization led by his family members, to the United States more than four years after his arrest following a shootout with Mexican police. His brothers are already serving long sentences in the United States, and the Drug Enforcement Administration contends that the gang has largely been crippled, though several others have taken its place as top suppliers of cocaine and marijuana to the United States. Still, Lanny A. Breuer, a Justice Department official, called the extradition a milestone in our fight against the Mexican drug cartels.

title: The Bullet That Changed History
description: It was late afternoon on Aug. 30, 1862, the concluding day of the Second Battle of Bull Run, and the largest simultaneous massed assault of the Civil War was about to be unleashed. The Confederate general James Longstreets corps was in position on the left flank of the Union general John Popes unsuspecting Army of Virginia, and when the signal was given 25,000 Rebels surged forward, catching the surprised Federals in an immense hammer on anvil movement.

title: New York City to Pay in Another Prisoner Suit
description: New York City will pay $850,000 to settle a lawsuit stemming from the beating of an inmate at Rikers Island that fit a rogue disciplinary pattern cited by law enforcement officials in which favored prisoners, in a system known as the Program, received tacit approval to keep order by assaulting and threatening other prisoners.

title: Outfielder, Like Team, Detoured To Success
description: At the start of this season, Lew Ford, five years removed from his last stint in the majors, had a single goal: to bring a championship trophy to Central Islip, N.Y., the home of the Long Island Ducks of the independent Atlantic League of Professional Baseball.

title: The Ice Pick Seems Antiquated, but It Still Shows Up on the Police Blotter
description: The young man staggered down a city street as blood flowed from a puncture wound. The weapon used in the steely attack  an ice pick  was sticking out of his lower back.

title: A Killing on a Brooklyn Block Known for Its Violence
description: The morning after his mother was killed in Brooklyn, Chinnarie Gordon, 5, took his grandmothers hand and walked to Parkside Playground. As his cousins played in the fountains, Chinnarie climbed up to a checkers table and began drawing a picture of his mother in blue chalk, giving her long blue hair and a mermaids tail.

title: Mainstreaming Efforts Praised in Schools Study
description: A study released on Friday said that the New York City Department of Education had done a good job of preparing for significant special education reforms that will begin in earnest next week, but it expressed concerns about whether schools had enough money and teachers had enough training to carry out the changes.

title: Its Roddicks Opponent Bowing Out
description: As if it were not enough to have to face Andy Roddick the day after he announced his retirement, Bernard Tomic had a tough act to follow even entering Arthur Ashe Stadium on Friday night. The stadium lights were not yet on, but Roddicks enormous face glowed from a video montage with clips of his electric serve and equally electric smile.

title: Mercurys Core
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  I am of two minds about todays puzzle, by Tim Croce.

title: Federal Judge in Ohio Restores Early Voting
description: A federal judge in Ohio on Friday ordered the state to give all voters the right to cast their ballots in person on the final three days before Election Day.

title: A New Guide to the Democratic Herd
description: A look at the major blocs of the Democratic Party going into the 2012 election.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Aviation History

title: Giants Terrell Thomas Will Miss Another Season
description: Giants cornerback Terrell Thomas will miss a second consecutive season after the team placed him on injured reserve Friday because of a knee injury. Earlier in training camp, he aggravated the right knee that cost him the 2011 season with a torn anterior cruciate ligament.

title: Student Reviews of Introduction to Congress
description: Online evaluations of the Harvard class taught by Matthew B. Platt reflect largely scathing opinions of the course. Nearly half of the 279 students enrolled in the spring class were accused of cheating.

title: An Easier Way to Find Adult Classes
description: My girlfriend is a teacher and a graduate student, and every year around this time, I get a pang of nostalgia for the school life as she runs around buying new notebooks and checking class schedules while I prepare for another day at the office.

title: Harvard Students in Cheating Scandal Say Collaboration Was Accepted
description: Harvard students suspected in a major cheating scandal said on Friday that many of the accusations are based on innocent  or at least tolerated  collaboration among students, and with help from graduate-student teachers who sometimes gave them answers to test questions.

title: Giving the Yankees Reason for Pause
description: A few starts ago, Hiroki Kuroda threw a seven-inning shutout in a rain-shortened victory over the Toronto Blue Jays. The win, on July 18, increased the Yankees lead in the American League East to a whopping 10 games. The margin has been slashed to two, in part, by a rash of injuries and inconsistent performances.

title: Pro Medium Repents for Life of Cons
description: Dont mistake Mark Edward for John Edward. The two men, who are not related, are both professional mediums, men who charge money for their supposed skill at transmitting messages from the dead. But whereas John Edward had a nationally syndicated television show and still plays to large crowds in Las Vegas and across the country, Mark Edwards biggest gigs were a baby shower at Eddie Murphys house and Buddy Hacketts 70th birthday party.

title: Striking a Work-Life Balance
description: Sara Horowitz, 49, the founder of the Freelancers Union, has a commitment to workers rights that runs several generations deep: her paternal grandfather was vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, and her father was a union lawyer. She received a MacArthur Fellowship in 1999. Ms. Horowitz, who grew up in Brooklyn Heights, lives in a brownstone in Park Slope with her husband, Peter DeChiara, 47, a lawyer whose firm represents unions, and their daughter, Rachel, 12. Like many of the freelancers whose champion she has become, she mixes work and home life on Sundays.

title: Dickey Blanks Marlins for 17th Win
description: MIAMI  The Mets have been anything but a certainty this season, except perhaps when they send R. A. Dickey to the mound against the Miami Marlins.

title: Old Friends and Oysters
description: When the wife-and-husband team of Jennifer and Shane Covey opened their 28-seat East Village restaurant, Upstate, last July, the concept was monkishly minimal: beer and oysters. Were relatively uncomplicated people, Ms. Covey said, though she also said her husband used three types of beer glasses at home. Not that more complicated people have found a better way to salute a late summer sunset. The Coveys have since added a few cooked dishes, some wine and free slices of Ms. Coveys whiskey cake, but it is still the original pairing that brings the customers in  some calling it a light dinner, others pre-dinner ballast, an evening equivalent of elevenses. The dcor is spare, and the menu would almost fit in a Twitter post. From 5 to 7 p.m., you get a beer and six oysters for $12. One evening at the end of August, a crowd waited on the sidewalk for seats to open up. Inside, the early birds slurped and slugged. Were oyster happy hours everywhere this summer? Yes, they were. What took them so long?

title: 2 Campaigns Differ Sharply on Medicaid, Seeking Vast Growth or Vast Cuts
description: The way Mitt Romney and Representative Paul D. Ryan frame it, the debate over social programs that has become a dominant theme of the presidential race is all about the future of Medicare, the government health insurance program for retirees.

title: Weapons Plant Security Issues Are Described in U.S. Audit
description: WASHINGTON  The contractors in charge of guarding the national stockpile of bomb-grade uranium in Tennessee knew well before an 82-year-old nun and two other pacifists broke through three barriers this summer that a lot of the security equipment was broken, and government managers knew it too, according to an internal audit of Energy Department operations at the weapons facility. The inspector generals investigation found troubling displays of ineptitude.

title: As a Catalog of Pain Shows, She Isnt Riding Just for Show
description: NORTH SALEM, N.Y.  Georgina Bloomberg, 29, the younger daughter of New Yorks mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, practiced in a white T-shirt and dark helmet, jumping her bay mare Radio City over imposing panels and open water in a grass field at her farm here.

title: Guiding Golfers to Rock Their Shots
description: TO find the head professional at the Marine Park Golf Course in Brooklyn, look for a flamboyant outfit of plaids and pastels, and follow the smoke.

title: Tipsarevic Beats Baker at Own Game
description: Janko Tipsarevic, the eighth seed from Serbia, outplayed Brian Baker on Friday, winning, 6-4, 6-3, 6-4, to advance to the third round of the United States Open. Tipsarevic used his superior movement to thwart Baker, who struggled to return his serve, especially his accurate, deceptive second delivery. By contrast, Tipsarevic broke Baker five times, including the final game, when Baker had a chance to draw even late in the third set.

title: First Death Is Reported From New Pig Flu Strain
description: The first human death from a new strain of pig flu was reported Friday by state health officials in Ohio.

title: Ryans Budget Proposal Is Pitting G.O.P. Troops Against Top of the Ticket
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Even as Mitt Romney and Representative Paul D. Ryan exhort Republicans to embrace their proposed Medicare changes and spending cuts, the partys rank and file is growing less enthusiastic about the fight than the top of the ticket.

title: At Paralympics, First Thing Judged Is Disability
description: LONDON  Anthony Dawson, who has cerebral palsy and little muscle function on his right side, rode for South Africa in the first round of the equestrian dressage competition at the Paralympics on Thursday, guiding his horse through an intricately choreographed series of movements.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Too Busy or Just Too Tired, Some Floridians Paid Convention Little Mind
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Kaye Collie really wanted to pay attention to the last night of the Republican National Convention, particularly the big moment when the nominee, Mitt Romney, would step out on the huge stage in Tampa, Fla., and make the speech of his lifetime.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Far From Action but Right at Home
description: From where Denise Starr was playing on practice court No. 13, she could see the upper reaches of Arthur Ashe Stadium, and hear the roars of the crowd during Novak Djokovics victory over Rogerio Dutra Silva there. Or perhaps it was the cheers coming from Louis Armstrong as Laura Robson beat Li Na.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Inquiry Finds No Misdeeds by Sheriff in Arizona
description: PHOENIX  The United States attorneys office announced on Friday that it had closed an investigation over abuse-of-power allegations against Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County, some of his current and former employees, and the former Maricopa County attorney, concluding that none of them had done anything wrong.

title: A History of New York in 50 Objects
description: An artichoke and an elevator. A Checker taxicab and a conductors baton. A MetroCard and a mastodon tusk. From ancient artifacts to common everyday accessories, which objects tell the story of New York City?

title: Who Will Be the Next in Line to Replace Roddick?
description: Within hours of Andy Roddicks announcement on Thursday that he would retire after the United States Open, the focus of American tennis turned to the next generation.

title: Jets Trim Roster as Season Opener Nears
description: The Jets cut three draft selections: receiver Jordan White, running back Terrance Ganaway and offensive lineman Robert Griffin.

title: Teenager Dies After Sticking Head Through Bus Hatch and Striking Underpass
description: A teenager was killed when he popped his head out of a rooftop hatch on a double-decker bus and struck an underpass near the George Washington Bridge on Friday night, an official at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.

title: Corrections: September 1, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Breathing Life Into a Dead Language
description: LONDON  It seems that Latin is a dead language that refuses to lie down.

title: What I Saw at the Republican Convention
description: The outcome of American elections affect the entire world  yet most people outside the United States (and many inside) dont understand American politics. In an effort to bring greater understanding to the process, the politics, the personalities and the policies, The New York Times, for the first time, livestreamed coverage from the Republican National Convention. I was one of the anchors of that coverage.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Recent amendments to the Right to Information Act of 2010 have weakened the State Information Commission, a watchdog agency tasked with safeguarding the laws provisions, Hindustan Times reported. Civic groups and opposition politicians criticized the changes; the chief information commissioner, G.R. Sufi, accused the state government of trying to make the commission a toothless body.

title: The Weekend Word: Political Theater
description: Todays Times

title: How Greek Taxpayers Hide 11 Billion Euros a Year
description: After a brief summer holiday, the euro crisis is back. Adam Davidsons latest columnpreviews seven dramas coming to the Euro zone this fall. As usual, things begin with Greece, which has to cut its budget by an additional 11.5 billion euros in order to secure the next round of debt relief. In a surprising twist, that may be the exact amount of money that Greece loses from tax evaders each year.

title: In Vietnam, Message of Equality Is Challenged by Widening Wealth Gap
description: HANOI, Vietnam  She wore a pink outfit and matching high heels as she toured the dusty construction site. Soon after To Linh Huongs visit in April, photos that captured the moment went viral on the Internet, but not because of Ms. Huongs sense of style.

title: Three Hours, Four Hours, Whatever
description: Ahem. (Via Mark Thoma, who has more).

title: What to Watch on Saturday
description: Down a set and trailing 3-2 in her second round match Thursday, nothing seemed to work for Sloane Stephens. Her first serve was off, her forehand shaky. Tatjana Maleks route to victory seemed easy enough: Keep balls in play and wait for the inevitable miss.

title: Woodford on Monetary Policy (Sort of Wonkish)
description: Im not in Jackson Hole  actually, I appear to have been blackballed for a long time, probably because I had the temerity to criticize the great Greenspan before it was fashionable. No matter. I can still read the papers  and the most important one was by Mike Woodford (pdf).

title: Live Updates: First Saturday
description: The stars have aligned for the first Saturday of the college football season. Paul Myerberg is in Manhattan. Tim Rohan is in Happy Valley to watch Penn State host Ohio. Later tonight, Tom Spousta will be in Arlington, Tex., to provide feedback on Alabamas date with Michigan. Keep close tabs throughout the day for updates and analysis.

title: A Brief History of Timelines
description: 385 million B.C. During the Middle Devonian Period of the Paleozoic Era, a prehistoric fern adds a new growth ring to its trunk, creating the worlds first timeline. A trilobite third-grade teacher immediately assigns it to her class as busywork.

title: Alice Waters
description: A pioneer in the organic, locally grown and slow-food movements, Alice Waters is a chef, cookbook author and owner of Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif.

title: Angolas Governing Party and Its President Are Poised to Win Election
description: LUANDA, Angola  Angolas governing party was poised on Saturday to sweep parliamentary elections, winning a landslide victory that would ensure President Jos Eduardo dos Santos a five-year extension to his 33 years at the countrys helm.

title: N.F.C. South Preview: Saints, Stained by Scandal, Have Staying Power
description: Player to Watch Its possible that no quarterback has had to shoulder as much as the Saints Drew Brees will this season with Coach Sean Payton suspended and the interim coach Joe Vitt benched for the first six games.

title: A.F.C. South Preview: Houston Is in Line to Win Division, and Maybe More
description: Player to Watch The Colts may not go far this season, but follow quarterback Andrew Luck anyway. Were probably going to be watching him win for a long time.

title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  At one point in the not-too-distant past, I was critical of the Puns and Anagrams puzzles because I thought they were too easy. I had compared them in my mind to the cryptics we work on occasion, and perhaps that was my mistake. Perhaps I was feeling cranky that day.

title: Excluded From Inclusion
description: Tampa, Fla.

title: The U.S. Open Chronicles: A Loss, but Its Cool
description: Irina Falconi, who is playing at the United States Open this year, will write posts throughout the tournament for Straight Sets. She has her own tumblr page, and can be followed on Twitter.

title: Bombers Strike Outside U.S. Military Base in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Taliban suicide bombers staged what appeared to be a carefully coordinated attack southwest of Kabul on Saturday that killed at least a dozen Afghans and wounded 58 more just outside the same American military outpost where a similar attack one year ago wounded scores of American soldiers.

title: Californias Willful Disobedience
description: Last year the Supreme Court took the extraordinary step of ordering California to reduce the dangerous overcrowding in its prisons. The state had challenged an earlier ruling requiring it to meet a specific limit on the number of state prisoners. The court firmly rejected that challenge.

title: Nets Show Interest in Blatche
description: The Nets ongoing search for frontcourt depth has led them to Houston and a meeting with Andray Blatche, who was cut this summer by the Washington Wizards.

title: Franklin Delano Romney
description: THE last time the United States held a presidential election amid the mass unemployment left in a financial crisiss wake, the challenger offered only a partial glimpse of what he would actually do in office. Mostly, he played the opportunist, attacking the incumbent party for spending too much and helping too little, for being indifferent to human suffering and for failing to balance the budget, for overtaxing and undertaxing and everywhere in between. He claimed to be offering a bold contrast of visions, but mostly he just relied on the unemployment rate to do his work for him.

title: Syrian Rebels Say They Have Seized an Air Defense Post and Its Missiles
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Opposition fighters in Syria said early Saturday that they had captured an air defense base in the eastern province of Deir el-Zour, taking at least 16 soldiers captive and seizing weapons and ammunition in what appeared to be part of a broader rebel offensive against Syrian military installations in several parts of the country.

title: Tuning Out Taunts but Not Escaping Doubt, Brauns Back in Top Form
description: CHICAGO  As the Milwaukee Brewers Ryan Braun jogged to left field in the first inning of a game against the Cubs last week, the catcalls cascaded from the Wrigley Field bleachers.

title: Loopholes in Tobacco Regulation
description: Give the tobacco industry credit for ingenuity. Just when it looked as if federal regulators could block their ability to addict children and young adults, several companies that make cigars and pipe tobacco have sidestepped the barriers by taking advantage of loopholes in federal law.

title: Altidore Hears Coachs Message to U.S. National Team: Get Tough
description: In some quarters, Jurgen Klinsmanns admonition that the United States national team needs to be less gentle has been discussed and dissected, called unsporting by some, too cynical and severe by others.

title: It Began With a Bang
description: If you havent started following the 2012 Summer Paralympic Games, which began Wednesday in London, youve missed some good stuff, including an opening ceremony that was truly cosmic. It featured the physicist Stephen Hawking as master of ceremonies and Sir Ian McKellen as Prospero, wearing a gown of stars and telling Miranda, who was floating above the stadium in a wheelchair, to shine your light on the beautiful diversity of humanity, which wasnt Shakespeare but sounded enough like it. The ceremony, whose theme was Enlightenment, re-enacted the Big Bang and featured an appearance by the Large Hadron Collider, the Higgs boson, giant falling apples and a choir singing a new piece, Principia.

title: The Envelope Please: Chandler Buckingham
description: Chandler Buckingham, a student at Rogers High School in Rogers, Ark., is one of eight high school seniors around the world who are blogging about their college searches.

title: Still No Justice for Mortgage Abuses
description: It has been six months since the big banks settled with state and federal officials over evidence of widespread foreclosure fraud, promising to provide $25 billion in mortgage relief in exchange for not being sued over past foreclosure abuses.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Obama Takes a Page From an Unexpected Victory in Colorado
description: DENVER  As President Obama navigates the battleground states that will determine whether he wins a second term, his campaign strategists have unfolded a road map for one in particular. And they are following it closely as the best route to their destination.

title: Mrs. Clintons Asia Mission
description: Mitt Romney has identified Asia as one place where he wants to focus more attention if elected, but the truth is that President Obama has already staked out a forceful position there with his commitment to rebalance American interests from the Middle East to the Pacific.

title: In 1972, Hockeys Cold War Boiled Over
description: Forty years later, it remains seared in the Canadian consciousness. The Summit Series of September 1972: eight games that not only changed hockey but also became a defining national event.

title: Sunday Dialogue: How Corporations Behave
description: Readers discuss business ethics and priorities over the years.

title: Reagans Personal Spying Machine
description: IN 1961, when Ronald Reagan was defining himself politically, he warned that if left unchecked, government would become a Big Brother to us all. But previously undisclosed F.B.I. records, released to me after a long and costly legal fight under the Freedom of Information Act, present a different side of the man who has come to symbolize the conservative philosophy of less government and greater self-reliance.

title: Road Shows Get Rolling for Romney and Obama
description: CINCINNATI  Big crowds cheered both of the presidential candidates on Saturday as Mitt Romney began a cross-country campaign swing here testing his momentum coming out of the Republican convention, and President Obama started his own tour heading into his convention this week.

title: Ode to the List
description: Michael Jacksons show notes, Picassos recommendations and other lists up-close.

title: A Trial on Death Row
description: An extraordinary trial is scheduled to begin Wednesday in Connecticut, held at the prison housing the states death row. The petitioners are inmates sentenced to death for violent felonies, who are seeking to have their sentences reduced to life without parole on the ground that the death penalty in Connecticut is unconstitutional because it has been randomly imposed on a small group of people.

title: Cruel Conservatives Throw a Masquerade Ball
description: TAMPA, Fla.

title: Our Longing for Lists
description: WITH school starting and vacations ending, this is the month, the season of the list. But face it. Were living in the era of the list, maybe even its golden age. The Web click has led to the wholesale repackaging of information into lists, which can be complex and wonderful pieces of information architecture. Our technology has imperceptibly infected us with list thinking.

title: Wheres Walden? GPS Often Doesnt Know
description: LYNN, Mass.  Walden Pond, Henry David Thoreaus idyllic retreat in the woods of Concord, Mass., has long been one of the most famous day trips in New England, drawing droves of visitors seeking the tranquil beauty immortalized in the 19th-century philosophers writings.

title: A Heady Nightcap in a City Not Known for Sleeping
description: Night tennis began at the United States Open in 1975 with certain stars trying to beg out and certain patrons trying to dump unwanted tickets on scalpers.

title: The Vengeance of the Lard
description: I spent a lot of time in England during the early 1990s (Robin was teaching there, while I was at MIT). And when there I regularly watched Have I Got News For You, a quiz show in which two teams competed to answer questions about the weeks headlines. Each timeteam consisted of a show regular and a newsmaker guest.

title: Drawing With a Purpose, By Michael Graves
description: Michael Graves explains, through his art, why drawing is still an important architectural skill.

title: Monetary Versus Fiscal Policy, Revisited
description: One recurring complaint from commenters on this blog is that they cant figure out where I stand on monetary versus fiscal policy as a response to a deeply depressed economy. Sometimes, they say, I declare that monetary policy is ineffective once youre at the zero lower bound; other times I berate Ben Bernanke for not doing more. Which is it?

title: Architecture and the Lost Art of Drawing
description: Princeton, N.J.

title: U.S. Womens Stars Hope, Cautiously, That a New Pro League Will Form
description: ROCHESTER  Three weeks after a gold medal victory at the Olympics, the United States womens soccer team gathered here Friday for a leisurely practice in advance of Saturdays first game of a 10-game celebratory tour.

title: Hate-Crime Trial Offers a Crash Course in Amish Folkways
description: CLEVELAND  When Nancy Mullet entered a federal courtroom here on Thursday to testify in the hate-crimes trial of her father-in-law, Samuel Mullet Sr., and followers of his renegade sect, the jury knew at a glance which side she favored in this wrenching clash among Amish.

title: Scaring the Voters in the Middle
description: THE claims of Representative Todd Akin that women dont get pregnant from legitimate rape now live in infamy. But a few things you may not know:

title: Its Still Halftime in America
description: Tampa, Fla.

title: Islamists Struggle to Run North Mali
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The radical Islamists who control northern Mali appear incapable of managing basic services  including electricity, water and schools  and in some cases are asking for the return of state functionaries to run them, according to a delegation that went to the region for talks recently.

title: N.F.C. West Preview: Makeover Continues for Rejuvenated 49ers
description: Player to Watch Randy Moss. You havent traveled a decade back in time. Moss may not put up the numbers he did in his best years, or even in 2007 with the Patriots. But if he can still stretch the field, he can make San Francisco even more potent.

title: In Louisiana, the Water Gives, and Takes Away
description: VENICE, La.  The end of the earth was farther away than usual.

title: A.F.C. West Preview: Broncos Success Hinges on Mannings
description: Player to Watch Dont overthink this. Peyton Manning.

title: Tracking a Subtle Scent, a Dog May Help Save the Whales
description: OFF THE COAST OF SAN JUAN ISLAND, Wash.  A dog named Tucker with a thumping tail and a mysterious past as a stray on the streets of Seattle has become an unexpected star in the realm of canine-assisted science. He is the worlds only working dog, marine biologists say, able to find and track the scent of orca scat, or feces, in open ocean water  up to a mile away, in the smallest of specks.

title: Salty Dog
description: Scientists analyze the scat of orca whales to monitor their health. But finding samples isnt easy unless Tucker, a black lab mix who can sniff out the droppings from a mile away, is on board.

title: In Russia, Opening Inquiries and Settling Scores
description: MOSCOW  When the Russian authorities began a series of investigations this spring into the business affairs of a prominent opposition lawmaker, it was widely viewed as thinly veiled political retribution.

title: With New Owners, Padres Bullish on Future
description: The San Diego Padres officially announced their $800 million sale last week to a group headed by Ron Fowler, the chairman of a beverage-distribution company in California and Colorado, and four grandsons of Walter OMalley, the Hall of Fame owner who took the Brooklyn Dodgers to Los Angeles in 1958. The group takes over a team that is probably better than most fans realize.

title: Between the Acts
description: GAIL COLLINS David, were halfway through the convention process. Weve spent quite a bit of time conversing about it in different venues and now  print! Im enjoying the conversing. Its just the conventions themselves Ive come to hate.

title: Is This Title O.K.?
description: Beginning  check. Middle  check. End  check. But, hold on a sec, isnt there something missing? Something rather vital? In fact, couldnt it be the key to your books selling or not? Ah, yes, the title.

title: At Journeys End
description: Before a game during the Mets last homestand, Terry Collins emerged from the dugout, picked up a baseball and began warming up his arm as he walked toward second base to watch batting practice. Three decades earlier, Collins, 63, would have performed a similar routine, when he was a utility player in the minor leagues.

title: Clear Goals Matter More Than Mission
description: This interview with  Tracy Streckenbach, president and chief operating officer of Innovative Global Brands, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Why Campaign Reporters Are Behind the Curve
description: It becomes popular around this time of year to lament the fact that media coverage treats the presidential campaign as little more than a horse race. Journalists, this line of argument goes, choose to fixate on which candidate is a superior campaigner or savvier strategist, not on who has sounder ideas or is better prepared to govern. From time to time, the journalists themselves concede that to maintain daily or hourly tension in the contests they promote, they have little choice but to elevate minor poll shifts into major developments.

title: Mortgage Registry Muddles Foreclosures
description: MORE good news from the housing front last week. Pending home sales rose 2.4 percent in July, to their highest level since April 2010. Mortgage delinquency rates are down: the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported a decline of 6.3 percent at the end of June from the March quarter.

title: Czech Towns Other Pride
description: The Czech Republic, with a little more than 10 million people, has produced a disproportionate number of tennis champions. Aside from tennis trophies, another thing the Czechs hoist in disproportionate amounts is beer. Unlike in tennis, the Czechs have little competition in this category, with the average citizenconsuming 131 liters a year, more than Germany, Austria and Ireland by 25 liters.

title: Letters: A Task Unfinished, a Lesson Learned
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters: Breaking the Silence on a Carbon Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Harrison Brothers Advance to Third Round
description: The American brothers Christian and Ryan Harrison defeated the veteran Israeli doubles team of Jonathan Erlich and Andy Ram, 6-4, 6-4, on Saturday in the second round of the United States Open.

title: Lengthy Deal, Shrinking E.R.A.
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  In 1996, the year he turned 7, Matt Moore moved with his family to Kadena Air Base in Okinawa, Japan. His father, Marty, worked on Special Operations helicopters and was transferred there from Florida.

title: Can Europe Survive the Rise of the Rest?
description: Oxford, England

title: Sharing the Stage
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  As quarterback Greg McElroy conducted an interview after the Jets preseason finale Thursday in Philadelphia, Mark Sanchez started plotting the prank. Nodding toward McElroy, Sanchez motioned to the teammate standing between them to pass an orange wedge. Sanchez crept behind McElroy and shoved the fruit down the back of his T-shirt. While McElroy squirmed, Sanchez bumped fists with his co-conspirator, Tim Tebow.

title: A Weight-Loss Strategy From an Unlikely Pair
description: WHEN Myles Berkowitz first met Steven Kates through a mutual friend in 2006, Mr. Berkowitz had serious doubts about him.

title: When GPS Confuses, You May Be to Blame
description: The turn-by-turn instructions of GPS-based navigation systems, ingeniously designed though they may be, cant always save us from ourselves.

title: German Drug Maker Apologizes to Victims of Thalidomide
description: LONDON  Decades of campaigning by victims of thalidomide, a morning sickness drug, have taken a new turn, with the first apology in 50 years to the victims and their families by the drugs German manufacturer  and an incensed rejection of the apology as too little and too late from many of those it was intended to placate.

title: On Top, but Off Radar
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In previous years, the Giants have been quick to embrace Coach Tom Coughlins seasonal slogan as a mantra, with the two most notable refrains  Talk is cheap, play the game and Finish  being featured prominently in the 2007 and 2011 Super Bowl championship seasons.

title: Troubled Times for Plaquemines Parish
description: Venice sits at the end of the road in Plaquemines Parish, the peninsula of southeastern Louisiana that was the first landing point of Hurricane Isaac and the scene of perhaps its most thorough destruction.

title: Murray Holds It Together in the Heat, and Federer Cruises to a Win
description: The Big Four in mens tennis came to New York minus Rafael Nadal, and for stretches of Saturday afternoon it looked as if the three present might be reduced to two.

title: Two Americans Are Buried a Year After a Train Crash in China
description: A year ago, Cao Erxing and his wife, Chen Zengrong, both 56, were killed in a high-speed train crash in China. But it was not until Saturday that their relatives in New York City were finally able to gather to mourn their loss and bury their loved ones.

title: Music of the Unquiet Mind
Mitt Romney and Abortion Politics
description: My Sunday column looks at the GOP and reproductive health, from abortion to sex education. As you can see from the column, I think its a pathetic sight  but in fairness, one point I wish I had had space for in the column is to note that if the Republican platform is baffling in its message to centrist voters, its also arguably a rare example of political courage. Republicans are looking at the same polls I am, and presumably they realize that their reluctance to back exceptions in abortion bans for rape or the health of the mother risk losing voters. Its not often that politicians risk losing votes for something that they believe in, and I give them credit for that  even though I think their positions are utter nonsense. Your thoughts?

title: Framing Prevents Needed Stimulus
description: WHY have so many teachers, police officers, firefighters and other public workers been laid off since the financial crisis hit  and why are so few being offered new jobs now?

title: Obama Visits Swing States Before Convention
description: URBANDALE, Iowa  With his partys nominating convention approaching next week, President Obamastarted a four-day, four-state campaign trip on Saturday in Iowa, the state where he opened his quest for the presidency five years ago.

title: Ryans Latest Reclamation Project Stands Out Right Away
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets and the Rams thought that by swapping tackles, each could salvage an underperforming player and improve in pass protection. After putting tackle Jason Smith through a crash course on the playbook and evaluating his performance in the preseason finale, the Jets proclaimed themselves satisfied with the deal.

title: Trying to Win Race He Helped Save
description: BALTIMORE  J. P. Grant III knows far more about financing than he does about auto racing. But he is a big civic booster, and he believes that the Indy-car race on the streets around the Inner Harbor can become like the Preakness  only with more horsepower.

title: 30 Seconds With Fredy Montero
description: After coming off the bench in four of the previous six games, Fredy Montero returned to the Seattle Sounders starting lineup last weekend against Chivas USA and scored his first hat trick in his 100th game in Major League Soccer. That increased his season total to 11 goals, giving him four consecutive seasons with 10 or more for the Sounders.

title: Duquette and Orioles Back in the Game
description: More than most, Dan Duquette understands the need to share credit for a teams success. As the general manager of the Boston Red Sox from 1994 to 2001, Duquette acquired many of the players who would win the teams first championship in 86 years, in 2004. While his successor, Theo Epstein, got the glory, Duquette spent nearly a decade without a job in the majors.

title: In a Ban, a Measure of European Tolerance
description: PARIS  During a recent protest in Marseille, seven people were suddenly surrounded by the police, bundled into a van and brought in for questioning. Their offense was not the demonstration itself but the balaclavas they were wearing, a violation of the French law banning full-face veils in public places, passed in April 2011.

title: In a Post-Convention Bump, Romney Draws Huge Crowds in Cincinnati
description: CINCINNATI  A crowd of thousands cheered Mitt Romney at a rally here during the opening leg of a cross-country campaign swing on Saturday, testing for the first time whether he can sustain political momentum coming out of the Republican National Convention.

title: Forward Progress
description: ENGLEWOOD, Colo.  The perfect time to tell this story is after we win the Super Bowl this year.

title: Good Girls Fight to Be Journalists
description: WHEN I graduated from college, before the Civil Rights Act of 1964 took effect, sex discrimination was legal. I wanted to write for a newspaper or newsmagazine, but despite an armload of credentials and skills, I soon learned the score: Women could do research, be secretaries and, if very lucky, work for the ghetto called the womens page. But other than that, the guys were hired as the writers, and that was that.

title: Unified, in America, by an International Sport
description: On a makeshift court in Minneapolis, victorious players locked arms around one anothers necks and broke into an unusual cheer.

title: Dont Shy Away From Growth Stocks
description: WHEN economic worries rattle the markets, some investors take cover in defensive areas, like slow-but-steady utilities. This is what has driven the risk-off trade that Wall Street types talk about.

title: Inquiry on Tax Strategy Adds to Scrutiny of Finance Firms
description: The New York attorney general is investigating whether some of the nations biggest private equity firms have abused a tax strategy in order to slice hundreds of millions of dollars from their tax bills, according to executives with direct knowledge of the inquiry.

title: 30 Yards in the Air or 3 Yards in the Dust?
description: The Giants had finished the first practice of training camp this summer when Coach Tom Coughlin, in a moment that might have seemed to come out of the mid-1970s, announced his hopes for the new season.

title: Hopes Are Dashed to Have Regular N.F.L. Officials Back for First Week
description: Negotiations between the N.F.L. and its locked-out officials broke off Saturday morning, all but ensuring that replacement referees would work at least the first week of the regular season, which starts Wednesday. No further talks were scheduled.

title: When the Work-Life Scales Are Unequal
description: KELLY Azevedo used to work upward of 70 hours a week.

title: In Flexible-Work Debates, Parents Have Unique Position
description: When it comes to workplace flexibility, fair doesnt always mean equal.

title: Yankees Get a Lift from the Newcomer Pearce
description: Steve Pearce was surprised when the Baltimore Orioles designated him for assignment July 21, but he believed the demotion was temporary. He was fully prepared to report to Class AAA Norfolk with the expectation that he would soon be recalled to join the Orioles in a pennant race.

title: At Age 59, Interning to Fulfill Old Dream
description: ONE of the things Ive learned is that career plans often go awry. Industries change, health problems arise, a baby comes along or other events intervene. I had always planned to become a mental health counselor, but I veered off course years ago and am interning in the field for the first time at age 59.

title: The Value of Starting Small
description: I GREW up in Minneapolis. My mother, a former teacher, went back to work when my younger brother went to kindergarten. I was 8. She had a friend whose child had a disability, which inspired the two of them to start the nonprofit Pacer Center. They wanted to help parents of children with disabilities and expand the opportunities for these youngsters. My mother still runs the organization today.

title: New Era at Penn State Starts With Loss at Home
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  The Penn State faithful would have stood here even if they could not see a thing. Thousands of them did. They held their sons and daughters on their shoulders for a glimpse. Down the street they lined up, holding signs that read, You stayed with us ..., and on the back, ... We stand with you.

title: Obama on Reddit, Ryan in Tweets
description: Ben Smith of BuzzFeed talks with The Timess Jim Roberts about headlines in social media at the 2012 Republican National Convention.

title: Hal David, Songwriter, Is Dead at 91
description: Hal David, the Oscar- and Grammy-winning lyricist who in the 1960s and 70s gave pop music vernacular the questions Whats it all about?, Whats new, pussycat?, Do you know the way to San Jose? and What do you get when you fall in love?, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 91 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Tony Hayward Gets His Life Back
description: LONDON

title: After Fed Action, Then What?
description: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo.  The Fed is on the verge of expanding its stimulus policies. We learned that much during the meetings in Jackson Hole, Wyo. But what may be more interesting is the undercurrent of discussion about what happens when those measures prove insufficient.

title: The Summit Series of 1972: Talking With J.P. Parise
description: September marks the 40th anniversary of the Summit Series, the unforgettable clash between the N.H.L. professionals of Team Canada and the titans of international hockey, the Soviet national team.

title: Pardon Ze Interruption
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Who knew there were so many ways to spell the sound zee?

title: The Agenda: Foreign Policy
description: The Timess Cairo bureau chief David Kirkpatrick discusses the future of foreign policy. Mitt Romneys foreign policy adviser Kristen Silverberg weighs in with The Timess Marcus Mabry.

title: Syrian Refugees Pour Into Jordan
description: Nearly 2,000 Syrians are flooding nightly into Jordan, which says it has accepted about 180,000 refugees since the conflict began.

title: Airstrikes Push Waves of Syrians to Jordanian Camps
description: ZAATARI, Jordan  The five Jamous brothers were early recruits to the Free Syrian Army, eager to oust President Bashar al-Assad.

title: A Nose for Research
description: A dog named Tucker has become an unexpected star in the realm of canine-assisted science.

title: A Delayed Mourning
description: After more than a year of fighting with Chinese government officials, the sons of two Americans killed in a train crash finally buried their parents in Queens.

title: Alexander Saxton, Historian and Novelist, Dies at 93
description: Alexander Saxton, who would go on to become a prominent historian of race in America, summed himself up in a blurb on the dust jacket of his first novel, Grand Crossing, published when he was 24.

title: Isaacs Vestiges Bring Midwest Rain
description: The remnants of Hurricane Isaac, the slow-moving storm that disrupted the Republican National Convention and flooded towns along the Gulf Coast, brought much-needed rain to the Midwest on Saturday, along with scattered reports of tornadoes.

title: Party Intrigue Seen in China as Official Is Demoted
description: SHANGHAI  Ling Jihua, a senior Chinese official and a close ally of President Hu Jintao, was named Saturday to a new post in a move that some Communist Party experts said was a demotion and a surprising development ahead of this years leadership transition.

title: Byard Lancaster, Jazz Alto Saxophonist, Dies at 70
description: Byard Lancaster, an alto saxophonist who took part in the great wave of free jazz inspired by John Coltrane and then diversified far into other music and cultures  living in Nigeria, France and Chicago, playing blues, reggae and Afrobeat  but kept returning to Philadelphia, his hometown, died on Aug. 23 at a hospice in Wyndmoor, Pa. He was 70.

title: The Summit Series of 1972: Talking With Vladimir Petrov
description: Forty years ago Sunday, on Sept. 2, 1972, in Montreal, one of the most stunning upsets in the history of sports took place. Team Canada  an N.H.L. all-star team led by Phil Esposito, Brad Park, Yvan Cournoyer, Frank and Peter Mahovlich, Bobby Clarke,Ken Dryden and the Rangers GAG Line of Jean Ratelle, Rod Gilbert and Vic Hadfield  met the Soviet national team, the world and Olympic champion but a group that had never played a game against professional opponents.

title: Almagro Ends Socks Run in Four Sets
description: Nicolas Almagro of Spain will advance to the fourth round of the United States Open for the first time after fighting off a spirited challenge from the up-and-coming American teenager Jack Sock on Saturday afternoon. Almagro, seeded 11th, pulled out a 7-6 (3), 6-7 (4), 7-6 (2), 6-1 victory in the sultry afternoon heat of the half-sunbaked, half-shaded Grandstand Stadium.

title: Peter Shelton, Architect Who Made Luxury Minimal, Dies at 67
description: Peter Shelton, an award-winning architect whose sleek yet luxurious interior designs won his firm commissions for the homes of wealthy people and for corporate showcases like the headquarters of Polo Ralph Lauren, died on Aug. 26 at his home in Manhattan. He was 67.

title: In Battle for Round of 16, Cilic Prevails Over Nishikori
description: Early in the third set, into a sky bright with a blistering sun, Kei Nishikori of Japan tossed the ball high and aced Marin Cilic of Croatia to take a 4-3 lead. For nearly 2,800 spectators, there was hope that the contest might extend beyond three sets. They got their wish.

title: Once They Stopped Laughing, Things Got Serious Fast
description: On a September afternoon in Montreal in 1972, I stood next to the Rangers Brad Park at the Forum as we watched the Soviet Unions best hockey players go through their bizarre practice rituals. In one routine, they swarmed at center ice like mad bees.

title: Sept. 1: Romneys Convention Bounce Appears Middling So Far
description: The Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla. received mediocre television ratings  and the polling data so far suggests that it may produce only a modest bounce in the polls for Mitt Romney.

title: Giving Juveniles Intensive Counseling
description: MART  The green-black lines of prison life are scrawled on 16-year-old Luiss face: a cross on his left cheek, three dots arranged in a triangle under his left eye and cholo written vertically on his right cheek.

title: McIlroy Attracts Following at TPC Boston, but Not All Are Watching Him
description: NORTON, Mass.  The willowy woman with the blond ponytail and Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis oversize sunglasses was standing outside the gallery ropes Saturday morning at the T.P.C. Boston waiting for Rory McIlroy to walk past when one man produced a tennis ball for her to sign. He was followed by another fan with another tennis ball. She obliged both with a smile while a bystander observing the scene from a few feet away turned to a friend and asked, Why the tennis balls?

title: Taking a Break From Poker to Win a Championship
description: The French championship was notable for the outcome on the womens side and for a stirring display of sportsmanship among the men in the face of tragedy.

title: Top Official at ICE Quits Over Discrimination Claims
description: WASHINGTON  A senior official at the Department of Homeland Security resigned on Saturday after accusations that she had created a sexualized office culture that was hostile to men. The official, Suzanne Barr, is a longtime aide to the departments secretary, Janet Napolitano, and had been on leave from her position as chief of staff to the director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement because of the allegations.

title: Singing Her Way Toward Exit, Sundhage Steps Down as U.S. Coach
description: ROCHESTER  Before the first game of a victory tour by the gold-medal-winning United States womens soccer team, Coach Pia Sundhage decided it was time to go home to Sweden.

title: Sometimes Being a Fighter Isnt Enough
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Sundhage Leaving U.S. Womens National Team
description: Pia Sundhage is taking her tactics, her teaching and her singing voice home to Sweden.

title: U.S. Open: Day 6
description: Serena Williams and Roger Federer advanced, but Jack Sock, a 19-year-old unseeded American, was ousted in the third round.

title: Reflecting on Ambitious Education Plan
description: At a tense meeting of the University of Texas System Board of Regents on Aug. 25, 2011, after several months in which the board was at the center of a tug of war between groups with differing approaches to higher-education reform, Chancellor Francisco G. Cigarroa unveiled his Framework for Advancing Excellence.

title: TimesCast Politics | August 30, 7 P.M.
description: Part one of Thursday evening's broadcast of the Republican National Convention.

title: Clinton Begins Asia Trip, Trying to Ease Tension With China
description: RAROTONGA, Cook Islands  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton began a 10-day, 6-nation visit to Asia pledging to broaden American diplomatic, economic and security support in the Pacific, but also offering conciliatory remarks toward China at a time when tensions are rising over territorial disputes.

title: Big-Box Store Has New Life as an Airy Public Library
description: McALLEN, Tex.  The hulking husk of a vacant Walmart here in the Rio Grande Valley is enjoying an unlikely second act. When the big-box retailer moved to a larger location down the street, the building might have been destined to house yet another large chain or to fall into disrepair. But rather than let it become an eyesore, the city scooped it up and spent $24 million transforming the drab structure into a 123,000-square-foot public library that serves as a vibrant space for residents here.

title: Kurt Maetzig, Pioneering German Director, Dies at 101
description: Kurt Maetzig, a pioneering East German director whose socialist films scrutinized anti-Semitism, explored corporate complicity in the rise of fascism and helped compel Germans to come to terms with their Nazi past, died on Aug. 8 at his home in Germany. He was 101.

title: Radwanska, Seeded Second but Nearly Unknown, Beats Jankovic
description: The second seed in womens singles at the United States Open finally played in Arthur Ashe Stadium on Saturday. Even then, she remained largely unknown outside the more hard-core tennis fans.

title: Conversations With Andy Murray: Questions From Readers
description: Andy Murray defeated Feliciano Lopez, 7-6 (5), 7-6 (5), 4-6, 7-6 (4), on Saturday to reach the fourth round of the United States Open. In his regular postmatch interview with Straight Sets, Murray took questions from readers of The New York Times who sent their inquiries from all over the world.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Sept. 2
description: Presidential politics will again dominate the conversations on the news shows on Sunday, on the weekend between the closing of the Republican National Convention and the opening of the Democratic National Convention.

title: The Other Power in the West Wing
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama was in a bind, and his chief of staff could not figure out how he had ended up there.

title: In a Tactical Test, Romney Stakes Hopes on Ohio
description: CINCINNATI  Fresh off his nominating convention, Mitt Romney is cranking up a well-financed political machine that will now bring its full force to bear on President Obama with a hailstorm of ads and nonstop campaigning.

title: Corrections: September 2, 2012
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: TimesCast Politics | August 30, 7 P.M.
description: Part two of Thursday evening's broadcast of the Republican National Convention.

title: Ninth-Inning Rally Sends Mets Past Marlins
description: MIAMI  It looked as if the good vibes that had been carrying the Mets through late August would not last one game into September.

title: Clijsters, Whose First Retirement Didnt Take, Says Her Latest One Will
description: Kim Clijsters walked onto the Court 17 at the United States Open on Saturday night with her signature smile, waved to the crowd and to her family in the stands and wielded her tennis racket for what was very likely the last time as a professional.

title: Lottery Numbers
College Football Replay
description: The nation watched to see a new era of Penn State football begin, and the Ohio State Buckeyes, led by Coach Urban Meyer, open the season with a win.

title: Anne Szeker, Leif Detlefsen
description: Anne Elizabeth Szeker and Leif Arthur Detlefsen were married Saturday evening at the Riverfront Boathouse in Hartford. Steven S. Mitchell, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Dana Litowitz, Nathaniel Stokoe
description: Dana Dubin Litowitz, the daughter of Robert D. Litowitz of Bethesda, Md., and the late Karen A. Dubin, is to be married Sunday evening to Nathaniel Lee Stokoe, the son of Caroline Lee and James Stokoe of Chevy Chase, Md. Rabbi William Rudolph is to perform the ceremony at the Sixth and I Historic Synagogue in Washington.

title: Lily Sutton, Ryan Hagen
description: Lily Anna Bers Sutton, the daughter of Edith D. Bers and Paul J. Sutton of Manhattan, is to be married Sunday evening at Gedney Farm in New Marlborough, Mass., to Ryan Alansson Lee Hagen, the son of Judith K. Hagen of Rhinebeck, N.Y., and Kevin A. Hagen of Albuquerque. The brides father, who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, is to officiate.

title: Meredith Wall, David DeCarlo
description: Meredith Rita Wall and David William DeCarlo are to be married Sunday at Holy Family Parish in Inverness, Ill. The Rev. Patrick Brennan, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Leela Sarathy, David Smith
description: Leela Sarathy, a daughter of Beth S. Goldstein and Ravi Sarathy of Newton, Mass., is to be married Sunday to David William Smith, the son of Star and Christopher Smith of West Windsor, N.J. Rabbi David Kudan will officiate at the Museum of Science in Boston.

title: Rachel Cotton, Philip Trout
description: Rachel Fellner Cotton and Philip Berkeley Trout are to be married Sunday at the weekend home of the brides mother in Washington Depot, Conn. Judge Amy Berman Jackson of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia is to officiate, with Maria P. Rivera, an associate justice on the California First District Court of Appeal, taking part.

title: Hillary Robbie, Maximillian Cavaleri
description: Hillary Kay Robbie and Maximillian Camillo Cavaleri are to be married Sunday evening at the Foundry, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. Cantor Edward Robin is to officiate.

title: Francesca Wilmott, James Stanley
description: Francesca Carol Wilmott, a daughter of Cathryn M. Wilmott and Dr. Robert W. Wilmott of St. Louis, was married Saturday to James Edward Stanley, a son of Dr. Ellen Li and Dr. Samuel L. Stanley Jr. of Old Field, N.Y. The Rev. Margaret H. Allen, a Unitarian Universalist minister, led the ceremony at Sunwood Estate in Old Field.

title: Sara Peach, Ryan Messier
description: Sara Frances Peach and Ryan James Messier are to be married Sunday at the Antique Boat Museum in Clayton, N.Y. The Rev. Molly Macsherry MacWade, an Episcopal priest, is to officiate.

title: Renuka Tipirneni, Craig Williamson
description: Dr. Renuka Tipirneni and Dr. Craig Andrew Williamson are to be married Sunday at the New England Aquarium in Boston. Krishna Polavarapu, a friend of the brides family who received permission from Massachusetts, is to officiate.

title: Jennifer Bra, Omar Wasow
description: Jennifer Michelle Bra and Omar Tomas Wasow are to be married Sunday outside the Aquinnah Lighthouse in Aquinnah, Mass., on Marthas Vineyard. The ceremony is to be led by Henry Louis Gates Jr., the Alphonse Fletcher University Professor at Harvard University, who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

title: Wendy Nguyen, Daniel Myers
description: Wendy Bao Chau Nguyen and Daniel Harris Myers are to be married Sunday at the Legion of Honor, an art museum in San Francisco. Edmundo L. Ortega, a friend of the bride and a Universal Life minister, is to officiate.

title: Amy Wolper, Jeffrey Price
description: Amy Beth Wolper, the daughter of Janet E. Wolper and Barry M. Wolper of Moorestown, N.J., is to be married Sunday evening to Jeffrey Daniel Price, the son of Vikki L. Price and Michael J. Price of New York. Cantor Martin Goldstein is to officiate at the Four Seasons Resort in Vail, Colo.

title: Jennifer Walter, Brent Ballantyne
description: Jennifer Claire Walter and Brent Kenneth Ballantyne are to be married Sunday evening in the Jefferson Market Garden in New York. Nicholas Haddad, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, is to officiate.

title: Aparna Raj, Mihir Parikh
description: Dr. Aparna Raj and Dr. Mihir Suryakant Parikh are to be married Sunday at the Indianapolis Marriott Downtown in Indianapolis. Pandit Krishna Jois Ji, a Hindu priest, is to officiate.

title: Claire Diesen, Rafael Steinberg
description: Claire Merrill Diesen and Rafael Steinberg are to be married Sunday at the Kunde Family Estate, a vineyard and event space in Kenwood, Calif. Cantor Kenneth Cohen is to officiate.

title: Gia Curatola, Cyril Dumuis
description: Gia Ann Curatola and Cyril Dumuis were married Saturday in Manhattan. The Rev. Joseph G. Marina performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, where he is an associate pastor.

title: Nicole Beemsterboer, Brian Rogers
description: Jennifer Nicole Beemsterboer and Brian Jason Rogers were married Saturday in Chicago. The Rev. Thomas J. Hurley, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Old St. Patricks Church, where he is pastor.

title: Laura Dickey, Jack Corey
description: Laura Wooding Dickey and John Hoysradt Corey were married Saturday evening at the Duke University Chapel in Durham, N.C. The Rev. Geoffrey Michael St. John Hoare, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Lesley Pinckney and Tiffany Miller
description: Lesley Norine Pinckney and Tiffany Lynn Miller are to be married Sunday in Woodstock, Vt. Judge John N. Fields, a retired Michigan Circuit Court judge, who presided in St. Joseph, Mich., and is an uncle of Ms. Millers, is to solemnize the marriage at the Woodstock Inn, having received authorization from the State of Vermont to do so. The ceremony will be led by Kent F. Miller, Ms. Millers brother.

title: Erica Schwartz, Mathew Picheny
description: Erica Lynn Schwartz and Mathew Jason Picheny are to be married Sunday evening by Rabbi Yosef Goldman, a cousin of the groom, at the Eugene ONeill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn.

title: Adekunbi Sijuwade and Olamide Odubogun
description: Adekunbi Ayinke Sijuwade and Dr. Olamide Adurasegun Odubogun were married Saturday at the Cathedral Church of St. Luke in Orlando, Fla. The Very Rev. Anthony P. Clark, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Emma Rebhorn, Benjamin Feldman
description: Emma Rebecca Rebhorn, a daughter of Rebecca F. Linn and James Rebhorn of South Orange, N.J., is to be married Sunday evening to Benjamin Ian Feldman, the son of Cindy R. Mogul and Elliott R. Feldman of Bala Cynwyd, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Jay E. Abernathy, a Unitarian Universalist minister, is to officiate at the Barn at Fallingwater in Mill Run, Pa.

title: Marie Gryphon and Sean Newhouse
description: Marie Elizabeth Gryphon and Sean Matthew Newhouse were married Thursday evening at the Santarella estate, an event space in Tyringham, Mass. Arthur I. Applbaum, who received a one-day solemnization certificate from Massachusetts, officiated.

title: Jennifer Wilkes, Sean Marley
description: Dr. Jennifer Jill Wilkes and Dr. Sean Patrick Marley are to be married Sunday at the Stone Mill, an event space at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Rabbi Beth S. Kalisch is to officiate.

title: Jenna Lafayette, Kimberly Ahern
description: Jenna Lee Lafayette and Kimberly Renee Ahern were married Saturday in Essex Junction, Vt. Christopher R. Blazejewski, a state representative in Rhode Island who received authorization from the State of Vermont to officiate, performed the ceremony at the Whitcomb House Bed & Breakfast.

title: Emily Harrison, Bryan Subach
description: Emily Jean Harrison and Bryan Robert Subach are to be married Sunday at Astor Court at the Bronx Zoo. Rabbi Nelly Altenburger is to officiate.

title: Sara Watson, Nicholas Smith
description: Sara Marie Watson and Nicholas Russell Smith were married Saturday evening at the Cove Cabin at the Mount Hope Farm in Bristol, R.I. Officiating was Ivan Kerbel, a friend of the couple, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion.

title: Celia Zeilberger, Tim Ahmed
description: Celia Le Grange Zeilberger and Hatim Nelson Ahmed were married Thursday at the law office of Gwen Carpenter in Alexandria, Va. Ms. Carpenter, a civil marriage commissioner, officiated.

title: Dana Sussman, Todd Weiser
description: Dana Gale Sussman and Todd Aaron Weiser are to be married Sunday evening at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn. Cantor Rachel Kohlbrenner is to officiate.

title: Megan McKenna, Bruce Connolly Jr.
description: Megan Elizabeth McKenna and Bruce Robert Connolly Jr. were married Saturday at the Basilica of St. Paul in Daytona Beach, Fla. The Rev. Tim Lozier, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Sima Gandhi, Richard Gurley
description: Sima Jagdish Gandhi, the daughter of Rekha Gandhi and Jay Gandhi of San Jose, Calif., is to be married there Sunday to Richard Kyle Gurley, a son of Jennie Gurley and Richard Gurley of Cullman, Ala. Peter S. Aiello, a friend of the groom and a Universal Life minister, is to officiate at Bella Montagna, a private residence and event venue.

title: Haley Naik and Aneesh Raman
description: Dr. Haley Bharat Naik and Aneesh Venkat Raman were married Saturday at the Chicago Cultural Center. Pandit Harendra Dave, a Hindu priest, officiated.

title: Suzanne Solomonic, Andrew Presberg
description: Suzanne Michelle Solomonic and Andrew David Presberg are to be married Sunday evening at the grooms home in Hauppauge, N.Y. Judge Jodi Orlow of New York City Civil Court in Queens, a sister of the bride, will officiate.

title: Julie Straus, Adam Harris
description: Julie Straus and Adam Daniel Harris are to be married Sunday at the home of the brides mother, Barbara E. Straus of Potomac, Md. Rabbi Joel Tessler is to officiate, with Rabbi Joel Roth taking part.

title: Meg Jacobs, Julian Zelizer
description: Meg Jacobs and Julian Emanuel Zelizer are to be married Sunday evening at the Synagogue for the Arts in New York. Rabbi Gerald L. Zelizer, who is the grooms father and the rabbi of Congregation Neve Shalom in Metuchen, N.J., is to perform the ceremony.

title: Samantha Morgenstern and Scott Lebenhart
description: Samantha Jill Morgenstern and Scott Lloyd Lebenhart were married Saturday evening at Pine Hollow Country Club in East Norwich, N.Y. Rabbi Marc Gellman officiated.

title: Beth Carasso, Samuel Spector
description: Beth Alyse Carasso, the daughter of Jill M. Carasso of Houston and Stephen S. Carasso of West Hartford, Conn., is to be married Sunday evening to Samuel Jacob Spector, the son of Bertram I. Spector and Judith D. Spector of Potomac, Md., at Gotham Hall, an event space in New York. Rabbi Arnold B. Marans is to officiate.

title: Jessica Fjeld, Benjamin Bearnot
description: Jessica Larkin Fjeld, a daughter of Carol E. Fjeld and Dr. George C. Fjeld of Brandon, Vt., is to be married there Sunday to Benjamin Ian Bearnot, a son of Dr. Sherry P. Katz-Bearnot and Dr. H. Robert Bearnot of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. Rabbi Edward Schecter is to officiate at the Brandon Inn.

title: Pippa Brashear, Frank Ruchala Jr.
description: Philippa Wimberley Brashear and Frank Ruchala Jr. are to be married Sunday on a New York Water Taxi in New York Harbor. Michael P. Piper, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate.

title: Peter Gandolfo, Andrew Paskoff
description: Peter Gandolfo and Andrew Paskoff were married Saturday evening at the southern end of the High Line park in New York. Judge Tammy S. Robbins of the Nassau County Court in Mineola, N.Y., officiated.

title: Mary Himinkool, Stephen Grove
description: Mary Malini Himinkool and Stephen Douglas Grove were married Saturday evening at Paradise Point, a resort in San Diego. The Rev. Abraham Johnson, a Baptist minister and a brother-in-law of the groom, officiated, followed by the Rot Nam Sang, a traditional Thai ceremony.

title: Alison Fisher and Ware Smith
description: Alison Elisabeth Fisher, the daughter of Nancy Collins Fisher and Richard W. Fisher of Dallas, is to be married Sunday to William Ware Smith III, the son of Isabella Williams Smith and Mr. Smith Jr. of Roanoke, Va. The Rev. Henry H. Edens III, an Episcopal priest, will officiate at the Moran, Wyo., vacation home of Roger Altman, a former deputy secretary of the Treasury and the brides godfather.

title: Beth Reisfeld, Charles Lesch
description: Beth Lynn Reisfeld, the daughter of Carol L. Reisfeld and Dr. Peter L. Reisfeld of Dix Hills, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Charles Harry Taylor Lesch, the son of Prof. Paula S. Fass and Prof. John E. Lesch of Berkeley, Calif. The wedding is to be held at Bridgewaters in Manhattan, with Rabbi Shlomo Shulman officiating. Rabbi Richard G. Hirsch, a cousin of the groom, is to take part.

title: Campaign References to Afghanistan Are Missing In Action
description: HONG KONG  The war in Afghanistan  the longest conflict in U.S. history at 128 months and counting  was barely mentioned onstage at the Republican National Convention last week. The actor Clint Eastwood made a loopy and apparently unscripted reference to the war, but in his acceptance speech the presidential nominee, Mitt Romney, did not once bring up the A-word.

title: U.S. Hopes Dimming as Stephens Falls Short
description: Americas tennis fans were full of hope at the start of the third round of the United States Open on Saturday.

title: Rookie Chen Stays Steady in Rotation for Orioles
description: Last April, Wei-Yin Chen had a rough initiation into the major leagues. Minutes after he stepped onto the mound to make his first start for the Baltimore Orioles in April, he watched as his fifth pitch whipped off the bat of Derek Jeter and landed 421 feet from home plate at Camden Yards for a home run.

title: Alabama Shows It May Not Be No. 2 for Long
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  That Alabama was ranked No. 2 as it opened defense of its 14th national championship did not register much ire heading into Saturday nights clash with No. 8 Michigan. Still, a fan joyously held aloft a sign deep into the fourth quarter that read, Road to 15 starts in Big D, a reference to the only mission that matters to Crimson Tide faithful.

title: U.S. Halts Training Program for Some Afghan Recruits
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The training of Afghan Local Police and special operations forces has been put on hold while their American trainers conduct stricter vetting to try to root out any infiltrators or new recruits who could pose risks to the coalition troops working with them, American officials say.

title: Has the Burqa Ban Worked in France?
