description: PARIS  The French law banning the full-face veil from public spaces has been controversial from the start, with loud debates about the meaning of liberty, individual rights, the freedoms of religion and expression, and the nature of lacit, or secularism, in the French republic.

title: How the Top 25 in College Football Fared
description: 1. SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA (1-0) beat Hawaii, 49-10.

title: What Would a President Romney Mean for the Arab Spring? For Europe?
description: In our video piece above, David Kirkpatrick, the Cairo bureau chief of The New York Times, explains the challenges and contradictions of Americas Mideast policy  whoever wins the election in November. And the Bush administrations last ambassador to the European Union, Kristen Silverberg, a foreign policy adviser to Mitt Romney, outlines to me how a Romney foreign policy would differ from that of President Barack Obama.

title: After Verdict, Assessing the Samsung Strategy in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  When a jury in San Jose, Calif., ordered Samsung Electronics to pay $1.05 billion in damages for violating Apples patents for the iPhone and iPad, it did more than decide who had infringed upon whose intellectual property. To South Koreans, the legal battle highlighted the strengths and weaknesses of both Samsung and their economy in general.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: The Supreme Courts decision to uphold Ajmal Kasabs death sentence has once again brought into focus the death penalty debate in India. Frontline, in its cover story, A Case against the Death Penalty, analyzes some gray areas in the debate.

title: What to Watch on Sunday
description: Retirement looked like the furthest thing from Andy Roddicks mind on Friday night as the former No. 1 dismissed the tricky Bernard Tomic in just under 90 minutes.

title: Mitt Romney, Weaponized Keynesian
description: OK, I missed this. From Romneys acceptance speech, attacking Obama:

title: Bronx Community College Gets a Library, and Building, Truly Its Own
description: The new North Hall and Library at Bronx Community College had scarcely been open a day when Dorian Whyte, 21, and Jang Sung Soo, 22, sat down last week to study physics on the light-filled balcony wrapping around an enormous central reading room. Neither had any books in front of him. But they were evidently enjoying the place.

title: In Pivotal Week for Euro Zone, a Test for the Central Banks Leader
description: FRANKFURT  The last time Mario Draghi addressed the news media after a meeting of the European Central Bank, on Aug. 2, he disappointed investors who wanted him to crack his whip and immediately bring bond markets to heel. The markets dropped even before Mr. Draghi was done speaking.

title: Henry Herx, Film Critic for Catholic Publications, Dies at 79
description: Henry Herx, who over three decades wrote thousands of movie reviews for Roman Catholic publications, assessing the moral complexities raised on screen through the prism of church tenets, died on Aug. 15 at his home in Ramsey, N.J. He was 79.

title: Parties Do Some Convention Spin on Sunday Talk Shows
description: WASHINGTON  It would probably be safe to say, based on the reviews of the Republican convention offered Sunday by some of President Obamas top advisers, that the gloves are officially off as Democrats look forward to their own turn on the convention stage in Charlotte.

title: Scenes from a Subculture
description: A look inside the world of youth dance competitions.

title: South Africa Lifts Charges of Murder in Mine Strike
description: JOHANNESBURG  Prosecutors provisionally dropped murder charges against the 270 jailed miners who had been accused under an obscure legal doctrine of killing 34 of their own colleagues when the police opened fire on them while engaged in a wildcat strike.

title: Tap-Tap-Tapping Into a National Obsession
description: On a Sunday morning in February  Super Bowl Sunday, as a matter of fact  out past the strip malls and the auto dealerships and worlds away from nearby Seattle, families streamed into the Highline Performing Arts Center in Burien, Wash., for a traditional American orgy of razzmatazz and rivalries.

title: Afghans Protest Vengeful Militias
description: KANAM, Afghanistan  On the bed of this villages only pickup truck, three bullet-riddled bodies were laid out on Sunday, hastily wrapped in sheets. Behind the truck, several cars, their hatchbacks propped open as they bounced down the dirt roads, carried one or two bodies each. All 15 of the villages vehicles, most of them shabby and old, joined the grim convoy, stuffed with 200 distraught relatives and 11 of their dead.

title: Mishmash Not
description: Props to Eddie Lazear; hes a loyal Republican whos been saying a lot of things I consider totally wrong lately, but his paper for Jackson Hole (pdf) is a professional, well-done piece that offers little aid and comfort to his political allies.

title: Golf Shoes for on the Course and on the Town
description: Watching golf on television, you may have noticed that golf shoes are shrinking. The minimalist movement is most obviously exemplified by the casual, street-style shoes some professionals have begun wearing in competition.

title: The Greg Norman Fan Club Is a Mutual Admiration Society
description: Greg Normans name still comes up an awful lot even though he has played in only three PGA Tour events in the last five years.

title: Shorter Days and a Chill in the Air Can Warm Fates Heart
description: I have a theory that the golf gods go on vacation in the fall. In the summer, they are much too busy to take time off. They have the major championships to keep an eye on, all the amateur tournaments and thousands of club championships.

title: With 08 on Their Minds, Democrats Gather in Charlotte
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Democrats will gather here on Tuesday to nominate President Obama for a second term in the White House, setting in motion the final sprint to Election Day.

title: Isaac Brings Touch of Relief, and Hope for Next Season, to Corn Belt
description: WARRENTON, Mo.  All through the scorching summer, as their crops withered under cloudless skies, Corn Belt farmers waited and prayed for this moment. Now, courtesy of Hurricane Isaac, it has finally arrived: three days of rain to soak their parched fields and soften the cracked soil.

title: Aliens With Dance Moves and the Midas Touch
description: There might be a utopian vision inside Shirish Kunders Joker, a Bollywood comedy about establishing contact with extraterrestrials. But if so, its buried under a mountain of static.

title: A SEALs Own Story, Bin Laden and All
description: The Navy SEALs who killed Osama bin Laden on May 2, 2011, learned from ABC News that they had gazelle legs, no waist, and a huge upper body configuration, not to mention calloused hands and gigantic egos. They learned from other American news sources that they had taken part in a 45-minute firefight and that an armed bin Laden, once cornered, had tried to defend himself in his final moments, staring straight at the fighters who would shoot him. Their raid was being turned into a bad action movie.

title: Mormon Says Romneys Are Leading Church Into Mainstream
description: BOSTON  With Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, looking on, a prominent member of the Mormon church, J.W. Marriott Jr., told his congregation on Sunday that the Romneys were helping to lead the church out of obscurity and into the mainstream.

title: Despite Eviction, Settlers of West Bank Outpost Maintain Goal
description: MIGRON, West Bank  The police officers went door to door on Sunday morning in this hilltop settlement outpost east of the West Bank city of Ramallah, handing out final eviction notices and waiting patiently for residents to come out.

title: Double Faults Prove Verdascos Undoing
description: Double faulting is absolutely the worst way to lose a point in tennis.

title: Dark Tale Told in an Atmospheric Tongue
description: Janaceks Jenufa, which Opera Slavica presented in a wrenching performance on Thursday evening at the Bohemian National Hall, has always struck me as a thoroughly wintry work. That may be because of its almost ceaseless grimness, or because its final act includes the discovery of a murdered baby, buried in ice. But then, much of the music that Opera Slavica specializes in  the Russian and Czech repertory  is set in dark, chilly landscapes. So a challenge that faces the companys young singers, along with bringing the music and characters to life, is evoking a suitably icy spirit for an audience that has just wandered in from the summer heat.

title: Seeing One Child Off to Preschool, Another to High School
description: When my daughter, now 4, was born, I was 44 1/2. The half is important  or was, to me, at the time, as I imagined the late summer morning I would drop her off five and a half years hence to start kindergarten, when shed be 5 1/2.

title: For Stephens, Lessons in a Loss to Ivanovic
description: Ana Ivanovic raised her level of play late in the second set, then stayed on the attack to come from a set down to beat Sloane Stephens at Arthur Ashe Stadium on Saturday night to advance to the fourth round of the United States Open. The match turned Ivanovics way when Stephenss first-serve percentage plummeted and Ivanovic moved inside the baseline to attack the second serve. This led to four breaks of serve for Ivanovic, a pivotal break at 4 all in the second set followed by three service breaks in the final set. And as the pressure on her second serve mounted, Stephens began to visibly struggle with her serve, giving away six points on double faults in the third set as the tall, lithe Ivanovic moved even further inside the baseline.

title: U.S. Companies Brace for an Exit From the Euro by Greece
description: Even as Greece desperately tries to avoid defaulting on its debt, American companies are preparing for what was once unthinkable: that Greece could soon be forced to leave the euro zone.

title: Rev. Sun Myung Moon, Self-Proclaimed Messiah Who Built Religious Movement, Dies at 92
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the Korean evangelist, businessman and self-proclaimed messiah who built a religious movement notable for its mass weddings, fresh-faced proselytizers and links to vast commercial interests, died on Monday in Gapyeong, South Korea. He was 92.

title: Everybody Does It
description: That seems to be the new Beltway line, now that the shock over the lie-fest in Tampa has died down a bit. At the Washington Post (except at Ezras blog), at Politico, and so on, its excuse time  sure, Ryan and Romney told a few whoppers, but isnt that just how politics is?

title: In Swing State, Ryan Shows His Ohio Chops
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Before Mitt Romney announced a running mate, many political strategists predicted he would choose Senator Rob Portman of Ohio, if for no other reason than his home state is a must-win state for the Romney campaign.

title: Bays Power Makes Rare Appearance for Mets
description: MIAMI  Things have been going well for the Mets of late. They have not for outfielder Jason Bay.

title: Rivals Jostle Before Apple Announces New iPhone
description: Back when Apple was an underdog, it had an easier time shrouding its product announcements in mystery and perhaps catching its competitors off guard.

title: The Hippocratic Oath, With Fingers Crossed
description: There was a moment when it seemed as if Lauren Ambrose would be taking on 2012s scariest acting assignment. She was cast in the Barbra Streisand role in a revival of Funny Girl that was to hit Broadway in April. Reprising the career-defining role of a legend? Yeah, thats scary.

title: Electronic Dance Music Goes Hollywood
description: Once marginalized as a novel European import, electronic dance music, or E.D.M., has become the dominant trend in American pop these days. Its lively synthetic beats and booming bass lines are inescapable, and its top D.J.s draw sold-out crowds to outdoor raves like Electric Daisy Carnival and even rock bastions like Lollapalooza and Coachella, earning them thousands, if not millions, of dollars for a single set.

title: Eat and Run to Another Channel
description: In the world of lifestyle television, few people get as much attention as Anthony Bourdain, and its fair to ask why a middle-aged former chef whose TV show draws fewer than 500,000 viewers deserves so much ink. (Figuratively speaking.)

title: Yankees Still Have the East Lead, but the Orioles Have the Momentum
description: The third question to Manager Joe Girardi about his ill-fated choice to leave Phil Hughes in to face Mark Reynolds in the sixth inning drew his ire.

title: Is Riff Raff Eccentric? Yes. Next Question?
description: The Riff Raff concert on Thursday night at Santos Party House began with a news conference, podium and all, except it wasnt nearly a news conference. It was after midnight in a sweaty, crowded nightclub, and Riff Raff, wearing a pink neon windbreaker, mostly took banal questions from the crowd: Will Riff Raff bring the rice out? Rice shall be brought. (More on the rice later.) Does Riff Raff play basketball? I hoop so good I damn near couldve been Sheryl Swoopes.

title: Telluride Film Festival: Geoff Dyer, Tarkovskys Stalker, Chaplin and More
description: Late Saturday night, near the end a lively dinner at a local restaurant, Tom Luddy, one of the Telluride Film Festivals triumvirate of directors, was lamenting that journalists covering the festival focus too much on the Oscar race. Timing has something to do with this. Telluride, synchronous with Venice and just ahead of Toronto, is inevitably one of the first steps on the long march to the Dolby Theater. For the past two years it has presented the eventual Best Picture winner. The presence of movie stars stopping through to receive tributes, answer audience questions and humbly promote their new movies may also contribute to the hype. Bill Murray, Ben Affleck, Dennis Quaid and Marion Cotillard are all here doing just that, sometimes accompanied by thunder and lightning at Elks Park in the center of town.

title: Left Alone by Its Owner, Reddit Soars
description: There are many ways to measure the traction of a social media platform: time spent, page views or unique users. But it might be useful to add one more metric: if the leader of the free world stops by to answer questions from your users, youre probably doing O.K.

title: In Praise of the Clash of Cultures
Obama Casts Republicans as Stuck in the Past
description: BOULDER, Colo.  As President Obama heads into the Democratic National Convention this week, he is seizing on the just-concluded Republican convention to ramp up his argument that Mitt Romney and his party are stuck in the policies of the past and are afraid to spell out the details of their plans.

title: Roddick Staves Off Retirement With a Win
description: For stretches after Andy Roddicks latest victory, the one that extended his farewell tour at least another two days, he seemed unsure how to react  what to do and how to celebrate.

title: Twitters Free Speech Defender
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Alexander Macgillivray, Twitters chief lawyer, says that fighting for free speech is more than a good idea. He thinks it is a competitive advantage for his company.

title: Roddick Is Having His Last Laugh
description: Sure, Andy Roddick said he was retiring, but have you noticed the bounce in his step in his victories against Bernard Tomic and Fabio Fognini?

title: Be of Use
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Happy Labor Day to all! This will be a brief one today, since I am desperately trying to squeeze every last bit of summer out of this weekend. Also, this is a Monday, and you really dont need my help for that, do you?

title: Storm Coverage Online Hints at Future of Times-Picayune
description: As the staff at The Times-Picayune in New Orleans applied their well-developed hurricane-reporting skills last week, it was not just flooded roads and power failures that they contended with. Hurricane Isaac struck the region a month before the paper is to cut back print publication to just three days a week, lose part of its newsroom staff and merge into a new company with the Web site Nola.com.

title: Ryan Admits Misstating Marathon Time
description: Representative Paul D. Ryan has taken back his claim that he had run a marathon in under three hours, an assertion that had drawn great skepticism in the running community and one that came after his convention speech faced scrutiny for some questionable and misleading statements.

title: Second World Mind Sports Games, in France
description: At the Second World Mind Sports Games in Lille, France, last month there was a subsidiary event of the subsidiary event.

title: A Chance to Dance
description: A look at the world of dance competitions for youngsters.

title: National Geographic Takes Hunter Off TV Show
description: The National Geographic Channel said on Friday that Melissa Bachman, an animal hunter who writes for a blog called Hardcore Huntress, will no longer be a participant in the coming reality series Ultimate Survivor Alaska, after an online petition protesting her involvement received more than 13,000 signatures in less than 24 hours. According to the Hollywood Reporters Web site the petition posted on Change.org by Tim Martell, a Florida resident, called for a boycott of National Geographic and stated that the cable channel had abandoned its traditional stance of conservation and protection by working with Ms. Bachman, who also has her own Web site that contains hunting videos, tips and a photographic trophy room. The National Geographic Channel has carefully considered the public discussion of our series on surviving the wilds of Alaska currently in production and premiering sometime next year, the cable channel said in a statement. Upon further reflection we plan to eliminate one of the survivalists from the ensemble cast, Melissa Bachman. Hunting is not the focus of the show, and we regret the misinformation that has clouded what we hope will be an exciting adventure series set in the incredible Alaskan landscape.

title: Spanish Filmmaker Wins Prize at Online Festival
description: The Spanish filmmaker David Victori was the grand prize winner of the first Your Film Festival, an online competition sponsored by YouTube, Scott Free Productions and Emirates airlines, for his short film The Guilt, about a man out for revenge after his wifes murder. The announcement was made at the Venice Film Festival on Sunday after his film was selected from a pool of 10 finalists by a jury that included the director Ridley Scott and the actor Michael Fassbender.

title: Live Read Series at Toronto Festival
description: The Toronto International Film Festival will host the latest installment of the director Jason Reitmans Live Read series  in which popular movie scripts are performed by contemporary actors  with an unrehearsed reading of Alan Balls screenplay for the 1999 film American Beauty. The performance will take place on Thursday at the Ryerson Theater in Toronto; Mr. Reitman, above, will announce the cast for the reading on his Twitter account, @jasonreitman, in the days before the event. Tickets can be purchased at tiff.net/festival. Mr. Reitman created the series last year in collaboration with Elvis Mitchell, a former film critic for The New York Times, for the film society at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. Previous entries included presentations of The Apartment with Paul Rudd and Emma Stone at the TimesCenter in Manhattan, and The Big Lebowski featuring Seth Rogen in Los Angeles, among others.

title: Garden & Gun Claws Its Way Back From the Brink
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Among the many magazines that were battered by the recession, few survived such a precarious financial state as Garden & Gun.

title: Young U.S. Player Relishes First Taste of Spotlight
description: At 16, Victoria Duval of Boca Raton, Fla., is signing autographs and basking in the warmth of attention and curiosity befitting a United States girls 18-and-under champion and wild-card entrant in the United States Open womens singles championship.

title: A High Line Thats Good for New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Arctic Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: Hate Attacks in Israel
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Klinsmann Includes Dempsey for Jamaica Qualifiers
description: Clint Dempsey may be out of practice, and possibly out of form, but he is not out of the United States national team.

title: The Arms Trade Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: The Reasons for Public Ire Toward Big Banks
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Giants, a Leader and Some Fresh Followers
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Michael Coe, who has never started an N.F.L. game, will probably be called upon Wednesday night to help shut down Cowboys receivers Dez Bryant and Miles Austin.

title: N.F.L. and Officials Still at Odds
description: The N.F.L. sent a memo to its teams Sunday indicating that it thought Friday that it was close to a deal to end the lockout of officials but that negotiations broke off the next day after a brief meeting in which officials made clear that retirement benefits remained the key sticking point. Now, people on both sides say it is doubtful a deal can be completed in time to use regular officials for Week 1, which starts Wednesday when the Giants host the Cowboys.

title: What Muffins Say About Mitt Romney
description: SOME supporters of Mitt Romney, in an effort to make him seem more human (or at least humanoid), have been disseminating a story, first told by a biographer, about how their candidate has a charmingly eccentric habit: he eats only the tops of muffins. His theory is that during the baking process, the butter sinks to the bottom. This story conveys so many things: our guy is an everyday Joe  he eats muffins, not crumpets. And look, even his breakfast is an opportunity to make disciplined decisions  just think how hell do with the budget.

title: HBO Will Offer Channel by Internet in Northern Europe
description: The pay television service HBO is about to make a lot of Internet users in Denmark, Finland, Norway and Sweden very happy.

title: When Capitalists Cared
description: Washington

title: Small Music Labels to Court Asia
description: To compete in the global marketplace, the major record companies have branches and subsidiaries all over the world. Most small labels do not have that advantage, so for help they are turning to federal and state government agencies.

title: Rebels Bomb Heavily Guarded Damascus Neighborhood
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Rebels set off two bombs among a cluster of military headquarters buildings in the Syrian capital, Damascus, on Sunday, as the new United Nations envoy for Syria pointedly refused to call for President Bashar al-Assad to give up power.

title: Rounding the Seasonal Mark
description: Other holidays are celebrated for the day and the season itself  Thanksgiving, Christmas, the Fourth of July. But Labor Day, as most of us know it, is a holiday about what comes next.

title: Alan M. Kriegsman, Who Won Pulitzer for Criticism, Dies at 84
description: Alan M. Kriegsman, a longtime dance critic for The Washington Post and the first dance critic to win a Pulitzer Prize, died on Friday at his home in Washington. He was 84.

title: At Least Fun in the Sun Isnt Banned. For Now...
description: LOS ANGELES  Whatever it is, Im against it! Groucho Marx sang in a 1932 picture filmed on the Paramount lot here.

title: Advertisers Join the Social Video App Showyou
description: As marketers debate the efficacy of online display advertising and users ignore the standard blocks of ads found on many Web sites, many advertisers are turning to videos that blur the line between content and marketing.

title: Egypt Abuzz as Newsreader on State TV Wears Hijab
description: CAIRO  In what was called a first for Egyptian state television, a woman wearing a head scarf presented headlines in a newscast on Sunday, breaking with a code of secular dress that for decades effectively barred the wearing of Islamic head coverings.

title: A Pitch-Perfect Voice for a Team in Need of Fine-Tuning
description: When Pia Sundhage became coach of the United States womens soccer team in November 2007, she gathered her players and sang The Times They Are A-Changin. Sour notes were evident, not in Sundhages voice, but in the teams internal discord.

title: Pakistani Blasphemy Case Shifts as Cleric Is Arrested
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Muslim cleric at the forefront of a campaign to prosecute a Christian girl for blasphemy has suddenly found himself at risk of facing the same charges, after one of his colleagues went to the authorities and accused him of falsifying evidence of burned holy papers.

title: Gen. William W. Momyer, Celebrated Pilot, Dies at 95
description: Gen. William W. Momyer, a celebrated World War II fighter pilot who helped plot postwar tactics for the Air Force and commanded aerial combat and bombing operations during the early years of the Vietnam War, died Aug. 10 at an assisted-living center in Merritt Island, Fla. He was 95.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the Institute for Supply Management manufacturing index for August and construction spending for July (Tuesday); revised second-quarter productivity, Automatic Data Processing employment for August, weekly jobless claims, and the I.S.M. service index for August (Thursday); and unemployment for August (Friday).

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes the weekly auction of three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

title: Account Says Navy Author Wrote Book After a Slight
description: The former Navy SEALs member who is a co-author of a first-person account of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden was willing to break the code of silence honored by many commandos because of bad blood with his former unit, the elite SEAL Team 6, according to a new e-book written by other Special Operations veterans.

title: For Times Square Patrol, a Stage the Tourists Dont See
description: The tour began just after dusk, as the lavender sky dissolved into night, backlit by the pulsing luminescence of Times Square.

title: Likely Successor to Disgraced Brooklyn Party Leader Is a Friend and Protg
description: Each time a Brooklyn kingmaker falls in this borough of the back-room deal  the tenures of three of the last four Democratic bosses have ended in scandal  the outrage turns to an outcry for one of New Yorks last political machines to be dismantled.

title: Oosthuizen Catches McIlroy With Early Flurry of Birdies
description: NORTON, Mass.  As he stood over his 23-foot birdie attempt on the ninth green Sunday, Louis Oosthuizen never doubted that his stroke would be pure. Playing TPC Boston as if it were a putt-putt course, Oosthuizen made birdies on 8 of the first 10 holes, including seven in a row, on his way to an eight-under-par 63 in the third round of the Deutsche Bank Championship.

title: After Wedding, Money Box Is the Something Borrowed
description: The bride and groom had said their I dos, the guests had danced the night away and the goodbyes were being exchanged as a glorious Saturday night was winding down. And then the matre dhtel at the West Sayville Country Club on Long Island noticed something amiss in the coat room: someone inside was clutching the money box, the white box in which the guests had deposited envelopes, many filled with cash, intended for the newlyweds.

title: Ticket Sales Fail to Make Hollywoods Summer
description: LOS ANGELES  This is one summer Hollywood would like to remake.

title: Trust, Immigrants and Gov. Brown
description: There is a significant and immediate step Gov. Jerry Brown of California can take to protect community safety and civil liberties in his state.

title: A Growing Nuclear Program
description: Iran has been developing its nuclear enrichment program since 1985.

title: As Democratic Convention Nears, Demonstrators Take to the Streets of Charlotte
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Protesters from scores of groups around the country filled the streets of Charlotte on Sunday afternoon to push their agenda as Democrats gathered in the city for their convention.

title: Success at Open Bodes Well for Britons Chances at Wimbledon
description: Whatever happens from here on out at the United States Open, the tennis summer of 2012 shall in no small part be remembered for compelling evidence of a countrys climate change. Those dark clouds of defeatism that hovered for decades over the famed Wimbledon lawns and British tennis have finally rolled out and been replaced by a sky of gold and silver hue and hope.

title: To Calm Israel, U.S. Offers Ways to Restrain Iran
description: WASHINGTON  With Israel openly debating whether to strike at Irans nuclear facilities in the coming months, the Obama administration is moving ahead with a range of steps short of war that it hopes will forestall an Israeli attack, while forcing the Iranians to take more seriously negotiations that are all but stalemated.

title: When a Coach Called a Shift
description: Frank Solichs faith in the option offense had been forged and confirmed over an almost three-decade association with Nebraska. Solich played fullback there under Bob Devaney. He coached under Tom Osborne, winning three national championships with the same reliable, grinding attack. When he replaced Osborne, the option helped him win 49 games in his first five seasons, more than either Devaney or Osborne over a similar stretch.

title: Health Care Where You Work
description: In the scramble to find ways to slow rising health care costs, experts are finding good ideas from organizations that are virtually unknown beyond their hometowns.

title: Siblings Throats Slit by Intruder; Boy, 6, Dies
description: A knife-wielding attacker broke into the bedroom of a boy and a girl in Camden, N.J., early Sunday and slit their throats, killing the boy, the authorities said.

title: Mexico Citys Aztec Past Reaches Out to Present
description: MEXICO CITY  The skeleton is that of a young woman, perhaps an Aztec noble, found intact and buried in the empires most sacred spot more than 500 years ago. Almost 2,000 human bones were heaped around her, and she is a mystery.

title: A Spotlight With Precedent Beckons a Mayor From Texas
description: SAN ANTONIO  Mayor Julin Castro will be closely watching two elections on Nov. 6.

title: Rosie Ruiz Republicans
description: Remember Rosie Ruiz? In 1980 she was the first woman to cross the finish line at the Boston Marathon  except it turned out that she hadnt actually run most of the race, that she sneaked onto the course around a mile from the end. Ever since, she has symbolized a particular kind of fraud, in which people claim credit for achieving things they have not, in fact, achieved.

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 2
description: A look at the day in sports around the world, from auto racing in Belgium to baseball in Chicago.

title: A House Speaker Proves a Mighty Fund-Raiser
description: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa  Speaker John A. Boehner, tanned, relaxed and seeming slightly giddy, slid up to the microphone and tossed off some one-liners to a small group of Iowans who had paid $100 for the pleasure of 12 minutes of his company on a recent Friday evening.

title: Hitting Pause in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An American commanders decision to suspend the training of new Afghan Local Police recruits for at least a month was the first tap on the brakes for what has been a headlong drive to fill out a police force. From the very beginning, the program has been one of the most controversial in the Afghan security plan.

title: U.S. Open: Day 7
description: Andy Roddick put off retirement for at least two days by winning his third-round match, but Lleyton Hewitt saw his Open run come to an end.

title: Federer Is Busiest After the Match
description: The questions started almost as soon as Roger Federers last match ended, same as always, the news media gantlet often longer and more intense than what happened on the court.

title: Data Show a Citys Car Sharing May Be Working, but Doubts Persist
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.  It has been more than two years since officials in this parking-starved city placed a counterintuitive bet: Hoboken would create parking spaces, they said, by taking them away.

title: Footballs Future Rests on Parents as Much as Players
description: Sherman Howard, 87, played professional football for five years and was a longtime high school coach in Chicago. The biggest problem you have now is in coaching, he said. I dont think the kids now have the best of coaching.

title: Lottery Numbers
After Daring Restart, Hunter-Reay Holds On at Grand Prix of Baltimore
description: BALTIMORE  Stacks of tires lined the sharp right turn at the end of the long main straightaway at the Grand Prix of Baltimore, and Ryan Hunter-Reay probably lucked out after the biggest restart of Sundays chaotic race by not barreling into them.

title: Muslims From Abroad Are Thriving in Catholic Colleges
description: DAYTON, Ohio  Arriving from Kuwait to attend college here, Mai Alhamad wondered how Americans would receive a Muslim, especially one whose head scarf broadcasts her religious identity.

title: The Cost of Living Blues
description: Last year, on Feb. 10, in the kind of pronouncement that has become all too familiar, Richard Kramer, the chairman and C.E.O. of Goodyear Tire & Rubber, announced the closing of a plant in Union City, Tenn:

title: To the Boys, Her Role Is Simple: Teammate
description: South Plantation High Schools third-string quarterback was warming up on the sideline before the fourth quarter of a recent preseason game, and each pass was quick, concise and purposeful. The quarterbacks nervous mother, Kathleen DiMeglio, was capturing the moment on video from the bleachers. Then, in an instant, the quarterback vanished from the frame, lost amid the sea of white jerseys.

title: Corrections: September 3, 2012
Slugger Guides Orioles on Strange Path Toward Playoffs
description: Because of Mark Reynolds, certain notions about the Baltimore Orioles may need to be reconsidered.

title: School Choice Is No Cure-All, Harlem Finds
description: When it came time to pick a Harlem middle school for her daughter, Eula Guest did her research. She inquired with friends, principals and PTA presidents, and talked to students inside art studios and auditoriums. I got down to the nitty-gritty, she said. I asked about everything.

title: Presidential Zeal
description: Whether shooting pool, reading to children or working to raise his bowling scores, President Obama cannot contain his competitive nature.

title: The Competitor in Chief
description: As Election Day approaches, President Obama is sharing a few important things about himself. He has mentioned more than once in recent weeks that he cooks a really mean chili. He has impressive musical pitch, he told an Iowa audience. He is a surprisingly good pool player, he informed an interviewer  not to mention (though he does) a doodler of unusual skill.

title: Sharapova Finally Returns to Quarterfinals
description: When Maria Sharapova and Nadia Petrova met at the net for the coin toss before their match Sunday night, it was hard to tell which player was more focused.

title: Breaking It Down: Querrey vs. Berdych
description: Being up a set and a break in a tennis match is not all its cracked up to be.

title: Sporting News
description: Where was a time, not so long ago, when my girlfriend, Rose, and I had the sort of conversations couples across the globe have when reuniting at the end of a long day. We talked about work, about whether to eat in or go out, about trivial gossip regarding the lives of our friends and (more trivially) those of celebrities. All this, however, has come to be replaced by a peculiar, often snippy back-and-forth that begins the moment we see each other and that, to the uninitiated, would sound a whole lot like gibberish.

title: Training Day
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: A Picasso Online for Just $450? Yes, It Is a Steal
description: Bargain hunting online? How about an original Rembrandt for $900 (you can clearly tell its age by the paper, the seller of this etching attests), or a signed piece in ink by Matisse for $1,250. (The artists work is, the online seller notes, radical and unprecedented in the history of Western art.)

title: In China, a Ferrari Crashes and the Party Is Dented
description: HONG KONG  When the chief of staff to President Hu Jintao was moved to a lesser position last week, it sounded like so much inside baseball, a ho-hum reshuffling of personnel as the Chinese Communist Party prepares for a leadership change this autumn.

title: Pitch on the Pasture: Cricket in the Cowboy State
description: The heart of the University of Wyomings campus in Laramie is Prexys Pasture, a big, grassy area surrounded by blue spruce and mountain pine. According to university lore, the pasture was where students grazed their horses in the late 19th century; a standing university rule dictates that the president, or prexy, has sole rights to the area for livestock grazing.

title: Hey, Teacher, Leave Those Kids Alone
description: HONG KONG  Students all around the world have been preparing for the start of the school year this month, and what a start it has been, with protests and scandals in Hong Kong, in London, in the Ivy League.

title: Gasquet Tops N.C.A.A. Champion Johnson
description: When Steve Johnsons final shot sailed long on Sunday, Richard Gasquet of France lifted a fist and shook it wearily in triumph as he walked to shake hands with him.

title: Aliens With Dance Moves and the Midas Touch
description: There might be a utopian vision inside Shirish Kunders Joker, a Bollywood comedy about establishing contact with extraterrestrials, Andy Webster wrote in The New York Times. But if so, its buried under a mountain of static.

title: Twitters Free Speech Defender
description: Alexander Macgillivray, Twitters chief lawyer, says that fighting for free speech is more than a good idea, Somini Sengupta wrote for The New York Times. He thinks it is a competitive advantage for his company.

title: When People Stood on Soapboxes
description: Dear Diary:

title: Avoiding Chaos in His Wake, Button Wins at Spa
description: SPA-FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium  The great track here has seen some of Formula Ones most exciting races, but that excitement has often come from the predictably unpredictable weather, which sometimes has it raining on one part of the track while other parts remain dry.

title: Dodging the Police at the 1968 Democratic Convention
description: One of our favorite photos on the picture desk at The New York Times is a black-and-white image (below) that shows three young men in the back of a police wagon.

title: In Mumbai, Open Spaces Are Rare, and Rarely Open
description: With over 13 million residents, Mumbai has earned its reputation for being a congested city, one where being jostled in crowded spaces is part of daily life.

title: U.S. Vehicle Is Rammed by a Bomber in Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A suicide bomber rammed his explosives-laden vehicle into a sport utility vehicle belonging to the United States Consulate in the northwestern city of Peshawar on Monday morning, Pakistani and American officials said, in one of the most brazen attacks against Americans in the country in recent years.

title: The Early Word: Playing for Keeps
description: Todays Times

title: Bartoli Blitzes Kvitova for Spot in First Open Quarterfinal
description: No. 11 seed Marion Bartoli roared back to beat fifth-seeded Petra Kvitova, 1-6, 6-2, 6-0, on the Grandstand court Sunday to reach her first United States Open quarterfinal. Bartoli, who won the girls singles title in Flushing Meadows in 2001, has now reached the quarterfinal stage of all four Grand Slam tournaments.

title: What to Watch on Monday
description: Its hard to find the right word to describe what Milos Raonic did to James Blake on Saturday.

title: The Twilight of the Public Corporation
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: St. Louis Rams, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
description: Andy Benoit is previewing all 32 N.F.L. teams. Hes entering the home stretch with the last division, the N.F.C. West. First up are the St. Louis Rams.

title: Sept. 2: Split Verdict in Polls on Romney Convention Bounce
description: My view is that the consensus of evidence so far points toward Mitt Romney having received a small bounce in the polls of perhaps two or three percentage points from the Republican convention in Tampa, Fla.

title: Q&A: Replacing a Sealed MacBook Pro Battery
description: Q.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Hanna Rosin on Women Who Support Their Husbands
description: Hanna Rosin wrote this weeks cover storyabout middle-class women in Alabama who are supporting their out-of-work husbands. The article is adapted from her new book, The End of Men: And the Rise of Women, to be published this monthby Riverhead Books. Rosin is a senior editor at The Atlantic and at Slate, where she co-founded the DoubleX blog.

title: Angered Isner Is Upset in Five Sets
description: For John Isner, the 2012 United States Open will be remembered for its major missed opportunities.

title: Fuel Efficiency Standard Could Jump-Start Electric Cars
description: The White House announced last week a significant tightening of future fuel efficiency standards.

title: In Beijing, Clinton Will Push for Talks Over Disputed Islands
description: BEIJING  As tensions mount with its neighbors over islands in nearby strategic waterways, China has scored some subtle victories, making the United States and its allies increasingly uneasy about the potential for violent confrontations.

title: E.U. Trade Commissioner Is Getting a Raw Deal
description: BERLIN  Being the European Union trade commissioner must sometimes be a thankless job, as Karel De Gucht is finding out. He has been fighting long and hard to establish a level playing field with China.

title: In-Store | House Blend
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Britains Paul Ryan
description: In a lot of ways George Osborne, the Chancellor of the Exchequer (finance minister) is Britains answer to Paul Ryan. True, hes a toned-down version  no Ayn Rand, please, were British  but other aspects of package are there in full force: hes articulate, has a vision thats completely at odds with everything we actually know about macroeconomics, and he was for a while the darling not just of the right but of self-proclaimed centrists on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: Monday Reading: Theyre Souvenirs, Not Stuff!
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Dolgopolov Says His Timing Left Him
description: Alexandr Dolgopolov is a chameleon.

title: David Lindsay-Abaire and Naomi Wallace Receive Horton Foote Prize
description: The playwrights David Lindsay-Abaire and Naomi Wallace have been named the 2012 recipients of the Horton Foote Prize, a biennial award named for the playwright and screenwriter who died in 2009 at 92. Mr. Lindsay-Abaires Good People was chosen as the outstanding new American play, and The Liquid Plain by Ms. Wallace received the award for promising new American play. Each winner will receive $15,000 and a photograph of Mr. Foote.

title: Activists Against Corruption Claim Police Harassment
description: Arvind Kejriwal offered himself up for arrest Monday as part of a Jail Bharo or Fill the Jails protest, designed to draw attention to what anti-corruption activists say is police harassment of the movements supporters.

title: On the Lens Blog: Dodging the Police and Tear Gas at the 1968 Democratic Convention
description: When they convened in 1968 in Chicago, the Democrats, like the nation, were deeply divided. Outside the convention, protests got out of hand and the police came down hard  Barton Silverman, a Times photographer, captured it all, including an arrest.

title: Seasonal Parking Bans Please Rockaways Residents but Irk Visitors
description: The houses in Neponsit and Belle Harbor, Queens, out past the last stop on the A train on the Rockaway Peninsula, are not what you picture when you think of New York City. Sandwiched between Jamaica Bay and the Atlantic Ocean, the homes have cedar shingles or vinyl siding, wraparound porches or, occasionally, a modern, boxy structure that stands Hamptons-ready. They are lovely and suburban, and feel very far from the frenetic boom-boom-boom of Midtown footsteps.

title: Welcome to Charlotte, a City of Quirks
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Politicians, delegates, lobbyists, journalists and protesters were gathering on Monday in Charlotte for the Democratic National Convention, which begins on Tuesday. They will find an Old South gold rush town that grew up to be a New South banking center with tall, shiny buildings, artsy statues and a few quirks  from a statue believed to be modeled after Alan Greenspans face to the Disco Chicken.

title: The Week in Political Pictures: August 27-31
description: A look back at the week in politics at the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla.

title: The Quiet American
description: On a quiet street in an unfashionable East Boston neighborhood not far from Logan Airport lives an 84-year-old man whom dictators around the world fear and despise. On the morning I go to meet Gene Sharp, the taxi driver cannot even find his house, and there is no sign on the door to mark the building as headquarters of the Albert Einstein Institution, the nonprofit organization he founded in 1983. When I arrive, Jamila Raqib, the institutions executive director, answers the door dressed in jeans and a T-shirt. We want to be low-key, she says. And keep it that way.

title: Image of the Day: September 3
Chess Gets the Artistic Treatment in a New Saatchi Show
description: Since the new Islamic art galleries opened at the Metropolitan Museum of Art last fall, one of the most popular objects on display has been a chess set dating from 12th-century Iran, one that looks surprisingly modern because the pieces are highly abstracted. The Shah (king), for example, is represented by a large throne.

title: 100 Years After the Titanic, Still Wondering Who Got the Story
description: If newspaper articles had routinely carried reporters bylines 100 years ago, there would be no question now about who got one of the biggest scoops of the early 20th century, the April 18, 1912, interview with the surviving telegraph operator from the Titanic.

title: To Beat the Execution Clock, the Justices Prepare Early
description: WASHINGTON  John Balentine was an hour away from being put to death in Texas last month when the Supreme Court granted him a stay of execution.

title: The Day of Knowledge
description: MOSCOW  My kids are first-class citizens, and so are the children of about half of my friends. The other halfs children are second-class citizens. The second-class citizens had to cut their summer vacations short and rise at the crack of dawn this past Saturday to take part in a brief but bizarre ritual.

title: To Back Democracy, U.S. Prepares to Cut $1 Billion From Egypts Debt
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly 16 months after first pledging to help Egypts failing economy, the Obama administration is nearing an agreement with the countrys new government to relieve $1 billion of its debt as part of an American and international assistance package intended to bolster its transition to democracy, administration officials said.

title: Venice Film Festival: Audiences Cheer P.T. Anderson Film, Jeer Terrence Malicks Entry
description: VENICE  The middle weekend of the Venice Film Festival saw the premieres of the two most eagerly awaited films in the official competition. Both, as it happens, are unorthodox love stories  as well as tales of spiritual crises  by American auteurs with perfectionist reputations and loyal followings.

title: The Stonewall of the West
description: As Generals Robert E. Lee and Thomas J. Stonewall Jackson were winning their smashing victory at the Second Battle of Bull Run in Virginia, another Confederate army triumphed even more decisively at the little known battle of Richmond, Ky., led in part by the man destined to be known as the Stonewall of the West: Gen. Patrick Cleburne. Richmond was potentially even more decisive than Bull Run  it opened Kentucky to Confederate invasion, giving the rebels a possible route to the aorta of the Union war effort, the Ohio River.

title: Too Young to Have a Stroke? Think Again
description: Six years ago, Todd McGee was a lean, athletic 34-year-old working in construction and living with his wife and toddler daughter on Marthas Vineyard, where he spent summer weekends surfing. A stroke changed his life forever.

title: Empire Boulevard, Brooklyn, 5:40 A.M.
Plan for Change in Schools Stirs Protest in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  A plan by the Hong Kong government to require schools to teach courses in contemporary Chinese history has set off an acrimonious dispute here with political implications. The controversy may threaten the prospects of pro-Beijing candidates in the legislative elections scheduled for this Sunday, and it has opened a broader discussion over the citys future.

title: All You Can Eat, All Over Mumbai
description: The Gujaratis are best known in Mumbais culinary scene for thalis, restaurants offering several courses of all-you-can-eat platters of food with a variety of subtle flavors. The restaurants take pride in leaving their customers full; one has a Web site that claims, We serve as long as you can eat.

title: White House Beer: A Brewer Weighs In
description: Now that the White House has revealed its recipe for Honey Brown Ale, brewed by cooks in the White House kitchen using honey from its own hives (along with releasing a nifty video of the beer-making process), I thought it would be worth assessing the recipe and methods, and conjecturing on how the beer would taste. This required a beer-making professional, so I called on Garrett Oliver, brewmaster at the Brooklyn Brewery and editor of the encyclopedic Oxford Companion to Beer.

title: G.O.P. Seizes on a Question: Are You Better Off Than You Were 4 Years Ago?
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican vice presidential nominee, slammed President Obamas handling of the economy on Monday, seizing on hesitant responses by Mr. Obamas top strategists when asked whether the country was better off than it was four years ago.

title: Alex Rodriguez Returns to Yankees Lineup
description: 11:09 p.m. | Updated

title: Arborio and Friends: Multigrain Risottos
description: These days chefs get away with calling all sorts of grainy dishes risottos. Ive seen farro risottos, barley risottos and even quinoa risottos on plenty of menus. The problem with calling these dishes risottos is that if theyre made with grains other than starchy rice like arborio, carnaroli or the rice from the Camargue I used when I was in Provence this summer, they dont have the creamy texture that makes classic risottos so appealing.

title: Warhol Soup Cans, Now at Your Local Target
description: Christies may have been able to get nearly $10 million for a 1962 painting of Andy Warhols Four Campbells Soup Cans back in November, but now everyday shoppers can buy their own piece of the Pop artist for just 75 cents. On Sunday Target started selling a special edition of 1.2 million Warhol-themed tomato soup cans.

title: Really? Some Plants Can Filter Airborne Chemicals
description: THE FACTS

title: Obama Ad Reprises Theme That Romney Would Hurt Middle Class
description: As President Obama kicks off his convention week in Charlotte, N.C., his campaign has a new ad that doubles down on his charges that Mitt Romneys economic policies would harm the middle class.

title: Mitt Romney's American Pictorial
description: New York Times photojournalist Richard Perry has been covering Mitt Romney's presidential bid since 2008. Here, Perry gives insight into the difference in visuals from the two campaigns.

title: The Caucus Click: Madame President?
Citing Health Reasons, Fish Pulls Out
description: Mardy Fish withdrew from the United States Open on Monday, hours before his scheduled fourth-round match against No. 1 Roger Federer, citing health concerns probably related to his continuing heart problems.

title: At Democratic Convention, Rove Can Cause a Stir, Simply by Being Here
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  All was pleasant aboard the shuttle bus ferrying New York Democratic convention delegates to the convention center here Monday morning.

title: Squirrel Watch
description: Q. What has happened to all the squirrels in Central Park? I have not seen any this summer.

title: In Ruined Apartments, a Symbol of Irelands Fall
description: DUBLIN  To visit Graham Ushers dream apartment in Priory Hall, the most notorious of Irelands ruined ghost developments, is to see what Ireland aspired to be, and what it became instead.

title: Inside the Royal Society
description: A selection of objects and images from inside the archives.

title: Anticonvulsant May Relieve Chronic Cough
description: A medicine commonly used for seizures and nerve pain may help treat chronic cough, a new study has found.

title: Abortions Linked to Risk of Preterm Birth
description: Induced abortions may raise the risk for very preterm birth in subsequent pregnancies, a new study reports.

title: Setting the Mood for Smaller Meals
description: A change in fast-food restaurant ambience can affect the amount of food consumed by customers, an unusual study has found.

title: China Faces New Scandal Over Crash of a Ferrari
description: BEIJING  Chinas carefully scripted leadership transition appears to have suffered another glitch: a fatal car crash involving a Ferrari, a privileged son and two women.

title: On Labor Day, Obama Talks Up Auto Bailout in Ohio
description: TOLEDO, Ohio  President Obama pointed to his bailout of the auto industry, which Mitt Romney opposed, as a major argument for his re-election over the Republican rival as he spent a fourth Labor Day with union workers in a swing state.

title: In Pursuit of Truth, Corporeal and Cosmic
description: In the Royal Societys early years, scientists wrote of research both bizarre and elegant, made seemingly uncanny predictions, and sought to reconcile their findings with prevailing beliefs about God. A few samples from the archives:

title: A Redoubt of Learning Holds Firm
description: LONDON  To stroll out of Carlton Gardens into the elegant confines of the Royal Society is to find a trove of centuries-old wonders, from Sir Isaac Newtons reflecting telescope to the first electric machine to fantastical illustrated catalogs of fish and birds.

title: Farm Use of Antibiotics Defies Scrutiny
description: The numbers released quietly by the federal government this year were alarming. A ferocious germ resistant to many types of antibiotics had increased tenfold on chicken breasts, the most commonly eaten meat on the nations dinner tables.

title: European Proposal Presses for Women to Join Boards
description: BRUSSELS  Companies allocating fewer than 40 percent of seats on supervisory boards to women could face serious sanctions later this decade, according to a proposal made Monday by Viviane Reding, the European Union justice commissioner.

title: Syrian Minister Assails Egyptian and Turkish Leaders
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrias top government spokesman declared Monday that the refugees fleeing its borders were welcome back at any time, mocked the leaders of Egypt and Turkey for their condemnations and called the armed opposition unfit for negotiations.

title: Mustards Spiciness Related to Its Hardiness
description: A small family of genes regulates not only the spiciness of mustard plants but also their prospects for survival, scientists report.

title: Jordans King Cancels Fuel Price Rise in Face of Protest
description: AMMAN, Jordan  King Abdullah II of Jordan moved quickly to block a recent increase in fuel prices after angry protesters took to the streets over the weekend, raising the specter of renewed social and political unrest in the cash-poor kingdom.

title: Ancient Warriors Unearthed in Denmark
description: A fractured skull and a thighbone hacked in half were found at the lake.

title: Taking the Measure of a Single Molecule
description: For the first time, a device can measure the mass of a single molecule.

title: A Glimpse of Lobbyists Convention Exile
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Lobbyists are beside themselves: the presidents public cold shoulder has exiled them to the fringes of the convention. Just how far afield?

title: Literature in Any Language: Journal Takes That Literally
description: When the first issue of its new Chinese-language edition appears next month, the London-based literary journal Granta, a publication that has existed in English since the Victorian era, will have a presence in four of the five most widely spoken languages. But plans for the globalization of a leading quarterly that proudly calls itself the magazine of new writing dont stop there.

title: Tuberculosis: Stubborn and Expensive to Treat, Drug-Resistant Strains Show Growth
description: A new study has confirmed, once again, that hard-to-cure drug-resistant tuberculosis is a growing problem.

title: School Bullies Prey on Children With Autism
description: Connie Anderson didnt know what was bothering her 17-year-old son, a Baltimore-area high school senior with Aspergers syndrome, a form of autism. He was usually a diligent student, but his grades began to plummet.

title: Battling Progress and Other Demons
description: The title of Michael Chabons pungent new novel, Telegraph Avenue, refers, of course, to the famous Telegraph Avenue that bridges Berkeley and Oakland, Calif., that frisky, clamorous thoroughfare so identified, since the 1960s, with the counterculture and community life.

title: Dreamers Who Sell Out on the Road to Success
description: Whether you love or hate Dreamgirls, the vintage Michael Bennett musical about the rise and death of a 1960s singing group that strongly resembles the Supremes, you cannot deny the power of its signature number. When Jennifer Holliday opened her mouth to sing And I Am Telling You Im Not Going at the Imperial Theater in 1981, Frank Rich wrote in The New York Times, Broadway history was made. And Dion Millingtons performance as Effie at the Harlem Repertory Theaters inviting chamber production of the show is a thrilling reminder of how and why. The lyricist, Tom Eyen (who also wrote the book), and the composer, Henry Krieger, gave theater an undeniable moment of greatness.

title: Overtreatment as Myth (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Focus Hocus Pocus, Redux
description: Oh, dear. Dean Baker is on the case; were back to Obama should have ditched health reform to focus on the economy.

title: Rodriguez Returns; Lead Slips to One
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  As the Yankees once-formidable lead in the American League East continues to slip from their hands like melting ice on a hot day, they continue to talk about it as if it is still something they can hold onto. They may be able to, but if the lead continues to dwindle at its current rate, the Yankees will be in second place by Wednesday.

title: Remnants of Japans Tsunami Attract an Archaeological Interest
description: ABOARD THE SEA DRAGON, 1,000 miles east of Japan  After narrowly avoiding a typhoon, battling seasickness and being pelted by rain for days on end, crew members aboard the Sea Dragon were galvanized by the sight of a stranded boat.

title: Floating Debris
description: The tsunami that hit Japan in March 2011 swept an estimated 5 million tons of debris into the ocean.

title: Crops in India Wilt in a Weak Monsoon Season
description: MURUMA, India  Vilas Dinkar Mukane lives halfway around the world from the corn farmers of Iowa, but the Indian sharecropper is at risk of losing his livelihood for the same reason: not enough rain.

title: Ryan Adds Some Loaded Examples to Question of Better Off?
description: 9:02 p.m. | Updated  A revised version of this post is available here.

title: New Virus Tied to Ticks Poses Puzzle for Doctors
description: For a year and a half, scientists have been swarming over a 100-acre farm in northwestern Missouri, catching ticks and drawing blood from raccoons, possums, turkeys and deer.

title: Treating Osteoporosis (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Risks for Travelers (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Exercise in Conflict (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: With Diversity Still Lacking, Industry Focuses on Retention
description: FOR many in the advertising business, the results of the 2010 census were a tipping point in terms of highlighting the growing importance of minority consumers. It showed that there were more than 50 million Latinos in the United States, nearly 40 million African-Americans and almost 15 million Asians. Nine million people identified themselves as belonging to more than one race.

title: A Conversation with Michelle A. Rhee
description: Michael D. Shear speaks with former commissioner of D.C. schools, Michelle Rhee, at the Democratic National Convention. She is now the C.E.O. of the education reform advocacy group, "StudentsFirst."

title: The Caucus Click: Michelle Obama on the Convention Floor
Eating Right Between Meetings
description: The stereotype of business trip dining consisted of an artery-clogging succession of meeting-room pastries, oversize restaurant portions and fast food snagged at the airport. Anyone on a vegetarian or gluten-free diet had an especially hard time.

title: Stanford Scientists Cast Doubt on Advantages of Organic Meat and Produce
description: Does an organic strawberry contain more vitamin C than a conventional one?

title: Romney Spends Labor Day at Home
description: BOSTON  On Monday, the traditional start of the general election campaign, President Obama rallied a crowd of thousands in Toledo, Ohio. Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. drummed up support in Detroit. And Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, spoke to an overflow audience in North Carolina, the state where the Democrats were set to open their national convention this week.

title: Dimensions of Data, Turned Into Art That Speaks
description: Scientists and engineers have a tremendous capacity to detect, track, measure and otherwise observe phenomena of all kinds. This growing capacity is perhaps their most powerful tool. But it presents problems, too, because it is no easy task to marshal this flood of data and present it in ways that others  or sometimes even they themselves  can understand and make use of it.

title: Use of Inhalers May Affect Growth
description: Children who use glucocorticoid inhalers to prevent asthma attacks may be shorter as adults, researchers said on Monday.

title: Relief for Severe Asthma, at a High Price
description: For two decades, Patricia DiGiusto struggled with severe asthma. Powerful medications and frequent use of her inhaler could not prevent repeated trips to the emergency room.

title: Rare Infection Prompts Neti Pot Warning
description: Neti pots  those odd teapotlike vessels used to wash out the nasal passage  have won legions of fans who rely on them for relief from allergies, congestion and colds.

title: How to Cope at the Airport Without a Wallet
description: DESPITE all the traveling I do, Im still a bit of a nervous flier. Therefore, it doesnt really make any sense that I flew with the Blue Angels last year after they offered the University of Rochester one seat on one of their planes. Several of us at the university received an e-mail invitation, and the first person to respond would get to go. I responded first. I figured it would be a good thing to do, until the day started approaching.

title: Science Times Podcast
description: The Royal Society; and a food safety conundrum.

title: Flying Nonstop to Bangkok? Time for Airborne Theater
description: I WAS at the airport in Singapore some years ago chatting with an oil company roustabout who was waiting to board Singapore Airlines for its 19-hour nonstop flight to Newark. He was traveling in business class, which features sumptuous food and free-flowing drink, seats that recline into lie-flat beds and an in-flight entertainment system with 80 on-demand movies available on personal high-definition screens.

title: A Conversation With the Keynote Speaker
description: Houston Bureau Chief Manny Fernandez talks to rising Democratic star Julin Castro, the mayor of San Antonio.

title: Music From Matchbox Twenty, Animal Collective and Jason Lescalleet
description: MATCHBOX TWENTYNorth (Atlantic)

title: Think You Know Loud? Try Throbbing Sound as the Body Vibrates
description: The live sound of Sunn O))) can draw you toward a kind of negative listening: paying attention to the movements between notes rather than the notes themselves. On Sunday  in hooded robes and in front of 18 amplifier cabinets  the two guitarists in the band, Greg Anderson and Stephen OMalley, made those movements, slow slidings up or down the neck, sound like buildings crumpling in slow motion. A fantastic, physical, indeterminate sound.

title: Five Questions for Michelle Rhee
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Michelle A. Rhee, the former schools chancellor in Washington, D.C., is now pushing education reform through her organization Students First  and continuing to annoy the teachers unions along the way.

title: With First-Round Open Juniors Victory, Less Teasing by the Other Kids
description: Tornado Alicia Black, 14, of Boca Raton, Fla., won her first-round match in the United States Open junior girls tournament with a bandaged left thigh and a stiff back that required a trainers assistance.

title: Stevie Wonder Backtracks on Comments About Frank Ocean
description: Stevie Wonder has issued a statement clarifying comments he had made about the R&B singer Frank Ocean, who recently surprised the hyper-masculine world of urban music by acknowledging on his Tumblr site that hed fallen in love with a man several years ago.

title: The Agenda: Climate Change
description: New York Times environment reporter John Broder says Mitt Romney is not a proponent of government action on climate change, while President Obama knows a climate change bill won't realistically pass.

title: Film Festival With Truths to Tell
description: TELLURIDE, Colo.  A film festival held almost 9,000 feet above sea level on a holiday weekend may not be the likeliest setting for philosophical speculation, but for the past four days the Telluride Film Festival has offered something like a seminar on the nature of truth. In an age of reality television, journalistic fakery and political mendacity everyone knows that words and images can distort and mislead. And film is a particularly unstable medium, alluring us with a promise of honesty while it feeds us ever more elaborate fantasies.

title: Staying Back Is a Losing Strategy for Isner
Social Media Site Creates Buzz With Convention Parties
description: At the Republican convention last week, the big bash sponsored by BuzzFeed at the Florida Aquarium in Tampa was among the most exotic and most talked about, featuring mermaids (undulating in full fin alongside fish in glass tanks) and penguins (sitting adorably in little wagons, with a helpful handler reminding revelers that, yes, even cute penguins do bite).

title: Mets Comeback Hopes Hindered by Disputed Call in Loss to Cardinals
description: ST. LOUIS  As reporters filed into the visiting managers office at Busch Stadium on Monday morning, one mentioned to Terry Collins that the Mets were roughly the same number of games outside a playoff spot that the St. Louis Cardinals were one year ago during their exhilarating World Series-winning run.

title: Expectation of Stimulus Lifts European Markets
description: European stocks rose for a second day on Monday, and copper advanced on speculation that central banks would take more steps to stimulate growth, as reports signaled that the global economic slowdown was deepening. The markets in the United States were closed for the Labor Day holiday.

title: Electronic and Hip-Hop, and Lots of It
description: One weekend, two festivals. Whats a critic to do?

title: Environment and Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Secretive Shell Corporations
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: The True Costs of Private Schools
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Reducing Air Pollution
description: To the Editor:

title: Project Aims to Harness the Power of Waves
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  About 15 years ago, this environmentally conscious state with a fir tree on its license plates began pushing the idea of making renewable energy from the ocean waves that bob and swell on the Pacific horizon. But then one of the first test-buoy generators, launched with great fanfare, promptly sank. It was not a good start.

title: With Time Running Out, 3 Chase Fixtures Are Back in the Pack
description: HAMPTON, Ga.  It has seemed preordained that the Chase for the Sprint Cup, Nascars playoff wrapped into a season, involves Jeff Gordon, Carl Edwards and Kyle Busch.

title: How Plan to Help City Pay Pensions Backfired
description: Jeffrey A. Michael, a finance professor in Stockton, Calif., took a hard look at his citys bankruptcy this summer and thought he saw a smoking gun: a dubious bond deal that bankers had pushed on Stockton just as the local economy was starting to tank in the spring of 2007, he said.

title: Moodys Reduces Its Outlook for Europes Credit Rating
description: Moodys Investors Service cut the European Unions credit outlook to negative on Monday, reflecting the risks to Germany, France, Britain and the Netherlands, the four countries in the group with AAA ratings, which account for about 45 percent of the groups budget revenue.

title: Tempers Cool in Brooklyn After Pools Rocky Rebirth
description: On a recent morning at McCarren Park Pool in Brooklyn, the crowds that had gathered there soon after it reopened were nowhere to be seen. Gone were the litter and the noise they brought with them, and gone was the heat wave that had throttled New York in early July, raising tensions in the long lines that had stretched around the pool.

title: Valeant to Buy Medicis, Maker of Dermatology Drugs
description: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, the largest publicly traded drug maker in Canada, agreed to buy Medicis Pharmaceutical on Monday for about $2.6 billion to expand in dermatological products.

title: In Charlotte, as in Tampa, the Weather Becomes a Worry
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Mother Nature is apparently bipartisan in her wrath.

title: Fears Rising, Spaniards Pull Out Their Cash and Get Out of Spain
description: LONDON  It is, Julio Vildosola concedes, a very big bet.

title: Electric Zoo and Rock the Bells Festivals
description: Music festivals feature two descendants of 70s disco, laptops at the ready.

title: From First Shot to Last, Williams Is Dominant
description: Serena Williams shouts, shrieks, squats, slouches, grimaces, huffs and puffs, grits her teeth and purses her lips and, on occasion, stares into her racket as if it were a mirror magnifying every little wrinkle and imperfection. And this is when she is winning.

title: First Lady Strives for Caring Image Above Partisan Fray
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  This is how Michelle Obama delivers a hug: The nearly six-foot-tall first lady envelops her target, her long arms often wrapping all the way around the recipients back. She leans in close, unafraid to press her body against a strangers. Working crowds with her husband, she sometimes falls behind him, because he is more of a hand-shaker or high-fiver, and in the second-to-second choreography of a rope line, the Michelle Obama hug takes time.

title: Federal Trial Set to Open for Ex-Mayor of Detroit
description: During his nearly seven-year stint as mayor of Detroit, there was little about Kwame M. Kilpatrick that was not big. His 6-foot-4 frame. His hip-hop mayor persona and the 1 -carat diamond that pierced his ear. His wide appeal made him, at the age of 31, the youngest person ever to lead the city.

title: Multinationals Stake a Claim in Venture Capital
description: MENLO PARK, Calif.  New York, London and Hong Kong are common addresses for blue-chip multinationals. Now Silicon Valley is, too.

title: Northern Ireland: Protesters Injure Police Officers in Belfast
description: The police said Monday that 47 police officers were injured Sunday when Protestant protesters angered by a Catholic parade in northern Belfast threw homemade bombs, bricks and fireworks. Four officers were hospitalized, and 43 were treated at the scene. The police used a water cannon to disperse hundreds of protesters, some as young as 12, and one person was arrested, the police said. Chief Superintendent George Clarke said most of the violence occurred after the parade and was aimed at police officers who were trying to keep the two sides apart. Late Monday night, a second round of sectarian clashes in Belfast left nine officers injured, Reuters reported.

title: A Summer of Easy Guns and Dead Children
description: In Harlem, Paula Shaw-Leary talks of her youngest, Matt, who got his college degree in May and was accepted to graduate school, a soulful-eyed young man with a broad nose and an impish sense of humor.

title: Largest Settlements Under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act
description: The largest settlements have not been with American companies.

title: Foreign Firms Most Affected by a U.S. Law Barring Bribes
description: A law intended to prohibit the payment of bribes to foreign officials by United States businesses has produced more than $3 billion in settlements. But a list of the top companies making these settlements is notable in one respect: its lack of American names.

title: A Woman Finds a Niche in a Cuban Tradition
description: Ana Prez reached into a pile of Connecticut shade tobacco leaves and placed one on the small table in front of her. She began spraying the leaf with water and carving it up with a chaveta knife.

title: Trick Shot Ignites Doubles Comeback
description: A between-the-legs trick shot may have kept alive the Bryan brothers chances of winning their fifth United States Open title. Down a set, Bob and Mike Bryan were two points from losing their third-round match when Bob Bryan executed the shot and followed it with a winner.

title: Health Issue Leads Fish to Withdraw Before Federer Match
description: On the day when Rafael Nadal announced that he was extending his break from tennis for two more months, he ended up sending long-distance condolences to another player with physical concerns: Mardy Fish.

title: Lobbyists and Friends in Exile (Wink, Wink)
description: Rules are rules, and President Obamas scrupulous restrictions on lobbyists have exiled them to the fringes of the convention in Charlotte, N.C.

title: Another Star Turn by McIlroy and Hard American Choices
description: NORTON, Mass.  The final round of the Deutsche Bank Championship was shaping up to be golfs version of Americas Got Talent, with at least seven competitors vying for the last four United States Ryder Cup spots before a national television audience and a judging panel headed by Davis Love III.

title: People Dont Vote When No One Asks Them To
description: The Democrats selected Julin Castro, the mayor of San Antonio, to deliver the keynote address at their national convention  the same honor that propelled State Senator Barack Obama into the national spotlight just eight years ago  as part of its courtship of Latino voters, whom the President needs to vote in large numbers if he wants to be re-elected. As it happens, as the campaign manager for a young, outsider candidate for San Antonios city council in 2011, I learned something simple but crucial: while younger Latinos are increasingly the focus of national political strategists, they are still largely ignored at the local level.

title: A Vast Frank Lloyd Wright Archive Is Moving to New York
description: The Modernist architect Frank Lloyd Wright wasnt a hoarder. But he did save just about everything  whether a doodle on a Plaza Hotel cocktail napkin of an imagined city on Ellis Island, his earliest pencil sketch of the spiraling Guggenheim Museum or a model of Broadacre City, his utopian metropolis. Since Wrights death in 1959 those relics have been locked in storage at his former headquarters  Taliesin, in Spring Green, Wis., and Taliesin West, in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Obama Makes Detour to Visit Hurricane Site
description: KENNER, La.  President Obama took a short detour from campaigning on Monday to inspect the damage wrought by Hurricane Isaac last week and the government response, a stop that took on outsized political overtones in this campaign season.

title: Union Jobs Plummet in the Private Sector
description: New York City has regained all of the jobs it lost during the last recession, but its labor unions have not, and the steep decline in the last several years may signal a lasting erosion of one of the few remaining bastions of union power, according to the authors of a report to be released this week.

title: Frank Lloyd Wrights Archives
description: MOMA and Columbia University are teaming up to make Wrights archive more accessible to the public.

title: The Man Behind Facebooks I.P.O. Debacle
description: It is David Ebersmans fault. There is just no way around it.

title: Michael Clarke Duncan, Actor, Dies at 54
description: Michael Clarke Duncan, who rose from working as a ditch digger to employ his booming bass voice and immense physical presence in many movie roles, most notably a tragic prisoner with a healing touch in the 1999 film The Green Mile, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 54.

title: Citibank Hid Firms Financial Troubles, Ex-Partner at Dewey & LeBoeuf Says
description: There has been no shortage of finger-pointing since the collapse of the law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf, with most of the animus directed toward the firms managing partner and its broader leadership.

title: As of Tuesday, Yellow Cabs Can Charge Higher Rates
description: Yellow taxis may begin charging more on Tuesday, ushering in an approved fare increase for riders, whose rates have remained virtually unchanged since 2006.

title: In Final Tournament, Roddick Is Last American Man Standing
Bennett Seeks Tighter Bond With His Quarterback
