description: The NBC series starts on Sept. 17.

title: A Cadillac XTS for All Occasions
description: In his recent review of the 2013 Cadillac XTS for the Automobiles section, John Pearley Huffman noted that Cadillacs new luxury sedan would soon colonize the curbside check-in areas of airports throughout the United States, supplanting the discontinued Lincoln Town Car as the countrys livery workhorse.

title: Excerpt: 'Guys with Kids'
description: The new NBC series starts on Sept. 12.

title: Excerpt: Animal Practice
description: The new NBC series starts on Sept. 26.

title: Excerpt: Chicago Fire
description: The new NBC series starts on Oct. 10.

title: Smartphone? Presto! 2-Way Radio
description: Cave drawings, smoke signals, letters, Pony Express, telegrams, phone calls, text messages. From the dawn of civilization, man has experimented with different modes of communication, each with pros and cons. Smoke signals, for example, contribute to far fewer car accidents than text messages. Text messages, on the other hand, leave much less soot.

title: Despite New Fame, Still Struck by Stars
description: THE bloggers behind TomandLorenzo.com have been to countless fashion shows, but one stands out as surreal. It was Oscar de la Rentas pre-fall collection last December, a tough ticket to score. Not only were the pair seated front row, but Anna Wintour was six seats away.

title: War Horse Is to Close in January
description: In choosing to close the Tony Award-winning hit play War Horse, Lincoln Center Theater and its producing partners decided that the costs of running the show, with its elaborate production and cast of 37, were too big to guarantee profitability. The show is midway through its second year, an unusually long run for a nonmusical on Broadway.

title: Ryan Says Prayer in Schools Is a State Issue
description: PROVO, Utah  Prayer in public schools was prohibited by the United States Supreme Court in 1962, but Representative Paul D. Ryan said on Wednesday that he believed that states should have the right to decide whether it should be allowed.

title: Report Assails Palm Oil Project in Cameroon
description: On Tuesday, we told you about land grabs by timber companies in Liberia that are threatening that countrys tropical rain forest. Today environmental groups and forestry experts are abuzz about a project in nearby Cameroon that is overseen by Herakles Farms, an affiliate of the New York-based company Herakles Capital that pursues agricultural initiatives in Africa.

title: Homes for $925,000
description: Properties in Virginia, Miami Beach and Hawaii.

title: What You Get for ... $925,000
description: ALEXANDRIA, VA.

title: House Hunting in ... Denmark
description: FOUR-BEDROOM VILLA NEAR A FOREST OUTSIDE COPENHAGEN

title: Four-Bedroom Villa Near a Forest Outside Copenhagen
description: A wood house built in 1917 and located on the edge of a forest north of Copenhagen, Denmark, is on the market for $2.5 million.

title: Fact-Checking the Democratic Platform
description: The Democratic Party platform, released this week during the convention in Charlotte, N.C., contained a number of exaggerated or misleading claims in civil liberties and housing.

title: Bill Clintons Democratic Convention Speeches
description: Former President Bill Clinton has spoken in prime time at every Democratic National Convention since 1988, in roles from rising star to former president, candidate to party luminary. The following is a collection of all of those speeches.

title: Spotify Is Said to Profit From Its Subscribers, but Lose More Luring Them
description: Media Decoder recently looked at the books of Spotify and Pandora, two of the most popular digital music services, and noted that both companies  despite having very different business models  wind up paying most of their revenue in music royalties.

title: Painting by the Beatles Heads to Auction
description: A painting created collaboratively by all four Beatles in 1966 is being offered as part of a music memorabilia sale by Philip Weiss Auctions, in Oceanside, N.Y., on Sept. 14. The auction house estimates that the painting, now called Images of a Woman, will sell for between $80,000 and $120,000.

title: Despite Rainy Day, Dickey Records 18th Victory
description: ST. LOUIS  R. A. Dickey added more credibility to his campaign for a Cy Young Award and took another step toward a 20-win season Wednesday afternoon, as he guided the Mets to a 6-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: For a Baby, Mobile Screens to Shake and Rattle
description: My two babies have one thing in common that they dont share with me. Some of their first toys were software apps on mobile devices that are more powerful than the computers that took Neil Armstrong to the moon.

title: Two Veterans Give a Nod to a Talented Youngster
description: Michael Feinstein, Marilyn Maye and Justin Bieber, together at last. Well, not quite. But at the opening on Tuesday night of Mr. Feinstein and Ms. Mayes show Swingin the Night Away at Feinsteins at Loews Regency, the big surprise was the appearance of a fresh-faced 16-year-old crooner, Nick Ziobro.

title: Cliff Hanger | Chris Sharma
description: The California native (who lives in Catalonia, Spain, the sports new epicenter) on the challenges of rock climbing.

title: Putin Pulls Off Latest Feat: Flying With the Birds
description: MOSCOW  Vladimir V. Putin is the unquestioned supreme leader of Russia, known for his icy stare and steely ways. But now Mr. Putin has taken on a new, perhaps more tender, leadership role. He has guided a flock of birds  through the air.

title: Football, Yes Sir!
description: The reporter Joe Drape looks at the challenges of playing college football at West Point.

title: Weather Vain
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Rock Star
description: The climber Chris Sharma tackles the toughest peaks in the world. But when it comes to skin care, hes totally down to earth.

title: Working a Crowd Is Part of the Act
description: Ten minutes after Mitt Romney finished his speech at the Republican National Convention last week Judah Friedlander walked onstage at the Comedy Cellar in Manhattan and got to work solving the worlds problems.

title: Live Updates From the Democratic Convention
description: The Times will be providing updates and analysis from Charlotte on our live dashboard. You can also follow along on Twitter @thecaucus, or follow our list of Times journalists covering the convention.

title: Study Finds Increased Risks for N.F.L. Players
description: A disproportionate number of men who played at least five seasons in the N.F.L. from 1959 to 1988 developed Alzheimers disease or Lou Gehrigs disease, according to a study released Wednesday.

title: Two Amsterdam Museums to Reopen After Major Renovations
description: For years, two major Amsterdam museums  the Stedelijk and the Rijksmuseum  have been largely closed for renovations, with only some of their prized artworks on public view. But that is about to change.

title: Jodi Picoult Changes Publishers
description: The best-selling author Jodi Picoult has jumped to Ballantine Bantam Dell from Atria for her next book deal, a three-book acquisition that the company announced on Wednesday. The first novel is scheduled for release in 2014. Ms. Picoult is the author of 19 novels including Sing You Home and House Rules. Her novels have more than 22 million copies in print.

title: Excerpt: 'Made in Jersey'
description: The new CBS series starts on Sept. 28.

title: Web Sites With a Historical Bent Join a Place to an Image
description: Jon Voss went to Washington last year with a very specific plan: to pose for a photo at the Jefferson Memorial with the Washington Monument in the background.

title: Stone Links: Is Doping Cheating?
description: Human enhancement has been high on the minds of philosophers in the wake of the Lance Armstrong affair. At The Atlantic, Evan Selinger wonders how the argument that Armstrong still deserves our sympathy even if he is guilty of using banned substances might affect our approach to problems like sustainability and climate change. Feeling bad for Lance, Selinger suggests, is roughly analogous to feeling bad for the present state of the world, and thus less conducive to attacking its problems.

title: Filial Piety: From Strangling Tigers to Taming the Internet
description: A selection of 14th-century parables reworked by the Chinese government to encourage parental devotion in modern times.

title: The Buzz
description: A PREVIEW of the A-list parties and dinners during New York Fashion Week. Strictly invitation only, unless otherwise noted. Photographs from last nights parties are at nytimes.com/fashion.

title: For U.S. Open Grounds Crew, an Arsenal to Combat Wet Courts
description: For most of last week, they were out of sight, out of mind. This week, they have been working around the clock.

title: Inside the Actors Abode
description: The actor B.D. Wong has taken several years to settle into his loft on East Fourth Street.

title: Every Last Thing Finally in Its Place
description: BRADLEY DARRYL WONG is finally settling into his apartment. Not that the place, a ground-floor loft with a subterranean bedroom on East Fourth Street, is new, exactly. Mr. Wong, otherwise known as B. D., bought it in 2005 and moved in, sort of, four years ago.

title: Hearing Voices in the Clutter
description: HOUSES, if we look and listen, have secrets to tell us. I didnt fully understand my parents until I finally faced up to emptying their house. Doing so would have been hard at any time, but it was even harder because I had waited 20 years after their deaths.

title: Its Time to Leave the Farm
description: A couples farm, overgrown with memories.

title: Saying Goodbye to the Farm
description: ITS time to leave the farm in Maryland.

title: Shopping for Kitchen Counter Stools
description: The founders of the Brooklyn design firm Workstead go shopping for special-height stools for kitchen islands.

title: Counter Stools
description: IN planning kitchens for clients, the founders of the Brooklyn design firm Workstead have discovered theres one piece of furniture that is particularly hard to find: the counter-height stool.

title: Open Teams at Second World Mind Sports Games
description: The performance by Sweden in winning the Open Teams at the Second World Mind Sports Games in France last month was remarkable.

title: Designing Sets for Oprah, Ellen, Tyra and Now Ricki
description: Ricki Lake, who next week begins her second go-round as a daytime talk-show host with The Ricki Lake Show, lives in a house thats beautiful but not too precious, likes the color purple and follows a somewhat green lifestyle. She also wanted her new set to feel less like a stage and more like someones living room, where everyones opinion is heard.

title: Turning the Tables on Gravity
description: Marcello Pozzi, the Italian architect and designer now living in Los Angeles, has designed his first mass-produced piece for the home. Commissioned by Restoration Hardware for its fall line, the Stack 50 table consists of 50 discs of plywood. Forty-eight inches wide, it has a metal disc embedded in the tabletop that secures a metal rod to keep the discs in place, and an asymmetrical base that juts hither and yon in the spirit of a bonsai. The table costs $2,495, and much is made in the promotional materials of its design: Stack 50 taunts gravity by shifting each disc away from the rods axis.

title: Eye Candy With a Sweet Center
description: Stephen Johnsons goal in designing Kiss for Artecnica was to create a lamp that demands to be touched. It was important for me to give it a real physicality, said Mr. Johnson, a London-based designer, adding that the versatile piece can be plunked on a desk as a task lamp or dangled over a table as a pendant. Its something you want to pick up and explore.

title: Explorations in Glass, Deceptively Simple
description: In 2009, the Belgian designer Sylvain Willenz began working with CIRVA, a research center in Marseilles, France, to explore new ways to manipulate glass. Today, in a show called Glassworks, the Victor Hunt gallery in Brussels will unveil the results of his experiments with the moody material: Shift, an asymmetrical side table (about $11,100); Spot, a globe-shaped lamp sprinkled with glass shards (about $4,160); and Block, above, a collection of geometric containers (from about $1,575).

title: Accessories That Can Withstand a Little Steam
description: Since the release of his first collection of bathroom accessories for Kontextr earlier this year, Josh Owen has been exploring what he calls other overlooked opportunities for that often overlooked room. Four of them were introduced last month at the New York International Gift Fair: two mirrors, a toilet-paper holder and a towel rack/accessories holder, all in silicone. The bathroom is such a wet environment, and most things are made of materials that are fighting the relationship with moisture, Mr. Owen said. Silicone can live on in perpetuity in those challenging conditions.

title: Sales at Sferra, Desiron, Westin Hotels and Resorts and Others
description: Sferra will offer up to 75 percent off first-quality discontinued and overstocked bedding from Wednesday to Sept. 16 (a queen-size Sasha 100-percent Egyptian cotton sateen jacquard duvet set, above, usually $890, will be $445; a queen-size Franco 600-thread-count cotton sheet set, usually $190, will be $75); Chelsea Market, 75 Ninth Avenue (15th Street), sferra.com.

title: Orioles Expecting Sellouts for Yankees Series
description: The Baltimore Orioles are expecting sellouts, or close to them, when they host the Yankees beginning Thursday night for what is arguably their biggest four-game series since 1997.

title: As China Ages, Beijing Turns to Morality Tales to Spur Filial Devotion
description: BEIJING  Reading it now, six centuries after Guo Jujing wrote this paean to parental devotion, The 24 Paragons of Filial Piety comes off as a collection of scary bedtime stories. There is the woman who cut out her own liver to feed her sick mother, the boy who sat awake shirtless all night to draw mosquitoes away from his slumbering parents and the man who sold himself into servitude to pay for a fathers funeral.

title: Chavez Takes Part in Pregame Ritual
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Eric Chavez wants to be a major league manager one day, and he got some practice Tuesday night when he was asked, minutes before the first pitch, to carry the lineup card to the home plate conference with the umpires.

title: Same Museum, but a Brand-New Look
description: FOR a few years there, museum construction projects seemed to be synonymous with lavish and expensive new architecture. But lately the thoughtful renovation of existing buildings has enjoyed something of a renaissance, and this fall a few notable examples are coming to fruition.

title: Making Room for Returning Offspring
description: OUR 23-year-old daughter, Rikki, recently returned home from nursing school to embark on her career, and found she had been downsized by her loving siblings to the worst bedroom in the house: a dark 63-square-foot green vise thats less than half the size of her previous room.

title: A Lot of Fuss for Just Sitting and Watching at New York Fashion Week
description: LAST September, Beyonc Knowles, with budding baby bump swaddled in the shimmering gold sequins of her plunging cocktail dress, turned up at Lincoln Center for the J. Crew Spring 2012 presentation with her sister Solange.

title: Reaction to Change of Venue for Obamas Speech
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  While a decision to move President Obamas speech at the Democratic National Convention to a smaller venue might have left some volunteers and visitors here feeling left out in the cold  or the rain, as the weather forecast was predicting  many took it in stride, their support for the President undiminished.

title: Romney Focus Is on Preparing for the Debates
description: WEST WINDSOR, Vt.  The sessions begin at 9 a.m. in the living room of a friends mountainside getaway here in Vermonts verdant interior. There are three folding tables: one for Senator Rob Portman of Ohio, who plays President Obama; one for Peter Flaherty, a senior aide who plays the moderator; and one for Mitt Romney, who plays himself.

title: The N.F.L.'s Conundrum
description: William C. Rhoden discusses how one of the games most popular attributes is bound to lead to changes that will cause the National Football Leagues downfall.

title: Spy Chief for Qaddafi Is Extradited to Libya
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis intelligence chief was extradited to Libya by Mauritania on Wednesday, handing a victory to the new Tripoli government in an international tug of war over the chance to put him on trial for murder and war crimes.

title: A Clarification to My Prior Post
description: I wrote vaguely. I wrote badly. I was misconstrued, and it was entirely my fault.

title: A Day of Protests, Spared of Confrontations
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Protesters returned to the streets of Charlotte for a fourth consecutive day on Wednesday, but this time without confrontation or arrests as the Democratic National Convention continued.

title: Head Injuries Pose a Serious Problem for the N.F.L.
description: William C. Rhoden discusses how one of the games most popular attributes is bound to lead to changes that will cause the National Football Leagues downfall.

title: Friends Remember a Big-Hearted Broadcaster
description: Some of his friends chose a New York nightclub rather than a tennis court to bid a proper farewellto Barry MacKay, who died in June at age 76.

title: Yankees Mood Not Shaken
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Shortly after 4:30 p.m. on Wednesday the visitors clubhouse at Tropicana Field emptied and the players and coaches went into a side room for a meeting to address their recent crises.

title: Jodi Picoult Changes Publishers
description: The best-selling author Jodi Picoult has jumped to Ballantine Bantam Dell from Atria for her next book deal, a three-book acquisition that Ballantine announced on Wednesday. The first novel is scheduled for release in 2014.

title: Excerpt: 'Vegas'
description: The new CBS series starts on Sept. 25.

title: Excerpt: 'Partners'
description: The new CBS series starts on Sept. 24.

title: Excerpt: 'Elementary'
description: The new CBS series starts on Sept. 27.

title: Is The Economy On The Mend?
description: Advance excerpts from Bill Clintons big speech tonight have him making the obvious argument:

title: Qatar Imperils Big Merger of Commodity Companies
description: A huge merger in the natural resources business is close to falling apart.

title: Germany: Officials in Berlin Clarify Guidelines on Circumcision
description: In the first move to create legal clarity since a court ruling in June equated circumcision with bodily injury, justice officials in Berlin laid out guidelines on Wednesday to allow the practice to continue in the city pending nationwide legislation that is expected to back the procedure. The move comes after an outcry from doctors who feared they could be prosecuted for carrying out circumcisions after the June 26 ruling in a Cologne court. While it is not applicable in other jurisdictions, it created legal confusion across the country. The ruling also provoked strong protests from religious communities in Germany and abroad. The Berlin guidelines stipulate that both parents must confirm they wish to have their son circumcised because of religious beliefs and that the practice must be performed in a sterile environment.

title: $1 Pizza Slice Is Back After a Sidewalk Showdown Ends Two Parlors Price War
description: The signs have been changed. The invectives have softened. The products remain, well, unlikely to win any culinary awards.

title: Gay Democrats Celebrate a Newfound Visibility
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  After years of struggling for attention and recognition from the nations political parties, gays and lesbians have catapulted to the forefront of the Democratic convention here, prominent on the stage, in speeches, in the platform and at parties that go on after the proceedings have finished.

title: Rachel Comey: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Like the Army Itself, Recruiters Prepare to Make Do With Less
description: WASHINGTON  From Uncle Sam saying I want YOU through Be All You Can Be to todays Army Strong, the United States Army has tailored its recruiting strategy to fill its ranks in war and in peace, in the years of the draft and with an all-volunteer force. It has reframed its education targets, sometimes opening its doors to high school dropouts, at other times pursuing college graduates and, more recently, finding a way to assess home-schooled students.

title: Russia: Police Convoy Is Attacked in Restive Ingushetia
description: Five people died and at least one was wounded when a police convoy came under attack on Wednesday in the volatile southern Russian republic of Ingushetia. A hidden explosive device ripped through the first of the convoys two vehicles as it moved through the republics Sunzhen district, said a local official of the Investigative Committee. Unidentified fighters then opened fire from a nearby wooded area before fleeing, the Investigative Committee said. Officials have begun an investigation and are searching for the attackers. The bombing came after several weeks of increased violence in the North Caucasus region.

title: Republicans Use Lopez Case as a Weapon
description: ALBANY  New York Republicans, sensing that the sexual harassment allegations against Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez could become a liability for Democrats, are moving to make the scandal a campaign issue.

title: Leak Prompts Netanyahu to Cancel Security Cabinet Meeting on Iran Issue
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu abruptly canceled a meeting of his security cabinet on Wednesday, saying information was leaked from the highly confidential deliberations, a security failure that could undermine his efforts to project a unified front to the West about how to deal with Irans nuclear program.

title: Illinois: Man Sues Over Terrorist Status
description: A Bridgeview man has filed a lawsuit in federal court seeking to lift restrictions placed on him by the Department of Treasury when it deemed him a specially designated terrorist in 1995. In the suit the man, Muhammad A. Salah, says, in essence, that it is impossible for him to lead a normal life  to open a bank account, get a job or donate to his mosque  without seeking approval from the government. In 2007, Mr. Salah was convicted of lying in a civil lawsuit about ties to Hamas, the Palestinian organization, but he was acquitted of more serious charges of racketeering conspiracy after prosecutors accused him of helping to funnel aid to Hamas. A spokesman for the Treasury Department, named as a defendant in the suit, said he could not comment on pending litigation.

title: Young Golfer Makes Progress in Focusing on Process
description: CARMEL, Ind.  It started with a shy request, made last week on the eve of the Deutsche Bank Championship. Kyle Stanley found himself on the practice green alongside Steve Stricker, one of the best putters in the game, so he asked if he could look at his stroke.

title: Emanuel Takes On New Role as a Super PAC Wrangler
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Senior Democrats put aside any remaining qualms about jumping into the super PAC era, enlisting Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago to focus on raising money for outside groups that are seeking to help the White House rather than keep a leadership role in President Obamas re-election campaign.

title: Gaza: Israeli Airstrike Kills Three Militants
description: An Israeli airstrike killed three Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip late Wednesday and seriously wounded a fourth, according to Palestinian and Israeli officials. Israel said the militants had been preparing to launch a rocket to attack Israel. The raid came days after Palestinian militants fired about a dozen rockets into southern Israel from Gaza, the coastal enclave controlled by Hamas. Groups affiliated with Al Qaeda claimed responsibility for those attacks and criticized Hamas this week for cracking down on them.

title: Manning Fails to Solve Cowboys New Look on Defense
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Eli Manning got a different look when he surveyed the Dallas defense in the season opener. For the most part, he did not like what he saw in a 24-17 loss to the Cowboys on Wednesday night.

title: Missouri: Bishop Will Face Judge, Not Jury
description: The trial of Bishop Robert W. Finn and the Diocese of Kansas City-St. Joseph on charges of failure to report suspected child abuse has been moved up to Thursday and will be decided by a judge, not a jury. The change was made public in a court filing on Wednesday, and avoids a lengthy public trial that was set to start Sept. 24. Bishop Finn is the first Roman Catholic prelate in the country to be indicted in the sexual abuse scandals. He and the diocese each face two misdemeanor counts of failing to report hundreds of lewd photographs of young girls on a laptop computer belonging to the Rev. Shawn Ratigan. Father Ratigan pleaded guilty to pornography charges in August.

title: Texas: Mosquito Spraying Shows Results
description: State health officials said Wednesday that the death toll from West Nile virus continues to rise, but they were encouraged by data that suggested the virus had peaked in the Dallas area. The mosquito-borne disease has sickened hundreds of people there and killed 13. A recent spraying operation in the area appeared to reduce the population of mosquitoes. Officials said the insects had declined by 93 percent in places that received two consecutive nights of spraying. Nationwide, 1,993 cases have been reported, including 87 deaths, a 25 percent increase over last weeks numbers. In Texas, there have been 1,113 cases, including 40 deaths, the most fatalities of any state.

title: U.S. Presses Iraq on Iranian Planes Thought to Carry Arms to Syria
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department said Wednesday that Iraq has an obligation under United Nations Security Council resolutions to insist that Iranian planes that are suspected of flying arms to Syria over Iraqi airspace land so the cargo can be inspected.

title: Empowerment
description: Ive spent most of the day with a parent in the hospital; and my thoughts turned to the GOP platform, which boasts that

title: Georgia: Fraud Suspected at Family Services
description: The state is investigating whether child-protection officials falsified records to qualify for millions of dollars in federal money. Agents raided a Division of Family and Children Services office in Columbus on Wednesday and issued arrest warrants for two former officials. The former director, Deborah Cobb, and a protective services supervisor, Phyllis Mitchell, were charged with destroying, changing and falsifying child abuse reports. They are suspected of having falsified reports to make it seem as if they had met federal rules for investigating abuse in a timely way.

title: Pushed by Obama, Democrats Alter Platform Over Jerusalem
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  President Obama, seeking to quell a storm of criticism from Republicans and pro-Israel groups, directed the Democratic Party on Wednesday to amend its platform to restore language declaring Jerusalem the Israeli capital.

title: Learning as Freedom
description: Middletown, Conn.

title: Excerpt: 'The Mindy Project'
description: The new Fox series starts on Sept. 25.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,093 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Roddick, at a Loss for Words, Leaves Behind a Career of Superlatives
description: It looked quite misleadingly like business as usual at the United States Open on Wednesday: Andy Roddick with a microphone in his hand and sweat dripping off the bill of his cap onto the blue court inside Arthur Ashe Stadium.

title: Jack Cermak, a Wind Tunnel Innovator, Dies at 89
description: Jack E. Cermak, an engineer who was among the first to use a wind tunnel to gauge the winds impact on skyscrapers and who did consulting work on the World Trade Center and the Sears Tower, among other projects, died Aug. 21 at his home in Fort Collins, Colo. He was 89.

title: A Controversial Reference to Jerusalem
description: Jim Rutenberg discusses the Democratic Party platforms controversial reference to Jerusalem as the capital of Israel.

title: Wide Area of Nation Still Parched After Storm
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The remnants of Hurricane Isaac that blew through the middle of the country over the weekend softened the worst drought in decades in some areas, but a large portion of the nation remains desiccated with ponds still too shallow to water cattle, fields too dusty for feeding and crops beyond the point of salvage, meteorologists and agriculture experts said Wednesday.

title: A Clash Over a Spine Treatment
description: Dr. Daryl F. Fourneys role as a lead researcher in a clinical trial for a device to treat back pain began normally enough.

title: Is Bad Weather Really the Reason to Move Obamas Speech Indoors?
description: On Wednesday, Democrats announced that they would move President Obamas Thursday night acceptance speech indoors, citing a threat of stormy weather at the Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, N.C.

title: Agent Orange Victims Get Scientology Treatment
description: BANGKOK  The Vietnamese government is treating some people exposed to Agent Orange, the defoliant sprayed by American troops during the Vietnam War, using a detoxification method developed by the founder of the Church of Scientology, according to doctors involved in the program.

title: Joe South, Singer and Writer of Hit Songs, Dies at 72
description: Joe South, a singer-songwriter who wove confrontational lyrics into bouncy pop hits of the late 1960s and early 70s, including Games People Play, Walk a Mile in My Shoes and (I Never Promised You a) Rose Garden, died on Wednesday at home in Flowery Branch, Ga., north of Atlanta. He was 72.

title: Voter ID Wars
description: If youve only got 30 seconds to make your case in the debate over photo ID laws  which require voters to show up at the polls with a government-issued photo ID  its much easier to argue in favor of the laws.

title: Voter ID Wars
description: In the second episode of an Op-Docs series, Electoral Dysfunction, the political humorist Mo Rocca explores controversial voter identification laws, which could benefit Republicans.

title: A Never-Ending Story
description: An article in the paper the other day caught my eye and led me to ponder something Id rather not have to think about at all: the Republican Party platform.

title: Standing on the Precipice, a Strange Place for the Yankees
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Red Sox do collapses: memorably in 1978, destructively just last fall. The Mets do collapses  regularly, even what can feel like annually. The Phillies collapsed so dramatically in 1964, losing 10 games in a row to blow a six-and-a-half-game lead, that the performance stood for decades as a benchmark for choking.

title: The Better Economic Question
description: Democrats have been nervous about the inevitable election-year question, Are you better off than you were four years ago? Gov. Martin OMalley of Maryland even stumbled over it a few days ago, saying no, before quickly blaming President George W. Bush.

title: Bidens Speech Likely to Spotlight Strengths, or Foibles
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Folksy and loose, passionate and sometimes off script, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. arrives onstage Thursday night as the presidents most important political partner, policy enforcer, conscience, scold and occasional albatross.

title: Despite Protections, Botanists Fear Droughts Toll on a Pink-Petaled Rarity
description: MONTAUK, N.Y.  At the eastern end of Long Island, on the South Fork, tucked among the wobbly clam shacks and the steroidal homes, there are a few small grassy plots sectioned off by short chicken-wire fences. The wire is rusty, and the wooden posts that hold it upright are weathered to a milky gray. One plot is not far from a cliff that drops straight to the sea. Another is within eyeshot of a condominium associations swimming pool.

title: Shopping Snapshots: Sept. 6
description: Falls opulent looks show up on shoes; Annelise Michelson designs dangerous-looking jewelry; and other shopping related news.

title: With Sales Sagging, Campbell Hands Off to a Powerful Spokeswoman
description: CAMPBELLS CHUNKY soup introduced its Mamas Boy campaign in 1997 with a commercial featuring the N.F.L. star Reggie White on the sidelines as his mother (played by an actress) sneaks onto the field dressed as a cheerleader to make sure that he has eaten his soup.

title: The Arkansas Innovation
description: Philadelphia

title: Lottery Numbers
Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago
description: Carl Hulse and Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago discuss Priorities USA, a pro-Obama super PAC, and Bill Cintons D.N.C. speech.

title: Hunts Point Market Deal Runs Into a New Obstacle
description: New York Citys Hunts Point Produce Market, which threatened to move to New Jersey in 2010, finally got the subsidy it wanted from the Bloomberg administration to revamp and expand its longtime home in the Bronx.

title: U.S. Court Halts Some Cuts for Medicaid Home Care
description: Charles Strouchler, a former publicity agent for classical-music management companies, has such severe multiple sclerosis that he has to be washed, fed, secured in a wheelchair during the day and turned in bed at night. For the past 15 years, he said, he has been able to live at home only because Medicaid pays for aides to take care of him around the clock.

title: College Coaches Keep Busy at Junior Tournament
description: By Wednesday, most of the college coaches had drifted back to their campuses, but by one rough estimate there were as many of them watching junior players here as there were junior players to watch.

title: Angels Continue Turnaround With Sweep of the Athletics
description: OAKLAND, Calif.

title: A Touchy Relationship
description: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton was in a philosophical frame of mind on Wednesday as she surveyed the impasse between the United States and China on a daunting range of issues. Our two nations, she said, are trying to do something that has never been done in history, which is to write a new answer to the question of what happens when an established power and a rising power meet. As the secretarys fifth trip to China demonstrated, that is proving to be a complicated process.

title: An AK-47 in a Tennessee Park
description: In camouflage gear one Sunday afternoon, Leonard Embody went into a state park near Nashville carrying a Draco AK-47 pistol fully loaded with 30 rounds to test his constitutional rights. Frightened visitors reported that a man was in the park with an assault rifle. A park ranger, thinking the weapon might be ready to fire, sensibly ordered Mr. Embody to the ground, removed his gun, patted him down for other weapons and detained him.

title: They Provide the Music to Sashay By
description: WHAT would a fashion show be without music?

title: Quebec Attack May Have Been Assassination Attempt, Police Say
description: MONTREAL  The return to power of the separatist Parti Qubcois continued to be overshadowed on Wednesday by a shooting here that the police said might have been an assassination attempt on Quebecs premier-designate.

title: More Tax Tricks, Private Equity Style
description: Gawker.com was onto something big last month when it raised questions about Mitt Romneys taxes by putting online confidential documents from Bain Capital, the private equity firm co-founded by Mr. Romney.

title: Steel Leads Revival in Ohio River Valley
description: PADUCAH, Ky.  On a mile-wide reach of the Ohio River, just upstream from where it converges with the Mississippi, Ray McKinney, the first mate aboard a towboat named the Mike Weisend, pounded the slack out of steel cables that lash 15 barges together in a 1,000-foot-long tow.

title: New Wrinkle in Mens Wear: Shops Just for Men
description: The conventional wisdom about guys and shopping has always been that they go together like paisley and plaid, which is to say not very well. There is a reason mens wear in most stores is relegated to the back walls and the basements, while womens wear is front and center.

title: Picking Up Tennis Balls, and Attention
description: As the television cameras canvassed the scene and the fans glued their eyes to Serena Williams as she crushed Andrea Hlavackova of the Czech Republic, 6-0, 6-0, on Monday, another actor on the court was feeling the glare of the spotlight at the United States Open.

title: Behind the Scenes at the D.N.C.

description: Charlotte, N.C.

description: On a backpacking trip once, I slipped on a steep ice sheet and began sliding uncontrollably toward the edge of a cliff overhanging an icy river.

description: The discord among the three Athanasatos brothers was nearly four decades deep, and it centered on the familys two-story brick house in Borough Park, Brooklyn.

description: Governor Martin OMalley of Maryland addresses an Iowa delegate breakfast.

title: Was Bryant Park a Better Location?

The September 6 puzzle by Ben Pall will be offered in all of the usual manners  Across Lite, PDF, Java applet  but there are elements in this puzzle that are impossible to reproduce in Across Lite. I strongly urge you to print out and solve the PDF for a better visual experience.

title: Rethinking Junk DNA
description: A large group of scientists has found that so-called junk DNA, which makes up most of the human genome, does much more than previously thought.

title: The Campaign-Super PAC Revolving Door
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.So much for keeping up the pretense that super PACs are independent from campaigns.

title: Motorola and Nokia Try to Gain an Edge in the Smartphone Market
description: In the smartphone market, Apple and Samsung have become the two giants. Is there room for a third?

title: Things I Saw  No. 30
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: For Farms in the West, Oil Wells Are Thirsty Rivals
description: GREELEY, Colo.  A new race for water is rippling through the drought-scorched heartland, pitting farmers against oil and gas interests, driven by new drilling techniques that use powerful streams of water, sand and chemicals to crack the ground and release stores of oil and gas.

title: Berdych Upsets Federer in Quarterfinals
description: In the third set, momentum swung back toward Roger Federer, winner of 17 Grand Slam singles titles, candidate for best player of all time. He felt it. Tomas Berdych felt it. The crowd, which obviously felt it, roared. The stands shook. The question lingered.

title: Immigration and the Democratic Party
description: A bus carrying undocumented immgrants rode from Phoenix, Ariz., to Charlotte, N.C. And Marcus Mabry and Representative Charlie Gonzalez of Texas discuss immigration and Latino voters at the D.N.C.

title: Louisiana: Storm Churns Up Oil Off Coast
description: Hurricane Isaac churned up enough oil in a part of south Louisiana that was among the hardest hit by the BP spill that state wildlife officials announced the emergency closing of some coastal waters to commercial fishing. Six heavy tar mats were found just offshore of a 13-mile stretch of sandy and marshy coastline, and tar balls were found on the beach as well. Tests are being performed to determine whether the oil belongs to the well drilled by the Deepwater Horizon, and results are expected within days. It possibly could be our oil, but we dont know, said Ray Melick, a spokesman for BP, adding that crews were engaged in cleanup activities in the area only days before the storm.

title: Shoe Designer Can Protect Its Pop of Red, Court Says
description: The case of Louboutin v. Yves Saint Laurent has been one of high stakes in high heels.

title: Andrew Rosenthal and Charles M. Blow
description: The Op-Ed columnist Charles Blow and the Editorial Page Editor Andrew Rosenthal discuss Bill Clintons, and other speakers, roles at the Democratic Convention.

title: In a Tax Case, a Debate: Is Lap Dancing an Art?
description: New York States highest court, the Court of Appeals, is used to considering weighty issues, like same-sex marriage and the death penalty. But on Wednesday, its august chambers entertained a debate of perhaps less significance but far more prurience: whether lap dancing constitutes a form of art.

description: On a day when Andy Roddick said goodbye to tennis, Serena Williams, Sara Errani, Andy Murray and Maria Sharapova advanced at the United States Open.

description: Marriage equality, which has become important to the campaign, has become an even bigger issue for Cindy Jordan and Laura Blackley of Asheville, N.C.

title: Court Rulings Help Illegal Immigrants College-Bound Children
description: Several states with financial difficulties have moved quietly in recent years to reduce spending on college education by denying low tuition rates and financial aid to American citizens who are the children of illegal immigrants.

title: For Warren, Bad Blood Over Ethnic Claims
description: Karen Geronimo, a member of the Mescalero Apache tribe in town for the Democratic convention, knows what she wants from Elizabeth Warren, the Senate candidate from Massachusetts: a blood sample.

title: Yankees Top Rays, and the Division
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Yankees streak of 84 days in sole possession of first place in the American League East ended with a thud Tuesday, but their time as co-holders of the division lead lasted barely one day.

title: Opinion: Charles Blow and Mo Rocca
description: Op-Ed columnist Charles Blow interviews the political humorist Mo Rocca on voter identification fraud.

title: Djokovic Is Still Talking About Tarps
description: Novak Djokovic, the defending mens champion at the United States Open, seems to be waging a one-man campaign for tarps at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center. At last years Open, after two days of play were wiped out by rain, Djokovic said, What I have to say is I just dont understand why, you know, if you have  for example, if you dont have a roof, O.K., on this Grand Slam, why you dont have covers on the court, you know?

title: The Buddy to Shop With
description: SOMETIMES you have occasion to look inside a strangers closet (hey, it happens), and you can see what theyre about. I recently had that opportunity and, affixed to the inside of the door, the gentleman in question had a Mr Porter sticker with his name on it. I didnt know very much about the guy, but quickly, I understood him.

title: Mark Leibovich on Joseph R. Biden Jr.
description: Richard L. Berke and Mark Leibovich discuss Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his impact on the Democratic ticket.

description: Richard L. Berke and Carolyn Ryan discuss whether the evolution of political conventions, and whether they still matter to voters.

title: Mayor Bloomberg Announces Winners of Project Pop-Up N.Y.C.
description: On Wednesday, in an effort to support fashion and technology entrepreneurs Mayor Michael Bloomberg announced the winners of Project Pop-UP N.Y.C., a competition that the mayors office and the Economic Development Corporation. Would-be winners had four weeks to get their applications in starting from the end of June. The nine application questions solicited thetype of information that one would put on a business plan: Who is your competition, and how are you different or better? Who is on your management team? What market does it address, and how big is thismarket?

title: A Look Back at Roddicks Career
description: At the time of his retirement, Andy Roddick was the most decorated active American male tennis player. He remains the last American to win a Grand Slam final.

title: Sultans of Swag
description: The Smithsonian Institution adds to its political collection.

title: A Street Sense on Exhibit
description: WHILE designers parade their creations this week and next on the New York runways, the Danziger Gallery in Chelsea is bringing fashion back to street level with an exhibition by the photographer Scott Schuman, whose blog, The Sartorialist, has made him one of fashions most notable documentarians.

title: Gin Palace
description: WHILE gin makes you sin, a juniper-based cocktail in Manhattan can also make you poor.

title: A Fashion Week Party, Without the Fashion
description: IT takes a lot of nerve to have an art opening on the first night of Fashion Week  which is also Fashions Night Out, in case you hadnt heard. Andy Valmorbida isnt worried. This is the fourth time that Mr. Valmorbida, the young pop-up exhibitionist and cocky Australian-born art entrepreneur, has crashed the all-important night with a big party. He says the timing is coincidental. Oh, sure.

title: Peter Baker on Bill Clinton
description: Richard L. Berke and Peter Baker discuss Bill Clinton and his approach to making speeches.

title: Bill Clinton Speaks
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.Watching Bill Clinton take the stage at the Democratic National Convention and take over the room with his first few, simple words  We are here to nominate a President and Ive got one in mind  was like watching a great violinist follow a group of gifted amateurs.

title: Transcript of Bill Clintons Speech to the Democratic National Convention
description: The following is the full text of former President Bill Clintons speech on Wednesday from the Democratic National Convention.

title: Elizabeth Warren's Speech
description: Elizabeth Warren, candidate for Senate in Massachusetts, addresses the Democratic National Convention.

title: A Startling Truth Amid the Hyperbole
description: Speakers at the Democratic National Convention used an out-of-context quote on Wednesday night to give the misleading impression that Mitt Romney enjoys firing people, and some referred imprecisely to his tax proposals. The partys platform also contained questionable assertions about President Obamas record on civil liberties.

title: Think Like a Doctor: The Blue Girl
description: The Challenge: Can you solve a medical mystery involving a 17-year-old girl who suddenly begins to turn blue?

title: Word of the Day | nettle
description: nettle \ne-tl\ noun and verb

title: The Slaughter of Elephants in Vietnam Is Nearly Complete
description: HONG KONG  The plight of elephants in Africa is being explained, in graphic and saddening detail, in a new series of stories by my colleague Jeffrey Gettleman of The New York Times. An epic elephant slaughter, he calls it, with poachers wiping out tens of thousands of elephants a year for their ivory.

title: Libyan Alleges Waterboarding by C.I.A., Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  Days after the Justice Department closed out its criminal investigation of the deaths of two detainees while in the custody of the C.I.A., new information has surfaced calling into question official accounts of the extent of waterboarding by American interrogators.

title: Clinton Delivers Impassioned Plea for Obama Second Term
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Former President Bill Clinton and President Obama hugged onstage Wednesday night after Mr. Clinton delivered an impassioned plea on behalf of Mr. Obamas re-election, the 42nd president nominating the 44th to a second term with a forceful and spirited argument that Democratic values would restore the promise of the middle class.

title: After Pregame Pomp, a Pratfall
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants players and coaches were adamant this past week that they had moved on. The Super Bowl victory was months ago, they said, and last season was in the past. Coach Tom Coughlin even invoked his pithy phrase-of-the-moment, Build the Bridge, more often than usual to remind everyone that the goal now is to link the 2011 title season to this one.

title: Cowboys Romo Wins Signature Victory
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: For Replacement Referees, Questioned Calls and Praise
description: Opening night of the N.F.L. season was opening night for the replacement referees.

title: A Fuller Explanation of Bain Stories Told at Democratic Convention
description: The three people who told their stories about their experiences with Mitt Romneys firm, Bain Capital, Wednesday night during the Democratic National Convention laid out the by-now-familiar Democratic critique that he prized profits over people during his 15-year career in private equity and that he was a job destroyer, rather than a job creator.

title: Evolution of the Democratic Conventions
description: Sam Tanenhaus, The New York Times Book Review editor, considers John F. Kennedy vs. Adlai Stevenson, protests in 1968 and Senator Edward M. Kennedys The Dream Shall Never Die speech.

title: Bill Clinton's Speech
description: Former President Bill Clinton addresses the Democratic National Convention.

title: Surging Rays Find Themselves in a Familiar Position
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  It is that time of the baseball season, when eyeballs linger a little longer on the scoreboard, and Rays outfielder Sam Fuld is no different from the average fan.

description: The rousing start to the Democratic convention here in Charlotte, N.C., makes last weeks Republican convocation in Tampa, Fla., look like, well, a tea party.

description: Nine months after knocking off the Cowboys on their way to a surprise Super Bowl championship, the Giants began their title defense with a dispiriting 24-17 loss to their rivals at MetLife Stadium.

title: News Quiz | September 6, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: 10 Hotels to Rub Shoulders With the Tastemakers During Fashion Week
description: You dont need an invitation to New York Fashion Week to gawk at the latest styles. Flooded with fashion editors, bloggers, celebrities and, of course, models, hotels will be celebrating with parties, panels, shopping and specialty drinks (care for a Kate Moss Cosmo?). Here are 10 places to rub shoulders with the tastemakers.

title: Boy, 2 Months, Is Grazed by a Bullet
description: A 2-month-old boy was grazed by a bullet in the Bronx on Wednesday night, the police said.

title: 4 Years Later, Scarred but Still Confident
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  He warned them in 2008, and when he formally opened his re-election campaign in May, he put it in his speech again. He will never be a perfect president, he said, a line he now repeats at stop after stop. The unspoken subtext: Its not my fault if you didnt listen or expected too much.

title: Conversations With Andy Murray: Federer Always Seems to Be Lurking
description: Immediately after Andy Murray came back to beat Marin Cilic, the No. 12 seed from Croatia, 3-6, 7-6 (4), 6-2, 6-0, in the quarterfinals of the United States Open on Wednesday, attention turned, as it usually has for Murray lately, to Roger Federer. In his regular postmatch conversation with Straight Sets, Murray detailed his rivalry with Federer, who later was upset by Tomas Berdych.

title: Indias Latest Reservations Bill Stirs Controversy
description: In a measure that could expand Indias affirmative action programs, the government introduced a bill Wednesday that would make it easier to grant promotions to members of Indias lowest castes and tribal people in government jobs.

title: Carine Roitfelds New Magazine
description: The first issue of CR, which has been the subject of much speculation since Ms. Roitfeld, after leaving French Vogue in December 2010, announced she would start her own title, comes with a theme of rebirth.

title: Carine Roitfeld, Going Her Own Way
description: CARINE ROITFELD has babies on the brain. Ever since the birth of her first granddaughter, Romy Nicole Konjic, in May, that is all she has talked about. Babies, babies, babies.

title: Embedded on the Front Lines of the Digital Revolution
description: PERPIGNAN, France  When Doug Menuez covered the Ethiopian famine in 1985 for Newsweek, he was devastated by the sheer scale of human suffering and by his inability to do anything about it.

title: What Music Inspires You?
description: In honor of Fashion Week, The Times asked 10 fashion designers what tunes have aided their creative vision. How would you answer that question? What music inspires you  whether to create things, or to exercise, study, pursue a hobby or just to feel good in general?

title: O.E.C.D. Warns of Recession in Germany
description: LONDON  The euro zones woes are finally taking their toll on Germany, the European economic powerhouse that has long avoided the worst of the crisis that began two and a half years ago.

title: A Conversation With: Author and Police Officer Nazrul Islam
description: KOLKATA  Despite his reputation as a tough, no-nonsense police officer who has stood up to the government on several occasions, Nazrul Islam is soft-spoken and gentle, even when refusing to discuss the controversy surrounding his latest book, Musalmander Koroniyo (What Muslims Should Do).

title: Qantas in a Venture to Improve International Reach
description: HONG KONG  Qantas Airways of Australia said Thursday it had ended a long-running partnership with British Airways and would instead form one with Emirates of Dubai on European routes in an effort to help turn around its beleaguered international operations.

title: Lost in Time in the Antarctic Ice Age
description: Alexander Kumar, a physician and researcher at Concordia Station, writes from Antarctica, where he conducts scientific experiments for the European Space Agencys human spaceflight program.

description: Jeffrey Durso-Finley and Holly Burks Becker are co-directors of college counseling at the Lawrenceville School in Lawrenceville, N.J.

title: What to Watch on Thursday
description: It took Novak Djokovic barely more than 90 minutes to go up by two sets and a break over Stanislas Wawrinka on Wednesday before his opponent called it quits  another dominant performance for the defending champion. Through four matches at the United States Open, Djokovic has lost just 20 games and has not dropped a set.

title: San Francisco 49ers, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
description: Today, Andy Benoit completes his marathon tour of 32 team previews. The final team is the 49ers, his pick to win the N.F.C. West. A complete look at Andys work this summer is available here.

title: Shopping for a Nursing Home? Theres a Tool for That
The Migron Settlement Myth
description: JERUSALEM  Sunday was an eventless day. Yes, Migron, the most famous of illegal Jewish outposts in the West Bank, was evacuated. But nothing happened, really. The move was peaceful, with only minor protests. The settlers warnings that theyd resist proved hollow, and the governments fear that they might, baseless.

title: Sept. 5: Looking Ahead After Charlotte
description: There was almost nothing worth talking about in the polls that were out on Wednesday. So lets take a quick look forward instead  to about a week from now, by which point we will have plenty of data on what effect the Democratic National Convention had on the polls.

title: Pereira Compliments Replacement Officials
description: The former N.F.L. director of officials Mike Pereira, who has supported his former colleagues in their labor dispute with the N.F.L., gave the replacement officials a passing grade in the Dallas-Giants game on Wednesday. Pereira, now a Fox analyst, wrote on FoxSports.com:

title: The Shortbread Variations
description: Chocolaty, citrusy, sugary or savory.

title: Short and Sweet
description: If you use half a pound of butter in a batch of cookies, it becomes short  because short means, historically, pastry with a high percentage of fat.

title: How Dangerous Is Your Couch?
description: In September 1976, a mail runner from Katmandu arrived at Base Camp on Mount Everest with a package for Dr. Arlene Blum, a member of the American Bicentennial Everest Expedition. The package had nothing to do with the climb, or Blums status as the first American woman to attempt the worlds highest peak. It concerned pajamas. Inside were the proofs of an article she co-wrote for the journal Science about a chemical then widely used in childrens sleepwear. The subtitle was unusually blunt for a scientific paper: The main flame retardant in childrens pajamas is a mutagen and should not be used.

title: Are the Big Banks Keeping Their Commitment to Small Businesses?
description: Last September in Cleveland, 13 of the nations largest banks stood beside Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Karen Mills, chief of the Small Business Administration, and announced a commitment to increase small-business lending by $20 billion over the following three years.

title: A Phone That Can Take a Dunking
description: People prone to dropping their phones in the drink  a drop in the toilet is one of the most common cellphone accidents  are usually condemned to buying vaultlike cases to protect their phones from everything including the kitchen sink.

title: Daily Report: Motorola and Nokia Fight for a Shred of the Smartphone Market
description: In the smartphone market, Apple and Samsung have become the two giants. Is there room for a third?

title: Climate Change and the Food Supply
description: 1:30 p.m. | Updated A small bit of good news about food prices from the Food and Agriculture Organization, a United Nations agency in Rome: The price spiral seen earlier this summer as markets reacted to droughts and other bad news has leveled off, with the agencys closely watched index of global food prices essentially unchanged in August compared with July.

title: Grading the Giants With All-22 Film
description: For a fee, fans this season can see full-length game film that was once exclusive to N.F.L. personnel. The film, known as the All-22, shows the whole field and all 22 players on it.

title: Tip of the Week: Linux on a Stick
description: An aging computer that cannot quite meet the requirements for a Windows 7 upgrade can sometimes find a few more years of usefulness with a switch to the Linux operating system. Ubuntu, which makes a free and easy-to-use version of Linux, has traditionally made it easy to try out the system by posting instructions for making a compact disc that can boot up and run Linux for a test drive before installing it. But for old computers with broken disc drives, Ubuntu Linux can also be run from a USB flash drive. The Ubuntu site has detailed instructions here for making a bootable USB stick (or CD) with the current version of Ubuntu from either a Windows or Mac computer, and an online demo here.

title: Huge Step Taken by Europes Bank to Abate a Crisis
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank on Thursday took its most ambitious step yet toward easing the euro zone crisis, throwing its unlimited financial clout behind an effort to protect Spain and Italy from financial collapse.

title: Papering Over Cracks in Europes Union
description: LONDON  When cracks in the roof of the European Parliament building in Brussels resulted in the buildings partial closure this week, skeptics were quick to seize on a handy metaphor for the state of the European Union.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Creating Characters You Worry About
description: EVERY now and then  and its a blessed now and then  a first encounter with a playwright leaves you surprised, intrigued and at least a little infatuated, as if youd had an unexpectedly successful blind date. This could be the beginning of a beautiful friendship, you think. You find yourself wondering and maybe fretting about the characters youve just met, as if they were friends, and anticipating more to come from their creator.

title: The Bride, Ahem, Needs That Dress
description: Ill get the Cobb salad with no chicken, no bacon, no cheese, no avocado, declares Regan (Kirsten Dunst), a snippy, overgrown alpha girl ordering lunch in a New York restaurant.

title: Thrive Capital Raises $150 Million Fund, Bolstering Profile
description: Thrive Capital, a venture capital firm based in Manhattan and run by Joshua Kushner, has raised $150 million for its latest fund as it seeks to raise its profile and become more competitive against larger firms.

title: Ford Expands Offerings for Europe
description: DETROIT  Even during the American auto industrys collapse three years ago, the Ford Motor Company kept investing heavily in new products for the future. As American auto sales recovered, so did Fords revenue and profit in what previously had been its most troubled market.

title: Not by Design, Another Clinton Watches a Convention From Afar
description: BANDAR SERI BEGAWAN, Brunei  When Michelle Obama addressed the Democratic National Convention on Tuesday night in Charlotte, N.C., it was already Wednesday morning in Beijing, and Hillary Rodham Clinton was meeting with Chinas president in the Great Hall of the People.

title: Publishers Back African Literacy Effort With E-Books
description: Years ago, David Risher, a former Amazon executive, came up with the unlikely plan of distributing Kindles to children in the developing world to help increase literacy.

title: Opinion Report: China and the U.S.

title: A.I.G. to Sell $2 Billion Stake in Asia Unit for Share Buyback
description: The insurance giant American International Group said on Thursday that it planned to sell a $2 billion stake in its Asian insurance unit as part of a plan to repurchase $5 billion worth of its own stock from the United States government.

title: Its Only September, but Motion Picture Academy Is Naming Some Awards Winners
description: TORONTO  As much of Hollywood moved to Toronto for its annual film festival, which begins on Thursday, some of the rest convened on Wednesday night to select four film veterans  Jeffrey Katzenberg, George Stevens Jr., D.A. Pennebaker and Hal Needham  as recipients of the next Governors Awards from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

title: Thursday Reading: Tips for Succeeding in College
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: At India Fantastique, Silk, Stars and High Fashion
description: LONDON  It is not often that stilt walkers wearing columns of silk sway and totter on the pavement on New Bond Street. But on Wednesday evening, towering models in a fanfare of silk outfits embroidered with tiny mirrors greeted guests, including the steel baron Lakshmi Mittal and film director Gurinder Chadha, at a book launch and auction for the celebrated Indian designers Abu Jani and Sandeep Khosla.

title: Meet the Parents, Part II
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.The G.O.P. convention last week, an opportunity to introduce the real Mitt Romney to America, doubled as a genealogy of the Republican leadership. Bob McDonnell said his grandfather, a poor farm boy, left Ireland 100 years ago and came to Ellis Island; Ted Cruz said his dad was imprisoned and tortured in Cuba; and Chris Christie noted that his Irish father worked at the Breyers Ice Cream plant.

title: A Collision on the Lake
description: Dear Diary:

title: Opponents of Malaysia Rare Earth Plant Promise to Protest
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Opponents of a rare earth refinery in Malaysia refused to back down Thursday after the authorities gave the Australian company behind the project the approval to proceed.

title: Bill Clinton and Structural Unemployment
description: Im pretty annoyed with Bill Clinton right now; hes just spoiled one of my standard joke lines. You see, when giving talks about the economy, Ive often said that I have a different take from other pundits, because I know some stuff most political reporters dont, like  arithmetic. Ill never be able to use that line again without being accused of stealing it from the Big Dog.

title: Summers (More or Less) Out. Schools In.
description: Today is the first day of school for New York Citys 1.1 million public school students, virtually all of whom will encounter at least one significant change this year. Teachers are beginning to roll out the new common core curriculum, a set of standards that emphasize more critical thinking and nonfiction reading.

title: Ford Transit and Transit Connect Make Landfall in Amsterdam
description: As part of a lavish event held to announce its European product plan, Ford introduced refreshed versions of its van fleet on Thursday in Amsterdam: the Transit, Transit Connect commercial van and Transit Connect Wagon. And in keeping with the automakers strategy of uniting its global vehicle lines, the vans are the clearest indication of the models to be offered in North America.

title: Face Time | Rachael Taylor
description: I met with the actress Rachael Taylor in her new Manhattan apartment, where the gorgeous Tasmanian transplant made me feel instantly at home with her warm, welcoming personality and candid conversation. We chatted a bit about her new television series, 666 Park Avenue (which airs Sept. 30 on ABC at 10 p.m.), a bit about her upcoming movie, The Loft, which co-stars the sexy James Marsden, and a whole lot about her beauty regimen.

title: Japan Said to Have Tentative Deal to Buy 3 Disputed Islands From Private Owners
description: KYOTO, Japan  The Japanese government has struck a tentative agreement to buy three uninhabited islands that are part of a chain at the center of a heated territorial dispute with China, a person close to the talks said Thursday.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Bill Clinton Grabs Spotlight, and New Tablets and Phones
description: Bill Clinton addressed the Democratic National Convention for 45 minutes Wednesday night, giving a detailed and impassioned endorsement of President Obama, Jeff Zeleny and Mark Landler reported. He frequently spoke off the cuff  according to NPR, which paired the written text to a tape of Mr. Clintons delivery, he added 2,300 words to a speech that started with 3,200 words of prepared text. Mr. Clinton pushed well past the start of 11 oclock local news on the East Coast.

title: Hailing a Cab May Be Easier, but the Ride Remains Unchanged
description: Can you see Holly Golightly stepping outside her East Side apartment and using a smartphone app to call a cab?

title: Big Fish Musical to Open in Chicago
description: A stage musical adaptation of the 2003 film Big Fish will play a five-week engagement in Chicago next spring, the producers announced on Thursday. The two-time Tony Award-winner Norbert Leo Butz (Catch Me if You Can) will star in the show, which has music and lyrics by Andrew Lippa (The Addams Family) and a book by the films screenwriter, John August. Susan Stroman (The Producers) will be the director and choreographer.

title: What Were Reading
description: Bon Appetit: For your consideration, a rant against the most iconic of all cocktail vessels, the martini glass.Robert Simonson

title: 2 Real Estate Firms Strike $2.9 Billion Deal
description: The Realty Income Corporation agreed to acquire American Realty Capital Trust on Thursday, striking a $2.9 billion deal involving hundreds of retail and commercial properties.

title: The Clinton Magic
description: In a sweeping, sprawling, drawling 48-minute stemwinder of a speech last night, the former President of the United States drove a rhetorical truck through the biggest opening that Mitt Romney and the Republicans created for Democrats last week. The G.O.P. convention promised to make difficult choices and hard calls and be bracingly honest with the public, but the Republican speakers discussed policy in only the broadest and loosest terms, eschewing detail in favor of generalizations and creativity in favor of boilerplate. In response, Bill Clinton did everything they didnt, diving deep on policy detail, covering issues ranging from Medicaid to welfare to prescription drugs to student loans, and effectively defining the Republicans defining them negatively, it need hardly be said on a range of issues where they declined to define themselves. Writing on Paul Ryan last week, I said that we shouldnt be surprised that his speech was less wonky than his reputation, since a VP address is hardly the time to talk about block grants and premium support and whether to peg spending rates to inflation or G.D.P. plus one percent. But Clinton reminded us that this need not be true  that its possible to get wonky without losing your audience, and to embrace policy detail as a weapon against your opponents. Journalists tend to assume that voters tune policy substance out, and when the substance is delivered droningly or too abstractly no doubt they often do. But for the most effective rhetoricians, the mere act of talking in detail about the work of government can be a more effective way to persuade the public that youre serious than a hundred vague promises to make the hard choices and level with the American people.

title: Unfit for Any Post
description: DELHI  Narendra Modi, the chief minister of Gujarat and the poster boy for growth in India, may be in trouble finally. At least he should be.

title: A Base Line for Methane in Water Supplies
description: Measurements in recent years of naturally occurring methane in New York State wells could serve as a base line for assuring the quality of water supplies if and when fracking for natural gas gets under way in the state, the United States Geological Survey reported this week.

title: Syrian Army Attacks Village Near Jordanian Border
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian Army stormed the village of Tal Shehab near the Jordanian border, opposition groups and activists said on Thursday, raising fears that the forces of President Bashar al-Assad may seek to cut off the torrent of tens of thousands of refugees who have been fleeing across the border.

title: Nomura Seeks to Save $1 Billion by Scaling Back Mainly in Europe
description: 8:38 p.m. | Updated

title: Ludo Lefebvre Is Coming to New York
description: Ludo Lefebvre, the French chef who relocated to Los Angeles years ago and has made a name for himself doing pop-up dinners there called LudoBites, will be coming to New York to celebrate the publication of his new cookbook based on those dinners. LudoBites will be published on Oct. 9, and to celebrate the occasion he will do a dinner at Blue Ribbon Bakery in Greenwich Village, cooking with Bruce Bromberg, whom he met when they were in the Michelin three-star kitchen at Pierre Gagnaire in Paris.

title: From Passion to Transcendence
description: THREE of the worlds greatest dancers, each from a different continent, each from a different dance idiom, come to New York this fall. The Spanish flamenco artist Soledad Barrio returns, with her troupe Noche Flamenca, to the Joyce Theater for two weeks starting Sept. 18. Nov. 1 through 3 the Indian Bharata Natyam dancer Malavika Sarukkai performs at the Baryshnikov Arts Center. And the Argentine tango master Gabriel Miss returns to New York from Nov. 23 through December, teaching workshops and appearing in the citys milongas, or social tango gatherings.

title: The Postmodern Revolution, Redefined
description: ITS hard to imagine there was a time when postmodern dance was considered extreme, but on a hot July night in 1962 at Judson Memorial Church, the fireworks happened onstage. Judson Dance Theater was born: now, 50 years later, the dance world is looking back to the artistic movement that inspired generations to come.

title: The Accidental Audience
description: HOW do you solve a problem like the Museum of Modern Arts atrium? By even the most generous of views, the cavernous, corporate arena is not an easy or even conducive setting in which to contemplate art. It has foiled many a maker and viewer.

title: Riding for Reform
description: Illegal immigrants ride to the Democratic National Convention in a mobile protest for an immigration overhaul.

title: Joyce Carol Oates: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of Two or Three Things I Forgot to Tell You and Black Dahlia & White Rose admits that she first found Walt Whitman disappointing: Please dont send contemptuous e-mails.

title: At a New School, a Math Lesson From the Mayor
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Schools Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott arrived at the New Settlement Community Campus in the Bronx on Thursday morning alongside a parade of navy-and-white uniforms, Spiderman and Hello Kitty backpacks and parents dropping their children off at kindergarten for the first time. (Once your child has reached the classroom and you give them one last hug and kiss you will be directed to the back exit, read a notice to kindergarten parents posted on the schools door.)

description: Business Day Live: Europe takes new steps to shore up its economy. | Apples rivals look for traction in the smartphone market. | Social media upsets the balance of power at Fashion Week.

description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The worst drought in decades is expected, over the next few months, to continue choking a large area of the Plains and Rockies that missed the soggy remnants of Hurricane Isaac, according to the National Weather Services Seasonal Drought Outlook released on Thursday morning.

title: Striking Notes Timely and Timeless
description: SEPTEMBER

title: Do We Really Need a Tooth Fairy App?
description: Heres one for the list oftools you can probably live without: An app for iPhones and iPads that helps compute what the tooth fairy should leave for your child.
