description: Pop

title: Have Guitars, Will Party
description: IN her senior year at New York University, Rachel Bishop left dorm living behind. Since then, she has always paid under $1,000 a month  sometimes well under  for rent.

title: Kansas City Bishop Convicted of Shielding Pedophile Priest
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  A Roman Catholic bishop was found guilty on Thursday of failing to report suspected child abuse, becoming the first American bishop in the decades-long sexual abuse scandal to be convicted of shielding a pedophile priest.

title: Toxic Beauty
description: Images from a new exhibition of works by the artist Frank Moore.

title: Jazz Listings for Sept. 7-13
description: Jazz

title: Mets Get Permission for 9/11 Hats
description: The Mets will wear hats representing the first responders from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks during batting practice and the national anthem before their game on Tuesday against the Washington Nationals.

title: Classical Music and Opera Listings for Sept. 7-13
description: Classical

title: Lewis Warns Delegates of Dangers of New Voter Laws
description: Representative John Lewis of Georgia told the delegates at the Democratic convention on Thursday that he first came to Charlotte, N.C., on a Freedom Ride in 1961, the year President Obama was born, and warned them that new voting laws passed in several Republican-led states requiring voter IDs and limiting early voting would make it harder for people to vote.

title: Dance Listings for Sept. 7-13
description: Dance

title: Riding, Rivalries and Romance
description: Dates and titles are subject to change, and all shows are subject to never actually making it on the air.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Sept. 7-13
description: Art

title: Intricate and Odd, With Little Childs Play
description: The strange, often beautiful beings in the animated feature Toys in the Attic exist in a faraway land located somewhere between Czech surrealism and Pixar communitarianism. A simple story intricately told, it centers on a small familial group  a doll named Buttercup, a teddy bear, a marionette and a blob  whose happy life is threatened by a bust of a bald man that looks as if it once sat on a pedestal in Communist Party headquarters. The bust is attended to by a motley assortment of minions, including what looks like a termite with a human head, and a severed arm wearing a black leather glove, which suggests that the director Jiri Barta is a Stanley Kubrick fan.

title: A New Marriage License and Each Other, and Little Else
description: Tiana Polomaine was stretched out on a bench sleeping next to her fianc, Dave Merritt, when their number came up just before noon on Thursday at the marriage bureau on Worth Street in downtown Manhattan.

title: The, Yes, Upside of Broadcast
description: SHED no tears for The Good Wife.

title: TimesCast Politics and Democratic Convention Schedule at a Glance
description: The Democratic National Convention culminates tonight with President Obamas acceptance speech, and The Timess political unit will be broadcasting live from Charlotte, N.C., beginning at 7 p.m. Eastern time. Here are a few program highlights:

title: The First Day of School in Pictures
description: Be sure to read all of our posts from the first day of school, 2012.

title: Mens Doubles Final Has a Familiar Feel
description: Marc Lopez of Spain, his left leg bandaged from ankle to knee, started toward a drop shot and stopped, the promise of pain too great. Moments later, his partner, Marcel Granollers, looked Lopez in the eye. Lopez nodded.

title: Movie Listings for Sept. 7-13
description: Movies

title: Visas-for-Dollars Program a Boon to Hotel Developers
description: When Marriott International wanted to open a new hotel in downtown Seattle, the companys developers didnt sell bonds, take out a mortgage or tap other traditional forms of financing for the $88 million project. Instead, it raised the bulk of the money from wealthy immigrants who wanted a green card.

title: Unhappy Hooligans, Dripping With Lust
description: In Among the Thugs, Bill Bufords horrifying nonfiction book about the brutal excesses of British soccer hooliganism, he writes about gangs of fans who travel to European cities like Turin ostensibly to support their teams. In one unforgettable scene Mr. Buford watches as hordes of Manchester United followers swarm out of a Turin stadium and into the streets in a frenzy of violence, savagely beating anyone, children included. In the middle of the mayhem, in between the stomping and punching, he overhears one of the rampaging goons say, The city is ours and repeat the word ours, ours, ours. Theres a sense that the rioting is a kind of postcolonial invasion for at least this one thug, an idea thats cemented when later he says, We took the city.

title: Draghi
description: Im still bogged down in family health-related stuff, hence limited interventions here. Still, I guess Id better weigh in on what would, if it werent for the DNC, be the story of the day: the latest announcement from the European Central Bank.

title: Comedy Listings for Sept. 7-13
description: Comedy

title: In Speech, Obama to Plead for Patience
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  President Obama prepared to accept the Democratic nomination to run for a second term on Thursday night, and planned to say that our problems can be solved, while making a forceful case that in four years, he has brought the economy from disaster to a recovery which would be imperiled by a return to Republican stewardship.

title: The Coming Tug of War Over a New State Budget
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Divorce Blues, Waylaid by a New Infatuation
description: The ostensibly grown-up man residing in the parental nest  usually in a boyhood bedroom full of movie posters, video games and action figures  is a staple of American comedy. He is a figure to be pitied and ridiculed, but also envied, since he still dwells in a juvenile paradise that the rest of us, with our jobs and kids and dreary domestic routines, supposedly long to recapture.

title: A New Way to Tackle College Algebra
description: Alexzandria Siprian, a senior at the University of Texas at Arlington who is double-majoring in Spanish and theater, is not a math person. Early in her college career, she squeaked through her required algebra course with a D.

title: Where Bronze Transforms Into Fine Art
description: THE brick-walled workshop is dark and quiet. Fine white dust hangs in the air and coats the walls and floor. A small group of men work intently, dressed in silver spaceman jackets and long leather aprons that cover their bluejeans.

title: Far Beyond Playhouse, Artist Remains Playful
description: The creativity grows like kudzu in Beauty Is Embarrassing, Neil Berkeleys enlightening and often hilarious portrait of the Los Angeles artist Wayne White. And it yields a thousand blossoms. Mr. White, an Emmy-winning puppeteer for Pee-wees Playhouse, has had his share of career dips, only to arrive as a popular painter of some very amusing canvases. Tracing his evolution, the film gets at larger issues  about imagination, relationships and laughter.

title: Rap Rivalry and Twitter Outrage Lead Pitchfork to Pull Video
description: Pitchfork, the usually irreverent music blog, has apologized for publishing a videotaped interview with the Chicago rapper Chief Keef that was filmed at a shooting range and features images of the young hip-hop star firing a gun. This concept was rushed and never should have happened, Pitchforks editor, Mark Richardson, said in an online statement. He called the episode, one of the sites Selector interviews with rappers, insensitive and irresponsible.

title: His Last Battle for Chelsea, or So He Says
description: WHEN Edward Kirkland gazes out the windows of his 16th-floor apartment at Seventh Avenue and 23rd Street, he zeros in, no binoculars necessary, on the construction cranes lately commandeering the western horizon. It is not a view he treasures.

title: For International Students, College Checklists for September
description: This week, The Choice published our monthly Counselors Calendar, designed to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

title: Woodward Book Details Battles Over Deficit
description: WASHINGTON  A new book by the journalist Bob Woodward chronicles the descent of Barack Obamas Washington into partisan trench warfare and mines the minutiae of the largely failed negotiations between House Republicans and the White House to tame the nations deficit problem over the last two years.

title: These Wedding Crashers Are Zombies
description: [REC] 3: Genesis, the latest in the [REC] franchise and the first without the co-director Jaume Balaguer, strips away the strengths of its predecessors  among them a spooky sound design and gloomy, warrenlike location  to deliver an altogether brighter, jokier blood bath. In doing so, however, the remaining director, Paco Plaza, may have murdered his fan base along with his films victims.

title: Back to China, Clueless Child in Tow
description: Living through Chinas social and political upheaval in the 20th century tends to raise the stakes on a typical parental lesson in family history and forbearance, as shown in the documentary Mulberry Child. Directed by Susan Morgan Cooper, this lumbering, re-enactment-heavy film adapts a memoir that was written by Jian Ping in hopes of enlightening her thoroughly Americanized daughter, Lisa, and perhaps forging a deeper bond.

title: Insurance Chief Answers Industry Bias Charges
description: Eleanor Kitzman has been Texas insurance commissioner for only a year, but her tenure in a usually obscure political post has already included headline-grabbing controversies.

title: Italian Doubles Team Wins a Shootout
description: Two point-blank shootouts enlivened Sara Errani and Roberta Vincis semifinal doubles victory on Thursday. The Italians won, 6-3, 6-2, over Nuria Llagostera Vives and Maria Martinez Sanchez of Spain.

title: Jets Seem Ready to Unveil Closely Guarded Wildcat
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Fifty-one seconds into his opening remarks at Mondays news conference, Jets Coach Rex Ryan coolly slipped in a mention of the offensive formation he had spent weeks trying to play down.

title: Moody Shots of Detroits Urban Decay
description: Late in Detropia, Heidi Ewing and Rachel Gradys dreamy documentary about a slowly crumbling Detroit, a Swiss tourist confesses an appreciation for the aesthetics of decay. That interest is not only shared by the filmmakers, but it also may be their driving force: in this visual caress of postindustrial blight, disintegration has never looked so gorgeous.

title: Softening a Truckers Rough Edges
description: Beating a sweet retreat from exposition and event, the Argentine director Pablo Giorgelli turns his minimalist road movie, Las Acacias, into a swelling meditation on wounded hearts and rekindled hopes.

title: Russia: Pussy Riot Lawyer Questioned
description: The police summoned a lawyer for the punk band Pussy Riot for questioning in a criminal case that the authorities say is unrelated to the Pussy Riot case. They plan to question the lawyer, Mark Feygin, about disturbances during a large street protest last spring in Moscow. The wide-ranging investigation has led to the arrests of many opposition figures. Mr. Feygin was one of the speakers at the protest, but he said that he never scuffled with the police and that he thought the summons was indeed related to his work as a defense lawyer for the band members, three of whom were recently convicted of hooliganism for a protest in a Moscow cathedral. I link this with the Pussy Riot case, there are no doubts about it, he said in an interview. I think this is simply an attempt to pressure us.

title: An Ad Agency Crowdsources Its Own Employees Morale
description: AN advertising agency that has been crowdsourcing ideas from its employees is at it again, adopting additional suggestions from staff members on how to improve operations and, by extension, morale.

title: Russia: Fighter Jet Crashes, Killing Pilot
description: A Russian Air Force MiG-29 fighter jet crashed Thursday afternoon near Chita, a city in Eastern Siberia, slamming into a hill close to a local airport and killing the pilot. Flights of MiG-29 fighters have been grounded pending further investigation, a Defense Ministry spokesman, Igor Konashenkov, told the RIA Novosti news agency. The pilots body was found by a search party, and there were no weapons on board, Mr. Konashenkov said. The Interfax news service reported that a second fighter plane crashed Thursday near the Siberian city of Novosibirsk, this one a Sukhoi Su-27.

title: Fashion Week Stargazing: Day 1
description: 10:49 p.m. | Updated

title: From Convention Floor, Delegates Give Obama Benefit of Their Doubts
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  In a perfect world, Sara Riley, a delegate to the Democratic National Convention from Cedar Rapids, Iowa, would have preferred that President Obama had done more to fulfill what the party saw as the transformative nature of the 2008 campaign and election.

title: Friendship Turns Into a Tense Triangle
description: Green, more sketch than fully realized film, musters a decently eerie cabin-in-the-woods tone and look. But Sophia Takal, writing and directing her first feature, has only immature ideas amateurishly executed to bring to her familiar troubled-couple-and-a-stranger setup.

title: Off the Runway: Day 1
description: Scenes from the first day of New York Fashion Week.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: A Fashionable Face-Off in 1973
description: What began as a clever stunt to raise money to restore Versailles  a fashion show featuring five French designers and five Americans  became a kind of battle: in one corner Europe, formal and staid; in the other the razzle-dazzle New World. The winner in a K.O.: America!

title: Conventional Contrast
description: I still remember 2004, when the contrast between the party conventions was painful to watch: disciplined, on-message Republicans, wimpy Democrats afraid to take a stand and hoping that biography would save the day.

title: Romance, the Quirky Souvenir
description: THIS summer, during a conference in Berlin, a fellow attendee told me about the kind of summer love that arises in his profession.

title: Notes From the D.N.C.
A Man, and a Potential Meal
description: Is tasty an acceptable word to use in reference to performances in a film about cannibalism?

title: Assassination Highlights Rifts Facing Syria Rebels
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The assassination of a Syrian rebel fighter linked to Al Qaeda called new attention on Thursday to the ideological differences among the Islamists fighting the government of President Bashar al-Assad and threatened to set off new strife among the rebels.

title: Living in a Material World
description: The poster for Desperate Endeavors says it all: Get It Today, Pay for It Later. Welcome to America. The film  about a man who moves to New York from Bombay in 1973  does little more than illustrate this point again and again. Directed by Salim Khassa from a script he wrote with Donald L. Wilhelm, the movie, stuck like a scratched record, doesnt know what to make of this one point it compulsively and clumsily dramatizes.

title: With Their Food Scarce From Drought, More Animals Try Dining in Town
description: DENVER  People move to the mountains to be closer to nature. But not this close.

title: Oops! The Mysterious Case of the Twice-Stolen Motorcycles
description: With entirely justifiable pride, the police commissioner and the Manhattan district attorney held a news conference in July to announce that a cast of many, many good guys had broken up a gang of motorcycle thieves who, it was believed, were so voracious that they had been responsible for most thefts of cool bikes in New York City during the preceding year.

title: Why Brokers Study Chinese
description: WITH a torrent of money flowing into the United States from China, some savvy real estate brokers are trying to jump in farther upstream to better position themselves to win new clients.

title: Dodgers and Giants Rejuvenate a Rivalry
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Black and White Kindles Are Here to Stay
description: You would think that to announce a black-and-white e-reader in 2012 would be to invite ridicule. Yet when Jeff Bezos, Amazons chief executive, showcased an updated black-and-white e-ink Kindle on Thursday, called the Kindle Paperwhite, people clapped withexcitement. There were even a few oohs and ahhs from the assembled crowd.

title: Hoping for Change at Queens School Where Chancellor Has Ties
description: From the outside, Public School 36 looks like any other utilitarian school building in New York City. Its red brick walls rise three stories over St. Albans, a venerable working-class neighborhood in southeastern Queens.

title: Web Businessman Sentenced for Threats
description: A Brooklyn man who terrified customers of his online eyewear store with threats of violence, including rape, was sentenced on Thursday to four years in federal prison and ordered to pay nearly $100,000 in restitution and fines.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,095 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: For Ryan, Perks of Joining Ticket Can Be Weighty
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  Flying high above the Rocky Mountains on Wednesday, Representative Paul D. Ryan and his brother Tobin jogged their memories to complete a list of the 14,000-foot summits below them that the vice-presidential nominee had climbed.

title: A Lack of Name Power, but Tipsarevic and Ferrer Have Staying Power
description: The people who bought tickets for the mens quarterfinals session at the United States Open on Thursday afternoon were not rewarded with a marquee matchup when Janko Tipsarevic of Serbia and David Ferrer of Spain fell into their laps, but they were rewarded with perhaps the best match of the tournament.

title: Breaking Through
description: Images of five strong performers from the new season.

title: Illuminating Performances
Character, Not Audacity
description: Charlotte, N.C.

title: Cleaning Up the Economy
description: Bill Clintons speech at the Democratic National Convention was a remarkable combination of pretty serious wonkishness  has there ever been a convention speech with that much policy detail?  and memorable zingers. Perhaps the best of those zingers was his sarcastic summary of the Republican case for denying President Obama re-election: We left him a total mess. He hasnt cleaned it up fast enough. So fire him and put us back in.

title: Anything Woods Can Do, McIlroy Does Better
description: CARMEL, Ind.  Tiger Woods produced a deft display of scoring, if not shotmaking, with a seven-under-par 65 at Crooked Stick Golf Club on Thursday in the first round of the BMW Championship. With a little bit of magic, including a holed bump and run shot for a birdie on his final hole, Woods managed to escape mediocrity but not the shadow of his playing partner, Rory McIlroy.

title: New Yorks Moonlighting Lawmakers
description: TO read the news, one might think that the perp walk was a necessary rite in the career of a New York State legislator. Eighteen Albany lawmakers have left office as a result of criminal charges or ethical misconduct since 1999, according to the government-reform organization Citizens Union  a run that the organization appropriately terms a crime wave. There are many reasons to account for this dismal record, but one in particular concerns a practice that, at first glance, may seem endearingly quaint: the legislators are part-timers.

title: Defunct Law Firm Keeps Its Troubles Off the Softball Field
description: On a field of bright green turf, a group of men and women trotted about on Wednesday evening, catching and throwing, hitting, spitting and sliding. They were ballplayers, but in a sense, they were also ghosts, casualties of an immense corporate collapse, with the name of their defunct former employer emblazoned on their torsos: Dewey.

title: Louisiana: Oil Linked to BP
description: Tests performed on Thursday confirmed that the oil found on the Louisiana shoreline after Hurricane Isaac was in fact from the BP spill in 2010. While the oil led to the closing of some waters to commercial fishing, samples taken elsewhere in the Louisiana marsh also matched the oil from the spill, said Edward B. Overton, an environmental sciences professor at Louisiana State University. BP said that it was performing its own tests, but that the cleanup of oil was continuing.

title: In Opposite Dugout, Reminders of Showalters Past
description: BALTIMORE

title: Lottery Numbers
Looking Past November for a Preview of 2016
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Whether President Obama wins or loses in November, one thing is certain for Democrats on the morning after Election Day: the 2016 auditions begin.

title: More Than Just a Category 1
The Latest Attempt to Save the Euro
description: It took a while, but on Thursday Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, explained what he meant last July when he said he would do whatever it takes to save the euro.

title: A Knuckleballers Year
description: If you are a New Yorker who hasnt been to a Mets game this year  and who but the die-hards has, given their cruddy season?  youll want to clear your calendar this month and get to Citi Field. Yes, true Mets fans will mock your fair-weatherness, but its too late to worry about that now. You have about five more chances to see R. A. Dickey play, and it would be a shame to miss them.

title: Voter Suppression, Then and Now
description: New Haven

title: Federer at Flushing Meadows: Flickering or Flaming Out?
description: Once the happiest of hunting grounds for Roger Federer, the United States Open has turned into a booby trap.

title: Judge Rejects New Rules on Access to Prisoners
description: WASHINGTON  Accusing the Obama administration of an illegitimate exercise of executive power, a federal judge on Thursday rejected the governments effort to impose new restrictions on lawyers access to prisoners at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, if they were no longer actively challenging the prisoners detention in federal court.

title: Protests Continue on Final Night of Democratic Convention
description: 12:01 a.m. | Updated  CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Five days of marches at the Democratic National Convention brought confrontation and compromise between protesters and the police, and there was a bit of both on Thursday, the final night of the convention.

title: A Homebuilders Profit Leaps
description: Hovnanian Enterprises, the largest homebuilder in New Jersey, reported an unexpected profit on Thursday for its fiscal third quarter as orders jumped and it recorded a tax benefit.

title: Foreign Policy Issues and Voters
description: Marcus Marby interviews Colin H. Kahl, an Obama campaign advisor on foreign policy.

title: September Release Schedule
description: All dates are subject to change.

title: October Release Schedule
description: OCTOBER

title: New Orleans Levees Hold, and Outsiders Want In
description: LaPLACE, La.  As the motorcade swept through waterlogged stretches of St. John the Baptist Parish earlier this week, Natalie Robottom, the parish president, made her case to President Obama. Using maps and force of will, she told him that while a new ring of levees had saved New Orleans from the waters of Hurricane Isaac, LaPlace and other communities in St. John, west of the city, were still unprotected despite years of study and discussion.

title: John Kerrys Speech
description: John Kerry's lambasted Mr. Romney for failing to pay tribute to troops in Afghanistan during his acceptance speech last week and said he had lied repeatedly about Mr. Obamas record on Israel.

title: November Release Schedule
description: NOVEMBER

title: Fox to Offer Digital Movies Closer to Theatrical Release
description: LOS ANGELES  Fox is about to pry open the window for digital film sales.

title: No Team, No Ticket Sales, but Plenty of Cash
description: For years, it was an underappreciated wrinkle in the historic deal that merged the established National Basketball Association and the upstart American Basketball Association in 1976. The owners of the Spirits of St. Louis agreed to be paid a small fraction of the N.B.A.s television money to comfort them for being cut out of joining the older league.

title: For Now, Taxi Office Says, Cab-Hailing Apps Arent Allowed
description: One day after a start-up company unveiled an app allowing yellow-taxi drivers and passengers to find one another, New York City issued this gentle reminder: Smartphone apps may be the future of hailing a taxicab, but at least for now, their time will have to wait.

title: December Release Schedule
description: DECEMBER

title: Despite Bunts, Yankees Arent Sacrificing Identity
description: BALTIMORE  At the most critical point in the Yankees season, mixed messages appeared to be emanating from the clubhouse over a two-day stretch against the Tampa Bay Rays. Kevin Long, the teams hitting instructor, talked about bunting. Manager Joe Girardi scoffed at the idea. But later, Alex Rodriguez talked about the virtues of playing small ball.

title: A Long, Slow Buildup to an Adoption
description: According to its publicity materials, Normalcy, a new drama at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater, tackles themes of identity, race, terrorism, nationalism, manifest destiny, marriage and the media as it presents a brutally honest look at transracial adoption. Perhaps. But while someone was minding all those issues, the story got up and wandered away.

title: Dont Cry for Them; Its All in Nasty Fun
description: Pssst. Hey, buddy. Yeah, you with the double-breasted pinstripes and the clueless expression. You in the market for the ultimate cheat sheet on Broadway musicals? You know, something thatll let you join the conversation and sound supersmart when your girlfriend (oh, sorry, dude, boyfriend) starts talking about these silly singing shows that put you to sleep?

title: She Went to Haiti
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  When I think about why I enjoyed or didnt enjoy a puzzle, I dont necessarily stop to count up the number of abbreviations, or obscure words, or instances of crosswordese.

title: Arizona Immigration Law Survives Ruling
description: TUCSON  A decision by a federal judge on Wednesday paved the way for the most controversial section of Arizonas sweeping immigration legislation, requiring the authorities to verify the status of people who they suspect are in the country illegally, to finally take effect.

title: The President Plays It Safe
description: The strongest impression left by Mitt Romneys convention speech last week was that the Republican nominees campaign sees itself on pace for a narrow victory in November, with no risks or course corrections needed. The impression left by President Obamas convention speech tonight was that incumbents campaign feels exactly the same way. This was a pure stay-the-course speech, workmanlike and occasionally somewhat distant, with a few inspired and moving passages standing out amid a litany of rhetorical moves that the president has made many times before. There was only the most general sketch of a second term agenda, only a relatively cursory defense of the presidents economic stewardship, and mostly assertions, rather than sustained arguments, to back up his claim that the country is headed (slowly) in the right direction. The strongest and most detailed portions of his remarks came on foreign policy (where his record is more popular and easier to defend)and in his late-in-the-speech attacks on the Republican ticket, which did effectively exploit some of the vulnerabilities that Romneys rather content-free address created. And yes, maybe if Bill Clinton hadnt covered so much of that territory so effectively last night, these strengths would have been enough to make the speech feel successful as a whole. But in the shadow of Clintons performance, the president often felt flat, rote, and unconvincing almost as though he wasnt quite convinced by his own arguments and promises, and felt a little awkward selling them to us.

title: The Weatherman Is Not a Moron
description: From the inside, the National Centers for Environmental Prediction looked like a cross between a submarine command center and a Goldman Sachs trading floor. Twenty minutes outside Washington, it consisted mainly of sleek workstations manned by meteorologists working an armada of flat-screen monitors with maps of every conceivable type of weather data for every corner of the country. The center is part of the National Weather Service, which Ulysses S. Grant created under the War Department. Even now, it remains true to those roots. Many of its meteorologists have a background in the armed services, and virtually all speak with the precision of former officers.

title: Before Blanchett Leaves Sydney Theater Post, Some Housekeeping
description: Cate Blanchett will bid farewell to her role as co-artistic director of Sydney Theater Company by starring with Isabelle Huppert in a new production of The Maids as part of the companys 2013 season, it was announced on Thursday. The Jean Genet play, about a pair of house servants with murderous designs on their employer, will be directed by Benedict Andrews, who previously directed Ms. Blanchett in Gross und Klein (Big and Small) and The War of the Roses for Sydney Theater Company. Its new translation is by Mr. Andrews and Andrew Upton, Ms. Blanchetts husband and co-artistic director. At the start of the year Ms. Blanchett and Mr. Upton said they would step down from their posts at Sydney Theater Company, after presenting several internationally acclaimed productions including A Streetcar Named Desire (which starred Ms. Blanchett as Blanche DuBois) and Uncle Vanya (which featured her as Yelena). But last month the theater company said it had appointed Mr. Upton to stay on alone in a new term that begins next year.

title: Who Made That Spray Tan?
description: In the 1950s, Eva Wittgenstein, a researcher at a Cincinnati hospital who had been treating children with a rare metabolic disorder, noticed that when the medicine she was using splattered, it stained the patients bodies but not their clothes. Curious, Wittgenstein painted her own skin with the solution, which contained dihydroxyacetone (DHA). Within hours these patches turned brown. Soon the miraculous substance was bottled into products like Coppertone QT, which promised 1960s-style convenience: bronze yourself while you sleep; tan groom your legs, so you wont need stockings. DHA produced the color changes by what was called a Maillard reaction, browning the top layer of human skin much the same way a steak browns as it cooks. The reaction turned some people as orange as Oompa-Loompas.

title: Jane Harman Can Take a Punch
description: Last April, your 92-year-old husband, Sidney Harman, the owner of Newsweek, died after being given a diagnosis of leukemia a month before. Was there anything left he wanted to do?  He left an unfinished manuscript for a book called Geezer Golf, about how golf is a metaphor for life, and if you have an excellent short game, you can play with people 20 or 30 years younger, because although your drives are shorter, the rest of your game is better.

title: 30 Variations and a Microphone
description: Glenn Gould was booked into 30th Street Studio for the two middle weeks of June in 1955. The weather in New York was sunny, the temperature in the 60s. He arrived at the studio by taxi from a hotel near Central Park, wearing an overcoat, a beret, a scarf and gloves, and carrying a leather suitcase and his folding chair. He stripped down to a dress shirt and a sleeveless V-neck sweater. Opening the suitcase, he set out pills, bottled water and towels. Rolling up his sleeves, he ran hot water in a sink, the sort of deep-basin porcelain sink that mops are wrung out in, and soaked his hands and forearms until they were red.

title: Voting for Dad
description: My 92-year-old father has entered hospice care. He is a lifelong member of one particular political party and is always the first one in line on voting day. JAN SHULMAN-CLEMENT, WEST HOLLYWOOD, CALIF.
