This shoot is kind of scandalous now that Im thinking about it.

title: Eastwood Says He Balked at Sharing Speech With Romney Campaign
description: Clint Eastwood said the idea for the most controversial convention speech in a generation came to him in the green room off stage, just after he greeted Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan, the countrys most influential Roman Catholic bishop.

title: Teenagers in The Times | The First Daughters, a Cheating Scandal and More
description: Here is our latest edition of Teenagers in The Times, a feature we started in July. In it, we collect all the latest news and multimedia about young people  roughly defined as those under 25  and supply a thumbnail photo and short summary for each piece.

title: Workers Drop Out of the Labor Force
description: Business Day Live: William M. Rodgers III, chief economist at the Heldrich Center, on why some people have stopped looking for work. | Competing for the attention of would-be space tourists.

title: Business Day Live: Hiring Slows in August, Adding to Pressure on Fed and Obama
description: What the job figures mean for the economy. | Competing for the attention of would-be space tourists.

title: Very, Very High Season
description: A quick rundown of whats being offered by some space salespeople.

title: Spaceport America Eyes the (Near) Future
description: AS you approach from the west, the Spaceport America main terminal looks like a gigantic moth, its rounded wings outspread against the arid, reddish-brown dirt of southern New Mexico.

title: Space Tourism Is Here! Wealthy Adventurers Wanted
description: WEDGED between a strip-mall chiropractor and a cluster of optometrists in Rochester, N.Y., the offices of the DePrez Group of Travel Companies hardly seems like the kind of place where someone would begin a journey to the stars.

title: At One With the Earth, and the Clients
description: The skeleton of the straw bale house has risen with remarkable speed. In little more than a week, we framed out the walls and almost finished the roof. Now there is no doubt that a house is coming into being, although at this point it is not obvious that it will be anything out of the ordinary. The trained eye will notice the lack of the evenly spaced studs that are normally needed to hang drywall, as well as the presence of a second set of wooden sill plates to support the inside edge of the 18-inch-thick straw bales.

title: In Maine, Walking Where Waves Moved Winslow Homers Brush
description: IN the summer, when the sun played on the juniper bushes, and in the fall, when the air was clear enough to see to the white lighthouse on Wood Island, and in the winter, when the sea battered the granite rocks, Winslow Homer thrived at Prouts Neck, a spit of land off the Southern coast of Maine.

title: Underwater Paradise at a Pacific Eco-Resort
description: WHEN, after two days of flying, one reaches the island of Bali only to realize that more days of travel lie ahead  from Denpasar to Makassar, then to Sorong in West Papua on one dodgy Indonesian airline after another, and finally a five-hour boat trip  a traveler begins to wonder whether a stay at an eco-resort on a remote Pacific Island will make all the jet lag, chaotic airports and carbon dioxide emissions seem worth it.

title: Restaurant Report: Nota Bene in Prague
description: Tracking down great beer in Prague has never been a problem. Finding a decent meal has certainly gotten easier. But for years, good food and good brews were like the Czech capitals version of Clark Kent and Superman: you never saw them in the same place.

title: Hotel Review: The Surrey in New York
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Costa Rica Goes Locavore
description: LOOKING at the sunny waters of the Pacific through the eyes of a hungry chef, Demian Geneau saw a smorgasbord. He also knew what was available to his own kitchen, at a posh resort on Costa Ricas Nicoya Peninsula. Between the two lay a great disconnect.

title: Ska Groove, Teen Vibe and Glam-Punk Fury
description: WAYLON JENNINGS Waylon Jennings cut some voice-and-guitar only songs in 1999 at the home studio of his steel guitarist, Robby Turner, intending to add instruments to them later. He never did, and died in 2002. Finally, heres the posthumous 12-song result produced by Mr. Turner: Goin Down Rockin: The Last Recordings, your basic outlaw-country mix of dire and tenderhearted songs for sports bars and campfires. Tuesday. Saguaro Road. (Ben Ratliff)

title: Namibias Dramatic Dunes
description: MANY sights of Namibia, from its grassy savannas to its lush waterfalls, appear in Samsara, the visually stunning, nonverbal film by Ron Fricke and Mark Magidson.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Regarding Fleet of Foot, on Land or in the Air (Sept. 2):

title: Police Seeking Man Who Abused Dog in Elevator
description: For at least the fifth time in less than three years, the police are seeking the publics help in tracking down someone caught on video beating a dog in a housing-project elevator. The latest incident happened Aug. 26 at the Wagner Houses in East Harlem, site of a similar episode in 2011.

title: Medicaid Changes Loom for the Elderly
description: The Times reports this morning on states efforts to rein in Medicaid costs with managed care programs and how these may affect the elderly in nursing homes.

title: Fire This Guy?
description: Get rid of him. Hit the road, Barack. Epic fail. Youre fired.

title: Shepard Fairey Is Fined and Sentenced to Probation in Hope Poster Case
description: The artist Shepard Fairey, whose 2008 poster of Barack Obama became an optimistic symbol of the last presidential campaign before spawning a bitter copyright battle with criminal overtones, was sentenced in federal court in Manhattan on Friday to two years of probation and fined $25,000 for tampering with evidence in the case.

title: Its Own Reason for Being
description: OSCAR DE LA RENTA was singing in his Madison Avenue boutique. Lines of people waited behind barricades to get into Bergdorf Goodman. Most of SoHo and the meatpacking district looked like a police state for fashion victims.

title: T-Mobile Offers a New Unlimited Data Plan
description: You may have noticed that unlimited data plans usually come with an asterisk  the speed at which you get the data slows to a crawl after you have used a certain amount of data. But T-Mobile is reversing the trend.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Jennifer Egan discusses Michael Chabons Telegraph Avenue; Parul Sehgal on the flood of important fiction this fall; Daniel Smith talks about his book Monkey Mind: A Memoir of Anxiety; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: This Weeks Movies: Sept. 7
description: In This Weeks Movies, the New York Times critics share their thoughts on Bachelorette, The Inbetweeners and Keep the Lights On. Full reviews can be found here.

title: Obama Counterpunches on Climate Change
description: Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential nominee, took a not-too-subtle jab at President Obama in his convention speech last week, mocking Mr. Obamas soaring 2008 campaign language about rolling back the rising seas and healing the planet. Mr. Romneys gibe drew thunderous applause from the Republican delegates, many of whom express doubt about the existence of climate change.

title: Quirky Gets Backing From Andreessen Horowitz and Kleiner Perkins
description: Social media has transformed many areas, including real estate and online communications. Now, venture capitalists are betting the sector can even tackle product manufacturing.

title: Six Days After 9/11, Another Anniversary Worth Honoring
description: In the coming days, the calendar will bring the anniversaries of two signal events. One, of course, is Sept. 11, a Tuesday this year, as it was in 2001, when Al Qaeda terrorists in four hijacked planes killed more than 3,000 Americans. With public memorial services and private tears, those deaths will be recalled and mourned.

title: Weekend Fare
description: To celebrate the start of the new school year, free soft serve yogurt will be handed out from 2 to 6 p.m. Friday at Chelseas Table, located at Pier 62 (just west of the 23rd Street entrance to Chelsea Piers). One free small cup of the yogurt with one topping will be available to each customer at the caf or the Stonyfield Organic Dairy Bar.

title: Family Property Means Managing for a Legacy
description: SOME wealthy people will have to make a decision soon if they are to take advantage of the $5.12 million gift tax exemption that is due to expire at the end of the year.

title: Off the Charts
description: At the onset of last summer, the magazine that employed me as a rock critic decided to continue publishing without me, no longer supplying a salary or respite from the office water cooler. My dismissal came via a private equity group situation  No hard feelings, right?  yet I couldnt help taking offense. For the next several months, I steered clear of the music world that for years I had cherished.

title: Share of Men in Labor Force at All-Time Low
description: Fridays jobs report for August was chock full of all sorts of bad news. Among the most distressing: The share of men actively participating in the labor force  that is, working or looking for work  was at an all-time low.

title: A Soldier on the Tennis Court
description: The players arent the only ones breaking a sweat on the courts at the United States Open.

title: Up Front
description: This week, Jennifer Gilmore reviews The Revised Fundamentals of Caregiving, a novel by Jonathan Evison, in which a former stay-at-home dad who lost his children in a grisly accident becomes a caregiver for hire. Caretaking is often stereotyped as womens work, Gilmore wrote in an e-mail, but in Evisons book, caring deeply, dealing with grief, transcends gender.

title: Inside the List
description: DOCTOR, LAWYER, WRITER? The suspense novelist Tess Gerritsen  her latest Rizzoli and Isles mystery, Last to Die, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 3  told The New Zealand Herald last year that she had been reluctant for more than 20 novels to introduce elements of her Chinese-American heritage into her fiction. Thats because early in her career, when she had just quit medicine to write romantic thrillers, editors warned her there was no market for Asian characters, and the advice stayed with her even as she moved away from the romance genre.

title: Editors Choice
description: MORTALITY,  by Christopher Hitchens. (Twelve, $22.99.) Like virtually everything Hitchens wrote over his long career, these dispatches from Tumorville, written after he learned of his ultimately fatal esophageal cancer, are diamond-hard and brilliant.

title: Paperback Row
description: BUSY MONSTERS,  by William Giraldi. (Norton, $15.95.) Speaking in a pastiche of idioms (Southern, Victorian, Western), Charles Homar, the cuckolded hero of Giraldis first novel, wrestles with notions of manliness. Pledging to win back his errant fiance, who has run off with a squid hunter, Charles chronicles his haywire schemes  involving Bigfoot, U.F.O.s and an oversexed Italian bodybuilder  in installments for a weekly magazine.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: THE ORCHARDIST  By Amanda Coplin.  Harper/HarperCollins, $26.99.

title: Indecent Exposure
description: Privacy is a topic that tends to inspire discursive essays rather than philosophical treatises. In A Bachelors Complaint, in 1823, Charles Lamb deplored the exhibitionism of married couples who perk up their public displays of affection when in the company of single friends. In 1890, Samuel Warren and Louis Brandeis lamented that American law, which protects privacy indirectly through laws safeguarding property, contains no remedies for the mental suffering that results from an offense against honor. Rather than attempting a comprehensive treatment of the subject, the privacy essayist identifies a distinctive value that privacy protects (ranging from dignity and autonomy to intimacy and friendship) and defends its value by using concrete examples and anecdotes from daily life.

title: Outback Outcasts
description: Kate Grenvilles latest novel, Sarah Thornhill, provides a wrenching conclusion to a tough-hearted trilogy about the colonizing of Australia. In her previous excursions into this rough, unforgiving land, shiploads of transported convicts, indentured servants and down-on-their-luck gentry were seen carving out English-style estates and tangling with aboriginals who somehow  to the newcomers astonishment  couldnt accept the fact that theyd been conquered. By the time the heroine of this new book is born, in 1816, the countrys future is almost settled.

title: Why Were We in Vietnam?
description: During the Casablanca conference in January 1943, Franklin Roosevelt spoke bitterly to his son about European imperialism: Dont think for a moment, Elliott, that Americans would be dying in the Pacific tonight if it hadnt been for the shortsighted greed of the French and the British and the Dutch. Earlier, he had spoken openly to the White House correspondents: There has never been, there isnt now and there never will be, any race of people on earth fit to serve as masters over their fellow men. . . . We believe that any nationality, no matter how small, has the inherent right to its own nationhood. That was the core of the Atlantic Charter in 1941, which both Churchill and Roosevelt signed. It called on the right of all peoples to choose the form of government under which they will live.

title: Haunted Highways
description: What would highway killers do without highways?

title: Panic Buttons
description: The long list of things that, over the years, have made Daniel Smith nervous includes sex, death, work, water, food, air travel, disease, amateur theater, people hes related to and people hes not related to, so the prospect of a book review probably wouldnt seem like a very big deal to him. Or would it?

title: Effect of Jobs Numbers on Presidential Race Is Uncertain
description: Fridays jobs report was a weak one  with Augusts job growth more in line with the tepidgrowth of the spring than the stronger numbers in July or over the winter months.

title: Side Effects
description: When 14-year-old Nora gets a pair of diamond earrings in the mail from the father shes never met, her mother, Ruby, looks at them and dryly remarks, Theyre the size of birth control pills.

title: Assisted Living
description: Failure makes me hungry, Ben Benjamin says in The Revised Fundamentals of Caregiving, Jonathan Evisons third novel. Ben responds to defeat with a Mr. Goodbar and a bag of chips, which is just part of what makes his funny and relatable voice the linchpin of this engaging book.

title: Two Cuts of Brisket
description: With Rosh Hashana approaching, Melissa Clark talks about how to select a brisket perfect for your family dinner.

title: Long Divisions
description: RajivChandrasekaran has done it again. Like Imperial Life in the Emerald City, his chronicle of Washingtons hapless management of the Iraq war in its early days, Little America is a beautifully written and deeply reported account of how a divided United States government and its dysfunctional bureaucracy have foiled American efforts abroad, this time to suppress the Taliban insurgency and bring stability to Afghanistan. It tells a story of political foibles, overly ambitious goals and feckless Afghans and Americans. The United States seems condemned to lurch between disastrous quick fixes and unrealistic visions of remaking countries overnight in its own image, never finding a middle road. No doubt most readers of this book will come away with the conclusion that our principal enemy in all this is ourselves.

title: Many Wars in One
description: Toward the end of this powerful narrative of World War II, Antony Beevor quotes a report, by the Australian war correspondent Godfrey Blunden, of an encounter with some American troops who had just been released from German P.O.W. camps. They had been in Europe only a few months, thrown into combat and almost instantly captured during the Ardennes offensive, Hitlers last big throw of the dice. The men now had xylophone ribs and gangling arms. Some of their fellow prisoners had been beaten to death by their guards for attempting to take sugar beets from fields. Blunden wrote: They were more pitiful because they were only boys drafted from nice homes in a nice country knowing nothing about Europe, not tough like Australians, or shrewd like the French or irreducibly stubborn like the English. They just didnt know what it was all about.

title: These Wild Solitudes
description: Paul Auster was a novelist in Brooklyn before there were novelists in Brooklyn. (When I was growing up there in the 1980s, my father used to point him out to me as we did the grocery shopping in Park Slope  this was a rare kind of sighting.) Back in those days, his novels  the New York Trilogy, Leviathan, Moon Palace  seemed postmodern and fresh. They mingled the tropes of detective fiction with a kind of European quasi-philosophical ambiguity. Kafka goes gumshoe, as one of his editors described it. The novels comprised stories nested within stories; there were characters named Paul Auster, and there were doppelgngers even for the doppelgngers.

title: Murder in the Cathedral
description: The biographers trap, John Guy remarks in Thomas Becket, his portrait of that foremost friend turned foremost foe of Henry II, is to look for a decisive moment of change. But, he adds, to do that is to write the history of the saint without his shadow. With Becket, this temptation often seems to have been irresistible, from the very night of his murder, Dec. 29, 1170, near the high altar of Canterbury Cathedral. As a crowd swooped down on the battered corpse of the archbishop, tearing off pieces of clothing to dip in the gruesome puddle of his blood and brains, the outlines of the story of Beckets sudden conversion from luxury-loving chancellor to ascetic defender of the church were already being rehearsed, soon to be followed by tales of his miraculous powers.

title: When Audio Books Do and Dont Count for School
description: Does listening to an audio book count for school reading, and if it does, when? I ran across this quandary when helping my rising third grader fill out her summer reading list before going back to school. She wanted to include the books shes listened to (Id like to say it was to show her teacher what she enjoyed, but I know full well it was to make her list look longer), and I hesitated. Did a book listened to, I asked here last week, really count as a book read?

title: Killing Time
description: The temptations that will beset you will be very great, a Mississippi man, already a veteran in the Civil War, warned his newly enlisted younger brother. The evil he warned of wasnt treason or desertion or theft. It was cards. Of all the evil practices that abound in Camp, gambling is the most pernicious and fraught with the most direful consequences.

title: Bonus Tracks: Bruuuuuuuuce!
description: This summer, Lizzy Goodman wrote about the New Jersey band the Gaslight Anthem. Her article highlighted the Gaslight Anthems anxiety  if you can call it that  of being seen as the heirs to Bruce Springsteens legacy. Last weekend, she got to see the real thing. Her dispatch from the floor seats follows.

title: Invite Briskets More-Tender Brother for the Holidays
description: FOR years, I thought brisket was by nature a somewhat stringy, dry and chewy cut of beef. No matter how exacting the recipe or how careful the cook, the leanness of the meat dictated the texture.

title: Peter Som: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Book Review Podcast: Michael Chabons Telegraph Avenue
description: This week in the New York Times Book Review, one Pulitzer Prize winner reviews another as Jennifer Egan considers Michael Chabons Telegraph Avenue. The novel is set in and around a used-record store on the boulevard where Oakland aligns with Berkeley. Ms. Egan writes:

title: At Peter Soms Show, Birds Suddenly Appear
description: The first few notes of Close to You by the Carpenters played at the beginning of the Peter Som show Friday morning. That was enough to suggest a little bit of romantic nostalgia, the kind that usually describes Mr. Soms dreamy floral prints. For spring, he made jeans in a pink print that looked like bubble gum, part of a collaboration between Mr. Som and Earnest Sewn, the jeans company, and a series of multicolored pieces, like a T-shirt, a coat and a skirt, each made of a patchwork of snakeskin in an oversize herringbone pattern.

title: Collect Call | Steven Kolbs Owls
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Judge Widens Scope of Prosecutors Investigation in Lopez Case
description: A judge authorized a special prosecutor on Friday to expand his criminal investigation into sexual harassment claims that two female staff members brought against Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, giving the prosecutor the power to examine whether crimes were committed when public and private money was paid to settle similar complaints brought by two other female staff members.

title: The Sweet Spot | The Film Festival
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk Telluride, Toronto and the taxonomy of the film festival.

title: What Ails the U.S.?
description: NEW YORK  Like hawkers on a crowded street, observers of all persuasions are busy peddling the notion that America is in big trouble.

title: Managing a Childs Allowance, the Online Version
description: Giving children an allowance always seems like a good idea at first. But just try following through in practice.

title: Sept. 9  15
description: THE Zimbabwe-born NORA CHIPAUMIRE, now working out of New York, has spent most of her (still relatively short) choreographic career exploring ideas about African identity  and even more specifically, ideas about female African identity. Until now her pieces have been largely abstract, even if they have dealt with Zimbabwean history and her experience of it. But in Miriam, which opens on Wednesday in the Fishman Space of the Brooklyn Academy of Musics new Fisher Building, Ms. Chipaumire turns to the life of the South African singer MIRIAM MAKEBA, taking inspiration from her dramatic narrative  first as an exiled, worldwide symbol of protest against the apartheid government, later as the beloved artist known as Mama Africa.

title: What My Fathers Dementia Told Me
description: I was the copy editor assigned to work on Alex Witchels memoir about her mothers dementia. I was fortunate because her writing is compelling and didnt need any help from me, and also because it forced me to focus on the quality of my fathers dementia, maybe for the first time.

title: What Citizenship Means
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  He didnt deliver a clear second-term agenda, or a speech that thrilled. He didnt explain how his re-election will spell an end to Washingtons policy stalemate. But President Obama did offer a sort of consolation prize in his convention speech: a new theme to sum up his case against Mitt Romney.

title: The Sweet Spot | Sept. 7, 2012
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk Telluride, Toronto and the taxonomy of the film festival.

title: As PC Sales Turn Down, Intel Trims Its Outlook
description: SAN FRANCISCO  With the personal computer market stalled, Intel, the primary maker of computer chips, warned its investors Friday that revenue would be lower than expected, as would profit margins.

title: Image of the Day: September 7
Study Finds Some African Farmers Adapting to Withstand Climate Stresses
description: Its been clear for many years that the stresses that come with extreme climate conditions have an outsize impact on poor communities, and nowhere more so than in sub-Saharan Africa. Given the studies projecting how greenhouse-driven warming will worsen drought and heat in regions that already tend to be dry and hot, its encouraging to see signs in one hard-hit African region of farmers capacity to shift practices to deal with intensifying climatic stresses.

title: Influence of Money Market Funds Ended Overhaul
description: Four years after the fall of Lehman Brothers, and with a presidential campaign in full swing, everyone can surely agree on one thing: we shouldnt risk another financial crisis.

title: The Employment Situation
description: My current favorite gauge of the jobs picture is the employment-population ratio for prime-age adults (25-54). EP ratio instead of unemployment rate, because U may be distorted by workers dropping out. Prime-age not because the old and young dont matter, but to take demographic change out of the picture.

title: After a Disappointing Jobs Report, Romney Attacks Obama
description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa  Seizing on a disappointing jobs report, Mitt Romney questioned on Friday whether President Obama knows what hes doing when it came to fixing the economy.

title: Think Like a Doctor: The Blue Girl Solved!
description: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to solve the mystery of a 17-year-old girl who was turning blue. We received more than 400 colorful responses that ran from Smurfitis and the occasional reference to Willy Wonka to the very serious suggestion of methemoglobinemia, a disorder in which patients turn blue intermittently because of abnormal red blood cells that cannot hold on to oxygen.

title: Lowercase Minimalists
description: THE day that Coexist, the second album by the miserabilist British band the xx, was mastered, the groups three members  Romy Madley Croft, Oliver Sim, Jamie Smith  went out for McDonalds. Each day during the months of recording the album, on the way to the studio with black velvet-covered walls they were hunkered down in, theyd walk past McDonalds and sigh, tempted by the smell but not giving in.

title: Freezing Brisket
description: This weeks column is about braising brisket for a holiday meal. For years, my mother often cooked her brisket ahead and froze it. This was extremely convenient and the results were good. She would transfer the cooked and cooled meat to a plastic Ziploc, spoon in the sauce and then close the bag, squeezing out the air. Squeezing out the air is the key step. Sometimes she created a faux vacuum by inserting a straw into the bag, inhaling the air and quickly closing it. Of course a vacuum sealer works even better if you have one.

title: Former Tennis Star Makes a Mark at Columbia Law School
description: Every fall, Columbia Law School admits a couple hundred students to its prestigious masters program. This years crop includes a civil rights activist from Armenia, a terrorism-finance expert from Bangladesh and a Croatian lawyer with a win over Roger Federer.

title: Truck Driver in Kerry Kennedy Crash Pleads Not Guilty
description: ARMONK, N.Y. -- The driver of a tractor-trailer who was involved in an accident with a car driven by Kerry Kennedy two months ago pleaded not guilty on Friday to leaving the scene of an accident and vowed to fight the charge.

title: Remembering Ashe, in Triumphs and Images
description: Tennis has produced many champions but few heroes  winners whose accomplishments have merged with or even shaped the larger currents of their time.

title: Andrea Hailey and David Williamson
description: THERE was very little Andrea Hailey disliked about David Williamson when she first met him through friends nearly six years ago.

title: Deciding What to Leave to Heirs
description: Paul Sullivan writes this week in his Wealth Matters column about the $5.12 million gift tax exemption that is due to expire at the end of the year.

title: On Whether to Use Allowance-Tracking Web Sites
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I write about Tykoon, the newest of a group of Web sites and apps that help parents dole out allowances, track chores and encourage saving.

title: Fashion Week Parties, Night 1
description: Richard Chai, Futura and Supreme kicked off New York Fashion Week.

title: In Midtown, Pedestrians Secret Shortcut Is Now Official
description: For years, it was an open secret  a midblock portal that kept the savviest travelers away from the pedestrian gridlock of Midtown avenues, even if they had to jaywalk a bit to execute the shortcut.

title: Out of the Box
description: Among the houses that Philip Johnson designed in New Canaan, Conn., the suburban enclave that became a laboratory for postwar Modernist design, the Robert C. Wiley house, completed in 1953, remains one of his most elegant. It is a strikingly simple composition of two rectangular boxes: one, a glass and wood pavilion with a single, 15-foot-tall living, dining and kitchen space, is cantilevered over the other, a stone and concrete base that contains, among other things, four small bedrooms, bathrooms and a sitting room. The 3,000-square-foot house typifies Modernisms insistence on efficient use of space, but by the advent of the McMansion era, despite its architectural pedigree, it merely seemed quaintly, and unsalably, tiny.

title: The Daily Shoe | Jason Wu
description: Jason Wu showed a very pretty and semiformal collection full of sex-pot signatures (leather harnesses, lace and leopard, lots of transparency) that, under Wus command, took a turn toward boudoir dressing without falling into bed. Some of the stilettos had nail-sharp heels studded with rhinestones. Others featured black netting bejeweled with circles and stars. These with tiny pearls dotting the contrasting ankle strap were the ones that T editors would, if they could, take home tonight.

title: So Thats How They Do It
description: Workers cleaning the exterior of the Guggenheim Museum on Friday morning, the first such work since the museums restoration was completed in 2008. View a larger version.

title: French President Must Cut Deficit, but How?
description: PARIS  Samir Chaffar shook his head slowly on a recent weekday as he scanned a raft of newspapers at a kiosk near the Louvre.

title: Through Fire, Glimpsing the Next Mercedes-Benz S-Class
description: Mercedes-Benz has unveiled a sculpture hinting at the lines of the marques redesigned flagship sedan.

title: Life Without Indian Point, Redux
description: The consequences of running the Indian Point nuclear reactors or shutting them down run from easy-to-spot to hard-to-calculate.

title: Now the Rutgers Coach, but Still a Teacher
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  The blinds in the corner office at the Hale Center abutting the Rutgers football stadium are always shut, keeping the square room dim, the dark leather couches cool and the flat-screen monitors shaded, so that Coach Kyle Flood can see his PowerPoint presentations.

title: What Happens When the Two Israels Meet
description: Kfar Vradim, Israel

title: Jobs Numbers Prompt Obama to Account for Anemic Recovery
description: IOWA CITY  His convention speech was only hours old when President Obama, confronted by a weak new jobs report, found himself Friday having to use precious time on the campaign trail to account for the countrys continued anemic economic recovery.

title: Outdoor Ad Company Already Had Planes, Now Adds Blimps
description: A leading outdoor advertising company is expanding its air force by adding ad blimps to its fleet of planes that carry ad banners.

title: Excerpt: 'Nashvile'
description: The new ABC series starts on Oct. 10.

title: Excerpt: '666 Park Avenue'
description: The new ABC series starts on Sept. 30.

title: Venice Film Festival: James Franco and Harmony Korine on Spring Breakers
description: VENICE  Harmony Korine made his first splash as the screenwriter of the 1995 sensation Kids, which was both hailed and denounced for its in-your-face depiction of sexually active, substance-abusing teenagers. His latest film, Spring Breakers, is another generational portrait of youthful debauchery, but Mr. Korine, at 39, is observing from the outside this time.

title: Tiny Lifesaver for a Growing Worry
description: It has become an all-too-familiar story in schools across the country: a child eats a peanut or is stung by a bee and suffers an immediate, life-threatening allergic reaction known as anaphylaxis.

title: Trying on an Old Soul With Some Alterations
description: MESHELL NDEGEOCELLO is wary of giving the wrong impression with Pour Une me Souveraine: A Dedication to Nina Simone (Nave), her 10th studio album, due out on Oct. 9. I dont want to necromance, she said recently. I feel like thats going on a lot.

title: Nokias Misleading Video Dents Lumias Image
description: Taking the stage a week before Apple, Nokia had the chance to put on a bold and confident performance with its demonstration of new smartphones. Instead, a misleading promotional video has left the company looking a little desperate. Its underwhelming presentation and a big drop in its stock price added up to a less than stellar week for Nokia.

title: Scenes From the New Season
description: A look at the new network series debuting this fall.

title: Riff Bonus: A Night in the Life of the Culture
description: This weeks bonus feature to Paul Elies Riff on using recording-studio equipment for classical music is just that: a bonus excerpt from Paul Elies book, Reinventing Bach, in which he surveys the American cultural landscape around one night that Glenn Gould was recording the Goldberg Variations in New York City.

title: The Old Mix and Match Inspires New Fall Shows
description: THE new fall season makes one thing clear: The television industrys Random Show-Idea Generators have been getting quite a workout.

title: Three Searches for a First Apartment
description: Four new graduates kept track of the ups and downs of their search from the moment they began looking for a place to the day they signed the lease.

title: Launching Space Tourism
description: Companies are competing to take amateur astronauts into space.

title: Williams and Azarenka Will Play in Open Final
description: No. 1 Victoria Azarenka and No. 4 Serena Williams will meet in the 2012 United States Open final, after winning semifinals Friday of very different difficulty levels.

title: Soldiers Friendship, Shared Across Generations, Ends With More Gained Than Lost
description: My friend Bob Kotlowitz died two weekends ago. He was 87  lucky enough to live a long, rich life  but he just as easily couldve been killed before the age of 19. Death is an integral part of an infantrymans life, floating around us in a thin, grim fog. Were trained and conditioned to kill, we go to war to kill: thats the heart of the life. Theres a cosmic balancing act to all this: death is pretty impartial. Our friends are killed in the war  whether theyre shot, blown up or snuffed out in accidents  or during training. It doesnt get easier, all this dying, even after leaving the Army. After all, were still at war and friends still die overseas. At the same time, some, faced with the cumulative weight of all this, seek their own quietus.

title: The Launching Pad
description: FOR countless newly minted college graduates, its a rite of passage. After the mortarboards have been tossed into the air, they head for New York City, ready to embark on the next chapter of their lives. In 2010, some 40,000 graduates age 22 to 28 moved to the city in search of jobs, according to the latest figures from the Census Bureaus American Community Survey.

title: African-American Theater in Minnesota Suspends Programming
description: Penumbra Theater in St. Paul, Minn.,which describes itself as the countrys largest African-American theater, has announced that it is suspending programming this season until it can resolve a severe budget crunch.

title: Ratings Gold for Gordon Ramsays Reality Empire
description: The reality television stars Simon Cowell, Nicole Snooki Polizzi and the Kardashian clan may have hoarded most of the headlines this summer, but the chef Gordon Ramsay has quietly (at least for him) cemented his spot as one of TVs most popular personalities. His three shows on Fox  Hells Kitchen, MasterChef and the recently launched Hotel Hell  all rank in the Top 10 of all summer programs in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, the age group most coveted by advertisers.

title: To Contend at the Paralympics, Race Brave
description: The wheelchair racer Joshua George will be competing in the 2012 Paralympic Games in London and writing for the 2012 London blog.

title: After High Note for Euro Plan, Discord Emerges
description: PARIS  In the long euro crisis, there is almost always a sobering morning-after whenever European leaders appear to have made a major breakthrough. And so it went again on Friday.

title: A Possible Renoir Surfaces at a Virginia Flea Market
description: Calling Antiques Roadshow. It was a Paul Bunyan doll that captured her eye, but the Virginia flea market buyer, who paid less than $50 for the box lot that held it, also purchased what could turn out to be a painting by the French artist Pierre-Auguste Renoir.

title: Not Looking, but Still Wanting to Work
description: The number of people not in the labor force  that is, neither working nor looking for work  rose by almost 600,000 in August.

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 7
description: A view of the day in sports, including the continuation of the Tour of Spain cycling race and the London Paralympic Games.

title: New Arrivals, in High-Def
description: Mamie Gummer, Emily Owens, M.D.

title: All Is Forgiven as Jets Lineman Re-Signs After Being Cut
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  On Tuesday, four days after he thought he made the Jets roster  and three days after the team cut him to make room for another defensive tackle  Marcus Dixon was at his home in Morristown when his phone rang.

title: Week in Review: Off to the Principals Office
description: A company tries to win over investors for a huge merger in the natural resources business. We visited multinationals staking a claim in venture capital. And Andrew Ross Sorkin pointed to the man behind Facebooks initial public offering debacle.

title: Wholesome Risotto With Whole Grains
description: If you love creamy risotto but want to make it more wholesome, try these tips from Martha Rose Shulman. This weeks Recipes for Health explores new ways to add whole grains to risotto.

title: Ahead of His Time | Norman Bel Geddes
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Close to the City, but With a Life of Its Own
description: AFTER 13 years in a house in Oradell, N.J., Florence Fleischman and her husband, Glenn, were ready to return to high-rise living. In May, the couple moved back to the same Fort Lee apartment building where they had lived as newlyweds and raised two children, now teenagers, through toddlerhood.

title: Chevy Thinks Small
description: The small 1.2-liter 84-horsepower Chevrolet Spark is thrifty and says something about G.M.s ability to adapt to the current marketplace.

title: Wheels Calendar for Sept. 7-9
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $6.3 Million
description: A luminous TriBeCa penthouse at 45-47 Warren Street, acquired in 1999 by Thomas Krens during his provocative tenure as the director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation in New York, sold for $6.3 million and was the most expensive residential sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Korean-Flavored Chevy Is Thrifty and City-Smart
description: AT the 2001 Detroit auto show, before he was pulled back into the family business like the movie mobster Michael Corleone, General Motors godfather-for-hire, Robert A. Lutz, gravely assessed the design studies on display: A whole family of angry kitchen appliances, demented toasters, furious bread machines and vengeful trash compactors.

title: Singer Gets His Van Back, but Pays a Price
description: Joseph Arthur, the Brooklyn-based singer and painter whose touring van was towed and sold at auction last month, has tracked down and retrieved his vehicle, full of amplifiers and artwork. But it cost him $5,500.

title: Taking the Cheap Out of the Small Car
description: THE idea that good things come in small packages has rarely played well with American car buyers. And who can blame them?

title: Q&A
description: Still Awaiting Financial Statements

title: Syrian Rebels Say They Freed 350 Prisoners, as Others Appeal for Unity
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian rebels claimed Friday night that they had freed 350 prisoners held in a security building in the divided city of Aleppo, while in the opposition stronghold of Homs the rebels supporters held a public protest against the disorganization and lack of unity among their forces.

title: Jason Wu: Naughty or Nice
description: The photographer Helmut Newton is a touchstone for any designer whos in the mood for the naughty, the kinky or the downright dark. So whats a sweetie pie like Jason Wu doing in that territory? His show today had models in glove-tight leather dresses, exposed bras and a lot of thin leather harness straps.

title: U.S. Open Food of the Day: Niman Ranch B.L.T.
description: This is the final installment of our daily reviews of food from the United States Open concession stands.

title: Black Voter in a Blue Dog District
description: Congressman Larry Kissell represents a white, rural district in North Carolina. He is not endorsing President Obama. Marcus Mabry talks with Walter Rogers, a black voter in the district.

title: Enjoying Results of Summers Labor
description: LABOR DAY is long past, but Im not ready to say goodbye to summer, and Im certainly not ready to give up on late-summer produce, most of which is still quite glorious. It would be a shame to fast-forward prematurely into autumn fare.

title: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
description: Photos from India, Hong Kong, Syria and Iowa.

title: Small Cars Are Changing; Will They Fit in the U.S.?
description: CARS have scale; they look different depending on the background they are set against. The Smart that seemed dashing when driven around Paris by Tom Hanks may look like a recycling container in the setting of a Montana highway.

title: Fixes to Get You Started and Cool
description: INFINITIS and Volvos with air-conditioning troubles and Chevrolet Silverados with failing starter motors are among the mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: The Invisibles at the Top
description: The Invisibles Omnibus, a collection of the entire run of the Vertigo series from DC Comics created by Grant Morrison and originally serialized in the 1990s, lands at No. 1 on our hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week.

title: The Trouble With Numbers: Complaints on a Much Anticipated Jobs Report
description: Theres a drumroll beforehand and a great crashing of cymbals as it happens. Its the federal governments monthly report on the nations employment  a matter thats given huge political weight in the current presidential campaign, as Jim Rutenbergs news analysis on todays front page makes clear. The Wall Street Journal and many other news organizations also gave it front-page treatment, before the fact.

title: Bahraini Activists Document Crackdown on Protest
description: Security forces again fired tear gas and arrested demonstrators in Bahrains capital on Friday, as protesters renewed their calls for reform and the release of political prisoners in the island kingdom that is home to the United States Navys Fifth Fleet.

title: R. A. Dickey Signs Deal for Three Childrens Books
description: The knuckleball pitcher R. A. Dickey is putting together a historic season for the Mets. Hes also been busy building a literary career. Mr. Dickey, the author of an acclaimed memoir, has now signed a deal to publish three childrens books with Dial, an imprint of the publisher Penguin.

title: Jason Wu: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Fashion Week Casting | Rag & Bone
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Meet the Nixons: Anthony LaPaglia, Kathryn Erbe Will Star in Checkers
description: The Tony Award winner Anthony LaPaglia will play Richard Nixon and Kathryn Erbe (Law & Order: Criminal Intent) will play Pat Nixon in the world premiere of Douglas McGraths play Checkers this fall at Off Broadways Vineyard Theater, executives there announced on Friday. The play, set during the 1952 presidential election, is a character study of Nixon (then the Republican nominee for vice president) as well as a rendering of the Nixon marriage in a moment of crisis, as he delivered his so-called Checkers speech addressing allegations of financial improprieties.

title: Breaking It Down: Ferrer vs. Tipsarevic
description: Thank you, Janko. Thank you, David.

title: Why My Kindergartner Will Stay Home for School
description: When my son was 2 and a half and our daughter was born, I fantasized about the day I would take him to kindergarten. But by the time he turned 4, he had evolved from a demanding toddler who seemed to wake his sister from every nap to a delightful little boy. We enjoyed each others company and I could tell that he was benefiting from our extended time together. Surrendering him to another persons influence for more than 40 hours a week didnt hold the same appeal as it once had, and suddenly, I wasnt sure what to do about school. What seemed like an easy default decision  sign your kid up for kindergarten, and off he goes  felt more complicated when I looked at my son.

title: A Key Witness in Rajaratnam Trial Is Set to Be Sentenced
description: A disgraced former Intel executive whose testimony helped convict the hedge fund billionaire Raj Rajaratnam of insider trading crimes deserves a lenient sentence because of his cooperation with the government, federal prosecutors said on Friday.

title: Suspensions Vacated for Players in Bounty Case
description: Four players suspended by the N.F.L. for their roles in what the league said was a bounty program conducted by members of the New Orleans Saints had their suspensions vacated by an appeals panel Friday, allowing them to rejoin their teams and play in season openers this weekend.

title: Alan Arkins Gallery of Heroic Roles
description: TORONTO  During an encounter at the Shangri-La Hotel here, we managed to ask Alan Arkin whether his role in Argo is possibly the most heroic hes ever played. In the movie, which has a gala screening at the Toronto International Film Festival on Friday evening, Mr. Arkin plays a wily movie producer who sets up a fake film, called Argo, to help spring a group of people from the clutches of hostile militants during the Iran hostage crisis of years past.

title: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 7
description: Images from New York City and the region include the West Indian American Day Parade, the first day of school and the return of a lost peacock.

title: Yigal Azroul: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A four-bedroom country manor house in Piscataway, N.J., and a two-bedroom contemporary in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Soho duplex loft co-op, a Murray Hill co-op and a Brooklyn Heights co-op.

title: A Windmill Comes to Life in Israel
description: With high hopes, the wooden sails of a new white stone windmill in Jerusalem began to turn in 1858. It had been commissioned by a Jewish financier in London who hoped to entice Jews to move from inside the walls of the old city and, once there, to grind their own grain. But the mill soon fell into disuse, probably because newer steam models rendered it obsolete, a historian said.

title: Mayors Office Shines Spotlight on Broadway
description: As part of an effort to celebrate Broadway, which contributes $11 billion to the New York economy, the mayors Office of Media and Entertainment has named its first annual Spotlight Award winners. Among them are  Chita Rivera, the actress and dancer; Charles Strouse, the composer of Bye Bye Birdie and Annie; Arlene Dahl, the actress and author; and Tommy Tune, the actor, director and choreographer.

title: Stale Bread, That Versatile Vehicle
description: This weeks City Kitchen column features the Middle Eastern bread salad called fattoush, which utilizes stale pita.

title: Indonesias Furtive Snake Trade
description: Rhinos may be poached for their precious horns and tigers for their skin and bones, but with reptiles its often about the allure of possessing live exotic animals. Illegal trading of reptiles and amphibians in Southeast Asia is aimed mainly at stocking the international pet trade.

title: Not The Time To Be Demanding
description: Ive been pounding the drum for Keynesian policies ever since the financial crisis struck; I was one of the few people to talk negatively about Obamas inaugural address, because it seemed to miss the point that we were suffering from inadequate demand; and I was frantic about the inadequate size of the stimulus.

title: A Special Day (Online)
description: IT started, as many crazy ideas do, with too much whiskey at the bachelor party. Thats when a groomsman, Ed Dale Jr., decided to create the Twitter hashtag #massewedding and enlist the wedding party, plus as many guests and vendors as possible, to tweet, he said, about every two minutes on the day his childhood friend Bryan Masse married Jill Solilak in Winnipeg, Manitoba.

title: Paying the Hidden Cost of a Destination Wedding
description: DANIELLE and Tim Jennings of Indianapolis booked a seven-night stay at the Couples Tower Isle resort in Ocho Rios, Jamaica, last August. They took advantage of one of those deals that couples considering destination weddings hear about all the time: pay for a week and get the wedding ceremony free.

title: Garda Security Gets $1.1 Billion Buyout Offer
description: QUEBEC CITY _ The founder, chairman and chief executive of Garda World Security, an armored car and security company based in Montreal, joined forces with a private equity fund to make a $1.1 billion offer to take the company private on Friday.

title: Now Online | T Mens Fashion Fall 2012
description: Jay-Z and Zadie Smith discuss his music, his life, politics and, oh yeah, the new Barclays Center in Brooklyn, in the cover story of the fall mens fashion issue of T. Inside, the actor Nico Tortorella models the latest knits, the musicians in Sweet Swing Trio show off looks from Paris, and the rock climber Chris Sharma proves hes actually pretty grounded. For the newest fashion trends, check out our roundup of svelte new overcoats or see what Suzy Menkes has to say about man bags. Dont forget to check out David Amsdens report on fitness gear that broadcasts your results to the world; Lynn Yaegers look at Artcurial in Paris, where the auction lots include hunks of meat; and Janine di Giovannis profile of Gene Sharp, who has helped spread peace around the globe for 40 years. When youre done, visit a classic Philip Johnson house filled with art; meet Brit Marling, an actress, screenwriter and Georgetown grad; and hit the Cannes red carpet with the likes of Zac Efron, Chris ODowd and David Cronenberg, who show off the seasons premier essential: a non-red-carpet coat.

title: Bryan Brothers Win 12th Grand Slam Doubles Title
description: Bob and Mike Bryan won the United States Open mens doubles title on Friday, 6-3, 6-4, over Radek Stepanek of Czech Republic and Leander Paes of India.

title: NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, 2:22 P.M.
Cushnie et Ochs: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Friday Night Music: Of Monsters and Men
description: In honor of Icelands successful debt-relief program:

title: Philip Roth Goes Public With Fact Check of Wikipedia
description: Philip Roth has written an open letter to Wikipedia that goes on for nearly as long as some of the celebrated authors recent short novels. The letter appeared on Page-Turner, the books blog of The New Yorker magazine, and in it Mr. Roth adamantly denies that his novel The Human Stain was based on the life of Anatole Broyard, a longtime cultural critic for The Times.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Sept. 7
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Plant Sprouting in Asphalt Leads to High-Minded Discussion
description: Sometimes, when you walk your dog, and your dog is a hound dog who moves very slowly and insists on sniffing every little thing, you notice things that might otherwise escape your attention. Such was the case on Thursday as Bart Quillen ambled along Grand Avenue in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn.

title: State Seeks to Set Up Unit to Oversee Pre-K Contractors
description: The New York State Education Department said Friday that it wanted to create a unit to oversee contractors in its program for disabled preschoolers, train the contractors about their financial responsibilities and subject them to rigorous audits on a regular basis.

title: Jamaica Beats U.S. in World Cup Qualifier, 2-1
description: Friday nights 2014 World Cup qualifier between the United States and Jamaica will be broadcast exclusively on beIN Sport  a new channel carried only on Dish Network, DirecTV, and, in certain markets, Comcast  forcing many fans, this reporter included, over to the local sports bar to catch the action.

title: As 9/11 Anniversary Nears, Guerrilla Cleaners Scrub the Sphere Memorial
description: In the belief that it ought to appear as if someone cared about the citys second-most-prominent 9/11 memorial  Fritz Koenigs Sphere for Plaza Fountain sculpture from the original World Trade Center  a guerrilla cleaning crew took matters into its own gloved hands on Thursday.

title: For Azarenka and Williams, Paths Diverge but Go to Final
description: The womens final at the United States Open is going to be a test of which is the better way to advance through a draw at a major championship: rolling over everyone in your path, or having to dig for every point in grueling victories.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Sept. 7
description: More Photographs

title: Off the Runway: Day 2
description: Scenes from the second day of New York Fashion Week.

title: Intersection: N.Y. Fashion Week Begins
description: At the start of New York Fashion Week, we caught Preetma Singh running to a show mixing Dries Van Noten and Marni.

title: 2 Leading Lights, Very Much Alive
description: The performance festival of the American Dance Guild usually honors two dance luminaries a year, one living, one dead. This year, however, both of the honorees  the choreographers Elaine Summers and Dianne McIntyre  are very much alive. And if the performances at the Ailey Citigroup Theater on Thursday werent the strongest arguments for the enduring merit of their art, the spirit of happy vitality was just right.

title: Editors Letter
description: This issue is about the fall mens collections, so perhaps it is best to start with the news: this season, youll want a new coat, because there havent been so many terrific options in years, but youll come to wear it counterintuitively. An impeccably tailored number in the finest cashmere? Pair it for day with knits and slouchy trousers, as the artist Jeremy Everett does under the chic guidance of Bruce Pask. An oversize parka in waterproof nylon? Make like the director Michael Haneke and toss it over your red-carpet suit. If it all sounds a bit mad, consider it thus: in reversing the normal codes of dressing well (evening coat with evening look, casual jacket with casual wear), designers are trying to make fashion more responsive to the way men actually aspire to dress, i.e. to look on-trend but with offhand elegance.

title: Chic in Review | Fashion Week Follies
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Teenager Arrested in Killing of 13-Year-Old
description: A 17-year-old from Brooklyn who was wanted in the murder of a 13-year-old boy was arrested on Friday, the police said.

title: How a Contraband Coolant Entered the United States
description: On June 26, Carlos Garcia, vice president of the St. Louis-based appliance supplier Marcone, was sentenced to 13 months in prison for his role in the illegal importing of more than $11 million worth of a controlled refrigerant gas called HCFC-22 by Marcones Miami branch. Federal laws strictly limit imports of this ozone-depleting gas while its use in this country is being phased out.

title: New Pussy Riot Video Released as Jailed Members Reject Attacks on Crucifixes
description: As the Russian news site Gazeta.ru reports, the all-female punk protest band Pussy Riot released a new video on Thursday in which they thanked fellow musicians for their support and burned a huge image of President Vladimir V. Putin.

title: Many Regions of India, All on One Menu
description: IT has been two years since a fire in downtown White Plains demolished the popular Bengal Tiger restaurant, and its a hard act to follow. But two months ago, Taj Palace opened in the space last occupied by Graziellas, and the promising menu may take up the slack.

title: Akin Defends Cashflow After Ad Dispute
description: Its not quite Mad Men Missouri, but a little drama is playing out in a dispute between a beleaguered Senate candidate and a television ad department in the state.

title: Darting and Stuttering Through Many Points of Light
description: An eclipse, when one celestial object obscures another, is fairly rare, just as the opening of a new experimental theater is these days.

title: Todays Scuttlebot:  Twitter Challenges French, and Facebook-Related Spam
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Go Give Your Regards, Then Come Back a Star
description: Many, perhaps most, of the students seen in Broadway or Bust, a PBS documentary about the National High School Musical Theater Awards, will not end up with careers in theater. But all of them seem to have already mastered vacuous showbiz-speak.

title: Working Hard on a Red Carpet
description: TORONTO  Its a lie. I never said it. Whatever it is.

title: Knicks Brewer Out for Six Weeks
description: Ronnie Brewer, the Knicks likely starter at shooting guard, will be out for six weeks after undergoing arthroscopic knee surgery, the team announced Friday.

title: Above the Hudson, Rocks That Inspire
description: YONKERS
