description: To the Editor:

title: Betting on the Proenza Boys
description: ON a recent weekend the fashion designers Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez met for a company retreat at the Hamptons home of John Howard, an investor in their Proenza Schouler label. They made pizzas and hung out in a pair of treehouses Mr. Howard installed in his yard, one with a television set that drops down from the ceiling.

title: An Actress in a Jealous Rage
description: Opened on Friday nationwide.

title: Creating a Line of Must-Haves
description: Runway looks designed by Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez of Proenza Schouler.

title: The Choice
description: Join Jacques Steinberg and Tanya Abrams as they examine all facets of the college admissions process.

title: For Spys Family, a Bad Trip
description: So murky that it is hard to discern shapes, let alone faces, in many of its scenes, and so crudely edited that its frenzied action has scant continuity, The Cold Light of Day is a catastrophe worth noting only for the presence of its name cast. Who knows why stars of the caliber of Henry Cavill (the next Superman), Bruce Willis and Sigourney Weaver signed on for this thoroughly incompetent Bourne movie imitation.

title: Fleeing Music, but Finding It Everywhere
description: BOLZANO, Italy  On the classical music beat, I get to travel around the world to newsworthy premieres and performances: a great privilege. Yet when it comes time for a real summer vacation, a complete break from music is appealing and beneficial.

title: Week in Pictures for Sept. 7
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the West Indian American Day Parade, the first day of school and the return of a lost peacock.

title: The Crazy Things That Get in Peoples Heads. And Throats. And Eye Sockets.
description: I Was Impaled isnt necessarily the type of television show I would choose to watch, let alone write about. Except for one thing: I was impaled!

title: Pot for Parents
description: San Francisco

title: Air of Rustic Formality, by Way of Italy
description: LA ZINGARA RISTORANTE has anchored a prominent spot on P. T. Barnum Square in Bethel since 2002. One reason for its continuing success is that, unlike Bethels native son Phineas Taylor Barnum, La Zingara knows how to put on a good show without relying on gimmicks like a Feejee mermaid or General Tom Thumb.

title: Joe Kennedy III Wins Primary for Barney Franks Congressional Seat
description: BROOKLINE, Mass.  Days after Joseph P. Kennedy III stood in front of the Democratic National Convention to offer a tribute to his great-uncle, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, he found himself on a smaller platform just outside Boston, shaking hands with commuters at a public transit station here on the first day of his general election campaign in the Fourth Congressional District of Massachusetts.

title: Plenty to Pull You Away From Poolside
description: The New York spring shows began in the modern fashion  with a slap, a high heel and a tacky bride.

title: When a Disorderly Life Rattles an Enviable Existence
description: Kevin and his sister, Donna, are very, very different people. He lives in Sag Harbor, the fashionable New York beach community, with his husband, Ted, and works on a novel and the occasional promotional brochure. She lives in a van with her 15-year-old daughter, Lottie, and dreams about being hired as a singer on a cruise ship. When she hears about the salary, she says breathlessly, $30,000  thats almost a double-wide trailer. The only double-wide anything Kevin and Ted know about are the prams (they use the British word, of course) pushed by breeders whove had twins.

title: Pact Is Signed to Protect Great Lakes
description: The United States and Canada signed an accord in Washington on Friday to protect the Great Lakes, the worlds largest freshwater system. The agreement, which updates promises between the two nations first made in 1972, sets goals for each country to address invasive species like the Asian carp; curb phosphorus runoff, which can contribute to algae blooms; and cut pollution from industry and vessels. Each nation will now need to develop policies to implement their common objectives, according to the agreement.

title: A Marketing Man Fights the Madness
description: Opened on Friday nationwide.

title: A Writer Evokes Loss on South Koreas Path to Success
description: SEOUL, South Korea

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: A withering drought in India, a new editor for Cosmopolitan, an ambitious bond-buying program from the European Central Bank and a lineup of new Kindle devices from Amazon.com were in the news this week.

title: Buffett Cup in Bridge to be Played in Omaha
description: The Buffett Cup, held every two years, is a tournament fashioned after the Ryder Cup in golf and usually held in the same area soon after the Ryder. This year, though, the fourth Buffett Cup will be played from Monday to Thursday in Omaha, the hometown of Warren Buffett, the tournaments namesake. The Ryder Cup will be held at Medinah Country Club, Medinah, Ill., over the last six days of September.

title: Let the Parties and the Games Begin
description: DINNER was at 8 or 8:30 or 9 or 9:30 or 10 or, well, you never know just when you are going to get fed a cracker anymore, now that New York has turned into Madrid. And so people were doing what New Yorkers prefer anyway, and that is to eat the air.

title: Saris: No Longer Under Wraps
description: SHE came, she saw, she wore.

title: At a Thai-Laotian Spot, Hot Dishes and Caution
description: IF you lean over the counter at the rear of the tiny Pho Thai-Lao Kitchen and peer past the two refrigerators, you can almost glimpse the bustling kitchen. Not quite, though, as a dark curtain obscures all but a sliver of the action. Thats a shame, because after encountering some of the unusual  and intensely flavored  dishes at this otherwise unassuming place, you might find yourself wondering whether the Wizard of Oz is working the controls back there.

title: Behind the Scenes, the Bloodiest Beltway Battle
description: As a plethora of election-year polls and surveys indicate, Americans are fed up with a deeply dysfunctional Washington paralyzed by partisan gridlock and increasingly incapable of dealing with the daunting problems facing the nation: a White House plagued by infighting, disorganization and inconsistent leadership; a Republican Party bent on obstruction and increasingly beholden to its insurgent right wing; and a Congress riven by party rivalries, intraparty power struggles, petty turf wars and an inability to focus on long-term solutions instead of temporary Band-Aids.

title: College Letter Men Look Back and Ahead
description: Each week, two of colleges footballs seasoned observers, Pre-Snap Reads Paul Myerberg and Robert Weintraub of Football Outsiders, get together over e-mail to discuss the biggest games and story lines around the country.

title: Whos That Handsome Man at Tommy Hilfiger?
description: Sitting in the open-air cabanas at the Maritime Hotel, waiting for the Tommy Hilfiger mens show to start Friday afternoon, several editors kept an eye on the seats reserved for celebrities. There was a very tall, handsome man, clearly someone famous, wearing a navy suit and blue shirt, but no one could quite put a finger on his name.

title: Spreading the Word (and Pictures) on Real Sex
description: ABOUT a decade ago, Cindy Gallop, a pixie-like businesswoman, said she began dating and sleeping with men about half her age. While their stamina and her experience made a good combination, Ms. Gallop said, she also discerned a disturbing trend: the boudoir moves of many of her young lovers seemed drawn entirely from pornography.

title: From Israels Archives, Papers on Munich Killings
description: JERUSALEM  The instructions from the Israeli government were clear in the hours after Palestinian terrorists killed two Israeli athletes at the Munich Summer Olympics in 1972, took nine others hostage and demanded the release of more than 200 Arab prisoners.

title: A Fall Theater Season of Infinite Variety
description: WORLD premieres, audience favorites, fresh Off Broadway hits and a Shakespearean drama, along with a mix of recent, familiar and uncommon works, are arriving this fall at New Jerseys professional theaters.

title: Big Names at Top Offer Inspiration
description: CARMEL, Ind.  He was inside the ropes, with the best vantage point to view two superstar golfers at their grinding bests, unbothered by the officious state troopers and overbearing marshals who have overrun Crooked Stick Golf Club this week.

title: The Bullet Didnt Leave the Only Scar
description: Twice a day, Patria de los Santos, a squat woman in her 50s, bends and gently rubs a little water on this new and tender and unwelcome addition to her otherwise unmarked body. She follows with a bit of antibiotic ointment. Then she replaces the bandage above her left knee. Her bullet wound.

title: Just After Closing Time, a Fatal Split Second
description: In the early hush of Friday morning, the manager and his young employee had finished another long shift, shuttered their Bronx bodega and headed home. But the young assistant had forgotten to grab a bar of soap that he needed. They went back, and when they unlocked the door, the thing so feared by those who work in neighborhoods contaminated by crime followed them in.

title: From Politics to Ads, Israel Archives Meet YouTube
description: JERUSALEM  In grainy black-and-white film, David Ben-Gurion, a founding father of modern Israel and its first prime minister, is reading out the new states Declaration of Independence for the first time in May 1948. There are crowds in the streets of Tel Aviv and families huddled around their radio sets, hanging on every word. Video: David Ben-Gurion Reads Israels Declaration of Independence

title: When the Express Came to the East End
description: THE September day when the brutal hurricane of 1938 hit the East End started out warm and sunny, but it ended up leaving behind a wasteland of uprooted trees, ruined houses and smashed cars. All that destruction, and more, is chronicled in an exhibition in East Hampton, The Long Island Express: Rare Photographs of East Hampton Town After the 1938 Hurricane. The Long Island Express is one of several names by which the hurricane came to be remembered.

title: Theyre Not With the Band
description: CRISTINA PEERENBOOM wasnt looking to pound away pounds. All she wanted in the summer of 2010 was to escape some romantic drama by disappearing into her drum playing. But the petite Ms. Peerenboom had broken her drum stool standing on it to reach a book, so she spent an hour squatting as she practiced her favorite Rage Against the Machine songs.

title: Father Waldos America
description: Sleep eluded the clergyman Daniel Waldo during the eve of his 100th birthday on Sept. 10, 1862. The former chaplain of the House of Representatives tossed and turned in bed at his home in Syracuse, lost in thought. What kept him awake were not reflections on his past, but concerns about the future of the Republic. Waldo had lived long enough to know firsthand that the leaders of the Southern rebellion were in deadly earnest, for he himself was once a rebel.

title: European Central Bank Candidacy Delayed Over Lack of Women
description: BRUSSELS  The leader of an influential committee of the European Parliament said Friday that a hearing to fill a seat on the executive board of the European Central Bank had been postponed after officials ignored demands to develop a plan to promote more women as candidates.

title: Questions Atop Mens Game as Big Three Thins to Djokovic
description: For seven years now, the very best mens players have monopolized the Grand Slam trophies. Either Roger Federer won, or Rafael Nadal won, or Novak Djokovic won. Simple as that. The rest of the field played in both the same tournament and another stratosphere.

title: School Year Just Begun, Teachers Strike Looms in Chicago
description: CHICAGO  With the possibility looming for a strike beginning on Monday across Chicagos public schools, contract talks for city teachers were expected to stretch into the weekend, as hundreds of thousands of families began grappling with the prospect that school, only a few days old for many students, may come to an abrupt halt.

title: The Fine Mess-Maker at Home
description: Fat and skinny guys comin!

title: Canada Closes Tehran Embassy and Orders Iran Envoys to Leave
description: QUEBEC  Calling Iran the most significant threat to global peace and security in the world today, Canadas foreign affairs minister, John Baird, abruptly announced Friday that his government had cut all diplomatic ties with the country.

title: A Planned Mosque Inches Along, but Critics Remain
description: A cluster of young Muslims in matching yellow T-shirts and broad smiles handed out free school supplies to a line of needy families in front of a gated construction site in the waning days of summer. Across the quiet residential street, two men glared at them, holding up protest signs.

title: Race Is On in Earnest as Candidates Hit the Road
description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa  Mitt Romneys plane touched down here on Friday, and with it arrived the beginning of what is expected to be the most expensive and intense political advertising war ever.

title: Dry Reds to Pair With Pizza
description: The current pizza craze prompted me to ask some Long Island vintners with Italian backgrounds: Does your family make pizzas at home, and, if so, which of your wines accompany them?

title: Said K. Aburish, Palestinian Journalist, Dies at 77
description: Said K. Aburish, an American-educated Palestinian journalist who drew on his experience as an arms dealer in the Middle East to write 11 books on the region, including a portrait of three generations of his sprawling family and indictments of Arab rulers, died on Aug. 29 in Bethany, a West Bank village controlled by the Palestinian Authority. He was 77.

title: A Day After the Party, Its Still the Economy
description: IOWA CITY  Only hours after accepting his partys nomination for a second term, President Obama found himself on the defensive over a jobs report that was weak in almost every way.

title: Taylor Townsends Fitness Report
description: The American Taylor Townsend, the top-ranked girls player, lost in singles and won in doubles in the United States Open junior tournament Friday. But most of the questions she faced after her matches were about a report in Fridays edition of The Wall Street Journal that said the United States Tennis Association declined to finance her trip to the Open over concerns about her fitness.

title: Far From Flushing, Authentic Sichuan Fare
description: A GENERATION ago, nearly every Long Island community had at least one Chinese restaurant, and usually a few takeout places as well. These days, new Asian restaurants are Japanese, Thai, pan-Asian or Asian fusion. Most existing Chinese restaurants have either disappeared or adapted, usually by adding dishes like sushi.

title: Record Number of Foreigners Were Deported in 2011, Officials Say
description: Immigration enforcement authorities detained and deported record numbers of illegal immigrants in 2011 and are on track for similar figures this year, even as the numbers of migrants crossing the border illegally dropped to a 40-year low, according to data published Friday by the Department of Homeland Security.

title: U.S. Suspends Its Antidrug Radar-Sharing With Honduras
description: MEXICO CITY  Seeking better controls for its militarized approach to combating drugs in Central America, the United States has suspended all sharing of radar intelligence with Honduras after the Honduran Air Force shot down two planes that might have been carrying drugs in July, American officials said Friday.

title: Sept. 7: Polls Find Hints of Obama Convention Bounce
description: The three national tracking polls that were published on Friday all moved toward President Obama, probably reflecting momentum from the Democratic convention.

title: Rag & Bone: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Abandoned Bank Accounts of Brooke Astors Surface, Their Value a Secret
description: Tucked into a long newspaper listing of everyday people who had forgotten a few dollars left in an old bank account, one name still had enough of its old boldface pop to jump out from the squint-inducing type.

title: Coming Together Without Cabrera, Giants Manage to Play Even Better
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Defying Canon and Civil Laws, Diocese Failed to Stop a Priest
description: On the surface, the Rev. Shawn Ratigan was just the kind of dynamic new priest that any Roman Catholic bishop would have been happy to put in a parish. He rode a motorcycle, organized summer mission trips to Guatemala and joined Bishop Robert W. Finn and dozens of students on a bus trek to Washington for the March for Life, a big annual anti-abortion rally.

title: Unpredictable Danger Looms Close to the Heart
description: Monsters attacked Avery de Groh when she was 4. That is how she remembers the day in 2007 when the defibrillator in her chest misfired, sending nine electric shocks through her body in less than 30 minutes.

title: New SEC Opponents Have the Look of Old Rivals
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex.  Little would suggest any animosity between Texas A&M and Florida. But fuel the pregame hype with a hurricane, a gift basket and a strategically placed billboard, and a heated rivalry might be born Saturday at Kyle Field.

title: Man Says He Questioned Safety Before Quebec Shooting
description: QUEBEC  The host of the election night victory party where a gunman killed one person and wounded another, apparently as part of an attempted assassination of Quebecs premier-designate, said that the police ignored his warnings about security deficiencies at the event.

title: Jobs and Politics
description: Coming two months before Election Day, the employment report for August is a problem for President Obama. The economy added 96,000 jobs last month, a slow pace that lowered the monthly average this year to 139,000, versus 153,000 in 2011. Even the decline in the jobless rate, to 8.1 percent from 8.3 percent in July, was a disappointment, because it indicated a shrinking labor force as people gave up looking for work.

title: A Court Denounces Executive Fiat
description: In a scalding opinion issued on Thursday, Judge Royce Lamberth of Federal District Court rejected new rules imposed by the Obama administration last spring that limit access to counsel for prisoners at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, who are not actively challenging their detention.

title: Democrats Face a Juggling Act Over Economy Message
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  With both parties conventions now concluded, what is clear is that each played to type  Republicans as the party of business, Democrats of the worker. For President Obama, however, the week here captured his tricky balancing act: a four-year struggle to show that pro-worker does not mean antibusiness.

title: Lottery Numbers
Justice Ventures Up the Church Hierarchy
description: The verdict was long overdue in the pedophile priest scandal, but a Roman Catholic bishop has become the highest-ranking church official found criminally guilty of shielding a priest known to be a threat to children. In a brief nonjury trial, Bishop Robert Finn, head of the Diocese of Kansas City-St. Joseph, Mo., was pronounced guilty on Thursday and sentenced to two years of probation for failing to alert law enforcement authorities about a predatory priest he knew was addicted to taking lewd photos of schoolgirls.

title: Building Ties by Opening Up
description: NASHVILLE  A certain brand of optimism had been required for James Franklin to forgive his father, to forget their past. But now it was being tested. In his fathers new home, Franklin listened to his fathers new wife deny his fathers sins against him, his sister and their mother.

title: Impasse in Japan Forces Delay in Spending
description: TOKYO  A political standoff forced Japan on Friday to postpone budget spending for the first time in decades, underscoring the beleaguered state of the countrys ruling party. The action clouded the countrys economic outlook just as analysts were warning of a slowdown.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Signed and Sealed

title: New Yorks Thursday Primary
description: Next Thursday, New York will hold a primary election that will come as a surprise to many voters. This election is the costly result of a dysfunctional State Legislature, which was incapable of making a sensible decision to hold the state primary on June 26, the primary for Congressional seats. The only consolation is that every single vote could make a difference.

title: Reading, Math and Grit
description: Early in his acceptance speech Thursday night, President Obama gave a nod to his administrations backing of education reform. Some of the worst schools in the country have made real gains in math and reading, he said, calling on the country to add 100,000 math and science teachers in the next decade. Then he moved on to other topics, like foreign policy and Medicare, that he clearly views as more vital to the campaign as it enters the home stretch.

title: Britain: Prince Harry Begins New Afghan Deployment
description: Three weeks after making headlines with a game of strip billiards with a group of women in a Las Vegas hotel suite, Prince Harry, third in line to the British throne, has begun a four-month deployment to Afghanistan as the co-pilot and weapons officer of an Apache attack helicopter. The 27-year-old prince joined his unit of the Army Air Corps at Camp Bastion in Helmand Province, where he will fly combat missions against the Taliban. His previous service in Afghanistan was in 2007 and 2008, when he served 10 weeks as a forward air traffic controller, helping direct strikes on the Taliban. The Apache deployment was one he had lobbied strongly for with British defense chiefs.

title: Take Ones Lumps
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Byron Walden puzzles dont come up in The New York Times that often anymore (hes a busy dad and a professor of mathematics), but when they do, I treat them as they deserve to be treated: with fear and respect, much as one would approach a wild lion that had suddenly materialized in ones living room.

title: Backstage McQueen: Q and A With Anne Deniau
description: For 13 years, the photographer Anne Deniau had a rare view into the backstage world of Alexander McQueens runway shows. Hired by the designer to create images that captured the spirit of his collections, she found a perspective on his work that audiences in the front rows never had a chance to see. Her images are compiled in the new book, Love Looks Not With the Eyes: Thirteen Years With Lee Alexander McQueen. Here, a Q and A with the photographer.

title: A 20-Year-Old Fathers Goal Was to Make His Slain Father Proud
description: Reynaldo Cuevas cried when his father, Maleno, was fatally shot in the street two years ago in the Dominican Republic over a gold necklace and a bracelet, relatives said. He was changed by it.

title: Pulling Levers to Play the Piano
description: RANDOLPH HERR, 64, sat at one of the two Steinway grand pianos in his cluttered living room in Queens on Thursday afternoon and began playing Liszts Liebestraum No. 3.

title: Students Are Suspended in Stuyvesant Cheating
description: A dozen Stuyvesant High School students have been suspended and more than 50 others are facing suspension because of new evidence that has emerged in a continuing investigation of cheating during final exams in June, school officials said Friday.

title: Studies Find More Students Cheating, With High Achievers No Exception
description: Large-scale cheating has been uncovered over the last year at some of the nations most competitive schools, like Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan, the Air Force Academy and, most recently, Harvard.

title: Tommy Hilfiger: Spring 2013 Menswear
description: New York

title: Lawyer Says Mans Link to Legislator Led to Arrest
description: A lawyer for an Israeli immigrant who raised thousands of dollars that helped elect Michael G. Grimm to Congress in 2010 said Friday that the authorities arrested his client last month on a charge of immigration fraud because of his ties to the lawmaker.

title: In a Swirl of Excess, No Guilt Included
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.

title: Conventions Draw Crowds but Sway Few Voters
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  The goal of the Democratic convention was to draw a sharp contrast between the visions offered by President Obama and Mitt Romney, promote a first-term record that many Democrats feel Mr. Obama has failed to articulate and persuade nervous Americans to stick with this president through tough times.

title: Convention Pop Quiz
description: The presidential nominating conventions are over! Really. So. Over. Lets see if you were paying attention.

title: The Engagement Gap
description: Forget the enthusiasm gap, lets focus on the engagement gap.

title: Alexander McQueen Behind the Scenes
description: Images from Love Looks Not With the Eyes: Thirteen Years With Lee Alexander McQueen, a book of 400 images taken and compiled by the photographer Anne Deniau, who chronicled the late designer.

title: McQueen Backstage, in Front of the Lens
description: THE coming weeks will bring at least three monographs examining the life of Alexander McQueen, including a biography by Judith Watt, the fashion historian at Central Saint Martins, as well as books made up almost entirely of images from his fantastic runway shows, which in themselves have enormous value.

title: A Walmart for Chinatown Stirs a Fight in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  Along Broadway here, in the heart of Chinatown, immigrants crowd around fruit and vegetable shops, asking prices in Mandarin and Cantonese. Men hawk huge red grapes from a pile in the back of a pickup truck. And poultry shops sell not only chicken, but roosters, guinea hens and pheasants  live poultry is available on request.

title: Islamic Poultry for Latino Tables (Yes, They Have Chilies, Too)
description: LOS ANGELES  Sebastian Flores walked out of Al Salam Pollera with a free bag of white-feathered chicken heads.

title: Yanks, Behind Three Homers, Knock Orioles Back Down
description: BALTIMORE  Ever since the Orioles used a six-homer barrage Thursday night to hammer their way into a first-place tie with the Yankees in the American League East, the specter of second place had hung over the Yankees like the humidity that draped this city all day and night.

title: Private Sector Role Is at Heart of Campaigns Split on College Costs
description: WASHINGTON  Ballots cast in November will help decide how the federal government confronts the costs of college and what role the private sector plays in higher education.

title: As Coolant Is Phased Out, Smugglers Reap Large Profits
description: MIAMI  The chief executive of the century-old company from Americas heartland shifted nervously on the witness stand here as he tried to explain how a trusted senior vice president had been caught on a wiretap buying half a million dollars in smuggled merchandise, much of it from China.

title: A Queen, a Poem and a Handbook, All Big
description: WATCH out when an academic press approaches a popular subject. Chances are that whatever merriment might have been mined from it will be buried again in footnotes or suffocated by scholarly jargon. In Queen of Vaudeville: The Story of Eva Tanguay (Cornell University Press, $29.95), Andrew L. Erdman defies that unfortunate stereotype in resurrecting an early-20th-century celebrity who was suggestively famous as the I Dont Care Girl because she popularized the song I Dont Care and made it her mantra.

title: N. Hoolywood: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Mets Honor a Longtime Rival, Who Returns the Love
description: Chipper Jones said he was asked the other day how he would feel about himself if he were a Mets fan. I would respect the body of work, Jones said, but I would hate his guts.

title: Bill Cunningham | Reality Check
description: Simple styles by two European designers, Azzedine Alaa and the label Alexander McQueen, designed by Sarah Burton, popped up consistently.

title: Local Stop: Fordham Road
description: Emerging from the Fordham Road subway stop in the Bronx, observers see majestic architecture and signs of decline, niche shops, ethnic restaurants, a university and Edgar Allan Poes old clapboard house.

title: We Saints Fans Thrive on Embracing the Horror
description: The Saints are going to win it all, baby, Pat Bode, the proprietor of Mugzs Bar in the New Orleans suburb of Metairie, her excited eyes wide with unwavering certainty, proclaimed to me on a recent evening. I got a lot of faith in that.

title: From Poe to Paradise in the Bronx
description: Brooklyn has its multitudes, Queens its fathomless diversity. The Bronx trades more in sharp contrasts: lush parks and roaring expressways, majestic architecture and harder times. Exiting the Fordham Road subway station youll find elegant 1920s buildings on the Grand Concourse; chain stores on East Fordham Road; Edgar Allan Poes tidy, tragic cottage in Poe Park; and down the hill, the campus of Fordham, with its close-cropped lawns and impressive gates, open only to those affiliated with the university. For the students who matriculate here each year, these surroundings might be as much an education as college itself.

title: U.S. Open Replay: Day 12
description: Victoria Azarenka and Serena Williams both advanced to the United States Open final, and Bob and Mike Bryan won their 12th Grand Slam doubles title.

title: Charlotte Ronson: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Fresh Beer and Brain Teasers
description: Serkan Piantino, with his newish job in new media  he has, for a year now, been the head engineer in charge of Facebooks Manhattan office  is also a relatively new New Yorker. Raised in Greenwich, Conn., Mr. Piantino, 29, studied computer science at Carnegie Mellon University and spent four years in California helping to develop Facebooks News Feed and Timeline features before he returned to the metropolitan area full time last year. He lives on Horatio Street in Greenwich Village and typically spends much of his Sunday in the neighborhood.

title: Photo in an Attic Leads to a Forgotten Teams Place in the Hall of Fame
description: Every journey to the Basketball Hall of Fame follows its own path. This one starts with flaming red hair, a dull black-and-white photograph and one mans ravenous curiosity about a team few others even knew.

title: Suno: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Jamaica Turns Back U.S. in First of Two Qualifiers
description: Jurgen Klinsmann has shown that he can lead the United States mens soccer team to historic road wins over powerhouse squads like Italy and Mexico. But he has not been able to secure a victory away from home when it really matters: during World Cup qualifying.

title: A Pay Phone Library
description: An architectural designer on the Upper West Side has been turning underused pay phones into community bookshelves, in an attempt to make the ubiquitous structures relevant again.

title: Superman, Grab a Book
description: THE best time to turn a pay phone into a lending library is early on a Sunday morning, said John H. Locke, an Upper West Side architectural designer who may be the worlds leading expert on the subject.

title: Helmut Lang: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Grounded Since Victory, While Loser Has Soared
description: With the United States Open feeling ever more an extended tribute to Serena Williamss dominance, Virginie Razzano stepped off a bus this week and walked toward the entrance to the National Tennis Center in peace, generating no crowd, no autograph requests, no buzz.

title: Divided by Immigration Policy
description: THE outpouring was intense this summer when President Obama announced that his administration would temporarily stop deporting many illegal immigrants who came to the United States as children. On Aug. 15, thousands of young immigrants flooded churches and community centers to apply for deferral.

title: Billy Reid: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Bulk of Charitable Giving Not Earmarked for the Poor
description: One weekend several years ago, as I was arriving at my neighborhood farmers market, a college student approached me with a clipboard and an impassioned, if easily forgettable pitch for Greenpeace. If I signed the papers he had in his hand, a $20 charge would appear on my credit card statement each month and a small but vital fraction of the worlds marine life could be saved. Confronted by an actual person and standing in the vicinity of cheese whose per-pound price was equal to the monthly cost of potentially saving a monk seal, I was too embarrassed to say, Thanks, but Ill pass, only then to move on to the artisanal cheddars of Pennsylvania.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. (1) vs. Jamaica (2)
description: The United States national team was stunned on the road against Jamaica, suddenly making its qualifying campaign for the 2014 World Cup far more complicated.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Corrections: September 8, 2012
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Haunted by Hillary
description: Charlotte, N.C.

title: In Toronto, Watching  and Waiting
description: TORONTO  The dirty little secret of the Toronto International Film Festival is that it can provide a somewhat tortured viewing experience, especially for the paying public.

title: Nicole Miller: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Safety Problems Persist in Indias Firecracker Industry
description: CHENNAI  A fire that killed dozens this week at an unlicensed fireworks factory in Sivakasi, the hub of Indias multimillion-dollar pyrotechnics industry, has revived a familiar debate about safety norms in the business.

title: Clinton Tells Russia That Sanctions Will Soon End
description: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton pledged Saturday that the United States would soon lift cold-war-era trade sanctions on Russia, but she did not address human rights legislation in Congress that has so far stalled passage, infuriated the Kremlin and become an unexpected issue in the American presidential race.

title: Russia and Japan in Agreement on Natural Gas Deal
description: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia  Gazprom, Russias state-controlled gas monopoly, signed an accord on Saturday with the government of Japan to move forward with plans for the construction of a $13 billion natural gas terminal here that would propel the Kremlins ambitions to multiply its business and trade ties in the Far East.

title: Canadas Latest Iranian Caper
description: LONDON  Do the Canadians know something that we dont?

title: Bomber Strikes Near NATO Office in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber on foot penetrated one of the most closely defended parts of Kabul on Saturday, blowing himself up outside a carpet shop a few hundred yards from international embassies and the walls of the NATO headquarters and killing at least six Afghan civilians, including some children.

title: The Weekend Word: Its Complicated
description: Todays Times

title: What to Watch on Saturday
description: Victoria Azarenka may be the top seed, and vanquisher of defending champion Samantha Stosur, but it is Serena Williams who comes into tonights final as the player to beat.

title: Art Modell and the Argument Over Honor
description: Does Art Modell belong in the Pro Football Hall of Fame?

title: Alexander Skarsgard Will Answer Reader Questions
description: TORONTO  Hes the Nordic vampire Eric Northman on HBOs True Blood, which recently completed its fifth season. He was the doomed groom opposite Kirsten Dunst in last years apocalyptic Lars von Trier film Melancholia. And now he is taking your questions.

title: Rodriguez Finds His Old Stroke, Which Yankees Have Been Missing
description: BALTIMORE  Throughout the week, Alex Rodriguez used his return to the clubhouse as an opportunity to outline his vision for a reformed Yankees offense  a master plan, he called it, that seemed to have something to do with bunting more.

title: Employment in Two Administrations
description: Update: These are thousands of jobs, in each case the cumulative change since January (of 2001 and 2009 respectively). I took the data from FRED, but theyre ultimately from the BLS.

title: Grand Dreams on the Far Edges
description: When the photographer Emily Berl visits a place for the first time, she said, she likes to go to its farthest edges, because she knows she will find something interesting happening there. In New York this instinct took her to Coney Island, the neighborhood defined by the two things it was not: the amusement park and the beach. Thousands of people go to the amusement park and never walk the three blocks into the neighborhood, she said. There was just so much life there that I didnt know existed.

title: Photos of The Moment | Rag & Bone
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Jobs Program That Wasnt
description: Macroeconomic Advisers on the American Jobs Act, proposed a year ago:

title: Murray Reaches Final; Second Semifinal Is Suspended
description: Its hard to imagine that a final four that consists of the Nos. 2, 3, 4, and 6 seeds would be considered a surprise, but thats the state of the mens semifinals at the 2012 United States Open. It was the first time in 33 Grand Slam events in which neither Roger Federer nor Rafael Nadal reached the semifinal round, though the cast of remaining characters was hardly an obscure one.

title: Hitching His Wagon to Obamas Star: a Republican Senator
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  President Obama is appearing in yet another television commercial in the Massachusetts Senate race. This time, it was not produced by the Democratic candidate, Elizabeth Warren, but by the Republican, Senator Scott P. Brown.

title: Clashes Worsen Misery in Syrias Biggest Cities
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Clashes between the Syrian military and rebel fighters burst a main pipe that delivered drinking water to hundreds of thousands of residents of Aleppo, opposition groups said Saturday, as the United Nations refugee agency said more than 1.2 million Syrians still inside the country, half of them children, had been displaced from their homes.

title: Highlights and Analysis: Second Weekend
description: The stars remain aligned for the second Saturday of the college football season. Paul Myerberg is in Manhattan. Tim Rohan, Tom Spousta, Zach Schonbrun and Hunter Atkins are scattered across the country, from New Jersey to SEC country, whether in Baton Rouge or College Station, Tex. Keep tabs throughout the day for updates and analysis.

title: Hong Kong Retreats on National Education Plan
description: HONG KONG  Faced with tens of thousands of protesters contending that a Beijing-backed plan for moral and national education amounted to brainwashing and political indoctrination, Hong Kongs chief executive backpedaled on Saturday and revoked a 2015 deadline for every school to start teaching it.

title: Photos of The Moment | Helmut Lang
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Fashion Week Stargazing: Day 2
description: By the second day of New York Fashion Week, the pace was picking up and so was the celebrity wattage.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: In a recent interview with Hindustan Times, Chief Minister Omar Abdullah said he was disappointed that the Armed Forces Special Powers Act, which gives the security forces wide latitude in using force, had yet to be revoked. Mr. Abdullah told the newspaper that political leaders in New Delhi didnt want to overrule the army, and that the senior brass of the army is being overly conservative about ending the law.

title: Paralympians Equipment Raises Debate on Fairness
description: LONDON  On the outskirts of the athletes village, across from the canteen where the competitors refuel and relax between events, there is a pile of dismembered feet, with a leg or two sticking out.

title: Dispute Over Costs Delays Opening of 9/11 Museum
description: A dispute between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo over the $1 billion museum at ground zero has dragged on for so long that the museum will not open in time for the 11th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks  or even for the next one.

title: A Study in Pinstripes: Embrace the Adversity
description: BALTIMORE

title: Backstage at the Democratic National Convention
description: A New York Times photographer, Doug Mills, was granted exclusive backstage access on Thursday at the Democratic National Convention in Charlotte, N.C., as President Obama prepared to accept the partys nomination.

title: Variety: A Chatty Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  This one fought me, but I conquered it. Did you have the same experience?

title: New Priorities USA Ad Hits Romney on Tax Plan
description: Priorities USA Action, the leading outside Democratic group supporting President Obamas re-election, released a new television advertisement on Saturday highlighting a study by the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center and suggesting that Mitt Romneys plans would raise taxes on the middle class while cutting them for the wealthy.

title: How Resilient Is Post-9/11 America?
description: Washington

title: A Terrifying Way to Discipline Children
description: IN my public school 40 years ago, teachers didnt lay their hands on students for bad behavior. They sent them to the principals office. But in todays often overcrowded and underfunded schools, where one in eight students receive help for special learning needs, the use of physical restraints and seclusion rooms has become a common way to maintain order.

title: Rebecca Delayed, Again, After Major Investor Dies
description: 3:30 p.m. | Updated One of the most expensive  and troubled  musicals of the Broadway fall season, Rebecca, is once again in limbo, with producers announcing on Saturday that a major investor in the show has died and they are in protracted talks with the estate to secure the promised money. The investor was responsible for an investment pool of $4.5 million for the musical, more than one third of its $12 million capitalization costs for Broadway, according to the producers, who declined to divulge the investors name.

title: Rain and Rest Days Spell the End of Super Saturday
description: Say goodbye to Super Saturday, as we have known it. With its meteorological and emotional intensity, its drama kings and drama queens, Super Saturday has been the centerpiece of the United States Open for nearly three decades.

title: The Magic Is Gone
description: THE Obama era in American politics began almost exactly eight years ago in Boston, when a youthful Senate candidates soaring speech to the Democratic National Convention stole the show from the actual Democratic nominee.

title: Photos of The Moment | Suno
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Bill Adair
description: As editor of PolitiFact, the Pulitzer Prize-winning fact-checking Web site, Bill Adair has been extra busy lately outing fibbers at the Republican and Democratic conventions.

title: Sunday Dialogue: The Benefits Trade-Off
description: Readers discuss how to preserve Medicare and Social Security.

title: U.S. Moves to Grant Former Mexican President Immunity in Suit
description: MEXICO CITY  A former Mexican president who is now a scholar at Yale University should be immune from a civil lawsuit brought against him in the United States in connection with a 1997 massacre during his term, the State Department said Friday.

title: Obamas English
description: TWO aspects of President Obamas acceptance speech to the Democratic National Convention on Thursday night were of linguistic interest. The first was signifying  the use of indirect humor as critique, and a much discussed feature of black speech. My opponent and his running mate are ... new ... to foreign policy, he said, adding the two pauses for great comedic effect. The second, and more familiar, was the soaring crescendo, beginning with in the words of Scripture, ours is a future filled with hope, in which Mr. Obama demonstrated his strongest mode of linguistic performance  the black preacher style  to end his remarks (knowing that providence is with us and that we are surely blessed).

title: India and Pakistan Sign Visa Agreement, Easing Travel
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan and India signed a new visa agreement on Saturday, easing restrictions for travelers in what was seen as a step toward warming relations between the rival South Asian countries after years of heightened mistrust and hostility.

title: Five Crucial Factors to Watch, Just 58 Days From the Election
description: WASHINGTON  Two months before the election, President Obama and Mitt Romney agree on one thing: the collection of states where the race will be decided.

title: If Achilles Used Facebook...
description: WHEN we pick up a mythological text like The Iliad or Beowulf, we like to imagine that the societies they describe existed. Even if the stories are fiction, we believe that they tell us something about ancient Greece or the Anglo-Saxons, and that some of the characters and events were based on reality.

title: Why Fathers Really Matter
description: MOTHERHOOD begins as a tempestuously physical experience but quickly becomes a political one. Once a womans pregnancy goes public, the storm moves outside. Dont pile on the pounds! Your child will be obese. Dont eat too little, or your baby will be born too small. For heavens sake, dont drink alcohol. Oh, please: you can sip some wine now and again. And no matter how many contradictory things the experts say, dont panic. Stress hormones wreak havoc on a babys budding nervous system.

title: The Issues? Yawn.
description: In this or any election year the candidates can be counted on to make regular references in their campaign speeches to the issues. Its important to realize that in doing so they are not actually alluding to the real-world challenges facing Americans. They are alluding to the issues  just that, that actual two-word phrase.

title: Obama, Stumping in Florida, Tries to Turn Focus to Medicare From Jobs
description: SEMINOLE, Fla.  President Obama on Saturday began hammering away at the Republican tickets plans for Medicare, using a campaign swing through Florida, with its large number of retired and elderly voters, to try to turn the page from anemic employment growth, his biggest weakness, to entitlements, a Democratic strength.

title: After Jobs Report, Obama Tries to Change the Subject
description: SEMINOLE, Fla. President Obama on Saturday began hammering away at the Republican tickets plans for Medicare, using a campaign swing through Florida, with its large number of retired and elderly voters, to try to turn the page from anemic employment growth, his biggest weakness, to entitlements, a Democratic strength.

title: Playing Now: Hail to Us Chiefs
description: CHARLOTTE

title: For Texans, Playoff Lost and Perspective Gained
description: HOUSTON  The sting of a playoff loss was only a few minutes old, so fresh that the Houston players had not even removed their shoulder pads inside the visitors locker room in Baltimore. In their decade of existence, the Texans had never before reached the postseason, let alone dealt with losing in one. Perhaps that explains the players unorthodox reaction last January when their best season screeched to an unceremonious halt in the second round.

title: Simple Treatments, Ignored
description: A new federal health analysis has found that 36 million adults in the United States have high blood pressure that is not being controlled even though 32 million of them get regular medical care and 30 million of them have health insurance.

title: Elephant Slaughter
description: Not long ago it looked as though elephant poaching in Africa was on the downswing, in part because of more rigorous enforcement of a global ban on trade in most elephant ivory imposed in 1989. That moment is gone and with it, elephants in the tens of thousands every year. These astonishing creatures, which seem more intelligent and emotionally aware the more we know about them, are being gunned down by poachers for their ivory tusks at a fast pace  the worst slaughter seen since the 1980s.

title: Fashion Week Casting | Edun
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Constitution on Skid Row
description: Skid Row in Los Angeles, which has one of the highest concentrations of homeless people in the country, has been the site of extended legal battles over the rights of individuals to live on the streets and the power of the government to impose order.

title: A Congress for the Many, or the Few?
description: OUT of work and stuck with an expensive mortgage, my friend was on the verge of losing her house. Attempts to get the bank to modify her loan led to a situation Kafka would have recognized: scores of letters, hundreds of phone calls  but no modification. Then she called one of her senators. Soon a member of the senators staff had contacted the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the federal agency that regulates national banks. Not long after, my friend received the loan modification she had been requesting, unavailingly, for years.

title: A Citys Heartbreak Outlives Its Source
description: On a bright, yet metaphorically dark day in 1995  temperature in the high 30s, balmy for Cleveland in December  my 6-year-old son and I trudged down toward the lake to witness the real Cleveland Browns dying day.

title: Milk of Human Kindness
description: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof visits the dairy of his childhood friend Bob Bansen, who has names for every cow in his herd and treats his girls like co-workers, not widgets.

title: New Rules
description: Shanghai

title: When Family Trees Are Gnarled by Race
description: My paternal grandfather, Marshall Staples (1898-1969), was one of the millions of black Southerners who moved north in the Great Migration. Those of us in the family who were born Yankees in the years just after World War II were given an earful about our place in 19th-century Virginia  and specifically about Marshalls white grandfather, a member of a slaveholding family who fathered at least one child with my great-great-grandmother, Somerville Staples.

title: Womens Final Is Moved to Sunday, Mens Final to Monday
description: 5:16 p.m. | Updated With the forecast calling for storms, the United States Tennis Association postponed until Sunday the Open womens singles final between Victoria Azarenka and Serena Williams, which had been scheduled to be played Saturday night.

title: More Choice, and More Confusion, in Quest for Healthy Eating
description: ATLANTA  Lisa Todds grocery cart reflects the ambivalence of many American shoppers.

title: Where Cows Are Happy and Food Is Healthy
description: YAMHILL, Ore.

title: Another Title for U.S. Women
description: Another group of American women were crowned champions of an international soccer tournament when the United States defeated Germany early Saturday, 1-0, to win the FIFA U-20 Womens World Cup in Tokyo.

title: Doubts as Portland Weighs Fluoride and Its Civic Values
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Who bears responsibility for an impoverished child with a mouth full of rotting teeth? Parents? Soda companies? The ingrained inequities of capitalism? Pick your villain, or champion. They are all on display here as the largest city in the nation with no commitment to fluoridating its water supply  and one of the most politically liberal cultures anywhere  has waded into a new debate about whether to change its ways and its water.

title: How to Find Weeds in a Mortgage Pool
description: IT sounds like the Domesday Book of the housing bust. In fact, it is a computerized compendium of millions of housing transactions  a decades worth from across the country  that could finally help us get to the bottom of troubled mortgage investments.

title: Grand Finale in Grand Slam
description: It was the last all-American mens final in a Grand Slam tournament; the last match between Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi; and though this was not clear at the time, the last match of Samprass career.

title: Defying Parents, Some Pakistani Women Risk All to Marry Whom They Choose
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Nusrat Mochi, now 25, left her parents home one day to go to work and never returned. Instead of starting a job as a domestic worker, she ran away to begin a new life, against her familys wishes, with a husband of her choosing rather than the one they had chosen for her. Her parents wrath has trailed her ever since.

title: His First Rule of Business: Dont Hope
description: This interview with  Ben Lerer, co-founder and C.E.O. of the Thrillist Media Group, which oversees mens lifestyle and shopping Web sites, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Second Guesses Start After Nationals End Strasburgs Season
description: The Washington Nationals shut down pitcher Stephen Strasburg for the season Saturday, a day after he gave up five runs in three innings against the Miami Marlins.

title: Dress Code | Lacoste
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Selling It With Extras, or Not at All
description: THE Haggler once knew a guy who worked as a salesman at a mattress chain in the Washington area. Every week, the chain ran a full-page ad in The Washington Post, advertising deep discounts on one make and model of mattress. And the rule among sales staff could not be simpler: if you sold any customers that discounted mattress, you were fired.

title: Techs New Wave, Driven by Data
description: TECHNOLOGY tends to cascade into the marketplace in waves. Think of personal computers in the 1980s, the Internet in the 1990s and smartphones in the last five years.

title: This Year, a Weak Economy Is a Relative Term
description: THE unemployment rate is 8.1 percent, hiring has slowed to a trickle and the economy is weak. For a president seeking re-election, those are high hurdles.

title: Cutting the Deficit, With Compassion
description: ASIDE from the empty chair that Clint Eastwood debated, the main prop at the Republican convention was a debt clock, highlighting the federal deficit and the growing national debt. The importance of dealing with the deficit will clearly be a major Republican theme this fall. So far, Democrats have mostly been playing defense on this issue by criticizing the Romney-Ryan approach. Its time for them to go on offense by putting their own plan front and center.

title: Strikeouts Record Unmatched 50 Years Later
description: Fifty years ago this Wednesday, Tom Cheney of the Washington Senators struck out 21 Baltimore Orioles over 16 innings. It remains a record for strikeouts in a game, and no pitcher has thrown more innings in any game since.

title: My Turn in Between the Readers and the Writers
description: WHEN Andrew Rosenthal, the editorial page editor, phoned to congratulate me on my appointment as public editor, he closed the call with a quip: I look forward to you trashing me.

title: Summer of Siege for West Africa as Discontent Boils Into Street
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Tear gas fired on hundreds of demonstrators in Togo. Mass arrests of protesters in Guinea. Guerrilla assaults against police officers and soldiers in Ivory Coast. Rock- and bottle-throwing antigovernment militants suppressed with force in Gabon.

title: A Fashion Week Miscellany
description: The scheduling, backstage and show details of New York Fashion Week.

title: A Fashion Week Miscellany
description: THE WEEK

title: Prabal Gurung: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: 2 Jets Defensive Linemen Hope Reunion Continues at the Quarterback
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  That Muhammad Wilkersons teammates and coaches on the Jets rave about his modesty does not seem to surprise Robert Prunty, who remembers his reaction the day players at Hargrave Military Academy were given three ham sandwiches as part of their lunch to eat during a six-hour trip to Annapolis, Md. As a practicing Muslim, Wilkerson cannot have pork. So he ate his apple and his cookies, and he drank his milk, and he did not complain. He did not even tell his coach.

title: What Work Is Really For
description: Is work good or bad? A fatuous question, it may seem, with unemployment such a pressing national concern. (Apart from the names of the two candidates, jobs was the politically relevant word most used by speakers at the Republican and Democratic conventions.)Even apart from current worries, the goodness of work is deep in our culture. We applaud people for their work ethic, judge our economy by its productivity and even honor work with a national holiday.

title: Prabal Gurung: Calm Before the Storm
description: Before an audience that included a first daughter, Barbara Bush, as well as a few socialites and the already reigning young actresses of this runway season (Allison Williams, Hailee Steinfeld and Kate Bosworth), Prabal Gurung showed a spring collection that seemed to be trying to straddle the fence between uptown and downtown. It started with street-tough outfits of layered trousers, sheer undershirts with an ominous bird-wing print, artfully folded skirts and an asymmetrical jacket or two  all in black and white  which had me thinking I was at the wrong show. Did I end up at Alexander Wang by mistake?

title: Wider Warning After 3rd Yosemite Hantavirus Death
description: After the death last week of a third person exposed to the deadly mouse-borne hantavirus, public health officials were expanding their warning to include more than 22,000 visitors to Yosemite National Park.

title: Orioles Have New York Connection: In Dugout and Broadcast Booth
description: BALTIMORE  Mark Reynoldss second home run in three innings and eighth in seven games had begun its high arc toward the lower left-field seats last Thursday night when the voice of Gary Thorne, an Orioles television broadcaster, took flight with it.

title: Tornadoes Touch Down in Brooklyn and Queens
description: A tornado ripped through a beach club in Queens on Saturday, one of several outbursts of severe weather across the New York region that flooded roads, felled power lines and forced the delay of the United States Open.

title: Lacoste: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Peter Jackson Beams Into Toronto in Support of West Memphis Three Film
description: TORONTO There he was again, possibly the most Skyped man on earth, Peter Jackson. This time, he was beamed down to a big screen at the Toronto International Film Festival.

title: Ryan to Spend Sunday Preparing for Debate With Biden
description: Each day the briefing books have grown fatter. At home in Wisconsin last Sunday, he watched a tape of Sarah Palins 2008 debate. And this Sunday, Representative Paul D. Ryan will hunker down for his first full day of debate prep before he faces off against Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. next month.

title: When Happy Cows Produce Happy Milk
description: My Sunday column takes a break from politics and looks at something even more basic: food. Regular readers know that Im distressed by whats happening in rural America and the way were drifting to vast corporate food factories that produce food that tastes plastic and raises public health concerns. Yet the defenders of industrial farming point out, correctly, that their system does produce food that is very cheap at the grocery store. They argue that family farms just cant compete and are an anachronism in the 21st century.

title: The Daily Shoe | Helmut Lang
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Inquiry Starts at F.A.A. Over Remark on Budget
description: WASHINGTON  A senior Federal Aviation Administration official told subordinates there would be budget cuts that could lead to furloughs if Republicans held control of Congress, and federal investigators are determining whether the remarks constituted political pressure to vote for Democrats, a person with knowledge of the inquiry said on Saturday.

title: Armstrong, Back When It Wasnt Tennis Rocking the House
description: It is fair to say that nearly every top-ranked tennis player during the last three decades has played at least one match at Louis Armstrong Memorial Stadium, the second-largest venue at the National Tennis Center in Flushing. Thousands more have faced off at the Grandstand, a smaller locale attached to Armstrong.

title: Where Student Work Is a Compliment
description: Why cant we sit with the press? Donna Karan asked before the start of a show Saturday morning for the first graduating class of a new M.F.A. program in fashion design at Parsons the New School for Design.

title: Humber a Long Way From Perfect
description: With his perfect game on April 21, Philip Humber of the Chicago White Sox pulled off the ultimate single-game achievement for a pitcher. Last Tuesday, he experienced the opposite.

title: Violence, Dissected
description: Photographs situate the actions of a killer and his accomplice in their time and place.

title: 30 Seconds With Darren McFadden
description: Running back Darren McFadden is finally healthy and, he hopes, ready to help lead the Oakland Raiders back into contention. Drafted fourth over all by the Raiders in 2008, McFadden has had shoulder, leg and foot injuries that limited him to 32 starts in four seasons.

title: Rebecca Taylor: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: One Pitch to the Head Proves a Lingering Blow
description: It is beyond dispute that the Chicago Cubs franchise is a never-ending, mind-numbing repository of bad luck and freakish occurrences.

title: Violence, Dissected
description: A boy, a girl, a car, and a gun. The formula lies deep in American mythology. Imagine the appeal: you and your love object are desperadoes on the run, death the only possible outcome. Its a suicide mission, the sort of fantasy that emerges when people are trapped. To go on the run is to chase the dragon of some other life, in full knowledge of the futility of the effort and the inevitability of the end. With sex, speed and ballistics stirred together, you simply have to accept that you will explode.

title: Other Mens Flowers
description: Rhetoric, simply put, is the study of how language works to persuade. So any writer seeking to make a case, or hold a readers attention  which is more or less any writer not in the service of the Democratic Peoples Republic of Korea  has something to learn from it.

title: Oil Disasters, Past and Future
description: To the Editor:

title: The Problem With a No-New-Tax Pledge
description: To the Editor:

title: Flexible Schedules for Tomorrow
description: To the Editor:

title: In Defense of the Power of Paper
description: PAPER still matters. The frequent whirring of printers in offices  despite the Internet, Microsoft Word, social media, scanners, smartphone apps and PDF files  attests to that. We may use less of it than we once did, but reading and writing on paper serves a function that, for many workers, a screen cant replicate.

title: Adelson Chooses Madrid Over Barcelona for New Casino
description: MADRID  Sheldon G. Adelson, the American billionaire casino magnate, is set to build a giant gaming and leisure resort on the outskirts of Madrid, ending a lengthy bidding battle between the Spanish capital and Barcelona, the countrys second-largest city.

title: Controlling My Own Destiny
description: MY parents raised me in a blue-collar neighborhood of Plainview, N.Y., on Long Island. My mother was a homemaker and my father was a furrier, a job that left him unemployed for months at a time, because no one bought fur coats during the summer.

title: Ups and Downs on Rosters Fringes
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Last Tuesday, four days after he thought he made the Jets roster  and three days after the team cut him to make room for another defensive tackle  Marcus Dixon was at his home in Morristown, N.J., when his phone rang.

title: Searching for a Speed Limit in High-Frequency Trading
description: CHATHAM, N.J.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Sept. 9
description: With the conventions in the rearview mirror, the general election is off and running.The Romney campaign is wasting no time, branching out from the nominees almost exclusive appearances on Fox News Sunday to date by scheduling Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, for an interview with NBCs Meet the Press.

description: New York

title: Romney Uses Lines From Pledge to Criticize Obama
description: VIRGINIA BEACH  Mitt Romney is fond of reciting things.

title: Venice Film Festival: Pieta and The Master Come Up Winners
description: Fittingly for a festival where about half the titles in the official competition had religious themes, the 69th Venice Film Festival awarded its top prize, the Golden Lion, to Pieta, a mother-and-son drama with a sadistic streak from the prolific Korean director Kim Ki-duk. The film sharply divided critics  as do most of Mr. Kims confrontational movies  but it was deemed the best of the 18 competitors by a jury led by the filmmaker Michael Mann. Other members of the jury included the actress Samantha Morton, the filmmakers Matteo Garrone and Pablo Trapero and the artist Marina Abramovic.

title: Game Maker Without a Rule Book
description: BELLEVUE, Wash.

title: Envoy for the Game
description: Viswanathan Anand, the world champion, is a natural ambassador for chess. He has promoted the game all over Europe and has fostered programs in many schools across his native India.

title: Penn State Hits Road, Only to Stumble
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  The Penn State football team, dressed all in white, sprinted out of the visitors tunnel veiled by a plume of silvery smoke.

title: Packers Against 49ers: Adjust the Contrasts
description: 49ers at Packers

title: threeASFOUR: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Young Talent Gives Mariners Hope for a Revival
description: Nothing has ever come easily for the Seattle Mariners. Even in their glory years, when they had Ken Griffey Jr., Randy Johnson and Alex Rodriguez in their primes, the Mariners could not win a pennant. When all three left and the Mariners won 116 regular-season games, they still lost in the American League playoffs.

title: Gabriel Vahanian, Professor, Dies at 85; Was Linked to Death of God Movement
description: Gabriel Vahanian, a theologian whose 1961 social critique, The Death of God: The Culture of Our Post-Christian Era, gave a name to a seemingly atheistic but widely misunderstood theological movement, died on Aug. 30 at his home in Strasbourg, France. He was 85.

title: Panthers Make Best of Hitch in Preparations for Their Campaign
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  The Carolina Panthers abandoned Bank of America Stadium last week after the chain-link fences went up and security personnel moved in. The stadium was preparing for what was supposed to be President Obamas acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention on Thursday night.

title: Circling the Job Listings
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  This was a cute idea. I liked the way the job qualifications matched each successive listing, so that while a BASEBALL PLAYER might need to wear gloves in the field, so would an ARCHAEOLOGIST, and that ARCHAEOLOGIST would also need to be experienced in surveying for sites, as would an ONLINE MARKETER.

title: Physical Therapists Turn to Wii Golf
description: In the world of health care, Nintendo Wii golf is more than a high-tech toy. The video game has become a tool in physical, occupational and neurological rehabilitation.

title: Max Bygraves, Jovial British Entertainer, Dies at 89
description: Max Bygraves, whose smart-alecky humor, Cockney charm and myriad renditions of easy-listening hits made him a British show-business institution, died on Aug. 31 in Queensland, Australia. He was 89.

title: A Big Default Problem, but How Big?
description: The Department of Education plans to release its official default rate in the next few weeks. Prepare to be underwhelmed.

title: Bad Student Debt Stubbornly High as Collection Efforts Surge
description: The amount of student loans that are delinquent has remained constant or increased at a time when delinquencies on mortgages and other types of consumer credit have declined.

title: Model-Morphosis | Constance Jablonski at Helmut Lang
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2013 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Constance Jablonski before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Hannah Murray and hair by Paul Hanlon.

title: Debt Collectors Cashing In on Student Loans
description: At a protest last year at New York University, students called attention to their mounting debt by wearing T-shirts with the amount they owed scribbled across the front  $90,000, $75,000, $20,000.

title: Rescued by Music, Happy to Mail Out His Own CDs
description: Just two years ago, Junky Star, the album by Ryan Bingham & the Dead Horses, was released by the celebrated Nashville label Lost Highway Records. It was the most commercially successful album of Mr. Binghams career, reaching No. 2 on the Billboard country charts. But on Sept. 18, when he releases its follow-up, Tomorrowland, the record will not appear on Lost Highway or any other major label. It will be put out by his own label, Axster Bingham Records, which has no track record and no other artists on its roster.

title: Martin Continues to Find His Groove
description: BALTIMORE  Russell Martin said he had not made any drastic changes to his swing of late and had not gotten over any serious injury to help explain his recent offensive productivity. In fact, he has been playing through a nagging neck strain that has limited his mobility, especially turning his head to the right.

title: In School Finance Tangle, Wealth Doesnt Necessarily Mean More
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Turkeys Female Athletes, Like Women Nationwide, Reap Rewards
description: BODRUM, Turkey  The gifts started pouring in for Asli Cakir Alptekin almost as soon as she sprinted across the finish line at Londons Olympic Stadium on Aug. 10, becoming Turkeys first female track and field gold medalist.

title: Program Gives Migrant Students Extra Help
description: Eighteen-year-old Alfonso Lucio remembers the sun beating down on the back of his neck as he toiled in asparagus fields in Michigan, something he began doing at age 12. His cousin Jazmine Hernandez, who is the same age and also came from a family of migrant farm workers, was often at his side.

title: Considering Death Row for Organs
description: Before Gov. John Kitzhaber of Oregon established a moratorium on his states death penalty last year, Christian Longo, a death row inmate, started a campaign to allow the condemned to donate their organs.

title: Afghans Wary in Push for Mineral Riches
description: Afghanistans estimated $1 trillion in untapped mineral resources seems imperiled by corruption and violence.

title: Potential for a Mining Boom Splits Factions in Afghanistan
description: KALU VALLEY, Afghanistan  If there is a road to a happy ending in Afghanistan, much of the path may run underground: in the trillion-dollar reservoir of natural resources  oil, gold, iron ore, copper, lithium and other minerals  that has brought hopes of a more self-sufficient country, if only the wealth can be wrested from blood-soaked soil.

title: Sy J. Schulman, Planner for New York City Parks, Dies at 86
description: Sy J. Schulman, who smoothed the way for a controversial sewage plant in Harlem by offering state financing for a park with playgrounds and ball fields atop the structure, now known as the popular Riverbank State Park, died on Sept. 1 at his home in White Plains, where he once served as mayor. He was 86.

title: Obama Makes Birth Certificate Joke
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Birthers, youre not going to like this one.

title: Mow Yard. Drop Off Kids. Take a Drive on Mars.
description: PASADENA, Calif.  Matt Heverly, 36, started a recent workday as any young father might: up at 5:30, gulping coffee, fixing a bottle for the baby. He threw on jeans and a T-shirt and drove his two sons to day care. He stopped to get the brakes on his Toyota checked and swung by the bank.

title: Yanks Eye Pettittes Return
description: BALTIMORE  As the Yankees head into the final weeks of the season, engaged in a tight race for the American League East title with the Baltimore Orioles and the Tampa Bay Rays, they could be adding one of the most game-tested pitchers in baseball to their rotation for the final two weeks.

title: Super Saturday Skies: Cloudy, Partly Happy
description: On Super Saturday at the United States Open, weather dominated instead of Serena Williams. This included torrential downpours, wind gusts so powerful they picked up chairs, a postponed womens final, a postponed mens semifinal and even an evacuation for an impending tornado.

title: Townsend Wins Doubles Title
description: Taylor Townsend, 16, of Boca Raton, Fla., won her third junior Grand Slam doubles title of the year on Saturday, claiming the United States Open title with Gabrielle Andrews, 15, of Pomona, Calif. They scored a 6-4, 6-3 victory over Belinda Bencic of Switzerland and Petra Uberalova of Slovakia.

title: A Rave at an Alexander Wang Show
description: A booming voice on the loudspeaker at Alexander Wangs show on Saturday asked guests to refrain from using flash photography, and that includes cellphones. What was that about?

title: Band of Outsiders: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Gators Recover in Second Half to Spoil SEC Start for Aggies
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex.  The Florida Gators appeared rocked by Texas A&Ms initial burst of energy, caught by the Aggies intent to make an immediate impact in the Southeastern Conference and their own struggles to forge their identity.

title: Fashion Week Parties: Night 2
description: Barneys dines for gay marriage, and Thom Yorke DJs for Rag & Bone.

title: Mickelsons 64 Shouts: Remember, I Can Play
description: CARMEL, Ind.  Nobody in this weeks BMW Championship field played at Crooked Stick Golf Club when it hosted the 1991 P.G.A. Championship, a major point of contention for Phil Mickelson, who qualified, or so he thought, by virtue of his win at the tour stop that year in Tucson.

title: Players Support of Gay Marriage Alters N.F.L. Image
description: Baltimore Ravens linebacker Brendon Ayanbadejo has been a consistent supporter of legalizing same-sex marriage. In 2011, he filmed his own video backing this Novembers ballot initiative in Maryland and posted it on YouTube, and he recently donated Ravens tickets to a Marylanders for Marriage Equality fund-raiser.

title: Tornado Videos From Queens and Brooklyn
description: As a swirling mass of black cloud swept over the Rockaways on Saturday morning, a perplexed New Yorker, his video camera rolling, wondered aloud about the cloud formation forming in front of his balcony.

description: Mitt Romney, in an appearance on Meet the Press to be aired on Sunday morning, praised former President Bill Clintons speech at the Democratic National Convention, suggesting that his performance outshone President Obamas speech accepting his partys renomination. He also criticized Mr. Obama and Congressional Republicans for agreeing to automatic cuts in defense spending as a way to force a deal on deficit reduction, in a process called sequestration.

title: Yanks Miss a Chance to Distance Themselves

The first-base umpire, Jerry Meals, had just made an incorrect call, according to both the naked eye and television replays, and instead of the Yankees completing a comeback with Chris Dickerson crossing the plate to tie the score, the game was over.

title: L.S.U. Crushes Washington Without Having to Strain

title: In Toronto, Moviegoers Waiting to See The Master Ask What Its About

Looper and Cloud Atlas, both introduced at the Toronto International Film Festival in the last few days, are loaded with migrating souls or leaps across the years. And Paul Thomas Anderson used the phrase time travel at least three times as he described his movie, The Master, at a press conference here on Saturday afternoon.

title: Death Sentence for a Top Iraqi Leader in a Day of Bloodshed

The verdict coincided with a wave of bombings and insurgent attacks that claimed at least 100 lives, making Sunday one of the bloodiest days in Iraq since American troops withdrew last year.

description: In 2009-10, about 57 percent of public school principals reported that their schools enforced a dress code. title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: Politics and political leaders dominated the magazine covers this week. Prime Minister Manmohan Singh found himself at the center of many stories that highlighted his governments predicament and his own loss of credibility. Outlooks cover carried the words King is Singed, a play on the title of a popular Indian movie. Manmohan Singhs integrity was the Congresss USP in 2009, it read. By making the P.M. the target of the coal scam, the BJP has turned the middle-class mascot into an electoral liability ahead of 2014, when the country will hold its next national elections.
