title: Romney Has Conciliatory Remarks on Obama and Health Overhaul
description: 3:09 p.m. | Updated Mitt Romney said Sunday that he would retain elements of President Obamas health care overhaul, blamed Republicans as much as Democrats for the mistake of agreeing to automatic cuts in military spending to avoid a fiscal crisis and acknowledged that Mr. Obamas national security strategy has made America in some ways safer.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Alexander Wang
description: The Look: Modern MinimalismThe Makeup: The makeup artist Diane Kendal opted for a clean, matte complexion to complement the minimalist nature of Alexander Wangs Spring 2013 collection. Skin was first primed with NarsSkin Optimal Brightening Concentrate, then coated with the brands Pure Radiant Tinted Moisturizer SPF 30/PA+++. Next, using a contoured blush brush (in place of the classic, dome-shaped powder brush), Kendal applied two shades of Nars Sheer Glow Powder Foundation  a lighter one on the outside of the face and a darker one across the cheeks  to perfect. (At press time, Kendal was not at liberty to disclose why, but a selection of models were given a more futuristic finish using Nars Light Reflecting Loose Setting Powder and Albatross Highlighting Blush on the high points of their cheeks, with some also sporting bleached or whited-out brows.) Eyes were contoured using Cayenne eyeshadow, while the same product in Blondie (light) or Bali (dark) were used to fill in the brows. Lashes were left bare.The Hair: Ponytails are always very prevalent in New York, says the stylist Guido Palau. Half my career has been based on trying to reinvent it. For Wangs presentation, Palau used a variation on a look hed originally conceived in the early 90s: the taped center-part. To modernize the look, the stylist opted for dual texture  a sleek top with movement in the back  and low positioning. To achieve this, the top of the head (to behind the ears) was first dampened, then parted and treated with Redken Satinwear 02 Ultimate Blow-Dry Lotion before being blown straight. Once secured into a ponytail, the ends were sectioned and curled.

title: Government Employment
description: During todays round table on ABC, Rand Paul seemed shocked at my claim that government employment is down under Obama. Of course, it is. But maybe hes thinking of the fact that since govt employment rose under Bush, were still at higher absolute levels than we were a decade ago.

title: A Slow Weekend at the Box Office
description: The fall movie season got under way, just barely, with what may turn out to be one of the least-attended weekends at cinemas in years. The only new release of note was The Words (CBS Films), a poorly reviewed drama about a plagiarizing novelist. It placed third, taking in about $5 million; CBS paid $2 million for domestic distribution rights. The No. 1 movie was a holdover: The Possession (Lionsgate) took in an estimated $9.5 million, for a two-week total of about $33.3 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. The Weinstein Companys Lawless was second, selling about $6 million in tickets, for a two-week total of $23.5 million. In its fourth weekend The Expendables 2 (Lionsgate) placed fourth, grossing about $4.8 million and lifting its total to $75.4 million. The Bourne Legacy (Universal Pictures) was fifth, taking in an estimated $4 million, for a five-week total of $103.7 million. Deadline.com summed up the weak box-office results this way: The weekend of Sept. 5, 2008, was the last time no films grossed over $10 million. Ouch!

title: A Sunny Sunday for Victoria Beckham

(Those came later.)

title: Spotlight on Safety for Shows Outdoors
description: Jim Digby, the tour manager for Linkin Park, knows better than most how dangerous a rock n roll show can be. In 1983 he was a 19-year-old technical director at a new nightclub outside Philadelphia when a piece of equipment he was operating came off a faulty overhead track, plummeted toward the floor and killed a young woman standing just a few feet from him.

title: Syria Criticizes France for Supporting Rebels, as Fears Grow of Islamist Infiltration
description: CAIRO  The Syrian government accused France of schizophrenia on Sunday for pledging to support a peaceful resolution to the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad and simultaneously aiding the armed groups driving the insurrection. At the same time, a French doctor returning from a rebel-controlled hospital raised new alarms about the presence of foreign Islamist militants in Syria, stoking fears that have discouraged the West from more forceful support for the rebels.

title: Ryan Defends His Yes Vote on Automatic Defense Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican nominee for vice president, on Sunday defended his decision to support automatic cuts in defense spending as a way to force a deal on reducing the deficit, an approach that was sharply criticized by his running mate, Mitt Romney.

title: Obama, Invoking Clinton, Says Romney Budget Doesnt Add Up
description: MELBOURNE, Fla.  President Obama, picking up where former President Bill Clinton left off, said Sunday that the budget proposals offered by Mitt Romney and Paul D. Ryan do not add up.

Musica Nuova, a spunky Boston-born early-music ensemble, opened its second New York season at Jimmys on Thursday evening with a fast-paced, 50-minute program, Men, Maids and Mischief: Bawdy English Songs, and delivered the goods (bads?) handsomely.

title: Obama Gets a Lift on the Trail
description: FORT PIERCE, Fla.  Scott Van Duzer, pizza parlor owner and blood donator, can bench press 350 pounds. So he had no trouble with the 6-foot-1, 176-pound, skinny President Obama.

title: Frayed Man of Action With a Head for Figures
description: A Wanted Man is Lee Childs 17th Jack Reacher novel and the last to be published before Reacher goes Hollywood with Jack Reacher, a big Christmas movie based on book No. 9, One Shot, and starring  cant say it aint so, because it is  Tom Cruise. Mr. Cruise seems such a wrong choice to play this jumbo vigilante that this is a good moment to contemplate the essential Reacher: not just what he looks like but also what he really is.

title: With a Composer as Your Umbrella
description: The weather on Saturday was seething and unsettled. Tornadoes even touched down in Queens and Brooklyn.

title: For Putin, a Flight of Fancy at a Summit Meetings Close
description: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia  At times, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia seemed to be limping and in pain this weekend, but as the annual Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting wrapped up here on Sunday, the Russian leader showed some of his trademark swagger, hitting back at political opponents who mocked his latest stunt: flying a motorized glider to help lead endangered cranes from Siberia on their migration south.

title: Before Chickadee Fame, Fields Had Canary Trouble
description: The scene unfolded like something out of one of W.C. Fields movies. A quick-handed, wisecracking entertainer wowed a packed house, only to find himself grabbed by two police officers after the show, paraded before the flashbulbs,and hauled before a judge, where he was charged with torturing a canary.

title: Any Other Questions?
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A miserable winter for the Jets bled into an optimistic spring, which gave way to a summer bursting with promise and possibility  at least from their perspective. For months, they were besieged with questions about the potential for a quarterback controversy, then dismissed them with a steely glance. They absorbed criticism for a sputtering offense, for curious personnel decisions  an unproven right tackle, an inexperienced receiving corps, a sociocultural phenomenon as Mark Sanchezs backup  for being equal parts carnival attraction and football team.

title: Crawford, Unseeded, Wins Junior Girls Title
description: Unseeded Samantha Crawford of Atlanta won the 2012 United States Open Junior Girls Championship on Sunday with a 7-5, 6-3 victory over Anett Kontaveit of Estonia.

title: Skaist-Taylor: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Innovation in Journalism Goes Begging for Support
description: Journalism has a shortage of many things: capital, advertisers and, in some instances, readers. But certainly its most precious commodity is innovation.

title: Third Annual Charity Pro-Am for BackStoppers
description: The BackStoppers, a nonprofit organization in St. Louis, gives money to the families of police officers, firefighters and emergency medical personnel who have been killed in the line of duty. A pro-am bridge event at Bridge Haven in Hazelwood, Mo., on Aug. 26 raised almost $5,000 for BackStoppers. The winners, John Samsel and Alan Lemley, scored very well in the diagramed deal.

title: Photos of The Moment | Victoria Beckham
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Glamour Campaign Tries to Claim a Generation
description: FOR almost three decades, Hearst attracted younger readers, and the advertisers who crave them, to Cosmopolitan magazine with a campaign carrying the theme I guess you could say Im That Cosmopolitan Girl. Now, a principal Cosmo competitor, Glamour, is seeking to reach the readers and advertisers of 2012 and beyond with a campaign that presents a contemporary take on the youthful woman.

title: Fashion Week Parties: Night 3
description: Carine Roitfelds news book and Alexander Wangs rap-themed rave.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Jones and Braves Depart With a Sweep
description: The fans in Queens have developed a complicated relationship with Chipper Jones of the Atlanta Braves, their enduring and frequent tormentor, who this year announced he would retire at the end of the season. As evidence, consider their response to him Sunday afternoon, when he entered as a pinch-hitter in the ninth inning of a tied game.

title: Transcending Real Sound in Real Time With the Unexpected
description: The first thing you notice about the young guitarist Rafiq Bhatias music is its hunger to combine, though it never sounds like established tradition A plus established tradition B. Hes merging more volatile tendencies  propositions, not facts  and hes in a hurry.

title: Spotlighting Prizewinning Composers
description: The music program of Trinity Wall Street, which was largely suspended and seemed in jeopardy in the spring as the churchs vestry was reassessing its costs and purposes, has come roaring back for the new season, more varied than ever. Under the direction of Julian Wachner the program has become a hotbed of early music, and Mr. Wachner has said that among other innovations he plans to do the same for contemporary music, giving greater scope to Trinitys instrumental ensemble Novus NY.

title: On Facebook, Bullies Like if You Hate
description: For the digitally native generation, self-worth is accrued in likes.

title: The Sadness of a Wife Mistrusted
description: Rama is the hero of the ancient Indian epic the Ramayana, but heroes dont always behave admirably.

title: Treasury to Cut A.I.G. Stake Below 50%
description: The Treasury Department said on Sunday that it was planning its biggest sale of shares in the American International Group to date, making the federal government a minority shareholder in the bailed-out insurer for the first time since it took control of the company four years ago.

title: Britain Exports Its Soul
description: The desperate center of Jessie Wares debut album, Devotion, is Taking In Water, a languorous and arresting tragedy about punishing oneself so that someone less worthy might live. Over gaseous, melancholy synths Ms. Ware unfurls her tale heavily.

title: Little Guy in the Garden
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  BACFill (formerly the Bay Area Crossword Tournament) was held on Saturday to benefit the Families of SMA, a support and fund-raising group dedicated to finding a cure for Spinal Muscular Atrophy. The Monday through Thursday New York Times puzzles that you will be doing this week were generously donated by Will Shortz.

title: Victorian London, Hypocrisy and Filth Included
description: The Victorian London on display in The Crimson Petal and the White, a four-hour mini-series beginning Monday on Encore, is not the one were accustomed to seeing on American television. Chamber pots, and the rear ends of those using them, figure prominently, as do blood, vomit, foul odors and the fully naked bodies of men and women who have not been to the gym in a long time, if ever.

title: Travel Site Built on Wiki Ethos Now Bedevils Its Owner
description: LIVE by the wiki, perhaps die by the wiki.

title: Queens Carwashs Employees Are First in City to Join Union
description: Workers at a carwash in Queens have overwhelmingly voted to join a union, organizers said Sunday, in the first major victory in a six-month effort in New York City to unionize workers in an industry the organizers say is rife with labor law violations.

title: Errani and Vinci Win Another Slam Doubles Title
description: Sara Errani and Roberta Vinci of Italy launched into a victory dance, tapping shoulders and leaping forward and back, after they won the final point that earned them the 2012 United States Open womens doubles title Sunday.

title: The Zombie That Ate Rand Pauls Brain
description: Aha. It seems that I was giving Rand Paul  more credit than he deserved. Think Progress has the video, and its clear that Paul was completely shocked at the notion that government employment had fallen under Obama, rather than soaring.

title: Tracy Reese: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: With Offense on Track, Yanks Plow Through Orioles
description: BALTIMORE  The mood in the Yankees clubhouse was decidedly more relaxed and cheerful Sunday than it was the night before, when loud, angry words rang out after a controversial loss. Thirteen runs and a breezy victory will do that.

title: To Smuggle More Drugs, Traffickers Go Under the Sea
description: KEY WEST, Fla.  For more than 24 hours last September, a Coast Guard helicopter and speedboat pursued drug traffickers and their contraband across the Caribbean Sea. Finally they caught up with the improbable vessel, the latest innovation in the decades-old drug war. It was a submarine.

title: Diane von Furstenberg: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Victoria Beckham
description: The Look: The Sophisticate.

title: Where Did the Free Spirits Go?
description: It wasnt the heat or threat of my colleagues being sucked into a tornado. No, that didnt annoy me. It was the soggy drama taking place in the name of daring new fashion: namely, Prabal Gurung and Alexander Wang.

title: Documentary Takes a Business View of Street Drug Trade
description: TORONTO  Films that take an outsiders view of business are routine at the Toronto International Film Festival. In 2010, for instance, financial corruption was in vogue, as Inside Job, Client 9, and Casino Jack all exposed the seamy underside of Wall Street and the lobbying business.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include consumer credit for July (Monday); the trade deficit for July (Tuesday); import prices for August and wholesale trade for July (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims and the producer price index for August (Thursday); and retail sales for August, the Consumer Price Index for August, industrial production for August, the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for September and business inventories for July (Friday).

title: Thakoon: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: The Daily Shoe | Derek Lam
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Google Struggles to Unseat Amazon as the Webs Most Popular Mall
description: Whether you are looking to buy a power tool or neon jeans online, chances are you start your search on Google or Amazon.com. But which one?

title: DVF Gives Google Glasses a Spin on the Runway
description: Look there, in the front row of Diane von Furstenbergs runway on Sunday afternoon. Isnt that Oscar de la Renta? And Valentino? Ooh, and Bravos dapper Andy Cohen sitting with his bestie Sarah Jessica Parker? And Barry Diller, Ms. von Furstenbergs husband was there, as usual. And then, wait a sec, Sergey Brin from Google?

title: Forgotten Neighborhood Underscores the Poverty of an Isolated Enclave
description: GAZA CITY  In the Forgotten Neighborhood, houses have walls but no floors: people sit, eat and sleep on the sand.

title: U.S. Puts Transfer of Detainees to Afghans on Hold
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  One of the centerpieces of the hand-over of American control to Afghan authority encountered a last-minute unexpected obstacle on Sunday when the United States paused the transfer of the final couple of dozen Afghan detainees at the Parwan detention facility.

title: William Moggridge, Designer and Laptop Pioneer, Dies at 69
description: Just after he had presciently opened a product design business in Silicon Valley in 1979, William Moggridge was hired by a start-up firm, Grid Systems, to design a new type of computer  one that could fit into a briefcase.

title: What Keeps the Chinese Up at Night
description: London

title: Amateur Mapmakers Redraw Boundaries, Working Online
description: Reshaped and renamed by generations of developers and gentrifiers, the borders of New York Citys neighborhoods are often hazy at best. Yesterdays Chinatown is todays east TriBeCa; a resident of Bedford-Stuyvesant may, after some real estate alchemy, morph into a citizen of Clinton Hill.

title: Cleaning Up Tornado Mess: Exhaustion Along With Relief
description: As Charlene Kahn trudged up a flight of stairs outside her home in Canarsie, Brooklyn, on Sunday, with a pile of debris the size of a sedan in the driveway and, above her, a blue tarp where part of the roof used to be, she did not have much to say.

title: Fashion Week Casting | Tommy Hilfiger
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Alexandre Plokhov: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Intersection: N.Y. Fashion Week Downtown
description: Ian Milan, a mens wear enthusiast, confessed that he takes pictures of his New York Fashion Week outfits.

title: Surprising Even Herself, Williams Rallies to Title
description: After a set, a fourth United States Open title for Serena Williams looked like a foregone conclusion as she ripped serves and ground strokes Sunday at Arthur Ashe with the same intimidating blend of power and precision that has defined her summer.

title: Do-It-Yourself New York Geography
description: The Internet has drawn would-be cartographers into the argument over neighborhood borders in New York City.

title: Accident Kills Police Officer Assisting Obamas Motorcade
description: WEST PALM BEACH  A Jupiter, Fla., police officer assisting President Obamas motorcade was killed on Sunday after the motorcycle he was driving was hit by a pickup truck.

title: Romneys Tax Plan Leaves Key Variables Blank
description: WASHINGTON  If any single question can be said to dominate the presidential campaign, it is whether the conservative policies advocated by Mitt Romney would help or hurt the middle class. And no issue hits the heart of that question more than taxes.

title: Attorney General and Comptroller Play Down Their Roles in Settlement
description: ALBANY  In late May, a lawyer for the New York State Assembly sent a note to his colleagues in the attorney generals and comptrollers offices, soliciting their advice.

title: Sanchez Shows There Is No Quarterback Debate
description: East Rutherford, N.J.

title: On Campus, an Experiment to Save Local News
description: MACON, Ga.  From the rattling cicadas at twilight to the willow trees bending in the late summer heat, the lush campus of Mercer University seems like the last place to find one of the nations boldest journalism experiments.

title: Fighting Off Biggest Names, McIlroy Again Tops the List
description: CARMEL, Ind.  As Phil Mickelson and Vijay Singh stalked their putts on the 18th green, Rory McIlroy stood outside the scoring trailer scrolling through his congratulatory messages. McIlroy, ranked No. 1 in the world, had secured his second title in two weeks and his third in his last four starts with a two-stroke victory in the BMW Championship. Among the first texts he retrieved on his smartphone was one from the tennis superstar Rafael Nadal, who wrote, Well done.

title: Lawmakers Push to Increase White House Oversight of Financial Regulators
description: Financial regulators may face a new obstacle in their efforts to police Wall Street.

title: Soda Ban Explained
description: I dont drink much soda, I dont buy Big Gulps, and my body mass index is right where it should be. Until the public hearing on July 24, I had largely ignored Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs proposed ban on large, sugary drinks because it would have no effect on my daily life. It was watching supporters of the ban struggle to articulate exactly what it would mean that motivated me to educate myself and ultimately make a movie about it. The proposal is best conveyed visually, not verbally.

title: Soda Ban Explained
description: The filmmaker Casey Neistat presents a guide to Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs proposal to restrict sales of big sugary drinks in New York.

title: Nuclear Mullahs
description: IRAN has returned to the front pages after a summer hiatus. Negotiations aimed at preventing the dreaded Persian Bomb have resumed their desultory course. Iran, although suffering from the international sanctions choreographed by the Obama administration, keeps adding new arrays of centrifuges while insisting the program is strictly nonmilitary. Israel is  or maybe isnt  edging closer to a unilateral strike. The U.S., we learn from The Timess reliable David Sanger, is considering more and bigger bouts of cybersabotage. Meanwhile, the mullahs are shipping arms to their embattled fellow despots in Syria.

title: German Envoy Goes to Greece, Leaving Lectures Behind
description: RHODES, Greece  To long-suffering Greeks, German officials embody the diktats from abroad that have deepened their countrys descent into insolvency and depression. Listening to Angela Merkel, Germanys Iron Chancellor, her tough-talking finance minister or the uncompromising head of the Bundesbank, it often feels like a game of bad cop, worse cop, worst cop.

title: Y-3: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: The Roar of the Night
description: In 1899, Dr. Robert Thaxter Edes, a Harvard graduate and Civil War veteran, noted that the tree cricket does not say much in the daytime. Dr. Edes was trying to calibrate the change in the pitch of a tree crickets note as the temperature changes. He offered a graph but not the actual pitches. F. H. Hall, writing in 1912, was more specific. The song is a clear mellow whistle resembling the words treat, treat, treat, pitched about in C, two octaves above middle C, on a warm evening rising to D. One species sings a half pitch higher and another about F# on an average summer evening.

title: Interactive Ones Site for Latinos
description: Interactive One, a digital media company best known for creating content for African-Americans, is set to announce on Monday that it has started a Web site aimed at urban Latinos.

title: Separatist Victory, but Not Separation
description: For the past four decades, proponents of an independent Quebec have fought a political battle with the federalist Liberals without achieving, or putting to rest, the separatists dream of an independent French-speaking state. Last Tuesday, Quebecers again voted into office the Parti Qubcois, whose purpose since its formation in 1968 has been separatism. This time separatism is not a serious prospect. Nor was it the main issue in the election.

title: Pro-Beijing Candidates Outmaneuver Opponents as Hong Kong Votes
description: HONG KONG  Pro-democracy candidates won strong voter support in legislative elections here on Sunday, but came away with fewer seats than expected because pro-Beijing political parties with greater financial resources proved more skillful in navigating Hong Kongs complex electoral system.

title: Corporate Contributions and Disclosure
description: The Supreme Courts Citizens United ruling in 2010 let loose a flood of unlimited independent spending in political campaigns. It has also inspired a wave of lawsuits seeking to overturn the reasonable campaign finance restrictions that remain on the books in various states.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: For Savannah State, a 55-0 Defeat Served Its Purpose
description: The heavens opened, lightning flashed, thunder struck. Savannah State trailed Florida State, 55-0, in Tallahassee, Fla., on Saturday, and with each crash and bang, it seemed, nature was bellowing, Enough.

title: A New Kind of Warfare
description: Cybersecurity efforts in the United States have largely centered on defending computer networks against attacks by hackers, criminals and foreign governments, mainly China. Increasingly, however, the focus is on developing offensive capabilities, on figuring out how and when the United States might unleash its own malware to disrupt an adversarys networks. That is potentially dangerous territory.

title: With Balanced Offense and Physical Defense, 49ers Control the Packers
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Even after quarterback Alex Smith directed five fourth-quarter comebacks in last years regular season and one more in the playoffs, the San Francisco 49ers emerged with a reputation as a dynamic defensive team with a one-dimensional, functional offense. Smith threw only five interceptions and managed the offense decently, but he certainly was no Aaron Rodgers, the electrifying Green Bay Packers star with whom he shares draft history.

title: Man Surrenders in Police Shooting
description: A man wanted in the shooting of a New York police sergeant in August turned himself in on Sunday evening, the police said.

title: Obstruct and Exploit
description: Does anyone remember the American Jobs Act? A year ago President Obama proposed boosting the economy with a combination of tax cuts and spending increases, aimed in particular at sustaining state and local government employment. Independent analysts reacted favorably. For example, the consulting firm Macroeconomic Advisers estimated that the act would add 1.3 million jobs by the end of 2012.

title: Family of Bodega Worker Killed by Officers Bullet Wants Grand Jury to Investigate
description: The family of the bodega worker killed by a police bullet met with the Bronx district attorney on Sunday to request that a grand jury investigate the actions of the police officer who fired the fatal shot on Friday, representatives for the family said.

title: 400 Years Later, Still Revered in Cuba (and Miami)
description: MIAMI  As the statue of La Virgen de la Caridad, Our Lady of Charity, completed its 30-minute journey across a stretch of the Biscayne Bay for her 400th anniversary celebration here on Saturday, a rainbow burst into view to frame her arrival.

title: Young Receivers Give Jets a Spark
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  If he had wanted to, the rookie wide receiver Stephen Hill could have looked up to Section 117 and seen his family in the stands at MetLife Stadium. His parents, sister and cousin all came from Georgia to watch his first N.F.L. game.

title: Traffic Safety Campaigner Finally Achieves His Goal
description: He pleaded with neighbors. He pestered his councilwoman. He hounded the city, though city officials say that by now they have gotten used to it.

title: A Watcher of the Police Says He Is Now a Target
description: In the streets of his native Harlem, Joseph Hayden is a familiar presence, patrolling the neighborhood with his video camera, ready to document interactions between the police and the residents they stop  and doing so at an age when most people have retired.

title: Textured Sportswear at Tommy Hilfiger
description: On Sunday night, Tommy Hilfiger took over a long portion of the High Line north of West 14th Street, building a runway that looked like a boardwalk with hundreds of illuminated lanterns dangling from an overhang. It was a beautiful setting for a collection he called American Voyage, which had a nautical theme and resembled a big Hamptons-style beach wedding.

title: Lottery Numbers
In Tortured Empathy, a Ghost Hovers
description: A ghost haunts the graveyard setting of The Train Driver, the latest play by Athol Fugard, which opened Sunday night at the Pershing Square Signature Center in a production directed by the playwright. This particular specter is made of flesh and blood. Roelf Visagie (Ritchie Coster) is unquestionably a living man, and yet there is something hollowed out about his presence, as if the soul that once inhabited his body has withered away, leaving an echoing emptiness behind.

title: Acting It Out, Like Valentino
description: Eeew. Did that filthy old pile of rags just move?

title: Roll Call and CQ Today to Merge Into One Paper
description: As many Washington-area news outlets continue their hiring sprees to feed the appetite for political news, two political newspaper stalwarts, Roll Call and CQ Today, are following what recently has been a far more common path in journalism. They are cutting back and merging.

title: Corrections: September 10, 2012
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: How Big Should the Defense Budget Be?
Fewer Pesticides Make Organic the Safer Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: The Architects Indispensable Hand
description: To the Editor:

title: Recalling Henry Ford, the Not-So-Good Capitalist
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tight Election May Be Tangled in Legal Battles
description: The November presidential election, widely expected to rest on a final blitz of advertising and furious campaigning, may also hinge nearly as much on last-minute legal battles over when and how ballots should be cast and counted, particularly if the race remains tight in battleground states.

title: Fighting for Bangladesh Labor, and Ending Up in Paupers Grave
description: ASHULIA, Bangladesh  His tiny office was lost among the hulking garment factories that churn out cargo pants or polo shirts for brands like Gap or Tommy Hilfiger, yet workers managed to find Aminul Islam. They came with problems. Unpaid wages. Abusive bosses. Mr. Islam, a labor organizer, fought for their rights.

title: Honoring Cubas Patron Saint
description: Thousand gathered at Miamis American Airlines Arena to attend Mass and celebrate La Virgen de la Caridad.

title: In Capital, Protecting a Treasured Right (Arm)
description: WASHINGTON  No baseball city has suffered like Washington, its losing teams so renowned they spawned a hit Broadway musical (Damn Yankees) and a vaudeville joke: First in war, first in peace and last in the American League.

title: With Help of Schools, Trickle of Talent Could Become a Flood
description: The retirement of Andy Roddick leaves Serena Williams as the United States only consistent championship-caliber tennis player and raises a question:

title: Girardi Shows His Faith; Chamberlain Shows His Stuff
description: BALTIMORE  When Yankees reliever Joba Chamberlain returned to the mound on Aug. 1 after missing 14 months with elbow and ankle injuries, he did not feel like the cocksure pitcher he once was.

title: U.S. Open Replay: Day 14
description: Serena Williams won her fourth U.S. Open title and second Grand Slam title this year, and Novak Djokovic advanced to Mondays mens final.

title: Dorothy McGuire, of Singing Sister Act, Dies at 84
description: Dorothy McGuire, who reached the top of the pop charts in the 1950s with the McGuire Sisters, one of the eras most popular vocal groups, and continued to harmonize with her two sisters on and off for another 50 years, died on Friday in Paradise Valley, Ariz. She was 84.

title: Reviewing Week 1 in the N.F.L.
description: DAYS BEST

title: Zac Posen: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Mondays Matchups
description: Bengals at Ravens 7 p.m. Eastern, ESPNLine: Ravens by 7

title: In One City, Signing Up for Internet Becomes a Civic Cause
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  With Googles promise last year to wire homes, schools, libraries and other public institutions in this city with the nations fastest Internet connection, community leaders on the long forlorn, predominantly black east side were excited, seeing a potentially uplifting force. They anticipated new educational opportunities for their children and an incentive for developers to build in their communities.

title: Refereeing the Referees
description: Replacement referees will be under the microscope early this season. The New York Times will monitor games for plays that appear to be incorrectly called.

title: Putting Bay Areas Water Source to a Vote
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif.  It is one of the oldest environmental battles in the United States, and it involves one of the countrys most famous national parks, one of its most liberal cities, leaders of Silicon Valley and a perennial source of conflict in California: water.

title: U.N. Report Questions Gazas Future
description: The United Nations questioned whether Gaza will be a liveable place in 2020, citing shortages of important services.

title: Jets Replay: Week 1
description: The Jets controlled the game against the Bills from the start and scored touchdowns on offense, defense and special teams in the victory.

title: Romney, Easing, Says Health Law Isnt All Bad
description: Adopting a new tone, Mitt Romney on Sunday said he would retain elements of President Obamas health care overhaul, blamed Republicans as much as Democrats for the mistake of agreeing to automatic cuts in military spending and said Mr. Obamas national security strategy had made America in some ways safer.

title: Tommy Hilfiger: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Ideological Opposites Prepare to Meet in Debate
description: Both root for the Green Bay Packers. Both are charged with rallying white working-class voters. And with a debate a month away, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Representative Paul D. Ryan are increasingly lobbing personal barbs while stalking each other across the same few Midwestern battleground states.

title: The Ryan Sinkhole
description: Unlike the Republican platform, which has mostly been ignored outside of the abortion issue, the Paul Ryan budget is the core document of the 2012 campaign. It is the most explicit expression of the Republican agenda, endorsed by the partys presidential candidate, Mitt Romney, and backed by decisive majorities of House and Senate Republicans.

title: With No Contract Deal by Deadline in Chicago, Teachers Will Strike
description: CHICAGO  Union leaders for this citys public schoolteachers said that they would strike on Monday morning after negotiations ended late Sunday with no contract agreement between the union and the nations third largest school system, which have been locked for months in a dispute over wages, job security and teacher evaluations.

title: Obama Campaign Says It Beat Romney in Fund-Raising for August
description: 12:51 a.m. | Updated The Obama campaign announced early Monday that it had raised $114 million in August, saying it had brought in more than the Romney campaign for the first time since April.

title: More Young Adults Have Insurance After Health Care Law, Study Says
description: WASHINGTON  The share of young adults without health insurance fell by one-sixth in 2011 from the previous year, the largest annual decline for any age group since the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention began collecting the data in 1997, according to a new report released on Monday.

title: Records Missing on Afghan Army Fuel Costs
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The American and NATO training missions in Afghanistan have told United States government investigators that more than four years of financial records covering about $475 million worth of fuel purchases for the Afghan National Army may have been shredded, raising concerns about potential fraud.

title: Popular Antibiotics May Carry Serious Side Effects
description: Antibiotics are important drugs, often restoring health and even saving lives. But like all drugs, they can have unwanted and serious side effects, some of which may not become apparent until many thousands of patients have been treated.

title: Kazakhstan Is Accused of Abusing Oil Workers
description: MOSCOW  A human rights group on Monday accused three oil companies and the government of Kazakhstan of abusing and repressing workers in the countrys oil fields.

title: Word of the Day | encroachment
description: encroachment \in-kroch, en-\ noun

title: Timo Weiland: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Patrik Ervell: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Four Ideas for Raising a Roof
description: The New York Times invited students from Kansas State Universitys College of Architecture, Planning and Design to brainstorm how they might keep the rain out of Arthur Ashe Stadium. Here are their proposals.

title: Manning in a Familiar Role: Winner
description: DENVER  In the weeks before Peyton Manning played his first meaningful game in 20 months, he did not know what to expect  of himself, of his team, of his opponents.

title: Making Mandarin Mandatory  in U.S. Kindergartens
description: HONG KONG  Bibb County sits smack-dab in the center of Georgia, and 150 years ago it was at the very center of the Confederacy. Its foundries supplied weapons and ammunition to the rebel army, and no county supplied a larger percentage of its men to the cause. Toward the end of the Civil War, the only local men not carrying a musket for the South were elderly, blind or disabled.

title: Contador Wins Second Vuelta
description: Alberto Contador won his second Vuelta a Espaa on Sunday, capturing a fifth victory in cyclings major races just over a month after his doping ban ended. Contador easily navigated the largely processional final leg, into and around Madrid, to edge out Alejandro Valverde and Joaquim Rodrguez in the 21-stage race. Valverde, the 2009 winner, finished 1 minute 16 seconds behind. Rodrguez was 1:38 back.

title: Norwegian Takes Montreal Race
description: Lars Petter Nordhaug of Norway held off the field to win the Grand Prix Cycliste de Montreal, one of the final events in cyclings elite World Tour series.

title: The Week in Political Pictures: Sept. 2-8
description: A look back at the week in politics at the Democratic National Convention in Charlotte, N.C.

title: Chado Ralph Rucci: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: News Quiz | September 10, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Trade Data Reinforces Slowdown in Chinese Economy
description: HONG KONG  Exports from China inched up in August and imports shrank unexpectedly, data released Monday showed, cementing the view that the Chinese economy has slowed abruptly in recent months despite a string of government measures devised to bolster it.

title: Children Who Sell Themselves
description: Children as young as 10 had begun to directly offer themselves to traffickers because they could no longer go hungry, Sonia Faleiro wrote of children in the northern state of Bihar in The International Herald Tribune.

title: In Monza, a Race That Resembles the Season

Backed by a $4.6 million grant from the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, Mercers Center for Collaborative Journalism will be home to reporters and editors of the citys 186-year-old paper, The Telegraph, and the local public radio station. Students will do reporting legwork, with guidance from professors and working journalists, in what the universitys president compares to the way medical schools use hospitals to train their students.

title: Leading Off: Manning Wins Big; Irsay Loses Bigger
description: The resounding conclusion of the circus that was Indianapoliss jettisoning of quarterback Peyton Manning after last season was that the Colts owner, Jim Irsay, had better be right about this. He had better be right that Stanford quarterback Andrew Luck would be franchise savior No. 2, as polished and poised as the original. And hed better be right that Manning was finished because, even if Luck is all that, Colts fans were always going to fume every time Manning engineered a winning drive for the Broncos, were always going to blame Irsay for shipping their beloved hero out of town, were always going to cringe when they thought of the man who cut Peyton Manning.

title: In the Caribbean Coral Die-Off, Myriad Wrinkles
description: At its ongoing conference in South Korea, the International Union for Conservation of Nature released a report on Friday indicating that live coral coverage on reefs in the Caribbean has plummeted from nearly 50 percent in the 1970s to less than 10 percent today. Yet describing the entire Caribbean as a region where reefs are in a state of general collapse tends to cloud the problems complexity, the study suggests.

title: Numberplay: Catbird Seat
description: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Numberplay reader Matthew Albright, who had come across the puzzle among a collection of compendious amusements at the blog Futility Closet. I asked Futility Closets creator Greg Ross where he happened to find the puzzle, and what he liked about it.

title: Designed in Iran
description: Nothing has captured my attention as much lately as the graphic design coming out of Iran. While Ive been familiar with the incredible work of more established designers like Reza Abedini, recently Ive been mesmerized by the generation of designers who were born around the time of the Islamic Revolution of 1979  those who grew up at a time whenIranians were grappling with an Islamic society. You can see this most notably in the work of Homa Delvaray, Iman Raad and Farhad Fozouni, who combine disparate cultural influences as well as technology and traditional applied arts. They utilize Farsi script as imagery, rather than simply as type.

title: Issues Linger as Afghans Take Control of a Prison
description: BAGRAM, Afghanistan  It was supposed to be a ceremony to celebrate the full transfer of Afghan detainees and prison operations to Afghan control. But top American commanders were absent on Monday, hundreds of Afghan prisoners remained under American detention, and details of the deal remained in dispute.

title: Company Says It, Not F.B.I., Was Hacking Victim

title: Millennials, in Uniform or Not, Come of Age in the 9/11 Decade
description: Raise your hand if you know someone serving in the military, my political anthropology professor asked one day during a senior seminar. I looked around the room and saw a few scattered hands in the air, then down at my own, firmly planted in my lap. It was the fall of 2007, and the United States military had been engaged in two theaters of war for the better part of a decade. I was about to graduate with a degree in global security, and I could not think of a single person I knew who was serving  nor had the thought even crossed my mind until the question was posed so directly. While public service was featured prominently in my schools and community growing up, and certainly among my peers in college, the thought of service was always relegated to the civilian sphere  Peace Corps, Teach for America, infrastructure projects in South America. Military service, though not portrayed in a negative way, was simply absent from discussions of post-graduation endeavors.

title: Reader Ideas | Teachers and the 9/11 Anniversary
description: Last year, for the 10th anniversary of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, we asked teachers to share their plans for teaching about it. Ideas poured in, and we published scores of suggestions from disciplines across the curriculum and teachers on every level from early childhood to college.

title: Sweet Tooth
description: Q. Are there certain sugar substitutes that are as corrosive to dental enamel as sugar?

title: Why User Friendly Is So Friendly: A Tribute to Bill Moggridge
description: Some considered it an inspired choice, others simply surprising, when Bill Moggridge was appointed director of the Smithsonian Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum in 2010. The 115-year-old New York institution is a treasure house of decorative objects, from panoramic wallpapers to dessert forks. Mr. Moggridge, who died Saturday at the age of 69,  was an industrial designer who invented the first laptop computer, the Grid Compass, in 1980, and was a founder, in 1991, of the global industrial design company IDEO. A British-born resident of Silicon Valley, with the intellectual curiosity of Nikola Tesla and the affability of Father Christmas, he had investigated the modes through which people manipulate machines, and used this research to pioneer a field known as interaction design.

title: Public Theater Announces Giant Casting
description: Public Theater executives said on Monday that their fall production of the new musical Giant, based on Edna Ferbers epic novel about a powerful Texas ranching family, will star the Tony Award nominees Brian dArcy James (Shrek) and Kate Baldwin (Finians Rainbow) as the patriarch Bick Benedict and his wife, Leslie, the roles played in the 1956 movie by Rock Hudson and Elizabeth Taylor.

title: TimesCast | Sept. 10, 2012
description: Michael Slackman, a deputy foreign editor at The Times, looks at the impact of Syrias civil war both inside the country and around the Middle East.

title: Steel-Cut Oats, Sweet and Savory
description: A couple of years ago in the course of touring Bobs Red Mill, the whole-foods purveyor based in Portland, Ore., I learned a new word: spurtle. A spurtle is a wooden dowel-like implement used to stir oatmeal. They are common in Scotland, where an international porridge-making competition called the Golden Spurtle is held every year in October. There are two sections to the competition: one for plain porridge made with steel-cut oats (also known as pinhead oats) and nothing more than water and salt; and one for specialty porridges, in which the steel-cut oats are used in a dish with other ingredients, sweet or savory.

title: Science Times Podcast

description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: U-20 World Cup: A Glimpse Into the Future
description: GOTHENBURG, Sweden  I love watching athletes celebrate. Its that moment of pure joy in accomplishment and extreme relief that the nerves, fatigue and struggle were worth it. Seeing these celebrations gives me chills every time. As the young American women ran to embrace  sweaty braids and ponytails swishing across their faces  they acknowledged the fact that together they had achieved the ultimate feat: being the best in the world at what they do.

title: Highlights and Analysis: Andy Murray Wins U.S. Open
description: Andy Murray won his first Grand Slam title, surviving a mid-match collapse to outlast defending champion Novak Djokovic 7-6 (10), 7-5, 2-6, 3-6, 6-2 in four hours and 54 minutes for the mens singles championship at the 2012 United States Open.

title: Driving the Volkswagen Golf GTD
description: The sixth generation of the Volkswagen Golf has been on American roads for three years. That may seem like sufficient time for a vehicle not named Murcilago, Zonda or Veyron to shake off the incredulous gasps and covetous glares of passers-by. But the Golf I drove over Labor Day weekend, painted a Kermit-like shade of green, was on a tourist visa, its German license plate gleaming below its honeycomb grille. The car prompted children to squeal and fanboys to fumble for their camera phones.

title: Ask a Hostage Negotiator

description: We know some of you are hurt. We want to help you, boomed a bullhorn on top of an armored police vehicle. Please come out with your hands on your heads and you will be treated. There is no place for you to go. The building, the block and the entire area is surrounded.

title: Toronto Film Festival: Partying With Ben Affleck and Reactions to The Master, Cloud Atlas and More
description: TORONTO  The front-loaded schedule at the Toronto International Film Festival  has yielded a few expected payoffs and a few unpredicted ones. Eagerly-awaited movies like Ben Afflecks Argo (which earned good word-of-mouth at a sneak preview at the Telluride Film Festival last month) delivered, earning a standing ovation at its packed premiere on Friday. Reviews called the film, about the Iranian hostage crisis in the 1970s, Mr. Afflecks coming-of-age moment as an actor-director. At the after-party last week, Mr. Affleck was jovial, ordering pizza and chatting with friends like Matt Damon, John Krasinski and Emily Blunt late into the night. He talked eagerly about shooting at CIA headquarters in Langley, Va., but admitted to some worry that the geo-political theme would make the film challenging to market. Im working harder to promote this movie, he said. I can furnish you with endless material. (We will expect it.)

title: Lasker Awards to Honor 7 Scientists
description: The Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation announced on Monday that seven scientists would be honored with the 2012 Lasker Award, one of the worlds most prestigious scientific prizes.

title: Putting Spain Back in Spanish Food
description: IT seems an impossible dream, if not the one that the Man of La Mancha crooned onstage. But here it goes: Over the next decade, dozens of American cooks schooled in the authentic cooking of Spain and trained in Spanish restaurants will begin to populate the United States. In due time, hundreds, then thousands, will serve up a cuisine that is not Mexican, or Caribbean, or Latin American, but one faithful to Spain. Not only will they staff a national roster of credibly Spanish restaurants, but they will go on to create new ones. Ultimately, that will ramp up American demand for the wine and products of Spain.

title: Netherlands Encounters Ghosts and Shadows in Budapest
description: Political racists and soccer revolutionaries haunt the clash between Hungary and the Netherlands as the Dutch team arrives in Budapest on Tuesday ready to decide who will top the fledgling Group D table in World Cup qualifying.

title: Guantnamo Detainee, a Former Hunger Striker, Dies
description: WASHINGTON  A detainee at the American prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, died over the weekend, the United States military announced on Monday.

title: Really? Using a Computer Before Bed Can Disrupt Sleep
description: THE FACTS

title: Nation Rich in Land Draws Workers From One Rich in People
description: OSTANINO, Russia  When a Chinese investor bought a farm outside this village a few years back, he was pleased enough to name it Golden Land. The soil was rich, the sunshine and rain bountiful.

title: Samurai Shopper | High and Dry
description: The Samurai Shopper takes her skin care very seriously, but hair care is barely a blip on the radar. Im more focused on fighting follicles that bloom outside the scalp zone; when fuzz attacks, Im already in the lounge chair at Browhaus, 56 Spring Street. The hair on my head simply requires occasional pruning, regular washing and daily brushing. Every so often, though, a hair product comes along that proves noteworthy. Take dry shampoo: apparently Im the last earthling to discover that dry shampoo does double duty as a waterless cleaning machine and a styling aid. Best of all, the cheap ones are pretty good, even if the good ones are better.

title: An Empathetic Eye on the Paralympics
description: The first Paralympic Games since 2009, when Emilio Morenatti lost his foot to a roadside bomb in Afghanistan, ended in London on Sunday night. For Mr. Morenatti, who does not consider himself a sports photographer, the Paralympics were a priority, a more personal assignment that better connected him with a community he recently joined.

title: Fashion Week Stargazing: Days 3 and 4
description: On a sticky Saturday morning, with heavy rain and humidity that turned ponytails into pom poms, the Lacoste show kicked off a long weekend of celebrity sightings.

title: Walkabout  9/10: Berlins Airport Is Late, and Indian and Pakistan Get Friendlier
description: Worse Than a Plane Delay: the Airport Is Late A look at what the numerous delays in the opening of the Berlin-Brandenburg Willy Brandt Airport mean for Germany. (The New York Times)

title: Geithner Holds His Own on Triathlon Front
description: Paul D. Ryan may not have finished a marathon quite as fast as he initially recounted. But Timothy F. Geithner can point to a respectable time for his latest triathlon.

title: Scourge of the Lionfish, Part 3: The Newest Fish in the Kitchen
description: Carl Safina is founder of Blue Ocean Institute at Stony Brook University and a MacArthur Fellow. His books include A Sea in Flames: The Deepwater Horizon Oil Blowout, and The View From Lazy Point; A Natural Year in an Unnatural World, which won the 2012 Orion Award. His series Saving the Ocean will be premiering this fall on PBS television.

title: Greece Wrestles With Cuts to Unlock Bailout Funds
description: ATHENS  Greek officials had another day of tough negotiations Monday with representatives of its so-called troika of European lenders, trying to agree to an 11 billion package of budget cutting measures that would enable Greece to receive its next allotment of bailout money.

title: A Crop Dividend: Restored Bird Habitat in New Jersey
description: Farmers and wildlife advocates dont often see eye to eye; each can look at a field and see widely divergent possibilities. Yet by encouraging farmers to plant fields of flowers, an innovative program in New Jersey is helping to finance the rehabilitation of wildlife areas for endangered species of birds.

title: Political Hurdles Clog Spains Path Out of Debt
description: Dont expect Mariano Rajoy, the Spanish prime minister, to leap without looking.

title: No, Nicki Minaj Did Not Endorse Mitt Romney
description: Lest there be any lingering confusion: sometimes performers say things in the context of their work that they do not mean literally  political endorsements included.

title: Head Injury to Revis Could Leave Jets Vulnerable
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  A newcomer to football whose only exposure to the sport consisted of the Jets victory Sunday might have come away convinced that Mark Sanchez is an elite quarterback, better than those Manning fellows; that Austin Howard resembled a young Dan Dierdorf at right tackle; and that a sculptor would be visiting team headquarters this week to survey the rookie receiver Stephen Hills facial features  you know, for his Hall of Fame bust.

title: After Summer of Turmoil, Oxford American Appoints Roger Hodge Editor
description: After enduring weeks of unflattering attention over the firing of its editor, The Oxford American has hired a successor: Roger D. Hodge, a Texas-born editor and veteran of New York media.

title: Photos of The Moment | Tommy Hilfiger
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Wisconsin Ranks First in Extreme Heat
description: Which state had the most extreme heat this summer? Wisconsin, according to the organization Climate Central.

title: Chuck Close Makes Art in a Fund-Raiser for Obama
description: Actors arent the only stars trying to help the president get elected. Artists are doing their bit, too. In a Talk of the Town piece in this weeks New Yorker, Calvin Tomkins reports that Chuck Close  who made a tapestry based on a larger-than-life size portrait of the president that was on view at the Mint Museum in Charlotte, N.C., throughout the Democratic National Convention  is making other artworks to raise money for the Obama campaign.

title: Member of Manhattan Political Royalty Celebrates a Birthday
description: It had the feel of a nominating convention, or an Election Day victory party. The big-name Manhattan politicians were there, and so were hundreds of rank-and-file voters. Hundreds of balloons lined the ceiling, the food and drink were free, and a jazz combo belted out Happy Days Are Here Again.

title: Ask About Navigating Student Debt
description: Updated |  The first set of answers to reader questions is here, the second is here, and the third is here. Ron Lieber also addressed some reader questions in his Your Money column.

title: Fashion Week Parties: Night 4
description: DVF Dinner at Indochine, Purple Magazine Turns 20, and Opening Ceremony Relives the 90s at Webster Hall.

title: Excerpt: 'Chaplin' on Broadway
description: Rob McClure sings If I Left for London from the new Broadway musical about the life of Charlie Chaplin.

title: Next Up: Grasshoppers in Bikinis
description: The voting is now closed in our Bug Beauty Contest, and the results are staggering: the three grasshoppers in the pageant took home the gold, silver and bronze medals (tiaras?). The Colorful Eupropacris Grasshopper edged out Toxic Grasshopper No. 1 with 2,289 votes to 2,143. Toxic Grasshopper No. 2 hopped into third place with 740 votes.

title: Spending Your Money to Make Someone Else Happy
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

title: Doubts on Ginkgo Biloba as a Memory Aid
description: Ginkgo biloba extract is widely marketed as a preventive for Alzheimers disease, but a new randomized placebo-controlled study indicates it does not work.

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 10
description: A view of the day in sports, including Britains fond farewell to the Olympics and Paralympics and the continuation of an L.P.G.A. event that took nine playoff holes to settle.

title: GoDaddy Goes Down, and a Hacker Takes Credit
description: 1:07 p.m., Sept. 11 | Updated  GoDaddy now says its problems were not hacker-related.

title: Earlier Mass Extinction for Most of Marine Life
description: Most scientists agree that dinosaurs became extinct as a result of a catastrophic meteor strike 65 million years ago near the Yucatn Peninsula.

title: Stagehands and Merkin Concert Hall Wrangle Over Contract
description: The stagehands union and Merkin Concert Hall are close to sealing their first contract, but a dispute over the language in a strike clause has kept the two sides apart. The union, Local One of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, said it would set up picket lines and inflatable rats on Tuesday and Wednesday mornings. Merkin has already begun paying stagehands at the higher negotiated rates and put in place new work rules. But a final agreement remains elusive after nearly a year of negotiations.

title: Metabolic Syndrome and the Teenage Brain
description: Metabolic syndrome, the combination of disorders that increases the risk of cardiovascular disease and diabetes, is known to be associated with brain changes and cognitive deficiencies in adults. Now a new study, published online in Pediatrics, has found a similar effect in teenagers with the disorder.

title: Families, Responders Get View of Exhibition Planned for 9/11 Museum
description: The September 11 museum gave victims families and first responders a preview Monday of the memorial exhibition that will eventually be the main attraction in the underground museum at the World Trade Center plaza.

title: Without Alcohol, Red Wine Is Still Beneficial
description: Drinking red wine may help lower blood pressure, but a new study from Spain suggests that alcohol is not the reason.

title: Vets and Physicians Find Research Parallels
description: Three times in the last two months, researchers from St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan headed across town to the Animal Medical Center to look at dogs.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Zac Posen
description: The Look: Duality.

title: Even in a Museum, Elements Eat at a Sunken Ship
description: The Swedish ship Vasa took its first and only voyage out of Stockholms harbor in 1628, famously sinking after sailing barely a mile.

title: A Postcard, and a Recipe, From Summer
description: Ask me how I spent my summer vacation and Ill tell you about August in a little cottage in Orient, N.Y., with my two children, no Internet and a television that got only two Connecticut stations.

title: Carolina Herrera: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Forget the Martini; 007 Will Have the Wine
description: ST. MILION, France  James Bond drank French Bollinger Champagne and ordered vodka martinis splashed with French Lillet. But at a conference in Paris in 2007, one French scholar declared that the fictional British secret agent was a pitiful connoisseur of wine.

title: Wes Gordon: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Alexander Skarsgard Answers Your Questions
description: TORONTO During our time at the Toronto International Film Festival, weve been talking to filmmakers and actors and, on this occasion, taking some of your questions with us. On Saturday, we solicited questions for Alexander Skarsgard, who plays the Teutonic vampire Eric Northman in the HBO series True Blood and is here to promote What Maisie Knew, an adaptation of the Henry James novel set in New York City. We received quite a number of varied questions and chose a selection to ask the Swedish-born Mr. Skarsgard, whose character, Lincoln, is a bartender who gets caught up in a nasty custody battle after he marries Julianne Moores Susanna. Below are his responses.

title: Door to Door in the Heartland, Preaching Healthy Living
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Like a missionary, Michael Bailey, a county health worker, spends his days driving his beat-up Nissan around this citys poorest neighborhood, spreading the word in barber shops and convenience stores about the benefits of healthy diet and exercise. Look at the kids, he said. Overweight, huffing and wheezing. Their lives will be miserable if this doesnt change.

title: Street Style: Bangs
description: The best of readers looks for the week of Sept. 10.

title: The Caucus Click: Testing the Field
A Messy, Exuberant Case Against Being Too Clean
description: Never fall in love. Oh, well, go ahead, if you must, but make sure you fall for a living being. A romance with anything else, be it a pair of shoes or a scientific theory, is only asking for trouble, so seldom will the inanimate beloved live up to your besotted expectations.

title: Miles Enjoys L.S.U.s Victories but Would Like More Turnovers
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  Louisiana States defense dominated Washington on Saturday  scaring its quarterback, smothering its running game  but Coach Les Miles, perhaps grasping for motivation, said he wished the Tigers bullied the Huskies into more turnovers too.

title: Hotels Seek an Edge in Offering the Right Digital Perks
description: One hotel has a customized application that allows guests to request an early check-in, or order valet service. Another is offering exercise videos with virtual instructors in its fitness room.

title: All Aboard
description: The old-fashioned trunk has gone over the top with crocodile skins, candy colors and distinctive hardware.

title: Ruth Bourdain Remains at Large
description: No, really, Robert Sietsema, a restaurant critic for The Village Voice since 1993, wants everyone to know, flat out and categorically, that he is not Ruth Bourdain.

title: Donna Karan: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: With Gensler in Hospital, Agency Scraps Public Vote
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has scrapped plans to publicly enact rules intended to protect customer cash after the agencys chairman was hospitalized over the weekend.

title: Suburban Lions Present a Conundrum
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The lioness lay sleeping in the bed of a dark green pickup, her eyes covered with a soft blue cloth, as a veterinarian in camouflage stood over her. Ni kubwa! he said in Swahili: Shes big!

title: The Stray Lion
description: A lion wanders in and out of a African backyard.

title: Passionate on Two Topics: Wine and India
description: I BECAME a frequent flier long before my days of traveling for the wine industry.

title: New York Architect Selected by Berkeley for Prize
description: The architect Deborah Berke has been selected as the first recipient of a new $100,000 prize that honors the advancement of women in architecture. The inaugural 2012 Berkeley-Rupp Architecture Professorship and Prize, awarded by the University of California, Berkeleys College of Environmental Design, was announced Monday.

title: Does Mitt Romney Deserve Credit for Bin Ladens Death?
description: The obvious answer to the question in the headline is no, he doesnt. But Public Policy Polling has a new survey suggesting that six percent of Ohioans, and 15 percent of Ohio Republicans, think Mitt Romney deserves more credit for the killing of Osama bin Laden than Barack Obama.

title: Romneys Post-Convention Predicament
description: To my admittedly non-expert eye, todays 7-day rolling averages from Gallup and Rasmussen suggests that President Obamas polling numbers leaped upward after Bill Clintons epic speech (and maybe Michelle Obamas as well) at last weeks Democratic convention and have held pretty much steady since. If the Democratic ticket had received extra boost from the presidents own remarks last Thursday, one would have expected his numbers to keep climbing over the weekend. Instead, his Monday advantage looks a lot like his Saturday advantage, which suggests either that 1) viewers were as underwhelmed as I was by Obamas performance, 2) theres a ceiling on the presidents poll numbers that no bounce can break through, or 3) Fridays mediocre jobs number prevented the bounce from bouncing higher.

title: Stalinists on the Scrimmage Line
description: I gotta say, its hard being an enemy of American values when George Will is on the case. Last year he uncovered our plot to undermine individualism by making people ride trains; now hes uncovered our long-term strategy of inculcating collectivist values through, um, college football.

title: Champions Are Floored by Their Victories
description: When Serena Williams fell gracefully on her back in triumph Sunday at Ashe Stadium, she was performing a ritual that has gripped the tennis world for more than 30 years.

title: Ovarian Cancer Screenings Are Not Effective, Panel Says
description: Tests commonly recommended to screen healthy women for ovarian cancer do more harm than good and should not be performed, a panel of medical experts said on Monday.

title: Man Arrested in Abuse of Dog in Elevator
description: A 28-year-old man was arrested on Monday and charged with the abuse of a dog in an elevator in an East Harlem housing project, in a scene caught on security video, the police said.

title: Getting Employment (And Other) Numbers
description: There were some odd reactions to my posts on the Rand Paul affair: a fair number of people wanted to question the numbers. So maybe I should just mention for newbies to this blog where to find such stuff.

title: Tuberculosis: Taking High Doses of Vitamin D Speeds Recovery, Scientists Report
description: High doses of vitamin D speed the recovery of tuberculosis patients, according to a new study.

title: Syrian Filmmaker Leaves Haunting Record of the War That Killed Him
description: Tamer al-Awam, a Syrian filmmaker and activist, was killed over the weekend in the city of Aleppo, where he was filming the bombardment of civilian neighborhoods in the continuing war between opposition forces and the Syrian Army.

title: Manning Forgoes a Grace Period in Denver
description: Bill Polian, the former Indianapolis Colts president who drafted Peyton Manning, had predicted that it would take half the season for Manning to get in sync with his new receivers and offensive linemen and have the Denver Broncos offense humming with the rhythm fans became accustomed to seeing in Indianapolis.

title: Early Music Lessons Have Longtime Benefits
description: When children learn to play a musical instrument, they strengthen a range of auditory skills. Recent studies suggest that these benefits extend all through life, at least for those who continue to be engaged with music.

title: Somethings Different About Olivier
description: The invitation to the Theyskens Theory show was coated with a substance that made it feel as scratchy as a piece of sandpaper. It was so rough you could file your nails with it. But the actual runway at the show today looked as smooth and wet as a slick of black oil, so you could imagine the designer Olivier Theyskens was playing with textures, or something like thats.

title: Parliament Raises Stakes Before Anti-Kremlin March
description: MOSCOW  Russian Parliament members moved a step closer to stripping an opposition lawmaker of his post on Monday, heightening tension before an opposition march planned for this weekend.

title: Ceramic Fragments Point to Artistry in the Ice Age
description: We know them best for their stone tools and intrepid mammoth hunting. But new discoveries in Croatia suggest that ice age humans made evocative ceramic art far more regularly than once believed.

description: To the Editor:

description: New York
