title: An iPhone 5 Case Arrives Before the iPhone 5
description: Before the announcement of the new iPhone 5 was made, the first protective case for the 5 arrived on my desk. I also got a news release promising me that another case was available as well.

title: Scouting Report
description: OPENINGS

title: An Artist Who Delineated the Money
description: The intricate Conceptualist drawings of Mark Lombardi attempted to map the vast, convoluted networks of money and power behind the likes of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International scandal or the Iran-contra affair. One begins to wish for a similar explication of Mr. Lombardi and his work during Mareike Wegeners frustratingly self-evident documentary, Mark Lombardi: Death-Defying Acts of Art and Conspiracy.

title: Lang College Offers Academic Credit for Taking a Gap Year
description: Sometimes, after a hectic high school experience overshadowed by a competitive  or perhaps, disappointing  college admissions process, seniors just need a break.

title: Murder in Benghazi
description: Libya and its pro-democracy revolution had no better friend than J. Christopher Stevens, the United States ambassador who was killed along with three other Americans in Tuesdays attack on the consulate in Benghazi. It was an outrageous act that deserved the strongest condemnation.

title: Rachel Zoe: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Matchbox Twenty Tops Album Chart
description: Matchbox Twenty has reached No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for the first time with North (Atlantic), its first studio record in a decade. North sold 95,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and leads a handful of high-charting new titles as the music industry begins releasing its fall albums. Imagine Dragons, an alternative-rock band from Las Vegas, is No. 2, with 83,000 sales of Night Visions (Interscope), its first full-length album. The Christian rapper Lecrae is No. 3, with Gravity (Reach), which sold 72,000 copies. Last weeks No. 1, Eye on It (ForeFront), by another Christian rapper, TobyMac, fell to No. 8 in its second week out, with 26,000 sales. Cat Power opened at No. 10 with 23,000 sales of Sun (Matador).

title: The iPhone 5: My First Impressions
description: Apple unveiled the new iPhone 5 today in San Francisco. As it turns out, most of the individual rumors about it were true  but even so, they didnt describe the whole package.

title: Take This Job and Obsess About It (Sing, Too)
description: Adam Szymkowiczs office comedy The Why Overhead has some genuinely funny moments and an odd sensibility. Its a decent play that pushes against its own boundaries with varying success.

title: D.J.s Stretch Out and Find More Fans
description: When the police showed up at the Fools Gold Day Off party this month, it wasnt completely clear why. Sure, the lines for the event, held in an empty lot behind City Winery, in TriBeCa, had been long for much of the afternoon, but not evidently rowdy. There were some loose cannons: at least one person climbed a 20-foot-high fence and jumped over, only to get netted by security and removed.

title: Long-Forgotten Picasso Is a Museums Windfall
description: When Arlan Ettinger, the president of Guernseys auction house in New York, first called the Evansville Museum of Arts, History and Science back in February to ask about a layered glass mosaic by Picasso that he had traced to the museum, officials there said, in effect, Sorry, wrong number. They had never heard of it.

title: Pop Striver From Britain Arrives for a Debut in Full Regalia
description: The search for the next Adele is a full-time quest in the British  and worldwide  music business. That would be a singer steeped in American soul music, a songwriter who touches on pop universals and is retro enough to draw grown-up listeners, a charmingly uninhibited stage personality, a fashion-conscious entertainer and an unambivalently ambitious trouper.

title: A Challengers Criticism Is Furiously Returned
description: WASHINGTON  The deadly attack on an American diplomatic post in Libya propelled foreign policy to the forefront of an otherwise inward-looking presidential campaign and presented an unexpected test not only to the incumbent, who must manage an international crisis, but also to the challenger, whose response quickly came under fire.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Inside Foxconn, and Technologys Limits
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Combining Taped Voices From 9/11 and Live Strings
description: When a composer takes up the theme of unthinkable man-made tragedy as the impetus for a new piece, what is the proper tone to adopt? Richard Strauss, responding to the World War II bombing of Munich with Metamorphosen, fashioned a lament not only for a city but also for a culture vanished in violence and guilt. John Adams, asked to imagine a response to the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, produced On the Transmigration of Souls, a complex, contemplative work that used personal mementos as a springboard to transcendental concerns.

title: Fashion Week Street Style Is Often a Billboard for Brands
description: Was it only a couple of years ago that these showily outfitted swans  stylists, bloggers and fashion editors  click-clacked on the pavements in what used to be seen as a commerce-free zone?

title: Decades Later, a Vision Survives
description: The park  a memorial to Franklin Delano Roosevelt  was conceived four decades ago. The visionary architect who designed it died in 1974. The site, a landfill along one of the more dramatic stretches of waterfront in New York City, remained a rubble heap while the project was left for dead.

title: Of Chryslers, Fashion Plates and Beards: ZZ Top Introduces 300C John Varvatos Limited Edition
description: Whether by positioning Eminem behind the wheel of a 200, Clint Eastwood in a dank, dimly lighted tunnel or Jennifer Lopez in an imaginary Bronx, Chrysler has strove to associate itself with totems of popular culture since emerging from bankruptcy in 2009. That impulse was given full rein on Tuesday night in SoHo when the automaker organized a meeting of ZZ Top, Jack Daniels, John Varvatos and GQ magazine under one roof.

title: Update: The Times Denies State Department Request to Remove Photo From Web Site
description: The State Department asked The New York Times on Wednesday afternoon to remove a photograph of the dying ambassador to Libya from a gallery on the newspapers Web site. The ambassador, J. Christopher Stevens, was killed Tuesday in an attack on the American Consulate in Libya.

title: Who Am I Wearing? Funny You Should Ask.
description: PIVOTING smartly, a hand on her hip, the better to show off her pipette jeans, Laura Ellner seemed the incarnation of street style. As she posed at Lincoln Center Plaza on Day 1 of New York Fashion Week last Thursday, a brace of cameras clicked and whirred, each competing to catch her performance.

title: A Closer Look at Four Freedoms Park
description: Images of Louis Kahns memorial on Roosevelt Island.

title: J. Mendel: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Democrats Apologize for Image of Russian Ships at Convention
description: On full display in all the pageantry of the Democratic National Convention as veterans gathered onstage last week was an odd backdrop: an image of the Russian naval fleet. And for this, convention planners have now apologized.

title: A Vreeland Library
description: Why dont you ... buy any number of books about Diana Vreeland for a fashionista in your life?

title: The Daily Shoe | Reed Krakoff
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Mapping a Path to Vreelandia
description: YOU might think that dating a grandson of Diana Vreeland would lead to scintillating dinner conversation, especially if he and you both work in the fashion industry. But according to Lisa Immordino Vreeland, who did just that and went on to marry him, the late, legendary editor hardly loomed over their relationship.

title: Yankees Go West for 2013 Interleague Play
description: BOSTON  The Yankees preliminary schedule for 2013 was released Wednesday, and it features several interesting new twists.

title: ATP Adopts Rules Changes to Address Pace of Play
description: The ATP Board of Directors announced two rule changes Wednesday that would allow for the quickening of matches, a growing priority given the consistently increasing length of matches on the mens tour.

title: In Fruitland, Wash., Where Dreams Began
description: A tour of Donnie and Joe Emersons home studio and farm after the recent cult success of their 1979 album.

title: Off the Runway: Day 7
description: Scenes from the seventh day of New York Fashion Week.

title: Census Bureau Chart and Report on Income Change and Poverty
description: Poverty leveled off but median household income lowered between 2010 and 2011.

title: A Time Capsule Set to Song
description: FRUITLAND, Wash.

title: Old Standbys, New Stand-Ins
description: EVEN through the latest cloud of glitter dust backstage at Fashion Week one can see a handful of beauty products, some on the market for over a century, that continue to pop up again and again. Herein, makeup artists weigh in on why these classics have never gone out of style, whether they deserve the reputation and which newer items are qualified to unseat them.

title: Photographer and Subject
description: Images from a new retrospective of the artist Carrie Mae Weems.

title: Photographer and Subject Are One
description: WHEN Carrie Mae Weems was first teaching photography in the late 1980s at Hampshire College in Massachusetts, she was struck by the difference in how her male and female students presented themselves in pictures. The women were always turning away from the camera, always in profile, said Ms. Weems, demonstrating by obscuring her face seductively with her graceful hands. They never squared themselves. The boys were squaring themselves.

title: The Cult of Disappearing Design
description: THE first thing you see when you walk into Patrick McInerneys living room is that theres nothing to see. The walls are bare, and ditto for the ceiling. You try to switch on the lights, but there doesnt appear to be a switch. Theres music playing, but where is it coming from? The lamp is obviously working  the bulb is lighted, after all  but it seems to be plugged into ... the plaster?

title: A Disappearing Act
description: A sampling of furniture and accessories that embrace the all-invisible aesthetic.

title: Tell the Dishwasher to Be Quiet
description: AN appliance may be hidden from the eyes, but that doesnt mean it escapes notice entirely. Manufacturers of household machinery are also taking heed of the demand for quiet.

title: A Sound System as Resonant as a Concert Hall
description: Chances are, your sound system isnt very good at math. It would sound a lot better if you could make it a little smarter, and you can.

title: In 2013, Mets Open at Home and Host All-Star Game
description: Mets fans looking toward next season may be pleased to hear that Major League Baseball has released its 2013 schedule. The Mets will get a fresh start on April 1, when they open the season at home against the San Diego Padres.

title: Reported Handwritten Union Proposal
description: Chicago Public Schools said this handwritten page of notes was the only proposal the Chicago Teachers Union had placed in writing during talks so far.

title: After Today Criticism, NBC News Chief Apologies to Affiliates
description: As it promised, NBC did not apologize on the air Wednesday for its decision not to observe a moment of silence during the Today show on Sept. 11.

title: Hiding in Plain Sight
description: ASPEN, Colo.

title: Vanishing Into Nature
description: This five-level house in Aspen, Colo., allows the brilliant landscape to take center stage.

title: Staten Island Pond Produces an Unexpected Catch
description: Kaitlyn Crabbe, 11, was fishing for sunfish and catfish last week at Brooks Pond in Clove Lakes Park in Staten Island when she hooked into something ferocious.

title: Shopping for Mirrored Accessories
description: The designer Miles Redd shopped for mirrored objects that introduce the right amount of reflection to an interior.

title: Abercrombie Hires Goldman
description: Abercrombie & Fitch has retained Goldman Sachs as an adviser as the troubled clothier assesses potential responses to moves by one of its investors, the activist hedge fund Relational Investors, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

title: Mirrored Accessories
description: TEN years ago, the designer Miles Redd spotted an entire bath and dressing room at a salvage warehouse in Chicago. And it wasnt just any bathroom: it was from the home of the banker Lester Armour and had been designed by the architect David Adler, with interiors by Mr. Adlers sister, Frances Elkins. It was also almost completely mirrored.

title: Reed Krakoff: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Why The Vileness Matters
description: I havent weighed in on Romneys awesomely awful intervention on events in Egypt and Libya; with even Republicans joining in the chorus of shocked disapproval, not much I can add.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. I own a historic home that has its original windows. Should I replace them with insulated windows to save energy or keep the originals for their aesthetic value?

title: Nate Berkus on Writing the Story of a Home
description: The interior designer Nate Berkus first appeared on the national scene in 2002 as a guest on Oprah. He was such a hit with the audience and the star that he became the shows featured design expert. Since then, his career has boomed. He has written a book, Home Rules: Transform the Place You Live Into a Place Youll Love, and starred in his own television program, The Nate Berkus Show, which ended this spring. In October, Mr. Berkus, 40, will have two major introductions: a 150-piece collection of furnishings for Target, and a new book, The Things That Matter (Spiegel & Grau, $35). Speaking from his office in Chicago (he has another in New York), he spilled details about both projects.

title: Lawmakers Delay Plans to Increase Oversight of Regulators
description: Lawmakers postponed plans to advance a bill that could curb the influence of Wall Street regulators, a move that came as some federal officials mounted opposition to the effort.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Michael Kors
description: The Look: Sharp Lines.

title: Feeding Believers and Doubters Alike
description: Manners dictate that one avoids politics at mixed partisan gatherings, but if you are determined to annoy certain family members, what better gift than the Obama Birth Certificate dish, which arrives today at the Manhattan housewares store Fishs Eddy? At $19.95, its not excessively expensive (though admit it, youd spend a lot more to zetz Uncle Frank), and at 8 by 7 inches, its not so big that when Uncle Frank slams it down on your head hell be able to do any real damage. And if youre thinking that it represents a point of view of the stores owners, youre right.

title: Mixing Mans Work With Natures
description: The Italian designer Andrea Branzi, 73, has been integrating rocks and trees into household objects for some 30 years. His Animali Domestici collection from 1985 featured laminate chairs with backrests of raw birch. A decade later, he hollowed containers out of stones and lumps of wood.

title: A Ghostly Glow in Paper and Steel
description: Harry Allen deals in twisted household archetypes. The New York-based designers ongoing Reality series includes a fruit bowl cast from a bunch of bananas, a coat hook shaped like a hand and a roller skate playing the role of door stop. For his latest project, Paperwork lanterns for Hive, he has transformed an old barn lantern into a ghostly light fixture. Its humble, like a found object, Mr. Allen said. Cast in papier-mch and mounted on black or chromed steel, the collection includes a table lamp, floor lamp and chandelier, all designed to hang from hooks attached to an armature. The lights are illuminated with LED bulbs. A single lantern measures 15  inches high, 9 5/8 inches wide and 4  inches deep, and costs $350. Information: (888) 889-9005 or designbyhive.com.

title: Designer Seating Made of Recyclables
description: Jean Nouvel, one of a handful of marquee architects who also design noteworthy furniture, has collaborated with Emeco, the Pennsylvania-based manufacturer of high-design seating, on the So So collection of chairs and stools.

title: Sales at Molla Space, Property, Jensen-Lewis and Others
description: Molla Space is taking up to 60 percent off some accessories, while supplies last (the Printing Vase bottle cover, shown, usually $26, is about $10); (888) 665-5277, mollaspace.com.

title: Travel Day Tomorrow
description: Also, I have a nasty cold  the perfect combination. Expect few if any posts.

title: When You Want to Say Thats How to Dress
description: Fashion Week has been a lavish rat race, an incredible assault on the nerves, with people rushing down to Chelsea, up to Lincoln Center, back to Chelsea while being bombarded by aimless weirdos with cameras and clothes you cant forget fast enough.

title: Pettitte Stays on Track for Return
description: BOSTON  No sooner was Bobby Valentine asked about the challenge posed by Andy Pettittes impending return to the Yankees than he was asked a follow-up question about Roger Clemens and his comeback in independent minor league baseball.

title: Punk Merged With Quirky Decoration
description: Long story short: I kind of linked up Madeleine Castaing with punk, Anna Sui said of her spring collection shown Wednesday night.

description: Washington

description: San Francisco

title: A Sugar High?
description: Democrats are riding a wave of enthusiasm. Republicans are dreading a Romney wipeout.

title: The Country Beckons Spaniards as Jobs in Cities Grow Scarce
description: VILLANUEVA DE LA VERA, Spain  A chemist by training, Silvia Barcenilla searched for a job in Madrid for almost a year. But in March, she decided to try a different approach, moving here to the village of Villanueva de la Vera, a two-and-a-half-hour drive to the west.

title: Things I Saw  No. 31
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: Board of Education Proposal
description: A proposal from the Chicago board outlines measures to achieve a new contract and end the teachers strike in public schools across the city.

title: The Girl Wonder of Golf
description: HOYLAKE, England  The golf prodigy Lydia Ko was asked how she would cope with being the youngest competitor this week at the Womens British Open, which was like asking Sean Lennon how he deals with being the son of a Beatle. The 15-year-old Ko knows no different.

title: The Old Dependable Is Depended Upon Once Again
description: A NEW campaign for New York Life, from its new creative agency, expresses an idea that is tried and true.

title: Denouncing Citys Move to Regulate Circumcision
description: The grandmother carried the sleeping infant boy on a white pillow toward the synagogues altar, and passed him to her son. Her son carried the infant toward the mohel, or Jewish ritual circumciser, who stood amid a cluster of chanting men.

title: 23 Years After Soccer Tragedy, an Apology and a Shift in Blame
description: LONDON  Nearly a quarter of a century after 96 Liverpool soccer fans were crushed to death in one of the worst stadium disasters in history, Prime Minister David Cameron formally apologized on Wednesday to the victims families, saying their appalling deaths were compounded by an attempt by the police, investigators and the news media to depict the victims as hooligans and to blame them for the disaster.

title: Through Primaries, Embattled Assemblyman Seeks to Shore Up Clout
description: Vito J. Lopez may be preparing for his last hurrah as Brooklyns pre-eminent power broker.

title: Fewer Uninsured People
description: The number of Americans who lack health insurance declined last year, the first drop since 2007. This is, in large part, the result of the health care reform law and better coverage under public programs like Medicaid. This also shows why repealing the health care law or revamping and shrinking Medicaid, as many Republicans want to do, would be disastrous moves.

title: My Map of New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Pennsylvanias Bad Election Law
description: On Thursday, the Pennsylvania Supreme Court is scheduled to hear arguments about the states strict new photo ID law, which is allegedly intended to prevent voter fraud. A voter must present a government-issued or other approved photo ID at a polling place to vote or can file a provisional ballot, which must be validated later by a submission of a photo ID or proof that the voter is indigent.

title: Is Bundled Medical Care a Good Idea?
description: To the Editor:

title: Vote Thursday in New York
description: With a low turnout expected, voters have a chance to make a big difference in Thursdays primary elections for judgeships and state legislative seats in New York City. Here are our endorsements in some judicial races and in a few heavily Democratic legislative districts, where a victory in the primary would be tantamount to election. Polls are open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m.

title: Lessons in the Chicago Teachers Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: A Ban on Flavored Tobacco Products
description: To the Editor:

title: 18 Are Arrested in Theft of Tiny Liquor Bottles
description: The question is no doubt asked about minibars in hotel rooms across the world: If just one of those tiny liquor bottles were to go missing, would anyone notice?

title: Design Thrills Apples Partners, but Will Cost Users
description: The iPhone 5 has plenty of new features to keep Apple fans happy. But there is one feature Apple unveiled on Wednesday that is likely to annoy many: a new connector on the phones base.

title: New Features for iPhone 5
description: While Apple has been reluctant in the past to radically alter its smartphone, the new iPhone 5 has several significant design changes.

title: Reports Say Calhoun Is Retiring as Coach
description: Jim Calhoun  a three-time national champion, a three-time cancer survivor and a renowned coach whose verve and talent turned a mainly regional program into a national college basketball powerhouse  will retire Thursday as Connecticuts coach, according to multiple news media reports.

title: State Comptroller Office Wrote Part of Lopez Settlement, Documents Show
description: ALBANY  The office of the state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, wrote portions of a controversial sexual harassment settlement involving a prominent assemblyman, according to documents the office released on Wednesday.

title: Lottery Numbers
Obama Grows More Reliant on Big-Money Contributors
description: Kirk Wagar, a Florida lawyer who has raised more than $1 million for President Obamas re-election bid, had his choice of rooms for the Democratic convention at Charlottes Ritz-Carlton or Westin hotels and nightly access to hospitality suites off the convention floor.

title: Marchesa: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Clinton Sticks to Domestic Issues While Campaigning for Obama
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  On a rare day when both parties were focused on foreign affairs after the explosion of anti-American tumult in North Africa, former President Bill Clinton stuck to domestic issues of the economy and middle-class struggles on Wednesday as he continued his roadshow to re-elect President Obama.

title: Does Mideast Democracy Complicate Diplomacy?
Offers Rejected as Players Ponder Europe as Option
description: The N.H.L. on Wednesday continued to move toward its third lockout in 17 years, with each side offering a new proposal that the other called insignificant.

title: Off-Duty Police Officer Stabbed by Intruder
description: An off-duty police officer was stabbed Wednesday afternoon by a knife-wielding man who apparently forced his way into the officers second-floor apartment in Jamaica, Queens, the police said.

title: Mitts Major Meltdown
description: Mitt Romney broke our deal.

title: In Soda Fight, Industry Focuses on the Long Run
description: Fearful that stricter limits on soda sales in New York City could incite a national trend  and a long-term erosion of profits  the nations sweetened-beverage companies plan to continue campaigning against Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs restrictions on large sodas, even after the plans expected approval on Thursday by the Board of Health.

title: Man Is Charged With a 1993 Manhattan Murder, Based on DNA Evidence
description: It took nearly two decades, but the trail of blood down the stairs outside a Manhattan apartment where a social worker was stabbed to death in 1993 led to a man the authorities say was the killer.

title: Students Over Unions
description: The most important civil rights battleground today is education, and, likewise, the most crucial struggle against poverty is the one fought in schools.

title: Opportunity Knocks at Deaths Door
description: Just hear me out. This innocuous phrase, spoken by one young Irishwoman to another, betokens another painful turn of the screw in Fly Me to the Moon, a dark comedy written and directed by Marie Jones that opened Tuesday night at 59E59 Theaters as part of the 1st Irish festival. When Francis (Katie Tumelty) turns to her fellow caregiver Loretta (Tara Lynne ONeill) and utters those four imploring words, chances are that both are going to find themselves drifting ever closer to calamity.

title: Get Back on the Horse
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Before we get started on todays puzzle discussion, Id like to give you an example of why things are not always fair in love and journalism.

title: In Pivotal Start, a Pivotal Victory
description: BOSTON

title: Obama Speaks of Libya Attack at Rally in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS  President Obama began what was supposed to be a boisterous campaign rally here Wednesday before his most ardent group of supporters with a somber remembrance of the four Americans who were killed at the United States Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, on Tuesday.

title: Wilson Set to Replace Revis, if Necessary
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  As soon as the Buffalo Bills lined up in one of their favorite formations Sunday, Jets cornerback Kyle Wilson had a pretty good idea where their receivers would run. Then he stepped in front of a pass intended for David Nelson.

title: MetroCards May Lose 7% Bonuses by Next Year
description: The volume discount has long been a staple of New York City commerce, permeating bakeries, electronics stores and, for more than a decade, even the citys transit system with a simple pledge: You buy something, you get something free.

title: Facebook Friends Boasted of Gang War, Police Say
description: They became Facebook friends, filling each others in-boxes with requests to join their networks, these young men from rival gangs who called the Brooklyn neighborhood of East New York their turf.

title: Portland Approves Fluoridation by 14
description: Portland, Ore., which never fluoridated its water supply and over time earned the distinction as the biggest city in the country to just say no, reversed course on Wednesday with a unanimous vote by the City Council to add fluoride beginning in early 2014.

title: Another Quiet Night for Mets Bats at Home
description: Even the boos at Citi Field spewed forth without their usual bite. But that is just how things have gone recently in Queens. Everything has felt a bit halfhearted.

title: Business Trip as Schiano Returns to New Jersey
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Greg Schiano is a native of Wyckoff, N.J., who coached Rutgers for 11 seasons. None of that is affecting him, he said, as he prepares to lead the Tampa Bay Buccaneers into MetLife Stadium to face the Giants on Sunday.

title: Obamas Top Fund-Raisers
description: Fund-raising totals through May for some of the top bundlers (those who gather checks from friends and business associates) for President Obamas campaign and the Democratic National Committee, according to internal financial documents obtained by The New York Times.

title: Push to Add Charter Schools Hangs Over Strike
description: CHICAGO  Of the issues that remain to be settled in the contract dispute here between the teachers union and the city, expanding charter schools is not officially on the table.

title: In South Africa, Labor Unrest in Mining Deepens
description: JOHANNESBURG  The labor strife gripping South Africas mines spread Wednesday, with riots prompting the worlds largest platinum producer to halt production at a number of its mines in the country and guards firing tear gas on protesting workers at a major gold mine.

title: Judge Rules Against Law on Indefinite Detention
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge on Wednesday blocked the government from enforcing a controversial statute about the indefinite detention without trial of terrorism suspects. Congress enacted the measure last year as part of the National Defense Authorization Act.

title: Corrections: September 13, 2012
description: NEW YORK

title: Labor Fight Poses Risks to Coalition for Obama
description: Democrats left their convention in Charlotte, N.C., with an unusual amount of unity and enthusiasm, but the three-day-old strike by 26,000 teachers in Chicago has quickly deflated some of that enthusiasm  and could, some political analysts say, ultimately put some sizable cracks in the coalition that President Obama hopes to ride to re-election.

title: Attack Victim Shared His Fears in Messages
description: Sean Smith, an Air Force veteran working on temporary assignment as an information management officer in Libya, was one of the four Americans killed Tuesday in the attack on the diplomatic mission in Benghazi.

title: Proenza Schouler: Modern Excavation
description: How was it getting here? Jack McCollough asked before the Proenza Schouler show on Wednesday. Was it too far?

title: Deal on a Farm Bill Appears Unlikely
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional agreement on a stalled farm bill seemed increasingly out of reach on Wednesday, as a few hundred farmers gathered near the Capitol to press for its passage. They were greeted by an unusually bipartisan group of lawmakers pushing for action in the House, where Republican leaders have declined to pursue legislation.

title: Proenza Schouler: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Ryan Plays Up Wisconsin Pride as Obama TV Ads Begin in State
description: DE PERE, Wis.  Paul D. Ryan is running for the second-highest office in the land, but a voter might have confused him for a state candidate here on Wednesday, so frequent were his Wisconsin references as he sought to maximize his native appeal.

title: Eli Zborowski, 86, Leader in Holocaust Remembrance, Dies
description: Eli Zborowski, a survivor of the Holocaust who made it his mission to ensure that it would never be forgotten, founded an American organization to support Israels official Holocaust memorial and raised more than $100 million for it, died on Monday in Queens. He was 86.

title: After Mistakenly Purging Citizens, Florida Agrees to Let Them Vote
description: MIAMI  In a partial victory for voter rights and immigrant groups, Florida residents who were mistakenly removed from the voter rolls this year because the state classified them as noncitizens will be returned to the rolls and allowed to vote in November.

title: Struggle for Ideological Upper Hand in Muslim World Seen as Factor in Attacks
description: DOHA, Qatar  The Arab uprisings have appeared to offer a new bridge in the anguished relationship between the United States and the Muslim world, perhaps most of all in Libya, where American firepower helped oust Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and earned the United States deep popular gratitude.

title: Missteps Dont Become Stumbles
description: BOSTON  The Yankees have been sitting precariously atop the American League East standings for a week. One misstep could cast them into second place for the first time in three months. That misstep appeared to have cropped up Wednesday night when Derek Jeter landed awkwardly on first base while trying to beat out a double play ball in the eighth inning.

title: Spotlight Is on Libya, but Bigger Challenge for White House May Lie in Egypt
description: WASHINGTON  For all the harrowing images of the deadly attack on the American mission in Benghazi, Libya, the Obama administration is grappling with the possibility that its far bigger long-term problem lies in Egypt, not Libya.

title: Support for the Euro Is Seen in Dutch Election Results
description: AMSTERDAM  In a closely watched election, Dutch voters appeared Wednesday to give Prime Minister Mark Rutte and his center-right Liberal party a narrow victory over the center-left Labor party, which will bring a sigh of relief to European allies anxious about rising euro skepticism in the richer countries of the north.

title: Anna Sui: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: France: New Leader Is Named for the Socialist Party
description: Harlem Dsir, a member of the European Parliament and former leader of an antiracism organization, was designated Wednesday as the next leader of Frances governing Socialist Party, replacing Martine Aubry, who is stepping down. Mr. Dsir, 52, is an Aubry ally and replaced her as interim party leader when she ran unsuccessfully for the party presidential nomination. She and Prime Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault nominated Mr. Dsir; next months party vote on the nomination is considered a formality.

title: Young Childrens Deaths Said to Drop Again in 2011
description: Fewer than seven million children around the world died before their fifth birthday from disease and birth complications in 2011  a new low  the World Health Organization, the United Nations Childrens Fund and other agencies announced Wednesday. About 12 million children that age died in 1990, and the number fell below 10 million for the first time in 2007, so the pace of saving childrens lives is accelerating, experts said. Half of all the deaths occurred in five countries: India, Nigeria, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Pakistan and China. The leading causes, in descending order, were pneumonia, premature birth, diarrhea, birth complications and malaria. Most of those deaths were preventable with relatively cheap interventions, the United Nations agencies said.

title: Quality Defense a Key to U.S. Victory
description: Of all the positives coming out of the United States 1-0 victory over Jamaica in Tuesdays World Cup qualifier in Columbus, Ohio  the way the Americans dominated the first half, Danny Williamss quality showing, another strrong match from Geoff Cameron, Graham Zusis solid performance, the number of chances the team created, Herculez Gomezs free kick for the games only goal  perhaps one has been overlooked: the confident and strong play on defense.

title: The Widows Doctor Visit
description: I walked into the examination room and saw her sitting there, her arm around her 10-year-old son, her teenage daughter across the room.

title: Word of the Day | deadpan
description: deadpan \ded-pan\ adjective

title: Must All U.S. Embassies Now Be Fortresses?
description: HONG KONG  There is certain to be a demand  any minute now, wait for it  for more rigorous security at American embassies and consulates around the world. The attacks this week on the consulate in Benghazi, Libya, and the embassy in Cairo almost require a review of how U.S. diplomatic facilities are sited, designed, built and guarded.

title: Dole in Talks to Sell 2 Businesses to Itochu of Japan
description: TOKYO  Dole Food has said it is in advanced talks to sell its packaged foods and Asian fresh fruit businesses to the Japanese trading house Itochu.

title: Yuvraj Singhs Roaring Comeback Quiets Critics
description: India may have lost the second Twenty20 game by a solitary run against New Zealand on Tuesday, but the teams biggest consolation was the successful return of Yuvraj Singh after his battle with cancer.

title: Mexico Announces Capture of Gulf Cartels Top Leader
description: MEXICO CITY  In a major strike against one of Mexicos largest drug-trafficking organizations, the Mexican Navy said Thursday that it had detained one of the most sought-after drug kingpins in Mexico and the United States, the top leader of the Gulf Cartel.

title: News Quiz | September 13, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Delhi Donts: High Heels in Khan Market
description: Khan Market looks like many other outdoor markets in Delhi  a crowded inner lane, uneven pavement, spontaneous potholes and an occasional pile of garbage or stray dog. Like the others, this U-shaped market is not the easiest to navigate, but many of its patrons wouldnt dream of shopping there without the right footwear  high, high heels.

title: A Farewell to Indias Milkman
description: My latest column is an inadequate eulogy to one of the most useful Indian men ever, Verghese Kurien, who died this week. Mr. Kurien, who helped make India into the worlds leading milk producer, was among a generation of extraordinary social revolutionaries who are the proof that sometimes some Indian politicians do fully back good people and give them complete freedom.

title: Test Yourself | English, Sept. 13, 2012
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the restaurant review Where Fresh Flavors Flip.

title: American Ambassador Killed in Libya
description: Please note: Though our questions today seek to help students understand basic facts about this event, you may want to check the New York Times homepage for the latest updates as the story develops.

title: Boomers vs. Millennials: Whos Really Getting Robbed?
description: The only way to save Americas children is to lock up the baby boomers. We are robbing the next generations future.

title: Looking Toward Retirement
description: In case you missed the special retirement section on Wednesday, its worth having a look, particularly if youre a boomer heading that way. Itll give you a lot to think about. Paul Sullivan has a more than a little worrisome story on how hard it is for retirees to rely on Social Security alone, The Tightwire Act of Living Only on Social Security. The numbers are not on our side.

title: Getting Back to Work
description: While the unemployment rate for baby boomers is lower than for younger workers, once boomers lose a job, it takes them longer to find a new one.

title: Mellow Drinks in a Surprising Neighborhood
description: Unless you live there, the East Village is usually not the first neighborhood that comes to mind when you want a drink after work. The East Village is where your kids go with their friends  or where they rent an apartment (also with their friends).

title: Welcome to Your Living Room, Boomers
description: This isnt the best thing to admit, but the term baby boomer makes me a little queasy. In my mind it conjures images of 65-year-old hippies skipping through meadows on their way to the local Social Security office.

title: If Football Is So Dangerous to Players, Should We Be Watching It?
description: Devon Walker, a Tulane University football player, broke his neck last weekend while making a tackle during a game. Three days earlier the journal Neurology reported that football players are three to four times more likely than the rest of us to die from brain diseases. If football, Americas most popular spectator sport, is inherently dangerous to players, should we be watching it?

title: Why Cant I Read This AARP Bulletin?
description: Your arms can push that book only so far away before you have to admit there is a problem, and it isnt with your arms: it is with your eyes. Its called presbyopia, and lets not sugarcoat it. Thats a Greek word for old eyes, said Dr. James J. Salz, a Los Angeles ophthalmologist.

title: Baby Boomers Who Celebrate Birthdays This Week
description: Baby boomers are aging gracelessly. Its exhausting listening to us. How many times have you heard a boomer say, I cant believe Im this old  as if we are the first people in the history of the planet to turn 58. According to the Yankelovich research firm, the average boomer thinks old age begins at 79. Since average life expectancy is 77, this means boomers believe that first they will die, then they will get old.

title: For Better, for Worse, Couples Who Endure
description: In Tom Brokaws best seller The Greatest Generation, he makes the case that the men and women who survived the Depression and led America to victory in World War II  the baby boomers parents and grandparents  made a contribution to this country like no other in history. Among the many reasons he cites is their commitment to family. Only one in six of their marriages ended in divorce; for the boomers it has been one in two.

title: Im Not Getting Any Better
description: Im turning 58 next month, and the birthday present Im giving myself is to call a halt to all of my efforts at self-improvement. Im done trying to better myself. This is as good as Im going to get. From now on, the goal is to try to hang on to what Ive got.

title: Introducing the Latin Euro
description: Peter Boone is chairman of the charity Effective Intervention and a research associate at the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics. He is also a director of Salute Capital Management Ltd. Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund.

title: A Long View of Afghanistans Wars
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  One of the most troubling things about the national conversation about Afghanistan is that it tends to focus almost solely on the decade since the 2001 American-led invasion. Perhaps this is understandable, since the Afghan conflict marks the longest stretch of time that the United States has actively been at war. And as always, the latest crisis, any of them, dominates attention: the growing threat posed by Afghan forces who kill their NATO colleagues, the unwillingness of Pakistan to stop sheltering militants who carry out attacks in Kabul, the plague of official corruption that undermines Western trust and the Afghan publics support.

title: Egypt May Be Bigger Concern Than Libya for White House
description: WASHINGTON  For all the harrowing images of the deadly attack on the American mission in Benghazi, the Obama administration is grappling with the possibility that its far bigger long-term problem lies in Egypt, not Libya.

title: Europes Governments and Investors Are Wary of a Giant Aerospace Merger
description: PARIS  European governments and shareholders reacted with caution on Thursday to news that the regions two largest aerospace and military companies were in advanced discussions to create a $49 billion behemoth to rival the likes of Lockheed Martin and Boeing.

title: Turmoil Over Contentious Video Spreads
description: SANA, Yemen  Deadly outrage in the Arab world over an American-made video insulting Islams founder spread to at least half a dozen places across the Middle East on Thursday and threatened to draw in Afghanistan, two days after assailants in Libya killed four American diplomatic personnel, including the ambassador, and caused a foreign policy political clash in the United States.

title: The New New List
description: Chennai is the new Mumbai

title: Big Data Gets Its Own Photo Album
description: Rick Smolan, the photographer and impresario of media projects, has tackled all sorts of big subjects over the years, from countries (A Day in the Life of Australia in 1981) to drinking water (Blue Planet Run in 2007). He typically recruits about 100 photographers for each, and their work is crafted into classy coffee-table books of striking photographs and short essays.

title: The Early Word: Fallout
description: In Todays Times:The deadly attack on an American consulate in Libya on Tuesday pushed foreign policy to the front of the presidential campaign, with Mitt Romney quickly attacking President Obama for his response to the situation, Peter Baker and Ashley Parker write. But Mr. Romneys attempt to use the event to draw a contrast with Mr. Obama on foreign policy started a confrontation that landed him on the defensive and drew attention away from questions about Mr. Obamas handling of uprisings in the Arab world.

title: Searching U.S. Colleges, Doubt Creeps In Amid the Confidence
description: In fifth grade, I knew I wanted to study computer science when I grew up. My school did not offer much in that subject, so I spent my time building Web sites and silly apps on Visual Basic, and exploring random software. In high school, when I could finally take programming classes, I fell in love with programming. It was the perfect mix between art and science. I knew just what I wanted to do.

description: AMSTERDAM  In a closely watched election, Dutch voters appeared on Wednesday to give Prime Minister Mark Rutte and his center-right Liberal Party a narrow victory over the center-left Labor Party, which will bring a sigh of relief to European allies anxious about rising euro skepticism in the richer countries of the north.

title: David Simon on Ravens, Gay Marriage and Free Speech
description: David Simon, the former Baltimore Sun crime reporter who went on to create award-winning shows like The Wire, commented on Saturday on the Maryland politician who attempted to silence Baltimore Ravens linebacker Brendon Ayanbadejo over his support of gay marriage.

description: This weeks Poetry Pairing matches Full Flight by Bob Hicok with At Ground Zero, Readers Offer Plain-Spoken Tributes to Those Lost, an article that appeared on Tuesday, the eleventh anniversary of the terrorist attacks of 9/11.

title: Always Be Crisping
description: Cooking is sales, as any child or restaurant chef will tell you. The single word crispy sells more food than a barrage of adjectives describing the ingredients or cooking techniques on a menu, Mario Batali writes in Babbo, the best restaurant cookbook of the modern age, dedicated to the menu at his flagship restaurant in Greenwich Village. There is something innately appealing about crispy food.

title: Introducing: Creating Value
description: Business owners start businesses for a variety of reasons. A few do it to make a lot of money, but a vast majority do it for other reasons.

description: The Guy

title: Silent Echoes
description: Its the rare campaign skirmish that barely makes a splash. President Barack Obama shrugged off a question about Venezuela from a popular television anchor in Miami, saying the country posed no serious threat to the national security of the United States. Mitt Romney declared himself stunned by the idea that Hugo Chvez isnt a danger. To think so, Romney said, is simply naive.

title: Tip of the Week: Photos in Full Screen View
description: The ability to see photos in full-screen mode on the computer cuts down background distraction from icons cluttering the desktop. In Windows, when you open a photo in Windows Explorer, press the F11 key on the keyboard to expand the picture to the full screen. If it does not work, the manufacturer may have modified the keyboard function; try pressing the Function key and F11 or check the computers manual.

description: 12:21 p.m. | Updated

title: Larry Gibson, 66, a Foe of Mountaintop Mining, Is Dead
description: Larry Gibson, the retired autoworker who gained national attention for his fight against mountaintop-removal coal mining in his native Appalachia, died of a heart attack on Sunday at his home in West Virginia. He was 66.

title: O.E.C.D. Finds New Signs of Weakness in World Economy
description: LONDON  More evidence of a weakening global economy emerged Thursday ahead of the Federal Reserves decision to take aggressive new steps to stimulate growth in the United States.

title: ESPN, Aided by Arbitron and comScore, to Follow the Audience Wherever It Goes
description: With more people using Twitter while they watch television, surfing the Web while they listen to the radio, or toggling between the content on their tablets and smartphones, advertisers and media companies are struggling to keep track of the eyeballs they covet.

title: Midwest Musketeers Storm Broadway
description: TO sit in the orchestra of a Broadway theater in the week before a show begins previews is to wonder that any show ever opens at all. Late on a Friday night, at the close of a technical rehearsal for Grace, a play by Craig Wright at the Cort Theater, doors wobbled, lines faltered and costume changes dragged.

description: The world welcomed a piece of good news today: The number of children dying under the age of 5 has steadily dropped over two decades, according to a report by United Nations Childrens Fund.

description: Indias central government hopes to push through significant financial reforms in coming weeks aimed at kick-starting the countrys slowing economy, but Mamata Banerjee, West Bengals chief minister, may again stand in the way.

description: LONDON  While Americans were mourning the death of their ambassador to Libya and three of his embassy staff, many in the Middle East were lamenting the latest blow to their hopes for the Arab Spring.

title: Hey, Elmo, That Concept Has Legs
description: ON a steamy June morning five 4-year-olds at a Harlem day care center lined up on the floor and focused intently on a tiny television set. Around them a half-dozen young women sat on miniature chairs and intensely monitored their every reaction. Were the children looking away? Smiling? Making a negative comment? Clapping?

title: Instruments of Young Dreams
description: A combination of road movie, buddy comedy and musical, the new indie film Brooklyn Brothers Beat the Best (coming Sept. 21) is out to have a good time. It is the brainchild of Ryan ONan, an actor making his directorial debut. He also wrote the film and co-stars with Michael Weston, who has appeared on TV shows like House and Six Feet Under and now gets to flex his comedy muscles in a lead role.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Proenza Schouler
description: The Look: Lived-In.

title: Humans and Nature: Can the Gulf Be Bridged?
description: Basking in a surprise dose of early morning sun, we sat together on a bench made from yellow-cedar at the Gustavus Forelands Preserve, a landscape of spruce and cottonwood forests and beaches overlooking the Icy Strait waters. We were staring at a diagram on a piece of paper I had handed to Hank Lentfer, a lifelong Alaskan and longtime resident of the tiny town of Gustavus.

title: Balanchines Enduring Pact With Stravinsky
description: FOR over a hundred years now the music of Igor Stravinsky has been central to ballet. In 1909, while still a virtual unknown, he orchestrated a Chopin number for the ballet Les Sylphides as part of the opening season of Diaghilevs Ballets Russes. The next year Diaghilev presented the premiere of The Firebird with Stravinskys new score. The 20th century certainly spawned modernist composers, but none of them matched his profound instinct for dance rhythm; and none kept on so restlessly unlocking aspects of the new.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Washington Post: A dish of loin with roasted apples and Cumberland sauce is just one of the dishes the ubiquitous chef Jos Andrs will bring to the upcoming NBC series Hannibal, concerning Hannibal Lecter, the serial killer/gourmand who favored human liver with some fava beans and a nice Chianti. Andrs is now the shows food consultant.  Glenn Collins

title: Plugging Into a New Synergy
description: SHOKAN, N.Y.

title: Teenage Dress Codes: Easier Said Than Done
description: In 2009-10, about 57 percent of public school principals reported that their schools enforced a dress code. Some rules are intended to promote modesty, others to encourage a respectful learning environment.

description: David Ramirez

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Anti-Muslim Trailers Murky Past, and Casting Nina Simone
description: Tanzina Vega discusses the online debate over the casting for the role of Nina Simone in Nina.

title: Sept. 16  22
description: The weekend-long festivals by the London promoter All Tomorrows Parties have often been in faded vacation spots  English holiday camps and their counterparts in the Catskills and Atlantic City. As musical experiences the American events have been blissful but not boffo; costs ran high and attendance ran low. So the company is trying a new model with ALL TOMORROWS PARTIES AMERICA PRESENTS ILL BE YOUR MIRROR   nearly 40 acts across three days at Pier 36, an entertainment complex on the Lower East Side. Frank Ocean, the R&B man of the hour, headlines on Friday, after a day including the comedian Hannibal Buress, a collaboration between Tyondai Braxton and Philip Glass, and Lee Ranaldos Hanging Guitar project, involving suspended, swinging Fender Jaguars. The reunited Afghan Whigs headline next Saturday, and other bands that day include the Roots, Jos Gonzlez, Dirty Three and Chavez; for next Sunday the organizers have a slate including Godspeed You! Black Emperor, along with the Make-Up, the Washington punk-soul band, in reunited form. 5 p.m. to 1 a.m. Friday; noon to 1 a.m. next Saturday and Sunday; South and Montgomery Streets; atpfestival.com; $60 to $199.

title: Cambodias Most Unwanted
description: PHNOM PENH  The municipal council recently hung a neon sign across Sisowath Quay, on the capitals popular riverfront. Phnom Penh  The Charming City, it boasted.

title: Kids Draw the News: Peacock on the Loose
description: The escape and capture of Kevin, a peacock kept by John Bowne High School in Queens, is the subject of drawings submitted by children.

title: The Death of a Butterfly in Kabul
description: Parwana means butterfly in Dari, and that is exactly what she was, fluttering around the grit and gloom of the green zone. She was killed last week, along with several other children, as they tried to call attention to a suicide bomber a few blocks from my house in Kabul. They were killed in part because I and so many well-meaning people drew them to a place where we could not keep them safe.

title: Fresh Hopes for End to Chicago Teacher Strike by Weekend
description: CHICAGO  Meeting behind closed doors into the evening, leaders on both sides of this citys teacher strike voiced optimism on Thursday that a deal could soon be reached, bringing an end to a walkout that has halted classes for 350,000 students in the nations third-largest school system.

title: Daily Report: An iPhone Tweak That Could Cost You
description: The iPhone 5 has plenty of new features to keep Apple fans happy. But as Brian X. Chen reports in Thursdays New York Times, there is one feature Apple unveiled on Wednesday that is likely to annoy many: a new connector on the phones base.

title: Do Romneys Budget Pledges Threaten S.B.A. Loans?
description: Should Mitt Romney become president next year, he will face a difficult question pitting his eagerness to help small businesses against his eagerness to shrink the government: What to do with the Small Business Administration?

title: There Will Be Megalomania
description: The Master, Paul Thomas Andersons imposing, confounding and altogether amazing new film, is partly concerned with the life and work of one Lancaster Dodd, leader of a therapeutic, quasi-religious cult known as the Cause. Dodds process, a stew of Freud, hypnosis and carnival sideshow mumbo-jumbo, is based on a kind of mental time travel. The subject is led, by a series of pointed, painful questions, on a search for past trauma  earlier in life, before birth, in a previous existence  that can be identified as the source of negative emotion and destructive behavior in the present.

title: Kids Draw the News: Tornadoes in New York
description: New Assignment

title: Checking Social Security Benefits Online
description: 12:52 p.m. | Updated  To add how much higher benefits would be at age 70 than at age 62.

title: At Apple Event, With Secrets Spilled, No Surprises
description: One of the big surprises at Wednesdays Apple Event was the lack of surprises.

title: The Label Says Organic  But Is It?
description: Business Day Live: California ballot initiative has national implications for food labels. | Standard Chartered prepares to settle in money laundering case. | Controversy over movie about Nina Simone.

title: At UConn, Its Time to Go
description: These arent necessarily good days to be a sporting icon, or at least one who clawed his way to the top with help from some moral or ethical sidestepping along the way, which in college sports, we now have come to expect, is just about everyone. But even a few years ago Connecticut Coach Jim Calhoun could have expected his retirement to be greeted by universal acclaim. He did, after all, lead a basketball backwater to the big time and establish himself as a great coaching mind, all while professing to be above the unethical muck dragging down lesser mortals in the sport.

title: If You Like Crosby, Stills and Nash . . .
description: Five years ago, Val Haller, a suburban Chicago mom, started valslist, a Web site aimed at exposing her generation  shes 55  to the music of the generation of her sons, ages 20 to 27. Unlike Pandora, a digital music recommendation service governed by an algorithm, Ms. Haller is governed by her ear, long hours of listening and serendipity. At Lollapalooza Chicago 2012, she was 25 years older than the average music reporter. My goal every single day is to find that one new track that speaks to me and wont let me go, she says.

title: Health Panel Approves Restriction on Sale of Large Sugary Drinks
description: Seeking to reduce runaway obesity rates, the New York City Board of Health on Thursday approved a ban on the sale of large sodas and other sugary drinks at restaurants, street carts and movie theaters, the first restriction of its kind in the country.

title: Right Begins to Rally Around Romneys Response to Attacks
description: Republicans were not exactly rushing to defend Mitt Romneys brisk critique of the Obama administrations response to a controversial Web video and the protests it seemed to help spawn. However, by Thursday, the rights establishment was starting to circle the wagons around Mr. Romney, the Republican presidential candidate.

title: Answers to Your Questions About Apples iPhone 5
description: 4:40 p.m. | Updated Adding more questions and answers.

title: Image of the Day: September 13
Taking the Preferences Out of Preferred Stock
description: You have to marvel at the lengths to which the radio station operator Emmis Communications has gone to strip its preferred stock of voting rights and accrued dividends worth millions. And deal watchers will salivate over the clever legal structures devised by Emmiss lawyers.

title: At Tech Conferences, All Eyes Are on the Celebrities
description: The chatter in the hallways of conferences are usually a better barometer of the tech scene than the conversations taking place on the stage.

title: At Lunch With Max and Eli Sussman
description: A big fish head in a hot pot? Max and Eli Sussman had no choice.

title: Business Day Live: Food Fight
description: California referendum has national implications for food labels. | Standard Chartered prepares to settle in money laundering case. | Controversy over movie about Nina Simone.

title: Soross Wisdom and Markets Ignorance
description: In my column this week, I discuss George Soross headline-grabbing insistence that the euro will survive only if Germany leads or leaves. My column focuses on his passionate conviction that a united Europes value goes beyond economics  this is also a political, and even moral, story.

title: Wheelies: The Dr. Sid Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: A Promotion for Francesca Zambello at Washington National Opera
description: The Washington National Opera said on Thursday it had promoted Francesca Zambello  from artistic adviser to artistic director, solidifying its reorganization after the departure of Plcido Domingo and its merger with the Kennedy Center. Mr. Domingo stepped down as artistic director at the end of the 2010-2011 season, and the company became a Kennedy Center affiliate in response to serious money problems. Ms. Zambello, who is also the artistic and executive director of the Glimmerglass Festival in Cooperstown, N.Y., had stepped in at Washington to fill the void after Mr. Domingos departure. She now will have complete oversight of casting, repertory, the young artists program and a new commissioning project. She will continue to direct one production a year, the company said. She will assume the position in January.

title: Louise Goldin: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Another Murder on the Resource Frontier  This Time a Journalist in Cambodia
description: Speaking truth to power is never easy. In some places, particularly where valuable resources are pursued in places with limited governance, it can be deadly.

title: Business Day Live | Casting Controversy
description: A casting choice for a biographical film about the singer Nina Simone spurs protests.

title: Federal Reserve Expected to Act to Spur Economy
description: WASHINGTON  Federal Reserve officials are expected to conclude a two-day meeting Thursday and announce new measures to aid the ailing American recovery.

title: Photos of The Moment | Anna Sui

title: My Night as a Billionaire
description: This summer, a case of mistaken identity earned me a seat at a formal dinner at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Led Zeppelin to Release Concert Film
description: Led Zeppelin, the hard-rock and seminal heavy metal band, will release a concert movie in October, just two months before the band is scheduled to be honored at the Kennedy Center in Washington for its weighty role in transforming rock music.

title: Nicholson Baker: By the Book
description: The author of The Way the World Works suspects Shakespeare is the most overrated writer of all time. Although I must say his sonnets are incredible.

title: 60 Minutes to Produce a Monthly Sports Show for Showtime
description: 60 Minutes is extending itself to another network, Showtime, for a monthly newsmagazine called 60 Minutes of Sports.

title: J.&J. Names Outsider to Run Its Troubled Consumer Unit
description: Johnson & Johnson named an outsider on Thursday to fill a top leadership role overseeing its troubled consumer health unit, a break from the companys longstanding tradition of promoting executives from within.

title: E-Book Planned on Embattled Russian Punk Group
description: The women of Pussy Riot, the Russian punk group protesting President Vladimir V. Putin, will have their message out in a new medium: an e-book. Pussy Riot! A Punk Prayer for Freedom, to be released in about two weeks by The Feminist Press, part of the City University of New York, will include previously unavailable material, including prison letters from the three Pussy Riot members who have been jailed for hooliganism inciting religious hatred after a brief performance in an Orthodox cathedral in Moscow. The book will also include statements by their defense attorneys, poems and tributes from performers and artists, including Yoko Ono, Karen Finley and the poet Eileen Myles. Proceeds will go to the legal defense fund for the group.

title: Turmoil at U.S. Posts Abroad
description: Protesters angered by an anti-Islam film attacked the American Embassy in Sana, the Yemeni capital, on Thursday, two days after the American ambassador to Libya was killed.

title: Fed Ties New Aid to Jobs Recovery in Forceful Move
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve opened a new chapter Thursday in its efforts to stimulate the economy, saying that it intends to buy large quantities of mortgage bonds, and potentially other assets, until the job market improves substantially.

title: 15-Year-Old Trails by Two at Womens British Open
description: HOYLAKE, England  Lydia Ko was climbing the first-round leader board Thursday at the Womens British Open when her group was put on the clock for slow play. The move was probably funnier to her than any punch line delivered by her coach and caddie, Guy Wilson, who told her jokes between shots at Royal Liverpool Golf Club to relax her.

title: Hey, Seorita!
description: Olympic swimmers Conor Dwyer and Ryan Lochte attended the Ralph Lauren show this morning, suggesting all is forgiven over the designers production in China of ceremonial uniforms for the athletes this year. But if you thought Mr. Lauren might make a big pro-America statement on the runway, you would have thought wrong.

title: Kevin Costner Plans Book Project
description: The director and actor Kevin Costner has signed a deal with Atria Books for a book project  an illustrated adventure series titled The Explorers Guild that will be released in 2014.

title: A Red Tide Epidemic?
description: As we mentioned here in an On Our Radar item this week, the Yangtze River in China changed from a warm brown to a deep, rusty orange a few days ago. Striking photographs showed a crimson current advancing alongside a stretch of untainted water. One Green reader wrote in to describe what she saw as a spate of red tide events around the world and inquired about the cause.

title: Watch List: How Film Might Look After Googles Glasses
description: For a preview of how we all may be making movies in a few years, take a look at DVF Through Glass, a short video made for, and partly shot by, the fashion designer Diane von Furstenberg. Other camera operators included employees of Ms. von Furstenbergs label, DVF, and models who walked in her recent Fashion Week show. All were wearing Googles futuristic Glass glasses, which come equipped with tiny cameras (as well as tiny computer monitors) and are poised to take us a big step closer to the cyborg age, once they become available to the public.

title: Dreamliner Makes Its Debut in Chile
description: Boeings 787 Dreamliner, the lighter, more-fuel efficient and purportedly more comfortable aircraft that has forged fans of hopeful fliers, recently made its American debut with the Chilean carrier LAN Airlines.

title: Fashion Week Stargazing: Day 7
description: And on the seventh day, there was Kanye West and Kim Kardashian. From the mayhem caused by the couple, first at Marchesa and later at Louise Goldin, you would have thought Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor had been reincarnated.

title: Bookshelf
description: Han Han, Chinas smart-aleck blogger (whos also a pro racecar driver), uses satire to skewer philandering pols and media censors. His posts are now translated in This Generation (Simon & Schuster, $24). Set in New York, London and Maine, Christine Schutts novel Prosperous Friends (Grove, $24) tracks a young couple lost in a game of psychosexual brinkmanship. The Grand Tour (Harper, $28) collects Agatha Christies unpublished letters from an epic 1922 journey from South Africa to Hawaii. Neil Steinbergs You Were Never in Chicago (University of Chicago, $25) is both a rollicking newspapermans memoir (hes a Chicago Sun-Times columnist) and a strong case for Second City exceptionalism  belied, a bit, by the citys inferiority complex: Chicago, Steinberg notes, once conducted a study to prove its pedestrians walk faster than those in New York.

title: The Nile Special
description: A particular patch of turbulent water on the Nile River in Uganda attracts the worlds best freestyle kayakers.

title: A Source of Thrills
description: HAIRY LEMON ISLAND, Uganda  There is a wave, far from passable roads and deep in the center of Africa, where those who seek to become the best of the best freestyle kayakers come to train.

title: Many Struggling With Prescription Drug Costs
description: While health insurance premiums may be increasing more modestly than they were a year or two ago, consumers who take multiple drugs but lack prescription drug coverage are nearing a crisis point because they cant afford to pay for them, a new report finds.

title: Man of Many Names Is Tied to a Video
description: LOS ANGELES  The spotlight in the search for the creators of an incendiary video mocking Islam that set off a wave of anti-American violence in the Middle East shifted Thursday to a shadowy gas station owner with a record of criminal arrests and bankruptcy, who associates said expressed anti-Muslim sentiments as he pushed for the making of the film.

title: Taking Pointers From Web Sites, USA Today Modernizes Its Look
description: McLEAN, Va.  Its face-lift time for the newspaper known for its pie charts.

title: Living With Cancer: The Trials of Cancer Trials
description: I spent last week trying to hope for the recurrence of a malignancy, a tumor of at least 1.5 centimeters (a bit more than half an inch) that would be visible on a CT scan.

title: How to Find (or Make) Real Buttermilk
description: Many thirsty readers wrote in to Dining on Wednesday after reading about the pleasures of buttermilk, asking how to get their hands on the good stuff.

title: Google Glass and the Future of Technology
description: New gadgets  I mean whole new gadget categories  dont come along very often. The iPhone was one recent example. You could argue that the iPad was another. But if theres anything at all as different and bold on the horizon, surely its Google Glass.

title: Legitimate Criticism
description: Stung by the furious response to Mitt Romneys attack on President Obama over the killings in Libya, some right-wing commentators have defended Mr. Romneys right to challenge Mr. Obama on foreign policy. Just for instance, Jennifer Rubin wrote in The Washington Post that Obama has no right to insist he is beyond criticism. She added: If [the media] are going to insist that holding a president accountable for his national security is out of bounds, then perhaps journalism is now farce.

title: Lionfish for Lunch, But Also Here For the Long Haul
description: Just in case you missed it, my friend and occasional fishing tutor Carl Safina has a string of posts on Mark Bittmans blog on the continuing invasion of American waters by lionfish, a reef denizen, studded with toxin-tipped spines, that was most likely brought here from Asian waters by the aquarium trade.

title: 36 Hours in Managua, Nicaragua
description: FOUNDED just before the Spanish left the country in the early 19th century, Managua, the capital of Nicaragua, is a city without a center, and, bizarrely, without conventional addresses; instead there are locations, many referring to Lake Managua, which the city, otherwise, doesnt much celebrate. The 1972 earthquake shattered Managuas once glorious boulevards, and today building styles vary wildly, from the squat residential buildings that popped up after the tremors, to older, more majestic neo-Classical and modern edifices. But despite an initial impression of chaos, you will find smooth roads and a full range of hotels and restaurants serving hearty local fare. The years of political upheaval marked by the 1979 revolution and then the brutal civil war of the 1980s have finally given way to stability. Yet travelers on their way to the coasts or quaint colonial towns still rush away from the capital upon arrival. Thats too bad. There is a blossoming of culture in this city that is the key to understanding modern Nicaragua.

title: Now Streaming | Calvin Klein Spring 2013 Womens Collection
description: The Spring 2013 womens collection show from Calvin Klein at New York Fashion Week.

title: Palace in Haiti, Damaged by Quake, Is Being Razed
description: MEXICO CITY  Armed mobs have marched on it. Desperate presidents have fled it. Crowds have partied outside its majestic gates.

title: Children of Aging Parents Are Often Nearby, Study Finds
description: Who moves?

title: Gagosian and Perelman File Suits Against Each Other Over Artworks
description: The billionaire investor Ronald Perelman and his longtime friend and art dealer Larry Gagosian both filed lawsuits in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Wednesday, with each man claiming the other cheated him out of millions of dollars over art purchases, Bloomberg reported.

title: Bobwhite Lunch & Supper Counter
description: Inside the no-fuss Alphabet City storefront that makes a mission out of Southern fried chicken.

title: A Southern Spot on a Mission
description: FIRST the chicken is baptized in sweet tea, a Southern elixir giddy with sugar, in which tea is an afterthought. It is left to brine overnight, then dredged in milk, flour, salt, pepper and mystery spices that the chef refuses to divulge. Into the pressure fryer it goes, then onto your plate.

title: Romney Delivers Broad Criticism of Obama on Foreign Policy
description: FAIRFAX, Va.  Speaking to a modest-sized crowd in Northern Virginia on Thursday, Mitt Romney sought to move beyond his criticism of President Obamas response to the turmoil in Libya and Egypt and instead broadly paint the president as weak on foreign policy.

title: Fashion Week Parties: Night 7
description: Details Fetes Michael Phelps, and Marchesa and Proenza Schouler Toast Their Collections

title: Paul Ryan Gets His Own Meet-and-Greet Room on Capitol Hill
description: Only a few months ago, Representative Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, was just another member of the House of Representatives, shuffling to the floor for votes with his iPod earphones stuck in his ears, or walking among colleagues in the Longworth House Office building.

title: Board Votes to Regulate Circumcision, Citing Risks
description: The New York City Board of Health passed a regulation on Thursday that will require consent from parents before an infant can have a form of Jewish ritual circumcision, prevalent in parts of the ultra-Orthodox community, in which the circumciser uses his mouth to remove blood from the incision.

title: Wisconsin Uses New N.C.A.A. Rule to Solve Quarterback Woes, Again
description: Confronted with devastating injuries to quarterbacks for the second consecutive season, Wisconsin has employed an inventive method to replenish its stock, far from college footballs conventional approach to cultivating the position.

title: Our Condolences, the Muslim Brotherhood Says
description: To the Editor:

title: At Film Society, Two Programmers Will Take Over From Festival Veteran
description: Nearly a year after the longtime programming director of the New York Film Festival said he was stepping down, the organization that runs it has chosen not one but two replacements. The Film Society of Lincoln Center on Thursday announced the appointment of Kent Jones as director of programming for the festival and Robert Koehler as director of programming, year round.

title: TimesCast Politics | Sept. 13, 2012
description: Romney's reaction to Benghazi. | Another foreign policy hurdle: Israeli relations. | Same-sex marriage and the New York primaries. | A deeper look at Obama's bundlers.

title: Theater Talkback: Flattened
description: Maybe it sounds a little perverse, but I usually try to avoid seeing any movies made from stage plays or musicals I have particularly enjoyed. A natural curiosity about how the material has been translated into a new medium tends to be outweighed by a general foreboding born of past experience. Too often the particular delights of a stage production evaporate considerably  if not entirely  in the translation.

title: Fiercest Competition This Season May Be Among Singing Competitions
description: Wednesday night brought further evidence that network television may be saturated with singing competitions, even as news reports circulated about which celebrated recording artists the Fox network would be adding as judges to revive the flagging flagship of singing shows, American Idol.

title: Photos of The Moment | Proenza Schouler
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Carlyle Buys Controlling Stake in Brazilian Furniture Retailer
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil  The Carlyle Group said Thursday that it had acquired a 60 percent stake in Tok & Stok, a Brazilian furniture company, in a move that positions it to take advantage of the countrys consumer retail market.

title: Disney Unexpectedly Reveals Movie Write-Down and Sluggish Ad Revenue
description: James A. Rasulo, Disneys chief financial officer, unexpectedly revealed two important tidbits at a gathering of Wall Street analysts on Thursday: The company will take a $50 million write-down at its movie studio, and summer advertising revenue at ABC was softer than expected.

title: Warm-Weather Leathers
description: Set on making the most of a good thing, a clutch of designers has reprised last seasons swoony romance with leather, trotting out unlikely springtime variations. Counterintuitive though it first seemed, the decision to experiment with skins proved an apt one, underscoring the starchy, crisply formal feel of some collections, and handily brightening others.

title: In His Narrative, Time to Get Back Into the Game
description: IN the 1980s the Israeli-born painter and sculptor Izhar Patkin often seemed to be everywhere in the New York art world. He was a star in the stable of the flamboyant dealer Holly Solomon, for whom he made not only art but occasional apartment dcor (painted dining-room curtains); an adventurous free floater among the worlds of art, fashion and design; and a standout in the 1987 Whitney Biennial, which featured his Black Paintings, an ominously beautiful series of images on pleated, hanging neoprene that is now in the collection of the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Americans Look to Be Conquistadors on Clay
description: The United States Davis Cup team upset Roger Federer and the Swiss on red clay in February. The Americans upset Jo-Wilfried Tsonga and the French on red clay in April.

title: Reaction to Libya Attack Could Color Poll Analysis, and Vice Versa
description: Earlier on Thursday, I suggested that we have now gotten some pretty good guidance on the size of President Obamas convention bounce. For the next week or two, most of our attention will be focused on how much of that bounce he maintains  and how it translates into swing states  and not on trying to gauge its magnitude.

title: Diplomats Pulled 2 Ways, Between High Walls and Open Doors
description: Security breaches at American diplomatic compounds in the Middle East this week highlight the two competing challenges that United States diplomats confront: keeping safe in a world full of anti-American extremism and interacting with foreign populations outside the towering walls of government installations overseas.

title: Why These Kids Get a Free Ride to College
description: Wings Stadium, a dim, beery sports barn in Kalamazoo, Mich., is an appropriate home for the K-Wings minor-league hockey team and the Killamazoo Derby Darlins.
