Yet every year, in June, the site hosts a spectacle more uplifting than a season of flip checks. This is when it is the setting for the graduations of the citys two main high schools. A couple of nights after Kalamazoo Central High fills the arena, its Loy Norrixs turn. The rink is covered, and students, friends and family take over most of the 5,100 seats.

title: TimesCast Politics: The Response to the Libyan Attack
description: Reuters

title: N.H.T.S.A. Releases Crash-Test List for 2013
description: 3:54 p.m. | Updated

title: In Toronto a Number of Films Find Homes
description: The Toronto International Film Festival is wrapping up with a spate of sales. Lionsgate and Roadside Attractions bought Joss Whedons adaptation of Much Ado About Nothing, which played well with Buffy fans at the festival. Shot in black-and-white in just 12 days, it has a modern tone (and a cast full of Whedon favorites, from Angel, Dollhouse and Firefly).

title: Hitting Hard Off the Field
description: William C. Rhoden hopes more professional athletes follow the lead of the Ravens' Brendon Ayanbadejo and the Vikings' Chris Kluwe when it comes to social issues.

title: Britains National Theater To Open New York Office
description: Following the financial and critical success of their London-to-Broadway productions of War Horse and One Man, Two Guvnors, executives at the National Theater of Great Britain announced on Thursday that they are opening their first office in New York next month to oversee future shows and deepen relationships with theaters and donors in the United States. While no new National shows are in the immediate offing for Broadway, the executives said, the new office is poised to make the National even more of a force in American theater than it already is.

title: Dear FloFab: Black Tie and Paper Plates
description: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: Ralph Lauren: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Video: Hitting Hard Off the Field
description: William C. Rhoden hopes more professional athletes follow the lead of the Ravens Brendon Ayanbadejo and the Vikings Chris Kluwe when it comes to social issues.

title: On the Trail in Colorado, Obama Tries Balancing Campaigning With Mideast Events
description: GOLDEN, Colo.  President Obama spent the second day of what was to be an upbeat swing through the politically vital Mountain West on Thursday balancing the somber tone that a foreign policy crisis demands and the hyper-partisan rhetoric that eight thousand Coloradoans came to hear.

title: Would You Take a Pregnancy Test in a Bar?
description: If you make a beeline to the stalls, you might miss the pregnancy test dispenser fastened to a wall in the womens restroom of Pub 500 in Mankato, Minn. There, with the swipe of a credit card, for a $3 fee, you can use a nearby toilet and learn whether you may proceed in good conscience with the martini you were about to order.

title: This City Confused Me
description: Even after 36 hours, we still couldnt figure out Managuas unconventional addresses. Readers tell us which cities they find most confusing.

title: Primary Day in New York
description: The results of some New York State primary races could have national implications.

title: A Warning on Bank Complexity, From Someone Who Would Know
description: Its still the talk of Wall Street: Are big banks too complex? And if so, what should be done?

title: The Truth Is Out Today, but We Begin Looking for Justice Tomorrow
description: LONDON  The most shocking experience imaginable in a sports venue is to witness the suffocation to death of 96 fans  men, women and children  in the stadium.

title: Week 2 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
description: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy.

title: 4 Years After Lehmans Demise, Regulators Debate Overhaul
description: Four years after Wall Street teetered on the brink of collapse, regulators are struggling to rein in foreign risk-taking that imperils American banks.

title: On Our Radar: Putins Wildlife Exploits
description: Russias president, Vladimir V. Putin, acknowledges that many of his outdoor adventures with wildlife have been carefully staged. For example, a tiger he was shown shooting in the wild with a tranquilizer gun was apparently a captive one that had been transported to the scene. [Reuters]

title: Profile in Style | Ulrika Lundgren
description: Whether shes designing her rock n roll-romantic fashion label, Rika, decorating the Amsterdam apartment she shares with her family or choosing art for the walls of Maison Rika, her tiny canal-side guesthouse, this Swedish-born, Netherlands-based tastemaker stays true to her roots  for the most part. Im super-Scandinavian in my style, she says, but because I havent lived there for so long, Im influenced by other cultures and the places I go, like London, Paris, Mexico, Mallorca and Bali. A common visual vein that runs through all of Lundgrens work is her signature palette: black and cream punctuated by jolts of primary color in the form of art and accessories. My interiors, like my clothes and bags, are quite urban, she says. But I dont like coldness, so I soften the edges and add warmth. More

title: Dusting Off a Horseman for New Battles
description: The Great Hall at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is such a busy place that its easy to miss the artworks periodically on view there. Two 1967-68 silk-screens of Warhols Flowers  a teaser to Regarding Warhol: Sixty Artists, Fifty Years, opening on Tuesday  were recently hung on the eastern side of the hall. A colossal statue of a pharaoh, weighing about nine tons, sits regally on the north side.

title: Defending Conscience, Restricting Rights
description: Having lost the fight over Dont Ask, Dont Tellrepealed a year ago this month Senators James Inhofe of Oklahoma and Roger Wicker of Mississippi are trying to make it as hard as possible for gay men and lesbians to exercise their civil rights while serving their country in the armed forces.

title: The Cost of Adapters Adds Up
description: In my post about the new iPhone 5, I grumbled about the new power/sync connector, which doesnt fit any of the millions of existing cords, docks, speakers and accessories. Unless, that is, you buy an insanely overpriced $30 plug adapter or a $40 cable adapter from Apple.

title: A Tax Tactic Thats Open to Question
description: Anyone may arrange his affairs so that his taxes shall be as low as possible; he is not bound to choose that pattern which best pays the treasury. There is not even a patriotic duty to increase ones taxes.

title: The New York Finale at Calvin Klein
description: Francisco Costa brought the New York collections to a close this afternoon with a Calvin Klein collection that showed a new take on the geometric black-and-white graphics that have been all over the runways in the form of stripes, grids and checks.

title: Video: Primary Day in New York State
description: Thursday was Primary Day in New York, and some state legislative and judicial races were on the ballot. Though primaries tend to attract a small number of races, some of the days races could have national implications.

title: Protests Spread as Anger Over Anti-Islam Film Mounts
description: Protests spread across the Middle East and North Africa on Thursday, most of them directed at American Embassies and offices linked to United States diplomatic activities, as anger mounted over a video denigrating the Prophet Muhammad.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Ralph Lauren
description: The Look: South American Aristocrat.

title: Suspect Sought in Rape of Occupy Wall Street Protester Near South Street Seaport
description: The police released a photo on Thursday of a man wanted for raping a woman and throwing her over a second-story railing near the South Street Seaport on Monday, breaking her pelvis.

title: A New Kind of Monkey, With Colors That Set It Apart
description: Scientists have identified a new species of African monkey whose coloring is unlike anything Ive ever seen, as one of them put it.

title: In Japan, a Birds-Eye View
description: The Tokyo design studio Nendo has created a treehouse for the Ando Momofuku Center in Japan that is part birdhouse, part human observation deck.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Egypt, Yemen, Syria and Afghanistan.

title: SFJazz Names Artists to Open Its Permanent Home
description: SFJazz, the Bay Area jazz institution which has for nearly 30 years presented concerts and festivals in rented spaces, announced on Thursday the lineup for a series of opening concerts and a wide-ranging full-season schedule in its new permanent space  with concerts by local as well as international artists and educational programming.

title: Mary Weatherford: Manhattan
description: Brennan & Griffin

title: Bloodstains With a Story: The Allure of Artifacts Linked to Famous Crimes
description: A bloodstained tan stocking was unrolled across a Manhattan cafe table the other day. It had belonged to Bonnie Parker, the murderous robber, and was found in her getaway car in 1934 after she and her partner, Clyde Barrow, died in a hail of police bullets.

title: In Chinatown, Martial Arts Alfresco
description: ON a recent Saturday morning, I joined eight kung fu students and their master, David Kaplan, in Chinatown for a lesson in martial arts. It was 8 a.m. and raining, but Mr. Kaplans outdoor classes run six days a week, year-round and without regard for weather.

title: Ruptures: Forms of Public Address
description: 41 Cooper Gallery

title: Penny Slinger: An Exorcism Revisited, 1977-2012
description: Broadway 1602

title: Manhattan Race in Jeopardy as Its Organizer Steps Aside
description: The Coogans five-kilometer race, a fixture on the New York road running scene for more than a decade as it evolved into a neighborhood party in Washington Heights, may have run its course. Peter Walsh, who started the run 14 years ago, has decided to step aside, citing personal reasons and rising race costs.

title: Rising Up, After Its O.K.
description: A banner attached to a lamppost on West 53rd Street outside the Museum of Modern Art has the word REBELLION in capital letters overlapping the MoMA logo, and a dotted line attached to the phrase starts here. It is a bold statement for a museum to make, since rebellious art (and behavior) invariably starts elsewhere and ends up in a museum only after reaching some consensus in the art world.

title: Jesper Just: This Nameless Spectacle
description: James Cohan Gallery

title: Big Movies for Little Kids on Governors Island
description: Cinemagoing highbrows tend to praise Buster Keaton in reverent tones. But the Miser knows from experience that nothing beats seeing Steamboat Bill Jr. while sandwiched between breast-feeding moms and enduring endless potty-break exoduses, all underscored by an aria of teething tantrums and the crunch of Skittles underfoot.

title: Passion for Victory That Knew No Bounds
description: This was back in the spring of 1990, almost a decade before Jim Calhoun won the first of three national championships at Connecticut, the state university in the middle of nowhere that he helped turn into quite the destination on the college basketball map of the United States. Behind the blue curtain that separated the postgame interview area from the locker room pathway, Calhoun was holding court with well-wishers, making a mole hill out of a miracle.

title: Calvin Klein: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Afghanistan Tries to Block Video and Head Off Rioting
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Racing to head off potentially violent demonstrations over an anti-Islamic video, the Afghan government on Thursday pushed Internet providers to shut down access to Web sites hosting the clip, and asked political and religious leaders to urge calm, senior Afghan officials said.

title: Erik Hijweege, a k a Kevin Erskine, the Storm-Chasing Photographer
description: To illustrate Nate Silvers recent article on the state of weather forecasting, we turned to the work of the storm photographer Kevin Erskine, whose haunting pictures of atmospheric disturbances are the subject of his book Supercell, which came out last year. Erskine is the professional pseudonym used by Erik Hijweege, aDutch photographer who was inspired to combine his longstanding interests in storms and landscape photography when he visited the United States seven years agoand met the meteorologist and well-known storm chaser Tim Marshall.

title: Rebirth for Cave Buddhas
description: In the Buddhist way of thinking, all things must pass, though it seems a shame when they do, especially if theyre out-of-this-world beautiful, as so much Chinese Buddhist art is. But could that vision of transience be changing in the 21st century, as technology lets all kinds of things, including art, live on forever out there in digital clouds?

title: Dutch and Germans Give European Union Reasons to Cheer
description: PARIS  There was a general sigh of relief in the European Union this week. The cause was not better performance in the troubled and highly indebted southern countries of the euro zone, but crucial decisions made in the rich northern nations with perfect credit ratings, where skepticism about the common currency is running high.

title: High Flier, Poised for Steep Descent
description: Arbitrage, a sleek entertainment about how very good greed can be, is a fairy tale masquerading as a tragedy. It pivots on Robert Miller (Richard Gere), a shifty hedge-fund manager and 21st-century robber baron whos foxed his way to the top of New Yorks moneyed classes. Charmed and charming, with a quicksilver stride and the self-possession of a man accustomed to hearing the word yes, Robert lives in a rarefied world of private jets, live-in help and seven-figure checks made out to favorite charities. Masterworks adorn his Gramercy Park mansion where a multistory crystal chandelier cascades in the foyer like a waterfall of diamonds.

title: The In-Crowd Is All Here
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has rushed in where museums more experienced in the new and the now might have feared to tread. It is highlighting its growing commitment to contemporary art with an examination of the immense, amorphous influence of one of the most important artists of the 20th century: Andy Warhol, the visionary Pop Art painter, innovative filmmaker, trenchant social observer, image thief, deadpan quotation machine, boho magazine publisher and forthright gay artist about town. This effort is not an encouraging sight, but then the Met has a long way to go where contemporary art is concerned.

title: The Daily Shoe | Calvin Klein
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: How Much Would Free College Cost for All New Yorkers?
description: In the magazines Education Issue, I write about the Kalamazoo Promise, a scholarship program that gives a full ride to all students who graduate from Kalamazoo public schools and go to college in Michigan. To replicate the program in New York City, to cover the college tuition of all 52,000 students who graduate from the nations largest school system every year, an endowment of something like $20 billion would be needed, according to Keith Luke, at the Connecticut-based Commonfund, which manages $25 billion in assets for nonprofit institutions. Such an endowment, he says, would provide for annual tuition payments of $5,000 for each student for four years, growing annually at the rate of inflation for higher education. Forbes magazine estimates that 57 billionaires live in the city. Mayor Bloomberg himself has donated more than $2.4 billion to favorite causes, and in 2013 Columbia University will finish a $5 billion fund-raising campaign, bringing in $1 billion more than its initial goal. So the money for a New York Promise is probably out there, but it would require one of the worlds biggest philanthropic efforts.

title: A Trip With Beyonce or on Hair Force One? You Decide.
description: First came the e-mail from Beyonc Knowles: want to fly to New York to hang out with her and President Obama?

title: Overdue Links
description: To start off, heres a little roundup of stories contradicting that Stanford study discrediting organics:

title: Fashion Week Stargazing: Day 8
description: Orange juice, iced coffee and tiny, tiny chocolate cake. The breakfast of fashion champions. That was the menu, served by waiters on silver trays, for the 9 a.m. Giulietta presentation at the Classic Car Club on Hudson Street, where J. Crews Jenna Lyons made rolling out of bed look sassy: the president and creative director sported mussed hair, a white shirt and navy pajama pants with white piping. O.K., so the neon orange pumps helped.

title: Off the Runway: Day 8
description: Scenes from the last day of New York Fashion Week.

title: My Eyes Were Heavy, but I Didnt Doze Off During the Show, Mike Francesa Says
description: The sports radio talk show host Mike Francesa  who appeared to take a brief nap while conducting an interview on Monday on WFAN-AM in New York  said on Thursday that while he had been tired from getting no sleep the night before, he had not actually fallen asleep while talking to Sweeny Murti, who covers the Yankees for the station.

title: Met Opera Concerts Set For Le Poisson Rouge
description: The Metropolitan Opera is going downtown. The Met has arranged with Le Poisson Rouge, the high-art cabaret space in Greenwich Village, to present two concerts based on Met productions of two contemporary operas: The Tempest by Thomas Ads and Nico Muhlys Two Boys. The collaboration gives the Met some visibility in the slightly hipper, younger and more contemporary music scene, and adds big-institution luster to Le Poisson Rouge, which has become firmly established as a New York concert site. The Met often collaborates with major institutions like Juilliard, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art but rarely with such a small fish. It seemed like a good idea, as a way of educating the audience and reaching out to a new audience, to have performances down there, Peter Gelb, the Mets general manager, said. Mr. Gelb said the first performance, on Oct. 26, would involve a few cast members of The Tempest and Mr. Ads as pianist performing scaled-down numbers from the opera. The concert will include works by Ives, Purcell, Stravinsky and Tippett, with other instrumentalists joining in, a spokesman later added. Mr. Muhly will play and program the second concert in May. Mr. Gelb said the Met was paying for the performances and would split the ticket take with Le Poisson Rouge.

title: A Convention Bounce for the Boss
description: Bruce Springsteen did not perform at the Democratic National Convention, but he is still enjoying a convention bounce.

title: Striving for New Standards, Just the Way They Are
description: If you pay little attention to the insular world of musical theater, you might not know that the 42-year-old singer, composer and playwright Jason Robert Brown is the Billy Joel of his generation. The heartfelt outpourings of this brainy, driven, hypersensitive, self-conscious introvert deserve to be standards, but still arent.

title: Life After Bankruptcy
description: EVERY month tens of thousands of people file for federal bankruptcy protection, mostly to wipe out debts and start anew.

title: Both Versions of Romney Critique Should Have Remained on Web
description: Its standard practice for news organizations to change breaking news stories as more information comes in. You start with what you know at, say, 6 p.m., and add to it, change it, refine it as the night goes on.

title: Lets Put on a Circus, and Lets Put It on Outdoors
Going Back to His Old School, Where Ties Wind Up Binding
description: The slick, feel-good Liberal Arts has enough dark notes to make the smug, obsequious performance of its star, Josh Radnor, who also wrote and directed, tolerable and at times even likable. As an actor and filmmaker, Mr. Radnor, of How I Met Your Mother, is steeped in sitcom conventions.

title: Whatever Happened to the Fourth Footman?
description: CANT wait until the new season of Downton Abbey starts in January? Well, then, how about the New York version, starring James Silvia, who in the 1950s served Alexander H. Rice as fourth footman in his Newport, R.I., mansion and New York town house at Fifth Avenue and at 71st Street. Now retired from a career of teaching in Manhattan, Mr. Silvia, the son of a Portuguese gardener who worked on the estates of Newport, has a unique perspective on servant life on the American continent.

title: Argentines Turn Cash Into Condos in Miami
description: MIAMI

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Google Glasses Movie and iPhone Fatigue
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Birds of a Feather: A Boy and Flamingos
description: Felix is an untrustworthy narrator. But really, when it comes to recounting our pasts, arent we all?

title: Searching the Soul of a Soulful Singer
description: Writing about a living subject, Sylvie Simmons says, means having to immerse yourself in that persons life to a degree that would probably get you locked up in any decent society. It can also mean abandoning all hope of objectivity. But despite her simpatico feel for the life and work of her subject, Ms. Simmonss Im Your Man is the major, soul-searching biography that Leonard Cohen deserves.

title: Sid Watkins, Formula One Safety Pioneer, Dies at 84
description: His reputation, his status, his influence were as big and important as any world-champion driver in Formula One. But the number of drivers lives he was directly responsible for saving made him even bigger. Yet probably nothing was quite as impressive as his humanity.

title: Comedy Listings for Sept. 14-20
description: Comedy

title: What You Need to Know About Thousands of Pages of UVA E-Mails
description: The story of Teresa Sullivans resignation and reinstatement as president of the University of Virginia  which I wrote about for the cover article in the Education Issue  would have been a campus drama under any circumstances, but it probably would not have become a national news story if not for Virginias open-records laws, which have allowed news organizations an unusually complete view into the e-mail accounts of the major participants. The first batch of e-mails, obtained by the student-run Cavalier Daily in the midst of the leadership crisis, provided the tantalizing glimpses into what had been, up to that point, a decision shrouded in secrecy. While they didnt provide definitive answers, the e-mails provided more than enough breadcrumbs to feed reporters, as well as conspiracy theorists who followed every stray reference, sometimes to questionable conclusions.

title: Movie Listings for Sept. 14-20
description: Movies

title: Manhattan, Elusive by Land, Comes Into Focus by Sea
description: Manhattan has one of the most recognizable faces in the world. Yet it can be strangely elusive, even Garboesque. The buildings are too tall and too close together to see in their entirety from the ground, so New Yorkers who want to get a good look at the skyline have to go to the movies, visit a prime viewing spot like the Brooklyn Heights Promenade or look out an airplane window.

title: Uneasy Allies in the Grocery Aisle
description: Giant bioengineering companies like Monsanto and DuPont are spending millions of dollars to fight a California ballot initiative aimed at requiring the labeling of genetically modified foods. That surprises no one, least of all the proponents of the law, which if approved by voters would become the first of its kind in the nation.

title: Pop Listings for Sept. 14-20
description: Pop

title: Clip: 'Brooklyn Brothers Beat the Best'
description: A performance scene from the comedy Brooklyn Brothers Beat the Best, featuring Ryan ONan and Michael Weston.

title: Madrigals, Tripe and Other Treats
description: Venice in the early 17th century was home to a heady mix of high and low culture. The city opened the doors to the first public opera house in 1637, making this new art form, the plaything of princes, more accessible. The plazas were alive with commedia dellarte troupes. Citizens could hear lofty tragic operas, sensual madrigals exploring the pangs of desire and bawdy street songs. Venetian composers drew from every genre.

title: Jazz Listings for Sept. 14-20
description: Jazz

title: Theater Listings for Sept. 14-20
description: Theater

title: Reversing Time to Honor Guthrie and Other Heroes
description: Tuesday being the anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks on top of the continuing Woody Guthrie centennial, the opening-night performance of Judy Collinss sixth season at Caf Carlyle had a ceremonial sense of occasion. As she delivered a stirring rendition of her anthem Kingdom Come, a tribute to New York City firefighters killed in the World Trade Center, my mind flashed back to the day of the tragedy on a similarly clear and mild September morning.

title: Classical Music and Opera Listings for Sept. 14-20
description: Classical

title: Riding High on Hatfield and McCoys, A&E Gives Dubuc a New Deal
description: The A&E Networks announced a new deal on Thursday for a woman who has become one of the most important programming executives in cable television, Nancy Dubuc.

title: Why the iPhone 5 on Verizon and Sprint Wont Juggle Calls and Data
description: A lot has changed in Apples new iPhone. But with the Verizon Wireless and Sprint versions of the iPhone 5, theres something that will remain the same from the old model: The phone still wont be able to place a call and handle data activity over the cellular network at the same time.

title: Dance Listings for Sept. 14-20
description: Dance

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Sept. 14-20
description: Art

title: The Heart of Darkness To the Soul of Defiance
description: Like so many dances Nora Chipaumires Miriam begins in darkness, so that you hear the actions onstage before you see them. Viewers dutifully sit, letting these aural mysteries wash over them, waiting for a fuller picture to emerge.

title: Spare Times Listings for Sept. 14-20
description: Around Town

title: Droll and Exaggerated, Murderous and Strange (In a Family Sort of Way)
description: A Guide to Kinship and Maybe Magic, by the choreographer Isabel Lewis, is billed as a production of Lewis Forever, the artistic collective that Ms. Lewis formed a few years back with her globe-scattered siblings  Sarah, Ligia and George Jr. But during the shows debut at Dance New Amsterdam on Wednesday, the only Lewis onstage was a decoy.

title: A Womans Place
description: The End of Men? This is not a title; it is a sound bite. But Hanna Rosin means it. The revolution feminists have been waiting for, she says, is happening now, before our very eyes. Men are losing their grip, patriarchy is crumbling and we are reaching the end of 200,000 years of human history and the beginning of a new era in which women  and womanly skills and traits  are on the rise. Women around the world, she reports, are increasingly dominant in work, education, households; even in love and marriage. The stubborn fact that in most countries women remain underrepresented in the higher precincts of power and still dont get equal pay for equal work seems to her a quaint holdover, the last artifacts of a vanishing age rather than a permanent configuration.

title: A Different View on the Waterfront
description: Getting a good look at Manhattans skyline can be difficult from the ground.

title: Spare Times for Children for Sept. 14-20
description: GO FISH

title: High School Is Over, but the Angst Is Not
description: It takes a while to sort out whos who in the gabby high school reunion comedy 10 Years. But once you do, the movie that comes together is an unpretentious, well-acted ensemble piece that doesnt aspire to be a portentous generational time capsule like The Big Chill, American Graffiti or Diner. But it has enough markers  a grown-up, married white rapper who break dances; a karaoke bar  to suggest an approximate date.

title: Regarding Warhol
description: Images from a new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Jeter Says He Feels Great, but Does He?
description: BOSTON  Derek Jeter is, in the eyes of his manager, difficult to read. So when he arrived at Fenway Park on Thursday and told Joe Girardi than his left ankle felt great, Girardi had to interpret what this actually meant.

title: Making a Case for Same-Sex Marriage
description: The kids are adorable, their two dads effortlessly likable and the love that binds them all inarguable. Yet Cassie Jayes squishy documentary, The Right to Love: An American Family, tries the patience, and not just because of its regrettably saccharine soundtrack. Any film this committed to arguing in favor of same-sex marriage needs at least as much spine as heart.

title: Searching U.S. Colleges, Doubt Creeps In Amid the Confidence
description: Nothing can quite convey the roller coaster of emotions of applying to college  bewilderment, elation, dejection, hope, fear  as powerfully as the voices of the applicants themselves. And so, as in years past, The Choice blog has selected eight high school seniors to tell their stories throughout the new school year as part of the latest installment of a first-person series we call The Envelope, Please.

title: Sweet 16 ... and a Runway Model
A Changing Landscape
description: While gold and copper mining have made Mongolia the worlds fastest-growing economy, they have also created some health and environmental problems in boom towns throughout the Gobi Desert.

title: Though Not Yet Open, a Huge Mine Is Transforming Mongolias Landscape
description: KHANBOGD, Mongolia  In the dry expanses of southern Mongolia, a handful of large blue buildings are clustered together, ringed only by a thin metal fence. A single plane sits on an airstrip, while power lines stretch off into the distance. They, along with the scattered flocks of sheep and goats, are almost the only things dotting the vast landscape.

title: Microsoft Finds PCs That Ship Pre-Infected
description: One more thing to worry about: Your brand-spanking-new computer could be infected with a virus that will raid your online bank account.

title: A Makeover on 34th St., but Not All Believe in It
description: Macys is giving itself a $400 million makeover that it says will maintain the stores architectural integrity, but one preservationist, Theodore Grunewald, is not happy.

title: Rebels With Fishing Poles
description: I dont detect an overload of films documenting the World War II-era internment of Japanese-Americans, even though the political, social and cultural history clearly is significant enough to warrant more interest. An artifact in the new documentary The Manzanar Fishing Club makes that case: a badge reading, Jap Hunting License  Open Season.

title: A Former No. 1 Calls It a Career
description: Juan Carlos Ferrero of Spain announced Wednesday that the ATP Valencia Open would be the final tournament of his career, ending a 14-year run in which he won a Grand Slam title and reached the No. 1 ranking in the time just before the tour takeover by Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal.

title: An Expiring Tax Credit Threatens the Wind Power Industry
description: When Brad Sawyer graduates next spring from Texas State Technical College in Sweetwater, he hopes to get a job as a wind turbine technician, working on the towering three-bladed machines that dot the West Texas countryside.

title: Panetta Set to Discuss U.S. Shift in Asia Trip
description: WASHINGTON  When Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta travels across Asia next week, on an arc from Japan and China to New Zealand, he will face two almost contradictory challenges.

title: Food Artistry, Served Family Style
description: If Step Up to the Plate were fiction, its players would deserve an award for best ensemble performance. But as this calmly intelligent film from Paul Lacoste is a documentary, the focal figures  the renowned chef Michel Bras and his son Sbastien, now leader of his fathers restaurant  should win acclaim as committed, heart-driven artists best appreciated in relation to each other.

title: Texas Law to Protect Student Athletes With Concussions Takes Effect
description: As public school athletic programs adjust to a new state law on how to respond when student athletes get concussions on the field, doctors and legislators say the health of the players will benefit.

title: For Slain Contractor, a Life of Risks Overseas
description: BOSTON  For Glen A. Doherty, being assigned to a high-stakes security detail in Libya was just one of over a decades worth of adventurous overseas missions he had participated in as a security contractor and a member of the Navy SEALs.

title: What Libya Lost
description: ON Wednesday morning, my colleagues and I were to meet in Benghazi with J. Christopher Stevens, the American ambassador to Libya, to discuss a plan for a new division of emergency medicine at Benghazi Medical Center, the largest and most modern hospital in eastern Libya. The meeting never took place. The night before, militants laid siege to the American Consulate in Benghazi, killing the ambassador and three other Americans. The ambassador was taken, without a pulse, to the hospital we hoped to upgrade.

title: Our Diplomats Deserve Better
description: Falls Church, Va.

title: Americas Health Worker Mismatch
description: Washington

title: Obesity and Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Inhumane Factories
description: To the Editor:

title: The Mideast and the Campaign, Roiled
description: To the Editor:

title: Off-Script Scramble for Power in a Chinese Leaders Absence
description: BEIJING  With still no sign of Chinas designated new leader, Xi Jinping, who has not been seen in public since Sept. 1, many insiders and well-connected analysts say the Chinese political ship is adrift, with factions jockeying to shape an impending Communist Party conclave.

title: Photos of The Moment | Calvin Klein
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The iPhone Stimulus
description: Are you, or is someone you know, a gadget freak? If so, you doubtless know that Wednesday was iPhone 5 day, the day Apple unveiled its latest way for people to avoid actually speaking to or even looking at whoever theyre with.

title: In Central Park, a Birders Secluded Haven Comes With a Dark Side
description: The Ramble in Central Park has long been known as a place where people prowl for anonymous sexual encounters. They are drawn by the cloak of dense vegetation, serpentine paths, giant boulders and meandering streams created by the parks designer, Frederick Law Olmsted.

title: Trial to Begin for Former UBS Trader Accused of Hiding Huge Loss
description: LONDON  UBS will face the harsh glare of the spotlight again on Friday, as opening arguments begin in the trial of a former trader accused of hiding a multibillion-dollar loss at the investment bank.

title: GTT
description: QUITAQUE

title: Warren Ad Paints Her as a Fighter, and Throws a Punch
description: BOSTON  Elizabeth Warren is throwing the first punch in the ad wars in the increasingly bitter Massachusetts Senate race, with a new television commercial on Thursday that accuses Senator Scott P. Brown, her Republican opponent, of siding with the big-money guys.

title: At Euphoric Louisiana-Monroe, Coach Isnt Ready to Smile
description: The day after perhaps the biggest victory in the history of Louisiana-Monroes football program  an overtime win against then-No. 8 Arkansas last Saturday  Coach Todd Berry was already wishing his team would forget about the thousands of fans who had greeted its return to campus at 2 a.m. He hoped the players would remember they had arrived not by plane, but by bus.

title: Drifter Known for Menace Is Charged With Raping Woman, 73, in Central Park
description: A drifter who hailed from the South and spent most of his adult life in and out of prison on a grab bag of felonies, including kidnapping and abduction, was arrested on Thursday and charged with the rape, beating and robbery of a 73-year-old woman in Central Park.

title: Facts, Arguments and Politics
description: Emotions drive politics. So why all the concern about facts and fact-checking? Because, among the whirl of our feelings, there is a desire for our beliefs to be rational, to have support from the facts. Were uneasy if we cant make a plausible case that what we say is true. Notice that political campaigns do all they can to undermine the analyses of the fact-checkers who award them Pinocchios. At a minimum, citing the facts is one important rhetorical ploy. I recall hearing of a university administrator who allegedly admitted, Sometimes telling the truth is the best way to get people to do what you want.

title: The Burden of Speech
description: A fanatic makes a hate movie, filled with wild claims about the founder of one of the worlds major religions. Fanatics of another sort are inflamed by the crude film, crying blasphemy.

title: Wright Creeping Closer to Kranepool
description: As the Mets stumble toward the close of another forgettable season, fans are left with two reasons to watch games: R.A. Dickeys pursuit of 20 victories and a possible Cy Young award and David Wrights pursuit of the Mets career hit record.

title: For Those Who Breathe Smoke
description: ON a recent Friday evening, a man walked into Smoking Culture in Greenwich Village, a store whose sign promises to fulfill all your smoking needs, and asked for a pack of Newports.

title: Amid Mideast Turmoil, Aides Say What a President Romney Would Do
description: WASHINGTON  If Mitt Romney were in the Oval Office during this week of turmoil in the Middle East, his foreign policy advisers said on Thursday, he would have already told Iran that he would not allow it to get close to building a bomb, setting a red line in a far different place from President Obamas.

title: A Shift in Energy Ads
description: Presidential and policy ads this year are more likely to promote policies that are friendly to fossil fuels.

title: Orioles Keep Showing Flair for the Dramatic
description: BALTIMORE  When the Baltimore Orioles loaded the bases with no outs in the bottom of the 13th inning of a tied game on Thursday afternoon, only to squander their opportunity, the teams long-deprived fans would have been forgiven for expecting something miserable to immediately follow. And it nearly did, when the Tampa Bay Rays put two men on base in the top of the 14th.

title: In Libya, Chaos Was Followed by Organized Ambush, Official Says
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  The mayhem here that killed four United States diplomatic personnel, including the ambassador, was actually two attacks  the first one spontaneous and the second highly organized and possibly aided by anti-American infiltrators of Libyas young government, a top Libyan security official said Thursday.

title: As Violence Spreads in Arab World, Google Blocks Access to Inflammatory Video
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As violence spread in the Arab world over a video on YouTube ridiculing the Prophet Muhammad, Google, the owner of YouTube, blocked access to it in two of the countries in turmoil, Egypt and Libya, but did not remove the video from its Web site.

title: Lottery Numbers
Prosecutors Seek Hearing in 95 Killing
description: Bronx prosecutors, saying that they cannot yet substantiate claims suggesting that five people were wrongfully convicted in the 1995 murder of a livery-cab driver, are declining to support a request that a court immediately vacate the convictions of two of the defendants.

title: Freed From the Constraints of Plaids and Stripes
description: Far from the madding crowd, far from even Kanye and Kim  now the organically blended Kimye  a small band of design explorers is getting closer to entering a new dimension.

title: Giants Deal With Loss: Assistants Mustache
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Kevin Gilbrides mustache, a legendary lip adornment that won two Super Bowl championships and was respected as one of the most enduring examples of responsible facial hair in sports, died last month in a shaving accident at the Giants practice facility here. It was believed to be about 41.

title: Israeli Fallout
description: It should go without saying, but apparently does not, that the tragic crisis unfolding in the Middle East calls for sober statesmanship rather than political posturing. The jihadist murder of the American ambassador to a newly liberated Libya; the carnage unleashed by the Assad regime on the Syrian people; the emergence of a Muslim Brotherhood regime in Egypt; the conundrum of Iranian nuclear ambitions  the region presents decades worth of complex challenges telescoped into real time.

title: Despite Virus, Visitors Trek to Yosemite, if a Bit Warily
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif.  A stones throw from the cluster of tent cabins where three victims of a deadly rodent-borne virus stayed earlier this summer, two tourists from the New York area were meticulously sorting their trash into sealed garbage bins while making sure that a ravenous-looking squirrel did not slip inside.

title: History Shows Relying on Power Is Not a Weakness
description: BOSTON

title: Spring Trends
description: Eric Wilson reports on the shows and the emerging spring trends that had editors and retailers talking at New York Fashion Week.

title: A Post-9/11 Conundrum
description: For 11 years, Americans have struggled to reach a sensible legal balance that protects both national security and civil liberties  an existential challenge made harder by the last presidents wild excesses and abuses of power in the name of combating terrorism. This week, a vote in Congress and a decision by a federal judge, Katherine Forrest, made starkly clear how much that remains a work in progress.

title: The Photographs of Pedro E. Guerrero
description: Images by and of the photographer, who died on Sept. 13, 2012.

title: Aprs Rahm, Le Dluge
description: Modern nations have two economies, which exist side by side. Economy I is the tradable sector. This includes companies that make goods like planes, steel and pharmaceuticals. These companies face intense global competition and are compelled to constantly innovate and streamline. Theyve spent the last few decades figuring out ways to make more products with fewer workers.

title: Pedro Guerrero, Who Captured Art in Photos, Dies at 95
description: Pedro E. Guerrero, a former art school dropout who showed up in the dusty Arizona driveway of Frank Lloyd Wright in 1939, boldly declared himself a photographer and then spent the next half-century working closely with him, capturing his modernist architecture on film, died on Thursday at his home in Florence, Ariz. He was 95.

title: Spots for Healthy Choice Try to Feel Dieters Pain
description: A NEW commercial for Healthy Choice opens at a supermarket meat counter, where an elegantly dressed woman takes an inelegant bite of a turkey drumstick, then reaches into another shoppers cart for a loaf of French bread, which she breaks over a knee and waves menacingly.

title: Pennsylvanias Broken Machinery of Death
description: Pennsylvania is scheduled to execute Terrance Williams on Oct. 3. The state has sentenced more than 400 people to death since the Supreme Court reinstated capital punishment in 1976 and has executed three who gave up on their appeals. But he would be the first person in 50 years to be put to death there while still fighting his sentence.

title: Belated Response From Egypt
description: The response from President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt to the murder of the American ambassador in Libya and the attacks on the United States Embassy in Cairo should have been swift and unequivocal. Condemn the violence, express condolences for the killings and pledge to strengthen security at foreign missions.

title: The Fed Makes Its Move
description: If the economy falters from here on out, it will be difficult to blame the Federal Reserve. Ben Bernanke, the Fed chairman, and all but one of the other members of the Fed policy committee, took decisive steps on Thursday to spur the economy, pledging to buy $85 billion worth of assets each month until the end of the year and to continue pumping money into the economy until the job market improves substantially.

title: Unclear Future for Airport That Is Seeking a Buyer
description: MONTAUK, N.Y.  The easternmost airport in New York State has things that La Guardia and Kennedy International do not. A beach just beyond the runway, where pilots can work on their tans and swim in the ocean. An outdoor shower, where they can rinse off before they climb back in their cockpits. And a for-sale sign.

title: Howard Moody, Who Led a Historic Church, Dies at 91
description: The Rev. Howard R. Moody the longtime minister of the historic Judson Memorial Church, who hurled himself and his Greenwich Village congregation into roiling social issues, at one point helping women from around the nation get illegal abortions, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 91.

title: Washington to Get Bronze Representative in Capitol
description: WASHINGTON  Perhaps nowhere in America do the people of the District of Columbia feel less respected than in the District of Columbia. Their lone delegate to the House must sit, seething, as Congress approves the Districts annual budget, absent the vote of that delegate, who is prohibited from voting in the House.

title: Cynthia Rowley: Spring 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Stick By the Water
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Nicely done, Peter Collins. This is a fresh, crunchy, struggle-to-get-a-toehold grid, but if you hang in there, you will be rewarded with a hefty group of new and interesting entries and some great wordplay in the clues.

title: Court Approves Schedule for Florida Early Voting
description: MIAMI  The Department of Justice has approved Floridas early voting schedule for the five counties in the state protected by a civil rights-era law, all but clearing the last significant conflict in the path of November balloting.

title: Egypt, Hearing From Obama, Moves to Heal Rift From Protests
description: CAIRO  Following a blunt phone call from President Obama, Egyptian leaders scrambled Thursday to try to repair the countrys alliance with Washington, tacitly acknowledging that they erred in their response to the attack on the United States Embassy by seeking to first appease anti-American domestic opinion without offering a robust condemnation of the violence.

title: House Republicans Welcome Back Ryan, and His Vote, on a Spending Measure
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, returned to the House on Thursday for a heros welcome from adoring Republicans, jeers from opposition Democrats and a mission that was as painful as it was politically necessary: to give his blessing to legislation financing the government into next year at a level higher than the one set in his own budget.

title: Internal Affairs to Investigate Officers Stabbing
description: The New York Police Department has opened an internal affairs investigation into a police officer who reported that he had been stabbed by an intruder on Wednesday, Paul J. Browne, the departments chief spokesman said. The move seemed to cast doubt on the officers story.

title: Bodyboarding World Circuit Qualifier
description: The day in sports included an international bodyboarding competition in Rio de Janeiro.

title: Jets Revis Is Pedaling but Stuck in Place
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Three days before what is shaping up as a tough test for the Jets defense, cornerback Darrelle Revis got to do calisthenics Thursday with the team. But he was not wearing his shoulder pads and did not have his helmet with him.

title: Events Abroad Take Bigger Slice of Campaign Debate
description: GOLDEN, Colo.  President Obama and Mitt Romney entered new political terrain on Thursday as their campaign debate moved more solidly onto issues of foreign policy, a subject that had largely been absent as a major general election issue until this week.

title: Fingers Pointed Over Seizure of Occupy Wall St. Library
description: When the police cleared Occupy Wall Street protesters from Zuccotti Park last November, the movement lost not only its central gathering spot, but also one of its more popular institutions: a collection of 3,600 donated books known as the Peoples Library.

title: McGrady Works Out With Knicks
description: Since the start of the off-season, the Knicks have been recruiting veteran free agents, some of them fairly old by N.B.A. standards. The latest to get a look is 33-year-old Tracy McGrady, a seven-time All-Star who is not as old as some of the other players the Knicks have signed but who has had significant injuries during his career.

title: N.H.L. Talks Still Frozen as Words Heat Up
description: The N.H.L. labor dispute remained deadlocked on Thursday with no new negotiations, but the rhetoric certainly got more pointed.

title: Obama Rebuffs Netanyahu on Setting Limits on Irans Nuclear Program
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Tuesday rejected an appeal by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to spell out a specific red line that Iran could not cross in its nuclear program, a senior administration official said, deepening the divide between the allies over how to deal with Irans nuclear ambitions.

title: U.S. Declares a Disaster for Fishery in Northeast
description: BOSTON  The Commerce Department on Thursday issued a formal disaster declaration for the Northeastern commercial groundfish fishery, paving the way for financial relief for the battered industry and the communities that depend on it.

title: Anger Rolls Across Pakistani City in Aftermath of Factory Fire
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  The towering metal door at the back of the burned-out garment factory could have been an escape for many of the low-paid textile workers caught in the fire here on Tuesday. Instead, it stands as a testament to greed and corruption at a factory where 289 trapped employees died.

title: Fossil Fuel Industry Ads Dominate TV Campaign
description: WASHINGTON  When Barack Obama first ran for president, being green was so popular that oil companies like Chevron were boasting about their commitment to renewable energy, and his Republican opponent, John McCain, supported action on global warming.

title: Biden Hammers G.O.P. Tickets Domestic Policies
description: EAU CLAIRE, Wis.  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. told a joke on himself Thursday while campaigning here. Im supposedly an expert on foreign policy, he said. Where I come from, an expert is anyone from out of town with a briefcase.

title: Chinese Ships Enter Japanese-Controlled Waters to Protest Sale of Islands
description: TOKYO  Six Chinese maritime patrol vessels entered Japanese-controlled waters around a group of disputed islands on Friday, the Japanese Coast Guard said, in the first such move by China since the Japanese government announced that it had bought the islands this week.

title: Action (and Inaction) by the Fed
description: A recent history of moves on the economy by the Federal Reserve.

title: Hughes Pitches Well, Jeter Has a Big Hit, and the Yankees Keep Pace
description: BOSTON  The Yankees have stood atop the American League East for three months, in recent days swatting back daily challenges by the Baltimore Orioles to replace them.

title: Born to Be Wild, Aging Bikers Settle for Comfy
description: MOUNT AIRY, N.C.  In his nearly 50 years as an avid motorcyclist, Grady Howard has roared down the tobacco roads of North Carolina and through the mountains of old Kentucky, all with his wife, Barbara, tucked behind him. But with a balky left leg and myriad other maladies, he knew the only way to stay wild was to add a wheel.

title: A Quick Note on the Fed
description: I was airborne until late, so no chance until now to weigh in on the Feds new move. And now I really need to get some sleep to fight off this cold! So just a few points:

title: Primary Results Close for 2 G.O.P. Legislators Who Voted for Same-Sex Marriage
description: Two Republican state senators who provided pivotal votes to legalize same-sex marriage last year fought opponents to a standstill on Thursday in primary races so close that they will be decided only after absentee ballots are counted.

title: Corrections: September 14, 2012
description: NATIONAL

title: Higuan Finds Comfort in Columbus
description: The Columbus Crew locker room had already emptied when Federico Higuan emerged from his ice bath, still visibly irritated with his teams performance in its 2-0 loss to the New England Revolution. After all, it was the first loss Higuan had experienced in the Argentines six games with his new club, ending a streak of four consecutive wins. When the conversation shifted from the match to his first impressions of the ambiance in Major League Soccer, Higuan smiled and said of course there were differences between M.L.S. and Argentinas Primera Divisin.

title: Word of the Day | manifestation
description: manifestation \ma-n-f-sta-shn, -fe-sta-\ noun

title: Brain Implant Improves Thinking in Monkeys, First Such Demonstration in Primates
description: Scientists have designed a brain implant that sharpened decision making and restored lost mental capacity in monkeys, providing the first demonstration in primates of the sort of brain prosthesis that could eventually help people with damage from dementia, strokes or other brain injuries.

title: Missouri: Documents Turned Over in Priests Abuse Case
description: After losing its appeals, the Survivors Network of those Abused by Priests has turned over about 180 documents that were subpoenaed by lawyers for a Roman Catholic priest accused of sexual abuse. The Survivors Network had argued that the documents, mostly e-mails, should remain confidential because they contained information about victims. The organization, the nations largest advocacy group for victims of clergy sexual abuse, was supported by rape crisis centers, news media outlets and several former prosecutors, but the Missouri Supreme Court upheld a judges order to comply. The Survivors Network said it had not yet released all of the subpoenaed documents and was considering its options. Among the documents it withheld were those pertaining to the Rev. Shawn Ratigan, a Kansas City priest who pleaded guilty last month to child pornography charges and is still the target of civil lawsuits. The documents are under a protective order and supposed to be viewed only by the lawyers.

title: Dead or Alive, Voters Will Find Choices Limited at Polling Places
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: A Little R&R for a Hit Man
description: With his ill-fitting puffy coat and curtain of greasy hair, Walter (Jrgen Rissmann), a two-bit German hit man, seems as burned out as any wage slave in a depressed economy. So when a botched assignment in a public restroom necessitates some off-the-grid R&R, he accepts his temporary banishment with customary resignation.

title: Second Thoughts on Marriage
description: Following Meryl Streep and Tommy Lee Jones in Hope Springs in the autumnal romance department  but a tad younger, and with smidgens of My Dinner With Andr and Before Sunrise  are John Shea and Lea Thompson in The Trouble With the Truth, written and directed by Jim Hemphill. The ambition is laudable, the results less so.

title: News Quiz | September 14, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: To Overcome Depression, Go to Kindergarten
description: Commend David Wexler for not going where you expect in The Stand Up, an oaf-in-kiddieland story, or at least not lingering there when he does. Its too bad that he didnt bring a little more creativity to the predictable tale he does fashion, though.

title: China Sets Trial Date for Figure in Scandal
description: BEIJING  A Chinese official at the center of one of the countrys biggest political scandals in years will go on trial on Tuesday, court officials said Friday.

title: This Weeks Movies | Sept. 14, 2012
description: The New York Times critics on "Arbitrage," "The Master" and "Liberal Arts."

title: Governments Rush to Reform Off to a Rocky Start
description: Political leaders across India have condemned the central governments decision to raise diesel prices, and protests are planned around the country.

title: Rising Tension  and Stakes  in Japan-China Island Dispute
description: BEIJING  It has all the ingredients of a future tragedy, peppered with grim farce. A collapsing Japanese ambassador. A noodle soup attack. A nuclear war threat. Music concerts canceled along with tens of thousands of private vacations and major friendship celebrations. An 81-year-old national trauma revived. And underneath all that, the shopping continues. Welcome to Chinese-Japanese relations in 2012.

title: Chinese Ships Enter Japanese-Controlled Waters to Protest Sale of Islands
description: TOKYO  Six Chinese maritime patrol vessels entered Japanese-controlled waters around a group of disputed islands on Friday in the first such move by China since the Japanese government announced that it had bought the islands this week, the Japanese Coast Guard said.

title: Test Yourself | Critical Thinking, Sept. 14, 2012
description: This question was written by Jessica Lahey. It comes from the article Private Sector Role Is at Heart of Campaigns Split on College Costs.

title: Fast-Food Calorie Counting
description: WHAT company will begin posting calorie counts on all its menus next week?WHAT healthy foods will this chain be adding?WHAT are the signs that other major restaurant chains are working to make their menus more healthful?

title: History in the Making
description: By the time you reach your 50s and 60s, youve lived through a good deal of history, although a lot of the time, as it was happening, you may not have realized it would turn into history. For many of my generation, that first memory is of Nov. 22, 1963, when President John F. Kennedy was assassinated. But during the recent memorial tributes to the astronaut Neil Armstrong, I was reminded of an earlier moment. When I was in third grade, in 1961, several classes at our school were led into the one room that had a TV, to watch Americas first manned spaceflight. Alan Shepards entire trip lasted 15 minutes  we watched the whole thing, broadcast live, in black and white. I remember the clapping when we knew he was safe and in particular how excited our usually reserved teachers were. Id forgotten this until I saw the old news clip.

title: Whats Your Favorite 60s or 70s Song?
description: Each Friday were going to ask you to give us your opinion about something or other that has to do with the boomer era. This is definitely not a test. Nor a scientific poll. In some cases it will be a more serious matter, like, What has been the biggest societal change in your lifetime? Other questions will be of absolutely no consequence, like, Name the worst clothing fad not including bell bottoms.

title: The Fragility of Our Superheroes
description: I will miss my family, but especially my dad.

title: Looking Back on the Party Conventions
description: The summer presidential nominating conventions in Tampa, Fla., and Charlotte, N.C., came and went  promises were made, stances were taken, confetti and balloons tumbled from the ceiling. The Republican spectacle was beset by bad weather, and the Democrats made every effort to demonstrate confidence. But the prevailing opinion of the pundits was that the conventions hardly mattered. Did they? Only 53 days remain until voting, and polls continue to show a neck-and-neck race, suggesting an electorate unmoved by all the fanfare.

title: Anti-American Protests Flare Beyond the Mideast
description: Anti-American rage that began this week over a video insult to Islam spread to nearly 20 countries across the Middle East and beyond on Friday, with violent and sometimes deadly protests that convulsed the birthplaces of the Arab Spring revolutions, breached two more United States Embassies and targeted diplomatic properties of Germany and Britain.

title: What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: Every Monday through Thursday we look for Times content we think youll like to create our Student Opinion questions, but on Fridays this fall, well be asking what you found most interesting instead.

title: France and Germany at Odds Over Aiding Spains Economy
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus  A split emerged on Friday between France and Germany over the urgency of supporting the ailing Spanish economy and the scope of banking regulation for euro nations.

title: Questions for Paul Elie, Author of Reinventing Bach
description: In this weeks Riff, 30 Variations and a Microphone, Paul Elie traces the fascinating relationship between the famously performance-averse pianist Glenn Gould, his landmark 1956 recording of Bachs Goldberg variations, and the rise of new recording technologies made it all possible. The essay was adapted from Elies forthcoming book, Reinventing Bach, which interweaves the stories of famous Bach interpreters  Gould, Pablo Casals, Albert Schweitzer and Yo-Yo Ma  as they grappled both with the legacy of Bach and the promise of new technologies. Elie is currently a fellow at Georgetown University, where he works on exploring the relationship of religion to the arts and literature. We spoke to him about his book.

title: Week 2 Matchups: Yards Dont Equal Wins
description: Saints (0-1) at Panthers (0-1)

title: An Advocate for Students With Disabilities Imagines His Ideal College
description: The bus came to an abrupt stop and we were there. I was among a group of 45, high school freshmen at the time, who stepped onto the recently mowed grass in front of the admissions office. We were about to begin our first college tour.

title: The Early Word: In It for the Duration
description: In Todays Times:

title: The Debt of Medical Students
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: Dancing on the Ruins
description: LONDON  Flash floods caused by monsoon rains across Pakistan have recently claimed at least 78 lives, prompting the government to declare a state of emergency in the worst-hit districts of Punjab, a populous province.

title: Chinese Leader Absent
description: Chinas designated new leader, Xi Jinping, has been absent from recent public appearances.

title: Benedict Takes Message of Tolerance to Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Pope Benedict XVI traveled to Lebanon on Friday with a message of tolerance that took on wider resonance as protests over an anti-Muslim video produced in the United States spread to about 20 countries.

title: An Argument Over Wind
description: With the wind industry facing the expiration of a production tax credit at the end of the year, the sectors main trade association is facing off against Exelon, the big power generation company, over whether the tax break should be renewed. Last week, the American Wind Energy Association expelled Exelon as a member because the company opposed a renewal of the credit.

title: Poetrys Cross-Dressing Kingmaker
description: When I asked Stephen Burts parents if they worried about him when he was young, Burts father, Jeff, replied by asking me if I was Jewish. I told him I was. Well, he said, to ask Jewish parents if they were worried about their children  it is a statement of fact! But were we more worried about Stephen than about the other children? The answer is yes. As a boy, Stephen, the eldest of their four sons, was, in his dads words, extremely precocious; his parents reminiscences make him sound lovable but very intense, with interests out of step with other boys his age. His mother, Sandra, told me that in third grade he wrote an essay about a little boy whose mother forced him to go out and play.

title: The Machines Are Taking Over
description: Neil Heffernan was listening to his fiance, Cristina Lindquist, tutor one of her students in mathematics when he had an idea. Heffernan was a graduate student in computer science, and by this point  the summer of 1997  he had been working for two years with researchers at Carnegie Mellon University on developing computer software to help students improve their skills. But he had come to believe that the programs did little to assist their users. They were built on elaborate theories of the student mind  attempts to simulate the learning brain. Then it dawned on him: what was missing from the programs was the interventions teachers made to promote and accelerate learning. Why not model a computer program on a human tutor like Lindquist?

title: How Many Times Can You Tweet the Same Tweet?
description: Im a heavy Twitter user. I love how fast it moves. If you are looking for instant feedback on anything, Twitter is the place to test your content or messaging. Its also the place to get answers to your questions. And its the best listening device on the Internet. You can search for keywords, customers, competition, and industry thought leaders and find out what everyone is thinking. And no one even knows you are listening.

title: Poll: Obama Holds Narrow Edge Over Romney
description: President Obama holds a narrow three-point advantage over Mitt Romney among Americans most likely to vote in November, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Daily Report: Google Blocks Access to Inflammatory Video
description: As violence spread in the Arab world over a video on YouTube ridiculing the Prophet Muhammad, Google, the owner of YouTube, blocked access to it in two of the countries in turmoil, Egypt and Libya, but did not remove the video from its Web site, reports Claire Cain Miller on Friday in The New York Times.

title: Q&A: Undoing AutoFormats in Microsoft Word
description: Q.

title: Sept. 13: After Convention Bounce, Holding Obamas Polls to a Higher Standard
description: On Thursday at 6:30 p.m. Eastern time, there was a deluge of comments in my Twitter feed when NBC News and Marist University released poll results showing President Obama with clear leads in three swing states. Mr. Obama led by five points in their polls of Virginia and Florida, and by seven in their poll of Ohio.

title: App Smart Extra: More Nostalgia
description: This weeks App Smart column took you into the wonderful world of retro apps  apps that give you a bit of a blast from your past by emulating things from yesteryear.

title: Answers to Your Questions About Student Loans, Part 3
description: This week, two New York Times reporters and Geoffry Walsh, an expert on student debt and bankruptcy at the National Consumer Law Center, are answering questions about ways to avoid default, pay off student loans or try to expunge student loans through bankruptcy court. Along with questions, some readers proposed their own answers. The first set of answers is here, the second is here, and the third set is below.

title: Friday Reading: Would You Take a Pregnancy Test in a Bar?
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: The Tricycle-Harley-Tricycle Cycle
description: Boomers love their bikes. First it was those little red tricycles with the fringe hanging from the handle grips. Then the 18-inchers with the training wheels. Then the banana seats and the baseball cards attached to the back wheel to making a flapping noise. Then the cruisers, with their thick tires, the Raleighs with the hand brakes and the racing bikes with the handlebars bent down.

title: Chicago Forges Outline to End Teacher Strike
description: CHICAGO  Five days into a teachers strike that halted classes for 350,000 public school students across this city, leaders on both sides of the contract dispute said on Friday that they had reached the outlines of a deal.

description: TOP STORIES

title: National Archives in New York to Move to Custom House
description: The National Archives and Records Administration  is to move its New York facility to a new site in late October: the Alexander Hamilton United States Custom House at 1 Bowling Green in Lower Manhattan. The move will provide greater visibility for the institution and make its holdings more accessible to the public,archive officials said.

title: Energy Takes Center Stage in Political Ads
description: The energy industry is pouring money into election commercials aimed at ousting President Obama. The clean energy sector is running a countercampaign, but with far less money.

title: Energy Policy in France Divides Governing Coalition of Socialists and Greens
description: PARIS  After just four months in power, the governing coalition of the Socialist Party and the Greens is already marred by deep ideological divisions over energy policy, in particular how quickly and sharply France should move to reduce its heavy dependence on nuclear energy.

title: India Opens Door to Foreign Investment
description: India ushered in the biggest economic reforms in two decades on Friday, allowing big foreign retailers like Walmart, foreign broadcasters and foreign airlines to invest in the country, among other reforms.

title: Lawmaker Who Defied Putin Is Expelled by Colleagues
description: MOSCOW  Russias Parliament on Friday took the rare step of expelling one of its members, a four-term lawmaker and former K.G.B. officer who last year crossed a political line in the sand, joining crowds calling for Vladimir V. Putin to give up power.

title: Bailed Out by Obama, but Rooting for Romney
description: If theres anywhere President Obama should expect to get a boost from the success of the governments rescue of General Motors, its Wentzville, Mo., and Lordstown, Ohio.

title: Healthy Food, Clear Labels
description: Business Day Live: Food companies, even those that make healthy products, fight consumers in California over a ballot initiative to label products with genetically modified ingredients.

title: What Were Reading
description: Details: Its like a sad bachelors life threw up on itself. Keith Wagstaff takes a look at Guy Fieris globe-scouring new Times Square menu.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Topless Royal Photos Expose Publics Bottomless Fascination
description: LONDON  The European media were all aflutter on Friday as a French magazine published topless photos of Kate Middleton, the Duchess of Cambridge, wife of Britains Prince William and the future Queen of England.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: USA Tomorrow? And an Anti-Muslim Video Vexes YouTube
description: A redesigned USA Today was on newsstands on Friday, and the redesign owes a big debt to the aesthetics and customs of the Internet, Christine Haughney reports. The USA Today Web site, which will be unveiled this weekend, has been redesigned to resemble an e-reader, with a smoother scroll from page to page. The twist, however, is that the abundance of information on the Internet has largely taken away what made the national newspaper special 30 years ago. The moves are part of a broader rethinking by USA Todays parent company, Gannett, to consolidate the news gathering of its TV and newspaper assets.
