title: Need Ryan Goslings Bacon Number? Ask Google
description: In a sign of how committed Google is to helping people answer their most pressing and urgent questions, the search engine has unveiled a way to find famous peoples Bacon number.

title: Shock Me if You Can
description: THE morning of The Rite of Spring premiere, on May 29, 1913, at the Thtre des Champs-lyses in Paris, Le Figaro predicted that ballet would deliver a new thrill which will surely raise passionate discussion and leave all true artists with an unforgettable impression. That turned out to be one of the greatest understatements of the new artistic century. The passionate discussion began during the first few bars of the music, as derisive laughter rose from the seats, and soon grew into an uproar that sent Stravinsky fleeing the hall in disgust.

title: Shocker Cools Into a Rite of Passage
description: THE RITE OF SPRING, or Le Sacre du Printemps, Igor Stravinskys historic shocker, a ballet that shows and celebrates a remorseless human sacrifice, will be 100 years old next May. The bandwagon of centennial commemorations is getting an early start on Thursday with the  New York Philharmonic. But in stark contrast to its present-day lionization, it was a spectacular flop at its first showing, by Sergei Diaghilevs Ballets Russes, at the Thtre des Champs-lyses in Paris.

title: It Was Just Cutlers Luck
description: There are more than a few things that make almost no sense in sports. Normally, wed get right to the most outrageous one, but we need to build up to the proper level of incredulous eye roll for the N.H.L.'s impending lockout. So well start with something simpler, a forehead slapper with universal appeal: that Chicago quarterback Jay Cutler was actually trash-talking in the leadup to Thursday nights game against the Packers.

title: From Ancient Deforestation, a Delta Is Born
description: Humans were tampering with nature long before the Industrial Revolutions steam and internal combustion engines arrived on the scene. The invention of agriculture around 8,000 years ago, some argue, significantly changed ecosystems as it spread around the globe.

title: On the House
description: I recently had a party and afterward had quite a few large bottles of leftover wine (they were opened and wouldnt keep). There is a particular corner in my neighborhood where benign drunkards hang out and drink. They have done so for years, and everyone accepts this as part of our neighborhood. My question is, Should I drop this mother lode of wine off on their perch for them (because who am I to judge their choices?), or pour it down the drain (which would be a waste)? DEAN D., LOS ANGELES

title: Who Made That Marshmallow?
description: A century ago, confectioners made marshmallows from a froth of sugar, starch and gelatin, in a laborious process that involved lots of primping. Each candy had to sweat for several hours to form its delicate skin, and then it was sprinkled with starch. In the 1950s, Alex Doumak  an executive at the Doumak candy company  dreamed up an efficient solution to the problem of the slow marshmallow: he treated the candy goo as an industrial material. Machines forced the marshmallow slurry through tubes, subjected it to blasts of gas at 200 pounds per square inch, extruded it into long tails and then cut it into bite-size chunks. Doumak filled the candy with air, like a tire, trapping nothingness in an architecture of sugar. Extrusion allowed for the marshmallow were used to today  with that springy, fluffy texture, Sue Watson, manager of the company archives at Kraft Foods, says. Kraft began extruding its own marshmallows in the late 1950s, but its most creative touch might have been the space-age name it gave to the factory process  jet-puffed  as if the marshmallows had exploded out of a rocket-ship engine. As part of a 1959 promotion, children sent in empty Kraft marshmallow bags for a chance to own a 29-foot spaceship equipped with astronaut suits, countdown lights and an astro projector for space observation. The modern marshmallow may be mostly air, but its a sweet lesson in less is more.

title: Melissa Leo Is a Fighter
description: Your new film, Francine, is about a woman, fresh out of jail, who seems destined to become one of those people on Hoarders, with a home piled with animal carcasses and feces. What is your own biggest eccentricity?  What you see is what you get.

title: The 9.2.12 Issue
description: WHO WEARS THE PANTS IN THIS ECONOMY?

title: Im With Stupid
description: There they were, my mother and my father, smiling up at me from the third row at my first-ever tap-dance recital. My husband, my teenage daughters and my daughters friend were also in the audience, but it was my parents I was most aware of as I sashayed through my shuffle-ball-changes and cramp rolls. Especially my father, who sat there beaming as if Id just won a Tony Award.

title: Feeling Blue
description: The 17-year-old girl was eating lunch in her high-school cafeteriain the Netherlands when one of her friends gave her a funny look.Your face is turning blue, the friend told her. The others at the table stared. They saw it, too. The young woman hurried to the bathroom, where she saw a faint bluish tinge across her cheeks.

title: Not So Hot for Teacher
description: In his State of the Union address in 2011, President Obama made a point of applauding the nations teachers and exhorted Americans to do the same. In South Korea, Obama reminded us, teachers are known as nation builders. . . . Its time we treated the people who educate our children with the same level of respect.

title: She Makes Sure Actors Step Up to the Plate
description: THE first-time director Robert Lorenz anticipated several challenges with the baseball sequences in Trouble With the Curve, about an aging scout, his daughter and his rivals. Quite a few roles required actors skilled at the game; one character is even described in the movie as a combination of Randy Johnson, Sandy Koufax and Steve Carlton, three of the greatest left-handed pitchers in the sports history.

title: Bookshelf: Woof
description: Picture books starring dogs.

title: Great Drama, but the Stars a Bit Stiff
description: Animal Planet, whose schedule of shows includes fluff like Call of the Wildman and scare fare like Man-Eating Super Croc, isnt anyones first choice for serious nature programs. On Sunday, though, it proves that it can still work that territory with an odd, fascinating special that stars a dead hippopotamus.

title: Bookshelf: Woof
description: BAILEY AT THE MUSEUM  Written and illustrated by Harry Bliss.  32 pp. Scholastic Press. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 6)

title: Protests Continue for a Fourth Day
description: The authorities in much of the Muslim world braced for demonstrations after Friday Prayer  an occasion often associated with public displays of dissent.

title: The Third Musketeer
description: In the 1790s, the son of an aristocratic white father and a black slave woman became a charismatic French general who for a time rivaled Napoleon himself, and afterward languished in an Italian dungeon. His story inspired the novel The Count of Monte Cristo, written by his son, Alexandre Dumas, who also drew upon his fathers adventures in The Three Musketeers. Posterity remembers this son as Dumas pre, to distinguish him from Alexandre Dumas fils, also a writer, whose novel La Dame aux Camlias was the source for Verdis La Traviata. But the general was the first of the three Alexandres (he preferred to be known as Alex), and in The Black Count, Tom Reiss, the author of The Orientalist, has recovered this fascinating story with a richly imaginative biography.

title: The Poisoned Earth
description: On the bookshelves of many a contemporary environmental journalist looms at least one canonical text shes hesitant to read. For this reviewer, it was Rachel Carsons Silent Spring, among the gloomiest books ever written, an unrelenting catalog of crimes committed by man against nature. But after reading William Souders engrossing new biography of Carson, On a Farther Shore, I returned to the book and discovered its central message to be  depressingly  timeless. Substitute organic pesticides and herbicides with the endocrine-disrupting compounds found in everyday household items or the creep of chemicals used in hydrofracking, and you may experience the same hair-prickling alarm felt by Carsons readers 50 years ago.

title: Vile Bodies
description: The Thing About Thugs is an odd confection of a novel, set mostly in what looks like late-Victorian London. The streets are gaslit. The underworld teems with the flotsam of empire: lascars, Irishmen and so on, the undesirables of many nations. The city is overwhelmed with crime and prostitution and an influx of immigrants. Opium dens abound. And a serial killer is on the loose. Known as the head cannibal, he decapitates his victims after murdering them, but the heads are never found. The Metropolitan Police are baffled, as they were by Jack the Ripper, active in 1888, who also desecrated the bodies of his victims. Meanwhile, characters with names like One-Eyed Jack make shady deals in low taverns, and at the dinner tables of the upper classes Darwinian ideas are hotly debated. It feels as if were in the disillusioned twilight of the 19th century, but our narrator  or one of our narrators  sitting in his grandfathers library surrounded by Dickens and Collins, claims that his story is set in 1837, the year Victoria ascended to the throne.

title: California Gothic
description: In her ambitious and much admired 2010 novel The Lotus Eaters (which won the James Tait Black Prize, one of the most prestigious in Britain), Tatjana Soli explored the experiences of a female war photographer who spent nearly a dozen years in Vietnam, and connected her themes and subject matter not only to Alfred Tennyson but to the Odyssey. In her second novel, The Forgetting Tree, she is no less daring, and no less haunting. Soli refuses to do the easy thing  she demands of the reader both patience and trust.

title: The Peeping Savant
description: Some days, all you really want is for someone to tell you a wicked-good story. Linwood Barclay answers the readers perpetual prayer with TRUST YOUR EYES (New American Library, $25.95), an offbeat thriller about a schizophrenic savant who witnesses a murder but is so clearly nuts that no one will take him seriously. In a neat twist on Hitchcocks Rear Window, Thomas Kilbride, who has been crazy about maps since he was 6 years old, is obsessively poring over Whirl360, a computer program rather like Google Street View, when he fixates on the image of someone being suffocated while standing at a window in an apartment building on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. But because he believes the C.I.A. has assigned him the job of committing to photographic memory all the streets in all the major cities of the world, Thomas has a bit of a credibility problem.

title: Benjys Red-Letter Days
description: What happens when you add colored ink to the previous black-and-white type of a William Faulkner classic? Could the technology somehow compromise the readers experience, or do multiple inks actually make for a greater novel? Is this what Faulkner had in mind  and does it matter?

title: A New Effort to Stimulate the Economy
description: Business Day Live  Fed opens new chapter in effort to stimulate the economy. | James B. Stewart on towns that benefited from auto bailout, but are voting for the man who opposed them  Mitt Romney.

title: A Long Lens on Afghanistans Wars
description: We tend to think of the phrase war in Afghanistan mostly in present-day terms. But for Robert Nickelsberg, one of the regions longest-serving photojournalists, the current war is only the latest of four distinct periods of violence hes seen and documented in the country since 1988. On the Lens blog, Richard A. Oppel Jr.  who has been with Mr. Nickelsberg in Afghanistan quite a few times  writes about the photographers new book-length project, A Distant War, that outlines those four ages of war. Mr. Oppel writes:

title: Business Day Live: Bailouts Success Is No Guarantee of Votes
description: Federal Reserve opens new chapter in efforts to stimulate the economy. | Benefiting from the auto bailout, but voting for Mitt Romney.

title: Testing Horrors Threshold for Pain
description: ACTRESSES are asked to do some arduous things in horror films, like running through the woods topless or shrieking until theres no shriek left.

title: For Young Athletes, Good Reasons to Break the Fast-Food Habit
description: When I ran high school cross-country 14 years ago, the bus that took us to meets always stopped at a Wendys or McDonalds after the event. Most of the team would order some variation of burgers, fries and a big soda. It was fast, easy and satisfying.

title: Upstairs, Downstairs
description: Sit back and relax, will you? Naomi Wolf has got her orgasm back. Yep. I know you were worried. We were all worried. I mean, to lose ones orgasm at a time like this, what with Syria undergoing mass civilian murder and Romney closing in on Obama, it is really enough to put a liberated gals thong in a knot.

title: New York Stock Exchange Settles Case Over Early Data Access
description: In the latest federal action against a major exchange, the New York Stock Exchange settled accusations on Friday that its trading data gave select clients a split-second advantage over retail investors.

title: Banana Republican
description: Amid the vast outpouring of literature about Americas banana empire in the Caribbean, no one seems to have written a full-fledged biography of the remarkable Samuel Zemurray, who guided the United Fruit Company through perilous times. Rich Cohen has rectified that oversight. Cohen, the author of Tough Jews: Fathers, Sons, and Gangster Dreams and Sweet and Low: A Family Story, now gives us the fascinating tale of Sam the Banana Man, a poor Russian Jew who emigrated to Alabama as a teenager and ended up controlling much of Central America.

title: Unnatural Women
description: The breast milk of the writer Florence Williams contains a striking level of perchlorate, a key component of rocket fuel. This does not, however, invest her with superpowers, as it might if she were a comic-book hero, or even make her special. Rather, as she explains in Breasts: A Natural and Unnatural History, her mammary glands are no different from those of most American women. In the year 2012, breast-feeding still passes many good things from mother to baby: vitamins, minerals and a solid hedge of extras to help ward off a lifetime of diseases. But the practice also typically transfers paint thinners, dry-cleaning fluids, wood preservatives, toilet deodorizers, cosmetic additives, gasoline by-products, rocket fuel, termite poisons, fungicides and varieties of flame retardants, one of which, Penta-BDE, was banned by the European Union because of its chronic toxicity to humans.

title: Truth in Masquerade
description: Clare Clarks fiction manages to maintain historical accuracy even as it indulges in great storytelling and lush prose. In her first novel, The Great Stink, a thriller that takes place in the sewers of Victorian London, Clark wrote with such rich detail that you could almost smell the fetid air as you turned the pages. In Savage Lands, she transported readers to the young colony of Louisiana in the early 1700s, setting a complex love story against a fecund yet relentlessly cruel landscape that became as important to the plot as the characters themselves.

title: Riding Future and Freudian Frontiers
description: Pursued

title: Introducing an Experiment: Weekly Common Core Practice Prompts
description: Last year we took some baby steps in thinking about how the new Common Core State Standards will affect the work we do on this blog.

title: Unplugged
description: Our brave new quickly expanding technological world has in it less human contact than ever before and less connection with  hence, less caring for  the natural world. Two new picture books explore this (oh, lets call it a) situation. Both contain an important message for young readers, but neither is burdened by it, as so many message-y books have been.

title: Night and Fog
description: What a literary legacy those Victorians left us! Not only are Charles Dickens, H. G. Wells and Charlotte Bront still widely read, but they and their compatriots continue to inspire writers today: steampunk aficionados with their marvelous mechanisms; those who go for Gothic shivers; and the many others who set their narratives in 19th-century England. Among them are writers for young people who, in addition to creating great stories, engage an audience with little knowledge or interest in Victoriana. Two who rise to the challenge this fall are the debut author Stefan Bachmann, a teenager who is studying music at the Zurich Conservatory, and the Newbery Award winner (for Good Masters! Sweet Ladies!) Laura Amy Schlitz.

title: On Mortality
description: To the Editor:

title: The Victims Revolution
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Unpublishable
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Top 5 | American Sexy and the New Surf
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Going to School on Rosh Hashana
description: This year my 15-year old son and I are having yet another conversation about Judaisms High Holy Days. Hes intent on capitalizing on his hard-won victory last year, the outcome of which was that he went to school on the second day of Rosh Hashana. This was no small concession for his parents. His father and I had never attended school on the High Holy Days while living under our parents roofs. But neither of us went to a high school as academically challenging as our sons.

title: Up Front
description: Since this weeks issue assesses an array of feminist ideas and arguments, it made particular sense to commission illustrations from a woman, in this case Kelly Blair, who created the cover image and the three other illustrations that accompany our lead essays (by Toni Bentley and Jennifer Homans).

title: India Lets in Wal-Mart, With Conditions
description: The Indian governments decision Friday to let big department stores like Wal-Mart Stores into the country could dramatically impact everything from the countrys food chain to its roads.

title: Rescue Dogs
description: As any reader of middle-grade novels knows, its a cruel, viciously uncertain world out there, and all too often the adults in a childs life are more a source of harm than help. Sometimes a child can trust no one but the loyal dog at his side. Together, they will survive and conquer.

title: Updates on Protests Over Anti-Islam Film
description: The Lede is following protests across the Muslim world on Friday in response to a film posted on YouTube that mocks Islams prophet.

title: On Our Radar: Temperature Record Is Cast Out
description: A team of meteorologists casts serious doubt on a world temperature record of 136.4 degrees recorded on Sept. 13, 1922 in El Azizia, Libya. They cite the antiquated instrument used, the likelihood that the observer was inexperienced and the wide disparity with subsequent temperatures recorded at the site. That means that officially, the new record surface temperature is 134 degrees, recorded on July 10, 1913 at Greenland Ranch in Death Valley, Calif. [Arizona State University]

title: Date Set for Unleashing of Godzilla
description: Godzilla last lumbered into American movie theaters in 1998 and gobbled up a respectable pile of money  $136 million in domestic ticket sales  while swatting away swarms of nasty reviews with his big scaly C.G.I. paws.

title: Image of the Day: September 14
Lamborghini Recalls 1,500 Gallardos for Fire Hazard
description: Lamborghini is recalling almost 1,500 of its 2004-6 Gallardo Coupe and Spyder models. In a report (PDF) posted recently on the Web site of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Lamborghini outlined a kind of thermochemical conga line of misfortune that could potentially lead to a fire.

title: In Lima, Literary Slams and Music
description: ITS a city with terrible traffic, alarming crime rates and a sky thats gray for eight months a year, said Daniel Alarcn, the 35-year-old author of the novel Lost Radio City, of his birthplace, Lima, Peru.

title: Mexico City for Tamales, Tortas and Tacos
description: ROBERTO SANTIBAEZ drove with me to a bakery in Mexico City called La Espiga expecting to be disappointed. Before leaving the city many years ago, he loved the tamales that a man sold on the sidewalk in front of the bakery, and he was hoping that maybe, just maybe, he could get those same tamales at that spot now.

title: Bookshelf: Harvest
description: Picture books about apples, carrots, potatoes, pumpkins and Johnny Appleseed.

title: Drawn to the Magnet of Chiles Surf Coast
description: I FOUND Pichilemu through a locals tip. In planning an itinerary that would start in Santiago and end a couple of hours south in the wine country, I was looking for a low-key weekend spot near the two destinations where I could stop for a few days and recharge with my family. Well, there is a new hotel in Pichilemu that opened a few weeks back, said a new friend who was born in Chile and travels all over the country. I figured if anyone would know, he would. One look at the Web site and I booked in.

title: Why the iPhone 5 Does Not Have N.F.C.  It Cant
description: Apples iPhone 5 got bigger than its predecessor, and some wonder why the company didnt make room inside for a technology called near-field communications (N.F.C.), which enables devices to exchange information wirelessly over very short distances. This feature could make paying for things with a phone less of a hassle. (Youd swipe the phone over a device at the checkout counter.) It turns out that getting N.F.C. to work right with the new design of the iPhone wasnt even possible.

title: A Tourist Revival in the Heart of Bogot
description: IT was a windswept Saturday in the Candelaria neighborhood of Bogot, and the Plaza de Bolvar was packed. Troubadours, jugglers, balloon vendors, pineapple sellers and Amazonian fruit-juice pressers vied for the attention of tourists. Grizzled Andean Indians led children around on llamas. Pilgrims gathered at the Bogot Cathedral, a soaring Gothic structure that contains the remains of the citys 16th-century founder, the conquistador Gonzalo Jimnez de Quesada. Beside a statue of the South American liberator Simon Bolvar, a tattooed comedian held an audience of hundreds rapt.

title: Off the Charts: The Job Score
description: Government jobs have been most affected during the current economic cycle, and they continue to decline while private sector employment recovers at a moderate rate. The top chart shows the percentage of jobs held by public sector employees since 1957. In recent decades, that proportion has tended to fall under Democratic presidents and rise under Republican ones. The other charts show the annual rate of change in the number of jobs during four-year presidential terms, and through August during President Obamas administration. While private sector employment is now a little higher than it was when Mr. Obama took office, overall government employment has declined at a rate not seen during any full presidential term since the reductions that followed the end of World War II.

title: Bookshelf: Harvest
description: APPLE  Written and illustrated by Nikki McClure.  40 pp. Abrams Appleseed. $12.95. (Picture book; ages 3 to 6)

title: In Guatemala, a Torturous Drive to a Remote Eden
description: YOU might have thought years had passed since a foreigner had traversed this remote stretch of road in the interior of Guatemala.Here, in Alta Verapaz state, just the sight of our big American vehicle cruising over the endless and totally unnecessary speed bumps in the small and even smaller villages was enough cause for children to abandon their soccer balls of crumpled-up paper and wave as we passed by.

title: A Santiago Barrio Recreates Its Image
description: BARRIO ITALIA, a neighborhood of once-monotonous facades in the western part of Santiago, was built as an alternative to the squalid tenements that dotted the Chilean capital in the early 20th century. After arriving from Italy, members of the Girardi family opened a hat factory along the districts northern edge in the 1910s, giving the area its commercial pulse and its name, for their country of origin.

title: Restaurant Report: Tarquino in Buenos Aires
description: Dining out at a Buenos Aires hot spot these days often means sampling the cooking of an internationally trained Porteo chef who is now back home interpreting local cuisine with his newly acquired skills.

title: For 2013 Range Rover, a Stage as Monumental as the Vehicle
description: ALPINE, N.J.  The Palisades Parkway runs opposite the northern reaches of Manhattan, skirting the former estates of titans of the Gilded Age. In the approach to this enclave high above the Hudson River, eight miles from Manhattan, a sign reads Rockefeller Lookout.

title: Village Voice Editor Blogs That He Is Quitting
description: Tony Ortega, the editor of The Village Voice, announced Friday morning on the sites news blog that he would be leaving  effective next week  to pursue a book proposal about Scientology in its time of crisis.

title: In Germany, Gay Player Mulls Coming Out
description: German soccer is abuzz after a professional player in the countrys top-flight league, the Bundesliga, gave an interview earlier this week in which he recounted his life as a homosexual.

title: A Story Exposes How the Chinese Government is Fueling Elephant Slaughter
description: Theres been a lot of hard-edged coverage of the bloody burst of African elephanticide of late, including the new series coming from Jeffrey Gettleman of The Times and Agony and Ivory, Alex Shoumatoffs devastating Vanity Fair portrait of the ivory flow from Africa to Asia.

title: Obama to Attend Ceremony Honoring Americans Slain in Libya
description: President Obama plans to go to Joint Base Andrews outside Washington on Friday afternoon to mark the return of the four Americans slain in Libya, the White House announced.

title: Obamas Jobs Number Still Beats Predecessors
description: THE job numbers in recent months have been disappointing, encouraging Republicans who hope that the slow pace of recovery will cause voters to reject President Obama.

title: The Secrets to Buying Excellent French Wine Right Now
description: PARIS  Its that time of year in France  la rentre or the return. Its when people come back from the beach, don their fall fashions and go back to work or school. Its also the time of year when retailers ring up the bulk of their wine sales for the year.

title: Paperback Row
description: ARGUABLY: Essays,  by Christopher Hitchens. (Twelve, $18.) The esophageal cancer that killed Hitchens last December throws a shadow over this provocative collection, one of the Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2011. Nearly 800 pages and containing more than 100 essays, it addresses an extraordinary range of topics, including Afghanistan, Harry Potter, Thomas Jefferson, waterboarding, Henry VIII, Saul Bellow and the Ten Commandments.

title: No Quarterback Controversy: One Starts, One Finishes
description: EVANSTON, Ill.  Northwestern quarterback Trevor Siemian was a baseball player as well, playing shortstop, third base and outfield for Olympia High School in Orlando, Fla.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Jennifer Szalai and Parul Sehgal discuss several new books about womens issues; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Tom Reiss talks about The Black Count; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: In Search of a Middle Eastern Strategy
description: Here are four thoughts on the sudden intrusion of foreign policy into our all-about-the-economy political year:

title: No Explosives Found After Bomb Threats at Colleges
description: DALLAS  The authorities in Texas and North Dakota said on Friday that they had found no explosives after two large public universities were evacuated over bomb threats  false alarms that forced tens of thousands of students and staff members to flee in the middle of classes at the University of Texas at Austin and at North Dakota State University in Fargo.

title: The Choice on the Today Show
description: Jacques Steinberg of The Choice, a senior editor at The New York Times, appeared on NBCs Today show on Friday morning to talk about college admissions and our student-led series, The Envelope, Please. Watch the full interview below.

title: Answers About Hostage Negotiation, Part 2
description: This is the second set of responses from Frank A. Bolz Jr., one of the founders of the New York Police Departments hostage-negotiating unit, answering reader questions. Read the first and third set of responses and the introductory post about Mr. Bolz. We are no longer accepting questions.

title: Romney Statement on Iran at Odds With His Foreign Policy Advisers
description: 11:06 p.m. | Updated An updated version of this post can be found here.

title: Editors Choice
description: TELEGRAPH AVENUE, by Michael Chabon. (Harper/HarperCollins, $27.99.) Chabons rich comic novel about fathers and sons in Berkeley and Oakland, Calif., juggles multiple plots and mounds of pop culture references in astonishing prose.

title: Latin America Through a Lens
description: Vibrant hues, playful art and zesty food are all part of this online-only collection of photos from our Latin America issue.

title: A Guaranteed Return on an Annuity Has Limits After All
description: ANNUITIES are sold with the word guaranteed sprinkled through the marketing material. A set payment for life seems mighty attractive when many people are worried about having enough income in retirement and interest rates on savings and Treasury bonds are almost nonexistent.

title: Nine Months of Hell
description: It was mid-September 1862, and the 900 soldiers of the 130th Pennsylvania Infantry were marching through western Maryland. Pvt. Edward Spangler  all 16 years and 92 pounds of him  struggled to stay with his regiment. The heat was intense, Spangler later wrote, and the suffocating dust more than ankle deep. Hundreds of raw recruits, ill-prepared and exhausted, were collapsing by the roadside.

title: In a Deck of Cards, Finding 52 Shades of Greed
description: Just in time for the one-year anniversary of the occupation of Zuccotti Park on Sept. 17, Occupy Wall Streets Alternative Banking group is offering for sale an acerbically educational set of anti-capitalist playing cards.

title: Weekend Fare
description: The annual Feast of San Gennaro is in full swing this weekend as local restaurants offer special menus during this street festival full of live music, parades and family-friendly activities. Bolstered in recent years by the presence of restaurants like Torrisi Italian Specialties, guests will find better food than whats offered at typical New York street festivals. The 11-day event ends on Sept. 23.

title: A New Opera Center, for Practicing as Well as Performing
description: No more arpeggios in the bathroom. Goodbye, church basements. Hello, soundproofing.

title: iConfusion
description: Ive had some bizarre reactions both to my iPhone post and to todays column. For some reason a number of people thought that the blog post was an attack on Apple, while a number of people thought that the column  which made the same point!  was a love letter to Apple.

title: The Sweet Spot | Adaptations
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss the dilemma that filmmakers are presented with when adapting movies from books.

title: What New Polls Say About the Campaign
description: New presidential election polls out today, including a New York Times/CBS News poll, dont resolve the uncertainty of this race, which remains too close to call. But they do provide insight into how some of the big issues in the campaign have been playing  the economy, womens rights, and Medicare.

title: New York Fashion Week | Board Game
description: Three designers have shared their spring 2013 mood boards with T. The challenge: To identify the images on each. See all the mood boards here >>

title: The Sweet Spot | Sept. 14, 2012
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about the dilemma that filmmakers are presented with when adapting movies from books.

title: Putting the S.B.A. Into Perspective
description: In this political season, there will be a lot of dialogue about the Small Business Administration as a possible solution to the small-business lending crisis in America. As two examples, the S.B.A.s administrator, Karen Mills, spoke recently at the Democratic National Convention and Robb Mandelbaum wrote a post for this blog about the effect a Romney administration might have on the S.B.A. budget.

title: More Fedding
description: Now that Ive coughed my way through the morning, I thought I would offer a bit of clarification on my Bernanke post from last night.

title: Hot Dogs and Hamburgers? During Fashion Week? How Dclass!
description: When The Timess fashion critic Cathy Horyn called the noted fashion designer Oscar de la Renta a hot dog, in her review of his Tuesday runway show at Fashion Week, the octogenarian decided to add to the menu. He took out a full-page ad in Womens Wear Daily on Friday, in the form of an open letter objecting to what he saw as personal criticism. If you have the right to call me a hot dog, why do I not have the right to call you stale 3-day old hamburger? he asked.

title: The Emerald City Gang
description: I have to admit that I havent been paying much attention to Mitt Romneys foreign policy; the domestic side already offers a target-rich environment. But my eyebrows shot up when Dan Senor popped up speaking for Romney in the Libya/Egypt flap. Dan Senor?

title: Loyalty to Embattled Assemblyman Is Seen in a Brooklyn Election
description: He may be down, but hes not out.

title: Inside the List
description: HEAD FOR THE BORDER: The new king of the hardcover nonfiction list is, no surprise, Mark Owen  or, as hes known to his friends (and the rest of America by now), Matt Bissonnette. A former member of the Navy SEALs, Bissonnette is the author of No Easy Day, which enters the list at No. 1 and describes, among other things, his role in the raid that killed Osama bin Laden. The book (written with Kevin Maurer) has received admiring reviews  in the daily New York Times, Janet Maslin called it an exciting, suspenseful account  but it has also stirred anger among special operations forces, who adhere proudly to a code of silence. Breaking it means Bissonnette is unlikely to be included in future SEAL reunions, one retired Navy officer told The Washington Times: The guys who run their mouths are typically not invited back. But Bissonnette hasnt let the critics keep him down. He sat for a recent 60 Minutes interview (heavily disguised, inset) and told Scott Pelley the first thing he did upon returning from the mission was visit a Taco Bell drive-through.

title: Summer Nights 2012
description: A roundup of photographs from the articles that made up the Summer Nights series.

title: Stephen Burt Explains His Favorite Poems
description: I asked Stephen Burt, the poet and poetry critic, to comment on two favorite poems, which accompany my profile of him. Why do you like them? I asked. Can you help the reader unfamiliar with poetry understand them? His answers are below.

title: The Romneys Tape Appearance on Live With Kelly and Michael
description: Mitt Romney  newly professed fan of the iPhone, Snooki and sleeping in as little as possible  offered a lighthearted, humanizing glimpse of himself Friday morning in an interview with ABCs Kelly Ripa and Michael Strahan, set to air Tuesday.

title: With High Winds, Play Is Halted and Days Scores Are Voided
description: HOYLAKE, England  On the 10th tee, her first hole of the day, Cristie Kerr stuck her teed ball in the ground. Never mind the ball staying put; Kerr said she was nearly swept off her feet by the strong winds that whipped through Royal Liverpool Golf Club on Friday, turning the second round of the years final major into the Womens Brutish Open.

title: Book Review Podcast: Hanna Rosins End of Men
description: This weeks edition of The New York Times Book Review includes considerations of several new books about womens issues, including Hanna Rosins The End of Men: And the Rise of Women. Ms. Rosin argues that weve entered a new era in which women are increasingly dominant in both public and private spheres. In her review of the book, Jennifer Homans takes issue with the triumphant tone of Ms. Rosins subtitle. Ms. Homans writes:

title: Making It Exclusive: Signing With an Agent
description: CHOOSING a real estate agent for selling a home may seem simple, but there is much to understand about the role of the agent and how the relationship works. And the stakes are high  the sale of what is likely the owners most valuable asset.

title: An Unqualified Success, at Least in London
description: The wheelchair racer Joshua George competed in the 2012 Paralympic Games in London and wrote for the 2012 London blog. Readers can continue to follow him on his Web site, joshgeorgeracing.com

title: Speaking at Values Voter Summit, Ryan Says Obama Creates Straw-Man Issues
description: Paul D. Ryan dialed up the Republican rhetoric against President Obama a few degrees hotter than it has been, caustically accusing the president of only being able to talk a good game and of using straw-man arguments because he has no record on which to run.

title: Under Cover of Darkness, a New Season Slips In
description: Autumn begins in the night.

title: Liz Garbus on 'Love, Marilyn'
description: The director Liz Garbus discusses her documentary "Love, Marilyn," which looks at letters and journal entries written by Marilyn Monroe.

title: A City Perch for a Reverse Commuter
description: LAST fall, Alfredo Sosa-Velasco landed happily in New York as a visiting scholar at New York University. He was provided with a furnished studio with a balcony, for $1,275 a month, in Washington Square Village, the university-owned housing complex.

title: When Children Get Medals for Standardized Test Results
description: A parent in California wrote me last week about the states STAR testing, and, more important, the practice, in some schools, of awarding medals for achievement on the tests to students. Her childs school presented gold medals for advanced achievement in language arts and/or math, and silver to children whose score was proficient. (Yes, a medal for proficiency.) The medals were given to the children in an assembly. Children who werent given a medal were given a certificate.

title: A Reminder of the Perils of Retirement Planning
description: People without a pension who want to set up something that will pay them set amounts of money when theyre in retirement often turn to annuities. But Paul Sullivan writes this week in his Wealth Matters column about a decision by Prudential Annuities to suspend the ability of some policyholders to make further contributions. And annuity experts told Paul that they expect other insurers to take similar steps because they made promises before the financial crisis that they are now unable to keep.

title: Near the Zoos Snakes, a Hospitals Collection of Medicine
description: The Bronx Zoo has an impressive collection of venomous snakes on display in its Reptile House. But out of sight it also has an impressive collection of antivenin to treat snakebites  though none of the zoos snakes have ever bitten an employee or a visitor.

title: Emmys Watch: Don Roy King on Directing Saturday Night Live
description: We will be talking to Emmy nominees leading up to the awards show on Sept. 23. First up is Don Roy King, nominated for best director for a variety show for his work on Saturday Night Live.

title: When It Comes to Calling Fouls, N.B.A. Should Look to the Playground
description: A long-standing criticism of the N.B.A. has been the influence of referees on the flow and outcome of games  especially how, when, and in what context certain fouls are called.

title: The Hamptons, for $500,000
description: WHEN Jahil Maplestone and Alexandria Fisk began looking for a second home in the Hamptons a couple of years ago, they were quickly discouraged by what their $500,000 budget would buy.

title: Patrice Kunkel: 1951-2012
description: The obituaries in The New York Times are about people who were leaders in their fields, including some of the best known humans on the planet.

title: Those Youthful Kennedys
description: In this weeks issue, Edith Zimmerman profiles Joseph P. Kennedy III, who is running for Barney Franks House seat  and who, if he beats out his Republican opponent, Sean Bielat, will become the latest Kennedy to hold an elected office. With $1.96 million in his campaigns coffers, Joseph has the financial upper hand on Bielat, whos running on roughly $65,000. At 31, Joseph has another advantage, too, one that the Kennedy clan has drawn on for generations: youth. (Bielat is 37.)

title: Try Curling Up With a Good Meatball
description: MEATBALLS are comfort food the world over, cheap, easy to love and simple to make.

title: Couscous, Large and Small
description: I wanted to serve couscous with the North African meatballs in this weeks City Kitchen column. But what kind?

title: Man, 21, Arrested in Murder of Bronx Gas-Station Worker
description: A 21-year-old parolee who has served time for robbery has been arrested in connection with last weeks murder of a Bronx gas-station worker, the police said on Friday.

title: Times Co. Offers Former Employees Lump Sum Option for Pension
description: The New York Times Company, which like many of the nations newspaper publishers is dealing with large pension obligations, is offering former employees the option of taking a lump sum payment for their pensions instead of a monthly payout.

title: Analysts See Minor Boost for Housing in the Feds Plan
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserves ambitious effort to spur the recovery by aiding the housing market is likely to have a modest effect on home sales, given the pervasive weakness in the real estate market and the economy, analysts said Friday.

title: India Backs Foreign Investment in Retailing
description: NEW DELHI  After years of intense debate, Indias government agreed on Friday to open the countrys retail sector to global behemoths like Wal-Mart and Ikea, pushing for a profound shift in Indias economic and political direction.

title: A Set Designer Sets Up Shop
description: Last month, the production designer Coryander Friend (Beginners) opened Storefront, a vintage shop in Downtown Los Angeless arts district. Housed adjacent to the popular eatery Wurstkche and around the corner from Apolis: Common Gallery and Poketo, Storefront showcases Friends rotating roster of eclectic antiques, home goods and other vintage finds. On my visit, I spotted everything from a brown Borge Mogensen leather sofa ($6,500) to a green dummy bomb ($650) to a 1960s jet-propelled aluminum surfboard ($1,800). Not to be missed are the stores collection of Navajo rugs and prison keys. As the stores head curator, Friend plans to switch up Storefronts aesthetic on a quarterly basis by featuring new collectors and artists. Currently Storefront is selling pottery by Victoria Morris and surf photography by Will Adler, whose uncle Tom Adler is well known for his own surf-themed work. For her next installation, Friend will feature the work of her friend and mentor, the Windows Greg Wooten. As for the theme? The next one has to do with music, geometry and something I havent figured out yet, Friend wrote in an e-mail. I come from set decoration and production design. We are always telling stories with our environments. I want to work that way in my store. Who knows where it will go?

title: Fashion Weeks Version of the Rockettes
description: WHEN you pack many famously thin and fashionable people into a confined space, strange things happen. Consider the pretzel twist seen on the crossed legs of front-row fashionistas like Anna Wintour; Carine Roitfeld, editor of CR Fashion Book; and the dedicated fashion follower Sarah Jessica Parker, among others.

title: Who Could Oppose a Jobs Bill for Veterans?
description: Congressional Republicans, resolute in their commitment to deny the Democrats anything that looks like an accomplishment in an election year, have spent the week obstructing passage of the Veterans Job Corps Act of 2012. Its a perfectly inoffensive bill from Senator Patty Murray, the Washington Democrat, meant to increase hiring and job training for veterans, especially those who served in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Wheels Calendar for Sept. 14-16
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

title: U.S. Says Fast Pace Continues on Reprieves for Young Immigrants
description: More than 82,000 illegal immigrants have applied for a two-year reprieve from deportation in the first 30 working days of an Obama administration program, and 29 have been approved, officials from the Department of Homeland Security said on Friday.

title: Rethinking the New Plant Hardiness Zone Map
description: For gardeners sad to see the summer drawing to a close, theres some comfort to be drawn from the fall planting season for perennials, trees and shrubs, which is just around the corner. Whats more, theres the novelty of this years updated Plant Hardiness Zone Map, released early this year.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A four-bedroom Colonial in Garden City, N.Y., and a four bedroom with water views in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Financial District condo, a Bedford-Stuyvesant condo and an Upper East Side co-op.

title: Michael Learned to Star in New Play by Bruce Graham
description: Michael Learned, the Emmy Award-winning actress, will star in The Outgoing Tide, a new play about family struggles by Bruce Graham that is set to open in November at 59E59 Theaters, on East 59th Street in Manhattan, the Delaware Theatre Company announced Friday.

title: Answering Questions on Student Loan Rates and the Murky Future
description: Figuring out how to pay for college has quickly turned into one of lifes most complicated financial decisions.

title: New York Fashion Week From the Ground Up
description: A ground-level view of New York Fashion Week.

title: Mr. Madison Moves On
description: ELIOT RABIN, the founder of the Upper East Side temple of navy blazers and sherbet-colored sweaters that is Peter Elliot, is a retailer of a bygone era of gentility. He loves to amuse a customer with a good clich, like his store motto: The whimsical mood of timeless elegance.

title: Rape Victim, 73, Says She Reported Earlier Confrontation With Suspect
description: The 73-year-old woman who was raped in Central Park said Friday that when she encountered a man masturbating in the wooded Ramble area two weeks ago, she not only took his photograph, but also reported what she saw to a park ranger.

title: White House Details Potential Effects If Automatic Budget Cuts Go Through
description: WASHINGTON  Army operations and maintenance would lose nearly $7 billion next year, and the Navy more than $4 billion under a looming series of automatic cuts in federal spending. Educational achievement and special-education programs would be shaved by $2.3 billion. Medicare payments to hospitals would fall by $5.6 billion.

title: Bill Clinton Is More Popular Than Ever, Poll Finds
description: Former President Bill Clinton is more popular now than at any time during the 20 years since his emergence as a presidential candidate, with two-thirds of registered voters viewing him favorably, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Week in Review: Contrarian Bets Looking Smart
description: We examined contrarian bets on European bonds that are looking pretty smart right now. And with Treasury set to reduce its A.I.G. bet below 50 percent, Andrew Ross Sorkin called a critic of the bailout.

title: Kansas Ballot Challenge Over Obamas Birth Is Ended
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Citing a wave of angry backlash, a Kansas man on Friday withdrew a petition in which he argued that President Obama should be removed from the states election ballot because he did not meet citizenship requirements.

title: Q & A
description: When a Home Isnt a Primary Residence

title: Official Challenge by Joe Montgomery and Obama Response
description: The official challenge filed by Joe Montgomery to keep President Obamas name off the ballot in Kansas, and the response by the Obama team.

title: Revis Is Ruled Out of Steelers Game
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Darrelle Revis attended the University of Pittsburgh and grew up in nearby Aliquippa, but there will be no homecoming for him this weekend when the Jets play the Steelers at Heinz Field.

title: My Brief Career as a Kennedy Speechwriter
description: Ive never met Joseph P. Kennedy III, the Congressional candidate profiled in this weeks magazine. But as a reporter at The Boston Herald in the early 1990s, I covered his father, Joseph Kennedy II, who was then a congressman. I found the older Kennedy (whatever you may think about his politics) charismatic and curious about the world outside Massachusetts, which led him, and me with him, to Germany.

title: Fashion Week Parties: Night 8
description: Lady Gaga ends Fashion Week with fragrance launch at the Guggenheim.

title: In Detropia, Leveraging the Remnants of a Proud City
description: DETROIT  Its a well-chronicled tale with an undetermined ending: the rise of Detroit as the Motor City; its dismal, protracted slide; and its current posture, where it wobbles but stands, proud but buffeted, in the grip of transformation.

title: Altima: Sailing Into the Mainstream
description: WHEN Nissan unveiled a new Altima for 2002, it heralded the companys redesign as much as the cars. Nissans workaholic new leader, Carlos Ghosn, was engineering a remarkably fast turnaround that made him a global auto-industry superstar. And the great-looking Altima  formerly an obscure runt among family sedans  was the model that, more than any other, transformed Nissan from a debt-ridden basket case into one of the most profitable automakers.

title: Reality Check From Honda, in Touch With Economics
description: LONG BEACH, Calif.

title: The Beginners Ninja Raises the Ante at the Entry Level
description: FOR years, the most thrilling new motorcycles have been those at the top of the model line: the racetrack replicas splashed with a Valentino Rossi livery or the high-stepping machines with the go-anywhere styling of a Dakar rally competitor.

title: Playing It Straight (And Why Not?)
description: The all-new and all-better Honda Accord does nothing to betray the cars enormous and well-established customer base.

title: Accord: Once More With No Nonsense
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.

title: When Work Makes You Choose
description: 4:50 p.m. | Updated  Rachel Robinson was doing well at T-Mobile in Chattanooga, Tenn. The company hired her in 2006 as a customer service representative, promoted her twice in two years and honored her with an employee award that included a trip to Hawaii.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Three Adolfs
description: The entire manga list is new this week, but the most significant book by far is the first volume of Message to Adolf, by Osamu Tezuka, at No. 6. Mr. Tezuka, who died in 1989, is frequently described as the godfather of manga. Clocking in at 648 pages, Message to Adolf begins in modern times, quickly jumps to the 1936 Olympics in Berlin and moves through World War II. It chronicles the fate of three men with the same first name: Adolf Kamil, a Jewish boy; Adolf Kaufmann, the young boy with a German father and a Japanese mother who befriends him; and Adolf Hitler. The boys become entangled in a struggle between opposing sides  one that wants to expose Hitlers Jewish ancestry and another that wants to suppress it at all costs. The book has a sprawling cast, and the relationship between the two young boys and their struggle to remain friends is touching.

title: Liz Garbuss Personal Look at Marilyn Monroe
description: TORONTO  It is rare for documentaries to receive gala screenings in one of the festivals largest venues, Roy Thomson Hall, but when the subject is Marilyn Monroe, there will be fanfare. Love, Marilyn, directed by Liz Garbus, focuses on letters and journal entries by the actress and uses celebrities like Uma Thurman and Marisa Tomei to bring her words to life on screen.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $17.5 Million
description: A starkly modern penthouse duplex with a Pop Art pedigree  the Andy Warhol alumna Jane Holzer once owned it  which fills the top two floors at the Volney, a former hotel built in 1928, sold for $17.5 million, making it the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Model for a Day
description: A writer tries the catwalk during Fashion Week.

title: Model Behavior
description: ID love to tell you that my modeling career got its kick-start when the photographer Larry Clark found me skateboarding in a disused swimming pool in Tulsa. Or when Karl Lagerfeld tweeted some photos he had taken of me in my capacity as the towel boy at his day spa.

title: How Much Does the Feds Plan Really Help Main Street?
description: Ben Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said Thursday that the Feds new stimulus was meant to help Main Street.

title: Richie Jackson and Jordan Roth
description: THE initials JR and RJ on the marquee of the Al Hirschfeld Theater on Sept. 8 announced a one-night-only event that, for its main players, Jordan Roth and Richie Jackson, was the culmination of a multiyear tryout as long and as full of emotion and humor as the shows appearing in the Broadway houses that Mr. Roth oversees as the president of Jujamcyn Theaters.

title: Slovenia Encounters Debt Trouble and May Need Bailout
description: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia  Small, affluent and westward-leaning, Slovenia was welcomed with open arms into the European Union in 2004 and slipped, almost unnoticed, into the euro union three years later.

title: Ex-UBS Trader Is Accused of Gambling in a Big Loss
description: LONDON  Fictitious trading and brazen gambling by a single individual could have brought down the Swiss financial giant UBS, a British prosecutor said on Friday at the trial of a former bank employee accused of causing a multibillion-dollar trading loss.

title: Oats for Dinner and Dessert
description: Steel-cut oats can make a hearty and healthful breakfast, but as Martha Rose Shulman recently discovered, oats are a great grain at dinnertime too. She writes:

title: Village Voice Is Losing Its Editor in Chief and Music Editor
description: After five and a half years as editor of The Village Voice, Tony Ortega announced in a blog post that he would be stepping down to work on a book about Scientology. The music editor, Maura Johnston, took to Twitter to say she was leaving the newspaper as well.

title: Learning to Love the Middle
description: The 2013 Nissan Altima is a terrific family car, among the best in the current field of midsize sedans. And thats saying something, considering the depth and multinational breadth of that class.

title: Photos of The Moment | Maria Grachvogel

title: New Animated Series Make Inroads in Ratings
description: Now that youngsters have headed off to school, it seems like a good time to take a look back at the animated shows they  and their parents  watched over the summer.

title: Friday Afternoon Music: Wilco w/Feist
description: Its early, but Im leaving for the airport soon, so something pleasant after a hard week:

title: Defining Middle Class
description: In a discussion on Good Morning America about his tax plan, Mitt Romney suggested the cutoff for middle income was for households earning $200,000 to $250,000 and less. President Obama has used a similar threshold in talking about extending tax cuts for the middle class.

title: 3 Experts, and Many Tips for Visiting Brazil
description: To supplement my seven rules for lowering the cost of a trip to Brazil, I asked three Brazil-based colleagues to come up with their own tips. They are Ricardo Freire, widely regarded as the dean of Brazilian travel bloggers; Fbio Peixoto, the editor of a Brazilian travel guide; and Kevin Raub, a Lonely Planet author who lives in So Paulo.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: H.P.s Smartphone and Twitters New Hacker
description: A Geeky Way for Children to Learn Their ABCsLaughingsquid.com | The new ABCs? A is for Apple, the company. B is for Bezier curve. Fun, nerd eye candy for a Friday afternoon. Damon Darlin

title: Wrapping Up TimesOpen: Sockets and Streams
description: This past Wednesday night, more than 80 developers came to the Times building for the second TimesOpen event of 2012, Sockets and Streams.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Egypt, Sudan, Morocco and Yemen.

title: Michigan State Tailback Thrives on Doubts
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.  LeVeon Bell took the handoff, his second of the season, moving fast enough to make everyone else look slow. He spotted a safety 7 yards away and ran purposefully toward him. Beyond the safety was space.

title: Exclusive | Bassman Carriage House
description: A three-story, 7,000-square-foot brick structure, now reconfigured as two residences, once served as home and studio for the fashion photographer Lillian Bassman.

title: The Carriage House in the Close-Up
description: THE highly personalized Upper East Side carriage house that for half a century served as home, studio and muse of sorts to Lillian Bassman, the iconoclastic fashion photographer, is being offered for sale for $14.9 million by her heirs.

title: BMW Previews Concept Active Tourer Before Paris Motor Show
description: The BMW Concept Active Tourer fits squarely in Europes predilection for efficient, premium small cars, pairing a turbocharged 1.5-liter 3-cylinder engine with an electric motor that sends power to  stand back  the front wheels.

title: Somber Ceremony as Bodies of Slain Americans Return
description: WASHINGTON -- Four flag-draped coffins bearing the bodies of the Americans killed in Libya arrived in the United States on Friday for their final journey home as President Obama said the victims laid down their lives for us all and vowed to honor their memory by never retreating from the world.

title: Whats in Store | Dior Homme

title: Remembering the Forgotten Borough
description: Its not called the forgotten borough for nothing (a dubious distinction it sometimes shares with Queens). Chances are that you have forgotten, or may never have known, that the first American tennis match was played there, that Cornelius Vanderbilt got his start there, that Sandy Ground was the first community established by freed slaves in North America, that by one account Manhattans first suburb sprouted there, that the last commercial farm there closed only three decades ago and that it will soon be home to a greensward three times bigger than Central Park.

title: Why Consumers May Not Win Much From Latest Fed Action
description: Over on Dealbook, theres a post making the case that it may be the banks that are standing in the way of the Federal Reserves latest move to try to improve the economy. At the moment, many of them simply do not want to give up the profit margins theyre earning on new mortgages.

title: Constant Motion, Elusive Point
description: AND so there was Carine Roitfeld being stopped at the door of a West 54th Street town house where the W party was held  one event among scores, or hundreds even, that made it feel during the New York Fashion Week continuum that one had wandered into a glossier version of Groundhog Day.

title: The Week in Metro Pictures for Sept. 14
description: Subjects include the 11th anniversary of 9/11, a controversial circumcision ritual and the New York primary race.

title: Canning Jam, From Preparing the Jars to Testing the Seal
description: REFRIGERATOR jams will last for weeks, maybe even a few months, when kept cold and tightly sealed. You can also freeze the jams for up to six months before they start to lose their texture. But any of these recipes can also be canned for longer storage  up to a year. And canning means you can keep the jams in the pantry, freeing valuable fridge space.

title: Moving Past Traditional to the Science Fictional
description: WHILE planning their wedding, which took place last October in Mesa, Ariz., Amber Balmer and Trey Memmott wanted to not only have references to one of their favorite television shows, Firefly  a space Western in which the universe was called the verse  but to change their last names to Reynolds, after Capt. Malcolm Reynolds, the lead character on the old Fox series.

title: All Cut Up
description: Sliced, diced and inter-spliced: it was a novel way of approaching color, and it made for some riotously kaleidoscopic effects on the runways this week. For quite a few designers, who introduced separates last season in madly clashing hues, combining disparate tints in a single item represented a continued commitment to color while advancing its cause by degrees.

title: Cathy Horyn's N.Y. Fashion Week Wrap-Up
description: An analysis of the spring collections from Calvin Klein, Proenza Schouler, Marc Jacobs and Narciso Rodriguez.

title: Romney Calls for Moment of Silence During Ohio Rally
description: PAINESVILLE, Ohio  Mitt Romney began his rally here on Friday afternoon by calling for a moment of silence for the four Americans who were killed in the attack on the American Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, on Tuesday.

title: The Price of Politics (Shorter Bai Edition)
description: This just in from the Dept. of Shameless Plugging: It has been gratifying to read reviews of Bob Woodwards new book  by Michiko Kakutani in The New York Times, David Lauter in The Los Angeles Times and Jeff Shesol in The Washington Post  and see the various references to Matt Bais excellent article about the debt deal gone bad, from our April 1 issue, saying that Bai had already revealed all the important information contained in Woodwards book. If you need to purchase The Price of Politics to complete your Woodward collection, dont let us stop you. But for those who want to understand how the deal went south and what the implications are  in shorter but exhaustively reported form  check out Bais article.

title: Making and Canning Jam
description: Try making your own jam with all those summer fruits available this time of year. Melissa Clark is joined by Cathy Barrow, a canning expert, to show how easy it is to make and can your own jam.

title: Fashion Week Kaleidoscope
description: The photographer Ben Sklar spent New York Fashion Week exploring the kaleidoscope of shows and parties around the city using a variety of cameras and techniques.

title: Week in Pictures for Sept. 14
Look of The Moment | Karlie Kloss
description: The Look: Rosy Outlook. Clean hair, a pink pout and black accessories  pump plus clutch  turn a simple jersey dress into an absolute standout.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Sept. 14
description: Images of cultural highlights from this week.

title: Make Room In the Fridge For Jam
description: MAKING jam is simple. Canning isnt.

title: Michael Bastian Show
description: Michael Bastian, spring 2013. Can you spot the writer on the runway of models?

title: House Passes Solyndra Act Aimed at Obama
description: The House passed legislation on Friday that would phase out a Department of Energy loan guarantee program for clean and renewable energy projects.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures | Sept. 14
description: More Photographs.

title: One on One: Reggie Fils-Aime, President of Nintendo of America
description: In an event in New York this week, Nintendo had demonstration booths where people could play with its new Wii U, a game console that can be operated with a touch-screen controller. It also introduced Nintendo TV, its new online video service that is intended to make its Wii U competitive with set-top box systems like the Apple TV, Google TV and Roku.

title: Design Tasting in Paris
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Women Running for Congress in Record Numbers
description: If the parties are indeed engaging in some sort of war on women, record numbers of them are successfully enlisting in the fight. More women have been nominated to the major parties for House and Senate seats than ever, according to researchers.

title: Broome Street, Manhattan
description: Scenes from along Broome Street, including shopping for yarn, guitars and Japanese food, al fresco dining and a traffic jam near the Holland Tunnel.

title: Kansas Birthers
description: Birther alert: Kansas is considering tossing President Obama from the November ballot because its not sure that hes a citizen. A citizen from Manhattan (Kansas) named Joe Montgomery filed a complaint to that effect, so the State Objections Board, controlled by Republicans, is duly looking into it. I dont think its a frivolous objection, said the Kansas Secretary of State, Kris Kobach.

title: How Tolstoy Learned to Ride a Bike, and Other Tales of Late-Life Learning
description: In our Education Issue this Sunday, we explore what it takes to send every child to college; get people reading poetry; create an always-on tutor; and fire up a university. Below, accounts of notable people learning new things at an older age.

title: Block by Block | Broome Street
description: Broome Street maintains a grimy, hardworking atmosphere as it intersects with chic side streets.

title: Less Gritty, More Gourmet
description: WHEN Bill and Jean Conlon moved into a loft on Broome Street 41 years ago, they felt like pioneers.

title: College Football Lettermen Stay On the News
description: Each week, two of colleges footballs seasoned observers, Pre-Snap Reads Paul Myerberg and Robert Weintraub of Football Outsiders, get together over e-mail to discuss the biggest games and story lines around the country.

title: Video: The Basics of Making and Canning Jam
description: Quick, before all the ripe fruit disappears  its time to make jam.

title: Likely Voters Weigh In on the 2012 Presidential Election
description: Results from the latest NYT/CBS News poll.

title: Latest New York Times/CBS News Poll
description: A new poll shows that 2012 presidential race is narrowly divided and that the outcome could still turn on unexpected events and how the candidates are perceived after their three debates next month.

title: Poll Finds Obama Is Erasing Romneys Edge on Economy
description: President Obama has taken away Mitt Romneys longstanding advantage as the candidate voters say is most likely to restore the economy and create jobs, according to the latest poll by The New York Times and CBS News, which found a modest sense of optimism among Americans that White House policies are working.

title: Critics Find a Target in the Circles of USA Todays Redesign
description: The day after USA Today unveiled its new edition, the design community was in a fluster about the newspapers new look and puzzled by the bold circles that appear in the top, left-hand corner of every section.

title: After Libya Attacks, Questions About Presidential Briefing Habits
description: President Obama sat down with intelligence officials on Friday for his presidential daily briefing. That might not sound all that surprising, but despite its title, this does not actually happen daily.

title: Hitching an Old-Fashioned Ride the Newfangled Way
description: To promote the season premiere of HBOs Boardwalk Empire, a fleet of a dozen town cars spent two days transporting fares to their destination in Manhattan. The third season of the Emmy-winning show, chronicling Prohibition-era Atlantic City, N.J., begins Sept. 16.

title: Reviewing the Nissan Altima and Honda Accord
description: Two of the three best-selling midsize sedans in the America, the Honda Accord and Nissan Altima, are reviewed in Sundays Automobiles section.

title: New Novel of Harlem Renaissance Is Found
description: A Columbia graduate student and his adviser have authenticated the students discovery of an unknown manuscript of a 1941 novel by Claude McKay, a leading Harlem Renaissance writer and author of the first novel by a black American to become a best seller.

title: Turned Away, He Turned to the Bible
description: ONE year after Matthew Vines was forced to leave the Wichita, Kan., church he had attended since birth  not because he is gay, but because he tried to convince people there was nothing wrong with that  he was sitting facing a crowd of 235Christians, most of them gay or lesbian, at the Marble Collegiate Church on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Showcasing an Eclectic Musical Biography and Some, Not All, of That Jazz
description: The brassiest moment in My Audio Biography, Bobby McFerrins collaboration with the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, running through Saturday at the Rose Theater, subjects a hallowed text to some studious whimsy. Its the third movement of Beethovens Seventh Symphony, arranged for big band by Jazz at Lincoln Centers artistic director, Wynton Marsalis. With its galloping triplets, the arrangement moves faithfully, up until a growlingly barrelhouse section, the concert hall equivalent of a nudge in the ribs.

title: Alice, Still Fighting to Save the World
description: The fifth entry in a series as indestructible as Alice (Milla Jovovich), its caffeinated heroine, Resident Evil: Retribution finds her still on the mysterious ship where Resident Evil: Afterlife left her. Almost a decade has passed since the endlessly mutating T-Virus began transforming most of humanity (and zoology) into drooling, pimply cannibals, but Alice  part human, part viral, all airbrushed  is still fighting to save the world. She must be as tired as we are.

title: Chic in Review | Gagas Fame in a Bottle
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Song of the Cheaters
description: AFTER 125 Harvard students were accused of cheating last month on the final exam of a course titled Introduction to Congress, there was predictable hand-wringing over the declining moral standards of the academic elite. A college education has become a transaction: a means of earning a degree for your rsum, rather than a place to explore the life of the mind, The Boston Globe bleakly proclaimed. The Associated Press asked whether Harvard should finally institute an honor code, a system that many peer institutions have had in place for years but that Harvard has long resisted.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: The introduction of Apples iPhone 5; a European proposal to regulate banks and the start of a trial for an ex-UBS trader were among the weeks top business news stories.

title: United States Wins Buffett Cup
description: The fourth Buffett Cup was played in Omaha from Monday to Thursday. Fashioned after the Ryder Cup in golf, it featured the following teams:

title: House-Made Pasta, and Gifts From Mom
description: EVEN before you enter Ristorante Giorgia, the omens look good: colorful petunias and marigolds cascading out of their red flower boxes next to the entrance, and pots of fresh rosemary, mint, sage, oregano, thyme and basil within snipping distance of the kitchen. Inside, the mood is immediately ebullient. New arrivals are greeted with hugs as they make their way among the crowd of tables; does everyone in here know one another, or does it just seem that way? If the bread and olive oil on the table are any indication, it is going to be a fine night.

title: What Congress Owes the Constituents
description: To the Editor:

title: You May Call It Cheating, but We Dont
description: MY husband and I have been together for 12 years. We talk throughout the day. We like each other a lot in addition to being in love. We plan to be together for the rest of our lives. I feel profoundly lucky.

title: A Delicate Balance of Diplomacy and Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Harsh Penalties for Disruptive Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Granholm and Her Curls on The Dating Game
description: As the former governor of Michigan, Jennifer Granholm was in the drivers seat during one of the states most economically painful periods, and now shes in the anchors seat on Current TV. But before that, Ms. Granholm was in the hot seat as a contestant on The Dating Game in 1978.

title: An Unconventional Romance
description: The lovers in Anurag Basus engagingly odd Barfi!  hes deaf and mute, shes autistic  are a particularly pure expression of a cherished Bollywood theme: love is the supreme goal. (Cue the songs: the movie does.) Stripped of conventional social expectations, Barfii (Ranbir Kapoor) and Jhilmil (a deglamorized Priyanka Chopra) have nothing to follow but their hearts, and nothing to battle but kidnappings, death and venality.

title: A Pasta Dish From the Slopes of a Volcano
description: I considered spaghetti alla Norma back in February, when we tasted wines from the slopes of Mount Etna in Sicily.

title: Seeking Justice for Mom and Dad
description: Fight, says Chanticha (Aphradi Phawaputanon), a nurse, to a critically injured boy in the hospital. You have to fight.

title: Pinot Hunting in the Anderson Valley
description: CALIFORNIA winemakers share a calling with the Cistercian monks of the Middle Ages: a relentless quest to find the best places to grow pinot noir. Over centuries, the monks settled on the heart of Burgundy, now famous as the Cte dOr, along with a few scattered sites in Germany that may only now be coming to fruition. In California, the search goes on.

title: The Lows of Higher Ed
description: Welcome back, college students! Always nice to see you.

title: Not Hollywood, but Once Famous for Movies
description: UNIVERSAL STUDIOS, which got its start in 1912 in Fort Lee, moved most of its production to California in 1915, but its 100th birthday is being celebrated here. The 11-year-old  Fort Lee Film Commission has planned a variety of events to mark the centennial and to make people aware theyre in a special place, according to its executive director, Tom Meyers.

title: The Unbridled Shower: Celebrating Divorce
description: IM not divorced. Yet. But when my husband tosses criticisms at me like wedding rice, divorce, were it to assume a human form, begins to look a lot like Channing Tatum.

title: Rothman Exits as Head of Fox Film Division
description: 8:10 p.m. | Updated

title: A Shoulder to Cry on and a Lot of Tough Talk
description: Evelyn Lozada begins her appearance on Iyanla: Fix My Life perfectly primped  hair, makeup, outfit, all pristine. It was filmed in July, 11 days after she married the football star Chad Johnson. Their not-always-romantic courtship had been documented in Basketball Wives, the VH1 reality battle royale of which shes the volatile star. (She was previously engaged to the basketball player Antoine Walker.)

title: Battle Renewed Between Sabathia and Price
description: C.C. Sabathia often says he prefers not to pay much attention to the starting pitcher hes facing on a given night. When the opponent is the Tampa Bay Rays, however, its a good bet Sabathia already knows who is on the mound against him.

title: For a Slick Operator, One Spin Too Many
description: A contemporary drama about a young political spin doctor who spins out of control on the campaign trail, Farragut North is better known today as The Ides of March. The screen adaptation of Beau Willimons play, which was released last year under that title, starred Ryan Gosling as the press secretary and George Clooney as the governor he strives to elect as president.

title: XOXO Fest, An Experimental Tech Conference, Gets Underway
description: What, exactly, is XOXO Fest, a hybrid of a conference, music showcase and local marketplace happening this weekend in Portland, Ore.?

title: Signs of High Demand for the iPhone 5
description: Did you forget to set the alarm on your iPhone to wake you up with a gentle marimba ringtone at 3 a.m. Eastern time Friday?

title: Are We Asking Too Much From Our Teachers?
description: Chicago
