title: Heck, Hes Abandoned the Whole Austro-Hungarian Empire
description: Liz Cheney Claims Obama Has Abandoned Czechoslovakia (Which Hasnt Existed Since The Early 90s).

title: Choosing All of the Above, the Yankees Stay on Top
description: It was in Tampa Bay earlier this month that questions flared up regarding how the Yankees offense should play the rest of the season. Should they bunt more, as the hitting instructor Kevin Long initially advocated after a tough loss at Tropicana Field? Should they employ the small-ball tactics that Alex Rodriguez espoused a day later after a victory, or should they continue to play the way they had, slugging their way to victories as Manager Joe Girardi insisted they would?

title: Mary Katrantzou: Spring 2013 RTW
description: London

title: With Frantic Fourth, Manning and Giants Slip Past Bucs
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants Coach Tom Coughlins sideline histrionics are legendary moments of football cinema. The death stares, the icy glares and the occasional (but impressive) hurling of perfectly creased play charts all dovetail nicely with Coughlins perpetually ruddy complexion, making for an entertaining spectacle as he upbraids his charges.

title: Pakistanis Try to Storm U.S. Outpost; One Is Killed
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  One person was killed and dozens of people were injured when anti-American protesters tried to storm the American Consulate in the southern port city of Karachi and clashed for several hours with the police and paramilitary troops on Sunday evening, rescue workers and police officials said.

title: Why I Love Mormonism
description: Ive spent what is rapidly becoming nine years in New York City. Its been a total blast. But as a transplanted Englishman one thing to which Ive become rather sensitive in that time is which prejudices New Yorkers are permitted to express in public. Among my horribly overeducated and hugely liberal friends, expressions of racism are completely out of the question, Islamophobia is greeted with a slow shaking of the head and anti-Semitism is a memory associated with distant places that one sometimes visits  like France.

title: A 60s Landmark in the Eyes of Children
description: Its fitting that 40 Dancers do 40 Dances for the Dancers, a project conceived and directed by Clarinda Mac Low, was ruled by children  at least on opening night. Part of Ms. Mac Lows intention for the event, as she states in program notes, is to recreate a childs-eye view of the 1970s New York avant-garde arts world. As the daughter of the poet, composer and performance artist  Jackson Mac Low, who died in 2004, she writes from experience. The children performing on Thursday evening at Danspace Project at St. Marks Church  notably, the adorable Ignacio Achugar-Granoff  offered some of the evenings most genuine encounters.

title: In a Dark Church, Nuances of Sound Turn Symphonic
description: Eleh, as he is called, walked down the aisle of Our Lady of Lebanon Cathedral in Brooklyn Heights after all the lights had been shut off and sat cross-legged before his equipment: an old Sequential Circuits analog keyboard synthesizer; a modular synthesizer about the shape of a large cash register, with red, yellow, orange, purple and black patch cables; and a hand-held digital multimeter to measure sound frequencies. You could see his outline only in the tiny readout lights of his gear. He is compact, of middling height and has short hair. Healthy. Maybe mid-30s.

title: Surging Brewers Beat Mets as Braun Hits Career-High 40th Homer
description: MILWAUKEE  Like many players who reach milestones, Ryan Braun tried to frame his accomplishments in the context of a victory. The Milwaukee Brewers needed to beat the Mets on Sunday afternoon to maintain their place in the clacking multicar train of the race for the second National League wild card, and Braun helped that along with two of Milwaukees three solo home runs off Chris Young in a 3-0 victory.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Temperley
description: The Look: Grace Kelly gone London rogue.

title: At Harlem Hospital, Murals Get a New Life
description: When the Works Progress Administration commissioned murals for Harlem Hospital Center in 1936, it easily approved the sketches submitted by seven artists, which depicted black people at work and at play throughout history. The hospital, however, objected, saying four of the sketches focused too much on Negro subject matter and that blacks may not form the greater part of the Community in years to come.

title: Time Travel With Einstein: Glasss Opera Returns to the Stage
description: As the audience milled into the Brooklyn Academy of Music for Saturday nights performance of Einstein on the Beach, an exhilarating revival of the pathbreaking 1976 opera by the composer Philip Glass and the director Robert Wilson, the piece seemed already to have started.

title: Itsy Bitsy Bit
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Welcome back to another week of puzzling! I always enjoy Mondays. Well, not the concept (getting up for work or school after a relaxing weekend), but the puzzles. It feels like a fresh start after wrestling with the increasingly difficult week, tackling the Friday and Saturday grids, investing time in the Sunday  and then, poof! All that is gone, and we have a nice, simple Monday puzzle to sail through. It restores my faith in humanity, I tell you.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released include the current account deficit for the second quarter (Tuesday); housing starts for August and existing home sales for August (Wednesday); and weekly jobless claims, the Philadelphia Fed index for September and leading economic indicators for August (Thursday).

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Jonathan Saunders: Spring 2013 RTW
description: London

title: A Future With Swords, Not iPhones
description: Armageddon comes in every shade of black: nuclear war, global warming, pandemic, alien invasion, zombie takeover or, even in some cases, a quirk of physics.

title: History Measured in War, Sex and Berets
description: The second volume of Ken Folletts Century Trilogy, Winter of the World, improves on Fall of Giants, the first. For one thing, it weighs in at 940 pages, which by Follett standards is concise. For another, it dispenses with some of the waxenness of its 985-page predecessor and breathes life into its fictional characters, many of whose parents appeared in the first book. The second-generation Winter of the World crew does enough procreating to ensure that Mr. Folletts third installment will be crowded too.

title: Distinguished Family Turns Out in Force
description: The name Sirota has been one to reckon with in New York musical circles for some years now. Nadia Sirota, a stellar young violist who has served as muse to prominent composers like Nico Muhly and Judd Greenstein, also cuts a high profile as a presenter on the Web-radio station Q2. Jonah Sirota, another violist and Nadias older brother, is a member of the respected Chiara String Quartet. The Rev. Dr. Victoria R. Sirota, Nadia and Jonahs mother, is an accomplished organist and the canon pastor of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

title: Womans Day Turns 75 While Looking Forward
description: A MAGAZINE that was introduced when the newest technology to reach consumers was the radio soap opera wants to demonstrate its relevance to readers  and advertisers  with a commemoration of its 75th anniversary that is focused as much on the present and future as the past.

title: The Puppetry of Quotation Approval
description: Now that its become clear that many journalists covering politics and government agree to quotation-approval as a condition of access, its tough not to see the pageant of democracy as just that: a carefully constructed performance meant to showcase the participants in the best light.

title: Selexicons: Your Contributions to That Should Be a Word
description: One of the great pleasures  and perils  of my That Should Be a Word column in The One-Page Magazine comes from the requests I receive to coin a word, generally stemming from an irritation that my suggestions, it seems, cannot mollify. (I need a word for that person who stands at the party with you and is just nodding  theyre not even listening! Okay  nodinage? No, thats not it!)

title: Kurdish Separatists Suspected After 8 Turkish Police Officers Are Killed in Blast
description: HATAY, Turkey  Eight police officers were killed and nine were wounded when a land mine exploded early Sunday in southeastern Turkey, the semiofficial news service Anatolian Agency reported.

title: Shock Value
description: Does art retain the power to shock? Must artists contrive to provoke? Join the discussion with artists, critics, reporters and readers.

title: Teachers Union in Chicago to Extend Strike Into 2nd Week
description: CHICAGO  The Chicago Teachers Union extended its strike into a second week on Sunday, after significant divisions emerged among union delegates over a deal that only a day before had been described by the unions leader as a good contract.

description: The arrival of the original iPhone in 2007 was a quantum leap for cellphones. Phones had never worked or looked like that.

description: MENDOTA, Calif.  Westside Grocery, serving this self-described Cantaloupe Center of the World since the 1940s, removed its gasoline pumps around 1980, the result of increased regulation. Fresh steaks and pork chops went by the wayside in the 1990s: too few could afford them.

title: Canada Auto Workers Chief Renews Threat Strike
description: OTTAWA  Despite making progress with the Ford Motor Company of Canada during contract talks over the weekend, Ken Lewenza, the president of the Canadian Auto Workers union, renewed his threat on Sunday to strike all three Detroit automakers.

title: Outside the Ring
description: Thirty years after the Korean boxer Duk-koo Kim died following his loss to Ray Boom Boom Mancini in Las Vegas, their families continue to heal.

title: London Fashion: Rethinking Luxury
description: LONDON  Its good to see Tom Ford nail down a hot look again. Two years ago he staged a private little show in his New York store, asking friends like Julianne Moore, Rachel Feinstein and Rita Wilson to model his first womens line since leaving Gucci and Yves Saint Laurent. It was a memorable night. Each outfit was a return-to-elegance occasion, as individual as the women involved, and Mr. Ford got a lot of press for withholding photos until the clothes arrived in stores. But then last fall he seemed to reprise styles from his YSL days. Editors expected more. So did Mr. Ford.

title: Patriot Game

title: Patriot Game

title: Online Mentors to Guide Women Into the Sciences
description: Hundreds of prominent women working in science, technology, engineering and math will become online mentors for college students next month, part of a six-week program to encourage young women to pursue careers in STEM fields.

title: New Territory for Ads, With a Moving Target
description: In the next month or two, subway and bus riders will find advertising where they have never seen it before: on the face of their MetroCards, always with them and inescapable  at least for that moment they pay their fare.

title: On Web, a Fine Line on Free Speech Across the Globe
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For Google last week, the decision was clear. An anti-Islamic video that provoked violence worldwide was not hate speech under its rules because it did not specifically incite violence against Muslims, even if it mocked their faith.

title: For a Fee, Streaming Local TV
description: On the ninth floor of an old tire factory in Downtown Brooklyn, Joe Lipowski, chief technology officer of a company called Aereo, proudly showed off a steel sheet covered with TV antennas.

title: Steelers and Errors Send Jets Offense Back to Reality
description: PITTSBURGH  It was perhaps inevitable that the Jets, whose surprisingly easy season-opening victory over the Buffalo Bills prompted at least one player to proclaim that the Jets had put the league on notice, would eventually slip back a bit toward the competition.

title: A Step Back
description: As a boy, Ray Mancini would pore over his fathers scrapbook, a collection of brittle-brown newspaper clippings and sepia-toned glossies, inevitably pausing to study the photograph of his father as a young fighter, his features bloodied and swollen, the right eye clenched shut like the seam of a mussel shell.

title: Beyond Obamacare
description: WE need death panels.

title: Karzai Denounces Coalition Over Airstrikes
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two of the most contentious issues dividing the United States and President Hamid Karzais administration re-emerged as the Afghan leader condemned American-led forces for killing eight women in airstrikes on Sunday and denounced his American allies for continuing to hold hundreds of Afghan prisoners.

title: Rallies Planned for Occupy Wall Street Anniversary
description: The crowd sat in a circle at the edge of Battery Park on Friday, as two young women held up a large map of the financial district that had been divided into sectors and marked with assembly points. They explained the plan for early Monday: protesters will gather at those points, then converge in an attempt to surround the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A Big Void, and Closing It Well
description: It has been 140 days since Mariano Rivera last threw a pitch, and the unspoken reality is that the Yankees have not missed him. For all of Riveras brilliance, the Yankees could not have expected him to do more than his successor has done.

title: London Fashion: Electric Millinery
description: LONDON  In a way, Philip Treacys hat show on Sunday night paid homage to the camp extravaganza that used to be common in London and Paris. The last great instigators were Alexander McQueen and Isabella Blow, both close friends of Mr. Treacys. He dedicated the show to them, and to Michael Jackson.

title: Where Daniel the Cuckold and Zig Zag Clown Vie for Office
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Batman is running for office in the Brazilian city of Uberlndia. Not one but two James Bonds are seeking city council seats, in Ponta Grossa and Birigui. Elsewhere in Brazil, voters are being urged to cast ballots for candidates with names like Daniel the Cuckold and Elvis Didnt Die.

title: An Unscenic Urban Walk: From Lower Manhattan to Kennedy Airport
description: The neighborhoods turn starkly at first, from the prix fixe brunches and kitchen appliance stores of the tours initial leg in Manhattan to the dominoes games and dimly lighted bars that follow.

title: Hating on Ben Bernanke
description: Last week Ben Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, announced a change in his institutions recession-fighting strategies. In so doing he seemed to be responding to the arguments of critics who have said the Fed can and should be doing more. And Republicans went wild.

title: Human Muscle, Regrown on Animal Scaffolding
description: PITTSBURGH  In the months after a roadside bomb in Afghanistan blew off part of his left thigh, Sgt. Ron Strang wondered if he would ever be able to walk normally again.

title: Extracellular Matrix
description: After 12 operations, Sgt. Ron Strang of the Marines was chosen for an experimental therapy to regrow some of his thigh muscle using a material called extracellular matrix, or E.C.M.

title: Declassified Documents Shed Light on a 1982 Massacre
description: Declassified documents reveal conversations between high-level American and Israeli officials before, during and after a massacre in Beiruts Sabra and Shatila refugee camps in 1982.

title: A Preventable Massacre
description: ON the night of Sept. 16, 1982, the Israeli military allowed a right-wing Lebanese militia to enter two Palestinian refugee camps in Beirut. In the ensuing three-day rampage, the militia, linked to the Maronite Christian Phalange Party, raped, killed and dismembered at least 800 civilians, while Israeli flares illuminated the camps narrow and darkened alleyways. Nearly all of the dead were women, children and elderly men.

title: Getting Your Prescriptions, Without a Prescription
The First Test for Albanys Ethicists
description: More than a year ago, Gov. Andrew Cuomo and New Yorks State Legislature passed a long-overdue ethics law to clean up Albany. The law contained one grave flaw, a supposedly independent Joint Commission on Public Ethics that is made up entirely of political appointees. The tangled controversy surrounding Assemblyman Vito Lopez has presented the commission with its first big test.

title: Republicans vs. Veterans Jobs
description: If you made a list of things lawmakers of both parties profess to value at all times  like jobs, opportunity, veterans, law enforcement, firefighters, safe streets, small business  and plugged them into a Congressional bill-writing app, you would probably end up with something like the Veterans Job Corps Act of 2012.

title: Giants Waiting Game Is a Work in Progress
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Seven months later, the Giants did better when it came to handling an opposing defense trying to let them score. But it still wasnt perfect.

title: Video Shows Libyans Retrieving Envoys Body
description: CAIRO  An amateur video that surfaced Sunday appears to show a crowd removing the motionless body of Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens from a window of the American mission in Benghazi, Libya, after it was attacked last week by Islamist militants, adding new details to reports that Mr. Stevens had died of smoke inhalation while locked in a safe room.

title: Scandal at Florida A&M Leaves a Football Season Without Its Soundtrack
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  It felt like family inside the football stadium at Florida A&M University on Saturday night. Old friends shouted greetings and delivered tight hugs; students clustered in the stands, snapping photos with their cellphones. Grandparents adjusted their orange cushions on the metal bleachers in more or less the same spots they had claimed for decades.

title: In Lebanon, Pope Laments Strife in Syria, Where the War Rages On
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Standing near what was once the dividing line of Lebanons bygone civil war, Pope Benedict XVI said a prayer on Sunday for the victims of the conflict in Syria, where the end is hard to see.

title: In Search of Excellent Teaching
description: The Chicago teachers strike was prompted in part by a fierce disagreement over how much student test scores will weigh in a new teacher evaluation system mandated by state law. That teachers unions in much of the country now agree that student achievement should count in evaluations at all reflects a major change from the past, when it was often argued that teaching was an art that could not be rigorously evaluated or, even more outrageously, that teachers should not be held accountable for student progress.

title: Eva Figes, Author and Feminist, Dies at 80
description: Eva Figes, a refugee from Nazi Germany who became an acclaimed novelist, memoirist and critic best known for an influential feminist treatise, Patriarchal Attitudes, published in 1970, died on Aug. 28 at her home in London. She was 80.

title: The Grand Old Straight White Mens Party
description: In a Time magazine column the other day, Joe Klein scolded the Democrats for being overly preoccupied with identity politics. In its admirable drive to be inclusive, he argued, the party has treated its constituents not as a population united by common ideals and interests, but as an array of caucuses to be pandered to: African-Americans, gays, Latinos, women, youth and so on. Klein wrote that if Im a plain old white insurance salesman, I look at the Democratic Party and say, Whats in it for me?

title: Amid Discord, Romney Seeks to Sharpen Message

Despite the balls having left Vicks hand cleanly, it was ruled a fumble rather than an incomplete pass. Maake Kemoeatu recovered for Baltimore.The dispute: The replay assistant challenged the ruling and it was reversed.

However, this was a celebratory occasion  to join him for the release of his latest book, Joseph Anton: A Memoir, in South Kensington.

title: Police Contain Afghan Rage Over Film, as Protests Spread Elsewhere

title: Jimmy Carters Brief Shining Moment

Of all the video clips linked here, the ones that struck me most were of former President Jimmy Carter, in September 1978, looking so vital at the Camp David peace accords, and then, just 10 months later, so deflated during his crisis of confidence speech. Its a dramatic example of history taking its toll on a president.

title: Should the Private Lives of Famous People Be Off Limits?
description: News broke last last week that paparazzi photographs of Kate Middleton, wife of Britains Prince William, had been taken while she sunbathed topless at a private villa in France. The photos, which appeared in tabloids in France, Ireland and Italy, appear to have been taken with a long-lens camera. Do you think public figures should expect to be ambushed by photographers, or should they be off limits when they arent in public?

title: Shell Stymied in 2012 Arctic Oil Quest
description: Saying that a spill response dome aboard a vessel has been damaged, Shell announced Monday that it would defer its plan to drill for oil in the Arctic off the Alaskan coast this year. In seeking approval to drill, the company fought a long battle against environmentalists and others who say that doing so in the pristine icy region is too risky. In a statement, Greenpeace claimed vindication and called Shells high-stakes program a monumentally reckless gamble. But the company says it will press on and seek a safety permit for the vessel next year.

title: Mission Viejo
description: In Panama Citys oldest standing neighborhood, the rooftops are bright red. Some are made of tile, in the style of the conquistadors who established the quarter in 1673, others of corrugated metal  temporary patches rusted crimson during decades of neglect. Together, they represent the storied past and seedy present of Casco Viejo, a neighborhood Panamanians call Casco and view as both a shrine and slum. These days, empty lots once home to squatters and stray dogs are giving way to valet parking, part of a process that may make the neighborhood more popular, if less compelling. Even hotel developers are torn.

title: The Bull Tied to Occupy Wall Street
description: With a full year having passed since it came into being, Occupy Wall Street is noting the moment in a manner that reflects one of the things it does best. It is celebrating itself.

title: Concord Conned, Etc.
description: Alec MacGillis has a long, interesting piece on the Paul Ryan phenomenon  on how Washington managed to convince itself that he was a Serious, Honest Conservative when he was nothing of the sort. Theres a lot of useful information in the piece. But Id question MacGilliss central thesis  namely, that Ryan was mainly exploiting the Beltways innumeracy.

title: As Chicago Strike Goes On, the Mayor Digs In
description: CHICAGO  As the president of the Chicago Teachers Union emerged from a meeting of her union delegates on Sunday night to announce that, no, school would not be starting up again and that, no, the delegates were not ready to sign off on what had seemed like a deal, Mayor Rahm Emanuel watched her on a television in City Hall.

title: Square Closes Financing Round
description: Square, the San Francisco-based mobile payments company led by the Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey, announced on Monday that it had closed its latest financing round.

title: A Fight to the Death to Commemorate Sherlocks Birth
description: You Downton Abbey enthusiasts who express your dedication to that show by gathering at parties, enjoying finger sandwiches and engaging in drinking rituals will have to step up your game, because the Sherlock Holmes fans have got you beat. BBC News caught up  with 70 members of the Sherlock Holmes Society (a group that claims more than 1,200 members worldwide) who celebrated the 125th anniversary of the novel in which Arthur Conan Doyle introduced his famous fictional consulting detective by traveling  in costume  to the waterfall in Switzerland where Holmes was believed, for a time, to have met his demise.

title: On Our Radar: Nuclear Plants and Flood Risks
description: An engineer within the Nuclear Regulatory Commission accuses its regulators of deliberately covering up information related to the vulnerability of nuclear power plants that sit downstream from large dams and reservoirs. [The Huffington Post]

title: What Were Reading
description: Smithsonian: A celebration of the oft-neglected fondue pot. If you still have yours kicking around in the closet, I encourage you to crack it out, because its a wonderfully social way to enjoy food.  Glenn CollinsThe Washington Post: To ease that arduous transition from summer to fall, Jason Wilson offers the McClelland Cocktail, made with real sloe gin. Why is it called the McClelland? If you know, tell us.  Eric Asimov

title: The Breakfast Meeting: YouTubes Balancing Act, and an App Aims for Stardom
description: Google rejected a request from the White House last week to pull The Innocence of Muslims from its YouTube service in light of the spreading protests of the video in the Muslim world. At the same time, it did temporarily block the video from Egypt and Libya, where the protests have been the most fierce  and that, in a nutshell, is the tricky situation Google faces in trying to fashion a policy on the acceptability of content viewed around the world, Somini Sengupta writes. Google quickly determined that the video  which depicts the Prophet Muhammad as a child molester and thug, among other things  did not violate its hate speech rules or any law, but nonetheless took it down in Egypt and Libya given the very sensitive situation there.

title: College, Still Worth It
description: Adam Looney and Michael Greenstone at the Hamilton Project have put together a beautiful chart illustrating once again why college is worth it, despite the current fad of claiming otherwise.

title: Trade Case May Produce Few Results
description: BEIJING  President Obamas trade case against China on cars and auto parts will have little immediate impact on jobs and companies in the United States, but it is one of the few legal options available to the United States as Chinas auto industry faces overcapacity problems and looks overseas to increase sales.

title: Truth Panel in Thailand Says Conflicts Are Festering
description: BANGKOK  An independent commission set up by the Thai government to investigate deadly clashes in Bangkok two years ago warned Monday that conflicts in Thai society were still simmering and that the country risked another escalation to violence.

title: Switching Contraceptives Effectively
description: The United States has one of the highest rates of unwanted pregnancies in the developed world  nearly half of pregnancies here are unintended, and theres been no improvement in the situation for a decade.

title: Why Kashmiri Muslims Blame America for Anti-Muslim Film
description: SRINAGAR Three young men picked a shady, grassy spot, out of earshot from the crowds bustling about the University of Kashmir campus, to talk on Saturday afternoon.

title: Chinese Company to Acquire DNA Sequencing Firm
description: Complete Genomics, a struggling DNA sequencing company in Silicon Valley, said on Monday that it had agreed to be acquired for $117.6 million by BGI-Shenzhen, a Chinese company that operates the worlds largest sequencing operation.

title: Photos of The Moment | Marios Schwab
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Five Ways to Teach the Constitution Through Current Events
description: Sept. 17 is Constitution Day, the day when the writers at the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia signed the United States Constitution in 1787.

title: Peter Pilotto: Spring 2013 RTW
description: London

title: Fire Hazard Prompts Ford to Recall 5,500 Edge Crossovers With 2-Liter EcoBoost
description: Ford recently informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration of its plan to recall almost 5,500 Edge crossovers from the 2012 model year equipped with 2-liter EcoBoost engines. Details of the action were included in a report posted to the Web site of the safety agency over the weekend.

title: Whats in a Label? Not Necessarily Sustainability
description: As consumers increasingly vote with their wallets for sustainable goods and groceries, producers are doing more to signal the eco-friendliness of their wares. But amid the many different certification logos, package designs and environmental claims, experts warn that all that glitters is not green.

title: The Times Needs a Policy on Quotation Approval, and Soon
description: David Carr wrote a great column in Mondays New York Times on the topic of news sources demanding that they approve quotations in stories. Mr. Carrs The Media Equation had the headline The Puppetry of Quotation Approval, and it laid out just what an unfortunate practice has developed. He wrote: Inch by inch, story by story, deal by deal, we are giving away our right to ask a simple question and expect a simple answer. It may seem obvious but it is still worth stating: The first draft of history should not be rewritten by the people who make it.

title: Introducing The Next Level: Can You Teach Entrepreneurship?
description: Talk about needing an exit strategy. I needed one from the humidity, heat and mosquitoes of the Okefenokee Swamp. But how does one go from Swamp Road in Waycross, Ga., to running a global company? Im sure there are other routes, but for me the fastest roads out were entrepreneurship and education.

title: Report Faults Militarys Strategies on Drug and Alcohol Abuse
description: Despite a well-documented increase in the abuse of alcohol and prescription medications among military personnel over the past decade, the Defense Departments strategies for screening, treating and preventing those problems remains behind the times, a major new report finds.

title: From Justice Thomas, a Little Talk About Race, Faith and the Court
description: WASHINGTON  Justice Clarence Thomas has not asked a question from the bench in more than six years, and he seldom appears in public in Washington, a city he says is full of cynics, smart alecks and people who have agendas rather than convictions.

title: Europes Discontent Over Austerity
description: Business Day Live: September 17th, 2012  Political progress in Europe, but popular discontent over austerity. | Corporate earnings start to falter. | Looking for the next daytime talk show star.

title: Image of the Day: September 17
Venus Williams Helps Kastles Repeat Team Title
description: She may not have won a singles title in 2012, but as Venus Williams watched Coco Vandeweghes final forehand fly long Sunday afternoon, the look on her face showed anything but disappointment. And unlike after any of her 43 career singles titles, Williams had an entire team mobbing her after championship point.

title: Business Day Live: Protesting Austerity Measures in Europe
description: Political progress in Europe, but popular discontent over austerity. | Corporate earnings start to falter. | Looking for the next daytime talk show star.

title: Pringle of Scotland: Spring 2013 RTW
description: London

title: Daily Report: The Future of Smartphones
description: The iPhone 5 that Apple introduced last week with only incremental changes seemed to signal that the industry has entered an era of technological bunny hops.

title: European Plan to Put More Women on Boards Runs Into Opposition
description: LONDON  A planned European Union law to impose sanctions on companies that do not allocate at least 40 percent of the seats on their boards to women has drawn enough opposition from Britain and other countries to risk being blocked before it is officially proposed.

title: Tips For Managing Your Increasingly Lumpy Income
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

title: Photos of The Moment | Acne
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Embracing a Bit of the Garden Variety
description: Looking back on the New York collections, one underlying theme that stood out among the younger set of designers was the embrace of collage. Designers like Kate and Laura Mulleavy of Rodarte were mixing fabrics in a single look, and Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez of Proenza Schouler specifically acknowledged the randomness of images on Tumblr as an influence of their photo print dresses.

title: Couscous Dinners, Ready When You Are
description: When I was researching my book Provenal Light, I went to Yom Kippur services at the Orthodox synagogue in Avignon for purely secular reasons: I wanted to sit upstairs with the women and eavesdrop on their discussions about what they had cooked for the meal to break the fast. If I was lucky, I would strike up a conversation and perhaps get an invitation to dinner. As it turned out, I was successful on both counts.

title: At Democratic Residence, Wallets Open for G.O.P.
description: The San Remo apartment building, a pair of ivory towers at the edge of Central Park, is one of the most sought-after addresses on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, which is as blue a political district as there is. So for the past few elections, the San Remo has been an A.T.M. for Democratic presidential campaigns, sometimes among the most generous addresses in the country.

title: Coachs No-Nonsense Ways Dont Translate in Malaysia
description: Peter Butler, a former West Ham United star, was a tough-tackling no-nonsense midfielder in the early days of the English Premier League, but he is taking on his biggest opponent yet  match fixing, corruption and unprofessionalism in Malaysian soccer. At least that is how he sees it. But not all in the country would agree.

title: Numberplay: Gas Stations
description: This weeks puzzle was suggested by frequent Numberplay contributor Marco Moriconi, who rates the puzzle moderately difficult.

title: Kovalchuk and Jagr Join Teams in Europe
description: The exodus of big N.H.L. stars to Europe accelerated Monday, the second day of the lockout.

title: Forest Fire Research Questions the Wisdom of Prescribed Burns
description: MISSOULA, Mont.  On a forested mountainside that was charred in a wildfire in 2003, Richard Hutto, a University of Montana ornithologist, plays a recording of a black-backed woodpecker drumming on a tree.

title: Christopher Kane: Spring 2013 RTW
description: London

title: Monday Motorsports: Ryan Hunter-Reay Rallies to Win IndyCar Championship
description: Though IndyCar fans were not treated to a wheel-to-wheel duel between Ryan Hunter-Reay, who entered the final race of the season 17 points from first place, and Will Power, the series leader, the finale to the 2012 IndyCar season was not without its nail-biting moments.

title: Whats Up With Quote Approval? A Call for Reporters and Sources to Weigh In
description: In Mondays Media Equation column, I wrote about the trend toward sources requiring quote approval, a practice that seems to be growing like kudzu.

title: Emmys Watch: Abi Morgan on The Hour and How West Wing Saved Her
description: We will be talking to Emmy nominees leading to the awards show on Sunday night. Previous entries in this series include Don Roy King, director of Saturday Night Live.

title: London Design Festival 2012
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Examining the Ubiquity of Private Equity
description: Jason Kelly, as a reporter at Bloomberg News, has been chronicling the moves of the worlds largest buyout shops and their billionaire founders long before the private equity industry became a political football in the presidential election.

title: Americas Bloodiest Day
description: In a letter to his wife, the Union general Alpheus Williams recorded his feelings on the eve of the fighting at Antietam Creek, Md. There was a half-dreamy sensation about it all, he wrote, but with a certain impression that the morrow was to be great with the future fate of our country. So much responsibility, so much intense, future anxiety. The morrow was indeed great  a pivotal moment in the struggle between North and South.

title: Romney Aide Concedes Campaign Has Been Short on Specifics
description: 7:27 p.m. | Updated  A top strategist for Mitt Romney conceded Monday that the campaign has not provided enough specifics about the candidates vision for the country and pledged a renewed effort in the last 50 days of the race to better communicate with voters.

title: Germany Making Jews Feel Unwelcome
description: BERLIN  A Jewish friend once told me something that I recalled when writing this weeks Letter from Europe about Germany and circumcision.

title: TimesCast | September 17, 2012
description: Anti-American protests spread to Lebanon and Afghanistan. | The first anniversary of Occupy Wall Street.

title: Baby Boomers Who Celebrate Birthdays This Week
description: Nothing makes the average baby boomer feel better than to know that a famous boomer is getting older, too. Of all the names on this weeks birthday list, I think Twiggy turning 63 is the hardest to keep in my mind alongside the image of the 1960s pixie model who looked about 12. Sept. 23 is Bruce Springsteens birthday. In an appreciation, Matt Richtel, a Times colleague, writes that one of the finest things about Mr. Springsteens music is his stories, which show, rather than tell. He let me fill in the blanks, interpret, reach my own conclusions about life, keep my dignity intact,' Matt writes. He turns 63 this week. A gift to us.

title: A Yearning for Springsteens Gift
description: The Rangers had a homecoming

title: Freedom From Facts
description: At the Values Voter Summit this weekend, Rick Santorum said that social conservatives would never have the elite smart people on our side. He also ruled out anyone who dedicates her life to teaching and research: our colleges and universities, theyre not going to be on our side.

title: Erdem: Spring 2013 RTW
description: London

title: Daytime Gold
description: Business Day Live  Reporters Brian Stelter and Bill Carter discuss this falls slate of new and returning talk shows all competing for big ratings and big salaries for their stars.

title: TimesCast | Cultural Clash Over Freedom
description: Protests about an anti-Islam film spread to Lebanon and Afghanistan.

title: First Anniversary of 'Occupy'
description: Colin Moynihan reports from New York Citys financial district on demonstrations on the anniversary of the start of the Occupy Wall Street movement.

title: Shell Delays Arctic Oil Drilling Until 2013
description: HOUSTON  With the prospect of rich new oil fields in tantalizing reach, Shell Oil announced on Monday that it was forced to put off completing wells in the Alaskan Arctic for another year after a spill containment dome was damaged during a testing accident.

title: Orca Mothers Coddle Adult Sons, Study Finds
description: Humans, pilot whales and killer whales are the only known species in which females have a prolonged period of menopause  a time of life when they cannot reproduce. Now, a study in the journal Science reports the purpose that menopause serves in orcas: for females to care for their sons and make sure their genes are passed on to future generations.

title: Better Eating, Thanks to Bacteria
description: SAY this about Sandor Ellix Katz: the man knows how to get you revved up to eat bacteria.

title: For Gastronomists, a Go-To Microbiologist
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

title: In Obesity Paradox, Thinner May Mean Sicker
description: A few years ago, Mercedes Carnethon, a diabetes researcher at the Feinberg School of Medicine at Northwestern University, found herself pondering a conundrum. Obesity is the primary risk factor for Type 2 diabetes, yet sizable numbers of normal-weight people also develop the disease. Why?

title: Photos of The Moment | Mary Katrantzou
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Jonas Abney joined Maxifier, New York, in a new post, vice president for United States sales. He had been head of publisher development and publishing operations at Zumobi. Maxifier is minority-owned by the Dentsu Digital Holdings division of Dentsu.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Sandor Katz Is Answering Your Fermentation Questions
description: He isnt a chef, but in recent years Sandor Ellix Katz has become one of the unlikely rock stars of the American food scene. At 50, the author of the Web site Wild Fermentation and the how-to guide The Art of Fermentation has emerged as an evangelist for the pleasures and health benefits of sauerkraut, kimchi, kefir, kvass, umeboshi plums and hundreds of other fermented delights.

title: Filing Trade Suit, Obama Raps Romney on China
description: CINCINNATI  President Obama, under renewed fire from Mitt Romney for not standing up to China on behalf of American workers, used a rally in this battleground state on Monday to announce a new trade case against Beijing. He said it was Mr. Romney who had sent jobs to China through his zealous practice of outsourcing at Bain Capital.

title: Adele Records the Theme for the New James Bond Film
description: Forget Adeles Grammy Awards and the fact that every teenage woman in the world knows the lyrics to most of her blockbuster album, 21. You know the singer has finally arrived because she has recorded the theme for the new James Bond film, Skyfall, according to the Total Film Web site.

title: Walkabout  9/17: Travelers to the Middle East Ponder Plans, and Students Go Abroad
description: Wait and See While protests against an American-made online video mocking the Prophet Muhammad continue in the Middle East, North Africa and South Asia, experts are not encouraging Americans to abandon their travel plans to those countries (except for Libya, which the State Department recommends avoiding). Rather, they suggest that travelers be patient while events unfold. (The Washington Post)

title: Myanmar Releases Hundreds of Prisoners
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Myanmars government said Monday that it was releasing more than 500 prisoners, the latest in a series of amnesties by President Thein Seins administration.

title: Welcoming Gretchen Rubin to the Motherlode Blog
description: One unexpected thing that makes Gretchen Rubin, author of The Happiness Project and Happier at Home, happy?

title: Examining Pre-Packaged Conventions
description: Politicians today live in the era of the sound bite, which may give way to the Twitter message (and then something else altogether)  either way, instantaneous news seems to be the only way our news is consumed now, and this ravenous cycle guarantees that stories sometimes fly by unnoticed, undigested.

title: An App to Help You Find Parking On the Spot
description: Parking Panda, an online service that helps you find and reserve parking spaces, has added the San Francisco market to its inventory and introduced a mobile app to help you find parking on the spot.

title: Why Little Bear Made Me Burst Into Tears
description: What kind of story would you like to hear? said Mother Bear.Tell me about me, said Little Bear. Tell me about things I once did.Else Holmelund Minarik, Little Bear

title: Brewing Obamas Ale, Step by Step
description: This month, after word got out that the White House was brewing its own beer, President Obamas staff released its recipe for White House Honey Ale. Diners Journal asked Garrett Oliver, the brewmaster at Brooklyn Brewery, to make a batch that we could sample and assess. And on Friday, Mr. Oliver started the brewing  a monthlong process that well occasionally drop in on, offering a glimpse of brewing both for those who know the art and for those who dont.

title: Stelter and Carter on This Falls Search for the Next Oprah
description: Katie Couric has begun a daytime talk show, joining a crowded field that is becoming more crowded with newcomers like Steve Harvey and Jeff Probst and a returning host like Ricki Lake. In this video clip, Brian Stelter and Bill Carter discuss the high rewards, and the high hurdles, to becoming a dominant figure in daytime television, as Oprah Winfrey once was.

title: Expanding Ball Toy Poses Hazard to Children and Pets
description: They are known as Water Balz, and at first glance they look like marbles: small and spherical, brightly colored. But these balls are made of superabsorbent polymer, and they are capable of rapidly expanding to the size of a racquetball when doused in water.

title: Were Not Perfect, a Synagogues Ads Proclaim
description: Madison Avenue loves to extol the perfection of products, from a whipped icing that is the perfect blend of fudge and vanilla to a luxury car that is devoted to the relentless pursuit of perfection. A new campaign, however, takes a much more modest tack by declaring, Were not perfect.

title: Look of The Moment | Astrid Bergs-Frisbey
description: The Look: In the Navy. A glittering drop-waist dress with a powder-white pouf skirt and coordinating collar and cuffs offers a lesson in how to wear nautical at night.

title: Silver Linings Playbook Wins Peoples Choice Award in Toronto
description: Silver Linings Playbook, the latest film from David O. Russell, received the BlackBerry Peoples Choice Award at the Toronto International Film Festival. The movie, based on a novel by Matthew Quick, stars Bradley Cooper and Jennifer Lawrence as unstable Philadelphians.

title: Really?: Adding Milk to Tea Destroys its Antioxidants
description: THE FACTS

title: House Tours in Manhattan and Brooklyn
description: Ten homes in Manhattan and Brooklyn will be open for tours on Oct. 6 and 7 as part of a collaboration between Dwell Media and New York Magazine to showcase New Yorks design and architectural talent.

title: Tip Sheet | 5 Ways To Find Your College Fit
description: Mim L. Runey is president of the Providence Campus and chief operating officer of Johnson & Wales University.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Mary Katrantzou
description: The Look: Blue-eyed Speedracer.The Makeup: A ballpoint-blue inky eye that feels like a tattoo, is how the makeup artist Val Garland described the look at Mary Katrantzou. To create this effect, she used a custom mix of M.A.C. Lipmix in a blue and a pinky red. One simple idea, Garland said. The rest of the face was M.A.C. mineralized foundation and a flesh-colored lip.

title: Chicago Board of Educations Request for Injunction Against the Chicago Teachers Union
description: Lawyers for the Chicago Board of Education have filed a motion seeking a legal injunction to end the teachers strike that has entered its second week.

title: When the Ice Melts
description: Q. Could the melting of ice at the poles affect the tilt and rotation of the Earth?

title: Wasps Find One Way to Support Humans
description: An Australian wasp provides an important service to humans, researchers report: It paralyzes a poisonous spider, the redback.

title: Where iPhone 5 Loses Its Way, Navigation Services Step In
description: In the battle between Googles Android smartphone and the Apple iPhone, free navigation is one of the most fiercely contested fronts. At least one area where Apple might have created a decisive advantage over Google has gone begging, however, in the latest generation of the iPhone, unveiled last week.

title: Trial Begins for Police Chief in Chinese Scandal
description: CHENGDU, China  The trial of the former police chief who was a key player in the fall of the politician Bo Xilai began in secret on Monday in this southwestern provincial capital, where he attempted to seek refuge in a United States Consulate in February.

title: Ground Breaker
description: In a scorching summer day in Marseille, France, the architect Rudy Ricciotti races down a dirt path in his battered black vintage Porsche and pulls up in front of a dusty construction site on the citys port-side docks.

title: Protests Over Anti-Islam Film Taper Off, but Effects Linger
description: Protests against an anti-Islam film spilled into a second week on Monday, although they appeared to be tapering off in size and taking place in fewer countries compared with last week.

title: Street Style: Saddlebags
description: The best of readers photos from the week of Sept. 10.

title: Long Wait and Worry for a Visitor to Yosemite
description: Bears were the only thing to worry about during our stay at a tent cabin in Yosemite National Park in August, or so my husband and I thought. We scrupulously emptied the car of food and anything a bear might mistake for food, including empty wrappers and scented items like soap. We cleaned every crumb of trail mix from our tent. We stashed everything that might attract a bear in metal lockers provided by the park.

title: Rushdie Relives Difficult Years Spent in Hiding
description: In 1989 the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini declared that Salman Rushdies novel The Satanic Verses was offensive to Islam and issued a fatwa against the author, sentencing him to death. For nine years Mr. Rushdie lived under the shadow of assassination, deprived of the freedom of ordinary life and made to fear for himself and his family. It was a nightmare weirdly like something out of one of his own surreal novels, and underscored the very themes hed been grappling with for years in his fiction: namely, the emotional costs of exile and being cut off from ones past; the consequences of globalization and the cultural clash between East and West; and the increasingly phantasmagorical nature of contemporary history.

title: Photos of The Moment | Jonathan Saunders
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Despite Lack of Surprises, Apple Sells 2 Million New iPhones
description: Apples announcement of its new iPhone 5 lacked surprises. Most of its secrets spilled ahead of introduction, but that didnt weaken early sales of the phone. People ordered more than two million iPhone 5s its first 24 hours on sale, double the previous record, held by the iPhone 4S, according to Apple.

title: Answers About Hostage Negotiation, Part 3
description: This is the third and final set of responses from Capt. Frank A. Bolz Jr., a founder of the New York Police Departments hostage-negotiating unit, to readers questions. We are no longer accepting questions.

title: Masks Come Off for 2 Callers Who Gave WBAI Grief
description: For decades, the liberal talk radio station WBAI has been hounded by a couple of conservatives calling in to taunt program hosts about their left-leaning politics and telling them in their thick Brooklyn accents to  and this was their stock phrase  Go back to Cuba, you commies.

title: Little Difference Seen in Asthma Strategies
description: There has been no general agreement on the best way to adjust the dosage of inhaled corticosteroids used by adults with asthma. Doctors determine the dose by assessing symptoms like lung function or by using biomarkers like exhaled nitric oxide, or they simply let patients decide how much is needed.

title: In Greece, Restlessness Amid a Push for Cuts
description: ATHENS  Public opposition to austerity budgets deepened in Greece on Monday, with judges stopping work, doctors going on strike and public transport staff and schoolteachers planning action for later this week. The moves are a prelude to a general strike called by the countrys main labor unions for Sept. 26.

title: U.S. Warns Judges Ruling Impedes Its Detention Powers
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration warned Monday that a judges ruling last week blocking a statute authorizing the indefinite detention of terrorism suspects has jeopardized its ability to continue detaining certain prisoners captured during the war in Afghanistan.

title: When Journalists Are Dying to Expose Environmental Plunder
description: Mike Shanahan, the press officer for the International Institute for Environment and Development and an energetic participant in the invaluable Earth Journalism Network, sent a compelling reaction to my piece on the brutal murder of an environmental journalist in Cambodia that is posted here as a Your Dot contribution:
