title: Burberry Prorsum: Spring 2013 RTW
description: London

title: Whom and What to Read to Make You Like Poetry (and Also Sci-Fi)
description: Stephen Burt, the Harvard professor and poet whom I wrote about in Sundays Education Issue, is a fanboy and an evangelist of poetry. As I wrote in the magazine, Burt defends his positivity by saying, Theres so little airtime available for any poetry these days that when I get space and time in which I can do whatever I want, I dont want to say, X sucks. I almost always prefer to say, Please check out Y, or Z isnt what you think, or Look at what A, B and C have in common.

title: Top Amateur in No Rush to Make Leap to Pros
description: HOYLAKE, England

title: Talking All Around the Food
description: YOU know a movie is in trouble when a voice-over narrator has to explain the plot that the combined efforts of screenwriter, director and editor failed to make clear. Something like that is going on at Eleven Madison Park, which just eliminated its $125 prix fixe option and now offers only one menu, a $195 blowout that lasts about four hours.

title: Deferred Prosecution Agreements and Cookie-Cutter Justice
description: Lanny A. Breuer, the head of the Justice Departments Criminal Division, last week spoke to the New York City Bar Association, extolling the virtues of deferred and nonprosecution agreements as the new standard for how the Justice Department deals with criminal conduct by corporations.

title: The Anthropocene as Environmental Meme and/or Geological Epoch
description: Paul Voosen, whos one of my favorite science journalists these days, has written a fine piece examining the scientific and societal debate over the Anthropocene, the proposed term for this era in which human decisions (or indecision) will leave a durable mark in planetary systems and even in the planets stratified rock.* (The video above explores the Anthropocene as environmental meme.)

title: Chaplin Off to Quiet Start at Broadway Box Office
description: The new Broadway musical Chaplin grossed a modest $460,925 in ticket sales in its first full week of performances since opening to largely negative reviews on Sept. 10, according to box office data released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade association of theater owners and producers.

title: Vasiliev Joins American Ballet Theater as Principal Dancer
description: American Ballet Theater has recruited Ivan Vasiliev as a principal dancer, and will cast him during next years season at the Metropolitan Opera and on tours, the company said on Monday. Mr. Vasiliev and the ballerina Natalia Osipova created a stir nearly a year ago when they announced they were leaving Moscows Bolshoi Ballet for the Mikhailovsky Theater in St. Petersburg. Mr. Vasiliev, who was born in 1989 in Vladivostok, Russia, made his debut at the Bolshoi in 2006 as Basilio in Don Quixote and made guest appearances at Ballet Theater last year. His roles with the company included Solor in La Bayadre, Franz in Copplia and Ali in Le Corsaire.

title: Metallica in London
description: I loved this shot during the finale at Jonathan Saunders, capturing the movement and shine of some sequined dresses. Get ready for more metallic tones from Burberry.

title: A Possible Breakthrough in Explaining a Mathematical Riddle
description: Numbers, addition, multiplication  the basic stuff of grade-school arithmetic  are suddenly the excited talk of cutting-edge mathematicians.

title: Patriots Injury Highlights a Receiving Shift
description: When Bill Belichick selected tight ends Rob Gronkowski and Aaron Hernandez two rounds apart in the 2010 draft, the rest of the N.F.L. took note. At the time, the New England offense rarely focused on the tight end, instead revolving around wide receivers like Randy Moss and Wes Welker.

title: Preparing to Tilt on Level Ground
description: Workers putting together Armor for the Joust of Peace, from about 1500, in the Great Hall at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Monday. The armor was bought by the Met in 1904, one of the museums earliest acquisitions. It has not been on display in nearly 25 years. Click here to see a larger version..

title: An Atom Smasher Is Squeezed Through a Museums Doors
description: If physics has to do with the actions and reactions of something, then this is about physics. But really it is about a thing  a thing that was at the heart of breakthrough physics experiments that led to the crash program for the atom bomb in World War II.

title: Richard Nicoll: Spring 2013 RTW
description: London

title: The Daily Shoe | Nicholas Kirkwood for Erdem
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: For Maimed Veterans, Animal Tissue Offers Hope of Repair
description: Thousands of veterans of the Iraq and Afghanistan wars have been maimed in explosions and have lost so much muscle from an arm or a leg that amputation is sometimes the best alternative. But in todays paper, our colleague Henry Fountain tracks a new treatment still in development that helped one Marine regain much of his lost mobility  using material from a pigs bladder.

title: An Extra Dose of N.F.L. Parity
description: There will be only six undefeated N.F.L. teams after Week 2 ends late tonight, with either Denver or Atlanta joining Houston, San Diego, Philadelphia, Arizona and San Francisco (provided that Denver and Atlanta dont produce a rare tie).

title: Driving Safety, in Fits and Starts
description: Auto fatalities have been falling for decades, but in a very interesting plateau-drop pattern.

title: Over 2,000 Miles, Hauling the Memory of the Mother Road
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. The Historic Highway Convoy 2012, consisting of 30 vintage trucks of modest and mighty proportions, had spent eight days and 2,000 miles on the road, tracing the remnants of Old Route 66, before rumbling into the Inland Empire on Saturday morning.

title: In the Studio | Peter Pilotto
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: London: Stripe Tease
description: Hardly any surprise that Mary Katrantzou and Peter Pilotto showed prints, but the spring affair with stripes continues across the pond. Mr. Pilottos stripes looked fragmented or blended with checks. Jonathan Saunders did straight-forward versions but also some lovely diagonal bands on silk dresses.

title: Dictionary Translates Ancient Egypt Life
description: Ancient Egyptians did not speak to posterity only through hieroglyphs. Those elaborate pictographs were the elite script for recording the lives and triumphs of pharaohs in their tombs and on the monumental stones along the Nile. But almost from the beginning, people in everyday life spoke a different language and wrote a different script, a simpler one that evolved from the earliest hieroglyphs.

title: The Citizens Have a Right to Know
description: Along with the very interesting comments on my piece about Californias Prop 37 came this letter, from the chairman of Stonyfield Organic:

title: Flying With Animals, Smiles All Around
The Real Romney
description: Oh, my. Mother Jones has what it says is a video of Mitt Romney talking to donors; it sure looks and sounds real. And it reveals a candidate who despises half the country:

title: The Mind and the Ear (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Drive or Fly? Depends on Your Tolerance for Risk
description: I HAD to travel to Southern California over the weekend, and I almost drove the 489 miles from my house in Tucson to my destination in Long Beach.

title: Not All Remedies Are Equal
description: To the Editor:

title: Check Mates | The Art of Chess at the Saatchi Gallery
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Corporate Events, on Campus
description: The description of the meeting center was effusive: The conference center has a million-dollar panoramic view of the Manhattan skyline that will leave you breathless.

title: My Grandmothers Cappelletti
description: 1:54 p.m. | Updated By the time I came along, both my mothers and my fathers families had been in the United States for two generations. I never felt particularly Italian, in spite of my very ethnic last name. Mine was not a family settled into an Italian-American enclave and gathered around weekly, shouting at one another in a style familiar from so many films, and eating pasta with the sauce they called Sunday gravy. No, they assimilated, and quickly.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Bad Piggies Trailer and Android App Art
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Exaggerating Your Race Results
description: It was my first half marathon, and I was anxious and jittery. I had never run more than 12 miles, and this race went on for 13.1. How was I supposed to hold a pace for that distance?

title: Google Buys Nik to Lure Photographers to Google Plus
description: Google said on Monday that it had acquired Nik Software, a company that makes tools for editing and sharing photos. It is Googles latest defensive move against Facebook and part of its strategy to become a photo-sharing hub.

title: An Operas Real Story Is Its Choreography
description: Although Einstein on the Beach, the 1976 collaboration between Robert Wilson and Philip Glass that is in revival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is labeled an opera in four acts, the tag that Mr. Wilson gave to some of his earlier theatrical works might also serve: dance play.

title: Hes Wild and Crazy, but a Subtle Guy, Too
description: No stand-up comic has arguably ever been bigger than Steve Martin. His albums sold in the millions. His act drew crowds in the tens of thousands. Critics adored him. Then, at the height of his success, he quit.

title: The Politics of Intimacy
description: Every election season is a reminder that the personal is political; now, in Michelle Clunies Us, a two-person play at the Lion Theater, we see how the political can be very personal indeed.

title: A Wave of Staggering Loss, in a Country Unprepared
description: PBSs American Experience can feel formulaic, but the episode on Tuesday, Death and the Civil War, makes itself wrenching and riveting by throwing out some of the formulas that have become familiar in documentaries about the war.

title: Suddenly There Came a Clapping
description: PHILADELPHIA  The last, distraught days of Edgar Allan Poe are charted with spellbinding vitality in Red-Eye to Havre de Grace, a highlight of the theatrical offerings at this years Live Arts Festival here. At times funny, at times heartbreaking, and from quirky start to haunting finish a feast of entrancing visual allurements, this exquisite show is among the most original musical theater works Ive seen in years.

title: Vaccines Power Wanes After Last Dose
description: Before age 7, children usually receive five doses of DTaP, the combination vaccine that protects against diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis. The acellular pertussis vaccine now in use has fewer side effects than the older whole-cell version.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Christopher Kane
description: The Look: Sleepwalking Beauty.

title: Be a Star, Then You Can Judge
description: Years from now, Christina Aguilera will be remembered for her glamour, her scandalous take on femme-pop and her Brobdingnagian voice. But she should also be remembered as the person who almost single-handedly reshaped music-competition reality programming. Her legacy as a judge on The Voice, on NBC, may well turn out to be deeper and more profound than the one shes forged in her music career.

title: Trauma: Manga as Medical Tool
description: In his unending quest to get surgeons to adopt a little-known generic drug to save hemorrhaging patients, a British doctor has produced a new medical-education tool: a manga comic.

title: Mariah Carey, Never a Fan of This Type of Thing, Tells How Idol Drew Her In
description: The new superstar-stocked judging panel of American Idol was already at work Monday auditioning hopefuls at Jazz at Lincoln Center in Manhattan for a second day, having begun on Sunday immediately after announcing its new additions for the season.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Afghanistan, India, Indonesia and South Korea.

title: Music From Pink, Dwight Yoakam and Aimee Mann
description: PINK

title: Village Voice Appoints a Music Editor
description: The Village Voice has named a new music editor, three days after it emerged that the weeklys editor was departing and its music editor had been fired.

title: Super PAC Makes Some Intriguing Bets on Romney
description: Mitt Romney may have had a bad run in polls in recent weeks, but he still has supporters who are bullish about his chances in some states that President Obama won handily in 2008.

title: Ford and Canadian Workers in Tentative Deal
description: OTTAWA  The Canadian Auto Workers union reached a tentative contract deal with the Ford Motor Company of Canada on Monday just hours before a midnight strike deadline.

title: Financial Strains Said to Threaten Stability of Palestinian Authority
description: JERUSALEM  As the Palestinian Authority marks the 19th anniversary this month of the signing of the Oslo Accords, the agreement with Israel that brought it into existence, the authority is facing a financial crisis that experts say could threaten its future operations and stability.

title: All the TV News Since 2009, on One Web Site
description: Inspired by a pillar of antiquity, the Library of Alexandria, Brewster Kahle has a grand vision for the Internet Archive, the giant aggregator and digitizer of data, which he founded and leads.

title: Christopher Kane Has a Gift for You
description: Shortly before the Christopher Kane show, in a high-rise near Oxford Street, the casting director Russell Marsh was playing Burt Lancaster to a bunch of blank-faced girls. He was giving them orders, drill-sergeant style, about not mussing up their clothes. Mr. Marsh probably gives such instructions routinely, but the spring collection of Mr. Kane was visibly delicate  in tissue paper-like silks and crepes, and in pale sugary pinks, yellow and dead white.

title: Iranian Cleric Says Rushdies Murder Could Stop Insults to Islams Prophet
description: As my colleague Michiko Kakutani explains in her review of the novelist Salman Rushdies new memoir, an Iranian religious foundation reportedly raised the price on his head over the weekend to $3.3 million. The cleric who leads the foundation claimed that Mr. Rushdies murder would stop others from disrespecting Islams founder, The Associated Press reported from Tehran.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Burberry
description: The Look: Sunny English girl thrown into the 40s.

title: In Video Clip, Romney Calls 47% Dependent and Feeling Entitled
description: 12:26 a.m., Sept. 18 | Updated

title: Seeking Positives on a Final Homestand
description: The Mets returned to Citi Field on Monday to start one last homestand in a season that has wandered well off track.

title: Photos of The Moment | Burberry Prorsum
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Grappling With Details of Medicare Proposals
description: When Claire Celsis father-in-law died in July, the one thing her mother-in-law did not have to worry about was the $300,000 hospital bill. Medicare covered most of it.

title: Liu Supporters Invoke the Holocaust and Nixon in Faulting an F.B.I. Inquiry
description: A former congressman on Monday called the federal investigation into the fund-raising practices of John C. Liu, the city comptroller, a Nixonian form of harassment and persecution.

title: Baseballs 500,000th Error Finds Jose Reyes
description: As baseball approached its unofficial 500,000th error, one thing was clear: a shortstop would most likely make it, since that position is most closely associated with the statistic.

title: A Childs Cancer Story Inspires Taylor Swift
description: By now you may have heard Taylor Swifts heart-rending song Ronan, about the too-short life of a little boy. Ms. Swift gave it an emotional performance on the Stand Up to Cancer telethon on Sept. 7, and it has been topping the charts ever since.

title: Congressional Republicans Raise Questions About New York Investigations
description: Congressional Republicans on Monday issued a letter to Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York attorney general, raising questions about his investigations into private equity firms and politically active tax-exempt groups.

title: Burberry: View From a Bridge
description: Christopher Bailey may have opened the Burberry show with a creamy white cape over a pleated silk bodysuit  the perfect outfit for a bareback circus rider  but a trench coat remains the main event at the British company. In a collection called Corsets and Capes, Mr. Bailey gave a clean, tighter, sensual line to his many coats (including a style that bled from red into pink), cute satin shorts and handsome lace dresses. The winners were the sleek trenches in leather, satin or micropleated satin, though perhaps the optimistic colors  inky blue, fuchsia, copper, pink, lipstick red  were the centerpiece of a polished, newsy show. You half wondered if London, seen from a Thames River bridge at night, was the inspiration for the jewel palette.

title: Assembly Releases Documents Listing Sexual Harassment Settlement
description: ALBANY  The State Assembly on Monday released a list of its 2012 expenditures from the part of its budget that was used to pay a secret sexual harassment settlement this summer.

title: Catholics Then, Muslims Now
description: Toronto

title: Maverick Minister in India Is as Perplexing as She Is Powerful
description: KOLKATA, India  When Mamata Banerjee, a 5-foot-tall dynamo in flip-flops, finally defeated the Communists last year after decades of misrule here, she became one of the most powerful but unpredictable politicians in India. Now the country is left to guess whether she will announce on Tuesday that she intends to try to pull down Indias governing coalition.

title: Newsweeks Muslim Rage Cover Mocked Online
description: CAIRO  After a week of violent protests over an online video demeaning the Prophet Muhammad, the American news media has conducted a searching psychoanalysis of the Muslim mind to ask why such an offense should trigger such wrath. Essayists have generalized about resentments dating back to the 8th century, an anachronistic discomfort with modernity, or the excesses of Islamist politics, among other familiar themes.

title: Czechs See Peril in a Bootleg Bottle
description: PRAGUE  The Czech Republic has banned the sale of liquor containing 20 percent or higher alcohol content after at least 20 people were killed and dozens of others were seriously injured from consuming methanol-tainted spirits.

title: Louis Simpson, Poet of Everyday Life, Dies at 89
description: Louis Simpson, a Pulitzer Prize-winning poet who told characteristically American tales of common people and often cast a skeptical eye on the American dream, died on Friday at his home in Stony Brook, N.Y. He was 89.

title: My Grandmother's Cappelletti
description: To teach a cousin too young to learn to make cappelletti and ravioli from my grandmother, our family created a video recipe, and a memory.

title: Savoring Success by Expanding the Brand
description: AS savings accounts shrank in recent years, spice racks expanded, with Americans cooking more to save money.

title: Success of Crowdfunding Puts Pressure on Entrepreneurs
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  An effort to build a sleek aluminum charging dock for the iPhone generated fervor online when it was announced last December. The projects creators raised close to $1.5 million through Kickstarter, a crowdfunding Web site, and promised to start shipping their Elevation Dock in April to those who had backed the project.

title: Manhattans Power Breakfast Must Move
description: The breakfast room at the Loews Regency Hotel has long been a favorite forum for New Yorks political elite. But is that daily gathering of power brokers over $24 omelets and $8 coffees a movable feast?

title: In a School Built on Trust, Metal Detectors Inject Fear
description: It looms inside the door of the school on Palmetto Street, a hunk of metal and a rubber belt. Innocuous, right?

title: Breaking Up the Echo
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Maneuvering in an Unsettled Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Occupy Wall Street: A Frenzy That Fizzled
description: It will be an asterisk in the history books, if it gets a mention at all.

title: Pennsylvania: Board Denies Clemency
description: Pennsylvanias Board of Pardons in Harrisburg denied on Monday an application for clemency by Terrance Williams, a convicted murderer who is scheduled to be executed on Oct. 3. Clemency requires unanimous approval by the five-member board, and the vote was only 3 to 2 in favor of the application. Shawn Nolan, Mr. Williamss attorney, argued that Mr. Williams had been beaten and sexually abused during childhood, and had killed Amos Norwood in Philadelphia in 1984 after the victim sexually abused him from the age of 13. Tom Dolgenos of the Philadelphia district attorneys office said the allegations of sexual abuse were hearsay raised by Mr. Williams years after his 1986 trial in an attempt to prevent the execution. Mr. Williams is now seeking a stay of execution in a state court.

title: Israeli Diplomat Is Man in Middle
description: WASHINGTON  With Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel engaged in an unusually public dispute with the Obama administration over Iran, Mr. Netanyahus man in Washington, Michael B. Oren, has been working rooms all over town.

title: Friends You Can Count On
description: You spend your time tweeting, friending, liking, poking, and in the few minutes left, cultivating friends in the flesh. Yet sadly, despite all your efforts, you probably have fewer friends than most of your friends have. But dont despair  the same is true for almost all of us. Our friends are typically more popular than we are.

title: Scream to Go on View at MoMA
description: Edvard Munchs 1895 version of The Scream  which became the most expensive artwork ever sold at auction when it brought nearly $120 million at Sothebys in May  will go on view at the Museum of Modern Art, courtesy of its new mystery owner, for six months, starting on Oct. 24.

title: Libya, Violence and Free Speech
description: Back when Salman Rushdie was made the object of a fatwa because his book The Satanic Verses was regarded by many Iranians as a blasphemy against the prophet, I went to a conference where a panel discussion was devoted to Rushdies situation. A member of the audience raised his hand and, without a trace of irony, asked, Whats the matter with those Iranians? Havent they ever heard of the First Amendment?

title: Massachusetts: Health Official Resigns
description: The commissioner of the Massachusetts Department of Public Health, John Auerbach, resigned on Monday amid allegations that a chemist at a state drug laboratory mishandled evidence samples, potentially affecting 34,000 criminal cases. Gov. Deval Patrick ordered the laboratory shut down late last month as prosecutors, the state police and the state attorney generals office investigate whether Annie Dookhan, a chemist, breached protocol, potentially causing wrongful convictions in state cases. Mr. Auerbach is the most senior official to step down in the scandal; last week, the laboratorys director resigned and another official there was fired.

title: Speaking the Truth to the Vatican
description: After years of drug addiction, serial theft and hard prison time, a 54-year-old mother named Renee is entering a revolutionary phase of her life  transition from a rehabilitation sanctuary in Coney Island to the possibility of self-reliance in the outside world. The sanctuary is one of several outposts of Providence House, a recovery program run by the Sisters of St. Joseph, a society of street-tough, adaptive New York nuns. The program has nurtured more than 12,000 women parolees and their children back from the brink.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Pier to Pay for a Park
description: New Yorkers cherish their access to the piers and green spaces that make up the Hudson River Park, which stretches from Pier 99 near 59th St. to Battery Place. Established by state law in 1998, the park gives urbanites a chance to stroll along one the nations great rivers.

title: Voters Annoyed by Hard-to-Read Ballots
description: Some states want their voters to take ID cards to the polls.

title: Chicago Standoff
description: The Chicago teachers strike should serve as an object lesson about the dangers of incendiary language in labor negotiations. The strike, which appeared to be near settlement over the weekend, has continued after angry union delegates failed to vote to return to work on Sunday. The dispute need never have reached this point, with 350,000 students starting a second week out of classes.

title: Iranian Official Says Blasts Targeted Nuclear Sites
description: WASHINGTON  Irans most senior atomic energy official revealed on Monday that separate explosions, which he attributed to sabotage, had targeted power supplies to the countrys two main uranium enrichment facilities, including the deep underground site that American and Israeli officials say is the most invulnerable to bombing.

title: Stuck in the Present, Mets Look to the Future
description: Something big was brewing at Citi Field on Monday. At least that is how it looked. The Mets installed three rows of temporary seats behind the backstop, on either side of home plate, the way they did at Shea Stadium for the playoffs and World Series. There were so many folding chairs and so much plexiglass that you almost expected the league president to ask for Jay Howells glove.

title: Russell E. Train, Conservationist Who Helped Create the E.P.A., Dies at 92
description: Russell E. Train, a renowned conservationist who played a central role in the creation of groundbreaking laws and effective enforcement in response to rising concerns about environmental protection in America, died on Monday at his farm in Bozman, Md. He was 92.

title: Professors and the Students Who Grade Them
Football Concussions
description: To the Editor:

title: Protecting the Gulf Coast
description: To the Editor:

title: Deterring Cyberthreats
description: To the Editor:

title: Bucs Schiano Defends Final Play of Loss to Giants
description: Through Pop Warner, high school and college, football players are coached to compete until the final whistle and take nothing for granted. Greg Schiano instilled that kind of fight into his teams in turning around a downtrodden program during his 11 years at Rutgers. He has said he intends to bring that never-say-die philosophy to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in his first season as their coach.

title: Widow Takes On Congressman Who Ousted Her Husband
description: Shelley Adler was still mourning her husbands death when the thought hit her: Why not run for his old Congressional seat? But when she approached her husbands longtime political adviser and close friend, he gently discouraged her.

title: Restoring the Walls, and the History, at Hitlers Wolfs Lair
description: KETRZYN, Poland  For nearly three years, Hitler commanded the Third Reich from a vast network of bunkers and buildings hidden in the forest here, guiding his genocidal war effort from an encampment called the Wolfs Lair.

title: On a Challenging Day, Romney Seeks to Shift to His Policy Specifics
description: An effort by Mitt Romney to give his campaign new direction  built around new ads intended to highlight how a Romney presidency would take the nation on a better course than President Obama  was quickly overshadowed on Monday by the video of Mr. Romneys unscripted remarks at a fund-raiser several months ago.

title: New Yorks Medicaid Reforms
description: New York State has substantially changed its Medicaid program in the past year and a half in ways likely to improve the health of its poorest residents and rein in the programs enormous costs.

title: M.T.A. Chiefs Latest Bold Move: Using Twitter by Himself
description: It began inconspicuously enough  a Ronald Reagan quote here, a whiff of harmless promotion there  the mark of a seasoned city official wading cautiously into social media.

title: Jets Turn Backs on a Game That Slipped Right Through Their Hands
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  On the ninth play of a 14-play drive that ate up more than 10 minutes of the fourth quarter, Pittsburgh running back Isaac Redman took a handoff and proceeded to shrug off what seemed like half the Jets defense. His right knee appeared to scuff the grass at Heinz Field while he was trapped in the backfield, and safety Yeremiah Bell wrestled the ball from Redman as he made the tackle. After an officials review, the Steelers kept the ball, and Redman got 6 yards.

title: Look How Far Weve Come Apart
description: In the witches brew of fearmongering, unkeepable promises and poll-tested metaphors that both parties serve up to the electorate every four years, you can always find this predictable dash of inspiration: the image of Americans uniting and working together for the sake of the country. President Obama said in Charlotte, N.C. that America is about what can be done by us, together. In Tampa, Paul Ryan said, Whatever your political party, lets come together for the sake of our country. And Mitt Romney closed his convention speech with three invocations of That America, that united America.

title: Thurston Howell Romney
description: In 1980, about 30 percent of Americans received some form of government benefits. Today, as Nicholas Eberstadt of the American Enterprise Institute has pointed out, about 49 percent do.

title: How to Fix the Schools
description: No matter how quickly the Chicago teachers strike ends, whether it is this afternoon or two months from now, its not going to end well for the citys public school students. Yes, I know; thats the hoariest of clichs. But that doesnt mean its not true.

title: College English Dept. Fights Class-Time Cuts
description: When members of the English department at Queensborough Community College voted last week against a plan to curtail their basic writing courses to three hours a week from four, they said they wanted to send the school a message: We support our students, Elise Denbo, a lecturer in the department, said Monday. Sometimes they need extra time.

title: Pettitte Rejoins Jeter in Another Stretch Run
description: When the Yankees trotted onto the field to celebrate another victory in their ritual hand-slapping conga line on Sunday, Andy Pettitte grabbed Derek Jeter from behind in a bear hug, and the two players, both dealing with injured left ankles, laughed as they headed to the clubhouse.

title: For Young Jews, a Service Says, Please, Do Text
description: MIAMI BEACH  Settling into their seats for Rosh Hashana service, the twentysomethings instinctively reached for their cellphones to turn them off, anticipating an admonition they hear often at synagogue.

title: Stop Fretting
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  If you grew up when I did (Im not going to be specific, but I will say that I am old enough to have been a devoted fan), you werent a fan of the rock and roll music unless you owned, played, memorized the liner notes of, and basically worshipped the album Led Zeppelin IV. This was the iconic album that contained the song STAIRWAY TO HEAVEN, which became the song of a generation and is celebrating the 40th (now 41st) anniversary of its release in November of 1971.

title: Cond Nast Plans French Vanity Fair
description: Vanity Fair magazine, which has been battling declining newsstand sales in the United States, is looking for more readers in Europe. Next year, Cond Nast is starting a monthly edition of Vanity Fair in France. The magazine will share the name of the American publication, but nearly 90 percent of the content will be original.

title: Gaza: Hamas Court Convicts 4 in Murder of Activist
description: A Hamas military court on Monday convicted four Palestinians of taking part in the 2011 kidnapping and killing of a pro-Palestinian Italian activist in the Gaza Strip. Two of the defendants received life sentences for kidnapping and killing the activist, Vittorio Arrigoni, in April 2011. A third man was sentenced to 10 years for taking part in the kidnapping, and a fourth defendant was sentenced to a year for sheltering the kidnappers, said Khalil Shahin of the Palestinian Center for Human Rights. At the time, an extremist Salafist group claimed responsibility for kidnapping Mr. Arrigoni, 36, and demanded that Hamas release all Salafists from its prisons. Mr. Arrigoni was found dead before the kidnappers deadline had expired. The suspects were later captured by Hamass security force. Mr. Arrigoni was a member of the International Solidarity Movement, a pro-Palestinian activist organization with foreign volunteers in the West Bank and Gaza.

title: Mets, Unable to Help Dickey to His 19th Win, Continue to Struggle at Home
description: The Mets have returned to Citi Field, where they will have roughly a week and a half to leave some sort of lasting positive impression upon their fans before the off-season.

title: One Day, Growing Spare Parts Inside the Body
description: LOS ANGELES  Dr. Tracy Grikscheit held a length of intestine in her gloved hands, examining it inch by inch as if she were checking a bicycle tube for leaks.

title: Behind the People Who Pay No Income Tax
description: Mother Jones has published a video of Mitt Romney at a private fund-raiser making incendiary remarks about Obama voters  and, well, about half of the electorate.

title: Parking Rules
description: On Tuesday, because of Rosh Hashana, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Gulati Talks About New Womens Coach and New Womens League
description: U.S. Soccer president Sunil Gulati said Monday that he wants to have a coach in place for the womens national team before Halloween, and that there is a still chance there will be a new league for the teams players to work in as soon as next spring. Completing the first task, it seems, will be much easier.

title: Last Chapter for a Court With a Place in History
description: MERIDIAN, Miss.  Across the street from a barbershop and upstairs from a post office sits a big empty room where Mississippi once began to face up to itself.

title: Polls: Warren Ahead in Massachusetts
description: Despite criticism of her campaign by some of her Democratic allies, Elizabeth Warren may be gaining ground in her bid to unseat Senator Scott P. Brown of Massachusetts, two new polls suggest.

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 17
description: A view of the day in sports, including cycling, baseball and a bit of nasty weather over Wrigley Field.

title: Bomb Threat Empties a Fourth Campus
description: Thousands of people were evacuated from the campus of Louisiana State University in Baton Rouge on Monday after a bomb threat, the fourth such evacuation on a college campus in four days.

title: Science Times Podcast
description: A people-friendly robot for the workplace, a dictionary for an ancient Egyptian language, and hantavirus exposure.

title: Limits Placed on Immigrants in Health Care Law
description: WASHINGTON  The White House has ruled that young immigrants who will be allowed to stay in the United States as part of a new federal policy will not be eligible for health insurance coverage under President Obamas health care overhaul.

title: Romney Responds to Release of Secret Video
description: What follows is a transcript, as recorded by The New York Times, of remarks by Mitt Romney discussing a newly released, secret video of him speaking to campaign donors. Mr. Romney addressed reporters in Costa Mesa, Calif., on Monday night:

title: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Back to Square 1
description: Chronic fatigue syndrome is not caused by a mouse retrovirus, according to a study initiated by the National Institutes of Health to settle what had become a contentious scientific question.

title: Word of the Day | transcribe
description: transcribe \tran(t)-skrib\ verb

title: A Robot With a Reassuring Touch
description: BOSTON  If you grab the hand of a two-armed robot named Baxter, it will turn its head and a pair of cartoon eyes  displayed on a tablet-size computer-screen face  will peer at you with interest.

title: The Co-Worker of the Future
description: The new frontier in robotics is machines like this one, named Baxter, which is designed to work alongside humans safely and cheaply.

title: Corrections: September 18, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: In Car Country, Obama Trumpets China Trade Case
description: CINCINNATI  In a vivid display of the powers of incumbency, President Obama on Monday filed a broad new trade case against China at the World Trade Organization, announcing the action in this industrial battleground where Mitt Romney has pressed his argument that the president has not done enough to protect American workers.

title: Kansas Board Officially Puts End to Obama Ballot Challenge
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  A challenge toPresident Obamas eligibility to appear on the Kansas ballot officially ended on Monday after a state board adjourned without ruling because the objection had been withdrawn last week.

title: Suicide Bomber in Afghanistan Strikes Minibus, Killing Mostly Foreign Workers
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber killed 14 people on Tuesday, including 10 foreigners, most of whom worked as flight crew members under contract with the United States government, officials said. The attack brought to at least 28 the number of deaths attributed to unrest sweeping the Muslim world as a result of a video parodying the Prophet Muhammad.

title: News Quiz | September 18, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: A Conversation With: Haryana Chief Minister Bhupinder Singh Hooda
description: NEW DELHI Bhupinder Singh Hooda has been chief minister of Haryana since 2005, and is currently serving his second term. The state, which hugs Indias capital, is said to be the site of the epic battle described in the Mahabharata; it is now home to just over 2 percent of Indias people, some 25 million.

title: Champions League: A Seasoned Dortmund Starts Fresh
description: Sixteen years is a long time in soccer. Between one decade and the next, players, coaches or even entire teams and leagues that came to dominate and influence the very sport have to eventually accept the simple facts of fate and step aside as time picks its next champion. On Tuesday, Borussia Dortmund hosts Ajax in their first Champions League encounter since a fateful quarterfinal in 1996, during a forgotten time when both clubs were considered big players in Europes premier competition. Today, both sides will be hopeful of three points, and another shot at European success.

title: Benetton Ads Address Youth Unemployment by Offering Help to Unemployees
description: For decades, Benetton, the Italian apparel retailer, has been known for provocative advertising that attracts publicity by stirring up discussion of contentious topics like politics, religion and the treatment of AIDS patients.

title: Smartphone Technology Pushes Forward
description: WHEN did the first iPhone (a quantum leap for cellphones) first arrive?

title: Test Yourself | English, Sept. 18, 2012
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article In Nepal, After Revolt, Art Was Changed Forever.

title: Dole Food to Sell 2 Businesses to Itochu for $1.7 Billion
description: TOKYO  Dole Food will sell its packaged foods and Asian fresh fruit businesses to the Japanese trading house Itochu Corporation for $1.7 billion in cash.

title: Purple Haze and Radical Ways
The Readers Always Write
description: Starting up a new feature like the Booming blog, were very interested in hearing comments from you, the readers, about what you like and what you dont. The good news is you liked most of the new features weve created and responded with hundreds of comments. The bad news  at least for me  is many of you would like to tear me from limb to limb for what I wrote about boomers and millennials.

title: How to Solve the Swing-State Puzzle
description: When I first considered Barack Obamas re-election chances in this magazine, last November, he was about a 50-50 contender against the Republican field. As I noted then, this was an unusual spot for a sitting president. A year before their own re-election races, Roosevelt, Eisenhower, Nixon, Reagan, Clinton and both Bushes were all favored. One year out, it seemed as if things could break either way for the president in 2012.

title: Visions of a Blind Photographer
description: Sometimes when shes taking pictures, Sonia Soberats forgets she cannot see.

title: Do Great Leaders Have to Be Outgoing?
description: This is the question asked in a recent Opinion piece that compared Bill Clinton, a famous extrovert, with Barack Obama, an introvert, and suggested that introverts make great leaders, too.

title: Somalias New Man
description: One of Hassan Sheik Mohamuds inaugural acts as president of Somalia was to survive an assassination attempt. After winning a decisive vote among parliamentarians last Monday, Mohamud took the helm of the long-suffering state. On Wednesday, a wave of explosions and gunfire struck the hotel in Mogadishu where he was meeting with Sam Ongeri, the foreign minister of neighboring Kenya. While the dignitaries survived, eight others were killed.

title: Breaking Down Victor Cruzs 80-Yard Touchdown
description: Throughout the season, Ill break down a big play from each week. In the Giants 41-34 win over Tampa Bay on Sunday, there was no play more vital than Eli Mannings 80-yard touchdown strike to Victor Cruz. Lets take a look.

title: Coalition Sharply Reduces Joint Operations With Afghan Troops
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In a significant blow to a core element of the Western exit strategy from Afghanistan, the American-led military coalition said Tuesday that it had temporarily curtailed joint operations with the Afghan Army and police forces.

title: Pakistani Government Relents in Judicial Standoff Over Zardari Corruption Case
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  After months of legal battles, Pakistans government relented on Tuesday to judicial demands that it agree to write a letter to the authorities in Switzerland regarding corruption charges against President Asif Ali Zardari.

title: Some Big Corporations Dont Pay Taxes, Either
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: A Start-Up Figures Out Photoshop Abuses
description: Hany Farid, a professor at Dartmouth College, has built a career and a reputation as a leading researcher in digital image forensics. He has made software tools for a number of impressive projects in recent years. One was a pixel-sleuthing program to detect how much fashion photographs have been burnished with Adobes Photoshop editing program to remove wrinkles and flab, while plumping up lips and breasts. Another was software for the automated detection of child pornography on the Web to help law enforcement agencies.

title: The Early Word: Executive Privilege
description: Todays Times

title: More Protests in China Over Japan and Islands
description: BEIJING  China drove home its opposition to Japanese control of a contested group of islands on Tuesday, with angry protests in dozens of cities and a warning from its defense minister that further actions were possible.

title: Fantasy Focus: The Cream of Next Years Crop
description: Its never too early to contemplate next years draft board, and with only two weeks to play, I dont suspect it will change all that much between now and the end of the year. (All statistics are through Sunday.)

title: As Uncertainty About Bailout Lingers, Spain Sells $6 Billion in Short-Term Debt
description: LONDON  Spain took advantage of improved bond-market sentiment in the euro zone to sell government debt on Tuesday, but questions still lingered about whether, or when, it would seek European help to lower its borrowing costs.

title: With Replacement Refs, Is N.F.L. Making Mockery of the Game?
description: Its not working. Anyone who watched the Falcons-Broncos game on Monday night could see that. The replacement officials are not at fault; the N.F.L. has put them in an almost impossible situation.

title: Lenovo to Buy Cloud Computing Company
description: Lenovo, the personal computer maker, said on Tuesday that it would buy Stoneware, a maker of cloud-computing software, as the frenzy for cloud-based technologies continues.

title: How the Romney Campaign Scrambled to Respond to Secret Video
description: COSTA MESA, Calif.  Around 4 p.m. here on Monday, an aide to Mitt Romney, Garrett Jackson, showed the candidate a grainy video that had been circulating online all afternoon.

title: Not My (Only) Kid
description: BEIJING  Coming out as gay is tough almost the world over. In China, it can constitute a major tragedy.

title: Why Should Readers Buy the Sunday Paper if They Can Read It on the Web First?
description: From time to time on this blog, Ill publish a provocative question from a reader and ask someone from The Timess newsroom to respond.

title: A Business Owner Expects the Worst From Health Insurance Overhaul
description: The Supreme Court decision upholding most of the Affordable Care Act came as a blow to Kurt Summers, a small-business owner in Austin, Tex. Soon after the decision was announced, he warned his fellow citizens, through the auspices of The Washington Post, that unless we elect officials to both Congress and the White House who understand the importance of small business and who will return some sanity to Washington  and repeal the health law  he will most likely have to postpone his considerable ambitions for his company.

title: Number Trouble
description: Heres another roundup of setbacks and slips in our continuing struggle to make verbs agree with their subjects and pronouns with their antecedents.

title: Tuesday Reading: Exaggerating Your Race Results
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Sept. 17: Electoral College May Not Help Obama
description: The FiveThirtyEight presidential forecast for Monday was essentially unchanged, with President Obama having a 74.8 percent chance of winning another term. Taken on the whole, Mondays data was consistent with the current story the forecast model is telling about the race, which is that Mr. Obamas polls have declined slightly from their post-convention highs, but are also still slightly better than his preconvention polls.

title: The Bumper Man
description: Dear Diary:

title: Jon Stewart and Bill OReilly to Debate Next Month
description: The election season has added another debate  one less likely, perhaps, to determine the next president of the United States, but with greater chances of intentional hilarity and use of the word pinhead. Bill OReilly, the Fox News personality and host of The OReilly Factor, and Jon Stewart, the satirist and anchor of Comedy Centrals The Daily Show, will face each other in a 90-minute contest of mental nimbleness and verbal dexterity, to be held in Washington on Oct. 6 and broadcast on the Internet, its organizers said.

title: Inflation Expectations: A Feature, Not A Bug
description: And now for something completely different: Im a bit puzzled by the tone of this FT report on how QE3 is doing so far, US inflation fears rise after QE3, which seems to imply that a rise in breakeven rates  the difference between the interest rate on ordinary bonds and inflation-protected bonds  is a danger sign. (Breakeven rates are a simple gauge of expected inflation).

title: Is Occupy a Fad?
description: Occupy Wall Street: From Frenzy to Fad? | Occupy Wall Street celebrated its one-year anniversary on Monday as protesters filled the Financial District. But the movement  which initially struck a chord, or a nerve, depending on your view  doesnt seem to be generating the same buzz anymore. As Andrew Ross Sorkin writes, Occupy Wall Street may now be more of a footnote in financial history:

title: Welcome, All, the Days of Forgiveness to Car Owners
description: Monday was the first day of Rosh Hashana, the Jewish New Year, and for observant Jews it ushered in a solemn 10-day period of reflection and repentance. For some of them and for others of different religions, it also ushered in a longer period of gratification and joy. These are New Yorkers, nonbelievers included, who share a bond that transcends faith.

title: Romney Says Remarks on Voters Help Clarify Position
description: Mitt Romney on Tuesday fully embraced the substance of his secretly recorded comments that 47 percent of Americans are too dependent on government, saying that his views helped define the philosophical choice for voters in his campaign against President Obama.

title: British Legislators Waver on Afghan War
description: LONDON  How many more wasted lives? asked the rhetorical headline in Britains Daily Mail on Tuesday, above photographs of the latest two British soldiers to die while serving in Afghanistan.

title: Providence Equitys Nelson and Netflixs Hastings Join the Giving Pledge
description: Businessmen like Jonathan M. Nelson and Reed Hastings normally focus on generating the maximum amount of profit from their work as possible. But the two men have joined Warren E. Buffett and Bill Gates in pledging to dole out most of their wealth to charity.

title: Teachers End Chicago Strike on Second Try
description: CHICAGO  The Chicago Teachers Union agreed on Tuesday to end its strike in the nations third-largest school system, allowing 350,000 children to return to classes on Wednesday and bringing to a close, at least for now, a tense standoff over issues like teacher evaluations and job security that had upended this city for more than a week.

title: Taxes Over The Life Cycle
description: Mark Thoma has the best data post so far on the execrable Romney speech, linking to the Hamilton Project work on taxes. This work makes a crucial point: even aside from the fact that there are other taxes besides the income tax, even aside from the larger point that lower-income working Americans are hardly grifters, the fact is that the vast majority of Americans do pay income taxes at some point in their life:

title: An Enigma in the Mortgage Market That Elevates Rates
description: Imagine a 30-year mortgage on which you only pay 2.8 percent in interest a year.

title: What Were Reading

title: Daily Report: The Perils of Successful Crowdfunding
description: Crowdfunding sites like Kickstarter and IndieGogo are letting designers and other creative people connect with audiences who want to finance their dreams, Jenna Wortham reports on Tuesday in The New York Times. But for the creators of these projects, getting the money is sometimes the easy part. They then have to turn their dreams into reality, with a crowd keeping an eye on their progress.

title: Real Photo, Fake Family
description: So, who was that family?

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Romney Caught on Tape, and Detecting Photoshopped Images
description: Secretly taped comments,  in which Mitt Romney said that nearly of half of Americans were dependent on government assistance and felt entitled, were released by the liberal magazine Mother Jones on Monday and threatened to derail the Romney campaign as it tried to redefine its message 50 days before the election, Jim Rutenberg and Ashley Parker wrote. Speaking to wealthy donors at a Florida fund-raiser in May, Mr. Romney said 47 percent of the people will vote for Mr. Obama no matter what, adding that they are dependent upon government, who believe that they are victims, who believe the government has a responsibility to care for them.

title: North Stars

description: Manchester Uniteds net loss for its fourth quarter widened significantly from the year-ago period, the soccer club said on Tuesday in its first earnings report as a publicly traded company.

title: A Son Searches for His Fathers Truth
description: What really knocks me out, Holden Caulfield said, is a book that, when youre all done reading it, you wish the author that wrote it was a terrific friend of yours and you could call him up on the phone whenever you felt like it.

title: Trial of Ex-Police Chief in China Scandal Ends in a Sign of Leniency
description: CHENGDU, China  A former Chinese police chief helped to cover up the murder of a British businessman by the wife of Bo Xilai, the Communist official toppled from power this year, but he also secretly collected evidence used to convict her, according to a lawyer for the police chief and an official account released Tuesday at the end of his trial.

description: London

description: Times reporter Andrew Martin explains how student loans are providing a payday for debt collectors.

title: Getting Bluefin Tuna Off the Hook
description: The longline fishery is aptly named. Fishermen will unroll a surface longline into the ocean that can extend for 40 miles and is segmented with baited hooks and buoys. Theyll let it float for a number of hours, hooking whatever swims along that has a taste for the bait.

title: Is Skepticism Too High for the Kalamazoo Promise to Work in New York?
description: The article in this past Sundayss magazine about the Kalamazoo Promise, a program announced in November 2005 that pays for the citys high-school graduates to go to public colleges in Michigan, is accompanied by a sidebar that imagines what it would take to do the same for students in New York City.

title: Couscous With Tomatoes, Okra and Chickpeas
description: Okra is popular in the North African cuisines of Tunisia and Algeria, where it is also dried. Because you dont cut it up, the okra doesnt become slimy. It contributes great flavor to the stew. Very high in dietary fiber, okra is a great source of vitamins A, C, B complex and the phytonutrients glutathione, xanthin, lutein and beta carotene, all believed to have antioxidant properties. For the best texture and flavor, look for the smallest pods you can find.

title: Wanted: Jewish Ballplayers
description: JUPITER, Fla.  Though Israels national baseball team has many excellent pitchers, catchers, infielders and outfielders, the roster has a shortage of something that might be considered essential: Israelis.

title: Usher and Shakira to Join The Voice Next Season
description: The judging wheel on televisions glut of singing-competition shows continues to spin, with two new superstar-singers, Usher and Shakira, signing on for NBCs next edition of The Voice in the spring.

title: Groups Prepare to Fight AT&T Over FaceTime Restrictions
description: A group of public interest organizations said Tuesday that they would soon file complaints against AT&T, alleging that the carrier was violating government rules by restricting the way customers can use FaceTime, Apples video-conferencing tool, which is built into iPhones and iPads.

title: Rangers Wing Considers Playing in Sweden
description: Carl Hagelin of the Rangers is considering playing for his hometown club in Sweden, SK Sodertalje, but he still has not made a decision, his agent said Tuesday morning.

title: Heritage Foundations
description: Hangaroa Eco Village & SpaEaster Island, a World Heritage site known for its ancient stone monoliths, has long been home to land disputes. In 2010, members of the Hito native clan staged a six-month occupation of Hangaroa, claiming the property had been taken from their ancestors illegally. Chilean police ended the protest, and now the hotel is open for business, with 75 rooms built of volcanic rock and a lobby that resembles a Polynesian canoe. The owners plan to donate funds to local charities. Doubles from $550; hangaroa.cl.

title: Couscous With Tomatoes, Cauliflower, Red Peppers and Olives
description: Cauliflower is one of the few cruciferous vegetables you find in North African tagines. The spicy tagines make a good vehicle for this nutrient-rich food and are one of the few types of dishes in which cauliflower can be cooked until quite soft and not lose its appeal.

title: Myanmars Opposition Leader Urges End to Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON  Myanmars opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, called for the lifting of American sanctions against her country on Tuesday, beginning an emotional visit to the United States that punctuated the remarkable shift in relations with Myanmar over the past year.

title: Mies Julie to Start New Season at St. Anns Warehouse
description: The South African production Mies Julie, based on the Strindberg play and an award-winning hit at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe last month, will have its American premiere this fall as the first production in St. Anns Warehouses temporary new home in Brooklyn, the theaters leaders said on Tuesday.

title: Image of the Day: September 18
The 47 Percent
description: Mitt Romney often accuses the Occupy Wall Street movement of dividing the country with its 99 percent slogan. A newly uncovered video of the candidate speaking at a private fundraiser shows him dividing the country more evenly: Between the 47 percent who are dependent upon government, who believe that they are victims and who pay no income taxand everyone else.

title: On Our Radar: William and Kate Visit Threatened Tuvalu
description: Inhabitants of Tuvalu, an island country deeply threatened by rising seas, hope to convey their plight to the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge as they arrive on the final stop of their royal tour. [R.T.C.C.]

title: Does Long-Term Care Insurance at a Young Age Make Sense?
description: The average age of people buying long-term care insurance has been falling, as people seek to balance the possible need for nursing home or in-home care with the considerable cost of the insurance premiums. Even some very young people are buying the insurance, and a few of them are making claims under their policies, according to an industry group.

title: For a Student Veteran, Graduation Is the Next Mission
description: It was the fall of 2011, and I was the quintessential fresh-out-of-the-fleet 23-year-old Marine. I was preparing for Georgetown Universitys New Student Orientation, my first official re-entry into academia and a day of assemblies and awkward greetings with a bunch of kids who would have been barely teenagers when I was spending my first weeks in Afghanistan.

description: Its easy to forget, sometimes, that behind all the screens, behind all the slide shows of funny animal photos and GIFs, the Internet is made of people.

description: The actress Tilda Swinton and 134 other readers are lending their voices to the Moby-Dick Big Read, an online audio version of Herman Melvilles epic novel.

description: Comments made by Mitt Romney at a private campaign fund-raiser about the nearly half of Americans who have no income tax liability have heated up a debate over who pays and who takes from the federal government.

description: Whether students are applying to a small, private college or a large, public university, there are some universal missteps that college applicants make year after year, much to the dismay of the institutions gatekeepers who decide whether the student should be admitted.

title: New Romney Ad Targets Women
description: As Mitt Romneys presidential campaign was consumed once again by events out of its control  the release of Mr. Romneys blunt discussion with donors in May  it was seeking to at least remain focused in the one place on TV where it has ultimate control of what is on screen: Its television advertising.

title: Life During Fatwa: Hiding in a World Newly Broken
description: Salman Rushdies Joseph Anton is a memoir of the roughly 10 years he spent in hiding, under police protection, after the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini called for his death in 1989 because his novel The Satanic Verses was deemed offensive to Islam. The memoirs title, cobbled together from the first names of Joseph Conrad and Anton Chekhov, is the alias he used while under the fatwa. In the book, which is written in the third person, Anton emerges as a character Mr. Rushdie regards both fondly and critically.

title: Get a Jump on Fall Color With States Travel Tools
description: For travelers who cant remember whether a hot summer means that the leaves change early, a couple of states are hoping to clarify matters with accessible travel tools.

title: The Impact of the 2004-5 Lockout on the Russian Superliga
description: With the locked-out N.H.L. players Evgeni Malkin, Sergei Gonchar, Ilya Kovalchuk, Ruslan Fedotenko, Alexei Ponikarovsky and Lubomir Visnovsky on their way to the K.H.L. after just two days of the latest lockout, it behooves us to look back at what happened in the Russian league during the last N.H.L. lockout, in 2004-5.

title: A Faded Piece of Papyrus Refers to Jesus Wife
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  A historian of early Christianity at Harvard Divinity School has identified a scrap of papyrus that she says was written in Coptic in the fourth century and contains a phrase never seen in any piece of Scripture: Jesus said to them, My wife ...

title: With Hollywood Hire, Microsoft Bolsters Entertainment Efforts
description: Microsoft has hired Nancy Tellem, a former top CBS television executive, to oversee the production of original video content to be delivered to the companys Xbox video game console, according to people with knowledge of the move who did not want to be named ahead of an official announcement.

title: McLaren P1, Heir to the F1, Will Make Debut at the Paris Motor Show
description: McLaren Automotive has cracked open the lid of secrecy over the scheduled debut of its new supercar.

title: When The Inner Party Believes The Prolefeed
description: As many people have been pointing out, Mitt Romneys talk about the 47 percent was no different from what you hear all the time from Rush Limbaugh and the like. But bear in mind that Romney was talking to the financial super-elite, and gave every appearance of believing what he said. (Im usually scornful of analyses based on how someone comes across, and would never put much weight on it, but the Romney of this video was a lot looser and more articulate than the guy we usually see).

title: London Fashion Week
description: Suzy Menkes spoke with designers who showed spring and summer 2013 collections at London Fashion Week.
