description: Without a steady supply of smuggled arms, the Syria rebels are resorting to making their own weapons including simple mortars.

title: Libyan Militia Blamed for Attack on U.S. Consulate Denies Responsibility
description: CAIRO  Mohammad Ali al-Zahawi, commander of the Libyan brigade believed to have led the assault on the American mission in Benghazi, on Tuesday made his first public statement since the attacks, telling the BBCs Arabic language news channel that his group was not responsible for the assault and had no ties to Al Qaeda. Nor, he said, did it have ties to other groups that might share its name, Ansar al-Sharia, which means simply Supporters of Islamic Law.

title: Who Actually Pays Taxes?
description: Behind a shocking statistic, the complex picture of who pays taxes. | The Times Alexei Barrionuevo takes a peek inside a billionaires haven, overlooking Central Park.

title: Harf Zimmermann, Landscaping With Light
description: For last weekends cover story about the University of Virginia, we sent the Berlin-based photographer Harf Zimmermann to visit the schools campus. Zimmermann is known for his picturesque landscapes and has photographed the Hudson River and the island of Socotra forthe magazine and T, respectively.

title: Wheelies: The Multistrada Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: HTC, Once Atop Market, Gambles on Windows Phone
description: As the first to use Googles Android smartphone software, HTC, the Taiwanese handset maker, was briefly the top smartphone manufacturer in the United States. It was surpassed by Apple and Samsung.

title: U.S. Gets Favorable Davis Cup Draw
description: The United States received one of the more favorable possible first-round 2013 Davis Cup match-ups when the draw ceremony was conducted in London Wednesday morning, finding themselves hosting Brazil in a tie to be held February 1-3. The location of the tie has not yet been confirmed.

title: Lohan Charged With Leaving Accident Scene in Chelsea
description: Updated, 2:08 p.m. |  Lindsay Lohan had another automotive encounter with the law early Wednesday, this one in Chelsea, where she was arrested on charges of leaving an accident scene after the police said she struck a pedestrians leg with her Porsche sport utility vehicle outside a hotel.

title: Blast in Pakistan Leaves 10 Dead
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A car bomb apparently aimed at a military vehicle killed 10 people and wounded 27 others at a busy intersection here on Wednesday.

title: Nets First Season in Brooklyn Is Made for TV
description: The Nets  relocated, revamped and re-branded  will soon arrive in Brooklyn with an army of cameras documenting every dribble for the NBA TV series The Association.

title: After a Year on a Hilltop, Balancing the Books
description: Its been six weeks since we returned to the New Jersey suburbs after living for a year in an off-the-grid cabin in the woods of Maine with our three kids and two cats. Reflecting on the year in my final Green post on the experience, the question that matters most is: Was it worth it?

title: Distortion in Tax Code Makes Debt More Attractive to Banks
description: Thanks to a leaked video, we know that Mitt Romney divides the country into those who pay taxes and those who dont, the makers and the moochers.

title: Vowel Play | Peter Coffin at Venus Over Manhattan
description: For anyone lamenting the disappearance of the artists hand in contemporary sculpture today, Peter Coffin has just the piece for you: a twelve and a half foot tall wooden construction built to resemble the universal symbol for O.K. Much like his Italian counterpart Maurizio Cattelan, Coffin lives on the absurdist fringe of conceptual art where critics are left wondering whether hes a savant or are they the idiots for taking him seriously. Vowels are fundamental sounds, Coffin explains of A, E, I, O, U, the nonsensical title of his new exhibition, which opens at Venus Over Manhattan on Sept. 21. Just reading the vowels has an effect like mouthing the words to a song without the consonants. The vowels are ethereal and consonants are anchors. Many of his artworks strive for the appearance of self-generation, be it the aforementioned hand that looks as though it was whipped up in a tornado or a dodecahedron made of starfish cast in gold. Coffin is quick to point out that this complex five-sided shape is, according to Euclidean geometry, what Plato believed to be a building block of the cosmos, but then immediately offers another read where the starfish couldve come together the way skydivers do for fun in free fall.

title: The Quinnipiac University/New York Times/CBS Poll Results
description: Polling of voters in three swing states shows a tight presidential race, but President Obama carries a slight lead over Mitt Romney in Wisconsin, Virginia and Colorado.

title: Starter: At Ganso, a Writer Tries His Hand at Ramen
description: Starter, an occasional column, takes a look at newly opened restaurants.

title: Romney Makes Appeal to Working-Class Men in Latest Ads
description: Mitt Romney trails President Obama significantly in several key demographics women and Hispanics chief among them.

title: Cartoons Spark Press Freedom Debate in France
description: LONDON  Press freedom or provocation? That was the question preoccupying France as a satirical weekly went ahead on Wednesday with a decision to publish cartoons featuring the Prophet Muhammad.

title: Elmore Leonard to Be Honored by National Book Foundation
description: Fall is awards season in the publishing industry, and on Wednesday the National Book Foundation announced the recipients of its annual lifetime achievement awards. The medal for Distinguished Contribution to American Letters will be presented to the novelist and screenwriter Elmore Leonard for his work in fiction. For over five decades, Leonards westerns, crime novels, serialized novels and stories have enthralled generations of readers, the foundation said in a statement. Harold Augenbraum, the executive director of the foundation, said Mr. Leonard has produced vibrant literary work with an inimitable writing style.

title: New iOS 6 Loses Google Maps, but Adds Other Features
description: The arrival of the iPhone 5 isnt the only big news for phone fans this week. Wednesday, Apple is also making iOS 6 available to anyone with a recent iPhone (3GS, 4, or 4S), iPod Touch (fourth generation) or iPad (2 or 3). It comes installed on the iPhone 5 and the new fifth-generation iPod Touch.

title: Library of Congress Overhauls Online Offerings
description: The Library of Congress released a beta Web site on Wednesday that it says will replace its existing online catalogs in about a year.

title: Polaroid Develops a New Instant Camera
description: Polaroids latest move to revive the field of instant photography (and Polaroid itself) is the Z2300 instant digital camera.

title: Emancipations Price
description: Historians would later render their own judgments, but in the aftermath of the Battle of Antietam, each side took fast solace in the outcome. For men like John Dooley, a private in the First Virginia Infantry, it was the wondrous achievement of 15,000 or so ragged, barefoot, hungry Confederate soldiers who had repulsed, prostrated, and demoralized Gen. George B. McClellans immense army, more than triple the size of the Confederate corps. For Abraham Lincoln, the stalemated outcome was an imperfect opportunity to release his Emancipation Proclamation, a statement he had impatiently waited weeks to make.

title: Photos of The Moment | Gucci
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Q&A: Extra Security for Gmail
description: Q.

title: Isner and Venus Williams Will Play at Hopman
description: The lanky Americans Venus Williams and John Isner will join forces to represent the United States at the Hyundai Hopman Cup XXV to begin their 2013 seasons, the tournament said Wednesday.

title: Finding Job Opportunities in Middle Age
description: Readers recently submitted questions about finding a job in middle age to Tory Johnson, founder of Women for Hire, which produces career expos, and Spark & Hustle which guides people in beginning and expanding small businesses. Here are her responses. [This feature is now closed for comment.]

title: Syrias Dark Horses, With Lathes: Makeshift Arms Production in Aleppo Governorate, Part I
description: There are many indicators of the stubborn determination and evolving organization of the fighting groups in Syria seeking to unseat President Bashar al-Assad. One of them is this: the development of local arms-producing industries in Syrian cities and the countryside. In a war in which the antigovernment fighters have sought outside support and been disappointed by what has been offered, especially from the West, the society that produced the fighters has also undertaken the production of matriel for guerrilla war, a social project of such a scale that it has contributed to the armed oppositions momentum and confidence this year. The progression is both intriguing and relevant to those seeking to understand the Free Syrian Army, as the loosely organized antigovernment fighters are called. This is not just for the view that local production provides of latter-day warfare with do-it-yourself arms. It offers insights into something else  the social forces within an uprising that is reordering the Middle East.

title: Class, Politics, and the 47 Percent
description: Among the many fallacies in Mitt Romneys now-infamous 47 percent speech is that people who pay no income tax will vote for the president no matter what. More than one-fifth of non-filers are elderly, a constituency likely to favor Mr. Romney.

title: New Hyatt Organic Menu Aimed at Smallest Guests
description: Childrens menus have come a long way since the Happy Meal. The latest in refined dining for little ones: a new all-organic, prix fixe menu designed by Alice Waters and prepared at Hyatt Hotels across North America.

title: A House of Intrigue and, the Neighbors Say, Espionage
description: In real estate, the saying goes, location is key, and it is certainly true for the little white house at 5437 Fieldston Road in Riverdale.

title: The 47 Percent Solution
description: David Brooks: Gail, greetings from Dulles International Airport. Im in a little clutch of travelers huddling around the electrical chargers like Napoleons soldiers around the fire on the retreat from Moscow.

title: Convicted New York Legislator Accused of a Final Swindle
description: It was no surprise when the Soundview Healthcare Network in the Bronx began to liquidate its assets this summer. After all, its founder and chief executive, Pedro Espada Jr., the bombastic former state legislator, had been convicted of stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars from the nonprofit organization, and soon afterward, seemingly a casualty of corrupt management, it stopped accepting patients and began laying off staff members.

title: Wisconsin Senate Race a Tossup
description: MILWAUKEE  The contest to fill the seat of retiring Senator Herb Kohl, Democrat of Wisconsin, is now a tossup, according to the latest assessment of the race by The New York Times. (Full Senate map)

title: An Emotional Victory for Stricker
description: ATLANTA  Steve Stricker was the winner of the Payne Stewart Award, named after the late golfer and given to players who exhibit sportsmanship and comportment on the course and engage in charitable activities.

title: Business Day Live: Rising Tower Emerges as a Billionaires Haven
description: Behind a shocking statistic, the complex picture of who pays taxes. | A peek inside a billionaires haven overlooking Central Park.

title: Some Religious Leaders See a Threat as Europe Grows More Secular
description: HOF, Germany  This sleepy town not far from the Czech border, in a hilly corner of Catholic Bavaria, is an unlikely place to find an active synagogue, and an even unlikelier focal point for a controversy that some see as a threat to religious tolerance in Europe and even the place of Jews in Germany.

title: The Get | Georg Jensens Magic Showpiece Earrings
description: Typically associated with exquisite silver accessories for the home, the Danish company Georg Jensen took a different approach to jewelry making with its latest offering. The Magic showpiece earrings shown here have a familiar baroque look, and make beautiful use of yellow gold, white pearls and diamonds, but its their ability to break down into a daintier drop size that really amazes. Abracadabra, indeed.

title: The End of a Kansas Tradition: Moderation
description: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Here is a look at Kansas, the Sunflower State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Joseph A. Aistrup, a professor of political science at Kansas State University; Burdett A. Loomis, a professor of political science at Kansas University; H. Edward Flentje, a professor in Wichita State Universitys Hugo Wall School of Urban and Public Affairs; and David Kensinger, president of Roadmap Solutions, Gov. Sam Brownbacks policy organization.

title: 36 Hours in Baltimore
description: YOU can look far and wide, but youll never discover a stranger city with such extreme style, John Waters once noted about his hometown. Maybe thats why Baltimores trumpeted glass-and-steel Inner Harbor development, with its chain restaurants, neon-loud amusements and brand-name shopping, feels so counterintuitive as a symbol for the city. But walk in any direction and the citys charm reasserts itself. Indeed, Baltimores best draws tend to be left-of-center: offbeat theater, grandly decrepit neighborhoods on the cusp of gentrification, a world-class museum devoted to outsider art and a dive-bar culture that must be one of the nations finest.

title: Baltimore Scenes
description: A museum for outsiders, the original Washington Monument and a diner are stops on this tour.

title: Drug Makers Join Efforts in Research
description: Ten of the worlds largest pharmaceutical companies said on Wednesday that they would cooperate on research aimed at accelerating drug development, starting with streamlining clinical trials.

title: Video of Romney Turns Spotlight on a Magazine
description: Mother Jones, the left-leaning magazine that was founded above a McDonalds restaurant in San Francisco 36 years ago, found itself lavished this week with the kind of attention usually reserved for larger news outlets. And that is not a bad thing for a nonprofit publication with a circulation of just over 200,000 and a business model partly dependent on its readers largess.

title: Another G.O.P. Lawmaker Says He Disagrees With Romneys Comments
description: Add Senator Dean Heller of Nevada to the ranks of Republican political candidates distancing themselves from Mitt Romney and his comments that 47 percent of Americans are dependent on the government and view themselves as victims.

title: A Madison Square Treat, From Rome
description: New York has enjoyed a spectacular shift in the quality, quantity and variety of its street food in the past five years. Rome, however, has more or less remained wedded to fried rice balls and square pizza slices despite its millennial history of fast and cheap street food.

title: Two Out-of-Print Nora Ephron Books to Be Published as Single Volume
description: Two out-of-print books by Nora Ephron will be reissued on Oct. 16 in a single-volume paperback and e-book edition, the publisher, Vintage Books, said on Wednesday.

title: A Bellwether of Chinese Revolution
description: BEIJING  In Asia, much hinges on China. And in China, much has traditionally hinged on change from the south  from Guangdong province, an outward-looking giant of more than 100 million people next to Hong Kong. Its $840 billion economy is about as big as that of the Netherlands or Indonesia.

title: James Gandolfini to Star in New Pilot for HBO
description: Just when he thought he was out, they pull him back in: HBO said on Wednesday that it had ordered the pilot episode of a new series that would star James Gandolfini in his first continuing role at that network (or anywhere else) since his heralded run on The Sopranos, confirming a report that appeared on Deadline.com. The new series, called Criminal Justice, is adapted from a BBC drama of the same title which, in two five-episode seasons, chronicled the lives of two different characters charged with murder; the HBO version will be written by Steven Zaillian (Moneyball, Schindlers List) and Richard Price (The Wire, Clockers) and directed by Mr. Zaillian.

title: U.S. Senator Warns Iraq Over Flights Into Syria
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administrations leading foreign policy ally in Congress said Wednesday that aid to Iraq might be made contingent on cutting off flights shuttling military supplies from Iran to the repressive government in Syria.

title: The Daily Shoe | Gucci
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Alberta Ferretti: Spring 2013 RTW
description: Milan

title: Q&A: Customize Folders in Windows 7
description: Q.

title: Homemade Rocket Test
description: A test of an early rocket developed by Ahmed Turki in Syria.

title: G.O.P. Blocks Veteran Jobs Bill
description: Veterans wont be getting a new, billion-dollar jobs program, not from this Senate. Republicans on Wednesday afternoon blocked a vote on the Veterans Job Corps Bill after Jeff Sessions of Alabama raised a point of order  he said the bill violated a cap on spending agreed to by Congress last year. The bills sponsor, Patty Murray of Washington, said that shouldnt matter, since the bills cost was fully offset by new revenues. She said Mr. Sessions and his party colleagues had been furiously generating excuses to oppose the bill, and were now exploiting a technicality to deny thousands of veterans a shot at getting hired as police officers, firefighters and parks workers, among other things.

title: Seeking Revenue, Postal Service Plans to Deliver More Junk Mail
description: WASHINGTON  Customers might complain about the flood of unsolicited credit card applications, supermarket fliers and shopping catalogs in their mail, but the Postal Service is hoping to deliver even more.

title: Delta Cracks Down on Mileage Tracking Sites
description: Delta Air Lines is the latest big carrier to crack down on start-up Web sites that aim to help travelers manage their frequent flier miles from multiple airlines.

title: Tailgating Recipe: Smoked Bologna With Bacon
description: As a child, one of my favorite brown-bag lunches was a very simple sandwich of a few slices of bologna and some mayo on Wonder Bread. (Crust left on, thank you very much.) And it was a breakfast treat when Dad would fry up some bologna slices to go with the bacon and eggs. (A few cuts in the edges prevented the bologna from rolling up in the pan.)

title: Unrest Follows Broadcast of Video Showing Prison Abuse in Georgia
description: MOSCOW  The senior official in charge of prisons in Georgia resigned on Wednesday, after a television station broadcast graphic video of prison inmates being brutally beaten and sodomized by guards.

title: New Voice in South Korean Politics Enters Presidential Race
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A 50-year-old graduate school dean whose appeal to disaffected voters has made him a political star officially declared his candidacy for president of South Korea on Wednesday, upending the contest by turning it into a three-way race just three months before the election.

title: The Place | Californias Central Coast, Part Three
description: The golden states middle ground is ripe with new wineries, gastro-inns and farm-fresh shopping.

title: Should Hazing Make a Prospective College Student Think Twice?
description: Hazing certainly isnt new to college campuses, but it has garnered more attention recently, especially after the deaths of students at Cornell and Florida A&M Universities made headlines.

title: Fast and Furious Report Recommends Disciplinary Reviews
description: A long-awaited report on Fast and Furious, the botched gun-trafficking operation that led to a politically charged confrontation between congressional Republicans and the Obama administration, was issued on Wednesday. The 471-page document is likely to be the closest thing to a definitive historical accounting of the operation.

title: Thursday Matchup: Giants vs. Panthers
description: Giants (1-1) at Panthers (1-1)

title: G.M. Executive Affirms Commitment to Opel
description: DETROIT  General Motors wants no doubts about its plans for Opel, its long-troubled European unit: It intends to fix the division, not sell it or close it.

title: For Older Drivers, Ranking the Help
description: The Hartford Financial Service Group and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology AgeLab published a study this week that identified 10 safety-related automotive technologies that its panel judged as the most beneficial for mature drivers. The list was compiled by a seven-person panel that included experts in occupational therapy, ergonomics, driver rehabilitation, geriatrics and related fields.

title: Rooting for Home, if Not Yet a Home Team
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland  Xherdan Shaqiri walked onto the field with a white cross against his heart and three flags embossed on his shoes.

title: Guns Inquiry Urges Action Against 14 in Justice Dept.
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Departments inspector general on Wednesday issued a scathing critique of federal officials for their handling of the botched gun-trafficking case known as Operation Fast and Furious, but essentially exonerated Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., whom many Republicans have blamed for the scandal.

title: Extra Protection for Weekend Warriors
description: Pelican Products has long been known for making durable cases for military and industrial fields. Seeking to reach a wider audience of consumers, the company recently began offering a new line of portable protection for laptops, tablets and smartphones.

title: Ranting Elmo Returns and Is Arrested in Times Square
description: A man with a history of shouting anti-Semitic rants while dressed as Elmo at popular tourist destinations was arrested in his red costume in Times Square on Tuesday.

title: Testimony Implicates a Chinese Official in the Cover-Up of a Britons Murder
description: BEIJING  The Chinese government on Wednesday released an official account of the trial of a former police chief that essentially accused the disgraced politician Bo Xilai of trying to cover up the murder of a British businessman by Mr. Bos wife.

title: TimesCast Tech | Content Creators
description: Companies sharpen their focus on content creators. | Paperless Post pushes the envelope, literally. | Digital etiquette dos and donts.

title: Complaining About Refs Isn't Enough
description: William C. Rhoden is tired of hearing N.F.L. players and coaches complain about the replacement referees. He says it's time they take action.

title: Londons Olympic Glow Is Undimmed
description: LONDON

title: 4-Year Deals for Unions at Verizon
description: Unions representing 45,000 Verizon workers announced tentative new contracts on Wednesday that call for an 8 percent pay raise over four years while requiring workers to pay more for health coverage.

title: Video: Complaining About Refs Isnt Enough
Samsung Takes More Swipes at Apple in Latest Ad
description: Samsung may have lost a big patent suit to Apple, but the company is winning in the snark wars with its latest television advertisement.

title: Gran Cuisine
description: Two of the seasons most enticing cookbooks come from a pair of unknown grandmothers, legends only within their immigrant families for simple, soulful recipes that taste of home. Salma Hage moved with her family from Northern Lebanon to London in 1967, and The Lebanese Kitchen (Phaidon, $50) catalogs all the aromatic dishes she took with her, including eight types of hummus and a wintry twist on tabbouleh with fennel, walnuts and pomegranate syrup. And in My Abuelas Table (Hardie Grant, $30), Daniella Germain sweetly illustrates her Mexican grandmothers greatest hits, which shed swoon for as a tot in her native Australia. Germain even draws a step-by-step guide for making picadas  breakfast tortillas topped with chile sauce, onion and cheese  just the way my abuelo liked it. Below, a recipe from each book.

title: Tentative Deal on E-Book Prices Is Reached in Europe
description: BERLIN  The European Commission said Wednesday that it was prepared to drop its investigation into the fixing of e-book prices by Apple and four European publishers after the companies agreed to let online retailers like Amazon sell e-books at a discount for two years.

title: An Alert System for Security Breaches
description: It was, no doubt, the year of the security breach.

title: Romney Says He Can Help the Poor
description: ATLANTA  Mitt Romney on Wednesday confronted the most damaging perception from a secretly taped video: that he had written off those who rely on government assistance.

title: Dave Matthews Bands Latest Opens at No. 1
description: The Dave Matthews Band leads a wave of new releases taking over the top slots of Billboards album chart, as record companies begin their fall assault of major new releases.

title: Stone Links: God and the Philosophers
description: For decades, and from different standpoints, Thomas Nagel and Alvin Plantinga have valiantly resisted various strains of philosophical reductionism. This week the two came together at The New York Review of Books, where Nagel reviews Plantingas latest book, Where the Conflict Really Lies.

title: The Missing Two Minutes in the Romney Video? Everyone Has a Theory
description: The video of Mitt Romneys speech at a fund-raiser in Boca Raton, Fla., released by Mother Jones magazine this week has been discussed broadly across the political spectrum. It has even apparently darkened the mood of Mr. Romneys campaign team. There seemed to be little Mr. Romney could do but clarify that his remarks were not elegantly stated and fully embrace the ideas that drove them.

title: F.T.C. Still Expects to Resolve Google Antitrust Inquiry by Years End
description: The Federal Trade Commission intends to decide by the end of the year whether to bring legal action against Google for anticompetitive practices, Jon Leibowitz, the chairman of the commission, said on Wednesday in Washington.

title: One on One: Ricky Gervais, Comedian Turned App Developer
description: Add Ricky Gervais to the growing list of celebrities turned entrepreneurs. On Wednesday, Mr. Gervais, the creator of The Office television series, will unveil a new app, called Just Sayin, that lets people record two-way voice conversations and broadcast them to Twitter and Facebook. In this e-mailed interview, the comedian discusses why the world would possibly need such a thing, the best conversation he overheard but did not have a chance to record and whether he plans to make himself available for tech support.

title: The Caucus Click: A Gift From Romney
Pettitte Is Early Attraction but Suzuki Steals Show
description: During a simulated tour of the American League East, Andy Pettitte pitched in empty stadiums in St. Petersburg, Fla., Baltimore and Boston, all the while aching to be part of a real game in a stadium packed with boisterous fans.

title: BPs Chief and Putin Meet, a Sign of Movement in a Joint Ventures Dispute
description: MOSCOW  BP may finally be close to resolving a long-running business dispute over its joint venture in Russia.

title: My Name Is Asher Lev Coming to Off Broadway
description: The Long Wharf Theaters critically praised production of My Name Is Asher Lev, a play based on the Chaim Potok novel about a young artist who clashes with Hasidic Jewish parents, will transfer for an Off Broadway commercial run at the Westside Theater starting in November, the lead producer, Darren Bagert said on Wednesday. The adaptation is by the playwright and director Aaron Posner, who before Potoks death in 2002 collaborated with him on a stage version of another well-known novel of his, The Chosen.

title: Photo Replay: Sept.19
description: A view of the day in sports, including Andy Pettittes return to the mound.

title: The Online Life of the Secret Romney Recordings
description: An anonymous Twitter user who claims to have produced the secret recordings in May of Mitt Romney speaking at a private meeting of wealthy donors in Florida alerted the Romney campaign on Twitter last month, as well as members of the news media and prominent Democrats, about parts of the video.

title: TimesCast Tech: Companies Make New Content Deals
description: Companies sharpen their focus on content creators. Paperless Post pushes the envelope, literally. Digital etiquette dos and donts.

title: The Redistribution of Wealth
description: Guided by pollsters like Frank Luntz, the Republican party upgraded all rich people into job creators, and tarnished the estate tax by calling it the death tax. Its candidates prefer energy exploration to oil drilling, and insist on the religious freedom of church groups to deny freedom of reproductive choice to their employees. Carefully choosing words to disguise or express contempt is so vital to the partys strategy that Republicans wont even properly use the name of the Democratic Party, cutting off the final ic.

title: Photos of The Moment | Alberta Ferretti
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: A Design School Showcases Jack Lenor Larsen
description: Jack Lenor Larsen, the celebrated textile designer who remains a major figure in his field, even after selling his company in 1997 to Colefax and Fowler, is getting a retrospective at the New York School of Interior Design. Jack Lenor Larsen: 40 Years, which will open Thursday, provides an overview of his career as a designer, collector and author.

title: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
description: Photos from India, Syria, Pakistan and England.

title: In Belgium, a Converted 19th-Century Mill
description: An 1850 mill house with four bedrooms, set on nearly three acres not far from Brussels, is on the market for $2.2 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Belgium
description: CONVERTED MILL ON THREE ACRES IN WALLOON BRABANT, BELGIUM

title: Familiar Faces in the Burton House of Horror and Humor
description: Tim Burton discusses four of the less visible performers who have worked with him frequently over the years.

title: Out on a Limb: Building Muscle Models in Science Class
description: Overview | Unlike some animals, we cannot regenerate diseased or missing body parts. Or can we? In this lesson, students learn about a soldier undergoing experimental treatment to help him regrow muscle missing from his leg. Then students build models to reinforce concepts surrounding cells, tissues and organs.

title: Netflix Picks Up New Ricky Gervais Series Derek
description: Ricky Gervais has no need to fear offending viewers of traditional American television with his latest series, because it wont be broadcast there: Netflix said on Wednesday that it had acquired the rights to show Derek, a new comedy program written, directed by and starring Mr. Gervais, following its run on Channel 4 in Britain.

title: Supreme Court Denies Request to Block Electoral Maps in Texas
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday allowed Novembers elections in Texas to proceed under interim electoral maps approved by a federal court in San Antonio.

title: Europe Aims to Encourage Young to Be Entrepreneurs
description: PARIS  If and when the euro crisis ends, Europe will still face an existential economic question: Who will provide the jobs of the future?

title: Freedom After Fire Ants and Tumult
description: Eighteen and a half years after he was sentenced to death for participating in the murders of three 8-year-old boys in Arkansas, Damien Echols finds himself in Faireyland. Mr. Echolss new book, Life After Death, has a Shepard Fairey-inspired cover design thats as coolly lionizing as Mr. Faireys Hope poster for President Obama. The book has a champion in Johnny Depp, who has compared Mr. Echolss writing to Dostoyevskys. And his story is the subject of a forthcoming documentary, West of Memphis, even though that story has been exhaustively told in the three Paradise Lost films that paved the path to Mr. Echolss release from death row.

title: The Breast-Feeding Professor Is a Red Herring
description: Many parents of infants have decided that breast is best. What they havent agreed on is where and when breast-feeding is appropriate, or even acceptable. In past months, women have been chastised for nursing at a water park, a library, and a Georgia church. The feeding practice thats encouraged (some would say pushed) by hospitals, pediatricians and fellow parents doesnt always meet with approval when it goes public.

title: Pill Found Promising in Treatment of M.S.
description: A new oral medication to treat patients in the early stages of multiple sclerosis has shown considerable promise in two clinical trials, researchers announced on Wednesday.

title: Training With Knicks, McIlroy Works on Jump Shot
description: ATLANTA  Rory McIlroy remains more likely to sink a 10-foot putt than a 10-foot jump shot, but the gap is closing.

title: Scouting Report
description: OPENINGS

title: How a God Finds Art (the Abridged Version)
description: At the start of Tuesday nights New York City Ballet performance the curtain rose on Robert Fairchild in the title role of George Balanchines oldest surviving ballet, Apollo. In this seminal work you see the young god discovering art; and Mr. Fairchild plays the ballet, coolly but keenly, as an adventure. His performance made an auspicious start for City Ballets four-week fall season at the David H. Koch Theater.

title: Obamas Lead Looks Stronger in Polls That Include Cellphones
description: As I observed on Tuesday, and as The New Republics Nate Cohn also found, Barack Obama seems to have received a much clearer bounce in some types of polls than others.

title: Buffett Cup in Omaha
description: In the Buffett Cup last week in Omaha, Europe led the United States by eight points going into the individual section. However, the Americans won that by 39 points to 27 to snatch victory in the tournament.

title: What You Get for ... $430,000
description: NASHVILLE

title: Homes for $430,000
description: Properties in Tennessee, New York and Montana.

title: Stark, Minimalist and Beckett All Over
description: She could be Miss Havisham. This ageless ghost of a woman with long, scraggly gray hair, dressed in a tattered, once-elegant gown, shuffling  noisily, rhythmically  back and forth across a bare floor in the growing dark. But Miss Havisham is a Dickens character and a villain, while May (Holly Twyford), the woman we see onstage, is a Samuel Beckett character and a leading lady. And while Miss Havisham is the eternal spurned bride, May is the eternal daughter. She has an elderly, bedridden mother who speaks in the tones of a cruel god (the voice of Kathleen Chalfant).

title: Veterans Jobs Bill Blocked in the Senate
description: Eager to shoot down President Obamas legislative agenda just weeks before the election, Senate Republicans on Wednesday blocked a measure that would have provided $1 billion over five years to help veterans find work in their communities.

title: New York Public Library Shifts Plan for 5th Ave. Building
description: Responding to objections raised by scholars, writers, artists and others, the New York Public Library has revised its plan to remove most of the books from its flagship Fifth Avenue research center to make room for a circulating library. Library officials said that an $8 million donation would help pay for enough new storage space to keep 3.3 million of its 4.5 volumes at the Stephen A. Schwarzman Building, at 42nd Street.

title: Click if You Can Afford It
description: SEAL flashed one on a recent stroll through Central Park with his children. Dakota Fanning huddled with hers on the set of her film Very Good Girls. Elisabeth Shue brought hers out at the Toronto International Film Festival last year.

title: Daily Journal Writing Without the Inconvenience of Paper
description: Despite being a wordy sort of fellow, Ive never put pen to paper daily to create a meaningful diary. I did make some tentative attempts when I was an adolescent, sure, but I never got hooked on a journal. With my sievelike memory, this means some precious moments of my past are now hazy. If I had a diary, Id simply be able to look up what happened.

title: Beauty Salons to Go
description: NEDA ARMIAN, 42, is an independent film producer based in Manhattan who takes meetings over lunch, while simultaneously reading e-mails and scripts. A couple days a week, I work late because of the time difference with Los Angeles, she said. Its just part of the routine.

title: Living in Their Art
description: A couples homestead in Catskill, N.Y., has grown into an art museum of sorts over the years.

title: Clip: 'Frankenweenie'
description: A scene from "Frankenweenie," the new film from Tim Burton.

title: Their Own Museum
description: CATSKILL, N.Y.

title: Jukebox Apps for the Party-Pleasing D.J.
description: My mission was to supply the music for a friends big birthday party. Sounds simple enough, right? Set up a playlist on an iPod and throw in a little Motown, because everybody likes Motown. Plug it into the sound system at the bar we had rented out and hit play. Instant revelry.

title: Misinformed Monetary Mitt
description: Leave aside what the now-famous video tells us about Mitt Romneys character; in a way the shocking thing is how uninformed he seems to be. The 47 percent number was the kind of thing you hear in yahoo forums like talk radio and the Wall Street Journal editorial page; and then theres what he said about US debt.

title: Letting Children Share in Grief
description: A FEW decades ago, children often didnt attend funerals. The thinking was that they should be sheltered from the pain of losing a loved one. And as Americans started living longer, the need to even broach the subject of death was delayed because many grandparents survived deep into their golden years.

title: Children and Minimalism, Coexisting
description: A home in San Francisco is renovated to accommodate children, while also maintaining its modern look.

title: Senate Republicans Not Eager to Discuss Romney Video
description: Republican leaders in the Senate on Wednesday were intent on showing Mitt Romney how its done: blast President Obama for his lack of leadership, castigate his economic record, then flee.

title: Another Angle on Family Life
description: San Francisco

title: Shopping for Tribal Patterns
description: Shanan Campanaro, the artist and designer who founded Brooklyn wallpaper and fabric company Eskayel, finds tribal inspiration without leaving New York.

title: Tribal Patterns
description: SHANAN CAMPANARO, the artist and designer who founded the Brooklyn wallpaper and fabric company Eskayel, has discovered that studying the traditions of other cultures  particularly their tribal patterns  often triggers ideas for new designs.

title: Nation of Takers
description: Do todays Republicans really believe that 47 percent of Americans are takers, living off money confiscated from the makers?

title: Ai, Reporter
description: Last Updated, Thursday 3:06 p.m. On Tuesday in Beijing, amid protests over the sovereignty of several tiny islands also claimed by Japan, a small group of protesters briefly surrounded the American ambassadors car outside the United States Embassy, pelting it with objects. As our colleagues Thom Shanker and Ian Johnson reported, Ambassador Gary Locke said later, I never felt in any danger.

title: A Living Room Suspended Over Columbus Circle
description: This week, the Public Art Fund is unveiling Discovering Columbus, by the Japanese artist Tatzu Nishi. Since 1997, Mr. Nishi, 52, has been fabricating domestic environments around artworks and public monuments, like the kitchen he built around a Picasso hanging on the wall of a museum in Nagoya, Japan.

title: You Had a Monster Hit. Now What?
description: For months theres been little else in pop besides the Carly Rae Jepsen song Call Me Maybe. Its the sort of hit that stifles dissent, that blinds with its brightness, that answers to no friction applied against it.

title: Naomi Wolf Sparks Another Debate (on Sex, of Course)
description: WHO gets to say it? Who gets to own it? Who gets to say what happens to it?

title: A Bunk Bed Born of a Couch
description: The convertible couch has been taken to a whole new level. Milano Smart Living, an Italian producer of high-end, space-saving furniture that moved into the New York Design Center last week, is selling a sofa that unfolds into a bunk bed. Named for the Italian word for castle, Multibed Castello springs open with the touch of a finger.

title: Alessi Welcomes the Next Generation
description: Not content with corralling the talents of leading designers and architects, Alessi is getting a head start with the next generation.

title: Mitt Says Dave Hates Him. Not So, Says Dave, Who Invites Him to Appear.
description: Does David Letterman hate Mitt Romney?

title: Furnishings Inspired by Art
description: After, a collection of eight furniture pieces and two wallpaper patterns by the interior designer Kelly Behun and her colleague, Alex P. White, currently on exhibit at R20th Century, pays tribute to the artists, living and dead, who have influenced them.

title: Earthy Lamps With a Disco Vibe
description: Robert Lewiss mica pendant lamps, now occupying the window of the Future Perfect in NoHo, have a disco-geodesic look  which is no surprise considering their origins. Mr. Lewis, a self-taught lighting designer whose pieces can be found at the Ace Hotel in Palm Springs and in several Kiki de Montparnasse boutiques, made the first model while living in Miami in the mid-90s. I was looking for a way to build something without a metal frame, he said. I ended up with an archetypal Buckyball structure, where the pattern holds itself.

title: Sales at Knolls, Jacques Carcanagues and Others
description: Knolls annual sale starts Friday, with 15 percent off iconic midcentury modern furniture, through Sept. 29 (the Richard Schultz 1966 chaise lounge, originally $2,713, will be about $2,306); 76 Ninth Avenue (15th Street), 11th floor, (212) 343-4087.

title: Cuomo Seeks Artists Touch in Replacing Tappan Zee Bridge
description: ALBANY  The artist Jeff Koons is best known for his whimsical sculptures of giant puppies made of flowers, and balloon animals fashioned from stainless steel.

title: Spinning the Family Name
description: ON the eve of New York Fashion Week, Target held a splashy party in a former carriage house on West 15th Street that had been transformed into four brightly colored pop-up shops. It was as if a suburban mall had momentarily alighted in the meatpacking district.

title: Trulia Prices I.P.O. at $17 a Share, Above Expected Range
description: Trulia priced its initial public offering at $17 a share on Wednesday, surpassing expectations as the real estate search site raised $102 million.

title: How I Got These Boots
description: Davy Rothbart reads from an essay in which he picks up a hitchhiker on his way to the Grand Canyon.

title: Ending Its Summer Melt, Arctic Sea Ice Sets a New Low That Leads to Warnings
description: The drastic melting of Arctic sea ice has finally ended for the year, scientists announced Wednesday, but not before demolishing the previous record  and setting off new warnings about the rapid pace of change in the region.

title: Tim Burton, at Home in His Own Head
description: LONDON

title: The Films of Tim Burton
description: Images from Tim Burtons filmography, including his latest movie, Frankenweenie.

title: Fox and TBS Close In on New Baseball Deals
description: Fox Sports is close to a deal with Major League Baseball that will let it add more playoff and regular-season games, justifying its plan to create a new cable sports network, said three people with knowledge of the negotiations. By contrast, TBS will get fewer games in its pending deal.

title: As Daddy, Mark Madoff Lives On
description: On Dec. 11, 2010, my husband, Mark Madoff, hung himself from an exposed beam in the living room of our downtown apartment. Even now I still wake up every morning with a jolt, as if I am hearing the news for the first time that my husband has killed himself. Im rattled for a good five seconds as my brain acknowledges and accepts that Mark is gone. Oddly enough, the painful jarring of my heart is what gives me the strength to get up and start my day. I get up and push forward not only for myself but also for my children, Audrey and Nicholas.

title: Bloombergs Fortune Jumped to $25 Billion, Forbes Estimates
description: Are you better off than you were a year ago? For Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the answer is almost certainly yes.

title: On the Road, a Poet of Lost and Found
description: NEW HAVEN  Davy Rothbart had misplaced his usual hype music, so Rage Against the Machine would have to do. Mr. Rothbart, a writer and a creator of Found magazine,  the repository for forgotten notes and photos, normally listened to Metallicas One to get himself pumped for a show. But on Monday evening he popped a CD with Bombtrack into the player in his rented Dodge minivan and began fist-pumping along.

title: 30 Eye-Catching Accessories From London Fashion Week
description: A look at statement bags, drool-worthy footwear and more from the spring 2013 shows.

title: Q. and A.: Chinas Leadership Transition and Xi Jinping
description: Sometime soon  perhaps next month in October  the most populous nation in the world will begin its biggest leadership transition in a decade. Dozens of the most senior positions in Chinas Communist Party, government and army will change hands in a process that will last months (in the case of the army, perhaps even years.) Here are some questions and answers about this important event. Join the conversation with your own answers and questions in the Comments below.

title: Exhibition Games Canceled
description: The National Hockey League announced the cancellation of the first week of the two-week exhibition schedule on Wednesday, the first games wiped out by the owners lockout imposed last Sunday.

title: This N That
description: NORTH Sixth Street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has undergone a remarkable transformation in the last decade, going from an industrial ghost town to a veritable runway of skinny jeans and European clubgoers. Now the latest change has arrived: an unassuming gay bar.

title: Scene City: New Yorkers for Children Gala
description: Justin Tuck of the New York Giants and John Demsey of Este Lauder are honored for charity work.

title: If in Doubt, Play the Super Bowl Card
description: THE city was quiet after Fashion Week, and though there were a few charity events, the social calendar was pretty light.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,104 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: One Comeback They Could Skip
description: TONY DANZA died recently, twice.

title: After Lending His Style to a Bus, Frazier Offers His Opinion on the Knicks
description: A two-time N.B.A. champion and one of the most famous Knicks, Walt Frazier was greeted by a dozen or so fans while being honored Wednesday by the sightseeing bus company Gray Line New York. He also spoke about the Knicks and their coming season, with the team set to begin training camp in less than two weeks.

title: Creative Destruction
description: Berlin

title: The Inconvenient Truth Behind the Diaoyu/Senkaku Islands
description: Ive had a longstanding interest in the Diaoyu/Senkaku islands, the subject of a dangerous territorial dispute between Japan and China. The United States claims to be neutral but in effect is siding with Japan, and we could be drawn in if a war ever arose. Let me clear that I deplore the violence in the recent anti-Japan protests in China: the violence is reprehensible and makes China look like an irrational bully. Chinas government should rein in this volatile nationalism rather than feed it. This is a dispute that both sides should refer to the International Court of Justice, rather than allow to boil over in the streets. That said, when I look at the underlying question of who has the best claim, Im sympathetic to Chinas position. I dont think it is 100 percent clear, partly because China seemed to acquiesce to Japanese sovereignty between 1945 and 1970, but on balance I find the evidence for Chinese sovereignty quite compelling. The most interesting evidence is emerging from old Japanese government documents and suggests that Japan in effect stole the islands from China in 1895 as booty of war. This article by Han-Yi Shaw, a scholar from Taiwan, explores those documents. I invite any Japanese scholars to make the contrary legal case.  Nicholas Kristof

title: On Planet Proenza
description: IN a world of fashion design densely populated by difficult, messy individuals, one can well understand the temptation to team up and clean up,  la Dolce & Gabbana or Viktor & Rolf. You and your partner may not agree on every inch of rickrack, but hell probably stop you from alcohol-fueled anti-Semitic rants and affairs with a tanned pornographic-film star half your age.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: After Touch Screens, and a New 3-D Printer
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: The 47 Percent May Struggle but the Top 20 Percent Are Feeling Flush
description: There has been a lot of talk about the 1 percent, the 47 percent, the 99 percent or whatever slice of the population is lately in the spotlight.

title: Failing American Families
description: With its matter-of-fact this or that cadence, this 30-second ad recalls the famous 1980s This is your brain on drugs commercials. This was household income when President Obama took office; this was the national debt, an announcer says as a bar chart adjusts accordingly, with the national debt bar growing as the income bar falls.

title: How Ethnicity and Nationality Can Set a Trap
description: ATLANTA

title: The Romney Plan
description: Heres something exceedingly rare in presidential campaign ads: A 100 percent positive commercial. No swipes at the president, no grenades lobbed at the other partys policies. This ad is just 30 seconds of Mr. Romney laying out a rosy, albeit vague, vision of what the country would look like under his leadership.

title: Living on Through a Label
description: THE hot new brands of this season are the old ones.

title: A Lofty Discussion on Ballet
description: SCENE: In a dazzling Midtown apartment with views of New York City and beyond, Sarah Jessica Parker and Valentino Garavani are seated in a living room discussing the ballet. On Thursday night, Ms. Parker, a board member of the New York City Ballet, will be among the hosts of a party that brings together fashion and dance. And Mr. Garavani, who retired from his fashion house in 2008, has created the costumes for four works that will be presented that night.

title: Cant Figure Out the Playoff System? Neither Can the Players
description: ATLANTA  Rory McIlroys supremacy on the PGA Tour brings no guarantee of taking the FedEx Cup title, even if he finishes as high as runner-up at this weeks Tour Championship.

title: Dear Daughter
description: Mr. Romney has a lot of catching up to do among women. The latest New York Times/CBS News poll has Mr. Obama up by 12 percentage points.

title: Chick-fil-A and Chicago Alderman Reach Agreement
description: ATLANTA  The question of whether or not to eat at Chick-fil-A got a bit murkier for people who use the companys chicken sandwiches as a political totem in the culture war over gay rights and marriage.

title: I Know Why the Caged Bird Shrieks
description: When people show you who they are believe them; the first time.

title: Mr. and Mrs. Jesus Christ?
description: AT an academic conference in Rome on Tuesday, Karen L. King, a church historian at Harvard Divinity School, presented a finding that, according to some reports, threatened to overturn what we know about Jesus, as well as the tradition of priestly celibacy. She identified a small fragment of fourth-century papyrus that includes the words, Jesus said to them, My wife... Another clause appears to say, she will be able to be my disciple. Some experts have concluded that the manuscript, written in Coptic, is authentic.

title: When Flexibility Hurts
description: Chicago

title: Endeavours Last Journey, Through Contentious Space
description: LOS ANGELES  The space shuttle Endeavour traveled 122,883,151 miles during its 25 missions, bursting out of the atmosphere at more than 17,000 miles an hour. On the last flight of its 20-year career, a three-day victory lap across the country on the back of a transport aircraft, it will log a few thousand miles more before touching down for the final time on Friday at Los Angeles International Airport.

title: Ashbel Green, Longtime Editor at Knopf, Dies at 84
description: Ashbel Green, a widely respected editor in the publishing industry who shepherded more than 500 books into print for Alfred A. Knopf, including detective novels, the autobiography of Walter Cronkite and the works of Gabriel Garca Mrquez, died on Tuesday in Westerly, R.I. He was 84.

title: Governor and Mayor Are Upset That 2 Backers of Gay Marriage May Fall
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg have had their differences. But on Wednesday, 130 miles apart, they rued the same development: two Republican primaries last week in which challengers may have defeated state senators who voted for same-sex marriage.

title: Louisiana: Arrest in Bomb Threat
description: The police arrested a man suspected of phoning in a bomb threat to Louisiana State University on Monday, prompting a campuswide evacuation. The man, William Bouvay Jr., 42, of Baton Rouge, La., was taken into custody shortly before midnight on Tuesday, the campus police department said in a statement. On Friday morning, Mr. Bouvay had called the 911 dispatcher and said that multiple bombs around the campus would detonate within two hours, the authorities said. Law enforcement agencies determined that the call had been made from a deactivated cellphone that could make only emergency calls; they were able to pinpoint the area from which the call was made through GPS technology. Mr. Bouvay, who was in the area, agreed to go in for questioning, but ultimately confessed and told the police where the phone could be found, the police said. They declined to discuss possible motives for the calls, but said Mr. Bouvay had been arrested in 2004 for making harassing phone calls to a former girlfriend who worked at the university.

title: A Reminder to Look(!) Both Ways
description: The British have a history of being unlucky on American shores, and in the winter of 1931, Winston S. Churchill was no exception. Alighting from a cab on Fifth Avenue on the Upper East Side, Churchill, accustomed to his home countrys driving conventions, looked right on the then-two way avenue when he should have looked left.

title: Google to Topple Facebook as Leader in Display Ads, eMarketer Says
description: Google is set to overtake Facebook in earning money from display ads, making it the leader in all three types of digital advertising  search, mobile and display.

title: Honor Inspires Aching Couples to Keep Going
description: ATLANTA  For Fred Couples, who is laid up with a sore back, the timing of his notification of admittance to the World Golf Hall of Fame last week was ideal. It will push me to play a couple more years, said Couples, 52, winner of 23 titles on the PGA and the Champions tours.

title: Washington State Makes It Harder to Opt Out of Immunizations
description: Washington State is home to Bill and Melinda Gates, champions of childhood vaccines across the globe. Its university boasts cutting-edge vaccine research. But when it comes to getting children immunized, until recently, the state was dead last.

title: A Tribes Epidemic of Child Sex Abuse, Minimized for Years
description: SPIRIT LAKE INDIAN RESERVATION, N.D.  The man who plays Santa Claus here is a registered child sex offender and a convicted rapist. One of the brothers of the tribal chairman raped a child, and a second brother sexually abused a 12-year-old girl. They are among a number of men convicted of sex crimes against children on this remote home of the Spirit Lake Sioux tribe, which has among the highest proportion of sex offenders in the country.

title: Mitts Snake-Bit Season
description: Our topic for today is: When Bad Things Happen to Mitt Romney.

title: It Takes One to Know One
description: As I watched a video of Mitt Romney scolding moochers suffering from a culture of dependency, I thought of American soldiers Ive met in Afghanistan and Iraq. They dont pay federal income tax while theyre in combat zones, and they rely on government benefits when they come back.

title: Advocate of Democracy in Myanmar Meets Obama
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama welcomed Myanmars opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, to the Oval Office on Wednesday, amid signs that the administration was likely to further ease sanctions on her once-isolated Southeast Asian nation.

title: The Democrats and the Liberal Catholic Voter
description: To the Editor:

title: What Makes a Leader
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Should Teachers Do It All?
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinas Economic Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: Romney Campaign Cautious With Ad Budget, Even in Key States
description: Mitt Romney has had a light campaign schedule lately. He held his first rally in five days on Wednesday night.

title: Skepticism and Caution Greet Indias New Policy on Retailers
description: MUMBAI, India  When Indian policy makers announced last week that they would allow big-box foreign retailers like Wal-Mart into the country, they pledged that it was the beginning of a long-awaited second wave of economic reforms that would make the country more hospitable to business.

title: Ovechkin Returns to Russian Team
description: Alex Ovechkin is returning to his former Russian team, Dynamo Moscow, for the duration of the N.H.L. lockout, while Pavel Datsyuk has signed with Dynamos city rival CSKA Moscow. Both K.H.L. clubs announced the moves on Wednesday.

title: Happy (Un)constitution(al) Day
description: If you regularly hang out around schools or colleges, you might have noticed that this is, by presidential proclamation, Constitution Week, and that Monday was Constitution Day.

title: In a Tight Race, Obama Draws on the Levers of His Power
description: WASHINGTON  For months, government lawyers and economists worked behind the scenes to develop a trade case against China. Then last month came a eureka moment: They confirmed the existence of a Chinese subsidy program for automobiles and parts that in their view violated international trade rules. They finished a complaint, circulated it among agencies and proposed a time frame for filing.

title: Santiago Carrillo, a Spanish Communist Leader, Dies at 97
description: Santiago Carrillo, who evolved from a bomb-throwing opponent of Gen. Francisco Franco and his fascist forces into a Spanish Communist leader who promoted a more moderate, democratic European Communist Party independent of the Soviet Union, died on Tuesday at his home in Madrid. He was 97.

title: High Court in Italy Backs Convictions for Rendition
description: ROME  Italys supreme court on Wednesday upheld the convictions of 23 Americans in the 2003 abduction of an Egyptian cleric in Milan, making it the first case to successfully challenge the contentious American program of extraordinary rendition.

title: Apples iPhone Update Leaves Out Googles Maps
description: Millions of iPhone customers may soon find themselves losing touch with an old friend: Googles maps.

title: Vox Pop Trumps the Parish Bulletin
description: Separation of church and state should be a cherished no-brainer under the Constitution, but that never seems so in an election year when some clergyman or other cannot resist the temptation to speak out as a political boss.

title: Ineffective Counsel in Georgia
description: Robert Wayne Holsey, on death row in Georgia for killing a police officer, is seeking a new sentencing hearing because he received ineffective counsel. He should get one. His own lawyer told a Georgia trial court reviewing the case that he probably shouldnt have been allowed to represent anybody while he was ostensibly providing a defense.

title: Segregation Prominent in Schools, Study Finds
description: The United States is increasingly a multiracial society, with white students accounting for just over half of all students in public schools, down from four-fifths in 1970.

title: Rubn Zuno Arce, Guilty in Drug Killing, Dies at 82
description: Rubn Zuno Arce, a central defendant in the 1985 torture and killing of an American drug enforcement agent in Mexico, a crime that increased tension between Mexico and the United States in part because of Mr. Zunos ties to Mexican government officials, died on Tuesday in a federal prison in Coleman, Fla. He was 82.

title: AT&T Chief Speaks Out on Texting at the Wheel
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Randall L. Stephenson, the chairman and chief executive of AT&T, spoke Wednesday morning at a conference in New York to hundreds of major investors, including Fortune 500 executives. The topic was the state of the telecom businesses, but he began with a request on a different topic: Please dont text and drive.

title: A Tight End Who Cuts Loose
description: Since joining the Giants in the off-season, tight end Martellus Bennett has proved to be a singular character. An outspoken player on a roster known for being almost allergic to controversy, Bennett is also a key part of the Giants offensive plans. He is big and athletic and has the potential to become a favorite target for quarterback Eli Manning. But there are so many reasons beyond his raw talent that Bennett is one of the most intriguing players in the N.F.L.

title: Jeter, After Resting in Game 1, Returns to Shortstop
description: On Wednesday afternoon, for the first game of a day-night doubleheader at Yankee Stadium, Derek Jeter rested. He wore a blue hooded sweatshirt and the expression of a child forced to miss a class field trip because of the flu. He had his spikes on, but for the first time since June 27, Jeter did not need to use them.

title: A Closer Look at Redistribution
description: Amid the fallout over Mitt Romneys comments that 47 percent of Americans believed they were victims and are dependent upon government, the Republican Party is stepping up attacks that President Obama favors redistributing wealth, citing a 1998 audio clip of him saying, I actually believe in redistribution.

title: The United States and the Muslim World
description: The anti-Islam video that set off attacks against American embassies and violent protests in the Muslim world was a convenient fuse for rage. Deeper forces are at work in those societies, riven by pent-up anger over a lack of jobs, economic stagnation and decades of repression by previous Arab governments.

title: Foes of Modified Corn Find Support in a Study
description: Rats fed either genetically engineered corn or the herbicide Roundup had an increased risk of developing tumors, suffering organ damage and dying prematurely, according to a new study that was immediately swept up into the furor surrounding crop biotechnology when it was released Wednesday.

title: One Year Later, Military Says Gay Policy Is Working
description: WASHINGTON  Every Tuesday and Friday morning in a dining area tucked behind Dunkin Donuts in the Pentagons main food court, a gay coffee group meets to talk, do a little business and tell a few jokes.

title: Struggling Young Adults Are Question Mark for Campaigns
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Millions of struggling working-class young adults, many in battleground states like Florida, Colorado and Wisconsin, are up for grabs in this election, making up what experts call one of the most potentially powerful but often overlooked voting blocs.

title: Things I Saw  No. 32
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: U.P.S. Bills Stores as Small-Business Solution
description: FEWER people are mailing their own packages these days, so shippers are looking for innovative ways to win new customers and persuade current clients to spend more. And what could be a more enticing image than homemade pie?

title: An Autocrat, but Still an Improvement?
Squinting at the Polls in New York City
description: Many New Yorkers who went to the polls last Thursday were a little surprised to find a large magnifying sheet inside their voting booths. One glance at the ballot explained why. The names of the candidates were tiny, like the lower lines in the optometrists eye chart or the small print on a credit card notice. Even voters with excellent vision found themselves squinting in search of their preferred candidates.

title: To Help Sanchez and Holmes, Healthy Keller May Be the Key
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Jets tight end Dustin Keller showed up Wednesday for practice in full gear, high-stepping over a row of barriers before running 30-yard sprints with elegant, exaggerated strides. That part of the day seemed to go smoothly.

title: Joshua Morse III, Law School Dean Who Defied Segregation, Dies at 89
description: Joshua Morse III, who as dean of the University of Mississippi School of Law in the 1960s defied segregationist tradition by admitting the schools first black students, a move that led to the desegregation of Mississippis legal profession and judiciary, died last Friday at his home in Tallahassee, Fla. He was 89.

title: Key Giants to Miss Panthers Game
description: The Giants will be without several key players when they face the Carolina Panthers on Thursday night: wide receiver Hakeem Nicks, running back Ahmad Bradshaw and offensive lineman David Diehl were among five players who did not make the trip to Charlotte, N.C., because of injuries.

title: Ex-Commander in Afghanistan Eyed for Africa
description: WASHINGTON  Gen. David M. Rodriguez, a former top Army commander in Afghanistan, has been chosen by the Pentagon to take charge of the militarys Africa Command, which in the wake of the Arab Spring has become one of the Defense Departments most challenging theaters of operation.

title: Fewer Children Are Found Exposed to Violent Crime
description: Exposure to violence has a profound effect on children, making them more prone to emotional problems like depression and anxiety and increasing the chances that they will either become victims of violence themselves or commit crimes in later life. But a new government report suggests that the number of children in the United States who are exposed to violent crime has dropped precipitously in the last two decades, a decline that one expert termed breathtaking.

title: In Discarding of Kidneys, System Reveals Its Flaws
description: ST. PAUL  Last year, 4,720 people died while waiting for kidney transplants in the United States. And yet, as in each of the last five years, more than 2,600 kidneys were recovered from deceased donors and then discarded without being transplanted, government data show.

title: After Death, Helping to Prolong Life
description: EDINA, Minn.  Just down the hallway, in Room 356, Curtis Kellys body lay covered to the chest by a white blanket, his torso rising and falling with the help of a ventilator. A neurologist at Fairview Southdale Hospital had declared him brain-dead nearly six hours earlier.

title: Recap: Red Bulls (0) vs. Kansas City (2)
description: HARRISON, N.J.  The only number that normally matters in soccer is the final score. Statistics are usually superfluous, but Wednesday night at Red Bull Arena, statistics told the story.

title: Guilty Pleas in Scheme to Help Applicants Cheat on Written Driving Test
description: A couple who ran a driving school in Brooklyn for more than a decade pleaded guilty on Wednesday to concocting an elaborate scheme to help non-English speakers cheat on written tests to obtain New York State commercial drivers licenses.

title: An Earthy Take on a Heavenly Book
description: God moves in unmysterious ways at the Flea Theater these days. There he was, manning (if that verb may be so applied) the box office on the night I arrived to see Thomas Bradshaws Job, in which he plays an important supporting role to the notoriously afflicted title character. And there was Gods son, Jesus, serving as an usher downstairs.

title: Whats That in Italy?
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  We havent seen constructor John R. Conrad for nigh on five years now, but he has returned today with a RING OF FIRE for us to jump through.

title: Corrections: September 20, 2012
description: NATIONAL

title: Drawn to Food and Liquor, Burglar Gains a Stiff Term
description: He was a serial burglar  with a taste for vodka, sake, pork belly and hamburgers  who broke into several Manhattan restaurants and bars just before sunrise.

title: Judge Details a Rule Requiring Pro Bono Work by Aspiring Lawyers
description: The states chief judge on Wednesday announced the details of a new rule  the first of its kind in the nation  requiring law students to perform 50 hours of unpaid work as a condition of practicing in New York.

title: Rhode Island: Central Falls Mayor Quits and Is to Plead Guilty to Corruption
description: The mayor of the financially struggling city of Central Falls resigned Wednesday and agreed to plead guilty to federal corruption charges. Prosecutors say that Mayor Charles D. Moreau directed work boarding up at least 167 properties in the city, buffeted by a wave of foreclosures, to a friend and political supporter, Michael G. Bouthillette, in exchange for gifts. Mr. Moreau, a four-term Democrat, was given an advisory role when the city went into receivership in 2010. It went under bankruptcy protection last year, from which it is expected to emerge next month. Mr. Bouthillette was also charged. Prosecutors said they would seek prison time for both men, but did not specify how much.

title: Lottery Numbers
When Justice Makes You Gasp
description: Theres a distinct sound made by audience members watching The Exonerated. Its a sharp exhale, part incredulous, part angry, and delivered with a wince or a shake of the head. That sound is a visceral reaction to stories of people unjustly sentenced to die. It staves off the compulsion to cry out, or maybe just to cry.

title: Defrocked Priest Sues New York Archdiocese for Libel Over Sexual Abuse Statement
description: A once-prominent Roman Catholic monsignor who was removed from the priesthood in 2010 for sexual abuse of a minor took the unusual step on Wednesday of filing a federal lawsuit against the New York Archdiocese, claiming he had been libeled in a church statement.

title: Inspectors Certified Pakistani Factory as Safe Before Disaster
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A prominent factory monitoring group heavily financed by industry gave a clean bill of health to a Pakistani apparel plant last month, just weeks before a fire engulfed the premises and killed nearly 300 workers, many of them trapped behind locked exit doors.

title: Belarus: Election Monitors Denied Visas
description: Belarus, which is preparing to hold a parliamentary election over the weekend, denied visas for two observers from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, representing a rocky resumption of ties with the election-monitoring group. The O.S.C.E. is returning to Belarus for the first time since it was expelled after a contentious 2010 presidential election.

title: Seeking a National Team
description: Soccer players with ties to Kosovo are seeking recognition for a national soccer team.

title: On Air and Before Audiences, Romney Makes Push for Hispanic Vote
description: MIAMI  Mitt Romney, hunting for an electoral edge in swing states, is intensifying his push for Hispanic voters, ratcheting up his Spanish-language advertising, deploying a Spanish-speaking son to court Latino leaders and putting himself in front of a growing number of Hispanic audiences.

title: In a City Plagued by Violence, a Spike in Crime Opens Eyes Nationwide
description: MARSEILLE, France  Walid Marzouki and his girlfriend stopped their black Renault Twingo at a red light on the deserted Boulevard Casanova late one night in August. Another car pulled alongside. The driver opened his window, pulled out an automatic rifle and killed Mr. Marzouki, using more than 20 rounds.

title: Harvey Shines but Mets Dont in Loss to Phillies
description: Fans at Citi Field rose to their feet Wednesday night, cheering with expectation, excitement and some incredulity as the Mets stood one out from their first home victory since Aug. 26.

title: In Switch, Kickstarter Darling Amanda Palmer Will Now Pay Volunteer Musicians
description: Amanda Palmer, the rock musician known for using social media to build financial and fan support, has reversed course in the face of fierce criticism and decided to pay volunteer musicians who were invited to join her band city by city on a tour.

title: Longtime Lopez Colleague Chosen to Lead Brooklyn Democrats
description: With his most formidable challengers effectively conceding, Frank R. Seddio, a friend and longtime colleague of the scandal-tarnished Brooklyn Democratic chairman Vito J. Lopez, was chosen Wednesday night by party leaders to succeed him.

title: Quirky Eyewear Brand Tries TV as an Ad Medium
description: A nontraditional e-commerce company is testing a traditional advertising medium, television, but with a twist.

title: Income Data Shows Widening Gap Between New York Citys Richest and Poorest
description: The rich got richer and the poor got poorer in New York City last year as the poverty rate reached its highest point in more than a decade, and the income gap in Manhattan, already wider than almost anywhere else in the country, rivaled disparities in sub-Saharan Africa.

title: Senate Forecast: What Has Gone Wrong for G.O.P. Candidates?
description: The trend in the presidential race has been difficult to discern lately. President Obama has very probably gained ground since the conventions, but its hard to say exactly how much, and how quickly his bounce is eroding.

title: Swiss Drug Giant Picks Manhattan for Research Site
description: What New Jersey loses, New York City gains, at least in part.

title: Word of the Day | elixir
description: elixir \i-lik-sr\ noun

title: Israel Wins Opener in World Baseball Classic Qualifiers
description: Behind two homers by Nate Freiman, Israel won its opening game in the World Baseball Classic qualifiers, defeating South Africa, 7-3, in Jupiter, Fla. Freiman, who plays in Class AA in the Padres organization, hit a first-inning solo shot, then added another in the ninth as Israel built a 7-0 lead.

title: Starbucks to Introduce Single-Serve Coffee Maker
description: Continuing its foray into new lines of business, Starbucks is introducing a single-cup coffee machine that will allow consumers to make their own lattes at home with real milk.

title: Iran: Top Nuclear Negotiator Calls Talks With Big Powers Constructive
description: Saeed Jalili, Irans top negotiator in talks with the big powers over his countrys disputed uranium enrichment program, called negotiations with Catherine Ashton, his counterpart, constructive and helpful, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported on Wednesday. The talks on Tuesday in Istanbul, their first face-to-face meeting in three months, produced no breakthroughs, and it remained unclear when they would meet again.

title: Could Gujarat Elections Be a Close Race?

title: Come September
description: Oh, the days grow short when we reach September. Kurt Weill and Maxwell Anderson got that right in September Song, didnt they? Cheerful its not, but for a year in my early 20s, the only music I could stand to hear was Weills. I was adrift, and politically charged cabaret numbers  often sung in a language I did not understand  somehow anchored me. I downed plenty of whiskey back then (and still do), but as with music, my taste in drinks was growing up. It was then that I first made a martini, first tasted absinthe and could, for the first time, call myself a regular at a New York bar  one where an indulgent bartender might sometimes pop onto the sound system the Lotte Lenya tape I just happened to have in my backpack.

title: Food of the Ancients
description: Ive traveled to the Yucatn Peninsula a dozen times looking for real Mayan cuisine, driving through the center and up and down both (or is it all three?) coasts, but the food thats at the soul of the Yucatn is not easily discovered. What you get as an outsider is feast food like cochinita pibil  a sometimes-wonderful chili-marinated pork buried and cooked in an earthen pit  which is not enough to have you rush down there and start eating.

title: Do You Really Expect Your Business to Get You Through Retirement?
