title: Man Mauled by Tiger at Zoo Is Charged
description: The police said on Saturday that they issued a desk appearance ticket for criminal trespass to a man who leapt from a monorail into a tiger enclosure at the Bronx Zoo on Friday.

title: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi in New York
description: The leader of Myanmars political opposition made her first visit to the United States in some 40 years.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Sept. 23
description: Campaign surrogates for each of the candidates have been dispatched to the Sunday shows this week, focusing less on the unrest in the Arab world and more on the economy and current climate of the campaign trail. But first, the candidates themselves will appear on Univisions Al Punto for an in-depth look at their policies and platforms. Telemundos Enfoque will air an extended version of a sit-down with Mitt Romney, who goes into detail about what some view as problems within his campaign and United States foreign policy toward Mexico and Latin America. Representative Xavier Becerra of California will be on hand to deliver a Democratic rebuttal.

title: Breathtaking
description: Just you wait, enry iggins, just you wait!Youll be sorry, but your tearsll be too late!Youll be broke, and Ill have money;Will I help you? Dont be funny!Just you wait, enry iggins, just you wait!  ELIZA DOOLITTLE, My Fair Lady

title: 30 Seconds With Nick Buoniconti
description: Nick Buoniconti was the linebacker who anchored the No-Name Defense for the Miami Dolphins when they went undefeated in 1972. His Dolphins teams made three consecutive Super Bowl appearances, winning two. Buoniconti, 71, was inducted to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 2001.

title: A Pipeline From Israel to Storrs
description: As Israel tries to qualify for next years World Baseball Classic, it has turned to a team of predominantly American players. It recalls the time when Jim Calhoun did just the opposite, looking to Israel for talent as he was building a mens basketball powerhouse at Connecticut.

title: The Caucus Click: Stopping for a Snack
Police Divers Pull Man From Capsized Boat
description: Four adults and two children plunged into the water just south of the Atlantic Beach Bridge off Long Island on Saturday morning after a boat they were in suddenly capsized, the authorities said.

title: With Sharon Stone as Auctioneer, amFAR Milano Has a Benefit
description: Milan is one of my favorite cities, the designer Kenneth Cole said Saturday night at a black-tie benefit for amFAR Milano, held for the fourth year straight at Milan Fashion Week.

title: In Kennedy Recordings, Historys Raw Materials
description: BOSTON  President John F. Kennedy opened the newspaper one day in 1963 and learned to his horror that military aides had built a hospital bedroom for his pregnant wife at an air base on Cape Cod in case she went into labor. He thought the $5,000 spent on the furniture was wasteful and would be a public-relations disaster that would prompt Congress to cut his military budget. The angry president picked up the phone.

title: Fighting for First, for as Long as It Takes
description: When the game seemed over, Ichiro Suzuki led off the bottom of the 13th inning with an infield single. A misty rain had begun to fall, like the soft spray in a carwash. The low sun through the clouds covered the stadium in a strange orange glow.

title: Man Arrested in Rape Along the Hudson River
description: A young woman was raped in Hudson River Park in Lower Manhattan on Saturday, and shortly afterward the police arrested a convicted sex offender in the crime.

title: U.S. League Is Loaded With Talent and Drama
description: If it were not for the Internet, there would be no United States Chess League, because it is the Web that allows teams from across the country to play one another without expensive airplane trips.

title: Sept. 22: Little Agreement Among Pollsters on Enthusiasm Gap
description: Saturday brought a light volume of polling data, and the FiveThirtyEight forecast was not much changed. Barack Obamas chances of winning the Electoral College are 77.5 percent, according to the model, slightly improved from 76.9 percent in Fridays forecast.

title: Jets Cut Bryan Thomas
description: The Jets made a surprising move Saturday by cutting the veteran linebacker Bryan Thomas to clear roster space for cornerback Donnie Fletcher ahead of Sundays game at Miami.

title: With Playoff Berth Secured, Liberty Unload on Shock
description: NEWARK  Citing recent champions who capitalized on the momentum of late-season surges, Liberty Coach John Whisenant says his team is in the right spot to challenge for the W.N.B.A. title.

title: Giving Viewers Some New Music to Treasure
description: Last month, just as Tim McGraw was about to sit down for his post-set interview in the Austin City Limits studio, his eyes wandered toward a framed photograph of George Straits first appearance on the PBS concert showcase. Mr. McGraw immediately ran back to his dressing room, grabbed his wife, Faith Hill, and showed her Mr. Straits baby face, beaming from beneath a tall white cowboy hat.

title: In Ryan Country, Obama Keeps Up Attack Over 47 Percent Remarks
description: MILWAUKEE  President Obama traveled to the home turf of his opponents running mate, Representative Paul D. Ryan, on Saturday, reprising his attack on Mitt Romney for remarks he made behind closed doors characterizing Obama voters as the 47 percent of the population who depend on government handouts and do not pay federal income taxes.

title: Shumpert, Walking Without Limp, Says He Is Feeling Fine
description: The first guest speaker for Allan Houstons Five Borough Basketball Tour was Knicks guard Iman Shumpert. When he was introduced, Shumpert was cheered by more than 100 children who participated in the event in Brooklyn. Shumpert smiled. He didnt have a brace on his left knee. And he walked without a limp.

title: How Perry Lost His Edge in Bid to Be President
description: Jay Root is the author of Oops! A Diary From the 2012 Campaign Trail, from which this article is adapted. It was published by Byliner.

title: For State Candidates of All Stripes, the Trick Is to Avoid Leaning Too Far
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Into the Cloud
description: James Glanz of The New York Times and Ken Brill, an expert in the field, tour a data center and show what is required to keep it going even when power goes out.

title: Into the Cloud
description: James Glanz of The New York Times and Ken Brill, founder of the Uptime Institute, tour a data center and show what is required to keep it going around the clock.

title: Orioles Sixth Straight Win Is Another in Extra Innings
description: BOSTON  At 3:30 a.m. Saturday, Mark Reedy and his son, Dan, put on their Nick Markakis throwback jerseys, climbed into a Jeep and left their Baltimore home for the seven-and-a-half-hour drive to Fenway Park.

title: An Evangelical Is Back From Exile, Lifting Romney
description: DULUTH, Ga.  Ralph Reed is clearly relishing his revival.

title: College Football Replay: Sept. 22
description: The days games included Central Michigans upset of Iowa and a shutout of Kentucky by Florida.

title: Snedeker Grabs a Lead; Now Hell Try to Keep It
description: ATLANTA  If Brandt Snedeker were a football player, he would be the tailback who has broken a few long, breezy runs for scores but has not been able to punch it in from a yard out.

title: A Par-3 Finishing Hole Comes With Its Share of Challenges
description: ATLANTA  When a golfer plunges a tee into the turf on No. 18 at East Lake Golf Club, his first impulse might be to blink twice to make sure his eyes do not deceive him.

title: Corrections: September 23, 2012
description: NEW YORK

title: Power, Pollution and the Internet
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  Jeff Rothschilds machines at Facebook had a problem he knew he had to solve immediately. They were about to melt.

title: In U.S. Exit From Iraq, Failed Efforts and Challenges
description: The request was an unusual one, and President Obama himself made the confidential phone call to Jalal Talabani, the Iraqi president.

title: Lottery Numbers
Margaret McGarry, Simon Tuchman
description: Margaret Elizabeth McGarry, a daughter of Dr. Laura G. McGarry and Dr. Terence M. McGarry of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married Saturday to Simon Isaac Tuchman, a son of Felicia P. Buebel and Jeffrey N. Tuchman of Pleasantville, N.Y. Rabbi Scott Matous officiated at the Tappan Hill Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Veronica Baugh, Diana Osterfeld
description: Veronica Eileen Baugh and Diana Beth Osterfeld were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. Virginia VerEecke, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Park, a restaurant.

title: Byron Kantrow, Matthew Slosar
description: Byron Lane Kantrow and Matthew William Slosar were married Saturday near the Pine Bank Arch, a pedestrian bridge in Central Park. A friend of the couple, Nikki James, a star of The Book of Mormon on Broadway who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Jessica Schultz, Andrew Floyd
description: Jessica Lynne Schultz and Andrew Talis Floyd were married Saturday at the Church on the Hill in Lenox, Mass. The Rev. Steven A. Small, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony, with Rebecca Floyd, the grooms sister, who is also a minister of the United Church of Christ, taking part.

title: Mai Dinh, Eric Ho
description: Mai Jannette Dinh and Shinn-Yow Eric Ho were married Saturday evening at the Peggy Notebaert Nature Museum in Chicago. The Rev. Rebecca Armstrong, a Humanist minister, led the event, which incorporated a tea ceremony in Chinese and Vietnamese traditions.

title: Teale Clark, Tarlton Long Jr.
description: Teale Lawrence Clark, the daughter of Linda W. Clark and E. McMichael Clark Jr. of Locust Valley, N.Y., was married there Saturday to Tarlton Heath Long Jr., the son of Harriet B. Long and Mr. Long of Charlotte, N.C. The Rev. Michael Sniffen performed the ceremony at St. Johns of Lattingtown Episcopal Church.

title: Sabrina Howell and Robert Berschinski
description: Sabrina Tugendrajch Howell and Robert Gardner Berschinski were married Saturday evening at Sharp Rock Vineyards in Sperryville, Va. Eliot Pence, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Danielle LaRaia, Andrew Barna Jr.
description: Danielle Kathleen LaRaia and Andrew Alec Barna Jr. were married Saturday at Our Lady of the Cape in Brewster, Mass. The Rev. John R. Dolan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Emma Haberl, Andrew Angerer
description: Emma Victoria Haberl, a daughter of Kate OBrian and Robert J. Haberl, both of New York, was married Saturday to Andrew James Angerer, the son of Jennifer and Thomas Angerer of Kettering, Ohio. The brides stepfather, Robert W. Etherington III, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the weekend home of Alison Overseth, a friend of the brides mother, in Bedford Hills, N.Y.

title: Rachel Been, Benjamin Brown
description: Rachel Lara Been, the daughter of Diane Israel Been and William H. Been Jr. of San Francisco, was married Saturday to Benjamin Nevin Sayre Brown, a son of Lynne C. Breslin of New York and the late Geoffrey W. Brown. Tyson Evans, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the home of the grooms mother in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Lauren Yee, Zachary Zwillinger
description: Lauren Denise Yee and Zachary Stein Zwillinger were married Saturday in San Francisco. State Senator Leland Y. Yee, a San Francisco Democrat who is not related to the bride, officiated at the M. H. de Young Memorial Museum under the California law that allows sitting legislators this authority.

title: Lily Parshall, Paul Wachter
description: Lily Low Parshall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David B. Parshall of New York, was married there Saturday to Paul Alexander Wachter, a son of Marianne Agholm and Theodore J. Wachter, both of Columbia, S.C. Eugene L. Nardelli, a retired appellate justice of State Supreme Court in New York, officiated at the Colony Club.

title: Clare Whipple and Robert Bergan
description: Dr. Clare Hope Whipple, a daughter of Joan Shlora Whipple and George Amiel Whipple III of Rye, N.Y., was married there Saturday afternoon to Robert John Bergan, the son of Anne Fallon Bergan and Robert T. Bergan of Exeter, N.H. The Rev. Daniel P. OReilly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Resurrection.

title: Trevor McLaren and Owen Ryan
description: Trevor Douglas McLaren and Owen Patrick Ryan were married Saturday in Washington. Guy Cecil, the executive director of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee and a Universal Life minister, officiated at the couples apartment.

title: Emily Levine, Matthew Rascoff
description: Emily Jane Levine and Matthew Zev Rascoff are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Daniel F. Greyber at the Cotton Room at Golden Belt, an events space in Durham, N.C.

title: Alais Griffin, Christopher Elbrecht
description: Alais Lachlan Maclean Griffin and Christopher Alan Elbrecht were married Saturday at the Warren United Church in Warren, Vt. The Rev. Susan G. McKnight, a minister of the United Church of Christ and the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Amber Forrester, Patrick McPeak
description: Amber Lee Forrester, a daughter of Lisa T. Forrester and F. Lee Forrester of Hopewell, N.J., was married at her parents home Saturday to Patrick William McPeak, a son of Isabella C. McPeak of Seattle and Glenn C. McPeak of Sarasota, Fla. The brides father, who sits on the New Jersey Superior Court in Trenton, officiated.

title: Lauren OGarro-Moore and Colin Brown

Joseph of Fresh Meadows, Queens, and the late Mr. Mack Jr., who lived in Brooklyn. Elizabeth M. Phaire, a Universal Brotherhood Movement minister, officiated at Mymoon, a Brooklyn restaurant.

description: Elizabeth Ottesen Prentke and Stuart Michael Yingst were married Saturday at Locusts on Hudson, an event space in Staatsburg, N.Y. The Rev. Terence L. Elsberry, an Episcopal priest, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

description: Alice Jeeyoung Hong and Brant Duncan Kuehn were married Saturday at St. Elizabeth Roman Catholic Church in Edgartown, Mass. The Rev. Michael R. Nagle, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Jonna McLaughlin, Brian Lonergan
description: Jonna Allison McLaughlin and Brian Parker Lonergan were married Saturday at the summer home of the brides family in Lake Luzerne, N.Y. The Rev. Erik Kolbell, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

title: Kathryn Babick, Benjamin Brickner
description: Kathryn Linda Babick and Benjamin Theodore Brickner were married Saturday at the Mountain Lakes House in Princeton, N.J. John Richard Kunz, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Shelly Johnson, Steven Soutendijk
description: Shelly Ryan Johnson, the daughter of Deborah Templeton Johnson and Robert W. Johnson of Chesapeake, Va., and Steven Armstrong Soutendijk, a son of Kathryn Markel Soutendijk and Huibert A. Soutendijk of Sagaponack, N.Y., were married Saturday at the home of the grooms parents. Bruce M. Kaplan, a retired Family Court judge who presided in the Bronx, officiated.

title: Heidi Bertels, Jess Brallier
description: Heidi Malvina Josephus Bertels and Dr. Jess Wallace Brallier were married Saturday at the City Hall of Antwerp, Belgium. Stephan Bogaert, the first alderman of the District of Antwerp, officiated.

title: Allison Doran, Adam Benenson
description: Allison Jane Doran, a daughter of Susan C. Doran and Robert P. Doran of New Canaan, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Adam Sarnoff Hartley Benenson, a son of Serena Sarnoff Benenson of New Canaan and Thomas H. Benenson of Conway, S.C. Susan Guthrie Ceresa, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated at Grace Farms in New Canaan.

title: Kate Stinson, James Webster
description: Kate Delamere Stinson and James Joseph Webster were married Saturday at the Cathedral Church of St. James in Toronto. Canon David Brinton, an Anglican priest and the cathedrals vicar, performed the ceremony.

title: Sara Gross, Konrad Kaczmarek
description: Sara Rose Gross, the daughter of Lorraine H. Gross and Alon W. Gross, of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and Konrad Eric Kaczmarek, the son of Sheila F. Kaczmarek and Leonard K. Kaczmarek of Guilford, Conn., were married Saturday at the home of the grooms parents. Rayzl Feuer, a friend of the grooms family who was ordained by Aleph, a Jewish spiritual organization, performed the ceremony.

title: Jessica Vascellaro, Samuel Lessin
description: Jessica Elizabeth Vascellaro and Samuel Wharton Lessin were married Saturday at the Santa Lucia Preserve in Carmel, Calif. Philip M. Wharton, an uncle of the groom who became an American Marriage Ministries minister for the event, officiated.

title: Maeve Rullo and Joshua Lahey
description: Maeve Allegra Rullo and Joshua Michael Lahey were married Saturday evening at the Emerson Resort, an event space in Mount Tremper, N.Y. Adam Connolly, a friend of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Alexandra Nez, Patrick Costello
description: Alexandra Crawford Nez and Patrick Charles Costello were married Saturday evening at the University of Massachusetts Club in Boston. Vernon Hunte, a friend of the couple who received a one-day solemnization certificate from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, officiated.

title: Jessica Freese, George Turner
description: Jessica Lynn Freese, a daughter of Karen J. Freese and Robert W. Freese of Brownsburg, Ind., was married Saturday evening to George Damon Turner, the son of Sally D. Turner and Roger D. Turner of Greenwich, Conn. P. Kevin Castel, a judge of the Southern District of New York, officiated at the Bryant Park Grill in New York.

title: Tessa Benson, Tucker Tooley
description: Tessa Menefee Benson and William Ryan Tooley are to be married Sunday at All Saints-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Santa Barbara, Calif. The Rev. Sandra Casey-Martus, an Episcopal priest and the churchs associate rector, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Katherine Thompson, Andrew Brunner
description: Dr. Katherine Dodge Thompson and Dr. Andrew Mark Brunner were married Saturday afternoon at the Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Lynne Alley-Grant, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

title: How to Settle the Fight Over Some Guano-Covered Rocks
description: HONG KONG  No matter what theyre called by their claimants in China, Japan and Taiwan, the East Asian islands at the center of an angry dispute are little more than remote shards of guano-covered rock.

title: College Football Around the Country
description: TAYLOR HEINICKE The quarterback set a Division I record by passing for 730 yards as Old Dominion beat New Hampshire, 64-61. Heinicke had 55 completions on 79 attempts, setting team records for both and coming two completions short of the Football Championship Subdivision record. Sam Durley of Eureka (Ill.) College set the N.C.A.A. single-game mark with 736 passing yards in a Division II game Sept. 1.

title: Seminoles Stand Atop A.C.C. After Offense vs. Offense Duel
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  It was a harmless, clichd joke  Florida State Coach Jimbo Fisher saying he had appealed to use 13 or 14 defenders to slow Clemsons offense  that now seemed facetious. The same compliment could have been paid to Fishers offense, but no defender laughed now. If either No. 4 Florida State or No. 10 Clemson had such an advantage, it might not have mattered, as each offense hummed along Saturday.

title: Notre Dame Improves to 4-0 for the First Time in a Decade
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  Notre Dames return to national prominence took another step forward Saturday night. It was far from graceful, but the 11th-ranked Fighting Irish are 4-0 for the first time in a decade after knocking off No. 18 Michigan, 13-6.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: Tehelkas cover story this week, The Invisible Dead, is about malaria, which the magazine calls Chhattisgarhs silent killer. Officially, the story says, there have been no malaria deaths in the state this year; investigating such claims, the writers found what they call a snare of lies and Stalinist statistics.

title: Ecstasy in the Front Row
description: The front row of campaign events is the place for the dedicated, the excited and the superfans.

title: Now Streaming | Marni Spring 2013 Womens Collection
description: The Spring 2013 womens collection show from Marni at Milan Fashion Week. Delays may occur.

title: In Praise of What Has Been Lost at U.S. Embassies
description: Rendezvous regular Mark McDonald asked for fresh U.S. embassy stories. Here is an old one from back when America waded into Vietnam, China was a forbidding foe, and Cold War rivals could have easily blown each other off the map.

title: A New Home Advantage in the N.F.L.?
description: As the N.F.L.s replacement officials try their luck again today, heres a trend to monitor:

title: Im Spoiled, but Im Not a Brat
description: While growing up, I would routinely choose to play Pokmon over doing the dishes. The fact that I had a choice never struck me as strange. While I certainly had chores  cleaning my room when it became unlivable, walking the dog I had begged for, attending the piano lessons my parents had paid for  I had very few household responsibilities. You could say I was spoiled. And thanks to the recent discourse surrounding my generations upbringing, Ive just discovered that Im one of millions of 21st-century American kids who have been shielded from hardship by overprotective parents.

title: Nebraska G.O.P. Draws a Tougher Map for Obama
description: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Here is a look at Nebraska, the Cornhusker State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with John R. Hibbing, a professor of political science at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, and Paul Landow, a professor of political science at the University of Nebraska at Omaha.

title: Getting Some Air in Milan
description: Everyone in Milan seems taken with minimalism this season. Firmness sparseness as elegance, the Marni show notes began. Scraping away most of the Marni trinkets and funky layers, Consuelo Castiglioni presented a very spare collection indeed. The newsy portions included sleeveless dresses that floated over the body, with their shape enhanced by crisp fabrics and flattering pleats and folds. Nothing seemed too much in this appealing show. The checked outfits that opened the show had a slight 3-D effect, and Ms. Castiglioni included a few more eye tricks later with dresses in a green half-circle print cut and assembled on a diagonal. But she was right to concentrate on her sculptural A-line pieces in solid neutral tones, some as simple as a loose cotton top over flared matching shorts and others with a kind of crazily deconstructed peplum.

title: Jil Sander: Minimalism With a Kick
description: One could find all kinds of meaning in Jil Sanders show and her return to the label after an eight-year absence. There was the white set with a concave, spherical ceiling that resembled an architects idea of a modern, corporate conference room. One woman  Ms. Sander herself  was going to speak that day and the audience, seated around the square platform, was going to listen.

title: Aung San Suu Kyi Visits U.S.
description: Myanmars opposition leader, Aung San Suu Kyi, visited the United States.

title: Marni: Spring 2013 RTW
description: Milan

title: Expectations and the Confidence Fairy
description: Some readers have asked whether there isnt an inconsistency between my view that the Fed can promote economic recovery by changing expectations about future policy, and my ridicule of austerity proponents who invoke confidence as a reason to believe that austerity will actually be expansionary. But there isnt really any inconsistency; its an orders of magnitude thing.

title: Mr. Mental Recession
description: Brad DeLong is upset by the illogic of John Taylor and Phil Gramms attack on the Fed. Indeed: it boggles the mind that they believe that a downside of expansionary policy now is that it will require contractionary policy once the economy has recovered. Um, isnt that exactly what you want monetary policy to do  boost the economy when its weak, take away the punchbowl when the party gets going?

title: A Roosevelt Mimic Plays Him for Posterity
description: ROCK TAVERN, N.Y.  Double bully!

title: Disruptions: Will Apple Be the First to Break $1 Trillion?
description: If Apple continues on its current trajectory, something remarkable might happen on April 9, 2015, at around 11 a.m.

title: Bill Clinton Says Hes Unsure of Wifes 2016 Plans
description: WASHINGTON  Former President Bill Clinton said Sunday that he had no earthly idea whether his wife might decide to run for the presidency in 2016, but that he had never met a more qualified public servant and that she would have his full support no matter what she decides.

title: Now Streaming | Salvatore Ferragamo Spring 2013 Womens Collection
description: The Spring 2013 womens collection show from Salvatore Ferragamo at Milan Fashion Week. Delays may occur.

title: Police Chief in Chinese Murder Scandal Convicted and Sentenced to 15 Years
description: BEIJING  Chinese court officials have found Wang Lijun, a former police chief, guilty of four criminal charges after he fled to a United States Consulate last February and told diplomats there that the wife of a senior politician had murdered a British businessman, according to a report on Monday by Xinhua, the state news agency.

title: Dolce & Gabbana: Spring 2013 RTW
description: Milan

title: Yanks Abroad: Bernardo Carries On in Guatemala
description: As soccers profile grows in the United States, an increasing number of young American players are playing abroad.

title: Study Divides Breast Cancer Into Four Distinct Types
description: In findings that are fundamentally reshaping the scientific understanding of breast cancer, researchers have identified four genetically distinct types of the cancer. And within those types, they found hallmark genetic changes that are driving many cancers.

description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

description: Milan

title: A Vanity Fair for France Puts Timing in Question
description: PARIS  For several years, media executives in Paris have been buzzing about the expected introduction of a French version of Vanity Fair magazine.

title: Koch Faults Obama on Israel and on Libya Attack
description: Edward I. Koch, the former three-term Democratic mayor of New York, has some critical words about President Obamas relations with Israel and his handling of the attack on the American consulate in Benghazi, Libya, this month.

title: Betrayed by Those Wonderful People Out There in the Dark
description: Any Hollywood history can describe a stars X factor. But not many film historians can see the whole equation as Ty Burr does in Gods Like Us, his lively and provocative chronicle of the genesis of movie stars and the metamorphosis of movie stardom. He offers original thinking about the audience factor.

title: Films Tie for Top Box Office Spot
description: Clint Eastwood faced some empty chairs at North American movie theaters over the weekend: Two new movies, End of Watch and House at the End of the Street, tied for No. 1, followed by Mr. Eastwoods Trouble With the Curve.

title: Ferragamo: Spring 2013 RTW
description: Milan

title: Joy Turns to Despair at National Zoo as Newborn Panda Is Found Dead
description: WASHINGTON  A giant pandas distress call sent keepers at the National Zoo rushing to the aid of her tiny, lifeless cub on Sunday, and the elation over the cubs birth just a week earlier turned to despair over its death.

title: With a Servants Pregnancy Comes a Mans Chute From High Society
description: Class conflict gets a workout in the Mint Theater  Companys lively, penetrating revival of Mary Broome, the troupes latest invigoration of a largely forgotten work. The plays author, Allan Monkhouse (1858-1936), also a novelist and critic, was known for his acerbic dissections of the English bourgeoisie. Mary Broome  a comedy that first appeared in Manchester in 1911 and was last staged in Manhattan in 1919, at the Neighborhood Playhouse on Grand Street  cuts right to its heart.

title: The Daily Shoe | Marni
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Visual Aside Accompanies Sounds of an Ensemble
description: The third movement of Mozarts Gran Partita, his Serenade No. 10 for winds in B flat, is one of the most quietly, simply sublime passages in music. It begins with a simple four-note figure that rises and then falls into a gently pulsing, syncopated carpet of sound.

title: Before Armanis Show, a Look at the Past
description: Guests walking into the Giorgio Armani show tonight had the option to first take a detour into an exhibition of his designs spanning 20 years or more, loosely grouped around the theme Eccentrico, or Eccentric.

title: Princeton University President Is Stepping Down
description: Shirley M. Tilghman, the president of Princeton University since 2001, will be stepping down from her post in June. She announced her decision on Saturday in an e-mail to the Princeton community, our colleague Ariel Kaminer reports:

title: Kovalchuks SKA St. Petersburg Topples Ovechkins Dynamo Moscow
description: Alex Ovechkin scored a goal, but Ilya Kovalchuk emerged the winner Sunday in the superstars first clash since the N.H.L. lockout began one week ago.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: 2012 Emmy Awards: Homeland and Modern Family Win Top Honors
description: Dave Itzkoff, Mike Hale, Brian Stelter and others provided analysis of the TV shows honored  and left out  during the broadcast of the 64th Primetime Emmy Awards. Follow here and on Twitter at @nytimesarts.

title: Robust Cello and Viola, With a Few Whoops
description: When the New Juilliard Ensemble made its debut in September 1993, Edward Rothstein, writing in The New York Times, described the splintered nature of the citys new-music scene at the time and the intense competition for audiences and financing.

title: After a Fitting Tribute, Liverpools Inspired Play Falls Short
description: LIVERPOOL, England  In the buildup to the Liverpool versus Manchester United match Sunday, there was little talk of the soccer game; the eyes of the world focused not on the field but the spectators surrounding it.

title: Even When Theres a Him Around, Balanchine Is Still About Her
description: The biographies of George Balanchine tell us of his several wives, of his other loves, and of his devotion to the female dancer. His ballets, though, make his feeling for women yet more complicated. Even in moments of amorous surrender one part of his women stays unreachable. And one part of his men always craves, in female terms, what they cannot have.

title: NFL Networks Added, but Not Available to All
description: 7:12 p.m. | Updated

title: When Silenced, They Speak Out in Art
description: On Friday night at New York Live Arts the two-part Voices of Strength: Contemporary Dance & Theater by Women From Africa unveiled its second program, a shared evening of works by Maria Helena Pinto and Bouchra Ouizguen. These choreographic voices  the first from Mozambique, the second from Morocco  each had something to impart about the link between feminism and making art.

title: Giorgio Armani: Spring 2013 RTW
description: Milan

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released will include the Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller home price index for July, and consumer confidence for September (Tuesday); new-home sales for August (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, durable goods for August, second-quarter gross domestic product (final) and pending home sales for August (Thursday); and personal income and spending for August, the Chicago purchasing manager index for SeptemberThomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for September (Friday).

title: You Have a Role in This Play: Peeping Tom
description: When I first looked in on them, around 4:30 p.m., they were all asleep. Or unconscious. Or dead. It was hard to tell. An hour and some minutes later, the three of them were knocked out again, but this time in different positions, different places and, come to think of it, different clothes. And that was when things started to get interesting.

title: A Jazzman Looks at Loss and Finds Inspiration
description: Dave Douglas dealt sparingly with the emotional back story at 92YTriBeCa on Wednesday night, in the auspicious first outing by his new quintet. During a concert built around the Protestant hymns on his gorgeous and contemplative new album, Be Still  due out on Tuesday on Greenleaf, his independent label  Mr. Douglas spoke of his motivation only in passing. The album, he said simply, came about because all these hymns and songs were songs that my mother recommended that I play.

title: Iraq, Afghanistan  Iran? Weve Been Here Before.
description: WASHINGTON  Ten years ago, President George W. Bush and top officials in his administration assured Americans that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction and that an American invasion of that country was justified and wouldnt be that difficult.

title: Yankees End Homestand With Loss, but With Lead Intact
description: There would be no dramatic comeback or postgame delirium at Yankee Stadium, in contrast to the previous two days. The Yankees, for the third time this series, had an opportunity to win with a hit. But the Oakland Athletics held on for a 5-4 win Sunday.

title: Kind of Like Will & Grace, but Both Guys This Time
description: Some shows need a script doctor. The new sitcom Partners, based on the working relationship of its creators, David Kohan and Max Mutchnick, calls out for a couples counselor. Maybe he could explain why this celebration of friendship feels so sour and joyless.

title: After Jail and Release, New Fame as an Author
description: On a Thursday afternoon walk along Canal Street, Damien Echols was reflecting on how this busy thoroughfare once nourished him in the first few months after his August 2011 release from a super-maximum-security prison in Arkansas.

title: The Pettiness, the Paparazzi, the Pressure
description: Stardom is a vale of tears in Madhur Bhandarkars Heroine, about the ups and downs, and downs and downs of Mahi Arora (Kareena Kapoor), a Bollywood queen with a self-destructive flair for making headlines. Pulpy but attenuated, Heroine tries to do too much: deliver an expos of the back-stabbing film business while also drawing a portrait of a woman caught in its vice.

title: Jets Make the Most of a Second Chance
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  All the Jets wanted was for this game to end already, this ugly, sloppy, chaotic game that had claimed their best player, Darrelle Revis, confirmed that their Week 1 offensive eruption was an aberration and would send them scurrying afterward to gulp Pedialyte as if it were water in the desert.

title: A Touch of Melancholy From the Top of the World
description: Time was, if you were an ambitious pop band looking to upholster your music with orchestral finery, you enlisted an arranger who traveled in similar circles: a Jack Nitzsche, Clare Fischer or Michael Kamen. Presumably, no rock star ever phoned Aaron Copland.

title: Buffett Cup in Omaha
description: At the Buffett Cup in Omaha this month probably the best defense occurred in the diagramed deal. It was played in three no-trump four times, but the contract failed only once.

title: Perpendicular to the Keel
description: Administrivial Unusual Puzzle Alert! The Tuesday, Sept. 25 puzzle will be offered in both Across Lite and as a PDF. Because of the unusual nature of this puzzle, some elements of the grid and the cluing will not reproduce the same way in Across Lite. If you normally solve online in Across Lite, we strongly recommend that you print out the PDF and solve it that way.

title: Belarus Votes as Europe Keeps a Watch for Signs That Sanctions Can End
description: MINSK, Belarus  Belarus held parliamentary elections on Sunday, though the outcome was hardly in doubt: supporters of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko have traditionally won, and now hold, all 110 seats in the chamber.

title: More Treme Is on the Way
description: Fans of the HBO drama Treme were given multiple reasons to celebrate over the weekend as David Simon and Eric Overmyer, the creators of the series, announced that HBO had ordered a fourth and final season one day before the Season 3 premiere, The Times-Picayune of New Orleans reported. In a speech before a show screening at the Joy Theater in New Orleans on Saturday Mr. Simon told the audience that the fourth season would be shortened, with a total episode count to be determined. We are going to be back for a season 3.5, Mr. Simon said. He also announced that all of the actors who portray the varied characters that populate the shows post-Katrina New Orleans, will return, To a person they all came back, he said. Were happy for a chance to finish the story on our own terms.

title: Televisions Fall Season Endures
description: For years, Alan Wurtzel, the head of research for NBC, has questioned the enduring validity of a television season  the ritual competition of network series, which begins again Monday night.

title: A Connecticut Building for Sanaa
description: Designs for a new building by the architecture firm Sanaa, to be used as a spiritual and community center, are to be submitted for approval on Monday by Grace Farms Foundation in New Canaan, Conn. The plans for the building, called the River, which must be approved by the towns Planning and Zoning Commission, call for construction on a sliver of the 75-acre Grace Farms property that the foundation is preserving as permanent open space. The building is to have landscaping by the Philadelphia firm Olin. Sanaa, founded in Tokyo in 1995, is the architecture firm of Kazuyo Sejima and Ryue Nishizawa, who received the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 2010.

title: Another Lesson in Consistency, as Vettel Wins in Singapore
description: SINGAPORE  It has been the leitmotif of the season: The key to who will win the drivers title will likely come down to consistency, not necessarily victories. Sebastian Vettel took only his second victory of the season in his Red Bull car at the Singapore Grand Prix on Sunday, but he moved back into second place in the series.

title: To Complete a Sweep, the Mets Overcome the Sun, the Wind and the Marlins
description: The Mets struggling offense sprang to life Sunday as Ruben Tejadas bases-loaded single with two outs in the ninth inning drove in Scott Hairston for the winning run in a 3-2 victory against the Miami Marlins.

title: Kerik Is Leaving His Cell to Testify at a Bronx Trial
description: Bernard B. Kerik, the disgraced former police commissioner of New York, will return to the city in the coming days, though certainly not triumphantly, and not yet as a free man.

title: Manchester United 2, Liverpool 1
description: Kristian Walsh was at Anfield on Sunday for Manchester Uniteds 2-1 victory over Liverpool. But of course the day was about much more than that. Read his article on the game, the Hillsborough tributes and the fans behavior here, and come back to comment.

title: Schiano Does It Again
description: Tampa Bay Coach Greg Schiano remains unimpressed with your victory formation. He was criticized by Giants Coach Tom Coughlin and many others last Sunday for ignoring an unwritten rule about not attacking an offense when the quarterback is poised to kneel to kill off the final seconds of a game.

title: For Vice President, a Heartbeat Away From the Public Isnt Close Enough
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Yes, Joseph R. Biden Jr. gives a lot of stump speeches.

title: Sept. 23: Does Omaha Matter?
description: Its something of a tradition for newspapers to release polls on Sundays late in a presidential campaign. This Sunday, there were polls out in Ohio, Florida and Pennsylvania  but as its Nebraska day at FiveThirtyEight, lets start with one from the Cornhusker State.

title: Reinventing Ethics
description: Whats good and whats bad? There are plenty of reasons to believe that human nature changes slowly, if at all  alls still fair in love and war. For millennia, religious believers have attributed our nature to Gods image, as well as to Gods plan. In recent years, evolutionary psychologists peered directly at our forerunners on the savannahs of East Africa; if human beings change, we do so gradually over thousands of years. Given little or nothing new in the human firmament, traditional morality  the goods and bads as outlined in the Ten Commandments or the Golden Rule  should suffice.

title: Mobile Services and Cable TV Are Unexpected Allies
description: BASKING RIDGE, N.J.  Tucked amid rows of office cubicles at the sprawling Verizon Wireless headquarters here and hidden behind a locked door sit the companys best kept retail secrets.

title: Obama and Romney Offer a Possible Preview of Their First Debate
description: WASHINGTON  Mitt Romney criticized President Obama in remarks broadcast on Sunday for refusing to meet with Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, during this weeks United Nations General Assembly meeting, saying it sends a message that the administration is distancing itself from an important Middle East ally.

title: Using Twitter to Promote the Fall TV Season
description: Lots of people are accustomed to watching television while simultaneously posting updates to Twitter or Facebook or looking up information online, or what is known in media circles as the second screen experience. But why watch two screens when you can start with one?

title: Emmy Awards 2012 Red Carpet
description: Looks from the crimson runway at the 64th annual Emmy Awards.

title: Helicopter Coaching Hurts Could-Be Leaders
description: Phil Simms remembers a harsh lesson in leadership as if it happened yesterday. During a mundane practice in 1987, the season after the Giants won Super Bowl XXI, the offense, especially the offensive line, seemed to be sleepwalking.

title: Spotlighting Women Who Lead
description: It would be nearly impossible to write about the 100th anniversary of the Advertising Women of New York and Advertising Ages first ever list of the 100 most influential women in the industry without mentioning the last season of the AMC drama Mad Men.

title: Conservatives Want to Let Ryan Be Ryan on Campaign Trail
description: Representative Paul D. Ryans selection as the Republican vice-presidential nominee is now yielding something Mitt Romneys campaign can do without: second-guessing about how Mr. Ryan is being put to use.

title: Seminoles See Dawn of New Glory Days
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  What E. J. Manuel would call the biggest victory of his career had been secured when he galloped free down the sideline, with a clear path to the end zone. All night, he had listened to the former Florida State quarterback Charlie Wards advice  take what the defense gives you  and with this run, Manuel joined Ward as the only Seminole to throw for 300 yards and rush for 100 in a game.

title: Skills Honed in Illicit Trades, and Put to Better Use
description: As a heroin dealer in Rhode Island, Jose Vasquez made $2,000 a day. He said he had a way with his customers. He took his best clients out for dinner and bought them presents on their birthdays.

title: Yankees Not the Best in Tight Races
description: For all the American League and division titles in their glorious history, the Yankees were for decades seldom involved in a day-to-day, night-to-night pennant race that boiled down to the seasons final weekend, if not the final game.

title: Proposed Bill Could Change Royalty Rates for Internet Radio
description: Willing buyer, willing seller. Those four words would seem innocuous, but in the world of Internet radio nothing is more contentious.

title: Romney Blames Obama for His Campaign Challenges
description: DENVER  Mitt Romney, who has been criticized by members of his party in recent weeks for not campaigning aggressively enough and who trails President Obama in polls in most swing states, placed the blame for his campaigns struggles squarely on the president himself Sunday afternoon.

title: With Win, Snedeker Also Takes Tour Title
description: ATLANTA  Before the most critical round of his professional career, Brandt Snedeker stopped by the Shepherd Center, a rehabilitation hospital for patients with spinal cord or brain injuries, and spent 30 minutes with his longtime instructors son, Tucker Anderson.

title: The Satanic Video
description: THE alchemy of modern media works with amazing speed. Start with a cheesy anti-Muslim video that resembles a bad trailer for a Sacha Baron Cohen comedy. It becomes YouTube fuel for protest across the Islamic world and a pretext for killing American diplomats. That angry spasm begets an inflammatory Newsweek cover, MUSLIM RAGE, which in turn inspires a Twitter hashtag that reduces the whole episode to a running joke:

title: Americas Inevitable Retreat From the Middle East
description: THE murder of four Americans in Libya and mob assaults on the United States embassies across the Muslim world this month have reminded many of 1979, when radical Islamists seized the American mission in Tehran. There, too, extremists running wild after the fall of a pro-American tyrant had found a cheap way of empowering themselves.

title: Frankenweenie Digital Book Updates the Movie Tie-In
description: Coffee-table books, while entertaining to thumb through, tend to gather dust when they languish on said table. So to showcase the animated movie Frankenweenie, Disney Publishing Worldwide took an interactive approach, bypassing the traditional oversize tome and heading straight for the iPad.

title: The Optimism Cure
description: Mitt Romney is optimistic about optimism. In fact, its pretty much all hes got. And that fact should make you very pessimistic about his chances of leading an economic recovery.

title: Government Issues Order to Disband Libya Forces
description: CAIRO  Libyas interim government on Sunday ordered the breakup of all militias that do not fall under its authority, and demanded that those militias pull out of military compounds and public property within 48 hours.

title: Discovery of Skeleton Puts Richard III in Battle Once Again
description: LEICESTER, England  For more than 500 years, King Richard III has been the most widely reviled of English monarchs. But a stunning archaeological find this month here in the English Midlands  a skeleton that medieval scholars believe is very likely to be Richards  could lead to a reassessment of his brief but violent reign.

title: Jennifer Jaff, Advocate for the Ill, Dies at 55
description: Jennifer Jaff, a lawyer whose nearly four-decade struggle with a debilitating disease led her to become a leading advocate for people with chronic illnesses, died on Sept. 14 at her home in Farmington, Conn. She was 55.

title: Public Television Takes Role in Curbing Dropout Rates
description: More than 100 public television stations reaching two-thirds of the nations viewers turned over their air on Saturday to an unusual seven-hour telethon broadcast live from WNET-TVs Lincoln Center studio in New York.

title: The Cost of the N.F.L.s Will to Win
description: One of the N.F.L.s locked-out officials was at home Sunday waiting and watching, like everyone else, for the weekly blooper reel to begin.

title: Rape in Hudson River Park Is Latest in a String of Jarring Crimes
description: Just after 6 a.m. on Sunday, Georgie Lau cut a solitary figure as he walked down Harrison Street toward the Hudson River in Manhattan, a fishing rod in one hand and a bucket in the other. Before him was a patch of Hudson River Park where, little more than 24 hours earlier, a young woman had been raped after going to sit near the water by herself in the early morning.

title: A Vexing Flaw in the Subway Is Finally Fixed
description: For more than half a century, it has stood out as a singularly vexing flaw of the subway system, a glaring inequity that has frustrated generations of riders and has even puzzled transit officials, who have wondered how the situation ever came to be.

title: Marv Kessler, Coach and Basketball Instructor, Dies at 80
description: Marv Kessler, a product of Brooklyns schoolyards who spent more than half a century in basketball as a player, a coach, a scout and, most prominently, a camp instructor who molded young athletes like Patrick Ewing and Stephon Marbury, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: Another E-Commerce Site Tests Advertising on TV
description: Decades ago, commercials for Fab detergent were a ubiquitous presence on television.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Uncertainty in Wake of Injury to Revis
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  Things figure to get a lot tougher for the Jets if cornerback Darrelle Revis cannot get back on the field. Revis, considered the leagues top cornerback, left Sundays 23-20 overtime victory against the Miami Dolphins in the third quarter with a left knee injury.

title: Politics, Principle and an Attack on the Courts
description: Two years ago, in what should have been a quiet judicial retention election, Iowa voters threw out three State Supreme Court justices for taking seriously their duty to protect fundamental rights. The three had provoked right-wing wrath for joining a unanimous 2009 ruling overturning the states prohibition on same-sex marriage. Conservative forces succeeded in ousting them by tapping antigay sentiment and attacking activist judges. Those same forces  aided openly this time by the states Republican Party  are now calling for the removal of David Wiggins, another capable judge who joined in the marriage decision.

title: What Do Teachers Deserve? In Idaho, Referendum May Offer Answer
description: BOISE, Idaho  In the struggle to fix the nations public schools, the old red-state, blue-state idea is looking as dated as Dick and Jane. You can hear the change in the voice of Gov. C. L. Otter, a Republican here in one of the most deeply conservative corners of the country, when he expresses a brotherhood bond with Rahm Emanuel, the Democratic mayor of Chicago and former Obama administration chief of staff.

title: The Shocking News About Cod
description: The ideal fish for human consumption would mature quickly and reproduce in staggering numbers. This does not describe the Atlantic cod. Cod mature late  at 4 to 6 years old  and they can live as long as 25 years. Female cod do, in fact, produce astonishing numbers of eggs. But older cod lay two or three times as many eggs as younger cod. This means that a healthy cod population must include relatively large numbers of older fish.

title: Deadly Attack in Libya Was Major Blow to C.I.A. Efforts
description: WASHINGTON  The attack in Benghazi, Libya, that killed Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and three other Americans has dealt the Central Intelligence Agency a major setback in its intelligence-gathering efforts at a time of increasing instability in the North African nation.

title: On the Wrong Side
description: Leaders of Iraqs Shiite-led government have often advised the United States not to worry about their ties with Iran, where Shiites are also in the majority. But the assurances are getting harder to swallow. Baghdad is showing a distressing willingness to side with the regions most repressive regimes, not just Iran but also Irans chief ally, the brutal Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad.

title: Woods and McIlroy Struggle in Final Round but Have Some Reasons to Celebrate
description: ATLANTA  Let the record show that before this past weekend, Tiger Woods could not have owned the East Lake Golf Club course more if he had held the deed to the property.

title: Liking It or Not, States Prepare for Health Law
description: PHOENIX  Like many Republican governors, Jan Brewer of Arizona is a stinging critic of President Obamas health care law. When the Supreme Court upheld it in June, she called the ruling an overreaching and unaffordable assault on states rights and individual liberty.

title: Apples Feud With Google Is Now Felt on iPhone
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Once the best of friends, Google and Apple have become foes, battling in courtrooms and in the consumer marketplace. Last week, the hostilities took a new turn when they spilled right onto smartphone screens.

title: To Sell Agenda, Cuomo Puts Team on the Road
description: NORTH HUDSON, N.Y.  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, dressed in khaki cargo pants and a navy windbreaker that said Team Cuomo/We Deliver, paddled expertly from the rear seat of a canoe on Sunday afternoon. He had just gone fishing, catching an eight-inch brook trout, and now it was time for another adventure.

title: Running as Outsiders, With a Catch: Theyre In
description: WASHINGTON  In one of his campaign advertisements, Joe Heck emphasizes his long career as a physician taking care of elderly patients. Dan Benishek, in an ad, refers with a tinge of sadness to the career politician who is competing with him for a House seat. Ann Kirkpatrick informs viewers that she is extremely fond of driving.

title: Covering the World of Business, Digital Only
description: Business titans are generally not prone to self-appraisal, and when they do take stock, it usually begins and ends with a list of their conquests.

title: Jets Replay: Week 3
description: The Jets overcame the Miami Dolphins in overtime, 23-20, but the game was not without injuries to key playmakers.

title: From Star to Spoiler, Yankees Nunez Tries to Look Ahead After a Costly Error
description: Life in the majors for a young player can bring with it many challenges and a number of lessons. Eduardo Nunez, a 25-year-old Yankees infielder, is a prime example of such a learning curve.

title: Uranium Substitute Is No Longer Needed, but Its Disposal May Pose Security Risk
description: WASHINGTON  At the dawn of the civilian nuclear age in the 1950s, one of the pressing questions was how to find enough fuel for reactors and bombs. The government and the private sector seized on a man-made substitute for natural uranium, producing about 3,400 pounds of an exotic and expensive material called uranium 233.

title: At United Nations, Renewed Focus on Syria, if Not New Ideas
description: UNITED NATIONS  The raging conflict in Syria will take center stage starting Monday as some 120 world leaders converge on the United Nations for what is sometimes called diplomacys annual trade fair.

title: More Access to Contraceptives in City Schools
description: A New York City pilot program to distribute morning-after pills and other contraceptives to high school students has encountered little resistance from parents since it began early last year, health officials said Sunday.

A Couple Hailing a Cab in Midtown Is Struck by a Car
description: She met her future husband nearly four decades ago, on West 34th Street. It was a beautiful summer afternoon, and they were both trying to hail a cab.

title: Costly Phone Calls for Inmates
description: Members of Congress and civil rights groups are pushing the Federal Communications Commission to rein in telephone companies that, in many states, charge inmates spectacularly high rates that can force their families to choose between keeping in touch with a relative behind bars and, in some cases, putting food on the table.

title: Sinai Group Claims Role in Attack on Israel
description: CAIRO  An obscure militant group based in Egypts North Sinai region claimed responsibility over the weekend for a cross-border attack that killed an Israeli soldier last week. The claim called fresh attention to the uphill struggle the newly formed Egyptian government is facing to control the restive Sinai region.

description: Quincy, a small farming town in central Washington, has become home to several enormous data centers, drawn by the cheap hydroelectric power produced along the Columbia River.

title: Israel Falls in Qualifier Final, but Team Plays for Much More

Israel had just taken a two-run lead against Spain in a World Baseball Classic qualifying game, and the 1,500 or so Jewish fans at Roger Dean Stadium on Sunday celebrated with equal parts pleasure and pride.

title: Foxconn Factory in China Is Closed After Worker Riot
description: Foxconn Technology, a major supplier to some of the worlds electronics giants, including Apple, said that it had closed one of its large Chinese plants early Monday after police were called in to break up a fight among factory employees.

description: QUINCY, Wash.  Set in the dry hills and irrigated farmland of Central Washington, Grant County is known for its robust harvest of apples, potatoes, cherries and beans. But for Microsoft, a prime lure was the regions other valuable resource: cheap electrical power.

Mr. Ross, 24, from Jacksonville, Fla., brought a relaxed but commanding sense of swing to his performance with a competition house band, consisting of the saxophonist Jon Gordon, the pianist Geoffrey Keezer and the bassist Rodney Whitaker.

title: Aspiring U.S. Diplomats Stiffen Their Resolve After Ambassadors Death
description: The recent killing of the U.S. ambassador to Libya, J. Christopher Stevens, along with three other Americans at the mission in Benghazi, now appears to have been a premeditated assault, not merely collateral damage from yet another anti-American protest. The deadly ambush reinforced the idea that many diplomats  even those guarded by security personnel and working in fortified buildings  can quickly find themselves in harms way.

Left to help smooth over any ruffled feathers will be Tom Donilon.

The speech capped a week in which the government announced a series of long-delayed measures, most notably raising the price of diesel and opening up foreign direct investment for retailers who sell multiple brands and in aviation and broadcasting.

He spoke with James Estrin last week. The interview has been edited.

Four years ago, my lab at the University of Washington started building a new buoy to measure the turbulence in breaking ocean waves. Now the chance to use it is fast approaching. Preparation is foremost on my mind.

title: A Voice From Myanmar, Worthy of a Heros Welcome
