Cable TV Finds an Ally in Mobile Devices
description: Cable TV's unexpected ally: the mobile device. | At a data center, a peek inside the computing cloud. | How changing technology empowered boutique book publishing.

title: Business Day Live: Mobile Services and Cable TV Are Unexpected Allies
description: Cable TVs unexpected ally: the mobile device. | At a data center, a peek inside the computing cloud. | How changing technology empowered boutique book publishing.

title: I Swear Im Going to Stop Doing That
description: My wife and I attended the opening of our towns newest library, which is magnificent, and on the way home I said I was glad to live in a fairly small place that manages to have six libraries. You forgot one, she said, and she mentioned another that Im not going to name here.

title: Seeking Allies, Teachers Unions Court G.O.P., Too
description: The strike by public school teachers in Chicago this month drew national attention to a fierce debate over the future of education and exposed the ruptured relationship between teachers unions and Democrats like Mayor Rahm Emanuel.

title: Monday Motorsports: Denny Hamlin Dominates Second Race of Sprint Cup Chase
description: On Sunday in Loudon, N.H., Denny Hamlin would not have his raceday success dictated by grid position.

title: Your Hazy Future Is No Excuse for a Lack of Planning
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

title: A $4.5 Million Gift for Princeton Art Museum
description: The Princeton University Art Museum has received a $4.5 million gift from Allen R. Adler, a longtime member of the museums advisory council and his wife, Frances Beatty Adler, vice president of Richard L. Feigen & Company, a New York art gallery, and chairwoman of the Drawing Center in SoHo.

title: Al Gore Sees Dirty Weather Ahead
description: On Sunday, Al Gore was in New York  well, he appeared in a video screened there  to promote the second iteration of 24 Hours of Reality, an event streamed online to help people connect the dots between climate change and its diverse impacts around the globe. This years version, scheduled for Nov. 14-15, is titled 24 Hours of Reality: The Dirty Weather Report.

title: My Reddit AMA
description: Today at 2:30 pm I will be holding an AMA (Ask Me Anything) on Reddit. I invite all my readers, including my critics, to submit questions regarding my coverage as a columnist on the editorial page, the PBS documentary based on the book I co-wrote with my wife, Sheryl WuDunn, Half the Sky, or my extracurricular activities (hiking the Pacific Crest Trail, sampling mouse shish kebabs, etc). I look forward to a stimulating conversation!

title: Apple Sells Five Million New iPhones
description: Apple on Monday said it had sold five million new iPhones just three days after the phones release, beating first-weekend sales of its predecessor, the iPhone 4S, by about one million, but still missing some analysts forecasts.

title: Gensler Calls for Overhaul of Libor
description: A senior regulator called for an overhaul of a crucial interest rate on Monday, telling the European Parliament that the integrity of consumer borrowing is at stake.

title: Times Company Completes Sale of About.com
description: The New York Times Company, which has been trying to shed its assets and focus on its newspaper and Web site, announced Monday morning it had completed the sale of About Group for $300 million in cash to IAC/InterActiveCorp. The About Group includes the Web sites About.com, ConsumerSearch.com and CalorieCount.com.

title: A Dynamic Duo: Beets and Beet Greens
description: The New York City Greenmarket Web site has a handy table that shows whats available during each month of the year. It tells me, for example, that fresh beets are available from June through November (beets from storage are available through February), but that you can count on the greens only through September. That gives me this week to provide you with my annual set of beet and beet green recipes, one of my favorite subjects.

title: Bishops Edict Angers Catholics in Germany
description: BERLIN  Matters of faith have been much on German minds in recent times with debate raging among its Muslim and Jewish minorities over a courts challenge to the practice of infant circumcision and, as I wrote in my latest Page Two column, over the countrys response to the contentious, American-made video denigrating the Prophet Muhammad that has stirred anger across the Muslim world.

title: The New Season: Big-Name Dance Makers on Parade
description: Theres a feast of dance coming up in the next few months, with some of the most interesting offerings coming from the big ballet companies. Thats often because they are taking a resolutely contemporary approach  more on which shortly.

title: Image of the Day: September 24
Can a Sports Car Be Green?
description: Its time for a new car. Your current set of wheels  an old BMW Z3 roadster  is perfect for your job (pizza delivery) but has miserable fuel economy: 20 miles per gallon. You decide you no longer care about being cool. You care about the earth. Youre up for anything.

title: Ann, Holland Taylors Play About Ann Richards, Will Open on Broadway
description: Ann, a play based on the life of Ann W. Richards, the colorful Democratic governor of Texas who died in 2006, is coming to Broadway. The play will open on March 7, 2013, at Lincoln Center Theaters Vivian Beaumont Theater, producers Bob Boyett and Harriet Newman Leve announced Monday.

title: Former Soccer Player Joins Lawsuit Against N.C.A.A.
description: Angelica Palacios can still remember the concussion that ended her collegiate soccer career.

title: Irans President Spreads the Outrage in New York
description: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran stoked the anger of Israel, the United States, Syrian insurgents and gay rights advocates on Monday, using the first full day of his final visit to the United Nations as Irans leader to assert that he has no fear of an Israeli attack on his countrys nuclear facilities, regards the Israelis as fleeting aberrations in Middle East history, is neutral in the Syria conflict and considers homosexuality an ugly crime.

title: Drivers Spend Less Time Getting to Work, Survey Finds
description: Updated, 4:37 p.m. |  Most New York City residents do not lack for access to some form of public transit. And advocates are always extolling the virtues of subway, bus, rail or ferry over sitting  and stewing  in gridlock inside a car.

title: At Este Lauder, a Brand Is Developed Just for China
description: How does an American-based company make deeper inroads in China after it has already introduced some of its popular, long-established brands?

title: The Dead of Antietam
description: On Sept. 19, 1862, just two days after the Battle of Antietam, Alexander Gardner, an employee of the photographer Mathew Brady, began documenting the battles grim aftermath. One of Gardners photographs, titled Dead Horse of Confederate Colonel; both killed at Battle of Antietam, depicted a milky-white steed lying on the field in an eerily peaceful repose. Another showed a line of bloated Confederate bodies along the Hagerstown Pike. Titled View in the Field, on the west side of Hagerstown road, after the Battle of Antietam, it is one of the most reproduced photographs of Civil War dead.

title: After U.S. Inquiries, Discover Agrees to Refund Some Credit Protection Fees
description: WASHINGTON  Discover Financial Services has agreed to pay $200 million in refunds to more than 3.5 million cardholders who bought credit protection services over the phone, plus an additional $14 million in civil penalties to banking regulators.

title: Look of The Moment | Top 10 Emmy Dresses
description: At last nights 64th Annual Emmy Awards the red carpet was busy with televisions brightest wearing colorful confections and glittering gowns. Canary and citrus shades of yellow dominated  Ts cover girl Claire Danes winning in sunny, strapless Lanvin  while midnight lace and armor-like embellishments proved that subtlety (and flattery) are still an actresss preferred awards ceremony statement.

title: I.M.F. Praises Central Banks, but Sees Slowing Ahead
description: WASHINGTON  Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, warned on Monday that the institution would probably cut its estimates of global growth yet again this year because of the tepid recovery in the United States, a slowdown in emerging economies and continued troubles in the euro zone.

title: Coaches Taking Out Frustration on Officials
description: It seems, in hindsight, a fitting end to a chaotic day of football. The most accomplished and highest-profile coach in the N.F.L. running after an official, seeking an explanation for what happened on the play that had just sent his team to defeat. And then that coach, the New England Patriots Bill Belichick, reached his right arm out to stop the line judge Esteban Garza as he headed for the tunnel. In that brief contact was crystallized the mounting frustration of coaches and players with replacement officials.

title: Tax Policy, Briefly, Is a Laughing Matter
description: As a matter of protocol, the secretary of state usually steers clear of electoral politics. But Hillary Rodham Clinton drew knowing laughs from an audience in New York on Monday when she said a few words  in an international context, mind you  about tax policy.

title: Low Waters and High Anxiety
description: This summers drought has continued to draw down water levels in Lakes Superior and Michigan-Huron (hydrologically speaking, Michigan and Huron are the same body of water). New forecasts suggest that water levels in the two lakes may soon hit an all-time low, aggravating an economic quandary: with such low levels, cargo ships have to forgo millions of dollars of freight.

title: Video | Welcome to The Learning Network
description: Earlier this month we published a detailed list of 12 Ways to Use The Learning Network Blog This School Year. Now, were pleased to follow it with this 1-minute-48-second video that gives a big-picture overview of what we do.

title: Mean Joe, Meat Loaf and Moon Unit
description: Compared to last weeks list, which generated a bittersweet tribute to Bruce Springsteen, this coming week yields a less starry list of birthdays. The nicknames are pretty good, though, including Mean and Meat Loaf. Ms. Zappa is not a boomer, but she is listed because because it struck me that Frank Zappa, a musical force in the 1960s and 70s, has a daughter who is 45 and who possesses a pretty colorful name herself, Moon Unit.

title: Wall Street Scandals Fill Lawyers Pockets
description: As Wall Street has faced a string of scandals, bank executives, investors and customers have suffered. But one group is thriving: lawyers.

title: As Wall Street Fights Regulation, It Has Backup on the Bench
description: Deep in enemy territory, Wall Street has found a powerful ally.

title: Allonda, the Next Act for 2 Altamarea Alumni
description: The name AllOnda refers to the style of risotto  of the waves, meaning soupy  served in Venice and at this restaurant, scheduled to open in November with Chris Jaeckle, the former chef de cuisine at Ai Fiori, in the kitchen. I like the idea of Venice, Mr. Jaeckle said. It expands the horizon because there are so many global influences in Venice, with spices, even Indian.

title: Jets Lose Revis to Torn Knee Ligament
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  After uttering the words he hoped he would not have to say, Rex Ryan looked down at the lectern and away from the cameras. A second went by. Then two. Then three, as if by taking time to collect his thoughts Ryan would somehow reverse the harsh sentence rendered Monday, when tests confirmed that the All-Pro cornerback Darrelle Revis had torn the anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee and would require surgery, ending his season after three games.

title: With Smartphone Deals, Patents Become a New Asset Class
description: David Berten has spent his legal career as a mercenary student of technological change. He has educated himself in one field after another: chemical coatings, genetics, navigation systems, semiconductors and digital communications software.

title: Is Illegal Immigrant the Right Description?
description: Jose Antonio Vargas is a man on a mission. The journalist turned immigration activist wants news organizations to stop using the term illegal immigrants, which he finds disparaging and inaccurate. Hes particularly focusing on The Times and The Associated Press to change their policies.

title: Photos of The Moment | Missoni
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: In Southern California, Courting Vegans and Vegetarians
description: A new wave of omnivores restaurants are preparing meatless dishes that exist side-by-side on the menu with steak.

title: Dont Be Afraid of the Eggplant
description: BACK in the 1970s, when the vegetarian movement began growing like wheat grass, eggplant moved into the mainstream. Casseroles of eggplant Parmesan and moussaka adorned numerous potlucks, mostly because the eggplants mild taste and chew  especially when breaded and fried  managed to imitate cutlets of veal and chicken.

title: Making Vegan a New Normal
description: LOS ANGELES

title: A Hotel Chain Scouts for Regional Art and Artists
description: A lodging chain whose customers are often on the road is sending a travel photographer and blogger out for a promotion devoted to the search for art across America.

title: TimesCast | U.N. General Assembly
description: World leaders gather in New York as the United Nations General Assembly opens. | President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt speaks to The New York Times ahead of his first speech at the United Nations.

title: Skimming the Brooklyn Book Festival
description: With more than 100 panels scheduled in and around Brooklyns Borough Hall over the course of eight hours on Sunday, the seventh annual Brooklyn Book Festival offered more choices than any one person could take in. But with an eye on logistics and a ruthless willingness to leave events early  the way one might drop a book after 50 pages if it doesnt grab you  it was possible to hear a great deal about sex, politics, violence and other literary subjects.

title: The Week in Political Pictures: Sept. 16-22
description: A look back at the week in politics, as all four candidates were out on the trail.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Black Bag Advertising, San Francisco, was acquired by Essence Digital. Financial terms were not disclosed. The deal is part of expansion plans in the United States for Essence Digital, which is based in London and has an office in New York.

title: Romney Camp Talks of Dialing Down Fund-Raising
description: When President Obama and Mitt Romney decided to decline public financing for the general election and raise hundreds of millions of dollars on their own, the upside was clear: No spending limits and effectively unlimited resources to spend taking their message to voters.

title: A Yahoo Series About Cyberterrorism
description: When youve created CSI, you dont have a lot left to prove in the entertainment business. But Anthony E. Zuiker isnt resting on his television laurels. He writes multiplatform digi-novels and is a partner in a YouTube channel, BlackBoxTV, that has more than 333,000 subscribers.

title: Safeguarding Social Security Checks as They Go Electronic
description: Consumer groups  along with paper-producing interests  -are urging the federal government to improve safeguards for Social Security recipients, as the government phases out paper checks for beneficiaries in favor of electronic deposits.

title: At U.N., New Syria Envoy Gives Bleak Appraisal
description: UNITED NATIONS  Prospects for any settlement in the Syria conflict remain dismal, but not impossible, the new Syria peace envoy said Monday, telling Security Council diplomats that the government of President Bashar al-Assad still clung to the notion that pre-revolution Syria could be resurrected.

title: Under Investigation, and Doing the Investigation
description: Whenever there is a report of corporate misconduct, a predictable response is that the company in question says it has hired a reputable law firm to conduct a thorough investigation, and it pledges to cooperate with the authorities to resolve the situation quickly.

title: Going Back to War, Trading a Gun for a Pen
description: The documentary filmmakers Sebastian Junger and Tim Hetherington embedded in Afghanistan with one mission: to document war. The result was the gripping documentary Restrepo. For nearly one year, they lived in peril alongside the United States Army. Their project won the Grand Jury Prize at the Sundance Film Festival in 2010 and was nominated for an Academy Award in 2011.

title: The Straw Bale Dilemma: How Smooth Is Smooth?
description: To raise a straw bale wall, several tools are essential: a chain saw, a three-foot-long iron needle and a large wooden mallet that Wyle E. Coyote would be proud of.

title: A Beeswax Dental Filling That Lasted 6,500 Years
description: Ancient dentistry has been discovered in a 6,500-year-old human jawbone: a lump of beeswax that appears to be the earliest evidence of a dental filling.

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 24
description: A view of the day in sports, including the shotgun world championships.

title: For Tig Notaro, an Album and Book Deal Based on a Memorable Set
description: 2:25 p.m. | Updated  For the comedian Tig Notaro, 2012 has been her annus horribilis, the year in which her mother died unexpectedly and Ms. Notaro learned she had breast cancer. But she turned the events into material for a stand-up routine last month in Los Angeles that quickly became one of the most-talked-about moments in the comedy world. Louis C.K. tweeted: In 27 years doing this, Ive seen a handful of truly great, masterful sets. One was Tig Notaro last night at Largo. Now the set will live on in two forms: as an album online and as the basis of a book.

title: Styled to a T | Oki Sato
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Street Style: Gender-Bending
description: The best of readers photos from the week of Sept. 17.

title: Walkabout  9/24: Rescuing Climbers in Nepal and Avoiding Pickpockets
description: Climbers Perish in Nepal Avalanche At least nine climbers on Mount Manaslu in Nepal died in an avalanche on Sunday, at the start of the climbing season. (The Associated Press)

title: I.M.F.s Call for More Cuts Irks Greece
description: ATHENS  As Greece enters a pivotal week in its economic crisis, tensions between the Greek government and the countrys international lenders have reached a boiling point. The government is resisting a push by the International Monetary Fund to impose additional austerity measures that Greek leaders fear could destabilize the shaky coalition government.

title: Mitt Romney on 60 Minutes
description: I didnt learn anything about either Mitt Romney or President Obama by watching their dueling appearances last night on 60 Minutes. But now I know for sure why Mr. Romney avoids getting into specificson his tax policies, his spending priorities, his foreign policy and so on. When he does get specific, he doesnt make much sense.

title: Year After Pepper-Spraying, Awaiting a New Cry: A Newborns
description: Buried in the news release on Monday morning that yet another Occupy Wall Street protester is suing the Police Departments pepper-spraying deputy inspector, Anthony Bologna, was this heartwarming tidbit: Kaylee Dedrick, Inspector Bolognas co-star in a viral video in which he wields his lachrymatory canister, is about to have a baby with the fellow protester who came to her aid.

title: Amid Criticism, CNN Defends Reporting on Ambassadors Journal
description: Despite a third day of vociferous criticism from the State Department, CNN executives on Monday strongly defended the decision to base some of their reporting about Libya on the private diary of J. Christopher Stevens, the ambassador who was slain in an attack on the United States consulate in Benghazi on Sept. 11.

title: Feathered Freeloaders at the Ant Parade
description: BARRO COLORADO ISLAND, Panama  Here in the exuberantly dour understory of the Panamanian rain forest, the best way to find the elusive and evolutionarily revealing spotted antbird is to stare at your boots.

title: Scene City: Fashion for a Cause
description: amfAR Holds Gala During Milan Fashion Week.

title: The Reporter Had a Life Jacket, but the Governor Knew How to Ply a Paddle
description: NORTH HUDSON, N.Y.  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo positioned himself in the stern of a canoe on Sunday while I clung to dry land a few feet away, befuddled by the straps on my life jacket. Were going to make an outdoorsman out of him, Mr. Cuomo declared.

title: Her Basic Instinct Is to Sell
description: MILAN

title: The Economics of Law School
description: Law schools have come under fire during these tough economic times, with critics saying that they leave too many graduates in debt, chasing too few employment opportunities. But it could be worse. Consider the plight of veterinarians.

title: Evolving Global Strategy Gives Law Firm an Edge
description: LONDON  EDWARD BRAHAM took over the corporate practice at the London-based law firm Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer at a rough time for deal-making. In the midst of the global economic slump in early 2009, banks were reluctant to lend money and companies did not want to spend their cash.

title: Three Fake J.M.W. Turner Paintings Authenticated
description: Three J.M.W. Turner paintings previously thought to be fakes or not fully by the hand of the master and hidden in storage for decades have now been reclassified as the real things. And unlike most painting authentication cases, which proceed in scholarly seclusion for years, this one played out on television.

title: At Brooklyn Invitational, Disrupting Notions of Motorcycle Culture
description: A send-off to a long, hot summer was orchestrated on Sept. 22, as thousands of motorcyclists descended on the waterfront of North Williamsburg for the Brooklyn Invitational Custom Motorcycle Show. The attendance and variety of motorcycle culture on view further cemented the position of the show, in its fourth year, as among the most important in North America.

title: Early Menopause Is Linked to Heart Risk
description: In a new analysis of a multiethnic population, early menopause has been shown to be associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease and stroke.

title: Building a Bat Cave to Battle a Killer
description: CLARKSVILLE, Tenn.  For about six years, Cory Holliday, the Nature Conservancys cave specialist in Tennessee, has feared that white nose syndrome, a devastating fungal disease that kills hibernating bats by the millions, would come to Bellamy Cave. Last winter it did.

title: Fava Bean Falafel Technique
description: Cook Taste Eat's free e-mail contains a video and hands-on cooking instruction.

title: Willie Geist to Co-Host Third Hour of Today
description: Willie Geist, a co-host of the rollicking MSNBC morning show Morning Joe, is moving over to NBCs flagship Today show as a co-host of the franchises 9 a.m. hour.

title: Blueprint of a Meal, From In-Box to Table
description: As cooking on the Web moves beyond recipe sites, Cook Taste Eat, a new enterprise from the San Francisco chef Michael Mina that opened Monday, brings back an early model of digital content: a free e-mail that lands in your in-box each morning. That e-mail contains a video and hands-on cooking instruction, like the one above, and is part of a larger plan.

title: The Drama of Aging and Caregiving, on YouTube
description: I dont want to take care of them, Erica confesses in Episode 12 to the man shes just slept with, speaking about her elderly parents.

title: In Bolivian Amazon, a Yardstick for Modern Health
description: SANTA MARA, Bolivia  There seems to be little that distinguishes the indigenous Tsimane of northern Bolivia from dozens of other native Amazonian peoples. They still live in small communities, fishing daily, hunting and relying on subsistence farming. They remain relatively isolated from the outside world. They still have large families and fall victim to parasites, worms and infectious diseases. And until a decade ago, few had contact with doctors.

title: Photos of The Moment | Roberto Cavalli

title: Doctor Empathy a Factor in Diabetes Care
description: People with Type 2 diabetes may be healthier if they have a doctor who shows high levels of empathy.

title: A Call for Caution on Antipsychotic Drugs
description: You will never guess what the fifth and sixth best-selling prescription drugs are in the United States, so Ill just tell you: Abilify and Seroquel, two powerful antipsychotics. In 2011 alone, they and other antipsychotic drugs were prescribed to 3.1 million Americans at a cost of $18.2 billion, a 13 percent increase over the previous year, according to the market research firm IMS Health.

title: During National Plug In Day, Getting the Silent Treatment
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  For four conspicuously quiet hours on the second-annual National Plug In Day, electric cars and motorcycles swarmed the flat, oak-shaded boulevards wending through office parks just south of Los Angeles International Airport.

title: Really?: Always Consume Carbs Before Surgery
description: THE FACTS

title: The Caucus Click: The Candidate (and His Bodyguard) Say Hello
In $2 Million Ad Campaign, FreshDirect to Emphasize Food Quality
description: FreshDirect, the online home-delivery grocer, is preparing a new advertising approach as it seeks to, er, um, freshen its brand image.

title: Groupon Moves Into Restaurant Reservations With Savored Deal
description: Over recent months, Groupon has sought to expand its core business of daily deals with a number of new business propositions, including with ventures like a mobile payment system.

title: Small-Business Lessons From Harley-Davidsons Turnaround
description: This weekend, I read an article in the Wall Street Journal about how Harley-Davidson turned itself around using lean manufacturing strategies. Lean, or just-in-time, manufacturing is the Toyota production system, which started with W. Edwards Deming and his work with statistical quality control. Whenever I see this kind of article about a large company, I think about how the thoughts and principles can be applied to the smaller companies I work with.

title: Pavel Datsyuk Makes His Debut With CSKA Moscow
description: Pavel Datsyuk scored a goal off a soccer-style header that was waved off Monday in his debut with CSKA Moscow, but emerged victorious anyway as Datsyuks army club beat Avangard Omsk, 1-0. Igor Radulovs second-period goal, set up by his more famous brother, Alexander, was the difference.

title: Williams v. Williams
description: Pennsylvania is scheduled to execute Terrance Williams next Wednesday, Oct. 3, the first time in 50 years that it will put someone to death who is still fighting his sentence.

title: A Law Firm Where Money Seemed Secondary
description: When I crossed the threshold of Cravath, Swaine & Moore 36 years ago next month, fresh from the bar exam and Harvard Law School, I entered a new world and began what turned into a life-changing experience.

title: So Many September Songs
description: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lTBu44Ui2Fg

title: How Shrek Persuaded Me to Let the Words Fly
description: Soon he came upon a peasant singing and scything. You there, varlet, said Shrek. Why so blithe?  William Steig, Shrek

title: After a Slack Period, Hotels Are Sprucing Up
description: Hotel owners in the United States are increasing their spending on improvements to their properties this year, upgrading guest rooms, restaurants, technology and other amenities.

title: The Daily Shoe | Roberto Cavalli
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: The Trade-Off That Created Germanys Job Miracle
description: INGOLSTADT, GERMANY  More than a quarter of the work force in Spain or Greece is without jobs, but this city on the Danube north of Munich has the opposite problem: not enough workers.

title: Culture Keeps Firms Together in Trying Times
description: IN the year before it collapsed, Dewey & LeBoeuf went on a recruiting binge. The law firm poached 37 partners from rivals with multimillion-dollar, multiyear guarantees. Existing partners typically learned about new colleagues via e-mail.

title: BPA Levels Tied to Obesity in Youths
description: Bisphenol A, or BPA, is a chemical widely used to prevent metal corrosion in food packaging, and more than 90 percent of Americans have detectable BPA in their urine. Now a new study published in The Journal of the American Medical Association has found that high levels of urinary BPA are associated with an increased risk of childhood obesity.

title: When Surgeons Leave Objects Behind
description: On an overnight shift in 2005, Sophia Savage, a nurse in Kentucky, felt a crushing pain in her abdomen and started vomiting.

title: Cervical Cancer: El Salvador Gets a Screening Test That Women Can Administer at Home
description: A new way to screen poor women for cervical cancer was introduced this month in El Salvador, using a test that was originally developed in China.

title: Girls Blasphemy Case in Pakistan Sent to Juvenile Court
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Pakistani judge transferred the case of a Christian teenage girl accused of blasphemy to a juvenile court on Monday, removing the threat of a death sentence and signaling that the case was slowly winding down.

title: Interviewing Egypts Islamist President: Answers to Reader Questions
description: Last Updated | Tuesday, 9:14 a.m. The interview with President Mohamed Morsi published this weekend prompted more than 1,200 questions and comments on our Web site and a surge of interest on Twitter. Thank you to everyone who participated, and the authors  David D. Kirkpatrick and I  are taking the opportunity to answer some of the most central and thought-provoking questions here.

title: Work Begins to Unearth an Ancient Mosaic
description: A giant Roman mosaic, made up of thousands of marble cubes just half a cubic inch in size, is being unearthed in southern Turkey.

title: A Naughty Word, and a Scolding From a Seatmate
description: IM a television producer, so Im flying almost all the time.

title: In Spain, Austerity and Hunger
description: As Spain tries to meet its budget targets, it has been forced to introduce one austerity measure after another.

title: In China, Sister of Ex-Police Official Bemoans His Conviction
description: BEIJING  The sister of a former police chief who played a central role in a seismic political scandal criticized his sentence of 15 years in prison in an interview on Monday, saying it was unfair and symptomatic of the lack of justice in China.

title: Spain Recoils as Its Hungry Forage Trash Bins for a Next Meal
description: MADRID  On a recent evening, a hip-looking young woman was sorting through a stack of crates outside a fruit and vegetable store here in the working-class neighborhood of Vallecas as it shut down for the night.

description: To the Editor:

title: Advisers on Contraceptives (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Lincoln Centers President to Leave
description: Reynold Levy, the president of Lincoln Center who shepherded an ambitious redevelopment of its 16-acre campus during hard economic times, will step down at the end of next year.

title: Bias Persists for Women of Science, a Study Finds
description: Science professors at American universities widely regard female undergraduates as less competent than male students with the same accomplishments and skills, a new study by researchers at Yale concluded.

title: U.S. Warning to Hospitals on Medicare Bill Abuses
description: Saying there are troubling indications of abuse in the way hospitals use electronic records to bill for Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement, the Obama administration warned on Monday that it would not tolerate what it called attempts to game the system and vowed to vigorously prosecute doctors and hospitals implicated in fraud.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Sri Lanka, Philippines and Nepal.

title: Milan Street Style | Serene vs. Extreme
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Big Law Steps Into Uncertain Times
description: The legal profession sits at the nexus of dealmakers worlds, from Wall Street to Silicon Valley to Washington. As regulations change and the threat of litigation rises, the importance of lawyers has never been greater.

title: Del Posto to Pay $1.15 Million to Settle Workers Suit
description: Del Posto, an Italian restaurant in Chelsea run by Mario Batali and Joe and Lidia Bastianich, has agreed to pay $1.15 million as part of a settlement with 31 current and former employees.

title: A Place Where Science and Science Fiction Can Be of One Mind
description: As befits a meeting ground for scientists and science fiction writers, the new Center for Science and the Imagination grew out of happenstance: a chance meeting last year between the novelist Neal Stephenson and Arizona State Universitys president, Michael M. Crow.

title: Ethan Bronner Discusses the Core Issue About Voting
description: When I wrote recently about the problem of false balance in news stories, I quoted the national legal affairs correspondent Ethan Bronner, whose Sept. 9 story was criticized by some readers.

title: Excerpt: 'L'Elisir d'Amore'
description: Anna Netrebko as Adina and Matthew Polenzani as Nemorino in Act II of the Donizetti opera at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Lessons of 107 Birthdays: Dont Exercise, Avoid Medicine and Never Look Back
description: Last year, for Juliana Koos 106th birthday party, the choreographer Jacques dAmboise rehearsed her great-grandchildren in a number that they performed. He scared them, recalled Mrs. Koos daughter Genevieve Young.

title: Demolition Derbies for Lovelorn
description: True love may be everlasting, but its not very funny.

title: Cowboys vs. the Mob in Las Vegas of the 60s
description: Its a tight race, but my vote for the drabbest and least informative title among the new fall television shows goes to CBSs Vegas over some tough competition, including Arrow, Revolution, Elementary, Partners and Nashville, which is at least the entire name of a city.

title: New Albums From Bad Plus and the Dave King Trio
description: THE BAD PLUS

title: Chinese Social Media Accounts Clash With Official Reports on Riot at Foxconn Factory
description: As my colleagues David Barboza and Keith Bradsher reported, Chinas official state-run news agency said 5,000 police officers were called to Foxconn Technology, one of Chinas largest manufacturing plants, to help quell a riot by employees that led to a shutdown of the plant on Monday.

title: Original Review: Sweet Bird of Youth
description: Brooks Atkinsons 1959 Broadway review of Tennessee Williamss play.

title: At Carnegie, Ripples of a Chicago Strike
description: Opening night at Carnegie Hall is one of the biggest musical events of the season, and this year the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and its star music director, Riccardo Muti, received the plum assignment.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: An American Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting in Touch With Her Selves
description: Tami Stronachs Me and Not Me, the premiere in her program at Dance New Amsterdam last week, involves two women, one child-size bicycle and basketfuls of yellow flowers. Only one of the women, Lindsey Dietz Marchant, rides the bicycle. All she wants to do is play. The other woman, Ms. Stronach, appears to have more on her mind.

title: The Universe Unseen, on Display in Chelsea
Graphic: White-Collar World
description: ARTHUR L. LIMAN, the renowned litigator, was once described as a big trouble lawyer because businessmen in hot water sought his counsel. Ubiquitous during the latter part of the 20th century, Mr. Liman appeared at the defense table alongside prominent clients like the Wall Street financier Michael Milken. The public knew him best, perhaps, as the chief counsel to the Senate committee investigating the Iran-contra affair.

title: Top Afghan Security Official Wins Case Challenging Corruption Accusation
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A judicial panel here ruled in favor of Afghanistans national security chief on Monday in an unusual case of a senior government official turning to the courts and the public to prove that allegations of corruption against him were untrue.

title: The Works of Shea Hembrey
description: A collection of images from Shea Hembreys exhibit, Dark Matters.

title: Letter From Obama Administration on Hospital Billing
description: The Obama administration warned in a letter to hospital associations that it would not tolerate what it called gaming the system.

title: The Delight Isnt Always in the Details
description: MILAN

title: Showtime Jumps to Capitalize on Emmy Glory for Homeland
description: LOS ANGELES  Heres what happens when you win an Emmy Award for best actress, as Claire Danes did on Sunday night. You give dozens of backstage interviews, answering the same questions again and again. Then your limo driver takes you to lavish parties, where you say thank you again and again and take photos with well-wishers. But all you really want to do is see your mom and dad, who watched your acceptance speech from a hotel suite miles away.

title: Stories From the Unchained Tour
description: In a film by Matthew T. Perry, Joan Juliet Buck  who wrote about her time on tour across Georgia with the Unchained Tour for our fall travel issue  expounds on the experience as wandering bard.

title: In a Monk Showcase, the Best Is Saved for Last
description: WASHINGTON  Jamison Ross sauntered onstage at the National Museum of Natural History here on Saturday with the solicitous gleam of a casino floor manager, his bulky frame encased in a suit and his face bearing a wide-open smile. Graciously, he initiated a round of applause for his fellow hopefuls in the 25th-annual Thelonious Monk International Jazz Competition, and another for the events unflappable house band. Then he sat down, picked up a pair of brushes and counted off Bye Bye Blues, an uncomplicated song recorded by dozens of American entertainers from the 1930s on.

title: Stories From the Unchained Tour
description: Joan Juliet Buck and members of a storytelling group embark on a tour across Georgia.

title: Graphic: Mergers and Acquisitions, Top Financial and Legal Advisers
description: In the third quarter of 2012, mergers and acquisition activity was $455 billion worldwide. The U.S. share was 43 percent, or $195 billion.

title: All Tomorrows Parties at Pier 36
description: Ill Be Your Mirror, the city edition of All Tomorrows Parties, the underground music festival, took place in Manhattan last weekend.

title: Festival of the Deeply Untrendy
description: On Sunday at 1 p.m., not long after the start of Day 3 of Ill Be Your Mirror, the musicians in the instrumental rock band Psychic Paramount prepared to begin. They turned on their amplifiers and their fog machines and quickly set off the buildings smoke alarm.

title: Conservative Super PACs Synchronize Their Messages
description: Independent political groups have long been the guerrilla warriors of presidential elections, tossing explosive advertisements into the middle of a campaign like hand grenades, with little regard for the strategy of the candidate they support.

title: 3Taps Files Antitrust Action Against Craigslist
description: Craigslist may be the worlds largest listings Web site, but after knocking down developers who try to build services on top of the Web site, it may also one of the least liked.

title: Two Billionaire Buyers Revealed at One57
description: Two fashion tycoons who are longtime friends and business partners are the first known billionaire buyers at One57, the Midtown tower under construction that will be New Yorks tallest building with residences, according to two people familiar with the matter.

title: Panel Reminds Doctors to Screen for Alcohol Misuse
description: Primary care doctors and nurses should screen their adult patients to determine whether they are misusing alcohol, and provide counseling when risky behavior is detected, a panel of medical experts reaffirmed on Monday.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: iPhone 5 Thieves, and Business Tech Start-Ups
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: An Old Warrior With No Taste for Nuclear War
description: Until very recently, Dwight D. Eisenhower has done a remarkably good job of hiding in plain sight. The Eisenhower era, the Eisenhower jacket and the still in-the-works Eisenhower memorial (planned for Washington) attract more news attention than the man himself does.

title: The AUDIT Assessment for Screening Alcohol Abuse
description: The United States Preventive Services Task Force reaffirmed a recommendation that doctors screen their patients for alcohol abuse by asking them a series of questions. Here is a sample of the questions your doctor may ask:

title: Death Shows Fragility of Pandas Lives
description: The giant panda cub that died Sunday morning had uneven coloring and hardness in her liver, officials at the National Zoo in Washington said Monday.

title: Model-Morphosis | Julia Frauche at Dolce & Gabbana
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2013 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Julia Frauche of Next Model Management before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau.

title: A Crucial Witness in Rajaratnam Trial Receives Probation
description: A former Intel executive who leaked secret information about his employer to Raj Rajaratnam, the fallen hedge fund billionaire, avoided prison on Monday when a judge sentenced him to two years probation.

title: New York Attorney General Rebuffs Congressional Republicans
description: Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman of New York on Monday rebuffed demands from Congressional Republicans to refrain from requesting tax returns and other information from tax-exempt groups that have spent heavily on campaign ads.

title: In Belarus Election, Presidents Supporters Win Every Seat in Parliament
description: MINSK, Belarus  Supporters of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko won every seat in Parliament in an election over the weekend that, as many in post-Soviet authoritarian states, was widely seen as rigged, if perhaps a little less so than before.

title: Wallace May Join Knicks Veteran Corps
description: If Rasheed Wallace comes out of retirement to join the Knicks, it will be because he feels the team is the perfect match for his veteran leadership and talent. That is what his agent, Bill Strickland, said Monday.

title: Lyor Cohen Resigns From Warner Music
description: Lyor Cohen, the dominant creative executive at the Warner Music Group for the last eight years, has resigned from the company, Warner announced on Monday. His departure adds another piece to the chess game of top music executives who are now free agents as the industry adjusts to changes after the Universal Music Groups absorption of most of EMI.

title: What Do Sharks Do in the Deep? Device May Tell
description: CHATHAM, Mass.  Beachgoers on Cape Cod may have spotted several sharks this summer, but when Chris Fischer and his crew  former subjects of History channels Shark Wranglers  went looking for the great whites here this month, there were none.

title: American Hospital Association Responds to Obama Administration
description: The association says that national guidelines on emergency room and clinic visits.

title: Tagging Great Whites
description: Scientists aboard the Ocearch tagged great white sharks off Cape Cod with GPS devices, hoping to track them with the ultimate goal of protecting the species.

title: In Arab Spring, Obama Finds a Sharp Test
description: WASHINGTON  President Hosni Mubarak did not even wait for President Obamas words to be translated before he shot back.

title: In-Flight Entertainment Arrives at a Crossroad
description: LONG BEACH, Calif.

title: 30 Accessories From Milan Fashion Week
description: From head to toe, heres a roundup of some of the most arresting pieces from the Milanese runways.

title: Shark-Hunting Off Cape Cod
description: Scientists working off Cape Cod attached GPS devices to great white sharks, hoping to learn more about the animals migratory patterns and breeding habits.

title: For Winner, Long-Ago Snub Still Stings
description: ATLANTA  The U-S-A cheer that greeted Brandt Snedeker on the 18th tee box Sunday at East Lake Golf Club was a long time coming. Long before his Ryder Cup debut this week, Snedeker seemed a lock to represent the United States against Britain and Ireland in the 2003 Walker Cup.

title: For Oreo Campaign Finale, a Twist on Collaboration
description: IF, as the saying goes, an apple a day keeps the doctor away, what, if anything, does an ad a day do?

title: Italy: Regional Leader Resigns
description: Renata Polverini, the president of the Lazio region, which includes Rome, resigned Monday in the wake of a political finance scandal that includes accusations of the misuse of public money. The scandal has tainted several local politicians associated with former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconis party and is another blow to the partys waning fortunes. Ms. Polverini, who has not been implicated in the scandal, said Monday that her administration, elected in 2010, had governed well. I leave with my head held high, she said.

title: Two Marines Face Charges
description: The Marine Corps said Monday that two noncommissioned officers accused of urinating on the bodies of dead Taliban fighters in Afghanistan last year would be court-martialed. The Marines, Staff Sgt. Joseph W. Chamblin and Staff Sgt. Edward W. Deptola, are based at Camp Lejeune, N.C. Three other Marines were disciplined last month for their roles in the episode, which provoked outrage in Afghanistan after a video of it became public.

title: Tracing the Root of the Ryder Cup Back to Its Seed
description: The Ryder Cup, which will be held for the 39th time this week at Medinah Country Club near Chicago, has become one of the most keenly anticipated team events in sports. But the origins of the event are somewhat muddled.

title: Ex-Regulator Has Harsh Words for Bankers and Geithner
description: Sheila C. Bair, who tormented Wall Street and its Washington allies as a banking regulator, is taking a fresh swipe at her foes in retelling the dark days of the financial crisis.

title: Tereska Torrs, 92, Writer of Lesbian Fiction, Dies
description: Tereska Torrs, a convent-educated French writer who quite by accident wrote Americas first lesbian pulp novel, died on Thursday at her home in Paris. She was 92.

title: India: Deluge Strikes Northeast
description: While parts of India struggle with crop failures and water shortages, the northeastern states of Sikkim and Assam have been hit by heavy rains and flash floods that have caused landslides and claimed at least 27 lives in recent days. Heavy rainfall last week has caused enormous damage in Sikkim, an official said. The region is now largely cut off from the rest of India because of the flooding and landslides, which have closed roads. In Assam, floods have affected nearly 1.3 million people, spread across 1,972 villages, said a state disaster official. The state has set up 166 relief camps, which now shelter more than 200,000 people.

title: After Graduating From College, Its Time to Plow, Plant and Harvest
description: RED HOOK, N.Y.  It was harvest time, and several farm hands were hunched over a bed of sweet potatoes under the midday sun, elbow deep in soil for $10 an hour. But they were not typical laborers.

title: Mayors Tale of Recovery Hasnt Been Reality for Some
description: Four years ago, New York City was the epicenter of the financial collapse. But since then  despite being burdened with huge job losses on Wall Street  we have been the epicenter of the national economic recovery.

title: On Stump in Ohio, Ryan Criticizes Obamas Military and Foreign Policies
description: LIMA, Ohio  Representative Paul D. Ryan took aim at President Obamas military policies on Monday, likening the differing national security philosophies of Mitt Romney and Mr. Obama to those of Ronald Reagan and Jimmy Carter, while lambasting a United States Army plan to halt Pentagon funding for several years for the nations only main battle tank, which employs 800 people at a plant in this northwest Ohio town.

title: Dead Men Share No Secrets
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: We Are the 96 Percent
description: WHENMitt Romney told the guests at a fund-raiser in Florida in May that America is divided between people who pay no income taxes and depend on government and pretty much everyone else, he missed the deeper truth. It is not just that most of the 47 percent Mr. Romney talked about do pay payroll taxes and that many of them have paid income taxes in the past. The reality he glossed over is that nearly all Americans have used government social policies at some point in their lives. The beneficiaries include the rich and the poor, Democrats and Republicans. Almost everyone is both a maker and a taker.

title: Results for G.O.P. Backers of Gay Marriage: Two Victories and, It Appears, a Loss
description: ALBANY  One of the four Republican state senators who voted for same-sex marriage claimed victory Monday in a close primary against an opponent critical of his vote, while another of the four appeared increasingly certain to lose his partys nomination over the issue.

title: Republican Team Attacks Obama on Foreign Policy
description: PUEBLO, Colo.  Mitt Romneys campaign is trying yet again to find solid footing, shifting its line of attack toward a subject President Obama has widely been thought to hold the advantage: foreign policy.

title: About-Face for Bankers New Lobbyist
description: I went to Wall Street and told them to get their snout out of the trough because they are some of the worst offenders when it comes to bailouts and carve-outs and special deals.

title: Mitts Mortification
description: That bloodied appendage? The one riddled with holes?

title: Cuomo Says Private Companies Could Run State Racetracks
description: New York Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Monday that the first charge of a newly formed board of directors to run horse racing in the state would be to determine whether its three racetracks should be bid out to private gambling companies.

title: Gerard I. Nierenberg, Negotiation Expert, Dies at 89
description: Gerard I. Nierenberg, a lawyer whose frustration with the adversarial nature of legal disputes led him to develop methods of negotiating that he promoted in training seminars and popular books, including The Art of Negotiating and How to Read a Person Like a Book, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 89.

title: Proportion Control
description: No other number attracts such a fevered following as the golden ratio. Approximately equal to 1.618 and denoted by the Greek letter phi, its been canonized as the Divine Proportion. Its devotees will tell you its ubiquitous in nature, art and architecture. And there are plastic surgeons and financial mavens who will tell you its the secret to pretty faces and handsome returns.

title: A Successful Yom Kippur Fast, With a Medical Assist
description: It will look like a scene out of a hospital ward.

title: Riot at Foxconn Factory Underscores Rift in China
description: SHANGHAI  The images and video began to appear on Chinese social networking sites early Monday: buildings with shattered windows, overturned police cars, huge crowds of young people milling about in the dark and riot police in formation.

title: A Shortage of Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Hazing = Bullying
description: To the Editor:

title: Visionary Entrepreneurs
description: To the Editor:

title: To Separate Gifted Students, or Not?
description: To the Editor:

title: For Reliever Aardsma, Two-Year Wait Is Almost Over
description: MINNEAPOLIS  David Aardsmas next major league pitch will be his first since Sept. 19, 2010, after having surgery on his left hip and right elbow. That pitch, however, will not come Monday night. Even though the Yankees flew Aardsma here from their training complex in Tampa, Fla., in time for the game against the Minnesota Twins  presumably to add an arm to their heavily used bullpen  they did not activate him.

title: The Conservative Mind
description: When I joined the staff of National Review as a lowly associate in 1984, the magazine, and the conservative movement itself, was a fusion of two different mentalities.

title: 3 Georgians Accused of Trying to Stage Prison Videos
description: TBILISI, Georgia  Georgian officials tried Monday to take control of a week-old prison abuse scandal, arresting three activists from an opposition party, Georgian Dream, and releasing video clips that purported to show them offering the police money to stage scenes of horrific abuse.

title: New Rules Upend House Re-Election Races in California
description: PLEASANTON, Calif.  Running against the Vietnam War, Representative Pete Stark entered Congress the year Richard M. Nixon was re-elected president. Since then, ensconced in Democratic strongholds here in the Bay Area, Mr. Stark was easily re-elected 19 times.

title: Apple Maps Errors Send Japanese to Homegrown App
description: TOKYO  When Hikarie, Tokyos new must-visit shopping destination, opened in April, it was already old news on Mapions map application. An elite team at the company, which is based here, had marked the glass tower a year earlier, keeping the service a step ahead in this fast-changing city.

title: Pirates Are Trying to Salvage a Promising Season Gone Bad
description: When the Pirates took the field Monday, they could have taken solace knowing that the Mets understood their pain. Misery has always loved company.

title: Assembly Punishes Worker for Online Posts
description: The New York State Assembly on Monday reprimanded an employee who had used a pseudonym while posting comments on the Internet defending Speaker Sheldon Silvers handling of a sexual harassment scandal.

title: Before Palestinians Act at U.N., Israeli Officials Urge Other Steps
description: JERUSALEM  With the Palestinians planning to make their case this week to upgrade from organizational status to nonmember status at the United Nations General Assembly, one senior Israeli minister condemned the move as the easy and wrong way out on Monday, while another said the time had come for Israel to consider its own unilateral move toward a separate state: annexing parts of the West Bank and withdrawing from others.

title: At Special Olympics, a Race for Better Health
description: When Special Olympics holds its competitions in the United States and around the world, it often enlists volunteer doctors and nurses to give its athletes basic health screenings. What they routinely uncover is evidence of a persistent gap in health care for people with mental disabilities. In basic areas  like dental work, eye and foot care and hearing exams  their unmet needs are appalling. Of 76,900 athletes examined between 2007 and 2011, more than 37 percent had untreated tooth decay. More than half had gait abnormalities, often a sign of ill-fitting shoes. More than 20 percent had never had an eye exam.

title: A Smart Step for Justice
description: In a significant law enforcement breakthrough with likely national implications, the New York Police Department has adopted a broad policy of videotaping custodial interrogations in murder, serious sex crime and felony assault cases.

title: Discarded Kidneys
description: More than 93,000 patients are on the waiting list for a kidney transplant, and last year more than 4,700 patients died while waiting. That makes it especially tragic that more than 2,600 kidneys were recovered from deceased donors last year and then discarded.

title: Why Romney Is Slipping
description: Mitt Romney said in an interview aired on Sunday that his campaign doesnt need a turnaround. He told CBS Newss 60 Minutes that he is tied with President Obama; he has a very effective campaign; its doing a very good job; and all he needs to do to win is keep repeating his plan to restore economic freedom.

title: The Trouble With Intentions
description: On their own, sentences are implacably honest. They may be long, short, simple, complex, clear, ambiguous, even incoherent. But they dont try to hide those qualities. They are what they are and they say what they say. Its as plain as the words on their faces. The trouble is that most sentences have writers, a fact that readers are well aware of. That makes it hard to consider sentences entirely on their own. Other questions arise. Whats she saying? What did he mean?

title: Housing Authority Leader Offers Plan to Raise Money
description: Acknowledging the considerable challenges bedeviling his agency, John B. Rhea, the beleaguered chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, unveiled a plan Monday to squeeze hundreds of millions of dollars out of parking lots, walkways, open spaces and other areas.

title: Lottery Numbers
Mayor of an Ailing Indiana Mill Town Turns to a Chicago Veteran for Advice
description: CHICAGO  When Karen Freeman-Wilson was elected the mayor of Gary, Ind., last year, she found herself confronting some grim truths about her hometown. Revenues in an already emaciated city budget were shrinking by millions of dollars. About a quarter of the buildings, she said, were empty. All the while, people were moving away.

title: Safer Flights, but Risk Lurks on the Runway
description: Southwest Airways Flight 844 from Minneapolis had just landed at Chicagos Midway International Airport last December and was about to cross a runway on its way to the terminal when the co-pilot noticed a business jet barreling toward him. He shouted for the captain to stop. The plane, carrying 74 passengers, screeched to a halt just short of the runway as the smaller jet crossed before their eyes.

title: Romney and the Forbes 400
description: Last week, sandwiched between Mondays leak of the video in which Mitt Romney dismissed the 47 percent and Fridays release of the Romneys 2011 tax returns  showing that they had paid an effective tax rate of 14 percent  Forbes magazine published its annual list of the 400 wealthiest Americans.

title: As Election Nears, Polls Are Better Predictors
description: With fewer than 45 days left in the presidential campaign, it is no longer a clich to say that every week counts. This is probably the last week, for instance, in which Mitt Romney can reasonably hope that President Obamas poll numbers will deteriorate because of a deflating convention bounce.

title: How the Center of the Earth Got a Little Off Kilter
description: SAN ANTONIO DE PICHINCHA, Ecuador  Those who visit the Middle of the World, a government-owned park that pays tribute to the Equator, are not drawn by the trinket shops or cafes offering roasted guinea pig. They want to stand on a yellow line painted on the ground here that is said to be precisely at Earths midpoint  0 degrees latitude, 0 minutes, 0 seconds.

title: U.S. Hearings Again Sought for 3 Detainees
description: WASHINGTON  Lawyers for three men who have been imprisoned by the United States military in Afghanistan without trial for nearly a decade are renewing their quest for hearings in American courts. They say new information has emerged that undermines an appeals court ruling against them two years ago.

title: Convicted Lobbyist Aids U.S. in Inquiry
description: A prominent New York lobbyist convicted of bribing former State Senator Carl Kruger has been secretly cooperating with the federal authorities and is asking a judge for leniency when he is sentenced on Friday, newly filed court documents show.

title: For Suzuki, Respect for Bats Is Key to Hitting
description: MINNEAPOLIS  During a game for the Orix Blue Wave in Japan in 1999, Ichiro Suzuki struck out and returned to the dugout unusually frustrated. In a fit of anger, he destroyed his black Mizuno bat. Embarrassed, Suzuki wrote a letter of apology to the craftsman who had made his bats by hand from Tamo wood, grown on the Japanese island of Hokkaido. Such was the respect that Suzuki felt for the process that created the bats, which he wielded with such skill.

title: Should the U.S. Be a Political Player in Russia?
Officials and League Remain Divided
description: After a weekend of negotiations between the N.F.L.  including Commissioner Roger Goodell  and its locked-out game officials, significant economic and noneconomic differences remain between the sides, according to a memo sent to the teams by Jeff Pash, the leagues general counsel and lead negotiator.

title: Washington State, Womens Rights and Big Cities
description: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Here is a look at Washington, the Evergreen State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Mark A. Smith, a professor of political science at the University of Washington.

title: City to Add Pre-K Efforts in Poor Areas Next Year
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Monday that the city would open a new type of preschool in Brooklyn next year, introducing a cradle-to-kindergarten approach to education for very young children in poor neighborhoods.

title: Formless Lump
description: Administrivial Unusual Puzzle Alert! The Tuesday, Sept. 25 puzzle will be offered in both Across Lite and as a PDF. Because of the unusual nature of this puzzle, some elements of the grid and the cluing will not reproduce the same way in Across Lite. If you normally solve online in Across Lite, we strongly recommend that you print out the PDF and solve it that way.

title: A Buried Family Secret, Not for the Faint of Heart
description: Generally speaking, when you hear a mournful folk melody played on a violin as the lights go down at the theater, it is wise to set aside any expectations of frothy pleasures  debonair quipping, pratfalling, tap-dancing chorus girls  and prepare for something more somber.

title: Shes Old and Faded; Hes Young and Trapped
description: CHICAGO  First glimpsed writhing buglike beneath satin sheets, she looks awfully small to be a towering legend of the screen. Breakable, too, as if a pair of strong arms could crush those fine bones to dust, leaving behind only a trail of mascara and remnants of that last, botched appointment with the hairdresser. Hey, this dame cant even breathe without the help of an oxygen mask.

title: Corrections: September 25, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Congressmans Campaign Office Vandalized
description: The campaign headquarters of Representative Michael G. Grimm on Staten Island was broken into over the weekend, and a computer server containing confidential campaign files and polling data was erased, the campaign said in a statement.

title: Ex-Informer to Serve 20 Years for Dealing Drugs and Guns
description: A former confidential informer for the New York Police Department pleaded guilty on Monday to dealing drugs and selling guns illegally as part of a plea deal under which he will be sentenced to 20 years in prison.

title: While U.N. Beckons Clinton, Obama Takes In The View
description: President Obama on Monday flew up to New York from Washington, rode in his motorcade to ABCs studios and sat down for an interview on The View. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton was not far away, in the Waldorf-Astoria, meeting with President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan.

title: Court Session in Patz Case Is Delayed for 6 Weeks
description: The next public court appearance for the man who confessed to killing Etan Patz in 1979 has been put off for six weeks, a move that has the effect of giving prosecutors and his defense lawyer more time to investigate before the case is presented to a grand jury for indictment.

title: Slight Dip in SAT Scores for the Class of 2012
description: For the high school class of 2012, the average score on the critical reading section of the SAT college entrance exam, 496, was down 1 point from the previous year, as was the average writing score, 488. The average math score, 514, was unchanged. Also unchanged: only 43 percent of the 1.66 million test-takers achieved the benchmark score, 1550, that indicates readiness for college. Among students whose parents have bachelors degrees, though, 60 percent were college ready. The College Board, which administers the test, says those with the benchmark score have a 65 percent likelihood of achieving a B- or higher grade average in their first year in college.

title: Louisiana: Accord Is Reached on Prison Overhaul
description: The Justice Department and the sheriff who runs the Orleans Parish Prison have reached an agreement on changes at the institution, where violence, suicides, unclean conditions and poor medical treatment are commonplace, said Thomas E. Perez, assistant attorney general for the civil rights division. The department said on Monday that it sought to intervene in a class-action lawsuit brought on behalf of prisoners. Sheriff Marlin Gusman, who oversees the prison, supported the federal involvement, which set the stage for the negotiated changes. The next step toward a final settlement will be finding money to pay for the overhaul.

title: Alabama: Ex-Professor Gets Life Term in Shooting
description: A former professor was sentenced on Monday to life in prison without parole for fatally shooting three colleagues and wounding three others at the University of Alabama, Huntsville, in 2010. The professor, Amy Bishop, pleaded guilty to avoid the death penalty. Jury deliberations  which state law requires in capital cases, even in plea deals  lasted for 20 minutes on Monday. Ms. Bishop opened fire during a meeting after being denied tenure. She could still face a trial in Massachusetts, where she is charged with killing her brother in 1986.

title: Grant Will Aid Effort to Find Old DNA Evidence
description: In an unusual partnership, the New York Police Department and a legal organization dedicated to exonerating people who have been wrongfully convicted have jointly received federal grant money to overhaul how the police store evidence in old cases.

title: With Doubleheader Split, The Orioles Lose Ground
description: As the baseball season moves into its final stretch, the story lines are becoming clearer. Three National League teams  San Francisco, Cincinnati and Washington  have clinched spots in the postseason, and Atlanta seems assured of joining them as a wild-card team. That leaves St. Louis fighting off Milwaukee and the Dodgers for the second wild-card slot. The Brewers loss to the Nationals on Monday afternoon made the Cardinals task a little easier.

title: Syrian Wars Spillover Threatens a Fragile Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  The civil war in Syria is testing Iraqs fragile society and fledgling democracy, worsening sectarian tensions, pushing Iraq closer to Iran and highlighting security shortcomings just nine months after American forces ended their long and costly occupation here.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,105 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Two Nets Take Stock of Future in Brooklyn
description: Two guys with Brook in their name opened the Nets first team store in Brooklyn, which seems almost poetic until you consider how close they were to becoming former Nets.

title: Mets Top the Pirates for Mejias First Win
description: The Mets prolonged the Pittsburgh Pirates swoon Monday night with a 6-2 victory that featured a solid performance by Jenrry Mejia and two home runs by Ike Davis. The win was the Mets fourth in a row, their longest winning streak since they took four in a row in late June.

title: New Ruling on Katrina Favors Corps of Engineers
description: A federal appeals court reversed itself, ruling Monday that the Army Corps of Engineers is not liable for devastation caused in Hurricane Katrina from a government-built navigation canal.

title: Pettitte Lifts Yankees in Another Scoreless Effort
description: MINNEAPOLIS  After witnessing another impressive performance by a former teammate and a fellow quadragenarian, Joe Girardi reached out from the dugout steps and shook Andy Pettittes right hand, congratulating him for the superb work Pettitte had done with his left.

title: Are Financial Fair Play Rules Destined to Be Broken?
description: As the UEFA president Michel Platini preached prudence and wisdom to Europes soccer elite last month, the setting seemed rather incongruous, almost undermining the words he spoke.

title: Word of the Day | translucent
description: translucent \tranz-l-snt\ adjective

title: Rebecca Sees Investor Fade, as if Dreamt
description: The business of Broadway has always been cloaked in mystery. Most of its 40 theaters are run by three private organizations that operate out of public view. Producers keep deal-making under wraps. The biggest mystery of all is why so many sophisticated investors go along with business-as-usual on Broadway when few shows turn a profit.

title: Striking Chicago Musicians Reach Tentative Agreement
description: The Chicago Symphony Orchestra strike appears to have ended after two days. The orchestra and its players, in a joint statement released Monday night, said they had reached a tentative three-year agreement that would take effect retroactively to Sept. 17 if the board of trustees and musicians ratify it.

title: Harsh Prison Sentences for 3 Vietnamese Bloggers
description: HONG KONG  Vietnam has hit three prominent bloggers with lengthy prison terms, reinforcing its reputation as one of the worlds most restrictive countries for freedom of speech and the press.

title: Swisher Leads Yankees Power Surge at Minnesota
description: MINNEAPOLIS  It took almost 32 years, but Nick Swisher is finally a grown man.

title: News Quiz | September 25, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: North Koreas Leaders Promise Improvements to Educational System
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Koreas leadership ended a rare second session of Parliament in a single year on Tuesday without making the announcements on economic reforms that many analysts had expected.

title: IHT Quick Read: Tuesday, Sept. 25
description: NEWS As Greece enters a pivotal week in its economic crisis, tensions between the Greek government and the countrys international lenders have reached a boiling point. The government is resisting a push by the International Monetary Fund to impose additional austerity measures that Greek leaders fear could destabilize the shaky coalition government. Liz Alderman and Landon Thomas Jr. report.

title: UB Group Companies Stock Up on Deal Talk
description: United Spirits, part of Vijay Mallyas cash-strapped group of companies, confirmed Tuesday it was in deal talks with global alcohol giant Diageo in a notice to the Bombay Stock Exchange. United Spirits stock price rose on the news, to 1098.80 rupees a share at noon in India, up 3.6 percent for the day. United Spirits stock hit a 52 week high of 1,099.95 rupees a share on Monday on rumors deal talks were underway.

title: Bat Cave to the Rescue?
description: WHO is Cory Holliday?

title: Test Yourself | English, Sept. 25, 2012
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Shrink to Fit.

title: India Enters Era of Regionalism
description: The Indian government has, for the moment, averted a political crisis. Despite full-throated resistance from the Bharatiya Janata Party and at least a dozen regional parties, which organized nationwide protests last week to oppose economic policy changes introduced by the government, it managed to cobble together sufficient support in Parliament to stay afloat.

title: History in Little Rock
description: The day marks an important milestone in civil rights history and the birth of one of the best known television personalities of our lifetime.

title: Hey, Big Saver!
description: If you want to know what the future of the American economy looks like  when the unemployment rate will return to below 6 percent, or when annual growth will climb back above 3 percent  its helpful to stop thinking for a moment about those families in serious financial distress. Thats because the future of the U.S. economy relies, in large part, on another group of people living in fear: the millions of Americans who have a little disposable income.

title: Retreating to Memory With a Song
description: Every morning these last few weeks, my 3-year-old son digs through a pile of old CDs on a bookshelf in our guest bedroom. He toddles between rooms, carrying one and then another of the plastic cases to the breakfast table, asking, You like this one, Mama?

title: Fragments of Fukushima
description: The first time the Tokyo-based photographer Kosuke Okahara visited a town near the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant in Japan, he grabbed his dosimeter, a device used to measure radiation levels, and looked at his watch to see how much time he could spend at the location.

title: Is Trying Too Hard to Be Happy Making You Sad?
description: In her opinion piece America the Anxious, Ruth Whippman argues that Americans relentless pursuit of happiness is actually causing us much anxiety. She begins her piece with a quote by the author-philosopher Eric Hoffer: The search for happiness is one of the chief sources of unhappiness.

title: A Conversation With: Landesa Founder Roy Prosterman
description: More than four decades ago, Roy Prosterman left a high-paying job at a white-shoe law firm in search of a different kind of job satisfaction. He ended up finding it in Landesa, a Seattle-based nonprofit that he founded, which works to secure land rights for the rural poor in countries around the world. Founded in 1966, the group is better known by its former name, Rural Development Institute. Today, Landesa has 120 employees; it has operated in more than 50 countries, including China, Vietnam and Russia, and says 100 million families have benefited from its work. Thirty percent of the groups $13 million annual budget is spent in India.

title: Syrian Shells Land Near Israeli Border
description: JERUSALEM  Several mortar shells launched from Syria landed in the Golan Heights near Israels northern border on Tuesday morning, prompting the Israeli military to file a complaint with United Nations forces operating in the area.

title: Part 2: Answers From Princetons Dean of Admission
description: Updated: Ms. Rapelye is no longer taking questions.This week, The Choice has invited Janet Lavin Rapelye, the dean of admission at Princeton University, to stop by our virtual Guidance Office and answer your questions about college admissions. Ms. Rapelye, who received a bachelors degree from Williams College and a masters degree from Stanford University, has 30 years experience in college admissions.

title: Republicans Champion Voluntary Taxes
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: After Monday Night Fiasco, a Call for Goodell to Apologize
description: A roundup of reaction to one of the most embarrassing episodes in N.F.L. history, when some egregiously poor calls in the fourth quarter culminated with a disputed last-second touchdown heave that gave the Seattle Seahawks a 14-12 victory over the Green Bay Packers on Monday Night Football.

title: Diageo in Talks to Buy Stake in United Spirits
description: LONDON  Diageo, the worlds largest spirits company, said on Tuesday that it was in talks to buy a stake in United Spirits of India.

title: Bond Investors Register Nervousness About Spain
description: PARIS  Spains borrowing costs rose on Tuesday at an auction of short-term debt, showing investors uncertainty about the countrys strategy for emerging from crisis.

title: On Our Radar: Toyota Retrenches on Electric Cars
description: Toyota scraps plans for wide sales of a new all-electric minicar, saying that it had misread the market and the ability of battery technology to satisfy consumers. Now it plans to sell only about 100 battery-powered eQ vehicles in the United States and Japan. [Reuters]

title: Near Disputed Islands, Japan Confronts Boats From Taiwan
description: TOKYO  The Japanese Coast Guard used water cannons on Tuesday to disperse fishing boats from Taiwan in waters claimed by Japan in the East China Sea, widening a territorial dispute that has already pitted Japan against China and threatened vital trade relations in the region.

title: The Big Banks Say They Are Meeting Their Lending Commitment
description: Earlier this month, I published a post entitled, Are the Big Banks Keeping Their Commitment to Small Businesses? It had to do with a commitment that 13 of the largest banks in the country made last September to increase their small-business lending by $20 billion over the following three years.

title: Early and Often
description: Even if the nonstop commercials and coverage didnt tip you off, there are certain words in the air that unmistakably say, Its election time!

title: Opinion Report: Videotaped Interrogations
description: From the editorial page

title: China Launches Carrier, but Experts Doubt Its Worth
description: BEIJING  In a ceremony attended by the countrys top leaders, China put its first aircraft carrier into service on Tuesday, a move intended to signal its growing military might as tensions escalate between Beijing and its neighbors over islands in nearby seas.

title: Qatars Latest Investment Stirs the French
