description: LONDON  A decision by the French government to allow Qatar to invest millions of euros in Frances depressed and neglected suburbs has prompted concerns across the political spectrum about the motives of the wealthy Arab emirate.

title: Relations between Egypt and the U.S.
description: Mohamed Morsi, Egypts first democratically elected president, said that it is up to Washington to revitalize the alliance with Egypt.

title: The Future of Big Law
description: The Future of Big Law | With business still tepid in the aftermath of the financial crisis, and with the industry reeling from the failure of Dewey & LeBoeuf, DealBook looks at the future of lawyering in a special section, Big Law Steps Into Uncertain Times. That future may involve an entirely new business model, one without any partners, writes Andrew Ross Sorkin in his column.

title: The Upscale Treatment
description: Dear Diary:

title: Love Potion Opens Season at the Met
description: Another Metropolitan Opera opening night, another new production of a Donizetti opera starring the charismatic soprano Anna Netrebko. Or so it seems these days.

title: Tuesday Reading: When Surgeons Leave Objects in Your Body
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Coulda Been Worse
description: Josh Lehner does something Ive been meaning to do: he compares US economic performance since the financial crisis with other episodes of major financial crisis. And guess what? We actually look better than most (sorry about the small print):

title: EconoTrolls
description: Noah Smith has a very funny and highly accurate description of the menagerie. If you think hes making fun of you, he probably is.

title: A Monster, but No Epic Battle
description: The author Michael Lewis once rebuffed the notion that he should write a novel by saying, Whereas journalists once felt humbled by the novel, we now live in an age in which the novelist lives in a state of anxiety about nonfiction. Mr. Lewis, the writer of Liars Poker and Moneyball, was talking to Robert S. Boynton for the interview anthology The New New Journalism.

title: Obama Tells U.N. New Democracies Need Free Speech
description: UNITED NATIONS  President Obama on Tuesday used his last major address on a global stage before the November election to deliver a strong defense of Americas belief in freedom of speech, challenging fledgling Arab and North African democracies to ensure that right even in the face of violence.

title: Turkeys Military Politics
description: ISTANBUL  A Turkish courts conviction on Friday of 325 senior military officers for plotting to overthrow the state has left me with mixed feelings. Like many Turks, Ive been pondering a host of questions: Was this justice or revenge? Is this the final curtain on a military that for decades believed it knew better than the elected politicians? Or was the 21-month courtroom drama the latest show trial, manipulated by a government that itself entertains delusions of grandeur?

title: Fashion, the Next Dimension
description: With Lily Kwong as his 3-D model, the photographer Simon Cave imagines a fashion world that is anything but flat. How close is this to becoming a reality? In an exclusivevideo, Cave takes The Moment behind the scenes of his epic shoot to get the full 360 degree view. And to experience the final results, go to sc-3d.com.

title: Daily Report: Riot at Foxconn Factory Highlights Labor Unrest
description: A riot at a factory in Taiyuan, China, late Sunday was noteworthy because the site is managed by Foxconn Technology, one of the worlds biggest electronics manufacturers and an important supplier to major Western technology companies, David Barboza and Keith Bradsher report in Tuesdays New York Times.

title: Leading Off: A Fiasco to End the Referee Fiasco?
description: To be sure, the conga line of complaining about the replacement referee fiasco had started before Monday nights N.F.L. game got even ESPNs Jon Everyones Doing a Great Job! Gruden all riled up. The line was headed right to the gilded  and now probably fortified  door of Commissioner Roger Goodell, whose baronial arrogance makes him so easy to blame for just about anything. But the ending to that dreadful game Monday night may be his crowning achievement.

title: Adding Up the Governments Legal Bills for Fannie and Freddie
description: The governments takeover of the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in 2008 may turn out to be a very expensive proposition.

title: In West Bengal, Cashless Microfinance Opens Doors for Women
description: CANNING, West Bengal  A debt crisis in Indias microfinance sector in Andhra Pradesh in 2010 revived the question of how to help the hard-core poor without forcing them into a debt trap. Now it appears that microfinance institutions may have had an alternative all along.

title: No Thank-You Note, but Several Lawsuits for a Pepper-Spraying Inspector
description: Never mind the celebratory demonstrations last week. This Monday was the important anniversary for Occupy Wall Street. On that day a year ago, the movement truly kicked into gear. It owed an enormous debt to a police deputy inspector named Anthony Bologna, who has received not a word of thanks for having put it on the map.

title: Home Prices Rise Again, This Time on the Low End
description: The housing market continues to gather strength, and the biggest gains in price now appear to be among the least expensive homes, whose values fell the most in the downturn and have weighed against any would-be recovery.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Its Showtimes Time, and N.F.L.s Monday Night Hangover
description: The Emmy awards won by the tense, terrorism-centric Showtime series Homeland could not have come at a better time for the network, or the series, Brian Stelter writes. The awards  including best drama, best actress (Claire Danes), best actor (Damian Lewis)  represent a coming of age for the network, which had never received a series prize for comedy or drama and has long been in the shadow of the Emmy-award-laden HBO. With the second season of Homeland beginning on Sunday, the subscription network was immediately setting out to capitalize on the wins. I think there might be some extra activity at the call centers this week, said David Nevins, president for entertainment at Showtime.

title: Rare Trout Survives in Just One Stream, DNA Reveals
description: The rare greenback cutthroat trout, Colorados state fish, is even more imperiled than scientists thought, a new study suggests. By analyzing DNA sampled from cutthroat trout specimens pickled in ethanol for 150 years, comparing it with the genes of todays cutthroat populations, and cross-referencing more than 40,000 historic stocking records, researchers in Colorado and Australia have revealed that the fish survives not in five wild populations, but just one.

title: Absurd Ending Fuels Disgust With Replacement Refs
description: SEATTLE  The play that best defines this N.F.L. season occurred at the end of another game in which replacement officials looked less like actual referees and more like the Keystone Kops. It was bizarre enough to almost defy description.

title: Report Cites High Civilian Toll in Pakistan Drone Strikes
description: A new report on targeted killing by C.I.A. drones in Pakistans tribal area concludes that the strikes have killed more civilians than American officials have acknowledged, alienated Pakistani public opinion and set a dangerous precedent under international law.

title: Can Vegans and Carnivores Get Along? Moby Thinks So
description: Ive been a vegan for 24 years, Moby, the musician, told me on the phone the other day. With two lapses. I had yogurt in 1992, and I have to say, it was really good. And then I was at a friends restaurant in Portland, Oregon, a few years ago, and they made me some vegan sushi, but they accidentally brought me crab sushi. So I had a bite of crab sushi, and then my friend who ran the restaurant came running out yelling, like, No! Its got crab!

title: How I Made My Memoir: Book Coming From Neil Patrick Harris
description: By now Neil Patrick Harriss bucket list must be short enough to fit on a Post-it note: host the Academy Awards; write a memoir; get the Criterion Collection to release a special cinephile edition of Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle. And he can cross one more item off that agenda: the Crown Archetype imprint of Random Houses Crown Publishing Group is expected to announce on Tuesday that it has acquired a new nonfiction book from Mr. Harris, the stage and screen performer; Emmy Award-winner; host of the Emmys, Tonys, TV Land Awards and Spike Video Game Awards; and star of CBSs How I Met Your Mother.

title: What Were Reading
description: The New York Times: Spain, which has one of the worlds best cuisines, also has an unemployment rate of over 50 percent among young people, and many have resorted to foraging through the trash for food. Emily Weinstein

title: In Munich, Classing Up Oktoberfest
description: Ah, autumn. That traditional time of pigskin, piping hot pretzels, copious quantities of beer and blitzed bonhomie. No, were not talking about college football season. Were talking about Oktoberfest, another fall tradition thats not exactly known for its high quotient of class. There you are, sitting cheek-by-jowl with a bunch of lederhosen-ed Bavarians  or, more likely, stag-partying Britons and study-abroad Americans  on a wooden bench in a frigid tent in some biergarten in the middle of Munich, slogging through steins and trying to hail the dirndl-clad beermaid (bierfrau?) to get another wurst. Its the worst.

title: U.N. Leader Opens General Assembly on Somber Note
description: The leader of the United Nations formally opened its annual General Assembly on Tuesday with a speech conveying a broad sense of crisis because of pressing problems including armed conflict in the Middle East, disruptive climate change and religious intolerance.

title: New York City Schools Provide Morning-After Pills
description: In 13 New York City schools, the morning-after pill is available to students without parental permission, although parents are given the opportunity to opt their teenagers out of the health program (and the provision of any contraceptives) at the beginning of the school year.

title: Trampoline Injuries Down, but Caution Is Urged
description: Trampoline injuries, which rose steadily through the middle of the last decade, appear to be on the downswing, according to a new study in the journal Pediatrics that looked at trampoline-related emergency room visits. But the drop in injuries appears to be a result of a decrease in trampoline sales rather than greater awareness of the dangers of trampolines and safer use, the authors said, and the American Academy of Pediatrics continues to advise against recreational trampoline use, a position it has taken since 1977.

title: As the Peoples Priest, He Fought for the Forgotten of the Bronx
description: The Rev. John C. Flynn could have been a monsignor, but as he told the story in later years, he refused the elevation because he already held a title more to his liking: the peoples priest.

title: Small Presses Take Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn Book Festival, which ended Sunday, was a showcase for the many small presses that have sprouted in Brooklyn.

title: Some Bettors Get Relief on Game Decided by Botched Call
description: While it remains to be seen what, if anything, Commissioner Roger Goodell and the N.F.L. are going to do about the controversial ending to the game Monday night between the Seattle Seahawks and the Green Bay Packers, the gambling world  which was boosted by the replacement referees decision on the games final play, as significant money was bet on the Packers  appears to be showing at least a little compassion.

title: Comparing the Job Losses in Financial Crises
description: For a while I was regularly updating a chart each month showing how far employment plummeted in the latest recession and how little ground has been recovered since the recovery began in June 2009. Compared with other recent recessions and recoveries, the last few years have looked especially disastrous:

title: A Critical View of the Financial Crisis
description: Sheila C. Bair on her harsh history of the financial crisis. | Ericssons chief, Hans Vestberg, on surviving disruption. | The Timess James B. Stewart and Peter Lattman look at big laws future.

title: Hit-and-Run Driver Kills Cyclist in Queens
description: The police are looking for a driver who fatally struck a 38-year-old bicyclist on Queens Boulevard on Tuesday morning and drove off. The collision occurred around 6 a.m. near the intersection of Hoover Avenue in Kew Gardens, the police said. The cyclist, whose name was not immediately released, was pronounced dead at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center. No information about the drivers vehicle was immediately available.

title: Business Day Live: Ex-Regulator Has Harsh Words for Bankers and Geithner
description: Sheila C. Bair on her harsh history of the financial crisis. | Ericssons chief, Hans Vestberg, on surviving disruption. | The Timess James B. Stewart and Peter Lattman look at the future of big law.

title: Romney Urges Attaching Certain Strings to Foreign Aid
description: 3:39 p.m. | Updated  Mitt Romney laid out the broad outlines of his plan to foster work opportunities and free enterprise in developing nations on Tuesday morning, suggesting during a speech at the Clinton Global Initiative in New York that he would make foreign aid conditional on progress on these fronts.

title: Obamas Speech to the United Nations General Assembly  Text
description: Following is a text of President Obamas speech to the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday, as released by the White House:

title: Charting the Success of Early Underdogs in the N.F.L.
description: Chase Stuart writes about the historical and statistical side of football at his site, FootballPerspective.com

title: Model-Morphosis | Montana Cox at DSquared2
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2013 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Montana Cox of IMG before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Charlotte Tilbury and hair by Sam McKnight.

title: Summer Stretches Into Fall, Held by a Crab Claw
description: WESTPORT, Mass.

title: Image of the Day: September 25
Short Film by Target Draws Big-Name Talent
description: Target on Tuesday will announce its most ambitious foray into so-called branded entertainment, a 12-minute-long film, Falling for You, that will showcase more than 100 home, beauty and fashion items the company is promoting for the fall season.

title: How Many Government Programs Have You Benefited From?
description: Mitt Romney stirred up a hornets nest with his comments about the 47 percent of Americans who he thinks are dependent on the government.

title: Video Reports From Japan, Taiwan and China on Confrontation Off Disputed Islands
description: As my colleague Hiroko Tabuchi reports from Tokyo, the Japanese Coast Guard fired water cannons on Tuesday at a flotilla of Taiwanese fishing boats off a chain of islands claimed by Japan, Taiwan and China. Japans state broadcaster, NHK, captured some of the confrontation on video.

title: Fashion in 3-D
description: With Lily Kwong as his 3-D model, the photographer Simon Cave imagines a fashion world that is anything but flat.

title: Man Charged With Hate Crime After Antigay Attack
description: A 44-year-old man has been arrested on charges of hate-crime assault for the antigay slashing last week of a 22-year-old man in a McDonalds in the West Village, the police said on Tuesday.

title: Oil and Nature: A Landscape Reconfigured
description: In the stark white space of the Aperture Gallery in Chelsea, billboard-size photographs present an array of haunting scenes. A chemical plant with a cemetery in the foreground. An empty basketball court alongside a turreted oil refinery. A lush swamp filled with trees, one of which has a Shell Oil sign nailed to it.

title: Producer Hopes to Bring Black Orpheus to Broadway
description: The Broadway producer Stephen C. Byrd, who mounted a multiracial Streetcar Named Desire last season and an all-black Cat on a Hot Tin Roof in 2008, is developing a new stage musical based on the 1959 film Black Orpheus, which won the Academy Award for best foreign-language picture in 1960.

title: Some Things Never Change
description: The International Herald Tribune celebrates its 125th birthday in October, and over the coming weeks well be sharing highlights from our archives.

title: Sheila Bairs Critical View of History
description: Times reporter Louise Story talks to Sheila C. Bair, former F.D.I.C. chairwoman, about her harsh history of the financial crisis.

title: Vain Glorious | Ruffians Barbershop in Edinburgh
description: What: Ruffians Barbershop

title: What I Brought Home
description: See dozens of your souvenirs and the stories behind them.

title: Antibiotic Prescription? It May Depend on Where You Live
description: A new study has found that older men and women in the South are more often prescribed antibiotics than older Americans elsewhere, even though there is no evidence that the South has higher rates of pneumonia and other diseases for which antibiotics are necessary. The findings suggest there are greater rates of antibiotic overuse in that part of the country.

title: Sept. 24: Deep Red Polling Mystery
description: The FiveThirtyEight forecast was essentially unchanged on Monday, with Barack Obama holding a 77.7 percent chance of winning the Electoral College.

title: On Eve of Paris Motor Show, Mercedes-Benz Provides Further Details on Yacht Design
description: PARIS  In a sour European automotive market, Mercedes-Benz is diversifying into other forms of mobility. On the eve of the international motor show here, where the German automaker is scheduled to introduce several new automobiles, it shared further details on the designs for a new yacht.

title: The Count and the Gymnasts
description: During the Battle of Antietam on Sept. 17, 1862, Col. Ernst von Vegesack, the commander of the 20th New York Volunteer Infantry Regiment, sat prominently on horseback, while the units banner, emblazoned with the words Bahn Frei, German for clear the way, streamed high over a ridge near the Dunker Church.

title: A Young Immigrant Struggles for a College Education
description: For graduating high school seniors, the months that stretch out between the end of spring and those first signs of fall can be magical  senior prom, graduation, soaking up summer then cramming in the last bits of time with childhood friends.

title: Delusions of Wonkhood
description: Dave Weigel has some fun with credulous journalists who are sure that Paul Ryan must be a Very Serious Wonk because  wait for it  he uses PowerPoint. With pie charts!

title: Barnes & Noble to Introduce New Video Service for Nook Devices
description: Barnes & Noble said on Tuesday it would introduce a new video store for its Nook products this fall, the latest expansion of the booksellers digital content.

title: More Coulda Been Worse Blogging
description: From Eurostat.

title: The Future of Big Law
description: Times columnist James B. Stewart  a former lawyer  and reporter Peter Lattman look at the future of big law.

title: Chinese Dissident Artist Says the Authorities Still Have His Passport
description: BEIJING  Ai Weiwei, the rebel artist and acid critic of the Chinese Communist Party who was detained by the government last year, said Tuesday that the authorities were still holding his passport, which means he cannot travel to the United States for long-planned artistic events there next month or start a job as a visiting professor in Germany.

title: Business Day Live: Law Firms Under Pressure
description: James B. Stewart and Peter Lattman of The New York Times look at the pressures facing the legal industry.

title: N.F.L. Supports Decision Not to Overturn Winning Touchdown
description: The N.F.L. issued a statement Tuesday morning declaring the Packers-Seahawks game result final and supporting the decisions of its replay-booth referees, who did not overturn the controversial call of a game-winning touchdown for the Seahawks.

title: A Form of Dementia That Is Often Misdiagnosed
description: Lori Robertss father, who used to deliver the mail in Mitchell, S.D., has undergone startling personality changes. He used to be very easygoing, Ms. Roberts said. Now hes gotten kind of physical with my mom and my brother, pushing and shoving. The other day, when her exhausted mother visited him in the nursing home he had recently entered  by sad coincidence, it was their 53rd wedding anniversary  he loudly insisted that she take him to Mexico, immediately.

title: If You Like Roy Orbison . . .
description: Each week, Val Haller, the founder of the music Web site Valslist.com, matches music from her baby boom generation to music of her 20-something sons generation.

title: Russia Eases Limits on Visas for Americans
description: Americans traveling to Russia face looser restrictions under a new visa agreement that the two countries reached this month.

title: First Night of the New Season Has NBC and CBS Swapping Places
description: The first night of the official network television season turned the competition almost on its head as NBC dominated in the advertiser-preferred ratings, ABC dominated with older viewers, CBS saw its Monday lineup take a dive and Fox took a general battering.

title: One Word: Plastics
description: In an effort to bring something new to the landscape of luxury handbags, the accessories designer Kristine Johannes deliberately avoided the one material that most obviously defines it: leather. I just got sick of skins, says Johannes, whose previous stints at J. Crew and Devi Kroell required a good amount of working with hides and exotics. There are so many amazing man-made materials, I thought, Why does the standard evening bag have to look like X?  Which is how Rauwolf, Johanness line of angular plexiglass evening clutches, came to be so Y. Produced in an Italian factory that specializes in accessory parts like belt buckles and shoe heels, the seven bags in the fall collection take their cues from cut gemstones, with sharp lines, reflective surfaces and facets as dizzying as diamonds. In a way, plexi is like stone, Johannes says. It comes in all of these thicknesses and gets carved down and filed down and heat treated to do what you want it to do. The glassy-blue Shalimar clutch above has a magnetic closure, a sharp hourglass shape and  bonus points  doubles as a mirror for the quick makeup check. $2,300; rauwolfnyc.com.

title: British Bankers Group May Give Up Control Over Libor
description: LONDON  A British banking group is preparing to give up its control over the interest rate at the center of a recent manipulation scandal, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.

title: Romney at the Clinton Global Initiative
description: The Republican nominees speech at the Clinton Global Initiative was surprisingly reasonable. Granted, Mr. Romney got in a few digs at President Obama, but they were subtle and almost funny. And he was a bit light on details, but the occasion didnt really call for granularity.

title: After Waters Inquiry, House Panel Recommends New Ethics Rules
description: Saying that public trust is at stake, a special House ethics panel on Tuesday called for new rules to prevent lawmakers and their staffs from violating conflict of interest standards and proposed other new measures designed to keep partisan squabbles from undermining future investigations of such wrongdoing.

title: The Sin of Sowing Hatred of Islam
description: Two weeks ago, on the morning of Sept. 11, I noticed a woman wearing a traditional Muslim head covering on the packed platform of the train station in Scarsdale, N.Y. Her attention was focused on a billboard ad that announced 19,250 deadly Islamic attacks since 9/11/01 and pre-empted those who might dispute that claim with the refrain: Its not Islamophobia, its Islamorealism. I could only imagine what she was feeling.

title: Charbroiling Burgers: An Air-Quality Scourge That May Be Worse Than Diesel Trucks
description: In Freakonomics-like fashion, researchers at the University of California, Riverside, have concluded that producing a charbroiled hamburger emits the same mass particulate matter as a heavy-duty diesel truck traveling 143 miles.

title: State of the Race: Yankees Facing a Welcome Foe
description: By now we all know the bad news for the Yankees.

title: AT&T Introduces Security Products for Bring-Your-Own Devices
description: AT&T on Tuesday introduced security software and services designed to help businesses protect the smartphones and tablets that employees are bringing into the workplace. The software will work for mobile devices on any cell network.

title: TCM to Screen Forbidden Planet on Land and on the Space Station
description: The Turner Classic Movies cable channel is joining with NASA to give an out-of-this-world opening to a series of film screenings.

title: Wheelies: The One-Upsmanship Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Molinaro Condemns Lady Gaga for Glorifying Drug Use
description: Updated, 6:07 p.m. | The Staten Island borough president, James P. Molinaro, waded hip-deep into the culture wars this week, calling Lady Gaga a slut as he excoriated her for glorifying drug use.

title: TimesCast Politics | Obama at U.N.
description: Obama and Romney visit New York. | A new generation of Democratic donors. | A deadline in the Missouri Senate race. | Has the Romney campaign misused Paul Ryan?

title: Matchy Matchy
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Maybe the Monkey Needs a Sports Stars Name
description: Theres only an hour on Wednesday night between the end of Animal Practice on NBC and the start of The Neighbors on ABC. That may not be enough time for you to recover from the brain cell loss the first one induced and prepare yourself for the even more severe brain cell loss the second will cause.

title: Weekly Reader: BPA, Well-Intentioned Teachers, Obesity and the Middle Class
description: Your inner wonk needs to read this Brookings Institution paper on Pathways to the Middle Class: Why do some children do so much better than others? And what will it take to create more opportunity? We dont, say the authors, have nearly as much economic and social mobility in this country as wed like to believe.

title: Video of Obamas U.N. Address
description: As my colleague Helene Cooper reports, President Obama devoted most of his address to the U.N. General Assembly on Tuesday to the Arab democracy movement and the tension between free speech and mutual respect among cultures and faiths in an era of instant, global communication.

title: Average A.T.M. Surcharge Reaches New High
description: Its getting more important to consider the size and scope of your banks network of A.T.M.s if you use them frequently.

title: For Tesla Motors, One Supercharger to Bind Them
description: 9:39 p.m. | Updated

title: Germany Acts to Increase Limits on High-Speed Trades
description: BERLIN  Germany intends to be one of the first countries to try to put the brakes on high-frequency trading, the computer-driven force that has been rattling stock markets across the globe.

title: Judge Orders DNA Test in Dispute Over Jeffersons Star Hemsleys Estate
description: The legal fight over the estate of Sherman Hemsley, The Jeffersons star who died in July, has escalated to a new level of bizarreness, as a judge ruled that a man claiming to be the actors brother must undergo DNA testing, The Associated Press reported.

title: A Hedge Funds Complex Scheme May Cost It Millions
description: Hedge funds are supposed to be the smart money, but sometimes even they can be outsmarted.

title: European Solar Group Seeks Wider China Trade Inquiry
Blasts Hit Syrian School as War Is Focus at the U.N.
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  Insurgent bombs exploded at a Damascus school building on Tuesday, and Syrian government shells landed in the disputed Golan Heights region held by Israel, underscoring the Syrian conflicts growing scope as it dominated much of the discussion on the first formal day of the United Nations General Assembly.

title: Search for Lost Leonardo Halted
description: ROME  A project searching for a lost mural by Leonardo da Vinci behind a fresco painted by Giorgio Vasari in the Palazzo Vecchio, now Florences city hall, has been suspended and the scaffolding that has covered the fresco for months will be dismantled this week.

title: Ichimura at Brushstroke
description: Inside the secret sushi bar, tucked away inside of Brushstroke in TriBeCa.

title: Hidden in a Nook, Mastery in Plain Sight
description: MANY people who love restaurants dream about discovering an extraordinary one that nobody else knows about and keeping it secret. Id always thought I was one of them until the Friday night not long ago when I ate with a guest in an empty sushi bar in TriBeCa. During the two hours we sat there, no customers arrived to claim the six other counter seats or the four chairs at a nearby table.

title: Iran Reveals More About What It Calls Foreign Sabotage
description: Iran said Tuesday that it had amassed new evidence of attempts by saboteurs to attack Iranian nuclear, defense, industrial and telecommunications installations, including the use of computer virus-infected American, French and German equipment.

title: The Art of Hair
description: Images from the exhibition at the Muse du Quai Branly in Paris.

title: A New Choreographer for Hands on a Hardbody
description: The Broadway choreographer Sergio Trujillo (Memphis, Jersey Boys) has taken over musical staging duties on the coming Broadway show Hands on a Hardbody from Benjamin Millepied, the producers of the show announced.

title: From Methane to Plastic to Methane, Without Waste
description: Imagine that you could go online and rent something in your neighbors garage rather than buy something new that you will need to use only a few times a year. Or that you could use microwave technology to transform timber residue or other waste biomass into a valuable industrial material like graphite.

title: A Deadline in the Missouri Senate Race
description: Tuesday is the last day that Representative Todd Akin, a Republican, can drop out of the Senate race against Senator Claire McCaskill in Missouri.

title: One of a Kind
description: In the eight hotels that Kit Kemp owns with her husband, Tim  among them the Crosby Street Hotel in Manhattan and the Dorset Square Hotel in London  no two rooms are alike. This is because Kemp, who designed the spaces, eschews the common practice of selecting a single scheme to be repeated throughout, instead embarking on a painstaking process of decorating every room to be utterly distinct from the next. She selects each, say, 1960s Lucite lamp, piece of boiled-wool upholstery and Filipino totem sculpture, then pulls them all together in a highly individualized, homey whole that is greater than the sum of its parts. In a new book, Kit Kemp: A Living Space (Hardie Grant, $50), Kemp details her approach to design (for residential as well as hotel projects), and sums it up as, Keep it personal. Her secret? Finding little touches  like using a kerosene can, instead of classically cut crystal, as a lamp base in a romantic bedroom.

title: In Paris, an Exhibition Dedicated to Hair
description: PARIS  Hair, as the song from the musical goes, can be long, straight, curly, fuzzy, snaggy, shaggy, ratty, matty, oily, greasy, fleecy.

title: BBC Causes Uproar by Reporting Queens Opinion
description: LONDON  Succumbing to what appears to have been a disastrous urge to brag about his super-important connections, a BBC correspondent unexpectedly declared in a radio interview on Tuesday that Queen Elizabeth II had once told him she was pretty upset about the presence of a radical Islamist cleric in North London.

title: Romney and the Rights Divisions
description: In his influential daily e-mail The Transom, which was excerpted yesterday on RealClearPolitics, Ben Domenech took note of the disagreements that have opened up between conservative pundits amid Romneys post-convention difficulties:

title: Anthony Vaccarello: Spring 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: Manhattans Power Breakfast Finds a New Temporary Home
description: Will the creatures of habit who frequent the power-breakfast scene at the Loews Regency Hotel adapt to a restaurant that changes not just its menu but also its dcor every three months?

title: Paul Taylor to Receive Bessie Lifetime Achievement Award
description: The choreographer Paul Taylor will receive a lifetime achievement Bessie, the nickname for the New York Dance and Performance Awards, Dance/NYC, which helps produce the award ceremony, said on Tuesday. Alice Teirstein, the founding director of the Young Dancemakers Company and a longtime faculty member at the Fieldston School, will be honored for service to the dance field. The ceremony will be held on Oct. 15 at the Apollo Theater, hosted by Elizabeth Streb and featuring performances by the Trisha Brown Company and Souleymane Badolo. Presenters include Marina Abramovic, Ron Brown, Brenda Bufalino, Archie Burnett, Bebe Neuwirth, Charles Reinhart, David Thomson, and Wendy Whelan.

title: Why the Health Care Tax Credit Eludes Many Small Businesses
description: The Agenda has now profiled three small businesses that are struggling in different ways with providing health insurance to employees. The companies are very different  they trade in very different parts of the economy, and couldnt be located much further apartgeographically  but they do have one thing in common: Though all three have fewer than 25 employees, not one has qualified for the tax credit in the Affordable Care Act that was intended to help small businesses pay for health insurance. Indeed, the credit is one element of the controversial health law that has already fallen short of expectations.

title: Science Times Podcast
description: A fungus thats killing bats, prescribing antipsychotic drugs, and an artist whose chosen subjects include dark matter  and other mysteries of the universe.

title: LElisir dAmore
description: Images of the opera starring Anna Netrebko.

title: Eighth Grader Says He Broke Congressmans Office Windows
description: Updated, 5:13 p.m. |The vandal who smashed windows over the weekend at Representative Michael G. Grimms campaign office on Staten Island has come forward, and he is not even old enough to vote.

title: La Vida Latina: Celebrating Hispanic Heritage Month With The New York Times
description: Updated: Sept. 18, 2014

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 25
description: A view of the day in sports, with Maria Sharapova winning in Tokyo and celebrities at a pre-Ryder Cup event.

title: A Tax Shelter Mitt Romney Could Love
description: Gov. Mitt Romneys 2011 tax return highlights the use of a questionable tax planning technique that may have avoided Medicare tax liability on up to $2 million of services income derived from his past employment at Bain Capital.

title: State of the Race: How the Cards Haunt the Brewers
description: For the Milwaukee Brewers and their fans, the 2012 season started under a cloud and remained that way pretty much until September, when that cloud parted and a magical run began. Could the Brewers be this years Team of Destiny? Could they be the St. Louis Cardinals of last season? As the wins piled up, it seemed inevitable. Ryan Braun is still the league most valuable player, the bullpen remembered how to pitch, the Pirates remembered they are the Pirates. Playoffs, here we come.

title: Spikes or Soles, Its a Mans World
description: THERE is no choice but to address the spikes head on, sharp as they may be.

title: Is the Sequester Working?
description: The sequester, the widely reviled law requiring indiscriminate spending cuts starting in January, may actually be working as intended: As a spur to action.

title: Bipartisan Agreement: Bring Back N.F.L. Officials
description: Few events transcend politics, especially in a campaign year. The National Football Leagues lockout of its game officials appears to be one of them.

title: TimesCast Politics: A Focus on Foreign Policy in New York Speeches
description: Damon Winter/The New York Times

title: Enjoying the Heat in Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn Botanic Gardens celebration of chiles marks its 20th anniversary this year with more peppers than ever. Dozens of varieties are being cultivated in the herb garden, which visitors can tour as part of the fiesta on Saturday. A farmstand will sell the chiles, from the mild aji to the impossibly hot bhut jolokia, or ghost pepper.

title: As Scandal Grows, Party of Berlusconi Cleans House
description: ROME  The conservative party of Italys former prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, announced a series of housecleaning measures on Tuesday following a financing scandal that prompted the resignation of the partys representative in the important Lazio region on Monday.

title: Oysters Party Like Its the 40s
description: Rifko Meier, a Dutch art dealer and entrepreneur, created the Oyster Girls, a clever idea for parties that met with some success in his native Amsterdam. Now hes brought them to New York. In place of a stationary raw bar, servers with buckets of oysters on ice hung around their waists circulate in the crowd and open shellfish on the spot for guests. They are also equipped with little containers of various sauces and a pail for shells. Each server can handle 100 oysters, Mr. Meier said.

title: Bookshelf
description: The Phaidon Archive of Graphic Design (Phaidon, $235) is the commercial art canon embodied: 500 topic sheets on everything from a 700-year-old Buddhist text to the album art of Becks The Information. Thanks for the View, Mr. Mies (Metropolis Books, $30) explores how Modernist architecture improves lives in the Lafayette Park section of Detroit, which has the worlds largest concentration of Mies van der Rohe buildings. (Its also one of the most racially integrated neighborhoods in what might well be Americas most segregated city.) Peter Trachtenbergs memoir Another Insane Devotion (Da Capo, $24)  about love, sex, marriage and especially cats  is a hallmark of brainy discursiveness, set into motion when the author loses Biscuit, a wan cat whose sniffles sound like a whisk broom briskly sweeping.

title: Protesters Take to Street in Madrid
description: MADRID  The pressures facing the government of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy mounted on several fronts on Tuesday, as thousands of demonstrators besieged Parliament and Spains two largest regions took steps that underscored their deepening economic troubles and displeasure with his austerity plans.

title: Taking Processing Out of Take-Away
description: Hu Kitchen, near Union Square, is proof of how far quick take-away food has come. The name sounds Asian, but Hu stands for human, and the philosophy is to serve food, most of it prepared on the premises, that puts a minimum on processed ingredients.

title: Ericssons Chief on Surviving Disruption
description: Business Day Live: Hans Vestberg, chief executive of Ericsson, discusses the fast-changing communications industry.

title: Japanese Look for Alternatives to Apples Maps
description: 5:01 p.m. | Updated Adding comment by Googles chairman in Tokyo and news about open-sourced maps in Japan.

title: Bleecker Street Station, 1:10 P.M.
RIM Shows Off New BlackBerry 10 Phones, but Gives No Firm Release Date
description: OTTAWA  Research in Motion said on Tuesday that its coming line of BlackBerry 10 phones would include the companys popular BlackBerry Messenger service, a feature still absent on its tablet computers.

title: Pakistani Papers Banned by Afghanistan in East
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In the often ill-tempered war of words between Afghanistan and Pakistan, the Afghans have just taken a new tack: outlawing Pakistani words.

title: Juan Luis Guerra Tops List of Latin Grammy Nominations
description: The veteran Dominican singer-songwriter Juan Luis Guerra leads the list of contenders for this years edition of the Latin Grammy Awards, picking up six nominations on Tuesday. In the song of the year category, Mr. Guerra even ended up competing against himself, with two of his compositions vying for that honor. The Mexican brother-sister pop duo Jesse & Joy followed with five Latin Grammy nominations, while the Colombian rocker Juanes, Guatemalas Ricardo Arjona and the Brazilians Caetano Veloso and Ivete Sangalo were among the artists getting four.

title: President Obama Addresses U.N.
description: Barack Obama spoke about Iran,the wave of new protests around the Arab world and the recent attacks on American Embassies.

title: Dumb Baseball Injury Chronicles: Dry Eyeballs?
description: If caffeine addiction were a major sin, a lot of us would be in big trouble. So, it would seem a bit hypocritical to snicker at the Rangers Josh Hamilton for revealing that caffeine was at the root of his recent five-game sick leave. On the other hand, not many of us ingest enough caffeine to dry out our eyeballs and give us blurry vision  something rather critical to a baseball player  so all ridicule seems to be fair game.

title: Candidates Address Class Size and Teachers Unions at Education Forum
description: Though education has not been a major focus in the presidential campaign, the charged issue of class size was injected into the race on Tuesday as Mitt Romney said that while governor of Massachusetts, he was able to do more with less during an economic downturn.

title: Behind a Restaurant Emergency, a Troubleshooter
description: ON a hot and humid Thursday, Brian Follander found himself in a familiar position, sprawled on a restaurant kitchen floor, staring into the nether regions of a stove that would not light.

title: Past Forward: The Fight Over Fracking
description: With a skeptical eye fixed on industry in an era of rapid technological development two generations ago, Rachel Carson made a powerful case for the idea that if humankind poisoned nature, nature would in turn poison humankind, as Eliza Griswold put it in last weekends magazine, marking the 50th anniversary of the publication of Carsonsseminal book, Silent Spring.

title: Sea Calls, but So Does Love
description: The warmhearted play Marius is a bit short on plot, but this revival, by the Storm Theater Company, doesnt want for talent. Here, affection takes precedence over action, and the shows deepest pleasures are reserved for those with patience.

title: A Musical in Celebration of Saving Face in China, That Booming New Market
description: Over the centuries China has given the world many treasures: Confucianism, pandas, table tennis, a superhumanly synchronized Olympics opening ceremony, pretty much everything ever sold at Walmart.

title: Which Presidential Candidate Is Better for College Applicants?
description: If youre a college-bound student who has been (loosely) following the 2012 presidential campaign, this is an excellent time to tune in (and catch up).

title: The Biggest Controversy, but Far From the First
description: The first three weeks of the N.F.L. season have been defined not by gripping games or outstanding performances, but by the performance of the leagues replacement officials, who many say are turning the sport into a mockery. No calls brought more attention and embarrassment than the ones in the debacle Monday night in Seattle, where the officials awarded the Seahawks a game-winning touchdown as time ran out against Green Bay, despite Golden Tates interfering with a Packers defender and then another Packers defender seeming to have initial possession of the ball. But there are plenty of others that have prompted a head scratch  or seven. Here are five that stand out.

title: In Paris, Restos for Fashions Restless
description: Coffee is having something of a fashionable moment in Paris, a city long derided for its substandard roasts. And at the vanguard of the bean revolution are David Flynn and Nicolas Clerc of the hot new cafe Tlescope, which proved an instant hit when it opened behind the Palais Royals illustrious arcades in April. Clerc, a Parisian photographer, and Flynn, the American co-founder of the monthly barista throwdown Frog Fight, also happen to be very attuned to the citys evolving culinary scene. Theyre as discerning about the food they eat as the coffee they brew and drink.

title: Qaeda Operatives Killed in Drone Strike, Official Says
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  An Al Qaeda operative of Turkish origin and an Iraqi reported to be a liaison between Al Qaeda and the Taliban were among five people killed on Monday in a United States drone strike in Pakistans lawless North Waziristan region, a Pakistani security official confirmed Tuesday.

title: TV Trends That Deserve the Unwelcome Mat
description: Many of televisions worst infestations  newscasters with hairpieces; reality shows with Extreme in the title; commercials featuring talking lizards, cats or infants  began quietly. Early attention or government action might have stopped them, but then ubiquity set in, and suddenly they were a fact of life.

title: MaryAnne Gilmartin
description: Ms. Gilmartin, 48, is executive vice president for commercial and residential development at Forest City Ratner Companies, which was a development partner of The New York Timess headquarters. Its Barclays Center arena, part of the Atlantic Yards development in Brooklyn, is to open this week.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bulgaria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Bulgaria, Afghanistan, Syria and Bolivia.

title: At a Desert Party, Everything Happens
description: Its a thin line, Chrissie Hynde sang, between love and hate. Reading Lawrence Osbornes new novel, The Forgiven, you may sometimes feel that you are straddling that line in a vertiginous way, like Philippe Petit walking a high wire between the World Trade Center towers.

title: Obama and Romney Talk Foreign Policy
description: Today was foreign policy day on the campaign trail, as President Obama addressed both the United Nations General Assembly and the Clinton Global Initiative, and Mitt Romney addressed the latter group. And what a day it was not.

title: With a Push From Google, California Legalizes Driverless Cars
description: California drivers could soon see cars on the road driving themselves, courtesy of Google and the state government.

title: Vitality Reborn, New Orleans Draws Developers
description: It has been seven years since Hurricane Katrina brought New Orleans to its knees and a month since Isaac threatened to push the city down again.

title: Rascals to Reunite for Three Shows
description: Steven Van Zandt has been trying to persuade his musical heroes the Rascals  the influential white soul group known for hits like Good Lovin  and Groovin   to reunite since the early 1980s. But the four original members, who started the band as the Young Rascals in New Jersey in 1965, agreed to perform together only once since  at a private benefit concert in 2010.

title: Dear Seth, Youre a (Fill in Here)
description: Do either of these Zagat-style summaries remind you of a certain travel writer you know?

title: Cathy Horyns Milan Report
description: Cathy Horyn reflects on spring 2013 collections, including Jil Sander, Prada and Giorgio Armani.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Benefits

title: Grooving to the Beat and Bang of the Subway
description: What is it about a subway ride that ignites a choreographers imagination? In recent years the subway-inspired dance has become as frequent as the L train at rush hour. Remember Camille A. Browns energetic yet contrived Groove to Nobodys Business for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater? Just about every retelling of what its like to experience the New York City subway proves that while theres a lot to see  stations bustle with constant activity  there really isnt much to say.

title: Apples Competitors Pile On With Map Critiques
description: Eric E. Schmidt, Googles chairman, told reporters in Tokyo on Tuesday that the company had done nothing to get its maps back onto the iPhone since Apple removed them in its new iOS 6 operating systemfor mobile devices.He said Apple should have stuck with Googles maps, but, according to Bloomberg, he declined to say whether the company had submitted a new maps app to Apples App Store.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Estonia Gets Highest Marks for Internet Freedom
description: Whats up with Estonia? The tiny Baltic nation affords its citizens the greatest measure of digital freedom as measured by Freedom House, a Washington advocacy group.

title: Music in Review
description: KIMIKO ISHIZAKA

title: A Veteran of Judson Dance Recalls Its Wild 1960s Heyday
description: Naked men and women gamboling through water and grass; nearly naked people taking pleasure in one another, lolling on the floor in raw chicken and fish. Ah, the 60s.

title: Radio-Tagged Socks for the Obsessive
description: How do you know when you have slipped from detail-oriented, past anal-retentive, all the way to obsessive-compulsive?

title: Efterklang, Tonight at the Apple Store in SoHo
description: I had the great fortune this weekend of seeing the Danish band Efterklang perform at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The band (whose name means reverberation or something close to it in Danish) performed with an orchestra, backup singers and a horn section. To reach the theater where the concert was held, you had to meander through the Egyptian exhibit: past ornate sarcophaguses and hieroglyphic friezes. Id never been to any kind of presentation in a museum, particularly on a Saturday night. I kind of half-expected some crank in the audience (all seated reverently) to rise and declaim his apocalyptic visions, as in The DaVinci Code or 12 Monkeys. That didnt happen, quite. But for an encore, the singer, Caspar Clausen, exhorted the crowd to stand and groove for at least a few minutes. The crowd obliged.

title: Q&A: Combining Two Facebook Pages
description: Q.

title: Pop-Punk Bands, Now Grown Up
description: The iHeartRadio festival is a hootenanny where the biggest acts in every genre convene for a two-day affair presented by Clear Channel, the gargantuan radio conglomerate, in support of its streaming radio application. As concerts or festivals go, its not punk.

title: Insouciant Elegance and Nonchalant Fireworks, Fueled by Ballet Power
description: LONDON  The San Francisco Ballet season at Sadlers Wells in London, which ended on Sunday, was an impressive, and tactical, display of ballet power. The company arrived with three programs and 10 ballets for its weeklong run no small feat on the artistic or financial front. With the exception of Balanchines 1956 Divertimento No. 15, all the dances were created during the past four years. The companys commitment to new choreography was clear; its technical aplomb and stylistic versatility shiningly apparent.

title: Vivid Dispatches From Syrias Front Lines
description: Eighteen months have passed since an adviser to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria scolded a BBC correspondent in Damascus for reporting that video posted on YouTube by activists appeared to contradict official accounts of a crackdown on protesters broadcast on state-run television. The events are happening in Syria, Bouthaina Shaaban insisted, one week into the uprising, therefore, its Syrian television who tells the truth, nobody else.

title: A Coastal Tax Fight
description: The Timess Kim Severson travels to Sapelo Island to visit Hog Hammock, population 50. The Gullah-Geechee residents have lived there since slavery, but may have to sell off their land over taxes.

title: Taxes Threaten an Island Culture in Georgia
description: SAPELO ISLAND, Ga.  Once the huge property tax bills started coming, telephones started ringing. It did not take long for the 50 or so people who live on this largely undeveloped barrier island to realize that life was about to get worse.

title: Sarah Silverman Talks About Voter ID Ad
description: In a follow-up to her Great Schlep video from the last presidential election, Sarah Silverman decided to take on new voter identification laws that could prevent some people from voting this time around.

title: MoMA Plans to Be Open Every Day
description: Two weeks after the Metropolitan Museum of Art said it was considering staying open seven days a week, the Museum of Modern Art announced that starting in May it would be open every day, including Tuesday, the one day it has traditionally been closed.

title: In the Studio | Anthony Vaccarello
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Santanders Mexican Unit Sells U.S. Shares at $12.18 in Dual Listing
description: The Mexican arm of Banco Santander priced the American portion of its initial public offering at $12.18 on Tuesday, within its expected price range, according to a person briefed on the matter who declined to be identified.

title: A Place of Desperation, Where Both Patients and Patience Are Tested
description: The crowded emergency room of Highland Hospital in Oakland, Calif., is the setting of Peter Nickss wrenching documentary The Waiting Room. Shot in 2010 over five months, the film, which has no narrator, titles, statistical analysis or overt editorializing, observes a composite day there during which nearly 250 patients  most of them uninsured  pour in.

title: Parking Rules: Yom Kippur
description: Because of Yom Kippur, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Wednesday in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Folk Stories From Many Lands, Conjured With a Colorful Spin
description: The French animator Michel Ocelot specializes in giving folk tales his own spin, and he does so in Tales of the Night, his latest modest, charming offering. A framing device involves a man considered too old for filmmaking and a pair of teenagers too young. In an abandoned theater they conjure stories, each from a different culture and ending with a twist.

title: Whats Wrong With Blasphemy?
description: Suppose there had not been a single riot in response to the now infamous video The Innocence of Muslims, Not a single car burned, not a single embassy breached, not a single human being physically hurt. Would the makers of this risible little clip have done anything wrong? If so, to whom, and why?

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Hacking Public Transit, and Twitter Rethinking Follower Counts
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently.See more here.

title: Student Accused of Invasion of Privacy at Princeton
description: A Princeton University student has been charged with invasion of privacy after a fellow student accused him of taking sexually explicit photographs of him while he slept.

title: In Romney-Obama Redistribution Debate, a Gray Area
description: Mitt Romney may be right about President Obamas Robin Hood tendencies. Future historians could well conclude that Mr. Obama led the biggest redistribution of wealth in decades.

title: The Roses Are a Draw. (So Is the Dress Code.)
description: MALMESBURY, England  Sunday was the last clothing-optional day of the season at Abbey House Gardens in this ancient Wiltshire village, and a cold and torrential rain had confounded many visitors clothes-free plans.

title: Gardner Returns for Pinch-Running Duty
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Brett Gardner still has not taken batting practice on the field, and he might not be ready to hit in a game until next week. But the Yankees need Gardners legs more than his bat, and his legs are fine.

title: Maurice H. Keen Dies at 78; Redefined Chivalry
description: Honorable men, as they were called in the golden age of chivalry, were rich enough to outfit a squadron of knights and brutal enough to lead them into battle, often culminating in the killing and plundering of civilian populations. The code of chivalry defined honor in ways that are familiar to people today  as honesty, loyalty, courage  and in ways that are not. It was honorable, for example, to show mercy to a defeated enemy, but only if the enemy was a social equal.

title: The Geechees of Sapelo Island
description: Sapelo Island, a tangle of salt marsh and sand reachable only by boat, holds the largest community of people who identify themselves as saltwater Geechees.

title: Board Votes for Bigger Type on City Ballots
description: Barack Obama and Mitt Romney may soon loom a little larger in the eyes of New York City voters.

title: Dr. Griffith Edwards, Addiction Specialist, Dies at 83
description: Dr. Griffith Edwards, a psychiatrist who helped establish addiction medicine as a science, formulating definitions of drug and alcohol dependence that are used worldwide to diagnose and treat substance abuse, died on Sept. 13 in a hospice near his home in Greenwich, England. He was 83.

title: Out of the Pool, Phelps Finds the Water at Medinah
description: MEDINAH, Ill.  Michael Phelpss wedge shot was a little thin, but it got airborne, giving rise to abundant applause from the fans in the grandstand behind the Medinah Country Club practice range. Phelps, the 22-time Olympic swimming medalist, felt like a fish out of water Tuesday when he swung his clubs alongside golfers who formed a major titleholders row.

title: Tolerance, Up in Flames
description: Washington

title: Zebra-nomics
description: Oh, the horror: on the greatest national stage we have, in the last second of a close game, a bunch of replacement referees from the Lingerie Football League and other far outposts of the sport took a game away from the rightful winners.

title: Anticipating Fallout From Lobbyists Legal Cooperation
description: ALBANY  The halls of the New York State Capitol have for years provided a happy hunting ground for prosecutors and ethics investigators.

title: Russia: 2 Police Officers Found Guilty in Police Brutality Case in Kazan
description: A regional court handed down the first guilty verdicts on Tuesday in a police brutality case that exposed the systematic torture of suspects in a police department in Kazan, the capital of the Tatarstan Republic. A judge said two officers, Ilshat Garifullin and Ramil Nigshatzyanov, illegally arrested Sergei Nazarov of Kazan, accused of stealing a cellphone. Mr. Nazarov later died. Four other officers are accused of sodomizing him with a Champagne bottle in an interrogation. Mr. Garifullin was sentenced to two and a half years in prison, and Mr. Nigshatzyanov to two years. The four officers charged in the assault have yet to stand trial.

title: Executive Change at Yahoo Suggests Thirst for Acquisitions
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As Yahoos newly installed chief executive, Marissa Mayer has given employees free cafeteria food, replaced their BlackBerry phones with iPhone and Android smartphones and closed a long-awaited deal with Alibaba that gives Yahoo $625 million.

title: New Girl Watch: A Season Premiere and a Balancing Act
description: A lot of sitcoms these days involve characters struggling against economic, romantic or psychological limitations, but no comedy goes straight for the heart of melancholy quite like New Girl, which returned for its second season on Fox with two episodes Tuesday night. Focusing on a group of roommates caught halfway between Judd Apatow-style immaturity and full-fledged adulthood, its an ode to vulnerability and confusion, a celebration of inappropriate choices and the fine art of tiptoeing around your friends feelings.

title: Obama at the Clinton Global Initiative
description: President Obama spoke at the annual meeting of the Clinton Global Initiative.

title: Romney at the Clinton Global Initiative
description: Mitt Romney spoke at the Clinton Global Initiative in New York.

title: Stuyvesant Students Describe the How and the Why of Cheating
description: The night before one of the 5 to 10 times he has cheated on a test, a senior at Stuyvesant High School said, he copied a table of chemical reactions onto a scrap of paper he would peek at in his chemistry exam. He had decided that memorizing the table was a waste of time  time he could spend completing other assignments or catching up on sleep.

title: As Libya Presses Some Militias to Disband, Fighters Attack a Hotel in Tripoli
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  Libyan militia fighters assaulted a hotel in Tripoli housing members of the newly elected General National Congress on Tuesday, dramatizing the challenge the government faces in enforcing its ultimatum that all unauthorized brigades must submit to its authority or disband by the start of the day.

title: NBC Unpacks Trove of Data From Olympics
description: ONE afternoon in early August, a 41-year-old working mother in Los Angeles didnt get much work done.

title: Sizing Up a Crown That Is Rarely Worn
description: DETROIT  A bronze plaque outside a players entrance to Comerica Park honors Ty Cobb as the greatest Tiger of all, a so-called genius in spikes. Among Cobbs achievements was the triple crown, which he won in 1909 by leading the American League with a .377 batting average, 107 runs batted in and 9  yes, 9  home runs.

title: The Internet: Puppet Theater for a New Age
description: Sometimes, theres nothing like a friend to stick up for you. Even an imaginary friend.

title: N.F.L. Chief Caught Between Bad Calls and Owners Hard Line
description: When Roger Goodell became the commissioner of the National Football League in 2006, he made protecting certain aspects of the sports good name his consuming aim. He was concerned with the fan experience at stadiums as well as the behavior of players in bars. Goodell wanted a league populated by upstanding citizens who provided captivating entertainment while, not incidentally, generating great business, too.

title: Boy Scouts Assert Good Faith Effort to Protect Youths
description: The Boy Scouts of America, facing what could be an avalanche of unfavorable attention in coming weeks from the court-ordered release of internal files about inappropriate sexual behavior by youth leaders, issued a report on Tuesday by a professor who reviewed the files and found what she called a good faith effort to protect boys from harm.

title: Former Programmer Demands That Goldman Cover His Legal Fees
description: A former Goldman Sachs programmer charged a second time with stealing valuable computer code from the investment bank is fighting back, demanding that his former employer cover his mounting legal fees.

title: An Electric Carmaker Struggles as Its Production Lags
description: As Tesla Motors, a maker of electric cars, burns through cash and misses production targets, it is turning to investors and taxpayers for extra financial help.

title: Amateur Hour in Pro Football
description: Does Roger Goodell really want his legacy as commissioner of the National Football League to be that he allowed a hugely popular and profitable sport to become a laughingstock? Obviously not. Then why isnt he orchestrating a rapid settlement in the dispute between team owners and the leagues regular referees over paychecks and pensions?

title: Backlash to the Backlash
description: One of the iron laws of Middle East politics for the last half-century has been that extremists go all the way and moderates tend to just go away. That is what made the march in Benghazi, Libya, so unusual last Friday. This time, the moderates did not just go away. They got together and stormed the headquarters of the Islamist militia Ansar al-Sharia, whose members are suspected of carrying out the attack on the U.S. Consulate in Benghazi that resulted in the death of four Americans, including Ambassador Chris Stevens.

title: More Children in Homeless Shelters
description: Almost 20,000 children now go to bed every night in New York Citys homeless shelters, up from 16,000 last year. If homelessness is hard on adults, for the young, it can be disastrous, starting a slide into a lifetime of problems. Mayor Michael Bloomberg and Gov. Andrew Cuomo could reduce these numbers by restarting programs that help homeless families move from shelters to permanent rental housing.

title: In Massachusetts, Brown Attacks Warrens Character
description: BOSTON  Video emerged on Tuesday showing supporters of Senator Scott P. Brown making tomahawk gestures with their arms and yelling Indian war whoops at supporters of Elizabeth Warren, his Democratic challenger, outside a pub on Saturday. The gestures were meant to mock Ms. Warrens assertions, for which she has offered no documentation, that she has Native American ancestry.

title: Abuse of Electronic Health Records
description: The Obama administration has issued a strong and much-needed warning to hospitals and doctors about the fraudulent use of electronic medical records to illegally inflate their billings to Medicare. Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. and the health and human services secretary, Kathleen Sebelius, cited troubling indications that some providers are billing for services never provided and vowed to prosecute. They sent a letter to five major hospital trade associations on Monday, two days after an article in The Times described in detail how greater use of electronic records might be making it easier for hospitals and doctors to submit erroneous payment claims.

title: Comparing the Deficit Proposals
description: President Obama and Mitt Romney have very different approaches to deficit reduction. Figures below are drawn from similar base lines reflecting realistic fiscal situations, as generally agreed to by research organizations and the Congressional Budget Office.

title: Prosecutor Deals Blow to Stop-and-Frisk Tactic
description: In a significant blow to New York Citys use of stop-and-frisk tactics, the Bronx district attorneys office is no longer prosecuting people who were stopped at public housing projects and arrested for trespassing, unless the arresting officer is interviewed to ensure that the arrest was warranted.

title: A G.O.P. Reunion, With Plans for More Togetherness
description: VANDALIA, Ohio  For the first time in almost a month, Mitt Romney reunited on Tuesday with the man who many Republicans thought would charge up the presidential campaign: Representative Paul D. Ryan, the charismatic PowerPoint-wielder who can draw thousands to rallies that are really mostly giant question-and-answer sessions where they can ask Paul, in effect, how to save the party, and the country.

title: President Obama at the U.N.
description: The anti-American violence in the Muslim world demanded a firm push back from President Obama, who finally delivered it on Tuesday in the last United Nations General Assembly speech of his term.

title: Justices Uphold Map for West Virginia Voting
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday ruled that small population variations among a states Congressional districts do not run afoul of the principle of one person, one vote, even though advances in computer mapping technology have made it possible to achieve near-perfect equality in representation.

title: Relic of an Era, Revitalized
description: CHICAGO  Once a dormant area of empty warehouses, the River North section of Chicago has evolved into a nexus of dining, night life and, most recently, an aspiring rival to Silicon Valley. Its 45 square blocks are home to the headquarters of Groupon, the Chicago offices of Google and several hundred technology start-ups.

title: Replacements Face New Scrutiny
description: SEATTLE  The latest, most egregious, least debated replacement referee fiasco prompted dozens of e-mails and thousands of comments in its aftermath. The N.F.L. felt compelled to release a statement in which it included excerpts from its rulebook. Even President Obama weighed in.

title: New Limits Considered in Airwaves
description: WASHINGTON  From East Hampton to Malibu, the only limit on how much beachfront property one can own is usually however much one can afford.

title: One Coalition Stays True to Todd Akin: Home-Schoolers
description: HARRISONVILLE, Mo.  On a recent Wednesday, when many teenagers here were doing homework or playing after-school sports, 17-year-old Ania Bishop, in an ankle-length skirt with American flags, was cheering at a political rally for Representative Todd Akin.

title: Deportation Deferrals Put Employers of Immigrants in a Bind
description: Manuel Cunha has been fighting for three decades to persuade the federal government to provide more legal immigrant workers for farmers in Californias verdant San Joaquin Valley. So he was initially excited when President Obama announced in June that he would suspend the deportations of hundreds of thousands of young illegal immigrants.

title: Thriving in School
description: To the Editor:

title: Test for Obama as Deficit Stays Over $1 Trillion
description: WASHINGTON  Four years ago, Barack Obama campaigned for president on a promise to cut annual federal budget deficits in half by the end of his term. Then came financial calamity, $1.4 trillion in stimulus measures and a maddeningly slow economic recovery.

title: Lottery Numbers
Teenager Joins Bullpen in Orioles Playoff Push
description: BALTIMORE  Jim Thome, the Orioles 42-year-old designated hitter, has slugged 611 home runs. The creases around his eyes date him, like rings around a tree trunk, and he has earned the right, after 22 seasons, to arrive at the ballpark later than most teammates.

title: To Save a Life: A Call for More Kidney Donors
description: To the Editor:

title: In Need of Help, and Grateful for It
description: To the Editor:

title: Fathers Bribery Case Hangs Over Daughters House Bid
description: Grace Meng, a New York assemblywoman campaigning for a seat in Congress, stood in front of the steps of City Hall last month to accept the endorsement of former Mayor Edward I. Koch. She was flanked by nine supporters, each holding aloft a red, white and blue sign that read Grace.

title: Is Alzheimers Type 3 Diabetes?
description: Just in case you need another reason to cut back on junk food, it now turns out that Alzheimers could well be a form of diet-induced diabetes. Thats the bad news. The good news is that laying off soda, doughnuts, processed meats and fries could allow you to keep your mind intact until your body fails you.

title: Why Not Debtors Prison?
description: So it has come to this:

title: California: Brown Signs Bills to Keep Parks Open
description: Gov. Jerry Brown signed several bills on Tuesday that will keep California parks open for the next two years and will provide greater oversight of the embattled state park system. Officials discovered this year that parks employees had hidden $54 million, even as 70 parks faced closings because of budget cuts. The bills signed on Tuesday would institute a two-year moratorium on park closings and provide $30 million to finance maintenance and parks at risk of closure, in addition to $10 million to match private donations made this year to keep parks open.

title: Do Drone Attacks Do More Harm Than Good?
Corrections: September 26, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Nets Have Big Goals to Conquer Heat
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Brooklyns Industrial Space Retools for a New Era
description: The hulking industrial buildings that line Sunset Parks waterfront once bustled with manufacturing and military activity. Elvis Presley deployed to Germany from the Brooklyn Army Terminal in 1958, one of three million troops to pass through the Cass Gilbert-designed building. The area was once so busy that it had its own rail line and police and fire departments.

title: The Brooklyn Army Terminal Enters a New Era
description: Occupancy rates are up at the 1919 edifice, which was once the largest military supply base in the United States.

title: House Panel Recommends New Rules on Ethics
description: WASHINGTON  Saying that public trust was at stake, a special House ethics panel on Tuesday called for new rules to prevent lawmakers and their staffs from violating conflict of interest standards, and proposed other measures to keep partisan squabbles from undermining future investigations of possible wrongdoing.

title: American Airlines Faults Its Pilots for Disruptions
description: Airlines typically try to keep flying through bankruptcy. But simmering labor tensions at American Airlines have boiled over from the negotiating room to the airports in recent weeks, disrupting operations and leaving a trail of delayed and canceled flights that the airline says is the fault of its pilots.

title: In Afghanistan, American Trainers Keep Their Armor On
description: In the field, where small teams of American advisers are now working with Afghan units, even minor misunderstandings are treated as potentially violent confrontations.

title: Training Afghan Allies, With Guard Firmly Up
description: BAD PAKH, Afghanistan  When American military advisers fly into Afghan Army outposts like the one nestled on the floor of this forested valley, they keep their body armor on and their weapons loaded.

title: Here We Go Again
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  This will be a short one, because I will spend tomorrow fasting and atoning for all of my puzzle transgressions and I am cranky about it. It will also be short because while Peter A. Collins is eagerly anticipating the start of FOOTBALL season, I am not a follower of football, so the theme of this puzzle was largely lost on me. Perhaps the football fans out there will pick up the discussion.

title: Tougher Penalties Sought in Russia for Drunken Driving After Accident
description: MOSCOW  Russian legislators called on Tuesday for stronger measures against drunken driving after a gruesome weekend accident in which a car crashed into a bus stop at 125 miles per hour, killing seven people, five of them teenagers with learning disabilities.

title: Despite Second-Half Slump, Wright Equals a Milestone
description: David Wright tied Ed Kranepool atop the Mets career hits list Tuesday night when he sent a single to right field during his teams 10-6 loss to the Pittsburgh Pirates at Citi Field. Kranepool, one of the original Mets, collected 1,418 hits over his 1,853-game career. Wright matched him after 1,255 games.

title: Fight for Second Wild Card in the National League
description: As the baseball season moves into its final stretch, the story lines are becoming clearer. Three National League teams  San Francisco, Cincinnati and Washington  have clinched spots in the postseason, and Atlanta joined them as a wild-card team with a win Tuesday. That left St. Louis fighting off Milwaukee and the Dodgers for the second wild-card slot.

title: Seeking Cures, Patients Enlist Mice Stand-Ins
description: BALTIMORE  Megan Sykes, a medical researcher, has a mouse with a human immune system  her own. She calls it Mini-Me.

title: Obama Without Romney
description: Imagine, for a moment, that the 2012 election really was the pure referendum that Mitt Romneys campaign strategists apparently expected it to be. Imagine that both the Republican challenger and his party were completely invisible on the campaign trail, that the press was allowed only to cover the incumbent, and that on Nov. 6 the choice was whether to vote up or down on President Obamas performance. How would the last three weeks have played out for the president?

title: Suburban Mother Pleads Guilty to Running a Brothel on the Upper East Side
description: A suburban New York mother who became a tabloid and television sensation after she was charged in February with running an Upper East Side brothel pleaded guilty on Tuesday to one count of promoting prostitution.

title: RIM Keeps on Loving You in a Video
description: In order to persuade consumers to buy its new BlackBerry 10 phones next year, Research In Motion must first convince developers to create apps for its new operating system.

title: Goodbye, Mr. Goodell
description: Richmond, Va.

title: Google Working on Maps for iPhone and iPad
description: People pining for a Google Maps app on their Apple devices will get one eventually, but likely not for another couple months or so.

title: NCIS Watch: How to Resolve a Cliffhanger
description: The perennially popular CBS drama NCIS ended last season with the ultimate cliffhanger. Practically every major character was set up to be killed off as NCIS headquarters was bombed and the venerable Ducky (David McCallum) suffered a heart attack.

title: How Exercise Can Help You Master New Skills
description: Can you improve your bodys ability to remember by making it move? That rather odd-seeming question stimulated researchers at the University of Copenhagen to undertake a reverberant new examination of just how the body creates specific muscle memories and what role, if any, exercise plays in the process.

title: Using Tech Tools at West Virginia
description: MORGANTOWN, W.Va.  Marlon LeBlanc, the head coach of the West Virginia University mens soccer team, looked up at eight framed, autographed jerseys lining his office walls. Among them are a No. 28 shirt from the Philadelphia Union right back Raymon Gaddis and a D.C. United jersey of the former defender Devon McTavish. The collection comes from W.V.U. alumni who graduated to become professional players.

title: Word of the Day | traumatic
description: traumatic \tr-ma-tik, tr-\ adjective

title: Yankees Lose Lead and Chance to Expand Edge
description: MINNEAPOLIS  With the Yankees embroiled in what at times has felt like a 22-game playoff series against the Baltimore Orioles, Joe Girardi has asked the left-handed reliever Boone Logan to pitch in 14 of those games. That has pushed Logans total appearances this season to 77, a career high, and it also qualifies as the most times Girardi has called on a pitcher in his six seasons as a manager.

title: Alderson Speaks on Davis Rumors and Future of Wright and Dickey
description: General Manager Sandy Alderson was interviewed by Gary Cohen and Ron Darling of SNY during the top of the fifth inning of the Mets game Tuesday night.

title: Barnes & Noble Tablets Aim for Niche Below iPad
description: In a series of moves meant to expand Barnes & Nobles digital offerings, the company on Tuesday introduced two new color tablets and said a video store for its Nook products would make its debut this fall.

title: A Tough Loss for Hughes
description: MINNEAPOLIS  It is tough to be diplomatic when you struck out your last batter, you still felt strong when you left the mound, and the game unraveled in front of your eyes.

title: Kashmiris, Disabled by Conflict, Battle for Compensation
