description: Around Town

title: Dress Code | Carven
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Saudi Forces Kill Two in Manhunt in Eastern Province
description: Saudi Arabias security forces killed a man who was wanted by the government in the countrys restive eastern region of Qatif on Wednesday, and also shot dead a youth who was with him.

title: Familiar Faces in Pop-Country Trios New York Debut
description: Blue Sky Riders, a sturdy pop-country trio consisting of Kenny Loggins, Gary Burr and Georgia Middleman, is the latest illustration of a continuing phenomenon in which Nashville is the late-career catch basin for singers and songwriters from both coasts. It makes sense. There never was much stylistic difference between introspective New York folkies and laid-back Southern California dudes whose close harmonies in guitar-based arrangements were marginally less rural in sound and attitude than modern country music. Homogenization was the thing.

title: A Fighting Puritan, Wielding an Arsenal Against Infidels
description: An Elizabethan English Puritan with mad sword skills named Solomon Kane sounds ludicrous, but his creator, the pulp writer Robert E. Howard (1906-36), excelled in outrageous fantasy. Best known for Conan the Barbarian, Howard described Solomon as a strange blending of Puritan and Cavalier, with a touch of the ancient philosopher, and more than a touch of the pagan. There isnt much philosophizing in the 2009 British movie Solomon Kane, which, in between the smoting and smiting, introduces a character whose name  evoking at once King Solomon and Cain  telegraphs that this is one caped crusader who brings both piety and Old Testament-style wrath.

title: Video: The Powerful N.F.L. Is Humbled
description: The N.F.L.s debacle with replacement referees proves that the league is not invincible.

title: Spare Times for Children for Sept. 28-Oct. 4
description: THE MEDIEVAL FESTIVAL

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Cable Haiku and Carbon Fiber Failures
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently.See more here.

title: The Sensational and the Political
description: In his installations the Swiss artist Thomas Hirschhorn waxes didactic on politics and philosophy, even as he bombards us with sensational imagery. But in Mr. Hirschhorns current double showing in Chelsea, at Gladstone Gallery and at the future Dia project space, those two approaches have been teased apart.

title: Some Melting-Pot Law Office: Newcomer From Next Door Brings Culture Clash
description: The title is terrible, and so is the accent, but surprisingly, the new CBS drama Made in Jersey as a whole isnt.

title: Taking a Time-Bending Leap Into a Final Season
description: Jack Bauer never had it this bad on 24.

title: Facing Pain in a Fathers Footsteps
description: In Six Million and One, the Israeli documentarian David Fishers third film in a family trilogy that includes Love Inventory (2000) and Mostar Round-Trip (2011), he and his three siblings retrace the steps of their Hungarian Jewish father, Joseph, a Holocaust survivor. Joining Mr. Fisher are his sister, Estee Fisher Heim, and his brothers, Gideon and Ronel. Their father was interned in Gusen and Gunskirchen, Austria, after a brief time at Auschwitz. While imprisoned he kept a memoir that was discovered 12 years after his death.

title: Which Language Rules to Flout. Or Flaunt?
description: Heres a chilling thought: What if our English teachers were wrong? Maybe not about everything, but about a few memorable lessons. So many millions of writers have needlessly contorted their prose to avoid ending a sentence with a preposition. So many well-intentioned editors have fought to change a historic to an historic. If it turns out that the guidelines we cling to (to which we cling?) are nonsense, maybe the texters have the right idea when they throw out the old rules and start fresh.

title: Where an Incorrect Answer Can Extinguish Everything
description: One of the enigmas of Puccinis Turandot is why anyone would seek to marry a man-hating princess with a track record of decapitating her suitors. But the unattainable beauty proves irresistible, luring dozens of admirers to their deaths.

title: Waiting to Play Golf, U.S. Team Excels at Table Tennis
description: MEDINAH, Ill.  Dont be fooled, Bubba Watson said Thursday with a twinkle in his eye.

title: A Thai Tale Wrapped in a Smoky Noir
description: The world turns literally upside down in Headshot, a dreamy, elliptical neo-noir about a cop turned killer turned something else altogether. This 180 shift in perspective occurs early in the movie, which the Thai writer and director Pen-ek Ratanaruang adapted from a novel by his compatriot Win Lyovarin. Its a contemporary if shopworn story of good and evil, decency versus corruption and one man fighting the machine when topsy-turvy and not. Mr. Pen-ek has said its also a political tale, if not transparently so for those unfamiliar with Thai history. For the uninitiated, the kick wont be the story or its meanings but rather its silky fusion of pulp fiction material and art cinema style.

title: Determined to Give a Craftsman His Due
description: The jewelry maker Gustav Manz produced thousands of works in gold, silver and platinum, operating a Manhattan workshop from around 1901 to 1944. But his name shows up hardly anywhere.

title: An Artsy Blast Before Winter
description: It should be no big secret that the Miser is a huge fan of Governors Island; more than a few recent columns have pointed readers there. But to be fair, its not the citys only culturally rich island park. Before winters bluster starts making outdoor adventures less palatable, its time to consider other, equally distinctive destinations.

title: Week 4 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
description: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy.

title: Loud, Proud and Painted
description: Mickalene Thomass brash, exuberant paintings dont care what you think of them; they are much too busy simply  or not so simply  being themselves. Their sense of independence is driven home by this artists invigorating exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum, along with the realization that the museums populist program sometimes hits the nail on the head.

title: Romney Adds Note of Inevitability to Stump Speech
description: To hear Mitt Romney tell it, a Romney administration is not a question of if, but when.

title: One Dead in Meningitis Outbreak Among Men Who Have Sex With Men
description: One man has died of meningitis and three others have fallen ill, one critically, over the last month in an outbreak of the infection among men who have sex with men, the New York City health department said on Thursday.

title: Girls Will Be Girls
description: I am in my early 30s, and was on a flight home after a brutal workweek abroad. I fell asleep quickly but was awakened by two teenage girls, who were laughing and pointing at me, as well as taking my picture and uploading it onto social media. I asked them to stop, but they didnt. So I reported them to the flight attendant, who kindly changed my seat. But the mocking began all over again when I saw them at customs, where they had gathered with several more teenagers and a teacher chaperon. Any thoughts on dealing with girls like these? Elizabeth

title: In What Universe Does This Guy Turn Into Bruce Willis?
description: Looper, an obstreperously entertaining, bullet- and attitude-ridden science-fiction pastiche, opens in a futuristic world that looks and sounds paradoxically out of the past. Set in 2044, in a dystopia with Turner Classic Movies flavor, it puts a spin on the familiar figure of the existentially troubled gun for hire while leaving a layer of dust on many of the other genre fundamentals it plays with. Some of it youve seen and heard before, intentionally so, though it adds a weird wrinkle: an attempt to transform Joseph Gordon-Levitt, his nose prosthetically bobbed and a smirk surfing his thinned upper lip, into the wisecracking Bruce Willis of the Moonlighting years.

title: A Beethoven Quartet, Better Heard Than Seen
description: The systematic dreariness of D D Dorvilliers Danza Permanente is depressing  schematic and soporific. In the first place, the ambience onstage is disagreeable. Four dancers metronomically plod their way through long routines, occasionally counting out loud. Usually they avert their eyes from one another and the audience  but sometimes they connect conspiratorially, like prisoners who are hoping the guards will not notice their escape plan. The escape, of course, came when they stopped.

title: A Festival Whose Age Is Just a Number
description: There is talk going around these days   again  about the death of movies, and the 50th New York Film Festival, which starts Friday night, might have offered an occasion for fond, gloomy retrospect. This festival was born in what is now invoked as a heroic era of local and global film culture  a feverish atmosphere perhaps best recalled by the writer Phillip Lopate in his 1998 book, Totally Tenderly Tragically  and its home at Lincoln Center frequently seems haunted by the ghosts of golden ages past. Remember the first festival in 1963, when we were dazzled and perplexed by Luis Buuels Exterminating Angel, Roman Polanskis Knife in the Water and Alain Resnaiss Muriel?

title: Boldest Color for Total Effect
description: Have any artists ever, anywhere, caught the hello-ness of spring and the farewell-ness of autumn more sweetly and sharply than the Rimpa painters of Japan? Two shimmering fall exhibitions, one at Japan Society and the other at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, argue persuasively that no, no artists ever have.

title: Always Ready With a Barb
description: IT was a typical fall Friday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with visitors massing on the steps and milling awe-struck around the Great Hall. Among them was the cultural critic Camille Paglia, a pint-size martinet in a black military-style jacket who strode purposefully through the crowds with a scowl on her face and a reporter in tow.

title: That First Play Without Dad
description: WHEN my father died, my therapist phoned, Daisy Foote recalled. And I said, Its so awful! Its the end of everything!

title: Paintings Close to Home for an Italian Renaissance Master
description: In his day Piero della Francesca was as well known a mathematician as he was an artist. But while his head for numbers may have been admirable, it was his paintings that endured. In the early 20th century American collectors like Isabella Stewart Gardner, Robert Sterling Clark and Philip Lehman bought work by this Italian Renaissance master, known simply as Piero.

title: Boy Meets Girl, Boy Finds Out Shes 118
description: The story flags, but the animation in Hotel Transylvania, a misunderstood-monsters story aimed at the Aladdin and Little Mermaid crowd, is never less than vivid. Younger children are unlikely to get all the references to monsters of yore, but if nothing else, the film will give their parents an opportunity to educate them about the Invisible Man and Quasimodo.

title: The Novelist, His Muse, and Her Japanese Gangster
description: Several things are murdered in The Yakuza and the Mermaid  a Japanese gangster, a Cole Porter song  to no clear purpose beyond the amusement of the films writer, photographer, editor and director, Chris Benker. Which is fine, but if wallowing in the creative hiccups of tortured scribblers is your moviegoing goal, there are much better options.

title: Kentucky House Candidate Unveils Graphic Attack Ad
description: A commercial that all but calls President Obama a murderer  likening him to Hitler and Ted Bundy because of his support for abortion rights  is running on television stations in Kentucky despite its graphic images and provocative religious references.

title: A Collegiate A Cappella Group Puts on a Show
description: Pitch Perfect has a pitch problem.

title: M.T.A. Amends Rules After Pro-Israel Ads Draw Controversy
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority approved new guidelines for advertisements on Thursday, prohibiting those that it reasonably foresees would imminently incite or provoke violence or other immediate breach of the peace.

title: A Grifter Mom Tries to Reform
description: Working a variety of bad accents and the wardrobe of a 1930s moll, Milla Jovovich takes a break from fighting zombies in the Resident Evil franchise to play Olive, a Ukrainian-born single mother who lives for two things: conning and her 10-year-old son, Bobby (Spencer List). When not drooling over her bratty offspring  who helps zip up her unmentionables  Olive can be found stealing indiscriminately, even fleecing a church group to finance a nonexistent ministry.

title: Why They Come Here
description: Harvest of Empire has a journalistic pedigree and a punch that comes from political advocacy. Based on a book  also Harvest of Empire  by Juan Gonzlez, a columnist for The Daily News, this documentary presents information about the history of Latino immigration to the United States.

title: Osaka Mayors Radical Message Has Broad Appeal in a Weary Japan
description: OSAKA, Japan  It took more than six decades, including nearly 20 years of economic stagnation, to persuade Japans change-averse voters to kick out the governing party long enough to move to a true two-party democracy in 2009. Now, just three years later, many voters have embraced a largely unknown new party led by a brash young leader who promises a drastic overhaul of the government.

title: British Authorities to Announce Changes in Libor Oversight
description: LONDON  British authorities are set to announce significant changes to the interest rate at the heart of a recent manipulation scandal as they aim to improve the accuracy and reliability of the benchmark.

title: Kerik Is Reluctant Witness in Perjury Trial of Brothers Who Remodeled His Home
description: When Bernard B. Kerik, the disgraced former police commissioner, testifies at the perjury trial of two brothers who prosecutors say remodeled Mr. Keriks home in exchange for his help with regulators, he will do so as a reluctant witness.

title: The Real 666 Park Avenue
description: THE title building of the new ABC series 666 Park Avenue is a fiction; the network is using shots of the Ansonia as a backdrop.

title: The Rental Alternative to Foreclosure
description: FOR homeowners who have been buffeted about by the foreclosure process, the suggestion that they willingly hand their deed to the lender and rent the home instead may only add insult to injury.

title: In Paris, Sharp Turns From the Cutting Edge
description: PARIS

title: For Medinah, the Biggest Thing Ever
description: MEDINAH, Ill.  The Medinah Country Club has long been a magnet for big events. It was the site of the United States Open in 1949, 1975 and 1990, and the site of the P.G.A. Championship in 1999 and 2006.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,106 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: A 20-Game Winner
description: Action from the Mets 6-5 victory over the Pirates, in which R. A. Dickey struck out 13 in becoming the franchises sixth pitcher to win 20 games in a season.

title: Answers From Princetons Dean of Admission
description: This week, The Choice has invited Janet Lavin Rapelye, the dean of admission at Princeton University, to stop by our virtual Guidance Office and answer your questions about college admissions. Ms. Rapelye, who received a bachelors degree from Williams College and a masters degree from Stanford University, has 30 years experience in college admissions.

title: At Balenciaga, Lots to Talk About
description: PARIS  The Balenciaga show was just over as Franois Pinault, the art patron and founder of PPR, slipped out of the backstage area, past a throng of waiting guests. A sustained roar followed as the models, still in their new ruffles and tweeds, cheered.

title: Worlds Tallest Ferris Wheel Planned for Staten Island
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Thursday that the worlds tallest Ferris wheel would rise above the Staten Island waterfront. The 625-foot-tall ride will displace the Singapore Flyer, at 541 feet the record-holder of the moment.

title: Officials Welcomed; Ravens Hang On
description: BALTIMORE  About an hour before the Baltimore Ravens kicked off to the Cleveland Browns to begin their game Thursday night, a roar circulated through the lower bowl of M&T Bank Stadium.

title: Raising Frogs for Freedom, Prison Project Opens Doors
description: LITTLEROCK, Wash.  The birdman of Alcatraz became famous. But the frogmen of Cedar Creek are still anonymous beyond the tiny cult world of amphibian science. For now, they say.

title: Gas Drilling Jitters Unsettle Catskills Sales
description: HANCOCK, N.Y.

title: Through the Yellow Hour
description: Scenes from Adam Rapps latest play.

title: The Myth of Fixing the Libor
description: Sometimes modern finance has a great need for something, and so bankers invent products that appear to fill that need. When it turns out that the invention was actually something else entirely, people are shocked.

title: Rimpa Painters
description: Images from new exhibitions at Japan Society and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Authorities Question Head of Google in Brazil Over Video
description: The authorities in Brazil questioned Googles senior executive there on Wednesday over a YouTube video that criticized a local mayoral candidate, and a court ruled that YouTube must block the video.

title: Origin of the Universe
description: Images from a new exhibition of works by Mickalene Thomas.

title: Popcorn in Hand, Mayor Rides Ferry to Staten Island
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg famously travels by helicopter and private jet, with an occasional foray into the subway. Most of the time, he is chauffeured around town behind the tinted windows of his city-issued S.U.V.

title: Prison-Crime Witness Now on the Defensive
description: A. P. Merillat has spent two decades investigating crimes in Texas prisons, and his testimony about the violence that inmates serving life sentences can inflict has helped send at least 15 murderers to death row.

title: Detroits Lead Is 2; Gonzalez Wins 21st
description: The playoff picture in the American League began to take shape Thursday, as Texas beat Oakland to add to its cushion in the West. The Angels could not make a move on the Athletics, though, losing to Seattle to leave them two games out of a wild-card spot, with Tampa Bay now also two back. Detroit increased its lead in the Central with a win over Kansas City, as the White Sox lost to the Rays. The Yankees lost, but their rival in the East, Baltimore, was off.

title: Iran Envoy Is Assaulted by Protesters Near the U.N.
description: Iranian exiles and the Iranian government can make for a combustible combination, as a spokesman for the Iranian Foreign Ministry discovered after an address by the countrys president to the United Nations during this weeks General Assembly.

title: Behind the Scenes of a Deal That Everyone Wanted Done
description: By Monday afternoon, the N.F.L. had been in 10 days of intensive negotiations with the union for its game officials.

title: A Flood of Applications, With a Trickle of Approvals
description: Justino Mora had been checking his e-mail several times a day for weeks to see if there was any word from a federal immigration agency on his application for a reprieve from deportation.

title: Administration Statements on the Attack in Benghazi
description: Statements made by officials in the Obama administration about the Sept. 11, 2012, attack on the mission in Benghazi, Libya.

title: The Arab Spring Still Blooms
description: THE violent demonstrations that have spread across the Muslim world in recent weeks have convinced many in the United States and Europe that the Arab revolutions that began in late 2010 are now over and that the democratic project has failed. Bitterness and a sense of impending catastrophe are replacing the enthusiasm that followed the toppling of dictators in Tunisia and Egypt last year.

title: Growth of Suburban D.C. Is Felt Politically in Maryland
description: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Here is a look at Maryland, the Old Line State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Donald F. Kettl, the dean of the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland; and Theodore F. Sheckels, a professor of communications and English at Randolph-Macon College in Ashland, Va.

title: When Growth Outpaces Happiness
description: Los Angeles

title: Sex and the City Creator Lists Apartment
description: THE sophisticated glass-sheathed condominium at One Central Park West exudes sensuality, and why not? Since 2005, it has been the East Coast lair of the producer Darren Star, the creator of a string of frothy television series headlined by Sex and the City, the cult classic that zeroed in on the high-wire exploits of four romance-addicted New York City career women. He also produced the film version of Sex and the City and its sequel.

title: Farewell to a Mustache Forever Linked to the Mets
description: Without his mustache, would Clark Gable have been as silkily charming when he told Scarlett OHara he frankly did not give a damn? Would Groucho Marx have delivered his one-liners with the same zing?

title: Governors Island and Its Future
description: Governors Island was, for many years, little more than a tantalizing wasteland  a 172-acre chunk of rock and mostly abandoned military structures. Politicians and urban planners dreamed of ways to turn this underused space into a compelling daytime destination for New Yorkers, but nothing really happened until the state, in 2010, ceded most of the island to New York City.

title: A Big Right Arm and a Little Man on His Shoulder
description: ATLANTA  The hottest starting pitcher in baseball is a 5-foot-10 right-hander with spiked hair, a flat-brim cap, a rebuilt elbow and a little man on his shoulder giving him all the answers.

title: The Wait for Postal Default
description: While House members are back home campaigning straight to Election Day, voters might want to alert them that the United States Postal Service is about to default on a $5.6 billion loan obligation  mainly because the House took off without allowing the service to modernize its archaic business practices.

title: Obama Fills in Blanks of Romneys Plans, and G.O.P. Sees Falsehoods
description: The Obama campaign has run advertisements charging that Mitt Romneys Medicare plan could raise seniors costs up to $6,400 a year and that his tax proposal would give millionaires another tax break and raises taxes on middle-class families by up to $2,000 a year.

title: A Duty of Health Care Workers
description: Health care workers should know better than anyone that it is important to get vaccinated against the flu virus to protect their own health and prevent the possibility of infecting patients. There were some encouraging signs in an analysis issued Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that doctors and nurses are beginning to get the message. But other health care workers  a broad group that includes clinical personnel like nurse practitioners and physician assistants and various nonprofessional aides and assistants  show remarkable indifference to performing what ought to be considered their civic duty.

title: A City Place for Country Doctors
description: FOR years, Gregory Turner wanted a second home in the city.

title: Europes Austerity Madness
description: So much for complacency. Just a few days ago, the conventional wisdom was that Europe finally had things under control. The European Central Bank, by promising to buy the bonds of troubled governments if necessary, had soothed markets. All that debtor nations had to do, the story went, was agree to more and deeper austerity  the condition for central bank loans  and all would be well.

title: The Geography of Nope
description: SALT LAKE CITY  In a part of Italy where chestnut trees are thick in the Apennine foothills, I once asked a neighbor in the little community where we lived how I might kill a wild boar. This impulse was driven by appetite, mostly  glimpses of those feral beasts on my morning runs that had me dreaming of a blood-red ragu made of local cinghiale.

title: State Is Trying to Put Brakes on High Cost of University
description: Ashton Curlee, the ambitious daughter of two teachers, received official notification of her acceptance to the new Texas Science Scholar Program at the University of Texas of the Permian Basin on the first day of college.

title: Man Tied to Anti-Islam Video Held on Probation Charge
description: LOS ANGELES  The man thought to have been behind the crude anti-Islam video that set off deadly protests across the Muslim world in recent weeks was arrested Thursday for violating terms of his probation in a 2010 bank fraud case.

title: The Psych Approach
description: In the 1990s, Vincent Felitti and Robert Anda conducted a study on adverse childhood experiences. They asked 17,000 mostly white, mostly upscale patients enrolled in a Kaiser H.M.O. to describe whether they had experienced any of 10 categories of childhood trauma. They asked them if they had been abused, if their parents had divorced, if family members had been incarcerated or declared mentally ill. Then they gave them what came to be known as ACE scores, depending on how many of the 10 experiences they had endured.

title: One57s Billionaires, and the Dust-Ups They Cause
description: AS problems go, this is a pretty good one to have.

title: A Blurring of Golfs Battle Lines
description: MEDINAH, Ill.

title: Talking at Cross Purposes
description: The alternate universes of the Israeli and Palestinian leaders were on display Thursday at the United Nations General Assembly.

title: N.B.A. Ready to Act on Flopping
description: ELIZABETH, N.J.  After years of complaints, the N.B.A. finally appears ready to outlaw flopping  the act of exaggerating contact to induce a foul call.

title: Trial Begins in Bus Crash That Killed 15
description: When Ophadell Williams should have been resting for his night shifts, a prosecutor said on Thursday, he was instead driving around in a rented car with little sleep in the days before his tour bus crashed into a signpost stanchion in the Bronx, peeling off the roof like a sardine can and wreaking death and destruction.

title: Fearing Fiscal Cliff, Investors Cash In and Seek Safety
description: After riding a quarter-long rally fueled by central bankers in Europe and the United States, investors are taking a more defensive posture on fears that politicians could derail the momentum.

title: Rumblings of a Tomato Trade War Between the U.S. and Mexico
description: The Commerce Department took steps to end a 16-year-old agreement with Mexico that makes Mexican tomatoes a bargain in American supermarkets.

title: Ammunition for a Trade War Between U.S. and Mexico
description: Estimates are that nearly one out of two tomatoes eaten in the United States comes from Mexico  a statistic Florida growers would like to change, even at the risk of a trade war.

title: As Fail to Gain Ground In a Showdown Series
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The Oakland Athletics left here stuck in the muck after a 9-7 loss Thursday to the first-place Texas Rangers in an American League West showdown. The As split four games with the Rangers, leaving Oakland in the same position it was in when the series started  four games behind the division leader.

title: Syrian Rebels Take Their Battle to the Skies
description: In an article published in The New York Times on Thursday, C.J. Chivers (@cjchivers) wrote about the battle for Abu ad Duhur, an air base south of Aleppo, Syria. Rebels have targeted the base to keep its planes from going out on missions. Rebel forces have been trying for months  at times claiming success  to shoot down government planes and helicopters in midflight.

title: At Home, and Accused of Trespassing
description: Few things can be more galling than the takeover of public housing projects by hoodlums who use law-abiding people as camouflage for criminal activity.

title: The First Pairings Are Set
description: MEDINAH, Ill.  The first ball of the 39th Ryder Cup will be struckFriday by either Rory McIlroy or Graeme McDowell, both of Northern Ireland, whom the European captain, Jos Mara Olazbal, is sending out against the Americans Jim Furyk and Brandt Snedeker in the first pairing of foursomes at Medinah Country Club.

title: Charges of Bias in Admission Test Policy at Eight Elite Public High Schools
description: A coalition of educational and civil rights groups filed a federal complaint on Thursday saying that black and Hispanic students were disproportionately excluded from New York Citys most selective high schools because of a single-test admittance policy they say is racially discriminatory.

title: United States Economy Still Weak, but More Feel Secure
description: Both economists and the Romney campaign are puzzling over the same paradox: The recovery has flagged and yet the countrys mood appears to be improving.

title: This Wake-Up Cup Is Fair-Trade Certified
description: GREEN MOUNTAIN COFFEE has been helping consumers wake up for more than three decades, but a new advertising campaign is meant to be an eye-opener of a different sort.

title: Challenging Crossings
description: Thomas Fuller, a New York Times reporter, visits Vietnams capital to document the daily duel between motorcycles and pedestrians.

title: Why Did the Tourist Cross the Road? The Real Riddle Is How
description: HANOI, Vietnam  Tourists who check in to the Meracus Hotel, a compact and friendly establishment in the Old Quarter of Hanoi, are handed a tip sheet by the receptionist titled How to cross roads.

title: Romney and Obama in Ohio
description: Mitt Romney and President Obama held rallies in Ohio while on the campaign trail this week.

title: Veterans Wait for Benefits as Claims Pile Up
description: For Dennis Selsky, a Vietnam-era veteran with multiple sclerosis, it was lost documents. It seemed that every time he sent records to the Department of Veterans Affairs, they disappeared into the ether.

title: Neighborhood Joint: Mulhollands
description: Mulhollands bar has been a haven for Williamsburg sports fans since 2006.

title: Picking Up the Pace, but Still Falling Behind
description: The Department of Veterans Affairs has been unable to keep pace with the growing number of claims.

title: U.S. Is Tightening Web Privacy Rule to Shield Young
description: Federal regulators are about to take the biggest steps in more than a decade to protect children online.

title: Behind the Padlocks of a New York Apartment
description: Oh, for the wild and woolly Manhattan of four decades ago, when the streets were mean, and life was cheap. New Yorkers with warm memories of their city in extremis  the era of Jules Feiffers black comedy Little Murders and an age evoked fondly in recent memoirs by James Wolcott and Edmund White  may feel a rush of nostalgia during the opening scene of Through the Yellow Hour, the new B-movie-like play by Adam Rapp.

title: Fool on the Ice
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  So. Weve had a series of puzzles from the Westchester Crossword Puzzle Tournament, and now this fresh Friday from Ed Sessa. Are you feeling any SENSORY OVERLOAD yet?

title: Thanks for the Warning. Now Shut Up.
description: Every single exclamation mark stays, says the riled-up Dr. Thomas Stockmann in the new Broadway staging of An Enemy of the People, Ibsens 1882 drama about a mans lonely battle for truth against the arrayed forces of a society bent on self-protection. If in doubt, he continues, add more.

title: Corrections: September 28, 2012
description: EDITORS NOTE

title: Pinning Hopes on a Digital Fix for Veterans Claims
description: SALT LAKE CITY  One desk, clean and empty, suggested a recently retired employee. The other, piled high with brown folders wrapped in rubber bands and bristling with color-coded tabs, screamed backlog.

title: Sports Haven in the Land of Cool
description: SINCE the 1990s, the Brooklyn waterfront neighborhood of Williamsburg has served as shorthand for New York cool. And though it has gone upscale in recent years, a few things remain as fixed as the gears on its bicycles: Youll never have to wander far for a good espresso, and wearing a football jersey on Bedford Avenue will probably never be in style.

title: Ex-Worker Left I.R.S. for Job at Bank He Audited, Complaint Says
description: People who hate the Internal Revenue Service are a dime a dozen.

title: Weakened, Council Bill on Sick Days Gains Favor
description: A new, watered-down version of a City Council bill that would give workers in New York City paid sick leave is quickly gaining traction among some business groups and union leaders.

title: Lottery Numbers
Is This the Nastiest Election Ever?
description: A month after pundits declared the current presidential contest the meanest, nastiest, most poisonous, and dirtiest campaign in history, those summer laments already seem like poignant reminders of a kinder, gentler time. Thanks to recent efforts to score political points on violence in Egypt and Libya, and charges of class warfare rising on both sides, this mean and nasty season has only gotten worse.

title: Waking Up From a Dream After Weeks Full of Pinches
description: To many, they will be remembered as impostors, a band of striped, whistle-blowing charlatans who crept onto the biggest stage in sports for a few weeks of singular and unabated outrage.

title: Which Language Rules to Flout. Or Flaunt?
The G.O.P. and the Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dirty Internet: How Data Centers Waste Energy
description: To the Editor:

title: In Search of Voter Fraud
description: To the Editor:

title: In Virginia, Nominees Reach Out to Military
description: VIRGINIA BEACH  In case anyone is wondering, Virginia is up for grabs this election. So, with 39 days to go, President Obama and Mitt Romney dueled in the commonwealth on Thursday, both trying to lock up support from voters with ties to the military.

title: Yankees Division Lead Shrinks as Novas Slump Persists
description: TORONTO  Ivan Nova lofted an 87 mile-per-hour slider approximately 18 inches higher than the intended target. It came in chest-high to Edwin Encarnacion, who lashed it into the right-field corner for a two-run double that may have determined Novas fate for the rest of the season.

title: N.H.L. to Resume Labor Talks as Preseason Is Canceled
description: Formal negotiations are scheduled to resume Friday between N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman and Donald Fehr, the executive director of the N.H.L. Players Association  the first formal bargaining since Sept. 12, three days before the lockout began.

title: Syrian Rebels Announce Big Offensive in Aleppo
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Rebel fighters in the northern Syrian city of Aleppo said Thursday that they had launched a major offensive against government troops in the city, just as the United Nations and humanitarian agencies warned that the number of Syrians fleeing to neighboring countries could surge past 700,000, far exceeding earlier estimates.

title: An Enduring Ritual of Politics Loud and Close
description: WESTERVILLE, Ohio  By 7 a.m. on Wednesday, supporters hoping to catch a glimpse of Mitt Romney extended for two blocks outside Westerville South High School in this suburb of Columbus, the site of a victory rally hastily shifted from an outdoor amphitheater when the forecast called for rain.

title: At U.N., Myanmar Leader Highlights Steps to Reform
description: The president of Myanmar, a former general who has led the move away from a prolonged era of dictatorship, poverty and isolation, asserted on Thursday in his first United Nations speech that amazing changes were transforming his country and could never be reversed.

title: A Father-Daughter Dance Revives Charges of Discrimination
description: CRANSTON, R.I.  The members of the parent-teacher organization at Stadium Elementary School had no idea that the father-daughter dance they were planning last spring was, in fact, against the law.

title: Mixed Returns for Endowments
description: An uneven economic year yielded uneven results for the largest university endowments, with reports released through Thursday revealing a range of results, from a fractional loss on investments for Harvard to a healthy gain for M.I.T.

title: Channel Surfing: Scandal in an Election Year
description: This season, the critics Neil Genzlinger and Mike Hale are checking out favorite shows and seeing how they hold up. Previous entries in this series include posts on New Girl and NCIS.

title: Rover Finds Signs of Old Streambed
description: NASAs Mars rover Curiosity has spotted pieces of an old streambed where water rushed by billions of years ago, scientists reported at a news conference on Thursday. It just seemed like someone came along the surface of Mars with a jackhammer and lifted up a sidewalk that you might see in downtown L.A., said John Grotzinger, the missions project scientist. From the size of the rounded pebbles embedded in the slab, the scientists estimated that water was flowing about a yard a second and was between ankle and hip deep. NASA has found bountiful evidence of liquid water on early Mars when it might have been warmer, but this was the first observation of an ancient streambed. Curiosity is looking for carbon-based molecules which, together with liquid water, could have provided all of the necessary building blocks for life.

title: Afghanistan: Joint Missions Rise Again
description: The number of missions in which Afghan security forces work in partnership with American and allied troops is growing again, although restrictions ordered after a spate of insider attacks have not been lifted, Pentagon and military officials said Thursday. In a significant restriction on a core element of the Western exit strategy from Afghanistan, the American-led military coalition said last week that all joint operations with Afghan forces conducted below the battalion level had to first go through a formal approval process  an effort to stem attacks by members of the Afghan security forces that have killed 51 American or allied service members this year. Officials now say those approvals were being handled efficiently enough that the number of partnered operations was returning to normal. Before the order, about 90 percent of all missions were conducted jointly. The number is now climbing again, said officials, who declined to offer specifics.

title: Time to Confront Reality, Now That Theyre Elected
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Mexico: Suspected Drug Boss Captured
description: The Mexican Navy said Thursday that its marines had captured a top leader of the Zetas drug gang, Ivn Velzquez Caballero. Mr. Velzquez Caballero had been feuding with another Zeta leader, Miguel ngel Trevio Morales, a Navy spokesman said. The feud had caused a surge in violence in parts of northern Mexico. Mr. Velzquez Caballero was caught on Wednesday night in San Luis Potos, north of Mexico City. The Navy has made several high-profile arrests recently, but experts say that lieutenants quickly rise to take the place of captured crime bosses, bringing struggles that generate new violence.

title: Irving Adler, Teacher Fired in Red Scare, Dies at 99
description: Irving Adler, a former New York City teacher who became a prolific writer of books on math and science for young people after being forced from the classroom during the Red Scare of the early 1950s,died on Saturday in Bennington, Vt. He was 99.

title: The Unraveling of Government
description: Frustrated over the inability of political leaders to find common ground on even the most pressing national issues, Americans have developed a long list of people or political practices to blame for the fact that government doesnt seem to work anymore. But the real problem is something thats not high on most such lists, something thats far more crucial.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: China: Dissident Artist Rejects Fines
description: Ai Weiwei, the persecuted artist and critic of the Chinese Communist Party, said Thursday that he would not pay taxes and penalties that the government said he owed. Mr. Ai made his statement after a court in Beijing rejected his appeal of a lower courts verdict saying he would have to pay back taxes. He was detained for 81 days last year, and after his release, Beijing officials said Mr. Ai owed $2.4 million in back taxes and penalties. Mr. Ai paid a bond of $1.3 million to contest the government order. Tax officials are expected to keep the bond, which means Mr. Ai will owe $1.1 million. It was unclear what would happen if he did not pay. The government still holds Mr. Ais passport, and he has been forced to cancel overseas appearances.

title: Enrollment Drops Again in Graduate Programs
description: Enrollment in college is still climbing, but students are increasingly saying no to graduate school in the United States.

title: Australias A-League Banks on Del Piero
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Perhaps it is ordained that Australia, blessed with sun, sea and surf, could not also have the beautiful game in all its glory. For years, soccer has struggled there. A national league folded in 2004 amid bankruptcy and bad feeling, and the shiny new A-League that started a year later has yet to establish a solid foundation.

title: Inquiry Faults Racing Officials in Horse Fatalities at Aqueduct
description: More than half of the 21 racehorses who had fatal breakdowns at Aqueduct Racetrack earlier this year might have been saved had racing authorities more closely monitored their health and the liberal use of prescription drugs to keep them racing, according to an investigation ordered by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York.

description: Medtronic, a medical technology company based in Minneapolis and listed in New York, said on Thursday that it would pay $816 million in cash to acquire China Kanghui, a manufacturer of orthopedic devices based in the eastern Chinese city of Changzhou and also listed in New York.

description: NEWS Mario Monti, the economist chosen as a stopgap prime minister of Italy after the collapse of Silvio Berlusconis government last November, said that he would consider another term in office if elections scheduled for next spring do not produce a strong majority for any party coalition. Elisabetta Povoledo reports from Rome.

title: Last Somali Militant Bastion Falls, Kenya Claims

title: After London Olympics Debacle, Security Firm Shuffles Top Managers

description: Gone are the days when picketing, candlelight vigils, marches or hunger strikes were enough to guarantee your cause a spot on prime-time television in India. No matter how grave or frivolous the cause, modern protesters employ far more creative tactics to draw attention.

title: John Sununus a Teddy Bear
description: You recently described the vaguely Southern accent the president uses in speeches as phony as his jaunt when he runs up and down Marine One. What exactly is a phony jaunt?  Every time you see him climbing up or down stairs, he elevates his arms and does this pumping, trying to look like a well-trained and trim dynamic individual. Its something he does all the time, particularly when hes climbing up to a podium to speak or address a crowd. This president understands that he got elected on the basis of style and not substance, and I think hes trying to preserve style.

title: How a Diner Gets the Most Out of Social Media
description: Squeeze In is a modest little breakfast-and-lunch diner with four locations in the greater Reno, Nev. area. The restaurants are open seven days a week, 7 a.m. to 2 p.m. While online commenters rave about the food, I cant get over how creatively this little chain has managed its social media. It has a Web site and a custom mobile site. It promotes the business through Foursquare, Twitter, Facebook, Pinterest and Instagram.

title: Internal Devaluation and the Road to Wigan Pier
description: Greg Ip, in correspondence, directs me to Chapter 3 of the latest IMF World Economic Outlook, which among other things contains an analysis of a case that bears directly on the attempts of euro area countries to restore economic health through fiscal austerity and internal devaluation: Britains return to the gold standard after World War I.

title: Leopard Poaching on the Rise, Group Warns
description: When it comes to the poaching of endangered species, elephants, tigers and rhinos tend to be in the limelight. But a new report sets out to plug the information gap on a different species that is imperiled by a tide of demand related to rising affluence in Asia: leopards.

title: Ousted From Party in China, Bo Xilai Faces Prosecution

The leaders also said they had scheduled the 18th Party Congress, the climax of Chinas once-a-decade leadership transition, to start Nov. 8.

title: At the U.N., Agitation, Outrage and Business as Usual

We knew all along that they could do it, despite the overblown forecasts of impending disaster, including the menace they were instructed by television to dread most of all: traffic jams.

title: Uncomfortable Truths
description: SO PAULO  It was more than two decades ago, but I still remember the shocked look my brother and I shared when our father first told us he had done time in prison for working against Brazils military government. In disbelief, we went straight to our mother. She was surprised: I thought we were going to wait until they were older.

title: Security Fears Hobble Inquiry on Libya Attack
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  Sixteen days after the death of four Americansin an attack on a United States diplomatic mission here, fears about the near-total lack of security have kept F.B.I. agents from visiting the scene of the killings and forced them to try to piece together the complicated crime from Tripoli, more than 400 miles away.

title: Shotgun Wedding Suburban Jungle
description: Do the self-satisfactions of the middle class and its rituals somehow prove irresistible to a novelist? Is it just too tempting to consider how a big social gathering might go disastrously wrong? Consider Ayelet Waldmans Red Hook Road, in which a young couple meet a tragic end hours after taking their vows, or, in a more playful register, Ali Smiths There but for the, which sends a dinner party spinning out of control when a guest locks himself in a room and refuses to leave. Lisa Zeidners funny, chaotic new novel, Love Bomb, is pitched in tone somewhere between Waldmans and Smiths: realistic in its depiction of sympathetic characters facing a crisis, while edgy in its satire of a well-off New Jersey suburb and its sometimes hapless police force.

description: How far can a presidential marriage go in explaining a presidency?

description: Paris

title: The End of the Middle
description: There are two major flaws in The Betrayal of the American Dream, a new book about the dismantling of the middle class. The first is its diagnosis of whats causing the countrys economic troubles. The second is its prescriptions.

title: Perspective Is at Play in Who Is Better Off
description: This president cannot tell us that you are better off today than when he took office, Mitt Romney said as he accepted the Republican presidential nomination. Since then, Are you better off? has become a central theme of the campaign, and is likely to surface next week at the first presidential debate.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: New F.T.C. Rules for Children Online, and Being a Replacement Official
description: The Federal Trade Commission is expected to tighten rules soon about Web sites that collect information about children, Natasha Singer writes, greatly increasing the need to obtain parental permission for common practices like using cookies to track young users activities online, or their location via a mobile phone, or accepting photographs submitted by children under 13. The current federal rule, which dates to 1998, requires parental consent before Web sites can collect personal information like phone numbers or physical addresses from children, but those rules can appear antiquated considering how technology has changed over more than a decade.

title: Potus v. Scotus
description: The Oct. 22, 2007, cover of Time magazine displayed a portrait of Chief Justice John Roberts above the line does the supreme court still matter? As the dust rises and the opinions, concurrences and dissents pile up, the court turns its attention to ever smaller cases related to ever narrower points of law, David Von Drehle lamented in the accompanying article. The courts ideology is playing a dwindling role in the lives of Americans.

title: State of Disunion
description: The Washington Post columnist E. J. Dionne Jr. has ascended to a sufficiently elevated plane of the Higher Punditry that his authors biography no longer mentions he received a doctorate from Oxford, where he was a Rhodes scholar. Even so, he still comes across as a precocious student, bubbling with boyish charm and enthusiasm for ideas, though sometimes a bit glib and preening. His books are clever, upbeat and interesting, particularly when he examines current political concerns through the lens of history, religion and philosophy. But while readers will admire Dionnes intellectual dexterity in diagnosing the historical origins of our present political problem of division and dysfunction, they may also wish he could make a more substantive case for how we might move beyond it.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Lanvin
description: The Look: Hair Swept to the Right, Makeup From Last Night.

title: Debating the Limits of Free Speech
description: LONDON  It was one of the more curious asides of this weeks annual procession at the United Nations General Assembly of heads of states airing their differences, setting out their political stalls and maneuvering for position both internationally and before their audiences and voters at home.

title: Gay Center to Make Its Village Home More Open and Less Noisy
description: The love that now dares speak its name can still sometimes be hard to hear.

title: From the Old South to the New Right
description: When Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina died in 2003 at the age of 100, he seemed to embody the term political survivor. Think of someone who began his career as a Roosevelt Democrat and finished it as a Reagan Republican, who campaigned for president as a white supremacist and ended up supporting a national holiday for Martin Luther King. Decades passed, one generation replaced another, but Thurmond soldiered on, swapping causes, even political parties, with a jugglers eye. Where many politicians become objects of contempt or indifference over time, with Thurmond the reverse was true: the longer he lasted, the more revered he became.

title: Pro-Life, Pro-Left
description: In 1968, Mark Hatfield, one of Americas most prominent evangelical politicians, wanted to abolish the draft and clandestinely wore a Eugene McCarthy pin under his lapel. A Republican senator from Oregon, Hatfield had fans in evangelical churches around the country. When organizers of the 1973 National Prayer Breakfast invited him to address Richard Nixon, Henry Kissinger and other conservative luminaries (the Vietnam War was a national sin and disgrace, he told them), he based his remarks on a text written by a renegade seminarian named Jim Wallis  a former member of Students for a Democratic Society who believed that being pro-life meant hating war and poverty as much as abortion.

title: Save Us
description: Steve Sterns characters  Shimmele, Avi, Fagie, Morty, Mendy, Mushie  are escape artists. They want to escape doting, caviling parents, the injunctions of Mosaic law and a stifling atmosphere where sedulous study was valued above action. They want, in other words, to escape Judaism.

title: Odd Men Out
description: In the American wars of the 20th century, soldiers of the rear echelon were derided as in the rear with the gear, or worse. However, the whole concept of a rear, predicated on a definable front, started slipping in Vietnam and met its official death in Somalia. By the time of the Iraq occupation, the place where clerks did their clerking and infantrymen got a plate of hot chow was no longer in a relatively safe rear area but in the forward operating base, or FOB, smack in the middle of everything, and the soldiers stationed there became known as Fobbits.

title: Image of the Day: Sept. 28
Who Built This City?
description: Could it be that one of the most famous speeches in American history was never delivered?

title: For Marchionne and Winterkorn, a Parisian Showdown Is Averted
description: A dispute at the highest levels of the principal lobbying group for Europes automotive industry was resolved with a handshake on Friday, as Sergio Marchionne, the chief executive of Fiat and Chrysler, met with Martin Winterkorn, chief executive of Volkswagen, on the convention floor at the Paris motor show.

title: Editors Choice
description: THIS IS HOW YOU LOSE HER,  by Junot Daz. (Riverhead, $26.95.) The stories in this collection are about love, but theyre also about the undertow of family history and cultural mores, presented in Dazs exciting, irresistible and entertaining prose.

title: Paperback Row
description: ANATOMY OF A DISAPPEARANCE,  by Hisham Matar (Dial, $15.) Matars fiction revolves around his parents, and especially his father, a Libyan dissident who was kidnapped by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis agents in Cairo in 1990. In his elegiac second novel, a boy struggles with the mysterious abduction of his father, exiled from an unnamed Arab country, and with his confused, preadolescent desire for his fathers much younger second wife.

title: Book Burdening
description: I recently started reading a wonderful and compelling book about sports. Before I finished it, I bought a copy and gave it to my 14-year-old nephew. As I got further into the book, I came upon a homosexual relationship that I thought might not be appropriate for my nephew to be reading, as he was brought up in a very religious household. Im now feeling irresponsible for not having finished the book before giving him a copy. I am inclined to tell his parents my feelings, but he may have already read the book and perhaps thought nothing of it. Do I confess all? KATHRYN KORS-JACOBSON, CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.

title: The 9.16.12 Issue
description: How Not to Fire a President

title: Who Made That Trampoline?
description: In 1960, George Nissen rented a kangaroo named Victoria from an animal-supply outfit on Long Island so that he could train her to hop on a trampoline he set up in Central Park. After a week of waltzing with Victoria, clasping her front paws as he taught her to bounce in time with him, Nissen finally produced a mind-bending photograph. In it, Nissen and the kangaroo stare into each others eyes as they levitate over the trampoline. The photo was reprinted around the world and helped establish the trampoline as a global phenomenon.

title: Inside the List
description: PILOT EXPERIMENT: Michael Chabons new novel, Telegraph Avenue  its at No. 7 on the hardcover fiction list  tells the story of two families, one black and one white, in Oakland and Berkeley, Calif. Twelve years ago, when Chabons novel The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay was starting to make some noise (it went on to win a Pulitzer in 2001), newspaper profiles mentioned that the author was wrapping up another project: a television pilot called Telegraph Avenue, about a black family and a white family in Oakland and Berkeley, Calif. How did Chabon get from there to here? When I first considered the possibility of transforming the script into a novel, he said via e-mail, I went through the usual process, apparently requisite to my beginning any novel, of lying to myself about how easy it was going to be. I told myself I would just be able to novelize it. Two and a half years later, battered and discouraged and ready to quit, and ready to kill the optimistic idiot who got me into this mess, I belatedly realized my mistake. A pilot is there to set the table. To set it beautifully, and with a proper and adequate complement of utensils for the coming meal. But in terms of nourishment it only really sets out some canaps, maybe a dish of olives. A novel has to serve a full, seven-course meal with sherbet in the middle and maybe a last little passed tray of petits fours. I had to start all over again, and reconceive the entire thing.

title: On Our Radar: A Desalination Giant
description: The San Diego County Water Authority agrees to buy the entire output of what will be the Western Hemispheres largest seawater desalination plant, removing a hurdle to construction. [Associated Press]

title: Manufacturing Music
description: At Fender, rock 'n' roll tries to beat the economy. | Real estate listings languish over fracking fears in Catskills. | James B. Stewart on which Americans are better off now.

title: Longshoremens Lament
description: Automation and large machines have cut deeply into the human workforce on the waterfront, loading and unloading the millions of containers that enter the Port of New York and New Jersey.

title: On the Waterfront, Rise of the Machines
description: NEWARK  IN the rising light of a mid-September morning, the CSAV Pyrenees, a blue-water freighter sailing out of Suape Port in Brazil, was lashed to its lines at Berth 59 of the Port Newark Container Terminal. At rest beneath a looming row of gantry cranes, the ship had come to port on a half-day call to discharge a load of South American cargo: 421 containers worth, each one weighing as much as a family of elephants  or slightly more than 40,000 pounds.

title: Model-Morphosis | Elsa Sylvan at Rick Owens
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2013 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Elsa Sylvan of One Management before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Lucia Pieroni and hair by Luigi Murenu.

title: Lexus LF-CC: A Japanese Grille Opens in Paris
description: PARIS  Lexus has released the latest in its series of Grilles Gone Wild concept cars.

title: Now Thats More Like It
description: If at times the sports world seems ready to be subsumed by the forces of big business, to give us all the feeling that were being played for deep-pocketed fools, turned upside down by leagues and owners until every last coin falls into their vaults, well, Thursday was the antidote. Times two.

title: Giving Jittery Frogs a Chance to Chill
description: Frogs have a reputation, earned or not, of being skittish creatures. Their physiology would almost seem to make the case by itself. With quads like that, youd be jumpy, too, right?

title: Brooklyn Academy of Music and Nets Owners Charity Join in Three-Year Partnership
description: Creating a cultural exchange between the United States and Russia, the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the Mikhail Prokhorov Fund have announced a three-year partnership.

title: Philanthropists Weigh the Returns of Doing Good
description: ALL philanthropists want their donations to mean something, be it for a new wing for a hospital or to finance a program aimed at doing social good. Increasingly, though, philanthropists are looking for a way to measure the impact of their dollars.

title: The Bond of Blueberry Jam
description: I started making jam with my daughter, Anna, the summer she was 3 1/2. Shes now a high school senior. That summer we had discovered a small blueberry farm that sold plump, fresh blueberries by the carton during their exceedingly short growing season. We sat at a four-seat counter in a hot, tiny room adjacent to the field and enjoyed the freshest blueberry ice cream wed have in our lives, before loading the car with berries to take home for jam.

title: The Dirtiest Part of a Catchers Job
description: As Russell Martin squatted into his crouch, he calculated the risk. It came in the form of a 6-foot-1, 210-pound player named Mike Trout. Fast, solidly built and eager to make another mark in his eye-opening rookie season in the majors, Trout stood about 80 feet away, near third base.

title: Amid Guns and Blood, an Ethicist Finds Religion in Eastwoods Films
description: Although a lifelong film buff, Sara Anson Vaux took a dim view of Clint Eastwood for decades. But in 1992 Dr. Vaux, who teaches religion at Northwestern University, saw Unforgiven, Mr. Eastwoods highly praised Western about an assassin drawn out of retirement for one last payday.

title: This Weeks Movies: Sept. 28
description: This week, the New York Times critics look at the futuristic thriller Looper, the education drama Wont Back Down, and the Thai drama Headshot. All of this weeks reviews can be found here.

title: How Inclusive Is Your Place of Worship?
description: Every week we offer The Friday Question, a feature that asks for your opinion and insights about things that have to do with the boomer era. Weve asked you to tell us your favorite rock song as well as the greatest post-World War II novel.

title: The Caucus Click: Philadelphia Fund-Raising
Christian Dior: Spring 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: Only the Songs Remain the Same
description: WHEN the 23rd annual New York Cabaret Convention begins three nights of performances on Oct. 17 at Rose Hall at Jazz at Lincoln Center, it will start a new chapter both for the convention and the nostalgic genre it celebrates. The future of both depends on cabarets reinvention into something more contemporary than a museum for the American songbook.

title: Notes From Brooklyn, Chicago and the Web
description: Tift Merritt

title: Redefining Southern Women With Spine
description: THE 1989 film Steel Magnolias, the story of small-town Louisianans negotiating lifes bumps and blessings, is a pop culture classic. A three-hanky comedy-drama, it is fondly remembered for female bonding and zippy one-liners about sanity, men and bitchiness. So Kenny Leon, the director known for spinning black stories into critical and commercial gold, was excited about an offer to direct a TV film version with black actresses, but wanted sound artistic reasons to tinker with the material.

title: The British Are Coming, Once Again
description: THERE are many things we can learn from PBSs splendidly refined British import Downton Abbey, like how to serve soup and what to do when a Turkish diplomat dies in your bed. But there are other areas of life, entire chapters of existence, to which it offers no guide.

title: Unplugged, Singer Taps Deep Into Her Roots
description: BETH ORTON was falling in love. At Retrofret, a vintage instrument dealer in Brooklyn, she grew smitten last last month with a Gibson Southern Jumbo from the 1940s: a spruce-topped, dreadnought-size guitar with a throaty low register and a price tag above $7,000.

title: Audi Crosslane: A Hybrid Mongrel That Leans Electric
description: PARIS  Crossover can mean just about anything in the automotive industry. But with the Crosslane Coupe Concept, introduced here on Thursday, Audi shoehorned a remarkable number of referents into what was already something of a catch-all notion.

title: Design for Good | The Pink Jalk Project
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Lennon Art Show Will Benefit Citymeals-on-Wheels
description: About 100 limited-edition drawings by John Lennon will be on view in a free exhibition that starts next week in SoHo.

title: A Soda Fight Moves to a Sitcom Town
description: A pragmatic city politician wants to reduce the size of sodas. The soft-drink industry fights back, saying the plan will hurt businesses and infringe on consumers rights.

title: Off the Charts: Looking Better, or Looking Bad?
description: With the economy an issue in the presidential campaign, the answer to the question of how the economy is doing may depend on ones point of reference. The charts show four economic indicators, using a relatively short time frame that shows substantial improvement, and a much longer one, showing that current conditions are well below prerecession levels.

title: Rules of War
description: In recent years, the American debate about war  about torture, drone strikes, the killing of civilians in Afghanistan and Pakistan  has also been a debate about the international laws of war. But much of this law, as John Fabian Witt shows in his magnificent new book, was originally made in America.

title: Abraham to Zachary
description: One night a few months ago, my 7-year-old son  who during the Republican primaries developed a mildly obsessional interest in presidential history  asked me to rank the American chief executives in order of greatness. With bedtime looming, I resolved to make it quick. Rattling off the successes (George Washington, Abraham Lincoln, Franklin D. Roosevelt) proved easy, as did listing the failures (James Buchanan, Andrew Johnson, Herbert Hoover, Richard Nixon). But filling in the middle drove me crazy. Should William McKinley place higher or lower than Gerald Ford? Martin Van Buren above or below Rutherford B. Hayes? Yawning, and under pressure from my eager son, I randomly plugged in Millard Fillmore, Chester A. Arthur and the Harrisons and called it a night.

title: In Battle Over Myanmar Mine, Folk Heroines Emerge
description: WETHMAY, Myanmar  They were trailed by plainclothes police officers and called cows by government officials. They spent four nights in prison, until a public outcry prompted their release.

title: Theres a Play at the Plate
description: A look at some of the memorable plays in baseball involving catchers and home plate collisions.

title: Sick Dolphin, Stranded in Queens, Dies on Arrival at Rescue Center
description: Updated, 5:48 p.m. |  A female common dolphin, six feet long and nearly 140 pounds, bobbed ashore at Far Rockaway, Queens, on Friday morning and flopped onto the beach.

title: Man Thought to Be Behind Anti-Muslim Film Is Arrested
description: LOS ANGELES  The man thought to have been behind the anti-Islam video that set off deadly protests across the Muslim world in recent weeks was arrested on Thursday for violating terms of his probation in a 2010 bank fraud case.

title: Where the Bubbles Come From, and How to Get There
description: PARISWhen I visited Champagne recently to have a look at the newly renovated Abbey of Hautvillers and to taste some Dom Prignon, the harvest was just about to get under way.

title: Rights During Wartime
description: Did President Lincoln violate civil liberties during the war?

title: Wealth Builds Confidence
description: Consumers confidence about the future generally rises with their income levels.

title: On a Night Crowded With Hits, Big Bang and Greys Anatomy Stand Out
description: The television seasons first Thursday  a night always packed with hit shows  delivered some of the most-watched episodes of premiere week with established favorites like The Big Bang Theory and  Greys Anatomy coming back strong.

title: Less Elbow Room
description: CROWDEDNESS is a reality of modern life (I tell myself as we chug across the Seine, or the morning salute of car horns begins outside my hotel window), and so it is in fashion.

title: Clip: Wuthering Heights
description: A scene from the latest film version of "Wuthering Heights," directed by Andrea Arnold.

title: Photos of The Moment | Issey Miyake
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Common Core Practice | A Kings Skeleton, a Musical Mystery, a Territorial Dispute
description: Each Friday we post three short tasks that Sarah Gross and Jonathan Olsen, New Jersey team-teachers, tried that week with their ninth-grade humanities students.

title: The Sweet Spot | Censorship
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss the turmoil that art and speech can create in the world.

title: Vatican Says Papyrus Referring to Jesus Wife Is Probably Fake
description: VATICAN CITY  The Vatican has raised doubts about a recently released fragment of a Coptic text in which Jesus alludes to having a wife, describing it as problematic and controversial, and most likely a fake.

title: Fracking Suspense Cuts Into Second-Home Sales
description: As I report in the real estate section of The Times, many would-be buyers are deferring purchases of second homes in upstate New York out of concern that hydraulic fracturing might be allowed nearby. For now, no one knows whether Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos administration will allow this controversial natural gas drilling process to go forward.

title: Raf Simons and the Remapping of Dior
description: In just six months at Dior, Raf Simons has shown that hes more than a creative director. Hes a decorator, an architect and a definitive tastemaker. His July couture collection put Dior again in the spotlight. Today, he gave Dior a modern blueprint for its ready-to-wear and accessories.

title: A Sand Castle Built for Life
description: The Making It Last feature profiles couples who have been together at least 25 years. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: The Sweet Spot: Sept. 28
description: In todays episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss the turmoil that art and speech can create in the world.

title: Knicks Appear Closer to Signing Rasheed Wallace
description: The Knicks appear to be one step closer to signing Rasheed Wallace, who could be the latest and yet another veteran player this off-season to join the team just before training camp. A person with direct knowledge of the situation said Wallace took his physical with the Knicks training staff Thursday.

title: Bolton Calls Obamas Benghazi Response Limp-Wristed
description: John Bolton, the former ambassador to the United Nations most famous for saying the 38-floor U.N. headquarters could be 10 floors smaller and it wouldnt make a bit of difference, shared his thoughts today on the recent unrest in the Middle East and North Africa.

title: How Cheerful Was My Bomb Shelter
description: Every week The Shot offers a photo of the people, places or things of our generation. Do you have memories related to this image? Share them with us in the comments.

title: Borrowing From Your Family, by Design
description: Its much tougher than it used to be for young Americans to make their financial way in the world, given the increasing cost of college and the challenge of finding a job with benefits and a wage high enough to cover the basics plus the servicing of any student loan debt.

title: The Debate Expectations Dance
description: BOSTON  Ripping the stuffing out of your opponent means it is another day on the campaign trail.

title: Referees Feel the Love, at Least for One Game
description: BALTIMORE  Gene Steratore and his brother, Tony, founded a janitorial supply business in 1988. They still run the company, but during autumn weekends they are usually focused on their part-time jobs as N.F.L. officials.

title: Viewing the Economy Through Campaign Glasses
description: ACCORDING to numerous economic indicators, the American economy is getting better.

title: China Alters Its Strategy in Diplomatic Crisis With Japan
description: BEIJING  After allowing anti-Japanese demonstrations that threatened to spin out of control, China has reined them in and turned instead to hard-edged diplomacy over disputed islands in the East China Sea to lessen any potential damage the conflict might have inflicted on the nations softening economy and a delicate leadership transition.

title: Displaying the Dinosaurs of the Digital Age
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Not everyones pulse will quicken with a glimpse of a 1956 I.B.M. Ramac actuator and disk stack. For many, too, the 1959 Telefunken RAT 700/2 analog computer will just look like a cross between an antediluvian switchboard and the control panel for a German submarine. And while those of us of a certain age who are technically inclined might recall elegant, finely made slide rules with fondness, can even a hint of nostalgia be summoned for the glowing five-inch screen of a barely luggable, suitcase-size 1981 Osborne computer?

title: Bill Cunningham | Turnabout
description: Freedom of expression in dress was out in full force during New York Fashion Week.

title: Book Review Podcast: The Great Disconnect
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Mark Lilla reviews I Am the Change: Barack Obama and the Crisis of Liberalism by Charles R. Kesler. Mr. Lilla writes that he needs help in understanding the conservative view of the president, whom he sees as a moderate and cautious straight shooter. Mr. Lilla continues:

title: Moving Handels Harpischord to the Modern Piano
description: HANDEL: KEYBOARD SUITES

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A Justice League of Scientists
description: In all my years of reading comics, I never thought that one of my favorite characters would be the real-life physicist Richard P. Feynman. I learned quite a bit about him last year, when I read the biography Feynman, published by First Second. As I said then, much of the science went over my head, but the story was always captivating as were the scenes from his everyday life.

title: Iranian News Agency Plagiarizes The Onion
description: Last Updated: Saturday, 6:13 p.m. Apparently unaware of the unwritten rules of both ethical journalism and satire, an Iranian news agency published an edited copy of a report from The Onion on Friday, without crediting the original or acknowledging that it was fiction.

title: For Bank of America, More Trouble From Merrill Lynch Merger
description: Bank of America has resolved one of the largest and most embarrassing pieces of litigation related to its merger with Merrill Lynch in 2008. But the settlement comes with a pretty hefty price tag, since the bank has agreed to pay $2.43 billion to end the lawsuit. That monetary award ranks it as one of the largest settlements in a securities class-action case, behind the settlement over the disastrous AOLTime Warner merger.

title: F.C.C. Backs Proposal to Realign Airwaves
description: WASHINGTON  The government took a big step on Friday to aid the creation of new high-speed wireless Internet networks that could fuel the development of the next generation of smartphones and tablets, and devices that havent even been thought of yet.

title: Universal Closes on EMI Deal, Becoming, by Far, Biggest of Remaining Big Three
description: The Universal Music Group closed on its $1.9 billion acquisition of EMI Music on Friday, a week after receiving regulatory clearance in Europe and the United States and more than 10 months after it first made the deal with Citigroup.

title: Surprises in Afternoon Pairings at Ryder Cup
description: After the morning foursome matches, the United States and Europe are tied at the Ryder Cup, 2-2. The captains, Davis Love III and Jos Mara Olazbal, will send out the following pairings for the afternoon fourball session. (All times Eastern.)

title: Morton Feldman: Crippled Symmetry
description: MORTON FELDMAN: CRIPPLED SYMMETRY

description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Netanyahus Bomb Diagram During U.N. Speech Stirs Confusion in Israel
description: JERUSALEM  When the prime minister of Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu, drew his red line on a cartoonish diagram of a bomb from the podium of the United Nations General Assembly on Thursday, he intended to illustrate in simple terms the point at which Irans uranium enrichment program must be stopped, at least in Israels view, to thwart a final sprint to a nuclear weapon.

title: Brittens War Requiem by Gianandrea Noseda
description: BRITTEN: WAR REQUIEM

title: Upsides and Downsides of Family Loans
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I provide a primer on creating a family loan pool. The advantages here are many. There is potentially more money available if many family members contribute. Many people can participate in setting the rules and distribution of loans, so emotion is less likely to get in the way. And it may be easier to enforce those rules if an entire clan is standing behind the loan.

title: Adopting the Classroom as a Stage
description: EVERYONE knows that a dancers performance career ends with age. But what about a dance teachers? At the School of American Ballet, a generational shift is under way. Not only do former and current New York City Ballet members, including Arch Higgins, Darci Kistler, Katrina Killianand Jonathan Stafford, dominate its staff, but Peter Martins, the artistic director and chairman of faculty at the school, has put programs in place to pump even more new blood.

title: Quail Is Worth a Second Thought
description: MOST people I know happily order quail in a restaurant, but rarely think of cooking them at home. I often wonder why, because nothing could be easier. If you can roast a chicken, roasting a quail is absolutely no problem, and it is ready in half the time.

title: Sept. 30  Oct. 6
description: ABC takes aim at lovers of the macabre on Sunday with the premiere of its drama 666 Park Avenue, but the creepiest program on television actually comes along on Friday, when Animal Planets MONSTERS INSIDE ME returns (8 p.m. Eastern).

title: Rookies Give Americans an Early Edge
description: MEDINAH, Ill.  Clearly the Ryder Cup is not such a steep learning curve, after all.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Le Taste of France on Pier 54, at West Street and 13th Street, celebrates French gastronomy and culture Saturday from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. and Sunday from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Chefs will prepare special dishes paired with French wines and liquors. A French flea market, live music, wine tastings, games and a French bulldog show are part of the schedule. On Saturday from 6:30 to 11 p.m., Le Soiree turns the event into a big dinner party where guests can meet chefs. Tickets for the day session are $30 in advance, available online or $40 at the door. The Sunday evening program is $149 a person.

title: New French Budget Focuses on Slicing Deficit
