description: PARIS  President Franois Hollande, a Socialist who was elected this year on a pro-growth platform, presented a budget on Friday that would produce the biggest cut in the public deficit in 30 years while raising the top rate for the wealthiest taxpayers to 75 percent from the current 41 percent.

title: In Paris, Ford Fiesta Tries On the New Family Face
description: PARIS  The 2013 Ford Fiesta subcompact hatchback arrived here on Thursday bearing signs of the automakers unified styling strategy, with a little bit of Fusion, Focus Electric and Evos concept reflected in its face.

title: Concern Over Fracking in the Catskills
description: September 27, 2012 - Real estate listings languish over fracking fears in Catskills.

title: Isabel Marant: Spring 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: How to Read Like an Economics Columnist
description: Editors note: This is the first installment of a new series on the 6th Floor. Once a week, a magazine contributor will be quizzed about books theyre reading or have read or hope one day to finally get around to reading. First up is Adam Davidson, who writes the Its the Economy column.

title: (Psst: We Feel Bad About Our Arms)
description: I HAD expected to keep mum about my problem with Michelle Obama until after the election, but my frustration has gotten the better of me. I can contain it no longer.

title: Rich Rome: The Venues
description: Dine with Colosseum views and visit a chocolate boutique on this well-funded tour.

title: Revelations in High-End Rome
description: IT was one of those absurdly hot Roman afternoons when the sun-blasted plazas empty out and the sherbet-hued town houses, peach and lemon and lime, look ready to melt into the cobbled streets. Weary of the touristy Tridente district, I crossed the tony Piazza San Lorenzo in Lucina and slipped into a tiny new art-house cinema, savoring the air-conditioning. Within seconds I was lost in a movie that I had never heard of: Cracker Bag, a moody coming-of-age film from Australia. The credits rolled and I fixed my eyes on the screen, eagerly awaiting the next movie  another obscure film from another far-off land.

title: The Beauty of Frugal Rome: Some of the Best Things Are Free
description: THE young waitress, hair tied up and black T-shirt tugged over one shoulder, was marking up the menu with her suggestions for a 10-euro tasting flight at Open Baladin, a spot in the historic center of Rome that serves over 100 Italian-made beers.

title: Frugal Rome: The Venues
description: Wine, history and more, all for less.

title: A Spanish SoHo Springs Up in Seville
description: A fashionable moniker is just the beginning of this reinvented neighborhoods story.

title: A Soft-Pedaled Escape From Paris
description: IT was easy to imagine that wed pedaled our bicycles deep into a Pissarro painting, one of his sun-dappled, late-19th-century Impressionistic scenes of riotous summer vegetation outside Paris. Rows of soldier-straight poplars lined the narrow Canal de lOurcq, their leaves rustling in a breeze that tempered the warm August air. The surrounding woods smelled heavy and green, and the canals still, dark waters reflected the slender poles of a few fishermen on its grassy banks.

title: Another Voice Had Come Between Us
description: ON a romantic trip through the English countryside, my husband fell in love with another woman. He met her at a car rental agency on the outskirts of London, where she arrived with the upgrade package.

title: Revisiting Mexican Flavors in a California Surf Town
description: YOU know what doesnt change in 20 years? The smell of eucalyptus. To some people, that soft, sweet green scent is the smell of massages and yoga classes. To me, its teenage angst. To me, the smell of high school, the smell of nervousness, awkwardness, acne, hormones, the smell of being a teenager is all wrapped up in the smell of eucalyptus.

title: Waves and Wildlife in Costa Rica
description: ITS not every day that you step out from a sunset surf session straight into a jungle habitat of howler monkeys dangling in leafy guarumo trees, cicadas conducting a symphony, and a pair of white-nosed coati  raccoon-like animals with striped tails and masks  strolling across a dirt road, sending geckos darting out of their path. It was so enchanting that I even forget to swat at the mosquitoes hovering about, getting ready to divebomb my legs.

title: A World Traveler (57 Times) on the Andes
description: IF there was anyone who could be forgiven for being unmoved by the sight of the Andes Mountains, it would be Bertram van Munster. As executive producer of the Emmy award-winning reality show The Amazing Race, whose new season premieres on Sunday, he says he has circled the world 57 times.

title: Hotel Review: TRYP Hotel in New York
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Restaurant Report: Manfreds & Vin in Copenhagen
description: The disco ball lighting up the glassed-in wine room in the back of Manfreds & Vin, a crowded wine bar in Copenhagens fashionably scuffed Norreborro district, doesnt help much when it comes to making out the labels. But it does set the mood: youre not here just to navigate a serious collection of hard-to-find natural wines from cult vintners with limited productions, youre here to have fun.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Regarding Pools, Caves and Chocolate (Sept. 16), I found this article to misrepresent the experience of visiting Semuc Champey, which is a standard stop on the tourist trail in Guatemala. Its a pity that the author has to recycle tired travel-writing tropes of discovery to make her observations seem more exciting. I understand that one of the appeals of Semuc Champey is its remoteness, that its not completely overrun with other tourists, but the author seems to be indulging in some kind of fantasy in which she and her boyfriend discover an untouched Eden.

title: Heather Thompson and Edward Burke
description: EDWARD BURKE was taking photographs of a group of young women from South Africa who were visiting the Smithsonians National Museum of African Art, where he is the public affairs specialist. As he framed a shot through the lens, his focus jumped to the chaperon: the tall, lithe Heather Joy Thompson.

title: Museum Tower in Dallas Says It Is Trying to Solve Glare Problem
description: The 42-story glass-skinned condominium in Dallas known as Museum Tower, which is sending a harsh reflective glare into the nearby Nasher Sculpture Center, addressed the issue in a paid letter printed in Fridays Dallas Morning News.

title: Bronts Lovers, Facing Even More Storms
description: WITH more than a dozen film versions, Emily Bronts Wuthering Heights is something of a cultural touchstone for ill-fated love. The title alone conjures up images of a brooding Heathcliff and a delicate Cathy clinging to each other or suffering alone on the Yorkshire moors. For many fans, the characters are synonymous with Laurence Olivier and Merle Oberon in the 1939 movie. And yet, at least when it comes to screen adaptations, the novel may be the most misunderstood book of all time.

title: Wheelies: The Hot Seat Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: The Morning Sky Hinted at Misery, and Then, It Delivered
description: It was a day that defined gloom. There was the color scheme: An ominous palette of grays and blacks when your too-early alarm clock had you hoping for a primary-color sunrise.

title: Romney Continues to Hit Obama on Defense Cuts and Foreign Policy
description: RADNOR TOWNSHIP, Pa.  Speaking to his second military group in two days, Mitt Romney on Friday hammered President Obama over cuts to military spending, as well as of his handling of foreign policy issues.

title: For Brooklyns New Arena, Day 1 Brings Hip-Hop Fans and Protests
description: After nine years as the focal point of a pitched confrontation over urban development, power and basketball, the Barclays Center in Brooklyn began its first day of life on Friday with the hip-hop superstar Jay-Z performing at a sold-out concert while activists outside the arena reminded attendees of the unfulfilled promises of the centers developer.

title: Thats Some Key
description: THERE are 383 aspirational keys in circulation in the Big City, each of them numbered and coded, all of them equipped to unlock any of four wrought-iron gates offering privileged access to undisturbed siestas or tranquil ambulation inside the tree-lined boundaries of Gramercy Park. At age 181, the only truly private park in Manhattan is lovelier and more ornamental than ever; yes, the colorful Calder sculpture swaying blithely in the breeze inside the fence is Janey Waney, on indefinite loan from the Calder Foundation.

title: Are Americans Better Off?
description: September 28, 2012  James B. Stewart on which Americans are better off now than four years ago.

title: Some Analysts Start to Like RIM
description: Investors, perhaps pleased by any bit of good news from Research in Motion, pushed up the beleaguered BlackBerry makers share price on Friday almost 7 percent after a quarterly financial report that, while loss ridden, was not as bad as feared.

title: 'Lawrence,' Before and After Restoration
description: A clip from Lawrence of Arabia, showing the look of the scene before the films digital restoration and after.

title: The Daily Shoe | Christian Dior
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Maison Martin Margiela: Spring 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: What Sands of Time Did Not Erase
description: NO studio today would make a film like Lawrence of Arabia  227 minutes long, featuring a cast of hundreds riding camels through the desert, shot on location (there were no computer graphics in 1962). Yet Sony Pictures new 50th-anniversary restoration  playing at the New York Film Festival on Sunday and in more than 600 theaters nationwide starting Thursday  seems fresh and modern, in its political themes and its stunning visual clarity.

title: The Party Politics of the Father-Daughter Dance
description: When a Rhode Island P.T.O. set out to plan a Me and My Guy dance, as well as a mother-son baseball game, it was unaware that the state and district had concluded that laws prohibiting sex discrimination in any and all other school functions and activities meant no father-daughter or mother-son events. One single mother complained, the A.C.L.U. responded, and the school district immediately apologized  the dance took place as scheduled with all genders of parents and children welcome to attend. But the ban itself has become, as Jess Bidgood reported for The Times, a fiercely debated political flashpoint with divisions falling along what have become predictable partisan lines.

title: Project Basement: Receiver Connectors Rule
description: Shopping for a receiver used to be a pretty simple matter. You listened to those in your price range and bought the one that sounded best.

title: Honey Boo Boo Has the Ratings, if Not the Critics
description: When TLCs reality series Here Comes Honey Boo Boo made its debut in August, it was met with such derision by some television critics, that it seemed like the title should be changed to Look Out! Here Comes Honey Boo Boo.

title: Artists Foundation Seeks Return of Sphere to World Trade Center Site
description: The chorus voicing a pledge for the return of the Sphere to its original place at the W.T.C. has reached as far as Landshut, Lower Bavaria, Germany, the letter begins. Thats a consequential destination because it is the home of Fritz Koenig, the sculptor of the World Trade Center Sphere, and of his museum and foundation.

title: Spain Needs $76 Billion to Recapitalize Its Banks, Audit Finds
A Downton Abbey Prequel in the Works
description: How did the distinguished Earl of Grantham, Robert Crawley, hook up with the American Countess Cora? Did he marry for love or her inheritance?

title: Giving With an Eye on the Impact
description: Paul Sullivans Wealth Matters column this week discusses philanthropists who not only want their donations to do good, they are looking for a way to measure the impact of their giving.

title: Norton To Publish Philip Roth Biography
description: W.W. Norton & Company will publish the previously announced authorized biography of Philip Roth, the press announced on Thursday.

title: Beyond the 6-Speed: More Ratios for Automatic Transmissions
description: Detroit

title: Till Death, or 20 Years, Do Us Part
description: IT makes little sense to explore a new era of family values based around Hollywood couplings. Or, worse yet, around mere rumors of the way movie stars conduct their marital affairs.

title: Beets Are Back, With Greens
description: The beet has always been a celebrated treat on Well. Weve put them in everything from smoothies and lasagna to birthday cake and risotto.

title: U.S. Move to Give Egypt $450 Million in Aid Meets Resistance
description: The Obama administration notified Congress on Friday that it would provide Egypts new government an emergency cash infusion of $450 million, but the aid immediately encountered resistance from a prominent lawmaker wary of foreign aid and Egypts new course under the leadership of the Muslim Brotherhood.

title: Versatile Housing, in Both Kind and Cost
description: AS it slices east to west through Port Jefferson Station, the thoroughfare called Nesconset Highway, or Route 347, is a dividing line in more than just a physical sense. According to the Census Bureau, the southern portion of town actually has a different name: Terryville.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $17.5 Million
description: Apparently bulletproof when it comes to investing in antique West Village real estate in need of renovation, Kiefer Sutherland, aka the infamous Jack Bauer of 24 and presently starring in Touch on Fox television, has sold his five-story brick town house at 763 Greenwich Street for $17.5 million, in the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: A Little Bit of Hepburn
description: Star Jones, 50, has appeared on television the last two decades. She is currently a panel member on Todays Professionals, a weekly segment of Today on NBC, with Donny Deutsch and Dr. Nancy Snyderman. A native of Badin, N.C., Ms. Jones, a former prosecutor, lives in Manhattan.

title: Charging Ahead on an Electric Highway
description: Los Angeles

title: One Big Step for Tesla, One Giant Leap for E.V.s
description: Berkeley, Calif.

title: A Quieter Side of Swizz Beatz
description: ON a muggy August morning, the hip-hop producer known as Swizz Beatz stepped from the SoHo apartment he shares with Alicia Keys, and climbed into an S.U.V. with his 5-year-old son. In the front seat was his uncle and bodyguard, a man who spent two decades in prison and has the biceps to prove it.

title: Whats Going On With My Bank?
description: Wednesday was kind of a busy day, but late in the afternoon I tried to log in to my banks Web site to see what checks had posted (I bank with PNC). I couldnt get in. Web sites dont load now and then, and I didnt give it much thought.

title: Carmakers Try to Figure Out the New Generation
description: PARIS  The digital generation is apathetic about cars. And thats a problem for automakers.

title: Paper or Plastic? Some Communities Say Neither
description: Bill Hoffman, owner of Aptos Jewelers in Aptos, Calif., sells bracelets, rings and pendants for thousands of dollars each. He balks at the notion of charging customers an extra 10 cents for a shopping bag, but Mr. Hoffman has no choice. It is the law.

title: That Loaded Gun in My Carry-On? Oh, I Forgot
description: The list of potentially lethal weapons was certainly eye-opening: 47 guns (38 of them loaded, including six with rounds in their chambers), three inert hand grenades, supplies of black powder, hunting knives, timing fuses and a sword.

title: Going the Distance
description: No single new model can overhaul the auto industry, but the Model S, along with its charging network for long-distance travel, suggests that Tesla is playing for keeps.

title: Photos of The Moment | Roland Mouret
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: As Apples Maps Stumbles, AOLs MapQuest Flourishes
description: As Apple struggles to improve its Maps application, which has been irritating and amusing users with its shortcomings and inaccuracies, the company is urging its users to seek transit and traveling directions elsewhere.

title: Mets Post Third Consecutive Decline in Attendance
description: During their meltdown after the All-Star Game, the Mets tried everything to get fans to go to Citi Field: T-shirts on Tuesdays, half-price tickets for those who brought Pepsi cans and free tickets for children.

title: A Paris Fashion Week Party at Les Deux Magots
description: Inside the velvet ropes, there were fashion insiders and celebrities including Gareth Pugh, La Seydoux and Jean Reno.

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 28
description: A view of the day in sports, as the Ryder Cup began.

title: Post-Runway, at the Brasserie
description: PARIS

title: A Big Settlement, Flexible Ethics and Special Section on the Law
description: Bank of America agreed to a $2.43 billion settlement. | A British trade group gave up its Libor power. | Andrew Ross Sorkin questioned the flexible ethics of bankers new lobbyist. | A special section explored the intense competitive pressures confronting law firms.

title: Hot-Button Issue: The Hot Factor
description: JOHN F. KENNEDY was a striking man  by most accounts, the best-looking person ever to occupy the White House  but he lived in an age before Facebook, Tumblr, YouTube, chat groups and discussion threads made that a subject to debate with as much fervor as health care reform and offshore tax havens. Not so this years presidential candidates.

title: In Florida, Biden Attacks Romney on Social Security and Medicare
description: Campaigning in Florida, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. widened his attack against Mitt Romney on Friday to accuse him of favoring higher taxes on Social Security benefits to pay for tax cuts for the rich.

title: California Issues 10,000th Rebate for Zero-Emissions Incentive Program
description: Start undressing Californias Clean Vehicle Rebate Project, a program intended to spur the sales and leases of zero-emission vehicles, and front-page topics come into view  reduction of greenhouse gases and job creation chief among them. So when the program recorded its 10,000th rebate earlier this month, it merited some pomp.

title: West Virginia Displays Art of Quarterbacking
description: From across the room, the teacher heard 3-year-old Geno Smith read a childrens book aloud.

title: Whats an Allowance For?
description: R. wrote me that she spent the summer feeling like a constant A.T.M. machine for her 14-year-old. If a young teenager wants to hang out at the mall, see a movie, or get a smoothie, inevitably theres cash involved. Fourteen, she notes, is too young to get a real job but not too young to spend whats adding up to real money.

title: For Flutist in West Bank, a Rare Chance
description: A LITTLE more than three years ago she was a quiet, serious-minded 16-year-old flutist in the West Bank with posters of the Berlin Philharmonic flute soloist Emmanuel Pahud on her bedroom wall. Travel restrictions made it a struggle to go for lessons in Jerusalem. Finding space to practice in an apartment crowded with four siblings was difficult. Despite her hard work, her prospects seemed limited.

title: Come Hither, City Quail
description: For this weeks City Kitchen column, I needed a few quail. It turned out that hunting them down in the urban jungle was less complicated than I imagined. Indeed, the first butcher I called had just received a delivery of fresh quail. Out of curiosity, I investigated a handful of other local options.

title: Friday Night Music: Transatlantic Sessions (Sarah Jarosz)
description: Seems appropriate given my current location:

title: The Image as Obsession, No Matter the Method
description: PARIS

title: Filmmaker Sets Focus Very Close to Home
description: UNDERSTANDING ones parents might be as difficult as fathoming the cosmos, but its something most of us try to do, in one way or another. Doing this through the lens of a camera for a documentary film, as a number of children of famous parents have in works like My Architect, by the son of Louis Kahn; William Kunstler: Disturbing the Universe, by the radical lawyers two daughters; and The Man Nobody Knew: In Search of My Father, CIA Spymaster William Colby, by Carl Colby, can be an effective, if grandiose method. It allows the filmmaker to use the tried-and-true tools of the profession while also making a very public statement.

title: Tall in the Saddle in 2 Eras at Once
description: LOUISE BROOKS is barely recognizable in Overland Stage Raiders, the 1938 Republic western that would prove to be her last film: the magnetizing star who went to Germany to make Pandoras Box and Diary of a Lost Girl (both released in 1929) has let her daringly close-cropped hair grow out into conventional waves, her nose and chin seem sharper, and the fire in her eyes has dimmed. But there she is, providing the perfunctory love interest in a low-budget feature meant for Saturday morning childrens matinees, playing against a good-looking but gawky young man who a few years later would become one of the biggest stars in the business, John Wayne.

title: Obama Orders Chinese Company to End Investment at Sites Near Drone Base
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, citing national security risks, ordered a Chinese company on Friday to divest its interest in four wind farm projects near a Navy base in northern Oregon where training missions for drone aircraft are conducted.

title: As It Followed a Car Chase, Fox News Showed a Suicide
description: 6:16 p.m. | Updated The Fox News Channel, in the course of following a car chase live in Arizona, on Friday broadcast the suicide of the man who was being pursued by the authorities.

title: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 28
description: Subjects include an excursion in the Adirondacks with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, Daw Aung San Suu Kyis visit to New York and a long-awaited subway transfer station in Manhattan.

title: Roasting Peppers
description: Roasting your own peppers are so much better than what you can buy in a store. Melissa Clark shows how.

title: Iran Ridicules Netanyahus Bomb Theatrics, and Calls on Israel to Renounce Nukes
description: Iran said Friday that Israels latest warnings at the United Nations of an impending Iranian atomic weapons threat were baseless theatrics, and called on Israel to disband its own unacknowledged nuclear weapons arsenal and sign the Non-Proliferation Treaty just as Iran had done 44 years ago.

title: Danger Lurks Between Peppers Sweet and Hot
description: THERE are sweet peppers; there are hot peppers; and then there are those peppers that fall somewhere in between. They are the Russian roulette of peppers, the kinds that you can never be quite sure about until you take a bite.

title: Inside the Mind of Worry
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Notes for a New Life
description: With help from friends at home and abroad, a young Palestinian flutist has found a way to escape the walls around her West Bank village.

title: Q & A
description: When a Trust Owns Co-Op Shares

title: Ex-SAC Analyst Pleads Guilty in Insider Trading Conspiracy
description: 8:31 p.m. | Updated

title: Peter and the Starcatcher To Close in January
description: After flying from downtown to Broadway and winning five Tony awards, Peter and the Starcatcher will close, the producers announced on Friday.

title: Photos of The Moment | Isabel Marant
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Romney Speaks With Netanyahu
description: BEDFORD, Mass.  Moments after finishing a phone call with  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, Mitt Romney told reporters on his private campaign plane Friday that he did not believe military action against Iran would be necessary, but added that he would not take that option off the table.

title: Rose Hartmans Photographs
description: Surely most people are familiar with the face of Linda Evangelista. But do you remember how that face looked in 1992, when the supermodel, shown below, was in her 20s?

title: Legends, Then and Now
description: Incomparable: Women of Style. By Rose Hartman. With texts by Anthony Haden-Guest, Rose Hartman and Alistair ONeill. 163 pp., 132 color illustrations. ACC Editions. $49.50.

title: Wheels Calendar for Sept. 28-30
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

title: Returning to Cozy Tradition For a Seasons 2nd Welcome
description: When is an opening night not an opening night? Perhaps when it is the second of two.

title: Barclays Center: An Arena With Many Faces
description: Diagrams of the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, the first new large indoor arena for sports and entertainment built in New York City since 1968.

title: Video: Last Call for Peppers
description: Its the end of fresh-pepper season, so if you havent had your fill of gorgeous sweet and hot peppers this summer, the time is now. In this weeks video, I show two techniques for roasting and peeling them  both in the broiler and on an open flame on the stovetop. You could also use your grill if the weather is clear in your backyard.

title: Tim Cooks Apology Is an Important Step Forward
description: On Friday morning, Apples chief executive, Tim Cook, apologized for releasing the flawed Maps app on iOS 6. I dont mean a flimsy P.R.-speak apology  I mean a heartfelt one that seems fully cooked.

title: Advertising Week Begins Monday, Focusing on Technology and Returning Veterans
description: It has been said many times that the most popular words in the advertising business are new and improved. But the phrase offers a way to describe changes in store when the ninth annual Advertising Week takes place in New York next week.

title: Yohji Yamamoto: Spring 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: Chic in Review | Raf Simonss New Look
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Baton Rouge Newspaper Sees an Opportunity in New Orleans
description: Its a Hail Mary pass for New Orleans newspaper lovers dreading the day that the city no longer has a daily paper. Starting on Monday, the first day that The Times-Picayune no longer prints every day, The Advocate from Baton Rouge will offer home delivery of a New Orleans edition.

title: At Summit Series in Moscow, Canadians Ask, Wheres the Beef?
description: In Canada, all that matters is this: we won.

title: Pictures of the Day: Nepal and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Nepal, West Bank, Spain and Israel.

title: Even Health Dept. Isnt Safe From Bedbugs
description: A single bedbug led to fumigation of one floor of the citys Department of Health and Mental Hygienes headquarters in Long Island City, Queens, on Friday.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A three-bedroom lodge in Hopewell, N.J., and a four-bedroom house in Bellmore, N.Y.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Manhattan Valley co-op, a Financial District condo and a Wallabout house.

title: The Illegal Trap
description: A vigorous discussion is taking place online about the word illegal as an adjective for certain immigrants. An immigrant activist named Jose Antonio Vargas, a former reporter, is urging news organizations like The New York Times to stop using it. He says the word is inaccurate, improper and demeaning.

title: Catholic Leader Is Turned Away at Exhibit He Deemed Offensive
description: On Thursday night, William Donohue, the president of the Catholic League, held a news conference outside an art gallery in Midtown Manhattan to denounce one of the works of art on display there: a 1987 photograph of a crucifix immersed in a jar of urine. But, when Mr. Donohue tried to enter the exhibition, the gallery would not allow him in, he said in a blog post on Friday.

title: Judge Strikes Down a Dodd-Frank Trading Rule
description: Wall Street posted another victory in the battle over regulation on Friday after a federal judge struck down a central piece of the Obama administrations financial overhaul.

title: Artists Books and Oil Pumps
description: This weekend the seventh annual NY Art Book Fair takes place at MoMA P.S. 1 in Queens. One of the exhibitors is ABC Artists Books Cooperative. And one of its featured projects is ABCED, a 33-volume series of artist books created in celebration of the artist Ed Ruschas 75th birthday this December. In the 1960s, Ruscha published a series of artist books  collections of his own photographs sold in small editions  that influenced generations of artists, including Mishka Henner, one of the cooperatives 25 members.

title: 2012 Paris Motor Show
description: With auto sales bottoming out in Europe, the mood during press previews for the biennial Paris salon reflected a hope that 2013 might mark the beginning of a slow recovery. Here is a look at some of the models that were shown.

title: Hybrid Strategy: Divide and Conquer
description: BOTH Honda and Toyota are far more committed to the hybrid car than to the battery electric vehicle, a fact that Toyota made clear this month when it scaled back its Scion iQ electric car project. And Honda is so enthusiastic about hybrids that, as its chief executive, Takanobu Ito, outlined in a recent speech, it will have three separate systems with up to three electric motors.

title: At Dior, Raf Simons Asserts His Authority
description: Is it fair to ask, in the blur of fashion shows, if something can be new?

title: How to Help Iran Build a Bomb
description: ADVOCATES of airstrikes on Irans nuclear facilities have long held that the attacks would delay an atom bomb for years and perhaps even buy Israel enough time to topple the Iranian government. In public statements, the Israeli defense minister, Ehud Barak, has said that an attack would leave Irans nuclear program reeling, if not destroyed. The blow, he declared recently, would set back the Iranian effort for a long time.

title: Lumire | Paris  la Hollywood
description: Not all that we see on-screen of Paris is Paris.

title: Chlo Gets a Salute in Paris
description: Chlo Attitudes is the name of a new exhibition that opened in Paris at the Palais de Tokyo with a cocktail party Friday night during Fashion Week, though there was little attitude in the way you might associate with the fashionista crowd.

title: The Roman Who Loved the Greeks
description: Being the sex slave of Romes gay emperor has its drawbacks.

title: Hold the Crepes, Bring On the Eggplant
description: WHEN Eddie Ulas Konca and Cevail Sarac first planned to start a restaurant together, they thought it would be a waterfront seafood spot in Huntington. Circumstances changed, and when they opened their restaurant, Mermaid, last year, it was in Hewlett, and nowhere near the water. The name was less apt, but they kept it anyway because they liked it.

title: A Romantic Whos Inspired by Streisand
description: Although the singer Ann Hampton Callaway doesnt sound at all like Barbra Streisand, to whom she paid fervent tribute on Wednesday evening in her new show, The Streisand Songbook, at 54 Below, the two share a fundamental, unshakable romanticism. Both favor overarching, dramatic love songs, and both have the vocal equipment to infuse them with fairy tale magic.

title: In Bridge, Game of Chicago at Regency Whist Club
description: Alan Greenberg, known as Ace, who celebrated his 85th birthday this month, was the chief executive of Bear Stearns for many years. Although he still has board positions with JPMorgan Chase and Viacom, he has more time for bridge now than when he was with Bear Stearns.

title: 150 Films, and Parking Spaces, Too
description: KAREN ARIKIAN, executive director of the Hamptons International Film Festival, referred to the event as small several times in a recent phone conversation. And in comparison to annual festivals in Cannes, Berlin and some other cities, the one on Long Island does seem rather diminutive.

title: Week in Pictures for Sept. 28
This Sunday: A Video Introduction to the Inspiration Issue
description: In the magazines Inspiration Issue, we tell you about the best books, movies, TV shows, music and art on the horizon, and the stories that led to their creation. Michael Chabon writes about how the O.J. Simpson verdict inspired Telegraph Avenue, Alicia Keys describes how she wrote the song Girl on Fire, Junot Daz shares the artifacts that help him write and much more.

title: Californias Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: When Crossing the Street
description: To the Editor:

title: A Vivid Glimpse of a Lost America
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.

title: In New York, the Ballet and Opera Are Stuffy No More
description: At a time when even the most august cultural institutions are being challenged by an ailing economy, a program or guest list larded with the names of celebrity designers, runway models and athletes can be a powerful draw.

title: Why the Beaver Should Thank the Wolf
description: San Francisco

title: Forging Ahead at the Paris Auto Show
description: Despite a faltering economy, big automakers showcase glistening new auto lines in France. Reporter Jerry Garrett talks to auto executives to find out how new offerings will survive the slump.

title: Going Hollywood
description: WHEN Olivia Palermo sauntered down the red carpet at Lincoln Center a week ago, she seized the occasion, the gala opening of the New York City Ballet, as a glittering photo op, a chance to shine in her multitiered Dior gown  and, oh, incidentally, to offer homage to Valentino Garavani, who stepped out of official retirement to create the costumes.

title: Should U.S. Stay Out of Mideast Affairs?
description: To the Editor:

title: The V.A.s Responsibility to Homeless Veterans
description: To the Editor:

title: Old Favorite Returns, Freshness Still In Its Step
description: Less than half of the quadruple bill that opens this years Fall for Dance season is much good  and yet, like so many Fall for Dance programs over the years, its refreshing. This intensely popular annual festival at City Center presents several works by different artists on each program; this years, for the first time, are spread over 12 evenings in three weeks. The emphasis is always on the modern and the unfamiliar; even when you decide you dont care for some offerings, youre usually still taken somewhere new. (Those of you who need your dance fixes from the Don Quixote pas de deux, go elsewhere.)

title: Reviewing the Tesla Model S
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Bradley Berman reviews the 2012 Tesla Model S in a more thorough manner than any other journalist has yet.

title: Apples Plans for Internet Radio Run Up Against Big Music Publisher
description: The rough news for Apple lately is not just about its much-derided new maps program.

title: Talent Shows
description: IT was a thoroughly modern economic game, this three-way tiff between N.F.L. owners, players and referees. The N.F.L.s unionized officials asked for significant wage and pension changes from Americas leading sporting league. In response, the N.F.L. locked out the unionized refs and brought in replacements. The replacement refs struggled. In turn, players spoke out against the replacement refs  especially after an egregious error that ended a marquee game between Green Bay and Seattle. Players, fans and members of the media demanded that the N.F.L. capitulate and pay whatever it took to bring back the regular refs. Finally, a deal was done.

title: A Diner Redefines Itself
description: THESE days, calling City Limits a diner may be a misnomer. After a four-month renovation, it reopened in August, with the traditional diner counter removed and a new earth-tone color scheme.

title: The Tip of Putins Wedge Between Urban and Rural
description: YEKATERINBURG, Russia

title: A Look at Computer History
description: The Computer History Museum in Mountain View, Calif., displays more than 1,000 technological artifacts.

title: At Paris Motor Show, the Home Team Continues to Flout Styling Norms
description: PARIS  The French have historically rebelled against the conventions of automobile design, and for that we have cars like the Citron 2CV and Renault Dauphine to admire and, at times, revile.

title: Dazzled by a Cute Picture, More Nannies Fall for Swindle
description: Stephanie Canales, 19, said she had only one hesitation about having her name used in this article. Please, she said, dont make me look like a moron.

title: Oklahomas Deal With Fox Sports Worth Nearly $60 Million Over 10 Years
description: Earlier this month, the University of Oklahoma announced a deal with Fox Sports that broadened the availability of its sports within the state and spread them throughout Texas, Arkansas and Louisiana. A national component was also added.

title: Waiting for Teixeira
description: TORONTO  It has been a month since Mark Teixeira injured his left calf during a game against the Blue Jays at Yankee Stadium. Going into Fridays game against the Jays at the Rogers Centre, the Yankees had lost two and a half games off their lead in the American League East during that time.

title: Nash Hurt in Switzerland
description: 8:09 a.m. Saturday | Update The Rangers reported Friday night that Nashs injury was related to his shoulder, not his head.

title: Remembering the Dream Teams Remarkable Supporting Cast
description: This has been quite the commemorative 20th anniversary year for the 1992 Dream Team, often referred to as the first and only collection of N.B.A. stars worthy of the signature. There was a documentary film shown on NBA TV. There was Jack McCallums excellent best-seller  Dream Team  that needed no subtitle but tacked on the rather verbose How Michael, Magic, Larry, Charles, and the Greatest Team of All Time Conquered the World and Changed the Game of Basketball Forever.

title: N.H.L. Negotiations Stick With Side Issues
description: League and union negotiators in the N.H.L. lockout, meeting for their first formal bargaining session since Sept. 12, reported modest progress on side issues Friday.

title: In His Sculptures, Vitality; In His Portraits, Precision
description: Greenwich, Conn.

title: Beach or No Beach, Bridgewater Is Thriving in Louisville
description: When asked to identify the key to success for the Louisville sophomore quarterback Teddy Bridgewater, most observers mention his poise, his athleticism, his detailed knowledge of the Cardinals offense. Yet it is possible that the secret behind Bridgewaters excellent play, which has landed him on some early Heisman Trophy watch lists, can be found in his socks.

title: 2 Plead Guilty as Kingpins in Drug Gang
description: Days before the start of a trial that had been expected to last three months, eight members of a large PCP drug ring that operated in Harlem pleaded guilty on Thursday evening to charges that will send some of them to prison for decades.

title: A Dickens Classic for the Ages
description: Snatches of songs punctuate the action in Charles Dickenss Oliver Twist, but this is not a predominantly upbeat show like Lionel Barts musical Oliver! The poverty, social hypocrisy and violence that rule Olivers world here are relieved only intermittently by streaks of dark humor and, of course, by the boys miraculous deliverance.

title: In Film and Unions Ads, Dueling Views of Teachers
description: Teachers unions have come under fire from politicians like Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago and Mitt Romney in recent months. But rarely has opposition to teachers unions worn a face as sympathetic as that of Maggie Gyllenhaal, the Academy Award-nominated actress who plays a crusading parent confronting a bullying, bureaucratic union in a new movie, Wont Back Down.

title: 2 Democrats, 2 Incumbents and One Tough House Race
description: LOS ANGELES  Howard Berman, the ranking Democrat on the House Foreign Relations Committee, has made more than 150 trips abroad during his three decades in Washington.

title: Washington Democrats Make a Move on Maine
description: Washington Democrats, after months of sitting on the sidelines, moved into the Maine Senate race on Friday with a sizable advertising buy to attack the Republican seeking to succeed Senator Olympia J. Snowe, the moderate Republican who is retiring at years end.

title: Australians Surge in Quest for New Class of Computer
description: Competing teams of Australian scientists have given that country a significant lead in an increasingly intense international competition to build a working quantum computer.

title: For Fat Sandwiches, an Uncertain Future
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.

title: Cooperation Is Cited as Lobbyist in Bribery Case Is Sentenced to 3 Months
description: Richard J. Lipsky, the prominent New York lobbyist who pleaded guilty in a political corruption case and had been secretly assisting federal investigators, was sentenced to three months in prison on Friday by a judge who said he deserved substantial credit for his cooperation.

title: Home Protection
description: A look at three techniques that Russell Martin of the Yankees and other Major League catchers use on plays at the plate.

title: A Father to Baseball
description: It is the end of the regular season, and time for goodbyes. I remember walking off the field in 2002, after we played our last game. One of my Phillies teammates said it was a sad time because you will never play with this same group again. So we gave out big hugs, knowing this nuclear family would forever be dispersed.

title: Overhaul Special Education for Preschool
description: New York State clearly needs to strengthen oversight of the fraud-riddled program that spends $2 billion a year on special education services for preschool children with learning or other disabilities. The State Education Department got off to a good start this month when it issued a preliminary reform proposal.

title: For Some U.S. Players, Waiting Pays Off
description: MEDINAH, Ill.  They were plenty rested after sitting out the morning matches, and when their turn finally came to show what they could do, Bubba Watson, Webb Simpson, Matt Kuchar and Dustin Johnson broke fast out of the gate at Medinah Country Club.

title: Lager, I.P.A. or Pilsner, Its Beer of the Local Variety
description: MENTION craft beer and places like California, Colorado and Oregon, where start-up breweries have thrived for decades, come to mind; not so Connecticut, where small-batch brewing has lagged behind. But with four new breweries  and two more preparing to release beers by years end  the way we think about the states locally made beer is finally poised to change.

title: The Economy and the Blame
description: As Mitt Romney sees it, this weeks economic data ought to be bad news for President Obama. The economy slowed to a crawl in the second quarter and the current quarter looks like more of the same. A nascent housing recovery was offset by setbacks in manufacturing. A drop in military spending previewed the pain that is to come if lawmakers dont find a way to avert even deeper automatic cuts that Republican lawmakers insisted on for 2013.

title: Seattles Tall Secondary Is Batting Away Conventional Wisdom
description: RENTON, Wash.  The youngest, tallest, most underappreciated secondary in professional football consists of two players chosen in the drafts fifth round, another plucked from the Canadian Football League and another whose diminutive stature almost led to the worst kind of group nickname: Three and a Half Men.

title: An Unfinished Campaign Against Polio
description: Leaders of the global fight to eradicate polio vowed at the United Nations on Thursday to step up their efforts to eliminate the virus from the three countries where the disease still has a foothold  Afghanistan, Pakistan and Nigeria. The challenge is that those countries are troubled by political unrest, violence and social customs that can interfere with the delivery of vaccines to the children and adults who need protection.

title: Thoroughbred Survival at the Racetrack
description: An alarming rise in thoroughbred fatalities last winter at Aqueduct Racetrack is prompting a much-needed overhaul of inept, pro-industry regulation of a sport that increasingly puts horses lives at risk in the pursuit of profit. A report by a panel of experts said the lives of 11 of 21 horses that died at the track might have been saved if the state had had proper safeguards against overmedicated and substandard horses running for purses inflated by profits from the new adjacent casino at Aqueduct.

title: Breaking Their Fast With a Downtown Twist
description: Kutshers Tribeca on Franklin Street was designed for a downtown crowd that still craves Jewish home cooking: it bills itself as a modern Jewish bistro, the hip offspring of the original Kutshers Country Club resort in the Catskills. For this years High Holy Days, it offered special meals, including a Yom Kippur break-fast menu of smoked fish and other favorites alongside nontraditional touches like duck schmaltz French fries. On Wednesday, families small and large and groups of friends filled the plush booths and tables set between blond-wood panels and glowing lights.

title: The College Rankings Racket
description: The U.S. News & World Reports annual college rankings came out earlier this month and  knock me over with a feather!  Harvard and Princeton were tied for first.

title: One Year Later, Roles Reverse as Red Sox Try to Spoil Orioles Playoff Plans
description: BALTIMORE  A year ago Friday, on the final day of the 2011 regular season, the Boston Red Sox played here needing to win to keep their playoff hopes alive. The Orioles, who had lost 93 games, refused to let that happen.

title: Shifting Reports on Libya Killings May Cost Obama
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administrations shifting accounts of the fatal attack on the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, have left President Obama suddenly exposed on national security and foreign policy, a field where he had enjoyed a seemingly unassailable advantage over Mitt Romney in the presidential race.

title: Hailing Wheelchair-Accessible Cabs
description: APP WOW Taxi

title: Cambodia Is Seeking 2nd Statue
description: The Cambodian government has asked the United States to help it recover a 10th-century Khmer sandstone statue from the Norton Simon Museum in California. It says the work was looted from a Cambodian temple complex during the countrys political upheavals in the 1970s.

title: A Career in Obstetrics, With On-the-Job Training
description: Its the fall TV season, which means that babies are thick in the air, since childbirth scenes are a sure way to draw aws and ews from jaded viewers. Babies arrived this week on the premiere of the Fox series The Mindy Project, about a young obstetrician, and on the wretched TLC reality show Here Comes Honey Boo Boo. Another birth is surely coming on the NBC series The New Normal, about a male couple and their mother-for-hire, and the first lady appears to be pregnant on ABCs Scandal.

title: Hard Times, With Regret But Without Apology
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J.  Bettye LaVette makes no apologies for her life. Sitting cross-legged on an Art Deco chair in her living room here, sipping wine, she was animated and gritty as she talked about the decades she spent singing in clubs and cursing her buzzard luck, while her contemporaries, like Aretha Franklin and Diana Ross, became superstars.

title: Sept. 28: A Circular Relationship Between Political and Economic Views
description: President Obamas probability of winning the Electoral College fell slightly in Fridays FiveThirtyEight forecast, from 83.9 percent to 82.7 percent on Thursday.

title: As Madoff Money Is Distributed, Mets Wonder What Might Have Been
description: Under better circumstances, the owners of the Mets would have an extra $67.3 million in their bank accounts today, money that could help their losing team after another miserable season.

title: Lavish Home, Corner of Fire and Brimstone
description: How powerful is the Devil? Powerful enough, apparently, to get a not particularly necessary series like 666 Park Avenue onto network television.

title: Museum Gathers Piano, Paintings and Video in a Blended Work
description: Some artistic engagements seem inevitable; others, highly unlikely. A brief, intriguing recital presented on Thursday evening by Mikhail Rudy, a Russian pianist born in Uzbekistan and based in France since the 1970s, managed to be both at once.

title: Forces of Nature: Lightning, Water, Music and Movement
description: A lighthouse guides a ship to safety. A lightning rod diverts a bolt from a structure by providing a direct path to the ground. Still, the opening images of Lighthouse/Lightning Rod, a new work by the choreographer Garth Fagan, with loose, exuberant music by the jazz composer and trumpeter Wynton Marsalis, hint at danger as much as at security.

title: Confirming the Beats Of a Throbbing Pulse
description: George Balanchine and Igor Stravinsky gave ballet a new pulse. When the curtain rises on Stravinsky Violin Concerto, its as if the five stationary dancers  four men and one woman  were taking a moment to match their heartbeats to the music. The ballerina takes the first step, a bent-knee kick to the side, and in that instant the music and the dance become one.

title: Russian Parliament Bars Opposition Lawmaker From Speaking
description: MOSCOW  Russias Parliament voted Friday to bar a prominent opposition lawmaker, Ilya V. Ponomarev, from speaking on the floor for one month after he called members of the majority party swindlers and thieves.

title: A Little Madhattery in Manhattan, Inspired by Strayhorn
description: The pianist Gerald Clayton began his first set at Jazz Standard on Thursday night with a piece called Future Reflection, assigning its annunciatory melody to a front line of trumpet and two saxophones.

title: Colombia Absolves Kidnapping Victim Accused of Misdeeds
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Bringing to a close a case that stunned Colombia and focused attention on a brutal episode in the countrys long-running guerrilla war, Colombian authorities this week absolved a former state legislator just months after accusing him of helping to arrange his own kidnapping by rebels.

title: A Bowling Hustler With a Big Left Hook
description: FIVE frames into the match, Rocky Salemmo was taking a beating.

title: Romney, Appealing to Wider Audience, Recalibrates Message
description: The language Mitt Romney used this week to describe his plan to cut income tax rates was somewhat unusual, at least by the standards of recent Republican presidential campaigns.

title: 2 Who Rode Casino Bus Tell of Crash
description: The bus swerved. It shook. It veered from one side of the road to the other.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Rethinking Patents, and Too Much Money
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently.See more here.

title: Damages, but No Profits, Awarded for a Song
description: WHEN Peggy Harley of Queens claimed in a lawsuit that a song she had written was recorded without her permission by another singer who was later nominated for a Grammy Award, she demanded millions of dollars in damages and a share of any profits.

title: Judge Approves New Entrance Exam for City Firefighters
description: A federal judge approved a new entrance exam for New York City firefighters on Friday, ending a long stalemate over hiring practices and increasing the likelihood that the department will hire thousands of minority applicants.

title: Apple Apologizes for Misstep on Maps
description: IPhone users grew more annoyed all week. When they used Apples new mobile maps, they found nonsensical routes and misplaced landmarks. Bloggers and talk-show hosts mocked the sometimes bizarre errors.

title: More Major-League Players With New York Roots
description: The Fans Have Spoken

title: Corrections: September 29, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: An Arm and a Leg and Then Some
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  It occurred to me after doing this puzzle that I should probably hand back my GIRLIE GIRL card. Apparently Im not using it properly, having not been a fan of Barbie dolls as a child.

title: Braves Honor Jones, as Eyes Turn to Mets Wright
description: ATLANTA  It only made sense that on the night Chipper Jones was honored by the Atlanta Braves for his exceptional career, it was the Mets who got a front-row seat for the ceremony. After all, Jones helped build his Hall of Fame resume by demolishing their pitching. He has a lifetime .311 batting average against the Mets, with 49 homers and 159 runs batted in in 242 games.

title: At Annual U.N. General Assembly, a Stage for All the World
description: UNITED NATIONS  The annual United Nations General Assembly debate, which comes to a close on Monday with a final flurry of speeches, might be called a convention of knotty causes, some of them distinct long shots.

title: Federal Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Against Ex-Gov. Spitzer
description: A federal judge on Friday dismissed a libel lawsuit against former Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the online magazine Slate for a column Mr. Spitzer wrote in 2010 about an insurance bid-rigging scandal.

title: Finding Joys Close to the Nest
description: Dogs and sons and work and a city that loves to be loved  are there really enough hours in a Sunday for more than that? For the documentary filmmaker Ric Burns, 57, whose Death and the Civil War had its premiere on public television this month, Monday often arrives before he has begun to exhaust that quartet. Mr. Burns, best known for his 1999 series New York: A Documentary Film, hews mainly to the Columbia University neighborhood where he has lived since 1976  these days with his wife and collaborator, Bonnie Lafave; their two sons, Adam, 12, and Simon, 14; and their three dogs, the newest a Gordon setter puppy named Fiona.

title: Marines Train to Protect Embassies
description: Fleet Antiterrorism Security Team Marines trained for close-quarters combat this week in Chesapeake, Va.

title: Training for Consulate Attacks, in Case Theres a Next Time
description: CHESAPEAKE, Va.  The riot erupted suddenly on the Virginia-North Carolina border in a remote pocket of marshland and pine. Go back to America! the protesters shouted, hurling rubber rocks at a large plywood structure meant to be a United States consulate. We dont want you here! This is our country!

title: Lottery Numbers
40 Days of Night
description: Mitt Romney is losing badly. And he has only himself to blame.

title: Files Offer Glimpse Into Shooting Suspect
description: DENVER  Two months after a gunman killed 12 people inside a Colorado movie theater, a very heavily redacted trove of legal documents in the case was unsealed on Friday, offering a few new details  including allegations from prosecutors that the defendant made a threat toward his psychiatrist several weeks before the shooting.

title: Same-Sex Couples Granted Protection in Deportations
description: The Department of Homeland Security has stated in writing that foreigners who are same-sex partners of American citizens can be included under an Obama administration policy suspending deportations of some immigrants who pose no security risk.

title: Execution Halted for Killer Claiming Abuse by Victim
description: PHILADELPHIA  A Pennsylvania judge on Friday granted a stay of execution and a new sentencing hearing to a convicted murderer who was scheduled to die by lethal injection on Wednesday.

title: College Football Matchups
description: There is a paucity of top 25 matchups this weekend, which raises the question: why rank just 25 teams? If 75 teams, say, or even all 124 were ranked, then every game would feature two ranked teams, and we could dispense with pretending that No. 14 Ohio State versus No. 20 Michigan State is some sort of epic collision.

title: Three Paths to Higher Mileage
description: Honda Plans to offer three hybrid systems, using one, two or three electric motors depending on the vehicles intent.

title: Human Faces of The Backlog at the Department of Veterans Affairs
description: Its a story about putting faces to numbers. In his Page 1 article in todays paper James Dao (@jimdao) lays out:

title: Brian De Palma on 'Passion'
description: Brian De Palma, the director of Passion, discusses his film starring Noomi Rapace and Rachel McAdams playing at the New York Film Festival.

title: Education Department Report Shows More Borrowers Defaulting on Student Loans
description: The percentage of borrowers who defaulted on federal education loans within the first three years of payments rose to an average of 13.4 percent last year  22.7 percent for those who attended for-profit colleges  according to statistics released on Friday by the Department of Education.

title: Citizen Held After 9/11 Wins Right to Be Tried
description: A federal judge in Idaho has ruled that the United States, after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, wrongly imprisoned an American under a law designed to keep trial witnesses from fleeing and that since there was evidence that the government may have willfully misused the law against him, his case should go to trial.

title: Seeing the Beauty in the Bronx
description: Daniel Hauben, 56, a painter who grew up in the Bronx, infuses his scenes of the oft-maligned borough with a touch of whimsy.

title: Battered and Beautiful: His Bronx
description: AFTERNOON sunlight splashed down into the main reading room of the Bronx Community Colleges new library, where nearly every desk was occupied, the enthusiasm of the semester still as fresh as the paint.

title: Opening Night in Brooklyn
description: The Barclays Center in Brooklyn began its first day of life on Friday with a performance by Jay-Z and protests outside the arena.

title: Romney Team Tries Hanging a Jimmy Carter Label on Obama
description: WASHINGTON  A president struggling simultaneously to cope with anti-American tumult in the Middle East and fix stubborn economic trouble at home: Is President Obama replaying the one-term presidency of Jimmy Carter?

title: On the Second Day, Tiger Sits
description: MEDINAH, Ill.  For the first time in his Ryder Cup career, Tiger Woods is sitting out a match. The United States captain, Davis Love III, benched Woods and Steve Stricker for Saturdays foursomes after the pair lost both their matches Friday. They will be replaced by Webb Simpson and Bubba Watson, who will be in the first group out, against the European duo of Justin Rose and Ian Poulter.

title: The Growing Role of Kurds in Syria
description: The Syrian government gave control of some areas to local Kurdish militias in exchange for their support.

title: Robert Newton, Maker of Racing Tires, Dies at 85
description: Robert Newton, who with his wife, Joyce, founded Hoosier Racing Tire, the Indiana company whose tires have become fixtures at car-racing tracks around the country, died on Wednesday at his home in Lakeville, Ind. He was 85.

title: Chastened King Seeks Redemption, for Spain and His Monarchy
description: MADRID  With Spain mired in an economic slump, many Spaniards are questioning their king, long revered for his role in bringing democracy to the nation but now being scrutinized for his deluxe lifestyle and opaque fortune.

title: Chris Economaki, Rumbling Voice of Auto Racing, Dies at 91
description: Chris Economaki, whose gravelly broadcast voice and prolific pen  specifically, his manual Royal typewriter  narrated the rise of auto racing from county-fair dirt tracks to a global multibillion-dollar business, died on Friday in a nursing home in Wyckoff, N.J. He was 91.

title: Schedule of Debates
description: Debates will take place from 9 to 10:30 p.m. Eastern time.

title: Kurds Prepare to Pursue More Autonomy in a Fallen Syria
description: DOHUK, Iraq  Just off a main highway that stretches east of this city and slices through a moonscape of craggy hills, a few hundred Syrian Kurdish men have been training for battle, marching through scrub brush and practicing rifle drills.

title: From Jordans Playbook: When Down, Sit Out
description: MEDINAH, Ill.

title: Debate Advice From the Beltway
description: Political insiders weigh in on what they think Mitt Romney and President Obama need to accomplish in the first debate.

title: Presidential Debate Moments
description: Sam Tanenhaus, editor of the Book Review, talks about some of the most memorable presidential debate moments of the televised era.

title: Before Debate, Tough Crowds at the Practice
description: WASHINGTON  In a conference room at the Democratic headquarters, President Obama has been preparing for the debate next week, but the reviews of his staff are already in. Too long, they tell him. Cut that answer. Give crisper explanations. No one wants a professor; they want a president.

title: In the Bronx, Throwing $97 Million Down 18 Holes
description: Were we to commit ourselves to making a master list of what New York City needs more of, it is fair to say that many of us would wear a third or fourth pencil down to the nub before settling on an 18-hole golf course and the increased presence of Donald J. Trump. And yet, with the renovation of a major portion of Ferry Point Park in the southeastern section of the Bronx, this is what New Yorkers will receive.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Keeping Pace With Orioles, the Yankees Bounce Back
description: TORONTO  The lopsided tally from Baltimore beamed on the out-of-town scoreboard on the right-field wall of the Rogers Centre and, as early as the first inning, the Yankees could see they would get no help from the Red Sox. The Orioles were on their way to an easy victory over Boston, and the pressure rose on the Yankees to keep pace with Baltimore.

title: To Fight Crime, a Poor City Will Trade In Its Police
description: CAMDEN, N.J.  Two gruesome murders of children last month  a toddler decapitated, a 6-year-old stabbed in his sleep  served as reminders of this citys reputation as the most dangerous in America. Others can be found along the blocks of row houses spray-painted R.I.P., empty liquor bottles clustered on their porches in memorial to murder victims.

title: New York May Restart Review of Gas-Drilling Rules
description: New York State appears to be further slowing its effort to produce rules governing fracking, shorthand for the suite of drilling methods used to extract natural gas from deep shale deposits. The pressure to drill has fallen sharply along with gas prices, and in the face of inevitable litigation. [Sept. 30, 11:13 p.m. | Updated | Danny Hakim describes the reaction of drilling supporters and foes to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos latest move on fracking.]

title: For Rays and White Sox, One More Reversal in Upside-Down Year
description: CHICAGO  The September narratives for the White Sox and the Tampa Bay Rays seemed written Friday morning. The Rays were in the midst of a late-season charge for the second straight year, winners of eight straight to trim a six-game deficit on Sept. 18 to two in the American League wild-card race.

title: Yemens Leader Praises U.S. Drone Strikes
description: WASHINGTON  The president of Yemen gave an unqualified endorsement of American drone strikes in his country during a visit here on Friday, cementing his status as a favored counterterrorism partner of the United States.

title: X-Rays for Cano
description: TORONTO  Robinson Cano was struck in the back of the left hand with a pitch in the sixth inning of Fridays 11-4 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays. He remained in the game, which was a good sign, but he wasnt able to get an X-ray until late on Friday, so there was no definitive word on the extent of the injury immediately after the game.

title: Greek Premier Sees Hope, but Only if Europe Helps
description: ATHENS  He waited his whole life for this moment, and many European leaders see him as Greeces last best hope for stability. But for Antonis Samaras, leading his country is no fun at all. Do you think anyone can be happy being prime minister of Greece? he asked in a low voice in an interview here on Friday, placing his elbows on his knees. This is the toughest job in the world. Its just pain.

title: Iranian Group Now Off Terror List
description: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton formally removed an Iranian opposition group from the State Departments list of designated terrorist organizations on Friday. The decision, first reported last week, is expected to make it easier to find new countries for more than 3,000 members of the group, the Mujahedeen Khalq, who are currently in Iraq. The department took into account the groups public renunciation of violence and the absence of confirmed acts of terrorism by the group, known as the M.E.K., for more than a decade. But the department said it would not forget the M.E.K.s past acts of terrorism, including its involvement in the killing of U.S. citizens in Iran in the 1970s and an attack on U.S. soil in 1992. It also expressed serious concerns about accusations that the group had committed abuses against some of its own members.

title: France: Roma Camp Burned
description: A mob set fire to an encampment of 35 foreign Roma in a Marseille neighborhood on Thursday night, the French authorities said. Local officials and rights groups were outraged, but there were no arrests, a police spokesman said. Residents of a housing project forced the Roma, also known as Gypsies, out of an adjacent field, the spokesman said, before setting fire to their possessions. Residents told local news media that they were responding to several recent thefts that they attributed to the camps inhabitants. As many as 20,000 foreign Roma are said to live in France, most of them Romanians or Bulgarians.

title: Government Can Decide How to Allocate Natural Resources, Supreme Court Rules
description: NEW DELHIIndias Supreme Court upheld the governments right to sell natural resources as it sees fit, saying it wasnt necessary for the administration to use auctions.

title: Honey Producers Lament a Bad Season for Bees
description: LONDON  Its been another bad year for bees.

title: The Weekend Word: Exposure
description: Todays Times

title: Vidya Balan and Jairam Ramesh Team Up For Toilets
description: NEW DELHI A traveling village fair is scheduled to kick off next week in India, but instead of cotton candy and tchotchkes, it will sell an important message: Use soap to wash your hands, and dont defecate in the open.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Chief Minister Omar Abdullah dismissed reports of a brewing battle between himself and Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party over the issue of providing security to sarpanches, the elected heads of village councils, Kashmir Live reported. A group of sarpanches from Kashmir met with Mr. Gandhi in New Delhi on Thursday to discuss security concerns after the killing of three village council members in the Kashmir valley earlier this week.

title: Accusations of Football Bounties for 10-Year-Olds
description: The allegations against leaders of a youth football team in California sound so outlandish that they seem to be from a Saturday Night Live skit. Imagine the former Saints defensive coordinator Gregg Williams telling a group of 10-year-olds that there may be a trip to Dairy Queen after the game, but only after you affect the head, kill the head.

title: Jay-Z Comes Home to Repay a Debt to Brooklyn
description: For many years, Jay-Z closed out his concerts with Encore, a soothing, triumphant number from The Black Album, which at the time of its release in 2003 was billed as something of a retirement. From Marcy to Madison Square, he rapped, sketching an arc that had taken him from a Brooklyn housing project to headlining the most symbolically important arena in the country.

title: Ristretto | Paris is Brewing
description: Finally, Paris has a coffee scene. The city has always been the paradox of the industry, a great cafe town where an otherwise discerning audience happily throws back watery shots of ashy swill. I first wrote about Paris coffee in 2010, and after returning to the topic last year I decided to sit on my hands until somebody in the city figured out what it was missing.

title: A Champions League Sojourn
description: GOTHENBURG, Sweden  I have to admit, I looked up Serbia on the map when I found out we would be going there for Champions League. This was a business trip, like any time Ive traveled to play a game, but it turned out to be a fascinating experience, leaving me wishing I could extend my stay and be a tourist for a couple days.

title: Arthur O. Sulzberger, Publisher Who Transformed The Times for New Era, Dies at 86
description: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, who guided The New York Times and its parent company through a long, sometimes turbulent period of expansion and change on a scale not seen since the newspapers founding in 1851, died early Saturday at his home in Southampton, N.Y. He was 86.

title: Remembering Arthur Ochs Sulzberger
description: As publisher of The New York Times, Arthur Ochs Punch Sulzberger saw the paper through a trying strike, expanded its sections and printed the Pentagon Papers.

title: Junya Watanabe: Spring 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: In Syrias Largest City, Fire Ravages Ancient Market
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Fire swept through the old central souk, or marketplace, of Aleppo, Syria, on Saturday, damaging a vast and well-preserved labyrinth of medieval storehouses, shops, schools and ornate courtyards as fierce clashes between security forces and insurgents vowing to carry out a decisive battle for the city continued.

title: Haider Ackermann: Spring 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: A Guitar Maker Aims to Stay Plugged In
description: IN 1948, a radio repairman named Leo Fender took a piece of ash, bolted on a length of maple and attached an electronic transducer.

title: Photos of The Moment | Lanvin
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Political and Class Issues Complicate a Colorado Land Dispute
description: PAONIA, Colo.  This is a story of a quiet billionaire and a middle-class mountain town, of class divisions, small-town quarrels and competing visions of the future of the West. But at its core, like so many stories here in the aspen-dappled hillsides, it is really all about land.

title: Highlights and Analysis: College Football Saturday
description: The Times is back today to host the best college football watch party in the country. Mike Huguenin will offer up his own analysis and insights on all of the big games and a lot of the not so big ones.

title: The New Stars in Republican Commercials Attacking Obama: Babies
description: Attack ads have come to this: President Obama makes babies cry.

title: From Two Great Showmen, Straightforward Hollywood Glamour
description: This was one of those rare seasons when the designers Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren of Viktor & Rolf went for straightforward fashion, instead of the conceptual variety. While it was not the usual three-ring circus, this collection, loosely themed around Hollywood glamour, offered a good opportunity to reiterate the signatures of the house. It was also a reminder that Mr. Horsting and Mr. Snoeren, besides being great showmen, are in the business of selling clothes.

title: Bound to Sea but Buried in Debt, Spains Fishermen Blame Blocs Policies
description: CDIZ, Spain  Millions of Spaniards took advantage of cheap financing to buy new houses during Spains decade-long economic boom and housing bubble beginning in the late 1990s. The countrys fishermen, many encouraged by European Union subsidies, did much the same for their own homes away from home: new boats.

title: Sorianos Renaissance Gives Cubs a Quandary
description: CHICAGO  Alfonso Soriano arrived in the big leagues as a gangly second baseman for the mighty Yankees. Fourteen years later, he is an aging left fielder for the Cubs, a team approaching 100 losses this season.

title: Viktor & Rolf: Spring 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: Sole Canadian Held at Guantnamo Bay Is Repatriated
description: OTTAWA  Omar Khadr, the only Canadian citizen held at the Guantnamo Bay detention center in Cuba, was returned to Canada early Saturday morning, the Pentagon and the Canadian government announced.

title: Triple Crown Would Paint a Clearer M.V.P. Picture
description: Lets answer the big question right away: if Miguel Cabrera wins the triple crown, he should be the American Leagues most valuable player. To lead the league in batting average, homers and runs batted in and not be named M.V.P. simply does not feel right.

title: Bettman Undisputed N.H.L. Enforcer
description: How much power does N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman have? Is he merely the instrument of the owners, taking orders and doing what he is told, or is it the other way around?

title: Punch Sulzberger, R.I.P.
description: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, better known as Punch, transformed this newspaper and had a vast impact on journalism. He oversaw the emergence of an array of feature sections that put this newspaper on a solid financial footing, and he risked everything when he defied the White House and published the top-secret Pentagon Papers from the Vietnam War. But on hearing just now that he passed away overnight at the age of 86, I kept thinking of Punch mostly as a really good and decent man who oozed likability as well as leadership. (Heres his obituary)

title: Variety: An Artsy Diagramless
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  O.K., so I stretched things a bit. Thats not the first time that has happened here at Wordplay.

title: Photos of The Moment | Junya Watanabe
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: At the Stedelijk, Tales of 2 Staircases
description: AMSTERDAMWhen the Stedelijk, the Amsterdam museum for modern and contemporary art and design, recently reopened here after having been shut for nine years, it was both a resuscitation of an old hangout and the birth of a new stage for art.

title: Holmes Has Become Focus by Design and by Necessity
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Santonio Holmes says life would probably be even better if penalty yardage on defensive backs could be tacked onto his statistics, and he would be awarded touchdowns on defensive pass-interference calls in the end zone.

title: Cacharel: Spring 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: A Freeways Closing Fails to Scare All of Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  Last year, before a 10-mile stretch of the nations busiest freeway, Interstate 405, was closed for an entire weekend in July, city officials warned of potentially endless gridlock (or more endless than usual). Carmageddon, they called it. And Angelenos listened. For one weekend in this city of cars, everyone walked. The citys roads had never felt emptier. It was, most thought, kind of nice.

title: Islamist Rebels Flee Key Port City in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Under the cover of darkness, the Shabab militant group withdrew from the port town of Kismayu early Saturday, abandoning its last major stronghold and vowing to take the war underground.

title: Mr. Sulzberger, Publisher and Projectionist
description: In 1995, at the funeral of the extraordinary journalist James Reston, I watched Arthur Ochs Sulzberger of The New York Times escort Katharine Graham of The Washington Post up the long aisle of the National Cathedral in Washington. I was struck by their grace and dignity, by how symbolic they were of great journalism, and by how much our profession owed to the man who had published The Times for nearly 30 years.

title: Supreme Court Faces Weighty Cases and a New Dynamic
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court returns to the bench on Monday to confront not only a docket studded with momentous issues but also a new dynamic among the justices.

title: Resurgent Driver Returns to Scene of Only Win
description: DOVER, Del.  Another miserable day for Martin Truex Jr. had included a bad pit stop and a crash, and there was nothing left for him to do but punch his trailer. Just seven races into the 2011 Nascar Sprint Cup Series, Truex was flailing, his career stalled.

title: Faced With Strengthened Rivals in Atlantic Division, Celtics Load Up
description: WALTHAM, Mass.  Wyc Grousbeck has been the head of the Boston Celtics ownership group for a decade. In that span, he has presided over a team that lost 18 straight games, a team record, and over another that lost 16 games in an entire season en route to an N.B.A. championship.

title: A Trans-Atlantic Trip Turns Kafkaesque
description: You, American Airlines, should no longer be flying across the Atlantic. You do not have the know-how. You do not have the equipment. And your employees have clearly lost interest in the endeavor. Like the country whose name graces the hulls of your flying ships, you are exhausted and shorn of purpose. You need to stop.

title: Short Political Memories
description: Busy day, so not much time for posting. Just a note about the oddly short memories of many people commenting on this final stretch of the presidential campaign.

title: San Franciscos New Archbishop Worries Gay Catholics
description: SAN FRANCISCO  At Most Holy Redeemer Catholic Church in the Castro, this citys largest gay district, about 20 of the faithful gathered for 8 a.m. Mass recently, clustering in the middle pews. Led by a visiting priest from nearby Oakland, the parishioners joined in celebrating the 30th anniversary of a gay couple.

title: Jets Among Elite Company in Replacing the Irreplaceable
