description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The day after their Darrelle Revis sustained a season-ending knee injury, the 2008 New England Patriots heard their coach say his name  Tom Brady  once, but not again for four months.

title: Popes Former Butler on Trial in Theft of Personal Papers
description: VATICAN CITY  Pope Benedict XVIs former butler, Paolo Gabriele, went on trial on Saturday on charges of stealing the popes confidential papers and leaking them to the press, an unprecedented security breach that set off an embarrassingly public airing of back-room intrigue and allegations of corruption at an institution known for its secrecy.

title: Main Streets Landlord
description: Cleveland Heights, Ohio

title: Return of Referee Known for Big Arms Is Welcomed With Open Arms
description: It was just a few hours after the N.F.L. had ended its labor dispute with locked-out game officials, and Ed Hochuli was already back to work.

title: Obamanomics: A Counterhistory
description: Washington

title: Janet H. Brown
description: As executive director of the nonpartisan Commission on Presidential Debates, Janet H. Brown is responsible for organizing and orchestrating the quadrennial verbal smackdowns that can define candidates. The first 2012 presidential debate will be televised live on Wednesday night. Ms. Brown has led the commission since its founding in 1987 and previously worked in staff positions at the White House, the Office of Management and Budget, the State Department and the Senate.

title: The Conservative Case for Obamacare
description: Washington

title: Better Off Than They Were in Years Past, Georgian Voters Ask: At What Cost?
description: TBILISI, Georgia  Ten days ago, after the release of video clips showing brutal abuse in a Georgian prison, the members of a soulful, apolitical indie-rock band called Landmark sat down to write a new kind of song. It was an anthem of defiance to the countrys law-enforcement system, building to the angry refrain, The system must be destroyed!

title: Why Obama Is Winning
description: LAST winter, I had lunch with a junior White House official who works on economic issues. The unemployment rate had just dipped to 8.3 percent, and I asked if he was encouraged by the figure, and hopeful that it might be down another point by Election Day.

title: The World Were Actually Living In
description: FOR the first time in a long, long time, a Democrat is running for president and has the clear advantage on national security policy. That is not how things are supposed to be, and Republicans sound apoplectic about it. But there is a reason President Obama is leading on national security, and it was apparent in his U.N. speech last week, which showed a president who understands that we really do live in a more complex world today  and that saying so is not a cop-out. Its a road map. Mitt Romney, given his international business background, should understand this, but he acts instead as if he learned his foreign policy at the International House of Pancakes, where the menu and architecture rarely changes.

title: It Goes With Everything, Even Blue Hair
description: SAVANNAH, Ga.

title: Kill the Indians, Then Copy Them
description: Los Angeles

title: New Mexico Offers Look at U.S. Elections of the Future
description: LAS VEGAS, N.M.  The volunteers fanned out in pairs last week, swarming the heart of this old settlers outpost in the north central part of the nations most Hispanic state.

title: Who Controls the Story?
description: JEREMY PETERS was doing a routine reporting job earlier this year when he stumbled across something that, as he put it, smelled funny.

title: Fullback May Soon Have More Carries Than Nicknames
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It was as innocuous as an N.F.L. play gets. The quarterback took a shotgun snap, handed the ball to the player next to him and watched the runner hop a few steps through the line before being tackled for a 3-yard gain. The crowd barely stirred. The television announcers gave the sequence little more than a cursory mention. There was not even a replay shown.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Honorable Clan of the Long-Distance Runner
description: As amateur marathon runners for nearly 50 years, we were surprised when our sport made headlines recently for an unusual reason.

title: Ukraine Ex-Premier Airs Video
description: MOSCOW  In a rare video message, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the jailed former prime minister of Ukraine, lashed out against President Viktor F. Yanukovich, who is widely viewed as responsible for her imprisonment, and urged voters to defeat Mr. Yanukovichs party in parliamentary elections next month.

title: Dempsey Scores for Spurs
description: Video: Dempsey scores to give Spurs 3-1 lead

title: Three Muffled Syllables
description: IN a few days, as you may have heard, Barack Obama and Mitt Romney will go head-to-head in their first presidential debate. What I most want from it isnt fireworks, though Im as big a fan of political theater as the next hack. Its a word, one that has gone sadly out of vogue over recent decades and been mostly absent from this campaign.

title: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, a Times Publisher, Dies
description: Mr. Sulzberger shaped the destiny of The New York Times for 34 years as its publisher and as chairman and chief executive of its parent company.

title: Away From Cities, a Life Laced With Violence for Syrians
description: RUWEIHA, Syria  The children slept on the floor of a school on a mountain slope.

title: Vivienne Westwood: Spring 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: Keeping the Music Alive
description: Electric guitars, huge as they are, have lost some of their old magic in this era of Jay-Z, Kanye West and The Voice.

title: Shots Falling and Spirits Rising, U.S. Puts Europe in Deep Hole
description: MEDINAH, Ill.  The skywriting planes that have been working the pale blue skies above Medinah Country Club this weekend have been relentlessly Eurocentric and optimistic.

title: The Caucus Click: Biden in Florida
Heartbeat of Rock n Roll
description: Fender is the worlds largest manufacturer of guitars. But the recession, inexpensive manufacturers and the shift toward synthesizers and drum machines have threatened Fenders profit margins.

title: With Good News About His Hand, Cano Stays in the Yankees Lineup
description: TORONTO  Yankees Manager Joe Girardi was not too worried Friday night that there was anything structurally wrong with Robinson Canos hand.

title: The Myth of Male Decline
description: SCROLL through the titles and subtitles of recent books, and you will read that women have become The Richer Sex, that The Rise of Women Has Turned Men Into Boys, and that we may even be seeing The End of Men. Several of the authors of these books posit that we are on the verge of a new majority of female breadwinners, where middle-class wives lord over their husbands while demoralized single men take refuge in perpetual adolescence.

title: October Term, 2012
description: On Monday, the Supreme Court opens a new term with a menu of important cases that deal with affirmative action, criminal justice, the right of defendants to effective counsel and more. The court may soon choose to hear a controversial case that could redefine voting-rights law, and, later in the term, one or more cases involving same-sex marriage.

title: Matchup: 49ers (2-1) at Jets (2-1)
description: 1 p.m. Eastern, Fox

title: Petrova Wins Wild Tokyo Final
description: When the spinning finally ended, the veteran Nadia Petrova of Russia fell to her knees having won a dizzying final at the Toray Pan Pacific Open in Ariake Coliseum in Tokyo, defeating the defending champion, Agnieszka Radwanska of Poland, 6-0, 1-6, 6-3. The title at the Premier 5-level tournament ties the biggest of Petrovas career and is her second in 2012 and 12th over all.

title: Matchup: Giants (2-1) at Eagles (2-1)
description: 8:20 p.m. Eastern, NBC

title: Democracy in the Former Soviet Republics
description: No leader of the former Soviet republics has been more pro-Western than President Mikheil Saakashvili of Georgia. He moves easily in Washington and dreams of bringing his country into full NATO membership. But his governments handling of prisons and its approach to parliamentary elections set for Monday are raising doubts about his commitment to democracy and reform.

title: 30 Seconds With Brad Richards: Locked Out but Dialed In
description: Before the N.H.L. lockout, the Rangers Brad Richards was hoping to build on his performance in last seasons playoffs. The alternate captain in his first season with the team, he had six goals and nine assists in 20 postseason games. During the regular season, Richards compiled 25 goals and 41 assists. He won the Stanley Cup with the Tampa Bay Lightning in 2004, when he was awarded the Conn Smythe Trophy as the most valuable player during the playoffs.

title: Photos of The Moment | Haider Ackermann
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Can Opium or Illness Explain a Keats Poem?
description: On Sept. 21, 1819, John Keats wrote to his brother George that he was scarcely content to write the best verses for the fever they leave behind. I want to compose without this fever. The fever is no metaphor. In another letter dated that same day, he had sent a friend a copy of his poem To Autumn, written just then, one of the greatest poems in the English language and the last of Keatss great odes. For Keats, poetry was never emotion recollected in tranquillity, as it was for Wordsworth. It was often tranquillity refigured by his fevered mind.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Rethinking Self-Reliance
description: Why do some tout individualism yet depend on public money?

title: Georgians Confront Revolutions Legacy in Vote
description: Nine years after reformers took power, Georgians are gearing up for parliamentary elections on Monday.

title: What I Learned From Playing the Gipper
description: WHEN Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic nominee for president in 1984, asked me to help him prepare for his debates with President Ronald Reagan by playing the Reagan role, I accepted with enthusiasm.

title: Tension, Though No Violence, as Protestants Parade in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland  The parades to celebrate the centenary of the signing of the Ulster Covenant  the 1912 petition against home rule that helped lead to the partition of Ireland  passed peacefully on Saturday amid the biggest police operation here in more than 20 years.

title: Peter Praeger, a Surgeon With a Health Food Company, Dies at 65
description: Dr. Peter Praeger, a heart surgeon who saved a mans life and as a result wound up owning a gefilte fish company  and who as a result of that wound up starting a successful natural-foods company  died on Sept. 22 in Hackensack, N.J. He was 65.

title: Ex-South Korea Leader Haunts Presidential Bid
description: SEOUL, South Korea  No matter how South Koreans cast their ballots in the Dec. 19 presidential election, one thing is certain: Their decision will depend at least in part on their view of a former president who has been dead for 33 years.

title: To Encourage Biking, Cities Lose the Helmets
description: ONE spectacular Sunday in Paris last month, I decided to skip museums and shopping to partake of something even more captivating for an environment reporter: Vlib, arguably the most successful bike-sharing program in the world. In their short lives, Europes bike-sharing systems have delivered myriad benefits, notably reducing traffic and its carbon emissions. A number of American cities  including New York, where a bike-sharing program is to open next year  want to replicate that success.

title: Potentially Deadly Virus Related to SARS Appears to Be Not Easily Spread
description: A new strain of a potentially deadly virus related to SARS, which has killed one man in Saudi Arabia and left a Qatari man critically ill in London, does not appear to spread easily from person to person, the World Health Organization says.

title: Women as Priests
description: REFORMERS within the Roman Catholic Church have been calling for the ordination of women as priests. The Vatican, however, refuses to consider the possibility and uses its power to silence those who speak out. Catholic clergy in Europe, Australia and the United States who have voiced public support for female ordination have been either dismissed or threatened with removal from administrative posts within the church.

title: Women as Priests
description: Photographs of women who have rebelled against the Roman Catholic Churchs decree that females cannot be priests.

title: Valiums Contribution to Our New Normal
description: IT wasnt funny, really, but everybody laughed at the scene in the 1979 film Starting Over when Burt Reynoldss character had a panic attack in the furniture department of Bloomingdales (something to do with terror at the prospect of buying a couch). Does anyone have a Valium? his brother called out as Burt hyperventilated. The punch line: Every woman in the store reached into her purse and pulled out a little vial of pills.

title: Tracking Voting-Age Hispanics
description: The rate of Hispanic cizitens has grown sharply in most states, but voter turnout among Hispanics is generally lower than it is among other demographic groups.

title: Women Hurting Women
description: ARE female leaders better for the worlds women?

title: Comme des Garons: Spring 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: Meg Whitmans Toughest Campaign: Retooling H.P.
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.

title: From Farm to Landfill
description: Feeding the planet is nearly always discussed as if it were mainly a matter of growing more food. It is not going to be that simple. In 2012 this planet will produce a record grain yield of 2.4 billion tons. That is a 1 percent increase over last year, a number slightly smaller than expected because of a devastating drought in this country that will result in a harvest 70 million tons short of earlier projections. One percent is a slender margin of growth when it comes to feeding a global human population where at least one in seven people go hungry.

title: When Humility and Audacity Go Hand in Hand
description: This interview with  Jacqueline Novogratz, chief executive of the Acumen Fund, which invests in businesses aiding the worlds poor, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Nationals Charms Proved Hard to Ignore
description: WASHINGTON  I have a confession to make. Ive been unfaithful  to my Chicago Cubs.

title: Things I Saw  No. 34
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: Escaping Ones Own Shadow
description: Before we get started, you should know this about me: Ive written short stories, news articles, essays, reviews and a couple of nonfiction books. In pursuit of my ambitions, Ive put in long hours of reading, writing and rewriting. But because life unfolds the way life does, I also have a day job as a think tank researcher, where I spend about half of my time writing or reading in genres and styles that are  how can I put this?  less juicy than the ones I practice and aspire to produce.

title: Gaultier Pays Tribute to 80s Pop Stars
description: Jean Paul Gaultiers show tonight was an absolute hoot. Paying tribute to pop stars of the 1980s, the designer dressed his models to look like Grace Jones, Madonna, Michael Jackson, David Bowie and Annie Lennox, with hilarious accuracy.

title: End of the Line for the Senators, and a Childhood
description: In 1989, my 10-year-old son, Brendan, asked if I would take him and his younger brother Patrick to a trading card show. When I was Brendans age, in 1955, I boasted the largest card collection in my Washington neighborhood  hundreds filling two large boxes. The cards in those days were not for collecting. They were for bartering, trading and learning the career statistics of favorite players.

title: Lifting Schools, via Healthier Food
description: I GREW up in San Antonio, and loved to spend time at my grandparents cattle ranch about 90 miles away in Hunt, Tex.

title: Follow a Career Passion? Let It Follow You
description: IN the spring of 2004, during my senior year of college, I faced a hard decision about my future career. I had a job offer from Microsoft and an acceptance letter from the computer science doctoral program at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. I had also just handed in the manuscript for my first nonfiction book, which opened the option of becoming a full-time writer. These are three strikingly different career paths, and I had to choose which one was right for me.

title: In Colorado, a Land Dispute
description: The industrialist Bill Kochs effort to acquire some public land is setting off a debate about private property and public access, privilege and tradition.

title: A New Team Stirs Memories, but Not a Passion
description: At the house where my parents live in Washington, there was a telltale sign of summer in the late 1960s and early 70s: two dirt patches interrupted the lawn behind the tall magnolia that leaned like the Tower of Pisa in the middle of our backyard.

title: How to Erase a Debt That Isnt There
description: GREETINGS, unhappy homeowners! Heres some wonderful news:

title: Loss Sets Back the Yankees as the Orioles Tie in the East
description: TORONTO  When the Yankees loaded the bases with nobody out in the first inning Saturday, it looked as if they might cruise to an easy victory and then sit back over dinner and wait for the result from Texas. A Yankees win and a Los Angeles Angels loss to the Rangers in Arlington later on would have clinched a wild-card berth for the Yankees.

title: The Lowest Fare? Ask the Crowd
description: TRAVEL search sites have made it easy to find the lowest available fares ever since the Webs early Jurassic period, when pioneers like Expedia and Travelocity opened shop. Many others, like Kayak and Hipmunk, have since joined in.

title: Lightening the Load for Manufacturers
description: SHIPPING pallets, those slatted platforms that fill warehouses, are intended to move heavy loads, not people.

title: Model-Morphosis | Yulia Terentieva at Vivienne Westwood
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2013 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Yulia Terentieva of Oui Management before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Val Garland for M.A.C. and hair by Sam McKnight for Pantene.

title: Repair the Infrastructure, or Pay More Later
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Wealthy, a 28 Percent Solution
description: EVERYONE knows that Americas tax code is a mess, yet despite considerable talk when elections come around, weve done nothing substantial to fix it. What is odd is that there is broad agreement on what should be done. We should strive to get the lowest possible tax rates on the broadest base, as five well-known conservative economists put it recently.

title: As Money Pours Down, Its No Wonder That Stocks Are Up
description: THE markets are getting plenty of help from the worlds big central banks. Will it be enough to keep the current rally going?

title: Washington, in Three Acts
description: The Nationals ascent has broken a stretch of mostly disappointing baseball from teams in the capital. But even the worst squads had their own appeal, with youngsters following, and collecting, from home.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Sept. 30
description: Just a few days before the first presidential debate, surrogates from both campaigns will join the Sunday talk shows to weigh in on what Mitt Romney and President Obama need to do to reach voters.

title: Reader Comments on Women Leaders
description: My Sunday column  is a painful reminder that women leaders arent necessarily any better for women than men leaders.

title: After 8 Touchdowns, West Virginias Smith Is His Only Critic
description: MORGANTOWN, W.Va.  By his estimation, Geno Smith had erred. He had six incompletions. West Virginia did not score on its first drive and stalled, briefly, on others. He forced passes when he could have scrambled. Generally, he could have made better decisions.

title: The Daily Shoe | Jean Paul Gaultier
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

description: A 75-year-old Manhattan man was struck and killed as he was walking near Columbia University by a driver who fled the scene, the police said on Saturday.

title: Car Talk
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Even when my cars battery kicked the bucket in the middle of a raging snowstorm with no notice, I still swore my allegiance to her (yes, its a her). Seemingly spontaneous flat tires, a Report for service now gauge that lit up randomly, causing me to spend an unusual amount of time at the dealership service center  no matter. We were partners in my quest to See Everything Within Driving Distance. She has delivered me and my kids to emergency rooms in the middle of the night, and borne the burden of a houseful of camp paraphernalia as I drove my kids to camp.

title: So Far Unfruitful, Fusion Project Faces a Frugal Congress
description: For more than 50 years, physicists have been eager to achieve controlled fusion, an elusive goal that could potentially offer a boundless and inexpensive source of energy.

title: Golfs Dynamic Duos
description: The Ryder Cup team of Phil Mickelson and Keegan Bradley electrified Medinah Country Club with three consecutive wins in the team competition on Friday and Saturday, calling to mind earlier noteworthy partners in the golfs long history.

title: A Familiar Face Returns, Heating Up the Sheriffs Race in Webb County
description: LAREDO The Rick Flores who sat alone in a supermarket parking lot last week and waited for a handful of supporters to wave campaign signs with him bore little resemblance to the Rick Flores of old the swashbuckling, 10-gallon-hat-donning Texas border sheriff whose quips to his critics were as sharp as the creases in his uniform.

title: Parents Pitch In to Help Schools Face Budget Cuts
description: The space used to be a vacant field, sandwiched between Casis Elementary School and a parking lot.

title: Texas Traffic Policy for the Future, Powered by the Graying of Its Baby Boomers
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Old Houston Salutes an Irreverent Heart Surgeon
description: Every once in a while, there are moments in Houston that provide a vivid glimpse of the city that was  that aggressively entrepreneurial, insanely individualistic and relentlessly optimistic place of lore. Such a moment was visible the night of Sept. 18, when the Texas Heart Institute celebrated its 50th anniversary by honoring its founder, Denton A. Cooley, whose name is almost always accompanied by the description world-famous heart surgeon.

title: Twins Cut Ties With Japanese Shortstop
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Flush with revenue from the opening of Target Field in 2010, the Minnesota Twins made a major foray into the Japanese market that winter, signing the flashy shortstop Tsuyoshi Nishioka from the Chiba Lotte Marines.

title: Eugene D. Genovese, Historian of South, Dies at 82
description: Eugene D. Genovese, a prizewinning historian who challenged conventional thinking on slavery in the American South by stressing its paternalism as he traveled a personal intellectual journey from Marxism to conservative Catholicism, died on Wednesday at his home in Atlanta. He was 82.

title: More Suspicious Voter Forms Are Found
description: MIAMI  The number of Florida counties reporting suspicious voter registration forms connected to Strategic Allied Consulting, the firm hired by the state Republican Party to sign up new voters, has grown to 10, officials said, as local election supervisors continue to search their forms for questionable signatures, addresses or other identifiers.

title: Spring Crush in Paris
description: Junya Watanabes show on Saturday morning had the kick of an energy drink. Using sports fabrics like mesh and nylon, Mr. Watanabe created a collection as simple as it was innovative, with neon-bright mini dresses and jackets with an array of zipped vents, cool shifts made from interlocking pieces of mesh and jersey, and some lovely fluted dresses with slivered insets. About 25 percent of the fabrics came from Puma for a one-time collaboration with Mr. Watanabe. (It was unclear whether the Puma pieces would be produced, but I will find out more tomorrow in the Comme des Garons showroom.)

title: Leonard Lerman, a Pioneer in DNA Study, Is Dead at 87
description: Leonard Lerman, a molecular biologist whose discovery of how to manipulate DNA was a vital preliminary step in enabling others to decipher the basic building blocks of the genetic code, died on Sept. 19 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 87.

title: Pointing the Way to Victory, One Fist Pump at a Time
description: MEDINAH, Ill.

title: A Thrilling Scene at No. 17
description: MEDINAH, Ill.  Two days before the start of the Ryder Cup, Steve Stricker was a passenger in a cart that spun out on a bank on the 17th hole, forcing him to bail out. Was it an omen?

title: Elite and Deft, Xi Aimed High Early in China
description: ZHENGDING County, China  Thirty years ago, a young government official with a plum job in Beijing made an odd request: reassignment to a poor rural area.

title: Offense Carries Bulldogs After Their Defense Fails
description: ATHENS, Ga.  Tennessee slid its protection on the offensive line toward the Georgia all-American linebacker Jarvis Jones and, all at once, Jones was trying to fend off three blockers in a triple team. Tyler Bray, the Tennessee quarterback, stood in the pocket and watched a Georgia linebacker turn a receiver loose underneath in a blown coverage, and then the scene in the Bulldogs secondary turned to mayhem as a Tennessee receiver ran wide open for another big play.

title: Cabreras 43rd Homer Carries Tigers Closer to a Division Title
description: MINNEAPOLIS  With his stocking feet propped up on his desk and the Ryder Cup broadcast on the television next to him, Detroit Tigers Manager Jim Leyland scanned the list of pitchers he had available for Saturdays afternoon game with the Minnesota Twins. Beginning with starter Justin Verlander, Leyland counted off eight names.

title: Romney Shifted Right on Energy as Presidential Politics Beckoned
description: WASHINGTON  Mitt Romney, true to his roots as the son of an auto executive, was talking about cars.

title: Land With Baseball Diamond in 1989 Movie to Grow by 24 Fields of Dreams
description: The Field of Dreams is about to get a new reality. After nearly a year of negotiations with local and state officials in Iowa, Denise and Michael Stillman expect in the coming weeks to close on their purchase of the 193-acre farm that includes the baseball diamond and home featured in Field of Dreams, the 1989 movie starring Kevin Costner.

title: Stealing Watsons Thunder With a Roaring Crowd
description: MEDINAH, Ill.  One of Bubba Watsons childhood friends, Giants kicker Lawrence Tynes, is expected to split the uprights with thousands of people screaming. So why should golfers be any different?

title: Womens Champion Cements Her Status at Grand Prix
description: There is no off-season in chess, but the past week was unusually busy, with three world-class events being held at the same time.

title: College Football Replay: Sept. 29
description: The days games included Texas A&M handing Arkansas its fourth straight loss, and Urban Meyer winning his first Big Ten game as Ohio State beat Michigan State.

title: Orioles Win, but No Celebrating Just Yet
description: BALTIMORE  As the statue of Brooks Robinson was being unveiled beyond left field, Manny Machado was in the tunnel taking batting practice. He could hear the crowds roar from beneath the concrete stands.

title: Lottery Numbers
Poll Averages Have No History of Consistent Partisan Bias
description: Presidential elections are high-stakes affairs. So perhaps it is no surprise that when supporters of one candidate do not like the message they are hearing from the polls they tend to blame the messenger.

title: For Rose and McIlroy, Ryder Cup Is Test of Stamina
description: MEDINAH, Ill.  The Europeans Justin Rose and Rory McIlroy are the only golfers on either team who will play in all five matches in the Ryder Cup. Rose and McIlroy are each 2-2 heading into Sundays concluding singles session.

title: Efforts in Integration: Losing Familiarity for Stimulation
After Decades in Institutions, a Bumpy Journey to a New Life
description: MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga.  On his last day in the state hospital, Wally Burns pulled on a new pair of plaid shorts and a neatly pressed polo shirt. He savored a final meal of eggs and grits, apple juice and milk, toast and a sweet doughnut stick.

title: Corrections: September 30, 2012
description: NEW YORK

title: Rays Roll On, but Their Time Is Running Short
description: CHICAGO  The Tampa Bay Rays lineup, posted in the clubhouse before Saturdays game, included a quote attributed to William Wallace: Every man dies. Not every man lives.

title: Liberty Eliminated From W.N.B.A. Playoffs
description: NEWARK  The Libertys defense stifled the Connecticut Sun for the first three quarters of Saturdays W.N.B.A. Eastern Conference semifinal game. But in the fourth quarter, Sun center Tina Charles showed why she was the leagues most valuable player this season.

title: Colleen Flanagan, Michael Johnson
description: Colleen Elizabeth Flanagan and Michael James Johnson were married Saturday in Hamden, Conn. Gov. Dannel P. Malloy of Connecticut officiated at the New Haven Country Club.

title: Oroma Homa Mpi and Orville St. Christopher Reynolds
description: Oroma Homa Mpi and First Lt. Orville St. Christopher Reynolds are to be married Sunday by the Rev. Jeffrey S. Browning at the Lutheran Church of the Resurrection in Garden City, N.Y.

title: Micki Howard, Phillip MacNaughton
description: Micki OBrien Howard and John Phillip MacNaughton Jr. were married Monday at St. Ritas Church in Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Daniel N. Gee, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Alexis Kay, Brian Levine
description: Alexis Britt Kay, the daughter of Robin J. Kay and Kenneth M. Kay of New York, was married Saturday evening to Dr. Brian Allan Levine, the son of Anita L. Levine of Babylon, N.Y., and the late Irwin M. Levine. Rabbi Dr. David M. Posner officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title: Shilla Kim-Parker, Zeev Krieger
description: Shilla Kim-Parker and David Zeev Krieger were married Saturday at the Won Dharma Center, a Korean Buddhist temple in Claverack, N.Y. Kate Wattson Wagle, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated. Dr. Neil Wattson Wagle, who also became a Universal Life minister, participated in the ceremony, which incorporated Jewish, Korean and Christian traditions.

title: Jessie Schweller, David Kuhn
description: Jessie Amanda Schweller and David Paul Kuhn were married Saturday at Montgomery Place, a historic estate in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y. Rabbi Clifford E. Librach officiated.

title: Meagan McArthur, John Neal
description: Meagan Brianna McArthur and John Patrick Neal were married Saturday evening at St. Marys Cathedral in Austin, Tex. The Very Rev. Albert Laforet Jr., a Roman Catholic priest and the cathedrals rector, performed the ceremony.

title: Adrian Hinman, John Edenbach
description: Adrian Katharine Hinman, a daughter of Emilie K. Hinman and George R. Hinman of Greenwich, Conn., was married Saturday to John Nicholas Edenbach, a son of Joan K. Edenbach of Middletown, R.I., and the late Charles A. Edenbach Jr. The Rev. Mary B. Johnstone, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Kay Chapel in Newport, R.I.

title: Sasha Gsovski, Blake Albohm
description: Sasha Rachel Alexandra Gsovski was married Saturday to Blake Courtland Albohm in Aquinnah, Mass., on Marthas Vineyard. Megan E. Hughes, a friend of the couple who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, officiated at the Gay Head Light.

title: Joan Norton, Jeff Felton
description: Dr. Joan Lynch Norton and John Edward Felton IV were married Saturday at St. Stephen Roman Catholic Church in Kingsville, Md. The Very Rev. Michael J. Carroll performed the ceremony.

description: In Tehelka, Sai Manish writes about the mismanagement of natural disasters in the northeastern state of Sikkim. One year after an earthquake wreaked havoc in the state, a deluge has caused landslides, landing yet another blow of devastation. The author argues that the lack of timely government intervention has intensified the effect of such disasters. He writes:

title: In Defense of the Doormat Dad
description: If Benjamin, my 2-year-old, has a meltdown because were leaving a park, I let him stay longer. If he wants to jump on our kiddie trampoline until 11 p.m. instead of going to bed, I indulge him. If he insists on taking a 60-minute bath, I sit there beside the tub.

title: Greek-Spanish Pension Split Illustrates Europes Dilemma
description: The differences in approach could not be more distinct  or telling.

title: A Public Service Reminder: Simpson-Bowles Is Terrible
description: Nate Silver gives Mitt Romney a 16 percent chance of winning, and gives Republicans a 22 percent chance of taking the Senate. A month is an eternity in politics, it aint over until its over, yada yada, but the main suspense right now is whether the Democrats can retake the House  Im eagerly waiting for Nates take.

title: Tales of Hope and Regret Test the Standard of Time
description: I cant wait for the future, Joe.

title: Hotel Transylvania Leads Weekend Box Office
description: Pent-up demand for a new animated movie and a long and lively marketing campaign powered Sonys Hotel Transylvania to No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend. The film, which cost at least $85 million to make, outperformed expectations to take in about $43 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. (An elated Sony e-mailed reporters on Sunday morning to announce a monster hit on our hands!!!!!!)

title: Turning Up the Volume on Global Poverty
description: Cranked-up guitars and sobering statistics shared a Central Park audience of more than 60,000 people on Saturday at the Global Citizen Festival, a five-hour concert on the Great Lawn devoted to ending extreme poverty worldwide. The concert was also webcast internationally.

title: Ryan Sees Media Bias in Campaign Coverage

Ryan of Wisconsin, suggested on Sunday that part of the problem might be in getting the message past the mainstream news media.

title: A Mockumentary Pulls In Real Players
description: TORONTO  During the Jan. 3 broadcast of ABCs World News Tonight Diane Sawyer introduced a heartbreaking segment from the Iowa caucus, featuring a distraught voter being consoled by Mitt Romney. Save the small families of America, she begged through tears, as Mr. Romney hugged her and promised he would.

title: Debates Can Shift a Races Outcome, but Its Not Easy
description: WASHINGTON  History shows that candidates have different ways to score through presidential debates: the forceful put-down, the surprising show of skill, the opponents fumble, superior post-debate tactics.

description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Teixeira Is Set to Rejoin the Yankees

title: Disgraced Chinese Officials Son Defends Him
description: BEIJING  The youngest son of Bo Xilai, the former Communist Party leader who is expected to be tried on a wide range of criminal charges, has released a statement defending his father as upright in his beliefs and devoted to duty.

description: Six major American banks were hit in a wave of computer attacks last week, by a group claiming Middle Eastern ties, that caused Internet blackouts and delays in online banking.

title: As Kenyan Forces Press Militants Across Border, a Church Is Attacked Back Home

title: Purveyors of Office Space and Lively Arts
description: One recent Monday morning the pianist Taka Kigawa took his place at a keyboard in the lobby of 1 Liberty Plaza, an office building near Wall Street, and worked through Debussys Preludes, Book II. A small audience  perhaps a dozen people at first, more than 100 an hour later  sat at tables or stood on the periphery, sipping coffee, listening to Mr. Kigawa and watching the parade of businessmen and tourists drift past the large window to the pianists left.

title: Rebecca Faces Broadway Postponement
description: 4:35 p.m. | Updated An executive involved with the Broadway musical Rebecca said on Sunday that the show would be postponed because its lead producers were unable to close a $4.5 million gap in its $12 million budget.

title: Right-Wing Extremists Popularity Rising Rapidly in Greece
description: ATHENS  The video, which went viral in Greece last month, shows about 40 burly men, led by Giorgos Germenis, a lawmaker with the right-wing Golden Dawn party, marching through a night market in the town of Rafina demanding that dark-skinned merchants show permits.

His parents  the composer John Adams and the photographer Deborah OGrady  met while working at the orchestra. More recently the younger Mr. Adams, 26, has been living in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, where he pursues his wide-ranging interests, including playing bass in new-music groups and creating sound designs for multimedia works.

title: Using Fame to Shine a Spotlight on the Suffering
description: No network, including PBS, is above using celebrities as audience bait in the interests of making a difficult documentary subject a little more commercial.

title: Being Where the Interceptions Are
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When linebacker Michael Boley produced one interception in each of the Giants first three games, the obvious common denominator was that he was in the right place at the right time. Not as readily apparent was the depth of understanding, attention to detail and level of experience that led Boley, an eight-year veteran, to be ideally positioned for each play.

title: Romneys Faith May Help in Idaho, Where He Doesnt Need It
description: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of each states political landscape and how its changing. Here is a look at Idaho, the Gem State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with David Adler, director of the Andrus Center for Public Policy at Boise State University.

title: A Rout Leaves the Jets Hurting and Cursing
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Jets season has deteriorated into a tragicomic mix of fluky injuries and M.R.I. tubes, of turnovers and incompletions, of hoping for the best but assuming the worst.

title: A Vote for Reason
For Yankees, a Playoff Berth and Unfinished Business
description: TORONTO  Two hours before the Yankees took the field Sunday afternoon, the stereo in the visitors clubhouse at Rogers Centre blared an old De La Soul tune called The Magic Number, but few of the players even noticed the significance.

title: Following an Artists Footsteps in the Sand
description: The Spanish director Isaki Lacuesta clearly set out to create an art movie with The Double Steps, a self-conscious exercise set in Africa, largely by swapping one set of cinematic conventions for another. The movie won top honors at 2011 San Sebastin Film Festival (and feels very much as if it was made for the festival circuit). It hinges on an American-born artist and writer, Franois Augiras (1925-71), who lived and worked in the Sahara and who covered an abandoned army bunker in frescoes, hoping, as some introductory text puts it, to make it the Sistine Chapel of the desert. Today, the on-screen text continues, some travelers are preparing to find, finally, Augirass lost frescoes.

title: Putting Philippine Justice on Trial
description: The miscarriage of justice recounted in Give Up Tomorrow, filmed over six years, is so comprehensive as to be disorienting. Paco Larraaga, a Filipino-Spanish student from a privileged family who was convicted in 1999 as the ringleader of a 1997 double murder and rape of two sisters in the Philippines, was, for starters, miles away on a different island when the crimes took place, according to 35 witnesses.

title: World Mind Sports Games in France
description: One of the arts of defense is trying to make declarer think you hold one hand when you actually have something very different.

description: HBO has taken heat over the years for the perceived arrogance of the slogan Its not TV, its HBO. But now its at least a little bit true. Hidden away on HBO Go, the online video site for the cable channels subscribers, are four shows that arent TV, although they might have been.

title: Winners Named for Dayton Literary Peace Prize
description: The novelist Andrew Krivak, who wrote The Sojourn (Bellevue Literary Press), and Adam Hochschild, the author of To End All Wars (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt), have won the 2012 Dayton Literary Peace Prize for fiction and nonfiction. The runners-up are Ha Jin, for Nanjing Requiem (Pantheon Books), and Annia Ciezadlo for Day of Honey (Free Press).

title: Cool and Complex: Many Moving Parts Running Smoothly Askew
description: The audience gave such lusty applause to all four offerings in Fall for Dances program on Saturday night at City Center that it sounded as if for each piece the theater was populated solely by the performers friends and family. Afterward, however, while leaving the theater, you could hear people discussing ardently which items had worked for them, which theyd tolerated and which they hadnt cared for. I was relieved to find that I wasnt the only person who hadnt loved everything.

title: Orioles Party Is Put Off, but Only for a Few Hours
description: BALTIMORE  Moments after the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Boston Red Sox, 6-3, on Sunday afternoon, the players stood in shallow right field.

Michele Mariotti, conducting in his Met debut, tore into the prelude, honoring the precedent set by Yannick Nzet-Sguin when the production was new, in 2009.

Cuomo was poised to approve hydraulic fracturing in several struggling New York counties, his administration is reversing course and starting the regulatory process over, garnering praise from environmental groups and stirring anger among industry executives and upstate landowners.

description: Photos from the festival at City Center.

title: Rangers Lock In Playoff Spot and Help Others, Too

But anxiety was beginning to build at the Ballpark here, and after the Rangers dropped the first game of a doubleheader Sunday, the calendar couldnt flip fast enough for them.

title: Fostering Tech Talent in Schools
description: SEATTLE  Leandre Nsabi, a senior at Rainier Beach High School here, received some bluntly practical advice from an instructor recently.

title: Analysts Weigh In on Getting Anthony and Stoudemire in Sync

For the Knicks, the big question will be whether the added experience will add up to something special.

title: Reubin Andres, an Advocate of Weight Gain, Dies at 89
description: Dr. Reubin Andres, a gerontologist who advanced the study of diabetes but gained his widest attention for arguing controversially that weight gain in older people increases longevity, died on Sept. 23 at his home in Baltimore. He was 89.

title: Eddie Bert, Jazz Trombone Player, Dies at 90
description: Eddie Bert, a jazz trombonist whose virtuosity and versatility allowed him to fit comfortably in a wide range of musical contexts, from the infectious swing of Benny Goodman to the wild experimentation of Charles Mingus, died on Thursday at his home in Danbury, Conn. He was 90.

title: Kodak Plans to End Line of Inkjet Printers
description: As part of its bankruptcy reorganization, Eastman Kodak is planning to wind down sales of consumer inkjet printers next year, products that were once called a crucial part of its turnaround effort.

title: Video: Meg Whitman on Fixing Hewlett-Packard
description: Few leadership attributes are as important as clear self-definition and a strong sense of direction. Meg Whitman, whose company I wrote about in Sundays New York Times, is among the clearest. In this video interview, she explains everything she needs to tell Wall Street at this Wednesdays analyst meeting.

title: Tired Cries of Bias Dont Help Romney
description: In the last few days, conservatives have become agitated about Mitt Romneys drop-off in the polls. So did they think the stumble was because of the ill-fated 47 percent slip of the lip, or the hasty effort to gain a political edge after the death of an American ambassador in Libya, or more problematically, a campaign that cant seem to stop pratfalling no matter what the news?

title: California Is First State to Ban Gay Cure for Minors
description: California has become the first state to ban the use for minors of disputed therapies to overcome homosexuality, a step hailed by gay rights groups across the country that say the therapies have caused dangerous emotional harm to gay and lesbian teenagers.

title: Soft Sales Crimp Outlook for Electric Cars
description: PARIS  Many auto executives were not that enthusiastic about battery-powered cars at their outset, and now that sales of electric vehicles made by Tesla and Renault have been disappointing, some carmakers are playing down the technology.
